Caving in to pressure from both parties, President Bush announced that he would break precedent and allow his closest foreign policy advisor,Condoleezza Rice,to testity in Public and under oath about the administration's actions before and after the 2001 terror attack.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL PRAISES TAIWAN RELATIONS ACT BEFORE ITS 25TH ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: Taiwan would rather the United States keep its 25-year-old Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) intact than revise it, because attempts to do so could led to "unexpected results, " an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Thursday.

With 10 days to go before the act's 25th anniversary, Ling-hu Jung-da, the deputy director for the Department of North American Affairs, said the act has stabilized relations between Taipei and Washington and has prevented the United States from tilting the power balance in Beijing's favor in the last 25 years. He added that itis not out of date in any way.

The act, passed in 1979 after Washington switched its diplomatic ties from Taipei to Beijing, virtually ensures Taiwan the best possible treatment from the United States next to formal diplomatic ties, according to Ling-hu.

Noting that some pro-Taiwan U.S. congressmen tried in vain to push for a Taiwan Security Enhancement Act in 1999, Ling-hu said that any attempts to revise the TRA might backlash and lead to results not intended by the initiators. Therefore, he went on, Taipei prefers "not to fix it if it is not broken."
Actually, Ling-hu said, the TRA gives the U.S. administration considerable leeway in dealing with Taiwan, and can accommodate most attempts on the part of the Congress to promote bilateral ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: MISSILE COMMAND INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: A new missile command was inaugurated Thursday under the Ministry of National Defense (MND), according to a statement released that day by the MND.

The command, founded on the basis of the Air Defense Missile Command under the Army, is to be led by an officer with the rank of lieutenant general, although it is currently headed by Maj. Gen. Ku Feng-tai, the incumbent commander of the Air Defense Missile Command.
The upgrading of the missile command is a step toward strengthening the country's air-defense system, which consists mainly of U.S.-made Patriot missiles.
Taiwan has deployed three batteries of Patriot advanced capability-II missiles around Taipei and is seeking another six batteries for the defense of central and southern Taiwan.

Besides the missile-defense system, the command will also control the domestically manufactured Tien Kung (sky bow) anti-aircraft missiles and the Hsiung Feng surface-to-ship missiles deployed around the island's coastline, as well as other types of missiles.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA PRESIDENT HONORED BY JAPANESE UNIVERSITY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 1 (CNA) (By Perry Hsieh & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Japan's Waseda University conferred an honorary doctorate in science Thursday on Lee Yuan-tseh, president of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest research institution.
Katsuhiko Shirai, president of Waseda University, bestowed the honor on Lee in a ceremony held at the university's campus to coincide with the commencement of the university's freshmen.
In the citation, the Japanese university authorities describe Lee as a representative of the Asian scientific field and one of the world's most prestigious scientists.
Lee is the 83rd recipient of an honorary doctorate from Waseda University.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER INSISTS ON ROC SOVEREIGNTY OVER SPRATLY ISLANDS

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien reiterated Thursday the Republic of China's sovereignty over the Spratly Islands and said that his ministry is willing to help the Foreign Ministry handle disputes surrounding the coral reef island group in the South China Sea.

Claiming that the Spratly Islands are part of the ROC's traditional territory, regardless of whether the issue is judged from the historic, geographic or international law viewpoints, Yu said that the Ministry of Interior (MOI) will help the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) resolve disputes arising from the island group.
Yu said that the MOFA is fully in charge of such matters but added that the MOI is ready to give a helping hand at any time.

His remarks came after Vietnam issued a warning a day earlier that Taiwan's construction of a house raised on stilts on one of the islands infringes upon Vietnam's territorial sovereignty and damages peace and stability in the region.
The disputed Spratly Islands are claimed by Taiwan, mainland China, the Philippines and Malaysia, in addition to Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. APPROVES SALES OF LONG-RANGE EARLY WARNING RADAR TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Pentagon has notified the U.S. Congress of the sale to Taiwan of two long-range early warning radar systems capable of detecting ballistic and cruise missiles, even though the Legislative Yuan has only approved the budget for one of the items.

Legislator Tang Huo-sheng of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said Thursday that the Ministry of National Defense actually wants to buy two of the radar sets. He accused it of using an clever method to make sure the purchase is passed by the legislature and said it will in the future try to present the budget for another radar system to the legislature.
Tang, who is opposed to the purchase, claims that the purchase of the long-range early warning radar is no more than Taiwan serving as a "doorkeeper" for the United States.

According to Tang, if the United States wants to sell two Ultra High Frequency long-range early warning radar systems, it should "have to make it cheaper for Taiwan, otherwise, Taiwan cannot afford the purchase."

In view of the missile threat from mainland China, the MND has been building up its anti-missile capability. In addition to the purchase of batteries of Patriot III anti-missile systems, it has also requested the purchase of the long-range early warning radar systems.

The military discussed the necessity of buying the 10-story-high radar system during the process, which some have claimed could be an easy target in battle, but went ahead with purchase preparations because of the fact that with its range of 3,000 kilometers, it can monitor as far as Inner Mongolia and Xinjiang on the mainland, giving Taiwan's air defenses more time to respond in the event of a missile attack.

The MND plans to have one early warning radar installation in southern Taiwan and another in northern Taiwan, but this plan has raised questions from legislators, who feel that the combat needs of Taiwan military only requires a range of 800 km.
They also questioned the cost of the systems, claiming that it is a burden that Taiwan cannot afford.
Faced with the stiff opposition from legislators, the MND had to make an estimated budget of US$800 million, appropriation of which will begin this year.
The full radar package also includes missile warning centers, facilities to house and maintain the radar equipment and training programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SPONSOR A SERIES OF APEC PROGRAMS

TEXT.P: Taiwan will sponsor a series of meetings under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in the coming months, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

First of all, the MOFA said, Taiwan will host the APEC International Youth Camp which is aimed at inspiring youth creativity, encouraging young people to dedicate themselves to community services and boosting youth exchanges among APEC member economies.

The youth camp program is divided into two stages. In the first stage from March through May, a creative design contest is being held through the Internet. In the second stage, a seminar will be held in Taipei from Aug. 1-6.

Meanwhile, Taiwan will hold the first meeting of the APEC Health Task Force from April 26 through April 27 to discuss various cooperative programs in public health and communicable disease prevention. The task force was set up at the suggestion of Department of Health Minister Chen Chien-jen last spring when Taiwan and several other Asian countries were gripped by the severe acute respiratory syndromes (SARS).
The APEC Business Advisory Council will hold its annual conference in Taipei May 12-14, with the participation of senior executives from APEC countries and APEC Secretariat.

MOFA officials said Minister of Education Huang Jung-tsun will head the Taiwan delegation to attend the third APEC education ministers meeting to be held in Chile April 29. Taiwan and Chile will present a joint report on the study of English and other languages at the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GRANTS TRADE PREFERENCE TO 50 LESS-DEVELOPED NATIONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) announced Thursday that Taiwan will grant preferential trade treatment to 50 less-developed nations by making 141 product items free of import tariffs.

Chien Liang-chi, director-general of the MOF's Department of Customs Administration, said that the move is a means of carrying out promises made prior to Taiwan's admission to the World Trade Organization in January 2002.

The products named, including coffee, leatherware and textiles, must come from the 50 least-developed countries as listed by the United Nations on its Web site April 1, including Afghanistan, Bangladesh and East Timor, Chien noted.
If a product is manufactured in more than one country, the country that is eligible to enjoy preferential treatment should obtain not less than 50 percent of its value, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN BEATS SINGAPORE WITH LATE GOAL IN WORLD CUP QUALIFIER

TEXT.P: Hosts Singapore lost to Japan 2-1 in their 2006 World Cup Asian group qualifying soccer match Wednesday night.

Naohiro Takahara put the visitors ahead in the 34th minute with a low shot before Indra Sahdan Daud equalized in the second half. But the Lions' hopes of holding on for a draw were dashed as Toshiya Fujita struck home the winner with nine minutes remaining.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. FORENSIC EXPERT RECOGNIZES CIB PROFESSIONALISM

TEXT.P: Dr. Cyril Wecht, an acclaimed U.S. forensic pathologist who visited Taiwan earlier this week to help investigate the March 19 assassination attempt on President Chen Shui-bian, sent a letter to the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) Thursday in recognition of its forensic investigative team's professionalism.
Wecht said in his letter that he was very grateful for the team's kindness and the hospitality extended to himself and his two partners.

"Without your courtesy and support, I might have been unable to carry out the forensic examination of the March 19 shooting, " Wecht said in his letter to Cheng Hsiao-kuei, the CIB forensic department chief.

Wecht praised the CIB forensic department for its speedy completion of forensic examinations of the crime scene and its gathering of evidence in a highly professional manner. He asked Cheng to convey his admiration and gratitude to her CIB colleagues for their assistance and cooperation during his visit.
Wecht also presented an autographed copy of his book "Mortal Evidence" to Cheng as a gift.

Wecht and two other U.S. forensic scientists -- Michael G. Haag, a forensic firearms expert with U.S. Forensic Science Consultants, Inc. and Timothy Palmbach, a crime scene investigative specialist -- went to the southern city of Tainan Monday to visit the scene of the shooting. They also visited the Chi Mei Medical Center, where Chen and Vice President Annette Lu, both of whom were slightly injured in the shooting, were taken for treatment.

The trio made the whirlwind visit to Taiwan at the request of Dr. Henry Lee, a world-renowned Chinese-American forensic scientist who was invited by State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa to assist in the forensic investigation into the election-eve shooting.
Because of his busy schedule, however, Lee cannot come to Taiwan until April 13.

After their examination tour, the three U.S. forensic experts said they would not draw any conclusion until they have conducted further studies in their U.S. laboratory. Lee will bring their study results to Taiwan later this month.
Chen suffered a 2 cm wide, 11 cm long wound when a bullet grazed his lower abdomen, while another bullet scratched Lu's right knee.

After viewing photos of the wounds provided by the CIB, and with the information provided by the Chi Mei hospital staff, Wecht said he initially determined that it was very likely a fresh gunshot wound.
Chen and Lu were shot while riding in an open-top jeep on a street in Tainan during the last day of campaigning for the March 20 presidential election.

Chen narrowly defeated his sole contender -- Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan -- in the bitterly fought race. Lien contested the result, claiming that the election-eve shooting unfairly led to a swelling of sympathy votes for Chen. Lien has filed a lawsuit to nullify the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL CHARTER PLANES TO TAKE OFF FROM TAITUNG AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Taitung's Fong Nien Airport in eastern Taiwan is scheduled to expand its runway in June to allow international charter planes to the facility, the head of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Thursday.

Traffic issues have long caused a bottleneck in the development of Taitung County's tourism industry, but CAA Director-General Chang Kuo-cheng said that the administration will invest NT$200 million (US$5.98 million) in expanding the runway there to facilitate international charter flight operations.

Taitung airport used to be for military use and its runway and taxiway are based on military standards, said Chang, adding that the width of the runway will be expanded by seven meters on both sides, making it 45 meters wide, but the original runway's length of 2,438 meters will remain unchanged.

In addition, extra land needs to be expropriated for construction of a second taxiway, making the distance between the runway and taxiway much wider. This will upgrade the safety index and enable jumbo jets to take off and land, Chang continued.
However, he added that assistance with the project from the Taitung county government and the Ministry of National Defense will also be required.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY DENIES DEVELOPING OFFENSIVE MISSILES

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense (MNA) denied Thursday that the country is developing mid-range missiles capable of hitting targets in mainland China.

Dismissing as "groundless" a report carried in the latest issue of the London-based Jane's Missiles and Rockets magazine that Taiwan has a tentative plan to produce surface-to-surface missiles with an eye to attacking mainland China, MND spokesman Huang Shuey-sheng said offensive weapons are not an option for Taiwan, which employs a defense strategy of "deterring attacks with impregnable defenses."

The magazine said in an unattributed story that Taiwan has a tentative plan to produce 30 mid-range and 120 short-range surface-to-surface missiles capable of hitting targets as far as 2,000 km and 1,000 km away, respectively, in response to the mounting missile threat from Beijing.
Earlier this year, Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min said his ministry is building a low-level missile defense system, with two-thirds of the missiles used being produced domestically.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.S. Optimism Is Tested Again After Ambush Kills 4 in Iraq.
An American general said Wednesday in Baghdad that despite an uptick in local engagements, the overall area of operations remains relatively stable with negligible impact on the coalition' s ability to continue progress in governance, economic development, and restoration of essential services.
Hours before the daily press briefing, four American civilians were dragged from their vehicle and mutilated in Falluja on Wednesday.
Wall Street Journal: Shell Estimate Ignored Warnings.
Royal Dutch/Shell Group planners warned their bosses as early as 2000 that the oil giant risked disappointing financial markets with overly optimistic assumptions about exploration-and- production projects around the world, according to internal Shell documents.
The warnings, contained in a June 2000 internal presentation, are part of a body of company documents warning at least Shell's top managers of deep-seated problems emerging at the Anglo- Dutch oil giant, according to a person familiar with the situation.
The report is the latest in a series of documents to emerge that indicate senior Shell executives were warned about serious problems at the company long before they disclosed them publicly.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO IMMEDIATE MILITARY CRISIS IN TAIWAN STRAIT: U.S. ADMIRAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 1 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The United States has been closely monitoring the situation in the Taiwan Strait and there are no signs of an immediate military crisis there, according to Adm. Thomas B. Fargo, commander of the U.S. Pacific Command.

Testifying at a public hearing in the U.S. Congress Wednesday, Fargo said that there is no danger of an imminent military conflict across the strait, but pointed out that miscalculation by either Taiwan or mainland China could easily lead to a destructive crisis.

The Taiwan Strait has become the most sensitive spot in the region and the U.S. military has maintained a close watch on the area since campaigns for Taiwan's March 20 presidential election kicked off, Fargo noted.

He added that the U.S. Pacific Command is ready to help Taiwan defend itself at any time according to orders issued by President George W. Bush under the policy framework set up by the U.S. government's "one China" policy, the three joint communiques signed by Washington and Beijing and the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA).

Asked whether the United States will move to deal with a military attack by mainland China against Taiwan should tensions between the two sides persist in the face of a continued military buildup by the mainland, Fargo said that the U.S. Pacific Command forces remain on high alert at all times because cross-strait peace and stability is of maximum importance to Washington.

Fargo declined to say whether he feels Taiwan will declare independence but added that the United States has an obligation to help Taiwan boost its defensive capabilities in conjunction with the TRA and that this is what it is doing now.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE CHIEF: PROBE INTO SHOOTING OF PRESIDENT UNBIASED

TEXT.P: It is out of the question that any police leader could skew the direction of the investigation into the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian, Criminal Investigation Bureau Director Ho You-yi claimed Thursday.

In a response to opposition calls for him to withdraw from the investigation because of his alleged relationship with the president, the chief of the country's detectives said forensic examination and identification is a highly developed science in which only evidence has a voice, and any attempts to steer a criminal investigation regardless of the evidence are doomed to fail.

Noting that three U.S. forensic experts have conducted an independent investigation into the case at the commission of State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa, Ho said that his bureau could not hog the investigation and is not in a position to meddle with its outcome.
He said his office is more than willing to exchange views with any lawmakers and forensic experts who question the work of the police in the investigation.
Meanwhile the National Security Bureau (NSB) denied Thursday that it was trying to lead the probe of the case.
An anonymous bureau official said the NSB is the country's supreme intelligence collecting agency and that the investigation of crimes is not in its bailiwick.
He denied an opposition lawmaker's claim that the NSB had called a conference of investigators involved in the case.

Also Thursday, two more women who were present at the scene of the March 19 shooting in Tainan according to TV news film, reported to police Thursday that they did not see anything unusual prior to the shooting.
Their appearance brought the number of people identified at the scene when the shooting took place to 60.
There are still some 40 people who appear on the TV tape that have not been accounted for, according to police.

DOC.HEADLINE: YEAR-END LEGISLATIVE ELECTION MOVING INTO POLITICAL LIMELIGHT

TEXT.P: Legislators of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) are united and are unlikely to change their stance, despite the alliance's defeat in the March 20 presidential election, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday.
Wang made the remarks as the topic of the year-end legislative election quietly moves onto the political scene in the wake of the presidential election.

At present, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is the largest political party in the legislature, but the KMT and the PFP between them still enjoy a slight edge over the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), in the 225-seat legislature. Both Wang and Legislative Yuan Vice President P.K. Chiang are also KMT vice chairmen.

The DPP, basking in its latest victory after winning 50.12 percent of the votes in the March 20 presidential election, is already eyeing the year-end legislative elections as crucial to gaining a stable legislative majority.

Reports have claimed that the DPP is trying to lure some of the KMT legislators who have identified with the DPP's promotion of a "Taiwan identity" into its fold in order to undermine the strength of the opposition camp.
Wang said that despite this, the opposition lawmakers have their hearts firmly set and are unlikely to change their allegiance.
On the possible course of the "pan-blue alliance" in the wake of the presidential election, Wang said that the cooperation mechanism will continue.
In nominating legislators for the December legislative polls, the alliance will give priority to incumbents before nominating new candidates, he said.
Wang denied reports that the DPP is trying to lure him because it expects a mass defection to the DPP fold if he were to take the lead.
Wang, who concurrently serves as a KMT vice chairman and campaign manager of the "pan-blue alliance, " has been the focus of keen attention since the election.

Known to have a close relationship with former President Lee Teng-hui, Wang said that he was unaffected by the outcome of the election. Instead, he said he will maintain neutrality and promote a middle-of-the-road stance, as well as handling legislative affairs in a fair manner.

Other reports have speculated that several DPP heavyweights are interested in the legislative presidency, including DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung, Legislator Hung Chi-chang of the New Trend faction, and Legislative Whip Ker Chien-ming.
However, Hung would only say that it is still too early to talk about the battle for the legislative presidency.
He said that the most important task is for Premier Yu Shyi-kun to continue to lead the administrative team so that its performance will win the party a stable majority in the Legislature.
Meanwhile, the TSU said that it was disappointed about Wang's performance in the role of coordinator in the legislature.

Chen Chien-ming, TSU legislative whip, claimed that Wang has not played his role as a president but is mostly a KMT vice chairman. He expressed hope that the DPP and the TSU can garner over half the seats in the December elections in order to give them the chance to vie for the legislative presidency.
In response, KMT secretary-general Lin Feng-cheng said that the "pan-blue alliance" will put its weight behind Wang and that the DPP's attempt to drive a wedge into the alliance is just a "fantasy."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-ISRAEL TEMPORARY ADMISSION AGREEMENT GOES INTO EFFECT

TEXT.P: A temporary duty-free admission agreement between Taiwan and Israel went into effect Thursday, according to the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).

Israel is the first country in the Middle East to sign such an agreement with Taiwan, a move that is expected to help promote mutual economic and trade ties between the two countries, a TAITRA official said.

For political and security reasons, Israel maintains tight regulations on goods imported for trade fairs, which has been inconvenient for Taiwanese businessmen doing business there, the official continued, adding that Taiwan started negotiations with Israel on the issue in 1996, which proved futile as a result of the lack of diplomatic ties between the two sides. After lengthy negotiations, however, an agreement was signed last July that is now in effect, said the official.

Under the international temporary admission system -- the ATA Carnet -- the signatories agree to offer temporary duty-free admission of goods traded internationally for use as commercial samples, goods for presentation and professional equipment or facilities for use at trade fairs, the TAITRA official said.
Taiwan has signed similar temporary admission agreements with 25 countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PROGRESS MADE IN TAIPEI-SEOUL AIRLINKS TALKS: MOFA

TEXT.P: Negotiations on resuming direct air links between Taiwan and South Korea are still ongoing, as no concrete agreement has yet been reached, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Richard Shih said Thursday.

Shih made the remarks after Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting earlier in the day that Taiwan and South Korean officials met late last year to discuss a resumption of direct air links, which were cut off in 1992 following South Korea's switch of diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

According to Lin, the two sides are discussing the wording of a new aviation agreement. "I hope the foreign affairs ministries of the two countries can reach agreement on the wording in the final stage of talks to pave the way for a resumption of direct flight services and thus help boost bilateral tourism and commercial exchanges, " Lin said.

Asked about the MOFA's stance on Lin's statement, Shih said the MOFA is continuing talks with South Korean authorities in line with the principles of "national dignity, reciprocity and substantial interests."
Shih said both sides fully understand that a resumption of air links is critical to upgrading bilateral relations and boosting mutual interests.
"But negotiations involve many complicated issues and no concrete results have been reached so far. We are still negotiating the issue," Shih added.
Diplomatic sources said the biggest obstacle to resuming the air links lies in Seoul's reluctance to recognize Taiwan's sovereign status in the new aviation agreement for fear of offending Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN AND SOONG WILL NOT ATTEND COURT HEARING ON ELECTION ANNULMENT

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and James Soong, his running mate in the March 20 presidential election, won't appear in court Friday at the first hearing of their suit against President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng said Thursday.
Instead, Lin said, they will be represented by their attorneys.

Lien and Soong, who lost the March 20 presidential election by a slim margin have asked the Taiwan High Court to invalidate the re-election of Chen as president and Lu as vice president, citing what they claimed unfairness in the election.
Lien and Soong are not obliged to appear before the court themselves since the action is a civil case, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Butchered by the mob.
As the gunfire died down and the bodies in the vehicles burnt, the people of Fallujah (west of Baghdad) ventured out, armed with shovels, stones and a deadly hatred for the foreign occupation.
Then the people fell on the charred corpses of the American contractors, hacking and kicking and dragging them through the streets.
Financial Times: Vodafone targeted over tax avoidance.
Gordon Brown has taken on one of the biggest mobile phone operators in a dispute over unpaid tax that provides the first concrete evidence of the Treasury's crackdown on avoidance schemes.
In a dispute that may end up in the high court, Vodafone is resisting efforts by Customs & Excise to recover millions of pounds in value added tax payable on sales of pre-paid phone cards into the UK.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO REMARKABLE TAX INCREASE BEFORE YEAR-END: FINANCE MINISTER

TEXT.P: There will be no remarkable increase in taxes this year, Minister of Finance Lin Chuan said Thursday.
Lin said during a Legislative Yuan interpellation session that without public consensus, the finance ministry won't put forth any measures to raise taxes, or reform taxes in a significant manner.

In response to a legislator's question, Lin said that a commission for financial reform will introduce mid-term reform programs within one to five years to raise business taxes by 1 percent to 2 percent to accommodate financial expenditure.
Lin said that an informed public is essential, and as such, the ministry will gauge the public's reactions to any tax reforms in addition to getting the consent of the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE URGED TO RESUME REVIEW OF MAJOR ECONOMIC BILLS

TEXT.P: An official of the Executive Yuan on Thursday urged the Legislative Yuan to get back to its review work quickly.

Liu Shih-fang, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, said that the review of many major economic bills has been put on hold since the March 20 presidential election, adding that even in the heat of the campaign in the run-up to the presidential election, the legislature was not stalled.

But she said that after the election, which saw President Chen Shui-bian win by a razor-thin margin of 29,518 votes out of a total of more than 13 million votes cast, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) is only concerned about the recount of the ballots and an investigation into the election-eve shooting of President Chen.

Both President Chen and Vice Annette Lu were lightly injured during the shooting when they were riding on an open-top jeep while canvassing in Tainan, southern Taiwan, on the eve of the election. The opposition KMT-PFP ticket claimed the shooting gave Chen sympathy votes and ultimately victory.

All the committees in the legislature have deviated from their major agendas, and the review of major economic bills and general interpellations have been put on hold, a situation she said was quite "inappropriate."

She cited as an example that because of the aborted meeting of the Economic Affairs Committee in the legislature, only six out of the scheduled 28 state-owned companies' budget review has been completed.

However, according to the Budget Law, the budget reviews of the state-owned enterprises should be completed by November of the previous year. She lamented the fact that the reviews are still in the committee, and has yet to pass the second and third readings.

She also pointed out that the education committee last week only discussed the protest at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, where supporters of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" have converged for days to protest against what they perceive as an "unfair" election.

Liu asked legislators from across the party spectrum to put away their political disputes and let the judicial system solve the questions surrounding the election now that the "pan-blue alliance" has filed a lawsuit with the Taiwan High Court to nullify the election.

She urged them to concentrate on the review of major economic bills, such as the administration's five-year, NT$500 billion (US$15.1 billion) 10 New Construction Projects and a financial reconstruction bill, so as not to disappoint the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY LAUNCHES SECURITY CHECKS OF 13 BRIDGES

TEXT.P: The municipal authorities started to make security checks Thursday of 13 key bridges in Taipei, and will continue the inspections April 16 to public security.

The 13 middle- and large-sized bridges scattered across the city, such as the Peiling Bridge in the Shihlin district and the Jingmei Bridge in the Wenshan district, will be wholly or partially closed for security checks from midnight until 5: 00 a. m. each day during the period, according to a spokesman for the Department of Maintenance of the Bureau of Public Works.
Pedestrians and vehicles using the bridges or adjacent areas should proceed slowly and with caution and keep a close watch on traffic lights and maintenance facilities nearby, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG, SINGAPORE TO STRENGTHEN CULTURAL TIES

TEXT.P: Hong Kong and Singapore, both seen as keen competitors for international investors, signed a memorandum of understanding on cultural cooperation (MOU) Thursday, pledging to strengthen cultural ties.
The signing ceremony was held in Hong Kong with officials from both sides inking the documents on behalf of their governments.
The MOU is another milestone in the warm relationship between Singapore and Hong Kong, a Hong Kong government spokesman said.
"It provides a formal framework to further strengthen the current state of active cultural exchange, and promote cooperation in the fields of culture and the arts," he noted.
"Such cooperation will lead to mutual awareness, respect, understanding, harmony and friendship between the people of Singapore and Hong Kong," the spokesman added.

According to the spokesman, both governments have started to explore the activities to be carried out. These will probably include visits and joint exhibitions in the fields of culture, museums, the arts and library collections. (Stanley Cheung)

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL WOES SHOULD NOT HINDER CROSS-STRAIT TRADE TIES

TEXT.P: Two-way trade and economic exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China should go on despite the fact that President Chen Shui-bian succeeded in his re-election bid in the March 20 presidential election, according to a veteran economist and a prominent political figure.

Vincent Siew, vice chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and a former premier of the previous KMT-led government, made the remarks at a seminar Wednesday in his capacity as chairman of the Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation. Scores of experts from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the academic sector also took part.

Pointing out that cross-Taiwan Strait trade and economic cooperation is an irreversible trend amid the many challenges brought by globalization, Siew said that political disputes should not hamper bilateral exchanges on this front. He called on the two sides to engage each other in a pragmatic manner to prevent political issues from undermining mutually beneficial activities.

Chen Chung-hsin, head of the DPP's mainland affairs department, and DPP lawmaker Hung Chi-chang, said that a policy framework outlined by President Chen to deal with cross-strait exchanges has covered the trade and economic fields and they contended that it is better now to focus on concrete issues, such as allowing mainland Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan and opening free cargo transport.

Juan Ming, a political dissident from mainland China who now serves as a guest professor at Tamkang University, said that he is in favor of Siew's idea of setting up a cross-strait common market. He said he believes that Taiwan-mainland trade and economic issues can be dealt with under such a mechanism without touching on the "one China" dispute.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 1, or the 12th day of the leap second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1572: The Dutch War for Independence from Spain begins.
1578: William Harvey, British physician and anatomist who discovered the circulation of blood, is born.
1815: Prince Otto Eduard Leopold von Bismarck, Prussian statesman and first chancellor of the German Empire, is born.
1908: Japan puts into practice a six-year compulsory primary education system.
1924: Adolf Hitler is sentenced by a court to five years in jail for high treason. He was released on Dec. 20.
1924: The Republic of China's Central News Agency is established in Canton by the ruling Kuomintang.
1930: Yen Hsi-shan, Feng Yu-hsiang and Li Tsung-jen revolt against the ROC National Government.
1938: The Emergency National Congress of the Kuomintang in Wuchang elects Chiang Kai-shek as its director-general and decides to organize a People's Political Council and a "Three Principles of the People" Youth Corps.
1940: The Nationalist government issues a circular to all levels of the nation's governments to call Dr. Sun Yat-sen the "National Father of the Republic of China."
1945: U.S. forces invade the Japanese island of Okinawa.
1959: The Dalai Lama arrives in India from Tibet.
1960: The United State launches Tiros I, its first weather satellite.
1965: King Hussein of Jordan appoints Prince Hassan, his younger brother, as his heir.
1968: Ma Ssu-tsung, former president of mainland China's "National Music Academy," and his wife arrive in Taipei from the United States.
1975: Cambodian President Lon Nol flees to Indonesia as Khmer Rouge guerrillas close in on Phnom Penh.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan visits the Taiwan Machinery Show at the grounds of the China External Trade Development Council.
1984: Chang Gung Memorial Hospital completes the first human pancreas transplant in Asia.
1986: The new Value Added Tax (VAT) system is inaugurated in Taiwan.
1989: Namibia gains independence from South Africa.
1992: President George Bush pledges that the United States will help finance the 24-billion dollar international aid fund for the former Soviet Union.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui starts a four-day visit to the United Arab Emirates and Jordan.
1996: Britain proposes slaughtering 15,000 of its cattle every week for the next six years in order to fight mad cow disease.
1996: Japan's Mitsubishi Bank and Tokyo Bank merge to become one of the world's largest banks, Tokyo-Mitsubishi Bank.
1998: Israel accepts a United Nations resolution calling for its withdrawal from south Lebanon.
2000: Acting Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan says that he expects the party will rise again by winning the elections for legislators and county magistrates in two years and by regaining the presidency in 2004.
2001: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presents a "Key to Taipei" to Tibetan spiritual leader Dalai Lama, saying that "the city always welcomes you and is always opened to you."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is easy to serve, but difficult to please. If you go beyond your duty to please him, he will not be pleased. But in his employment of men, he always takes into consideration their capacity. A fool, on the other hand, is easy to please, but difficult to serve. If you go beyond your duty to please him, he will be pleased. But in his employment of men, he expects them to be able to do everything."

The bourse opened at 6,504.54 and fluctuated between 6,534.69 and 6,459.74 during trading.

A total of 5.44 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$128.19 billion (US$3.83 billion), a decrease from the previous day's trading session that saw 6.22 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$135.99 billion.
Two of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with electrical shares moving up the most at 0.9 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 0.1 percent.

The other six major stock categories lost ground with construction stocks moving down the most at 1.9 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 1.6 percent, foodstuff stocks at 1.6 percent, bank and insurance shares at 1.2 percent, textile issues at 0.9 percent, and cement stocks at 0.8 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 473 to 378, with 128 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Top Focus Before 9/11 Wasn't on Terrorism; Rice Speech Cited Missile Defense.
On Sept. 11, 2001, national security adviser Condoleezza Rice was scheduled to outline a Bush administration policy that would address "the threats and problems of today and the day after, not the world of yesterday" -- but the focus was largely on missile defense, not terrorism from Islamic radicals. The speech provides telling insight into the administration's thinking on the very day that the United States suffered the most devastating attack since the 1941 bombing of Pearl Harbor. The address was designed to promote missile defense as the cornerstone of a new national security strategy, and contained no mention of al Qaeda, Osama bin Laden or Islamic extremist groups, according to former U.S. officials who have seen the text, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE MISSION GETS FRUITFUL RESULTS IN ARGENTINA

TEXT.P: Panama City, March 31 CNA) A Taiwan trade mission headed by Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long obtained fruitful results in seeking business opportunities in Argentina.

Well-placed sources close to the mission said Wednesday that during the three-day visit to Buenos Aires which began March 28, the mission obtained orders on the spot totalling US$220,000 as well as potential orders amounting to between four and five million dollars. The mission included members from various sectors, including the computer equipment, digital camera, electronics spare parts, textile and machinery sectors.

The mission held a trade-promotion symposium at the Intercontinental Hotel March 29 to discuss business matters with seven hundred Argentinean businesspeople and more than four hundred buyers from the region. On the same day, Taiwan's representative office in Argentina organized two meetings related to the South American country's trade issues and Taiwan's business opportunities.

Accompanied by Liu Tsen Chun-hsiung, Taiwan's representative to Argentina, Vice Minister Chen and key members of the mission also called on Marcele Elizondo, chairman of the Export Foundation of the Argentinean Foreign Affairs Ministry; Guillermo Jorge Feldman, director- general of trade policy and management of the Ministry of Economy and Production; and Daniel Novak, director-general of the ministry's Economic Coordination Department.

Chen also met with members and representatives of the Taiwan Chamber of Commerce in Argentina and expressed his appreciation for their contribution to Taiwan's economic development. He promised that his ministry will actively help them with any difficulties they face in restructuring their enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS EXPECTED TO BE REMOVED FROM US TRADE WATCH LIST: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: It is expected that Taiwan will be removed from the priority watch list compiled by the United States Trade Representative (USTR) office, a trade official said Friday.

The anonymous official from the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said the 2004 National Trade Estimate Report on Foreign Trade Barriers released the previous day in Washington by the USTR gives general approval to Taiwan's opening of its market in the field of finance, and its efforts to crack down on fake software used in computers.

Although there is still some room for the country to improve its trade practice in many sectors according to the report, the official said the affirmation of Taiwan's policy of bringing the country in line with others in trade law will strengthen the country's voice when it asks Washington to remove Taiwan from the USTR's priority watch list compiled according to its special 301 provisions of the 1984 and 1989 U.S. Omnibus Trade Acts.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL DEPOSIT INSURANCE TAKES OVER ANOTHER INSOLVENT FINANCIAL UNIT

TEXT.P: The Central Deposit Insurance Corp. (CDIC) took over another insolvent grass-roots financial institution Friday in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, according to the Ministry of Finance (MOF).

MOF officials said that the CDIC decided to take the action because a recent liquidation of debts and assets of Fengshan Credit Cooperative Association (FCCA) in Kaohsiung County showed that the institution is insolvent because its net assets are negative.
The FCCA will continue to operate normally and the interests of its depositors and other creditors will be fully guaranteed after the CDIC takes over, the officials noted.
The FCCA became the 47th domestic financial institution taken over by the CDIC since its establishment in 1985.
The CDIC, jointly established by the MOF and Taiwan's Central Bank of China, is in charge of deposit insurance and serves as an integral part of the country's financial system.

DOC.HEADLINE: WATER, POWER SUPPLIES FOR EPZ COMPANIES TO BE STRENGTHENED

TEXT.P: The Economic Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) will step up its efforts to improve the supplies of water and power to companies based in the export processing zones (EPZs) across the country, a spokesman for the administration said Friday.

Despite the fact that water and electricity supplies remain adequate for companies operating in nationwide EPZs for the time being, the EPZA has mapped out plans to fully step up its services in these areas in an effort to meet stronger demand that may come in the five to 10 years ahead, the spokesman said.

The EPZA has contacted the Taiwan Power Company and water companies in various regions around Taiwan to devise a long-term project for the matter, which the spokesman said will also help court businesses from both traditional and hi-tech sectors to increase investment or open shop at the EPZs.

The Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone in southern Kaohsiung City is provided with 30,000 tons of water and 320,000 kilowatts of power per day to maintain its operations, while the Taichung Export Processing Zone in central Taiwan receives 12,000 tons of water and 60,000 kilowatts of electricity on a daily basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT OPENS HEARING IN LAWSUIT TO NULLIFY PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court opened its first hearing Friday on the country's first lawsuit seeking to nullify the March 20 presidential election.

Instead of asking the court to recount all the ballots from the presidential election, attorneys for the plaintiffs, Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and his running mate, James Soong, requested the court to reexamine only the ballots for President Chen Shui-bian and his running mate, Vice President Annette Lu, who beat Lien and Soong by a wafer-thin margin.

Citing the president's decision to hold an unprecedented national referendum simultaneously with the presidential election on March 20, an unexplained assassination attempt in which Chen and Lu suffered light injuries on the eve of election day, and the government's decision to put the armed forces and police on higher alert after the shooting, the plaintiffs' attorneys claimed the election was not fair and a recount of the votes is necessary.
They requested the re-examination of only the votes for the winning ticket, as well as the 330,000-odd invalid ballots in the election, which they claimed were far more than in previous elections.

Attorneys for Chen and Lu, who have already agreed to the plaintiffs' request to recount all the votes in the election, were outraged that the plaintiffs changed their request and limited the scope of the reexamination to the disfavor of the defendants.
Instead of reexamining only the votes for the Chen-Lu ticket, they insisted all the votes be reexamined.

They also argued with the plaintiffs' attorneys over who should bear the cost of the recount, which is estimated at about NT$100 million (US$3.03 million) . The plaintiffs' attorneys said the defendants should bear the responsibility while the defendants' attorneys said the plaintiffs should.

Instead of handing down a ruling, Judge Wu Ching-yuan, who led two other judges in hearing the case, asked attorneys for the plaintiffs and defendants to work out an out-of-court agreement within five days on the range and procedure of the reexamination and how the recount should be financed. The hearing will be resumed after the court receives their written agreement.
"Don't blame the court if the recount cannot begin because no one wants to finance it," Wu said.
Today's hearing drew a large number of journalists, although neither the plaintiffs nor the defendants appeared.

The plaintiffs' request to reexamine the votes for the Chen-Lu ticket has drawn fire from Chen's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), with Cheng Wen-tsan, the DPP deputy chief for the Department of Culture and Communications, saying that the plaintiffs' request proves the insincerity of their claim that they wanted a recount of all the votes.
However, Legislator Chiu Yi from Soong's People First Party argued that the limited scope of reexamination of the votes for the Chen-Lu ticket and invalid ballots will save recount costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSSHIPMENT FROM HONG KONG TO TAIWAN SURGES IN FEBRUARY
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 2 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung & Eric Liu)

TEXT.P: Cargoes transshipped from Hong Kong to Taiwan in February surged in terms of value by 52.2 percent year-on-year, according to a report released Friday by Hong Kong authorities.

The report says that destinations with the highest growth of transshipped cargoes are listed below in order: Taiwan, South Korea, mainland China, France, Singapore, Japan, Germany, the U.S., England and Holland. The growth rates for South Korea, however, did not exceed 40 percent.

After accumulating the figures from the first two months together, the report showed only 15.4 percent growth for Hong Kong transshipment to Taiwan, just ranking in fifth place, with South Korea on top, an increase of 25.2 percent for the January - February period.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT STABILITY CRITICAL TO ASIA-PACIFIC PEACE: MAC

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's proposal to forge a viable mechanism for interaction with mainland China has a strong legitimacy as cross-Taiwan Strait stability is critical to regional peace, a mainland affairs official said Friday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong made the remarks after President Chen reiterated in interviews with major foreign news media in the wake of his re-election victory that establishing a "peace and stability" mechanism for cross-strait interaction is his administration's consistent policy goal.
Chen Ming-tong said cross-strait relations are not only related to Taiwan and mainland China but also to peace, stability and prosperity in the Asia-Pacific region.

Noting that Taiwan and mainland China have a shared interest in maintaining cross-strait peace and stability, Chen Ming-tong said Beijing should take a positive view on President Chen's call for negotiating a mechanism for peaceful cross-strait interaction.

"We need a viable interactive mechanism to boost mutual understanding, trust and goodwill while avoiding any misjudgment of the situation, " Chen Ming-tong said, adding that such a mechanism will also contribute to Asia-Pacific security and development.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORTS OF TERRORISTS IN PHILIPPINES DO NOT AFFECT TAIWAN CARRIERS
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, April 2 (CNA) (By Emerson Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Operations of Taiwan-based carriers in the Philippines have remained good and unaffected by a report alleging that a group of foreign terrorists have entered the country, executives of aviation companies said Friday.

Manager Chen Ming-tsung of the China Airlines (CAL) branch in the Philippines said that the company's business remains quite good and that there is no indication of a drop in the number of passengers on board CAL flights despite the report.
Chen added, however, that the company will still do its best to cooperate with Philippine authorities in airport security to secure in-flight security and the personal safety of passengers.
Lin Chung-hsing, EVA Airways Corporation's chief at Manila Airport, said that the airport's security checks are very strict but pointed out that the airlines' business has not been affected.

According to Lin, EVA Airways personnel at Manila Airport are closely collaborating with the Philippine security authorities in examining travelers' documents and baggage. He called it a necessary measure amid the current situation.

Meanwhile, a spokesman for the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in the Philippines said that the office has not yet issued a tourism alert for Taiwan travelers planning to visit the Philippines. But he still called on Taiwan tourists to refrain from heading to the southern regions, which are often frequented by terrorist elements.

DOC.HEADLINE: VETERAN DONATES ALL HIS SAVINGS TO NEEDY TO SHOW LOVE FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An elderly retired soldier who moved to Taiwan from mainland China along with the Kuomintang government in 1949 recently donated all of his personal savings to help needy people in a show of his love for Taiwan.

Wang Chun-chung, 86, who is living at the self-payment Pakuashan Veterans Home in central Taiwan, mailed a check for NT$1.3 million to Shen Chun-hua, a China Television Co. anchor, asking her to use the money to help those who most need assistance.
Wang said in his letter that he was worried about ethnic rifts in the wake of the bitterly fought March 20 presidential election.
In his view, Wang said, mounting ethnic disharmony is detrimental to Taiwan's future development.
"Therefore, I'm determined to donate my savings to help needy people as my way to give something back to the island, " Wang wrote in his letter to Shen.
Wang said he has only deducted a small sum of money to finance his future living expenses and funeral costs. He has to pay for his accommodation at the Pakuashan Veterans Home.
Wang retired from the military in 1969. He didn't marry and has no relatives in Taiwan. "I have habitually led a simple life and do not need much money," he wrote.
After an evening paper reported Wang's philanthropic deed, many reporters scrambled to the veteran's home to interview him. But Wang declined any publicity.

Wang's friends at the veteran's home said Wang is a fan of Shen. "As Shen has often reported on news events regarding disadvantaged people, Wang decided to donate his savings to poor people through Shen," said one of Wang's friends.

In the fiery and bruising presidential campaign, ethnic origin was used by some politicians as a tool to woo voters. Ethnic rifts seemed to become more serious after mainland-born opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan narrowly lost the election to incumbent Taiwan-born President Chen Shui-bian. Lien has filed a lawsuit to nullify the election on the grounds that an election-eve shooting of Chen unfairly swayed sympathy votes in Chen's favor.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTERIZED CENTER FOR NATIONAL EXAMINATION INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: Participants in the national examination will now be able to find out their results immediately after sitting the examination, thanks to the inauguration Friday of a computerized examination center.

Ministry of Examination Vice Minister Huang Ya-pang, who concurrently serves as the convener of a national examination task force, said that participants in the examination will from now in answer questions on computers.

Referring to concerns about anti-fraud measures employed by the computerized system, the Ministry of Examination officials said that they have taken advantage of the experience of other countries in preventing fraud when taking computerized tests for things like drivers' licenses and TOEFL certification.

The options in the tests could vary from one to another so as to prevent participants from copying from examinees in neighboring seats and the anti-fraud mechanism will be even stricter than in the traditional pen-and-paper examination, they said.

To avoid computer experts from hacking into the computerized center of the National Examination Building in Mucha, all computers at the center will be connected only within the center itself and will not be accessible from outside the center.

Examination Minister Liu Chu-chi also said that in view of the arrival of the computer age and the consideration of ease of use for the general public, the ministry began studying the possibility of giving computerized tests in the national examination two years ago.

Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen said that in the past, participants would have to wait for one or two months before finding out their test results and that the inauguration of the computerized center has greatly cut the waiting time.

The computerized center has been installed on the eighth floor of the National Examination Building, with 140 personal computers for the participants to use for the examination, according to Examination Yuan officials.

The center will not only save on the resources required to run the national examination, but will also make test-taking more convenient. Its inauguration represents a milestone in the national examination.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMPANY, ITRI DEVELOPING PLATINUM ANTI-CANCER DRUG

TEXT.P: Fueled by the government's drive to promote Taiwan's promising biotechnology sector, the private sector and the government inked a cooperative venture Friday to explore the development of an advanced anti-cancer drug.

Tsay Shwu-chen, general manager of Well-being Biotechnology Corporation, said at the signing ceremony that her company has already succeeded in developing a platinum anti-cancer drug in cooperation with the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) -- a leading research institute funded by the government.
According to Tsay, the platinum anti-cancer drug -- the first of its kind in the world -- is a genetic drug with a DNA-cleaving ability that makes it suitable for treating various types of tumors.

As the company has successfully developed the lead drug, Tsay said that it is expected that the new drug will hit the market in seven or eight years after it has undergone tests and clinical trials in animals and humans aimed at upgrading its bio-availability -- namely, increased water solubility and reduced toxicity.

After going through the whole examination process, the drug containing platinum will have the ability to recognize different DNA sequences presented by tumors without hurting normal cells, making it a secure and effective drug for the treatment of prostate cancer, colorectal cancer, ovarian cancer and breast cancer.
According to statistics, the global market scale of cancer drugs is worth about US$10.7 billion each year, with platinum cancer drugs accounting for US$1.1 billion.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs, which has kicked off an all-out effort to promote biotechnology -- a key segment included in its high profile "two-trillion, two- star" program -- granted financial aid worth NT$60 million (US$1.81 million ) to the joint venture set up by Well-being and the ITRI.

An ITRI official expressed his belief that Taiwan will be able to reap a rich harvest in the international market with this new and unique drug, which will help create business alliances with foreign companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN LAWMAKERS TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Leaders of a German parliamentary group friendly toward Taiwan will arrive in Taipei Sunday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Friday.

Berlin-Taipei Friends Group Chairman Klaus Rose and Vice Chairman Angelika Kruger-Leissner hope to learn more about Taiwan's political situation in the wake of the March 20 presidential election, in which President Chen Shui-bian won a narrow victory, as well as the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, MOFA officials said.

The officials added that the two parliamentarians will visit Chen, Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien, Foreign Affairs Minister Eugene Chien, Vice National Defense Minister Lin Chong-pin and Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Huang Chieh-cheng before leaving April 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush Aides Block Clinton's Papers From 9/11 Panel.
The commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks said on Thursday that it was pressing the White House to explain why the Bush administration had blocked thousands of pages of classified foreign policy and counterterrorism documents from former President Bill Clinton's White House files from being turned over to the panel's investigators.
Scott McClellan, the White House spokesman, said some Clinton administration documents had been withheld because they were "duplicative or unrelated, " while others were withheld because they were "highly sensitive" and the information in them could be relayed to the commission in other ways. "We are providing the commission with access to all the information they need to do their job, " Mr. McClellan said.
Wall Street Journal: The Future of Jobs: New Ones Arise, Wage Gap Widens.
Much of the American anxiety about outsourcing to India and China can be boiled down to this simple question: Will there be good jobs left for our kids?
The good news: The U.S. almost certainly isn't going to run out of jobs, even though history shows that it's impossible to predict what new jobs will replace those that are destroyed. The bad news: Outsourcing overseas and technology could widen the gap between the wages of well-paying brainpower jobs and poorly paid hands-on jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE SUSPECTS INDICTED ON CHARGES OF SPYING FOR MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Three men, including a middle-ranking technician with the military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology (CIST) , were indicted Friday on charges of spying for mainland China.

The Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court said in the indictment that the trio had helped give Beijing a glimpse into the Taiwan air force's weaponry systems and to break through the U.S. ban on arms sales to the mainland.

The three espionage suspects were identified as Chen Shih-liang, 53, a technician at the CIST's Electronics Research Institute; Yeh Wen-yuan, 55, a technology firm CEO who received training at the CIST's electronics system design center; and Hsu Hsi-tse, 58, a retired Chinese-American aerospace engineer who once worked at Boeing Co.

The trio were arrested last August. After nearly eight months of investigation, prosecutors said the trio were found to have committed a number of crimes, including disclosing national defense secrets, document forgery and offenses to the national security law and the trade law.

According to the indictment, Yeh got acquainted with a mainland intelligence officer in 1991 during a trip to the mainland. Yeh later set up a precision measurement equipment manufacturing firm on the mainland and also opened a high-tech firm in Taiwan.

The mainland intelligence agent, surnamed Hsu, then asked Yeh to help collect Taiwan defense intelligence and purchase banned strategic high-tech products from the United States and major European countries.

Yeh began in October 2002 to collect documents concerning the CIST's facilities and classified research programs with the assistance of Chen Shih-liang, who worked at the CIST's radar research department. The documents included an evaluation report on whether Taiwan should join the U.S.-initiated theater missile defense (TMD) program. Yeh personally brought the documents to his mainland handler, earning at least US$26,000 from the deal.

The indictment further says that Yeh made friends with Hsu Hsi-tse in February 2002. Hsu resided in Los Angeles but often traveled to Taiwan and the mainland for business purposes. As Hsu needed Yeh's assistance in lobbying the mainland to purchase airport flight control systems, he agreed to help gather information about Taiwan-U.S. military cooperation programs and collected information about Taiwan-U.S. cooperation in anti-submarine combat training.

Hsu is also accused of having hacked into the U.S. government's classified files to steal information about F-16 fighters' night-time weaponry systems and strategic data links. U.S.-made F-16s, along with French-made Mirages and locally built IDFs, form the backbone of Taiwan's air force.

Meanwhile, Yeh helped the mainland authorities to purchase a number of sensitive high-tech facilities, including PalmIR50 night photography machines and a variety of night-vision equipment, sale of which to the mainland have been prohibited by the United States since the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre.

Yeh also counterfeited CIST "end-user certificates, " which allowed Hsu to purchase sophisticated strategic night-vision equipment for the mainland. The devices were sent to Taiwan first and then brought to the mainland by Yeh himself.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO MAKE NEW PROPOSAL ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES IN INAUGURATION
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 2 (CNA) (By Perry Hsieh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said in an interview published by a major Japanese daily Friday that he will make a new proposal on cross-Taiwan Strait relations in his May 20 inauguration.

In the exclusive interview carried by the Yomiuri Shimbun, Chen said the new proposal will be based on his inaugural address of four years ago during which he made known his "four noes plus one" pledge, including no declaration of independence if mainland China does not use military force against Taiwan.

The president said that the idea of "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait" broached by him has become the view of the great majority of the people and that the Taiwan people will never accept the "one country, two systems" rhetoric espoused by the mainland.
Chen also said he will press ahead with his plan to write a new constitution in 2006 and implement it in 2008.

In addition to cross-strait relations, the president also touched on a broad range of issues, including Taiwan's first national referendum, the year-end legislative elections, the election-eve assassination attempt against him and the disputes in the wake of the presidential election, as well as Taiwan's relations with Japan and the United States.

Speaking on his narrow victory over his sole challenger, Lien Chan of the Kuomintang, by 0.228 percent, or 29,518 votes out of the 13 million votes cast in the March 20 election, Chen attributed his success mainly to a rising national identity in Taiwan.
The national identity is a growing consciousness of the need to protect Taiwan against the threat from the mainland, he said.

Claiming that the "one country, two systems" imposed on Hong Kong by Beijing has failed, Chen said Taiwan will never accept that formula as the basis for unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The mainland leadership is afraid of the democratic development in Taiwan, fearing it might affect Hong Kong and other restive areas of the mainland, he pointed out.

Chen denied that the referendum, which was held in tandem with the presidential election, was a flop because the participation threshold of 50 percent was not achieved. Instead, he said it was "quite successful."

Noting that there were concerns that the referendum would lead to a vote on Taiwan independence and bring war and disaster, he said the holding of the referendum attests that such was not the case and that referendum has now become part of the life of Taiwan people.

The two questions posted in the referendum asked the voters whether they approve of stepping up national defense in face of missile threats from the mainland and whether a negotiation framework for talks with the mainland should be established.
Of the roughly 45 percent of eligible voters that voted in the referendum, over 91 percent answered "yes" to both questions.

He also spoke of the election-eve shooting that left him slightly injured, saying it was the combination of "too many coincidences, " although he added that it will not affect the democratic development of Taiwan.

On the post-election turmoil in which supporters of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" protested against what they perceive as "unfair election" because of voting irregularities and the shooting -- which they believe swayed the bitterly contested election in Chen's favor -- Chen said: "Even if the winning margin is only one vote, it is still a win. This is what democracy is about," he pointed out.

The next goal of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will be to obtain over half of the seats in the 225-seat legislature in the year-end legislative election, Chen said, adding that the DPP had encountered difficulties over the past four years because it did not have an overall legislative majority.

Although the DPP is the largest party in the legislature, the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party between them command a slight majority over the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
He said that continued protests by the opposition camp after the election would help contribute to a DPP victory in the December legislative elections.
The paper also reported that Chen wants to become a dominant force in the legislature, probably because of his intention to push for a new constitution.

The president envisions the new constitution as calling for a three-branch government, instead of the existing five-branch one, along with measures to strengthen the president's power and halve the number of legislative seats.
But Chen stressed that the new constitution will not touch on Taiwan independence and will be shaped mainly to make possible further administrative reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TIMETABLE SET FOR BUILDING INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) has ruled out the feasibility of building an international airport in southern Taiwan in the short term, on the grounds that there is no immediate need for such a facility in the region.
The decision was reached during a CAA meeting Thursday in which officials discussed the location of a possible international airport in southern Taiwan, according to a CAA spokesman.

Although Chiku township in Tainan County and the Nanhsing Project in Kaohsiung City are highly interested in vying for the opportunity to host an international airport, the spokesman said that no timetable has been set to decide on the airport's location, as such a construction project requires long-term and comprehensive evaluation and the local authorities must first remove any hurdles blocking the way.

For instance, if the airport were to be constructed in Chiku, the Tainan county government would have to find ways to resolve problems arising from its brine ponds and the conservation of the endangered black-faced spoonbills that winter there, he said.

On the other hand, if the airport were to be located in Nanhsing, the Kaohsiung city government would need to iron out a comprehensive and detailed blueprint about its plans to reclaim land and submit an environmental impact assessment regarding its marine ecology and climate factors, he said.

The CAA will be able to start an across-the-board study of the issue in conjunction with the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and the Ministry of Economic Affairs only after the local authorities have put forward thorough assessments, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS CHARITY HEADS, OUTSTANDING BENEFICIARIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lauded Friday the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF) -- a Taiwan version of the U.S. Christian Children's Fund (CCF) -- for its unconditional care given to children from underprivileged backgrounds.
During an audience at the Presidential Office, Chen cited the TFCF as "a driving force enabling the government to try strenuously and undauntedly to administer the country."

During the audience, Chen met Edmund DeJarnette, a retired U.S. ambassador and chairman of the U.S. Christian Children's Fund, Mrs. DeJarnette, CCF CEO John Schultz, TFCF CEO Chen Pang-hung, and 10 newly elected "self-strengthening" children.

The president expressed his gratitude toward DeJarnette and Schultz for the CCF's long-term support of the TFCF that had enabled the Taiwan charity organization to continue to beef up its services to disadvantaged children and families.
The CCF's assistance to the TFCF has also underlined the truth that "love is without borders," Chen told his guests.

Chen also gave a thumbs-up to the TFCF management, which has helped more than 120,000 people since the organization's inception in 1950. For him, the name TFCF is shorthand for "home, " where orphans and children from poor or broken homes can find shelter and warmth, Chen added.
He also offered his respects and encouragement to the 10 children and teenagers that were elected as the 2004 TFCF "self-strengthening" youths.
Chen said he has been touched by the stories of each of the award recipients and added that their zest for life and their success in remaining undaunted by fate are worth emulation by all.
The 10 youths, all from poor and broken families, were cited as young "self-strengthening" heroes last week for their courage in the face of adversity.

The youths, aged between 10 and 16, were elected in recognition of their vitality and endurance against challenges and hardships that their counterparts from normal families could never imagine facing, said TFCF CEO Chen.
The 10 youths were selected from among 21,000 children and teenagers who are on a TFCF list of recipients of aid from Taiwan society.

According to TFCF management, 10-year-old Kang Yao-wen, the youngest among those cited, has undergone six operations over the years because of assorted genetic illnesses. Yao-wen, however, has never complained to his divorced and financially constrained mother. Instead, he has studied hard, despite his physical weakness, and has earned scholarships every year to help his mother out.

Han Chia-yun, 14, was deserted along with her mentally challenged older brother by their father and his second wife, who fled their village to escape their creditors. One night, after days of severe hunger, Chia-yun carried her brother on her back through farmland to a country road to seek help. The police came to their aid and later found their birth mother.

Having since lived with her mother, Chia-yun has been doing all the chores at home, including taking care of her brother, so that her mother can work outside the home to support the family. Despite all the adversities she has faced, Chia-yun has remained a top student at school, TFCF personnel said.

Chien Zi-chiang, 13, whose father died of illness and whose mother is an alcoholic, also has an older brother who is mentally challenged, but he has not been defeated by fate either. Instead, he has excelled academically and has become a Hualien County badminton champion. Zi-chiang has vowed to become a teacher when he grows up in order to help others.
The TFCF Web site can be found at www.ccf.org.tw.
