DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended the day higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 22.05 points to close at 6,545.54.
The bourse opened at 6,566.76 and fluctuated between 6,581.99 and 6,527.08 during trading.

A total of 5.17 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$120.46 billion (US$3.60 billion), a decrease from the previous day's trading session that saw 5.44 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$128.19 billion.

Six of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with construction stocks moving up the most at 3.1 percent, textile issues at 2.0 percent, cement stocks at 1.4 percent, foodstuff stocks at 1.0 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.8 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.5 percent.
Electrical shares closed even.
Pulp and paper issues moved down 0.6 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 516 to 253, with 204 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTION CHIEF CALLS FOR LAW REVISIONS TO BUILD UP CREDIBILITY

TEXT.P: Central Election Commission (CEC) Chairman Huang Shih-cheng said Friday that the Legislative Yuan should revise the law to build up the election commission's credibility.
Huang made the remarks during an inspection tour of the Changhua County Election Commission.

Since the end of the March 20 presidential election, Huang has been visiting election commissions in various parts of the island. In addition to extending thanks to election staff for their devoted services in handling the presidential poll, Huang has also reviewed the sealed ballot boxes and the rosters of local-level election staff.

As the defeated opposition "pan-blue alliance" presidential candidate, Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, has filed a lawsuit contesting the election outcome, the Taiwan High Court has impounded all ballot boxes and election staff namelists to use as evidence.

Lien lost to incumbent President Chen Shui-bian by a razor-thin margin of 29,518 votes, or 0.228 percent of the some 13 million ballots cast. Lien claims that the election might have been rigged as more than 300,000 ballots were invalid. He demanded a vote recount, a demand to which Chen has acquiesced. The High Court held its first hearing Friday afternoon as the first step in determining how and when the recount should be carried out.
Huang said the CEC has made every possible effort to prevent any irregularities in the election. "Since the case has entered the judicial process, we have to respect the court's ruling, " he added.

Huang further pointed out that the CEC is impartial, but he acknowledged that the procedure for selecting CEC members should be revised in order to enhance the commission's credibility. At the moment, CEC members are recommended by various political parties. Huang said he feels the legislature should amend the current rules to make the CEC recognized as a "credible, independent and impartial" agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 2, or the 13th day of the leap second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
742: Charlemagne, King of the Franks and founder of the first empire in Western Europe after the fall of Rome, is born. His court at Aix-le-Chapelle becomes the center of the Carolingian Renaissance.
1792: The first silver dollar of the new U.S. currency is struck in Philadelphia by the Bank of the United States.
1801: Britain's Admiral Horatio Nelson, aboard the HMS Elephant, sinks the pro-French Danish fleet off its home port of Copenhagen.
1805: Hans Christian Andersen, the Danish writer of fairy tales including "The Emperor's New Clothes" and "The Ugly Duckling," is born.
1840: Emile Zola, the French realist novelist whose books include "Therese Raquin," "Nana," "Germinal," and " La Terre," is born.
1872: Samuel Finley Breese Morse, the American painter and inventor who refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name, dies at the age of 81.
1902: The first U.S. movie theater is opened in Los Angeles, California.
1912: The provisional Senate of the Republic of China resolves to move the seat of the government to Beijing.
1917: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United States and the winner of the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize, summons a special session of Congress to declare war on Germany. At the Paris Peace Conference in 1919, he included the establishment of the League of Nations in the Treaty of Versailles.
1922: Soviet leader Nikolai Lenin appoints Joseph Stalin as general secretary of the Communist Party.
1938: The Spanish Civil War ends with General Franco's fascists as the victors.
1947: The United Nations Security Council votes to appoint the United States as the trustee for Pacific Islands formerly held by the Japanese.
1951: General Dwight Eisenhower assumes command of all allied armies in Europe and the Western Mediterranean area.
1953: Karl L. Rankin becomes American ambassador to the ROC.
1954: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the Extradition Law.
1965: The ROC government declares that "protocols" signed recently by the Beijing regime with Afghanistan are illegal and not binding on China.
1971: Garuda Indonesia Airlines makes its maiden flight to Taipei.
1973: Brig. Gen. Majed Al Haj Hassan and two other members of a Jordanian military goodwill mission arrive in Taipei for a 10-day visit.
1974: Georges Pompidou, president of France, dies at the age of 62.
1974: Madame Gloria de Lopez Arellana, the first lady of Honduras, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1981: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo is re-elected chairman of the Kuomintang by acclamation at the 12th National Congress in Taipei.
1982: Argentine military forces invade the British Falkland Islands.
1983: Chang Da-chien, a noted Chinese painter, dies in Taipei at the age of 85.
1991: Diego Maradona, star of Napoli soccer team, flies home to Argentina hours before being banned from every sporting activity in Italy after failing a dope test.
1996: Lech Walesa, Poland's first post-war democratic president, resumes his old job as an electrician at the Gdansk shipyard.
1997: U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Newt Gingrich meets with ROC President Lee Teng-hui during a four-hour visit to Taipei. Gingrich praises Taiwan's political progress and economic achievements.
1997: The Statute Governing Relations with Hong Kong and Macau is promulgated by President Lee Teng-hui to go partially into effect on July 1, 1997 for Hong Kong, and in 1999 for Macau.
2000: ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian denies that he sent an American scientist as special envoy to mainalnd China to discuss cross-strait relations with Beijing leaders.
2001: Exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama says in Taipei that he wants to pursue "a genuine autonomy" for Tibet, not independence. He makes the remarks while delivering a speech at the Legislative Yuan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man is dignified, but not proud. A fool is proud, but not dignified."

DOC.HEADLINE: 24 KILOS OF HIGH-GRADE AMPHETAMINE SEIZED IN TAIPEI COUNTY

TEXT.P: Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) officials announced Friday that they had seized amphetamine and processing equipment worth nearly NT$100 million (US$3 million) in a raid a day earlier on a drug manufacturing factory in the rural township of Pinghsi, Taipei County.

Acting on a tip, CIB investigators, collaborating with Keelung City and Taoyuan County prosecutors, first cornered drug lord Tu Chi-jen at an intersection in Tienmu, Taipei City at around 11: 30 p.m. Thursday and discovered in his car a bag containing high quality amphetamine and cash amounting to nearly NT$3 million. Tu has a criminal record that includes extortion and drug-trafficking convictions.

Following Tu's testimony, the investigators went to a place in Pinghsi the same night and there seized 24.27 kilograms of high-grade amphetamine, some 160 kilograms of semi-processed drugs, and three machines and other equipment used for producing amphetamine and other illicit drugs.

Tu, 53, is believed to have worked with Hsieh Ming-yuan, 26, who was nabbed at the Pinghsi factory, and others in manufacturing amphetamine twice or three times a month. They have frequently changed the location of their drug processing operations to avoid getting caught, according to Chou You-wei, a CIB squad leader.
Chou added that it has also be learned that Tu and his accomplices have pushed amphetamine at prices ranging from NT$300,000 to NT$600,000 per kilogram.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE PLAYS DOWN ISSUE OF SOURCE OF ELECTION CONGRATULATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 2 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A White House spokesman played down Friday questions on the origin of Washington's congratulatory statement on President Chen Shui-bian's re-election, saying that "he wouldn't read greater policy implications into the statement."

National Security Council spokesman Sean McCormack made the remarks while responding to media questions regarding the White House statement congratulating Chen on his re-election and the fact that the congratulatory message came from the White House press secretary rather than from President George W. Bush himself.

Chen defeated the opposition "pan-blue alliance" ticket of Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and his running mate, People First Party Chairman James Soong, by a razor-thin margin of less than 30,000 votes in the March 20 presidential election. Lien and Soong have challenged the election result and have demanded a vote recount.

The White House issued a statement March 26 in the name of the White House press secretary congratulating Chen on his re-election and reiterated its commitment to its "one-China" policy and the Taiwan Relations Act. The statement also exhorted the Taiwan people to resolve the election dispute through established legal mechanisms.
Asked to explain why the statement was not issued in the name of President George W. Bush, McCormack said that "we wouldn't read any greater policy implications into what we said."
"We congratulated Mr. Chen on his election victory and also noted our confidence in the Taiwan people and Taiwan's democracy to resolve any questions that surround that election," he added.

As to a question relating to Vice President Annette Lu's request that President Bush send a high-level delegation to attend the May 20 inauguration ceremony of the president- and vice president-elect, the spokesman said that no announcement would be made at this point.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN AIMED AT ENCOURAGING GOOD CROSS-STRAIT TIES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 2 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A senior U.S. defense official said Friday that the United States' arms sales to Taiwan are conducted in accordance with a longstanding policy.

Paul Wolfowitz, U.S. deputy defense secretary, made the remarks after testifying at a congressional hearing on military issues in response to media questions regarding the Pentagon's recent decision on arms sales to Taiwan.

The Pentagon has announced that it will sell two long-range early warning radar systems to Taiwan and the U.S. Defense Security Cooperation Agency notified Congress March 30 of the decision to sell the radar equipment.

Asked to explain why the Pentagon announced the sale right after Taiwan's controversial presidential election, Wolfowitz said that "we conduct our arms sales to Taiwan within the framework of a longstanding policy that is aimed at encouraging good cross-Taiwan Strait communications and encouraging a peaceful resolution of differences between the two sides."
"We have got to keep pursuing that policy in a careful way, as we have for a long time," Wolfowitz added.

DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: So Close, Jurors See Long Effort End in Nothing
The jurors in the trial of two former Tyco were told to hold off their deliberations Friday while the judge told them the case was all over. There would be no verdict.
The frustration was especially intense among the jurors. What caused the mistrial in the end, according to the judge, Justice Michael J. Obus of the New York State Supreme Court, was outside pressure brought to bear on one juror after her name was reported in the news media.
Given just a bit more time, several jurors said yesterday, the panel probably would have found the defendants guilty of at least some of the 32 charges against them.
Wall Street Journal: Judge Declares Mistrial In Tyco International Case
The grueling six-month trial of L. Dennis Kozlowski and Mark Swartz, the architects of Tyco International Ltd., was declared a mistrial by state Supreme Court Judge Michael Obus.
In making his decision, the judge cited intense outside pressure placed on juror Ruth Jordan, a 79-year-old former teacher who flashed what appeared to be an "OK" sign to the defense last week.
The two former Tyco executives were accused of looting the company of $600 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION, RULING PARTIES KEEP BICKERING OVER MARCH 19 SHOOTING

TEXT.P: The ruling and opposition parties kept bickering over the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu Saturday, with the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) calling for an independent investigation committee to be set up.

Claiming the shooting negatively impacted their campaign in the March presidential election, the KMT and PFP staged a rally in Taipei Saturday, demanding that an independent investigation committee be set up to probe the shooting in which both Chen and Lu were slightly injured.

Speaking at the rally, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou noted that President Chen Shui-bian has agreed to a recount of the votes in the election, which saw KMT Chairman Lien Chan and his running mate, PFP Chairman James Soong, defeated by Chen and Lu by a narrow margin. However, Ma went on, the president had not responded to the opposition's call for an investigation committee.

In order to clear the doubts surrounding the unexplained shooting, Ma urged the president to respond positively to the request for an independent probe into the accident by a special committee under the Legislative Yuan.
Ma's calls were echoed by Wang Jin-pyng, the president of the Legislative Yuan and a vice chairman of the KMT.
Emerging from a closed-door meeting with KMT campaign workers in Kaohsiung, Wang said the shooting dealt a heavy blow to the "pan-blue alliance's" election campaign.
The country's law enforcers owe the people an explanation of who was behind the incident, Wang added.

Meanwhile a group of PFP lawmakers claimed Saturday that a scheme is brewing among the president's aides to have the National Security Bureau (NSB) take the blame for the shooting, citing what they called "internal documents" of the NSB as evidence.
The accusation has been denied by Cheng Wen-tsan, a deputy director for the Department of the Culture and Communication of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
Cheng challenged the PFP lawmakers to substantiate their accusation with evidence or the credibility of their party would be ruined by their irresponsible speculation.
The opposition's questions about the shooting has put the country's police chief Chang Si-liang in a tight spot.

He told journalists that he will not dodge his responsibility for the incident but shrugged off questions about a report that he is set to offer to resign next week, following in the footsteps of the former chief of National Security Bureau Tsai Chao-ming, who quit earlier this week over the shooting.

In a related story Saturday, Kuo Cheng-ni, a prosecutor at the Tainan District Court who led the probe into the shooting, said investigators are still trying to interview all the people filmed at the scene of the shooting in Tainan by a TV news crew, adding that some people who appear in the film are still unaccounted for.

She also revealed that although two cartridges were found near the shooting scene shortly after the incident, investigators are not sure the place the cartridges were found is the place from which the gun was fired.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN RETURN HOME FOR TOMB-SWEEPING DAY

TEXT.P: More than 800 Taiwanese businessmen operating in mainland China used the "mini direct links" Saturday to travel by ship between the two sides of Taiwan Strait, mainly for April 5 Tomb-Sweeping Day, officials of the Kinmen office of the Bureau of Immigration said Saturday.

The "mini direct links" refer to trade and transport links between Taiwan-controlled Kinmen and Matsu islands and the ports of Xiamen and Fuzhou in mainland China's Fujian Province, which went into effect in January 2001 to boost exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

According to the Kinmen office of the Bureau of Immigration, 861 passengers used the "mini direct links" to travel by ship between Kinmen and Xiamen Saturday, with 80 percent of these passengers returning to Taiwan mainly for the Tomb-Sweeping Day, or Ching Ming Festival, in which people visit the tombs of their ancestors to pay their respects to their forebears, clean their graves and make offerings of food.

In the last three days, the number of passengers returning to Taiwan by the "mini direct links" totaled 1,847 and the officials said they expect that the businessmen will return to the mainland next week.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPENING OF DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT LINKS WILL COME: SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: Although many enterprises see little hope of the government opening direct cross-Taiwan Strait links in the wake of the March 20 presidential election, some scholars claim that the government will surely move in this direction.

In a telephone interview with the Central News Agency, Chen Poh-chih, chairman of the Taiwan Thinktank, said Saturday that the promotion of direct transport links between the two sides of Taiwan Strait is certainly a priority for the Democratic Progressive Party administration, as shown in its campaign promises.

Chen noted that both the DPP and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" made the promotion of direct cross-strait links one of their campaign promises, with the only differences being the method of implementation and other technical details.
For example, Chen said, the government is more concerned about the employment of local laborers and the possible impact direct transport links could have on domestic industries.
"I believe that even the opposition alliance will not advocate the entry of mainland Chinese agricultural products into Taiwan, " Chen said.

Chen said the government is already working unilaterally toward the opening of direct transport links, citing the recent approval for Air Macao to launch a new route connecting Shenzhen, in southern China's Guangdong Province, and Taipei via Macao.
"The total flight time is only two hours and 55 minutes, and it can been seen as the best alternative until the completion of direct transport links," Chen said.

Meanwhile, Hung Teh-sheng, vice president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, claimed that the government knows well that normalizing cross-strait economic and commercial relations is its only option, so that direct links are a must.
Although normalizing cross-strait economic and commercial relations is quite important, the nation's interests should be the government's main concern, Hung said.
The economist also warned the government to pay more heed to the problems resulting from Taiwan enterprises' growing dependence on the mainland market.
He noted that once mainland industries are highly developed and are more competitive in the global market, Taiwan companies' technical advantage in the mainland market will gradually decrease.

Judging from the normalization of economic and trade ties, Hung said local investors should see cross-strait trade as just one of the points of their global positioning rather than the whole of their investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CANCELS FIRST SCHEDULED TRIP OUTSIDE TAIPEI SINCE SHOOTING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Saturday canceled his first scheduled trip outside Taipei since the unsolved March 19 shooting in which he and Vice President Annette Lu were slightly injured.

The Presidential Office said heavy rain forced Chen to cancel a trip to his home village of Kuantien in the southern county of Tainan. He was originally scheduled to pay his respects to his ancestors and visit several temples in the county to mark Tomb Sweeping Day, a major occasion in the Chinese calendar.

He had also planned to visit the southern city of Tainan, where the shooting took place, although he was not expected to visit the actual scene of the attack, an incident that the defeated presidential challenger claims swung the March 20 presidential election in Chen's favor.

The Presidential Office spokesman said it has not yet been decided when Chen will return to his hometown to pay tribute to his late father and other ancestors. This year's Tomb-Sweeping Day falls on Sunday.

Police have yet to identify a suspect in the shooting and have called for witnesses to come forward with information. U.S. forensics experts have confirmed that Chen's injury was caused by a gunshot but will not report on the details of their findings until later this month.
The opposition presidential candidate, Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, has insinuated that the shooting might have been staged by Chen to win sympathy votes.
Chen won re-election by a narrow margin of 29,518 ballots or 0.228 percent of some 13 million ballots cast, prompting Lien to file a lawsuit demanding a recount.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCIAL INTEGRATION TO TOP AGENDA AT ASEAN MINISTERIAL MEETING

TEXT.P: No new initiatives are expected to be brought up at the 8th Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Finance Ministers' meeting in Singapore next Wednesday.

This is because the introduction of too many new initiatives could well "muddle up" the meeting's progress, according to the organizers, who said the meeting will focus on taking stock of work being done on initiatives endorsed at the last meeting.

ASEAN finance ministers will be discussing the Roadmap for Integration of ASEAN in the areas of capital market development, capital account liberalization, financial services liberalization and ASEAN currency cooperation.
These are initiatives aimed at achieving financial integration as part of the 2020 vision for an ASEAN common market.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE LISTED AS MOST COMPETITIVE ASEAN MEMBER

TEXT.P: Singapore leads the other members of the Association of South East Asia Nation (ASEAN) members and mainland China in terms of competitiveness, according to the results of a study conducted by Singapore's Institute of Policy Studies (IPS).
The IPS ASEAN 9+1 Competitiveness Ranking Indices is the first study to look at the relative competitiveness of the nine ASEAN members as well as the mainland.
Only Brunei is excluded due to data constraints.
The countries are ranked on four broad factors -- economic, political, business and social environment.
However, the researchers found that some of the other less developed economies can easily move up in the rankings if they manage to improve their conditions.
Already, Indonesia, Cambodia, Myanmar and Laos have managed to jump a few ranks.
Recognizing the vast and diverse nature of the mainland economy, the IPS ASEAN Competitiveness Ranking hopes to include some mainland provinces as separate economic entities in future studies.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIRWOMAN MAY LEAVE POST SOON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 2 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen will leave her post soon, reliable sources said Friday.
Shaheen became the AIT's sixth-term chairwoman and managing director in late 2002. She has been the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties for only 15 months.
Asked whether Shaheen will end her AIT service, a Bush administration official said it is possible. He further said it's up to high-level government authorities to make a final decision.
Reliable sources said paperwork regarding Shaheen's departure is already underway. According to the sources, Shaheen might be moving to another job.
Shaheen has been on leave over the past week and AIT staff said they did not know when she will return to work.
Shaheen is straightforward and passionate, but that persona made her somewhat incompatible with the AIT post, which deals with sensitive diplomatic affairs, critics said.

Diplomatic sources said Shaheen's friendliness toward Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party administration has sometimes surpassed the Bush administration's limits. For instance, the sources said, some of Shaheen's public statements last summer sent confusing messages to Taipei, thus misleading the DPP administration into underestimating the U.S. government's concern about its referendum plan.

Her remarks about the priority order for Taiwan's arms procurements also drew criticism, but the last straw that may have led to Shaheen's departure was her public expression of congratulations March 26 on President Chen Shui-bian's re-election. At the time, the White House had not yet issued a congratulatory message.

It remains unclear who will succeed Shaheen as AIT chief. The post was left vacant for six months after her predecessor, Richard Bush stepped down to take over the directorship of the Northeast Asian Research Center of the Brookings Institution, a Washington-based think tank.
The shortest-serving AIT chairman was James C. Wood, Jr., who was appointed by former U.S. President Bill Clinton in December 1995. Wood was in the post for only 13 months.

DOC.HEADLINE: SNOW ON HOHUANSHAN, HAIL ON YUSHAN

TEXT.P: A strong convection current which covered the island Saturday not only brought torrential rain to most of the island but also brought snow to Hohuanshan and hail to Yushan in central Taiwan, a very unusual occurrence for April, according to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).

Snowy season on the 3,416 meter Hohuanshan usually ends in February, but the humidity brought to the island by a cold front the previous day caused torrential rain in the island's mountain area Saturday morning and prompted a rare fall of spring snow on Hohuanshan that lasted for nearly an hour and covered the mountain with two centimeters of snow, according to the CWB.

The phenomenon was especially unusual as the temperature at the summit of the mountain was 0.7 degrees Celsius at the time. Weather forecasters attributed the snow to the strong convection current that led to clouds as high as 5,000 meters or 6,000 meters.
Meanwhile, Yushan -- the island's highest mountain -- had a hailshower, although the temperature was only minus 0.3 to minus 0.5 degrees Celsius there at the time.
However, a dryer cold current was beginning to take hold of the island from noon, putting an end to the unseasonable wintry weather the weather forecasters said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TEXTILE INDUSTRY TO BE BOOSTED BY LIFTING OF GLOBAL QUOTAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan textile enterprises are being urged to establish a strategic alliance to cash in on the growing market expected after the global lifting of textile import quota restrictions from Jan. 1, 2005.
Officials of the China Textile Institute (CTI) said Saturday that the removal of global textile quotas are expected to bring additional textile trade worth US$120 billion-US$324 billion per year.

Starting from 2005, member countries of the World Trade Organization will have easier access to markets in the European Union, United States and Canada, which at present set textile quotas on foreign importers, according to the CTI.
The CTI officials predicted considerable growth after the quota lifting for Taiwan's textile products in the United States, the island's major textile market.
The officials also predicted that Taiwan's textile industry will benefit significantly in the mainland Chinese market due to its high-quality products.

For example, the officials added, Taiwan-made polyester is quite competitive both in price and quality compared to that produced on the mainland. Although mainland companies are working to improve their technology, the quality of some specific items still lags behind international levels.

However, the CIT officials suggested that Taiwan textile enterprises should establish a strategic alliance to jointly explore the global markets in view of the growing competition from abroad amid a tendency toward regional economic integration in North America, Europe and Southeast Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FIRM SANCTIONED BY U.S. FOR IGNORING TRADE EMBARGO ON IRAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 2 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A firm in Taiwan has been sanctioned by the United States for violating an embargo against Iran by selling it items forbidden by the United States, the State Department reported Friday.

Adam Ereli, the deputy spokesman for the State Department, said U.S. intelligence shows that the Goodly Industry Company of Taiwan, along with twelve other firms, have since Jan. 1, 1999 sold goods or technology to Iran that could be used for the manufacture of weapons of mass destruction.
These firms have violated U.S. legislation enacted in 2000 and have thereby been deprived of the right to deal with the U.S. government for two years, Ereli said.
Although the subject of the sanction are firms rather than countries that have ignored the U.S. embargo, their respective governments have been informed of the U.S. sanction decisions, Ereli added.
Among the 13 offenders, five are mainland Chinese firms. Goodly is believed to be the first Taiwan firm sanctioned under the act.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP FACTIONS STEP UP PREPARATIONS FOR YEAR-END LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Major factions within the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have stepped up preparations for the year-end legislative elections, party sources said Saturday.
Now that President Chen Shui-bian has won re-election, the DPP has made winning more than half of the seats in the year-end legislative elections its top priority.
DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said the party must win a majority in the Legislative Yuan if it is to facilitate the implementation of Chen's reform agenda.

According to Chang, the DPP will hold intraparty primaries May 23 as the first step to deciding the party's nomination list. After discussions with leading figures in the major intraparty factions, Chang said the party will adopt an "elite" nomination strategy.
"The number of party nominees will be based on our party strength. We'll avoid excessive nomination," Chang said.

According to the DPP charter, legislative nominations are based on the results of the primaries and the outcome of a series of opinion surveys conducted by the party. Opinion survey results are even more important than the intraparty primary results (70 percent vs. 30 percent) . The DPP will conduct opinion surveys between late May and the first half of June.

Meanwhile, the major DPP factions have started internal consultations and coordination in order to determine their nomination recommendation lists. Basically, incumbent legislators will be given priority, faction leaders said.
Legislator Tsai Huang-lang, secretary-general of the Justice Alliance said his faction will come up with a recommendation list in mid-April.
Other major factions, including the New Wave and the Mainstream Alliance, have also started registration work for nomination hopefuls.

Party sources said several two-term legislators-at-large plan to vie for regional seats in the December legislative elections. Among them are Lin Chung-cheng, Chang Hsiu-chen, Yen Chin-fu, Parris Chang and Liu Chun-hsiung.
The DPP now controls 87 seats in the legislature by garnering 33.4 percent of the ballots cast in the December 2001 legislative elections.

Although the DPP is the largest single party in the legislature, it fails to control a majority. As a result, many of its reform programs have remained on the drawing board during Chen's first four-year term. The two major opposition parties -- the Kuomintang and the People first Party that between them control half of the legislative seats -- habitually block Cabinet-proposed reform bills.
However, Chen captured 50.11 percent of the vote in the just-concluded presidential election, indicating that the number of DPP core supporters has increased.

Against this backdrop, party sources said, the DPP plans to win at least 84 regional seats in the legislative elections. If this goal can be reached, the DPP will be able to win more at-large seats, which are allocated among the major political parties according to the ballots they bag in the regional-seat elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION VISITS EUROPE ON FACT-FINDING TRIP
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, April 2 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A delegation form the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung has embarked on a European tour to obtain information about urban development with a view to boosting Kaohsiung's development.

The 25-member delegation, headed by Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Lin Yun-chien, arrived in Rome April 1, where they were warmly received by Rome Deputy Mayor Mariapia Garavaglia. Both sides exchanged opinions on their respective urban development experiences.
Prior to their visit to Rome, the delegation had also visited London, Bonn and Barcelona to absorb experiences of urban development in those cities that could be applied to development in Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 3, or the 14th day of the leap second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:

1898: Henry Luce, the American publisher who founded Time, Life, and Fortune magazines, is born.
1903: Chou Jung, author of "The Revolutionary Army," dies in jail in Shanghai at the age of 21.
1922: Joseph Stalin is appointed general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party.
1930: Helmut Kohl, the German chancellor who stayed in power for a record 16 years until his defeat by Gerhard Schroeder in 1998, is born.
1933: Four Britons in two Westland biplanes make the first flight over the peak of Mount Everest in the Himalayas.
1946: Directed by the Soviet Union, the so-called "Inner Mongolian Autonomy Movement Committee," is established in Chengteh, Jehol Province.
1948: US President Harry Truman signs the Marshall Plan, allocating US$6 billion in aid to 16 European countries to help reconstruction after World War II.
1962: President and Mme. Philbert Tsiranana of the Republic of Madagascar arrive in Taipei for a six-day state visit.
1964: The Dalai Lama establishes a Tibetan office in New York.

2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and visiting Liberian President Charles Taylor signed a joint communique Tuesday calling on all nations to resolve international differences through dialogue, negotiations and other peaceful means.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man of strong, resolute, simple character approaches closely the true moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDS INMATES INCREASINGLY PROBLEMATIC FOR CORRECTIONAL AUTHORITIES

TEXT.P: The number of inmates with AIDS has soared to a record high and correctional authorities in Tainan County are finding it increasingly challenging to accommodate the special needs of these prisoners.

As of March 31 this year, the number of AIDS inmates in the Tainan Prison had shot up to 20, up from only four last December, making the Tainan Prison the correctional institution in Taiwan with the largest number of AIDS patients, prison authorities said.

The 16 newly arrived AIDS inmates - most being drug abusers who shared needles -- have been posing a challenge to prison authorities in terms of medical requirements and management of their daily lives.

According to prison authorities, it used to be easier to manage the AIDS prisoners when there were only four of them, with each staying in a separate cell. Now, the 20 inmates are being housed in five cells.

The time for the AIDS inmates of go out for fresh air or to exercise must be arranged at different times from those for ordinary prisoners who do not have AIDS, the authorities said, adding that the AIDS inmates are also prohibited from taking part in workshop activities for security reasons.

Since the prison has only basic medical and health facilities, it is inconvenient for the prison when the AIDS inmates need medical attention, they said, adding that the prisoners have to be sent to a hospital outside the prison under the company of prison authorities when special needs arise.
The Tainan Detention Center, meanwhile, is currently the prison in Taiwan with the second-largest number of AIDS patients at 14.

Increasing numbers of AIDS inmates are posing a three-pronged challenge to Tainan jail authorities: concern over whether the number of cells is sufficient to meet demand; whether the prisons should be staffed by professional doctors and nurses and equipped with specific medications; and whether psychological specialists should be hired to provide regular counseling to the AIDS inmates to prevent them from becoming "time bombs" who could endanger other inmates, the Tainan Prison authorities said.

The Washington Post: Brazil Shielding Uranium Facility; Nation Seeks to Keep Its Proprietary Data From U.N. Inspectors.
The Brazilian government has refused to allow U.N. nuclear inspectors to examine a facility for enriching uranium under construction near Rio de Janeiro, according to Brazilian officials and diplomats in Vienna, home of the International Atomic Energy Agency, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALL TAIWAN INVENTORS ARE PRIZE-WINNERS AT GENEVA INVENTION EXPO
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, April 3 (CNA) (By Lo Yuan-shao and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan captured global attention at the 32nd Geneva International Invention Exhibition Saturday with all of its 23 entries winning prizes.

Taiwan's "golden minds" were awarded four national awards, 12 gold, seven silver and four bronze medals at the five-day Geneva International Invention Exhibition, billed as the world's premier trade show for inventors, which opened on March 31.
A panel of 60 judges chose the masterworks by 21 Taiwan inventors two days before the annual inventions expo closes on April 4.

Four of Taiwan's gold-medal winning creations also garnered national awards from four countries. They are Wang Hsing-ken's salt water desalination processor, which receives a national award from Hungary; Chung Yu-lin's explosion-proof lithium battery, receiving a national award from Russia; Liu Teh-shan's mulberry tonic, receiving a South Korean national award; and Kao Chih-hung's one-touch faucet, receiving a Swiss national award.

Other inventors from Taiwan who won gold medals at the expo included Cheng Tsan-hsiung with his turnable inline skates; the Tseng brothers with their equipment for instant drinking of hot spring water; Tsai Chin-chen with his water-tight lock system; and Chou Wen-li with his first-aid-kit flashlight.

A majority of the Taiwan innovative works have high commerce value as well. For example, Wang Hsing-ken, who received both a national award from Hungary and a gold medal for his salt water desalination processor, received an order on the spot from a buyer from Saudi Arabia. Wang signed a contract to sell an unknown number of the desalination processors at NT$80 million (US$2.42 million) per unit.
Inventor Chou Wen-li has also received orders for his first-aid-kit flashlights.

Altogether 1,000 entries from 42 countries are on display at the invention expo, which has attracted nearly 60,000 visitors, of whom, 40 percent were from countries beyond Switzerland. Many of the visitors are looking for chances to commercialize the inventions.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN TO ASK TAIPEI CITY TO PREVENT RALLY ON APRIL 10

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will ask the Ministry of the Interior and the Taipei City Government on Monday to cancel a permission for a rally called by the opposition party of Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) in Taipei on April 10, Liu Shih-fang, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan said Sunday.
Liu said, the city government will be held responsible for all consequences if it refuses to abide by the Executive Yuan's order and withdraw apermission it already issued.

Besides the city government, the Executive Yuan's order will be delivered to the Ministry of the Interior because the police department under the Taipei City Government is also a subordinate to the National Police Administration which is controlled by the Ministry of the Interior, Liu said.

Judging by the city government's handling of previous rallies organized by the KMT and PFP, Liu said the Executive Yuan is concerned about the city's ability to prevent participants of the April 10 rally from overstaying their permission and turning their gathering into an illegal protest.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD TO PATROL FISHING GROUNDS IN CENTRAL AND WESTERN PACIFIC

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Administration is planning to send large fishing-protection ships to the central and western Pacific after local fishing ships found there are good fishing grounds there, said an official at the administration.

As more and more local fishing boats operate in the central and western Pacific, the administration feels it necessary to expand their patrols in that area to protect Taiwan's fishing boats especially during the busy fishing season between April and June, the official said.
The administration usually patrols the northern Pacific and southern Pacific, which are the traditional fishing grounds of the island's fishing industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTBOUND TOURISM REMAINS SLUGGISH FOLLOWING PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Outbound sightseeing travel following the March 20 presidential election remains sluggish, a stark contrast to high expectations from local tourist agencies which had eagerly hoped for an injection into their businesses, industry sources said Sunday.

Hsu Kao-ching, secretary-general of the Republic of China Tourism Association, said that many tourist agencies specializing in outbound travel are disappointed with the current situation because they had keenly hoped for a booming market after the presidential election.

According to Hsu, they had high hopes that political uncertainties would have been removed after the presidential poll and the post-election situation in Taiwan would become stabler to bring back customers.

Hsu pointed out that many people are still fervently mired in a dispute over the election result, bringing about a new cloud over Taiwan's politics and slashing the travel willingness among the local people.

So far, market response to travel to mainland China -- the most popular destination for a large number of outgoing Taiwan tourists -- has been lackluster, due to the election result, Hsu said. He contended that the re-election of President Chen Shui-bian, a pro-Taiwan independence advocator, has deepened the public worry over the island's security and stability when it comes to mainland China.

However, Hsu pointed out that pleasure travel to Japan has a great market potential despite the current political woes in Taiwan. A series of promotional activities marketed recently by the Japanese central and local governments will attract a larger number of Taiwan visitors, he added.

In addition to being a traditionally costly and upscale destination for many Taiwan tourists, pleasure travel to Japan has become much more diversified to court different clientele thanks to the promotional efforts by local tourist agencies on the Internet. Customers now are provided with a large variety of cheaper or economy trips to Japan through the many tourism Web sites.
According to an operator of a Taiwan-based tourist agency, Taiwan tourists are increasingly getting used to hi-end travel after a decades-old evolution.

The number of Taiwan tourists heading to Japan this year is expected to break the one million mark from the past average of more than 900,000 per year, he claimed, adding that the number will place Japan as the second-most popular destination for outbound Taiwan tourists only after the greater China area composed of mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau.

DOC.HEADLINE: TV ANCHOR WOMAN RETURNS AFTER NEAR FATAL TRAIN CRASH IN LONDON

TEXT.P: A TV personality who returned to Taiwan after a miraculous recovery from a near fatal train accident in London two years ago thanked Sunday all those who have been concerned about her.

Liu Hai-roh, who made her fame as a news anchorwoman for the Hong Kong-based Phoenix Television Co., said excitedly, "Thank you all. I've returned." Accompanied by her mother and brother, she returned from Hong Kong Saturday night.

Liu, together with friends Wu Chia-ching, a television journalist, and Lin Chia-hsin, a former TV journalist, was on the ill-fated train that crashed north of London May 10, 2002. The accident, which was caused by faulty carriage couplings, killed seven passengers, including Wu and Lin, and injuring more than 40 more.
Liu was initially pronounced brain-dead after being sent to Royal Free Hospital in London. She was later transferred to Beijing for lengthy treatment.
Her doctors at the Beijing hospital decided to grant her a one-month leave last month, saying that they were satisfied with her condition.

After her one-month "journey of recovery, " Liu said that she would return to the mainland for a thorough checkup to ensure that she has fully recovered, and she will then return to her anchorwoman post.

Liu, who looks fatter because of the drugs she is taking, doesn't recall anything about the train accident. In the beginning, she didn't even realize that her two best friends had perished and she could now only hope that they will have a better life in another world.
Liu visited the Wu's grave and had lunch with Wu's parents. She is expected to travel to Hualien, eastern Taiwan, to pay tribute to Lin and her parents Monday.
The anchorwoman said to Wu's parents that she hopes to serve them as a filial daughter on behalf of the deceased.

The family of Liu expressed their heartfelt thanks to Taiwan doctors for advising them not to ask that life support system be disconnected during the most critical time at the urging of British doctors.
They also expressed thanks to the boss of Phoenix Television for financial support during the lengthy medical treatment.
Liu is expected to stay two weeks in Taiwan during which she will meet with old friends and colleagues as well as do interviews with political figures in preparation for her future work.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER TENDERS WRITTEN RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien has tendered a written resignation to Premier Yu Shyi-kun, and the premier is taking into consideration the overall situation in assessing whether to approve his resignation, Liu Shih-fang, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, said Sunday.

Liu said that Yu had expressed his intention to resign orally to the Premier in a recent meeting of the Executive Yuan over the presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu on March 19.
Yu believed that the Ministry of the Interior is the superior agency of the National Police Administration (NPA), and he should take political responsibility, Liu said.
The premier had told Yu that there will be more mass rallies by the supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" and he wished Yu would stay to help maintain social order.

THe supporters are protesting against what they perceive as an "unfair election" because of the voting irregularities and the shooting which left the president slightly injured, but they believed to have won Chen sympathy votes and victory in a bitterly contested election.

Meanwhile, the NPA kept a low-profile on reports that its administrator, Chang Szu-liang, will tender his resignation Monday, saying only that Chang will go to the Legislative Yuan for the question and answer session as scheduled.
Reports had said that Chang would resign to take responsibility for the March 19 shooting.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHILDREN MUST USE SAFETY SEATS FROM JUNE 1: MOTC

TEXT.P: Car safety seats for children under four years old will be mandatory after June 1, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) announced Sunday.

An event to highlight the importance of child car seats was held Sunday at Fishermen's Wharf in Tamshui, Taipei County, with more than 70 free child safety seats given to infants born on April 4 and 61 seats awarded in a lottery.
The activity was jointly sponsored by the MOTC, the Jinchuen Children's Safety Foundation and the ROC Car Safety Association.

As of June 1, any child under four years old and weighing under 18 kilograms will be required to use a car safety seat. Parents who ignore the law will be fined NT$500, an official of the Committee of Traffic Safety Supervision under the MOTC said.
Police will step up monitoring of the use of safety seats in places frequented by families, the official added.

Based on the statistics of the U.S. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, around 61 percent of children lost their lives in the United States in traffic accidents due to the absence of safety belts or safety seats.
In Taiwan, car accidents claim the majority of children killed in accidents, according to statistics.
Statistics from Japan indicate that a child is eight times more likely to die in a car accident if he or she is not in a safety seat.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS BEGIN TESTING IN MAJOR FISHERY MARKETS FOR METHYL ALCOHOL

TEXT.P: Officials were conducting tests in several major fishery markets around the island Sunday following reports that yellow-striped porgies, a very popular delicacy in Taiwan, tested positive for toxic methyl alcohol in central Taiwan, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Sunday.

Officials of COA's Fisheries Administration said that they have received the latest report from the Taichung City Government's Department of Health, indicating that one sample had tested positive for methyl alcohol, used as a preservative to keep its freshness.
The fish came from Keelung, northern Taiwan, and the Fisheries Administration has already sent officials there for inspections, they said.

Fishery official Hu Chi-hsiang noted that as fishermen have often said that contaminated fish come from the mainland, the COA will not only trace the source of the contaminated yellow-striped porgies, but will also coordinate with the Coast Guard Administration to increase their crackdown on illegally smuggled fish catches.

Hu said that methyl alcohol, which has a strong odor and is easily detected, has not been used in fish catches before and therefore has not been included in the tests. If someone is using it illegally now, the administration will begin an across-the-board examination, he added.

The Fisheries Administration has asked the Taipei City Government's Department of Health to provide test kits for methyl alcohol and has invited officials in charge of the management and development of fishery markets to take part in a seminar and teach them how to conduct a quick test.
If the fish test positive, they will be banned from being sold immediately and will be sent to the local health authorities for examination, Hu said.
In addition to Taipei, the Fisheries Administration has sent officials to major fishery markets in Taichung, Chiayi and Hsinchu to teach how to inspect yellow-striped porgies.

DOC.HEADLINE: CZECH DIRECTOR WEDS AT TRADITIONAL CHINESE CEREMONY IN ILAN

TEXT.P: World renowned environmentalist film director Steve Lichtag married his fiancee at a traditional Chinese wedding held Sunday in Ilan, stealing the show at an international "green" film festival that recently opened in the eastern city.

Lichtag, whose films and videos have been regular prize winners at the ENVIROFILM Festival, married Ms. Marcela Kordova at a Taoist wedding ceremony at a village near the Dongshan River in Ilan County, with the wife of Ilan County Magistrate Liu Shou-cheng administering the ceremony.

About 10 other directors/producers from around the world who were also prize winners of the ENVIROFILM Festival and have been invited by Ilan authorities for the 2004 Ilan Green International Film Festival in Taiwan performed a lion dance during the wedding party. The lion was made of rice straw.
Among Lichtag's famous films on environmental protection and improvement are The Great White and In Search of the Crystal World.
The 2004 Ilan Green International Film Festival in Taiwan opened April 2 will run until April 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN VOWS TO BUILD TAIWAN INTO FULL DEMOCRACY WITH ECONOMIC POWER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian vowed in his hometown Sunday to build Taiwan into a full democracy with "invincible economic strength."

Meeting with his fellow countrymen in the rural township of Kuantian, Tainan County, where Chen was born to farmer parents, the president said that in the next four years, he will see to it that the country's economy turns "from good to better" so that all the people in Taiwan will fare better than before.
Chen, accompanied with his wife, Wu Shu-chen, went to a local temple in Kuantian to pay tribute to his ancestors at a worship-offering ceremony to mark Tombsweeping Day, which falls on Monday.

It is Chen's first visit to his hometown since March 19 when he and Vice President Annette Lu were shot during an election-eve campaigning ride in Tainan City. Chen suffered a minor flesh wound to his stomach. Chen and Lu won their re-election by a razor-thin margin of fewer than 30,000 votes out of more than 13 million ballots cast in the presidential election held March 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL CURRENCY TO REMAIN LITTLE CHANGED AGAINST U. S. DOLLAR

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar may hover around the 33.0 to 32.8 mark against the U. S. dollar during this week after experiencing a wave of surges last week fueled largely by a rising Japanese yen, sources from the banking industry said Sunday.

The local currency may increasingly lose stream in gaining in value against other major foreign currencies in the coming days due to a temporary halt to a rising Japanese yen as a result of strong manufacturing data and a fall in new claims for unemployment benefits announced by the United States, the sources said.

The new Taiwan dollar ended at 32.929 against the greenback last Friday -- the highest closing level for the local currency since July 2002 -- which represents a marked rise of NT$0.345 from the week-earlier level of 33.274. The gain in value was mainly prompted by an appreciating Japanese yen, which finished at 104.24 against the U. S. dollar.

Taiwan's Central Bank of China did not intervene to stop the local currency's rise last week, the sources noted, adding that it is unlikely that the new Taiwan dollar will continue to appreciate this week and surpass the 32.8 level unless the Japanese yen rises to break the 103 mark against the greenback.

For the time being, the delicate political situation at home will play a key role in the new Taiwan dollar's short-term levels in the run-up to the presidential inauguration on May 20, they said, pointing out that the local currency will not see dramatic fluctuations during that period and that the inaugural speech to be given by the president-elect will be the focal point for the market.

In essence, the local currency is not expected to continue rising and will hover between the 33.0- 32.8 range against the U. S. dollar this week under the pressure of a weaker Japanese yen, which may lose in value against a rebounding U. S. dollar, the sources said, adding that the lack of a bullish sentiment in the domestic stock market is another factor.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO UNDERGO MINOR RESHUFFLE FOR NOW: DPP LEGISLATOR

TEXT.P: The Cabinet will undergo a minor reshuffle to strengthen its financial lineup, a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Sunday.

Tsai Huang-lang, DPP whip in the Legislative Yuan, made the remarks in response to reports of a Cabinet reshuffle following the March 20 presidential election which saw President Chen Shui-bian win re-election by a narrow margin. According to general practice, the Cabinet will resign en masse before the inauguration of a new president on May 20.
"It is only appropriate to limit the scope of a reshuffle for now, " Tsai said, adding that a major reshuffle would have to wait until after the year-end legislative elections.
Tsai said that the Executive Yuan will seek stability between now and the year-end elections, believing it is best for political development.

Although the DPP is the largest single party in the legislature, Tsai said that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party between them will still command a slight majority in the legislature before the legislative elections in December.
"If the scope of the Cabinet reshuffle is too big, it will have an impact on the political situation," he said.
"It is therefore not proper to make a dramatic adjustment of the Cabinet lineup," he said, adding that any changes will base on the principle of stability.

"The moderately altered administration is aimed at bettering its performance to attract voters in the year-end legislative elections," Tsai said, adding that this is the current major task for the DPP.

To respond to the public's expectations of a new administration, he said the reshuffled Cabinet will strengthen the functions of the Executive Yuan, particularly those dealing with finance and economics.

Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i may not have to serve concurrently as the chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, and instead a financial or economic expert may join the administrative team, he said.

He said that the Executive Yuan, if it can work toward improving the economy and engage in continued reforms, will help to win more than half of the 225-seat legislature, and only then "will it be the best time for the Cabinet to undergo a major reshuffle."

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL TAIWAN VILLAGE GIVES GREEN LIGHT TO FIREFLIES

TEXT.P: A small village in mountainous central Taiwan has found a way to balance the needs of some its smallest residents -- fireflies -- and tourists who come to see the natural phenomenon.

The central Taiwan Tahsuehshan farming community, located 850 to 1,200 meters above sea level, is home to swarms of fireflies -- a favorite of local tourists. Unfortunately, street lights installed for the human residents of the village are too bright for the fireflies, who refuse to multiply in appreciable numbers under the lights.
Residents, hoping to replenish the population of fireflies, have turned off many street lights over the past three years and the fireflies have responded by returning to the area.
The problem is that tourists walking the darkened mountain trails to see the fireflies are in danger of falling or getting lost.

To address the situation, village authorities studied the problem for a year and, with the help of Philips Electronics Taiwan, came up with a solution -- light the pathways with low-level green LED lights.

The lights will cost NT$1 million (US$29,850) but will enable the fireflies a natural environment in which to live and allow those who wish to watch them to experience the sight in as close to natural conditions as possible.
The Philips LED lights have a life span of over 50,000 hours, equivalent to 14 years at 10 hours of use each day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 4, or the 15th day of the leap second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1581: Sir Francis Drake, who in 1580 became the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe, is knighted in London by Queen Elizabeth I. The English naval hero later became vice admiral of the fleet that destroyed the Spanish Armada in 1588.
1617: John Napier, the Scottish mathematician who invented logarithms and introduced the use of the decimal point in writing numbers, dies at the age of 67.
1841: William Henry Harrison, the ninth president of the United States, dies of pneumonia at the age of 68 after only one month in office.
1900: Prince Edward, heir to the throne of England, narrowly escapes death when a teenage anarchist fires two shots at the prince who is on a train in a Brussels station.
1905: An earthquake rocks Lahore, then part of British India, killing some 19,000 people.
1932: The Republic of China observes its first Children's Day. Children have the day off from school.
1942: Japanese forces sink three British warships in the Bay of Bengal.
1949: The foreign ministers of Belgium, Britain, Canada, France, Holland, Luxembourg, Norway, Denmark, Iceland, Italy, Portugal and the United States sign the North Atlantic Treaty in Washington to protect Western nations from Soviet aggression.
1950: The Chinese Refugees Relief Association is inaugurated.
1967: Australian Prime Minister Harold E. Holt arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1968: Dr. Martin Luther King, the American civil rights leader who won the 1964 Nobel Peace Prize, is assassinated at a motel in Memphis, Tennessee. His eloquence and commitment to nonviolent tactics formed the foundation of the civil rights movement of the 1950's and 1960's.
1973: The Republic of China and the Khmer Republic conclude a temporary air transport agreement with an exchange of notes in Phnom Penh.
1974: The 21-member women's national basketball team returns after a tour of the United States and Brazil. The team won 24 games and lost six.
1974: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with Botswana.
1974: U.S. Ambassador Walter P. McConaughy and his wife leave Taipei for retirement. He is succeeded by Ambassador Leonard Unger.
1976: Chinese at home and abroad mark the first anniversary of the passing of President Chiang Kai-shek with solemn ceremonies, tributes and prayers.
1979: Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, Pakistan's former president who was deposed by Gen. Zia ul-Haq in 1977, is hanged in Rawalpindi for the alleged murder of a political opponent.
1980: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo presides over a ceremony marking the inauguration of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
1983: The United States grants political asylum to Hu Na, a noted tennis player from mainland China.
1989: The Ministry of Education approves the applications of three mainlanders to visit Taiwan.
1990: Communist China's legislature approves the Basic Law, the constitution that will govern Hong Kong after it reverts to Chinese sovereignty in 1997.
1990: Britain publishes a bill to grant citizenship to up to 225,000 Hong Kong residents in the run-up to the colony's handover to mainland China in 1997.
1994: A communist Chinese court sentences Si Yang, a reporter at Hong Kong's Ming Pao newspaper, to 12 years in prison for "stealing and probing national secrets."
1999: At the conclusion of a weeklong visit to Taiwan, prominent mainland Chinese dissident Wang Dan urges Beijing to abandon threatening Taiwan with military aggression.
2000: Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Macchi reiterates that his country's stance of supporting the Republic of China in international forums will never change.
2001: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, meets with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong in Taipei to exchange views on issues of mutual concern.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman must be sympathetic, obliging and affectionate: sympathetic and obliging to his friends and affectionate to the members of his family."
