DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE AIRLINES RECRUITING PILOTS

TEXT.P: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and its cargo arm are looking for experienced pilots, and more than 100 captains and first officers from the SAS Group - the largest Nordic airline - have expressed interest.
Interviews began a week ago, and those selected will undergo a brief training stint before flying for the SIA group.

However, these pilots will not be on SIA's permanent payroll. It is understood that they will be with SIA under a four-year contract because SAS now has a surplus of pilots. They will return to their parent company when the contract expires.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOPES U.S. WILL PLAY BIGGER ROLE IN CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed hope Monday that the United States will play a more active role as a "peace envoy" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to help build a bridge of friendship across the strait.

The president made the remarks at the Presidential Office when he received a delegation of the National Committee on American Foreign Policy (NCAFP) , a major U.S. think tank, that came here to observe the post-presidential election situation.
Chen said that neither Taiwan, the United States nor mainland China should ignore the situation and challenge faced by Taiwan after the March 20 presidential election.
The significance of the election was the display of the will of the Taiwan people, which is to "protect Taiwan against China" and Beijing should heed this rising Taiwan identify, Chen said.

He noted that in the 2000 presidential election, he won by garnering 39.3 percent of the votes and that the victory was considered a "win by chance." At the time, he said, he was a minority president leading a minority administration without a broad-based mandate from the people.

Although he has made various proposals on cross-strait peace interactions over the past four years, they have been repeatedly questioned or rebuffed by the Beijing authorities, some groups in the United States and even by the opposition parties in Taiwan.

But he stressed that this time, though only winning a narrow victory against his rival, he garnered 1.5 million more votes than last time, making him a national leader that truly represents that mainstream will of the people.

"After this election, " he said, he is sure "the Beijing authorities will not regard him as a minority government or as someone who does not represent the will of the majority of the people" and will deal with him.

He also said that in his May 20 inauguration for another four-year term, he will make a new proposal on cross-strait relations based on his 2000 inaugural speech -- in which he made known his "four noes plus one" pledge, including no declaration of independence if Beijing does not use force against Taiwan.

He noted that in his last inaugural speech, he noted that the 23 million people of Taiwan cannot accept Beijing's "one China" principle, which he said is in fact "one country, two systems" and that the focus is "one country" and not "two systems" for Beijing, which the Taiwan people find impossible to accept.

Chen said that for Beijing, "one China" is a "principle," but for Taiwan, it is an "issue" and as such, both sides can discuss a solution. He added that he has urged the leaders of both sides to use wisdom to solve the issue.
"If Beijing had understood the appeal four years ago, then cross-strait relations would not be so stalemated and the sentiment of Taiwan identity would not have risen as high as it has, " Chen said.
"With the relentless stifling of Taiwan in military, diplomatic and trade areas by Beijing over the past four years, " he said, "Taiwan people have drifted further away from Beijing."

He cited as an example polls in recent years showing that those who identify themselves as Taiwanese rather than Chinese have increased to more than 50 percent, which was something unimaginable in the past.
"If the Beijing authorities will not adjust their policy toward Taiwan, the developments will be more unfavorable for them, " Chen warned.

In view of this, he said that he broached a peace and stability interaction framework -- one of the two questions put forward in the March 20 referendum vote -- so that both sides can negotiate and the stalled cross-strait relations can return to normal.
"The policy to unite Taiwan people, seek a stable cross-strait relationship, a stable society and prosperous economy will remain unchanged in the next four years, " the president said.

To promote peace and stability under a cross-strait interaction framework, he said he has commissioned Lee Yuan-tseh, president of Academia Sinica and respected Nobel laureate, as a co-convener to push for the operation of such a framework.
He also expressed the hope that the United States will play a more active role in helping build up the friendship between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

On his plan to write a new constitution and implement it in the next four years, he stressed that to put the new constitution to a referendum in 2006 is a goal of democratic reforms and a time schedule for deepening democracy, and will by no means represent a timetable for Taiwan independence.

"We seek the long-term national wellbeing and efficiency of the government by putting the new constitution to a referendum vote, " he said, adding that the referendum will have nothing to do with a vote on independence.
He reiterated that he will base constitutional reforms on the principles of "openness and transparency" and the premise of "no change of the status quo or sovereignty."

The NCAFP delegation was led by its president, George D. Schwab, with members including former Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs Winston Lord, Donald S. Zagoria and UC Berkeley Professor Robert A. Scalapino.
The delegation earlier visited opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, who lost by a small margin to Chen.
During the 90-minute meeting, Lien said that the issue of cross-strait relations lies in "what is the status quo? " He said he believes the status quo should be no advocacy of Taiwan independence.

Judging from former President Lee Teng-hui's words that "Taiwan has no need to declare independence, " he claimed that the "pan-green camp"-- referring to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) -- has made "status quo" equal to "Taiwan independence." Former President Lee is the spiritual leader of the TSU.

DOC.HEADLINE: PINGTUNG COUNTY CHIEF TO BECOME INTERIOR MINISTER

TEXT.P: Pintung County Magistrate Su Chia-chuan has been appointed by Premier Yu Shyi-kun to take over the post of interior minister, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan announced Monday.
Lin Chia-lung made the announcement after the premier met Su at his official residence.

Pan Mong-an, general-secretary at the Pingtung county government, attributed Su's appointment to his outstanding performance over the past six years. Su is now serving a second four-year tenure in the southern county.
Pan expressed his belief that Su's new posting will help the ruling Democratic Progressive Party seize a larger number of seats in the year-end legislative elections.
The vacancy left by Su will be filled by a successor to be appointed by the central government, as Su has served more than half of his current term, he added.

Su will succeed outgoing Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien, who offered to resign earlier in the day to assume responsibility for the gun attack on President Chen Shui-bian when he was campaigning in southern Tainan City on the eve of the March 20 president election.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LOCAL CHAPTER CHIEF PAYS RARE VISIT TO CKS MAUSOLEUM

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 's Hsinchu County chapter chief paid a rare visit Monday to the late President Chiang Kai-shek's mausoleum at Tzuhu in the northern Taiwan county of Taoyuan.
Lin Wei-chou, chairman of the DPP Hsinchu County chapter, headed more than 40 DPP members who paid tribute to the late president, as Monday marked the 29th anniversary of Chiang's death.

It marked the first time that a senior DPP member has visited Chiang's mausoleum. Surprised by Lin's action, the Tzuhu management at first sent more than 10 security officers to keep guard, but the visit ended smoothly and peacefully.

Lin, a graduate of National Taiwan University's Graduate Institute of History, said that through his study of Taiwan's history, he had come to conclude that Chiang made certain contributions to Taiwan.

At a time when ethnic rifts have become increasingly serious in the wake of the March 20 presidential election, Lin said he hopes his move can help defuse ethnic divisions and contribute to social harmony.
"Let history belong to history. I hope those who live on this island will identify themselves with this island," Lin said.

Even though the DPP won the election, Lin said, he feels uneasy about the mounting ethnic confrontation and Taiwan's future development. "I hope the 23 million Taiwan people can live harmoniously and work together for Taiwan's progress," he added.

In the fiery and bruising presidential campaign, ethnic origin was used by some politicians as a tool to woo voters. Ethnic rifts seemed to become more serious after mainland-born opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan narrowly lost the election to incumbent Taiwan-born President Chen Shui-bian. Lien has filed two lawsuits to nullify the election on the grounds that an election-eve shooting of Chen unfairly swayed sympathy votes in Chen's favor.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTER PROMISES TO CONVEY APPEAL OF STUDENTS TO PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Education Minister Huang Jung-tsun visited college students going into the fourth day of a sit-in relay fast Monday at Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei.

The students started the sit-in under the arch of the memorial hall last Friday. They were briefly dispersed -- literally carried away by police -- Sunday night, but soon returned to resume their protest against the political turmoil since the March 20 presidential election.

Huang expressed his concern about the students, saying that he would like to convey their views to the authorities and that he has coordinated with doctors to check their health and heed their safety.

Chen Cheng-feng, a history student at National Taiwan University who is one of the initiators of the sit-in campaign, expressed hope to Huang that President Chen Shui-bian will come to meet the students face-to-face.

Chen said that they have several appeals and he expressed hope that Huang would convey them to the president, adding that they hope the president will show goodwill and produce a timetable to solve the problems. He said neither the ruling nor opposition parties should continue to divide the people along ethnic lines.
Although Huang was verbally abused as he left the students, he promised to convey their wishes to the president.
Professors from National Taiwan University, National Chengchi University and National Taiwan Normal University also visited the students Monday.
Earlier in the day, Vice Education Minister Lu Mu-ling expressed his concern and the hope that the sit-in will not affect the students' schoolwork.
"The Ministry of Education is unable to address the appeals of the students, " Lu said, but is "concerned about the student's safety, health and schoolwork."
In response, the students said that they have brought their books with them to prepare for upcoming mid-term exams.

Chen told Lu that he does not blame the police who dispersed them Sunday, although he said he felt wrenching pain that those participating in a sit-in, which is quiet, rational, self-disciplined and does not compromise environmental safety, should have been dispersed.

Chen said that they had taken their "spiritual lead" from the "wild lily" student movement of 1990, when college students staged a more than one-month sit-in at the CKS Memorial Hall to push for constitutional reforms and express their discontent over senior legislators who had not faced election since their first terms in mainland China prior to 1949. The Legislative Yuan underwent a comprehensive election in 1992.

"We hope the leaders of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP), as well as those who took part in the 'wild lily' movement but have now arisen as political stars such as Legislator Lo Wen-chia, DPP official Cheng Wen-tsang and Executive Yuan spokesman Lin Chia-lung will come to listen to the voice of the students, " Chen said.
He stressed categorically that they had not been manipulated by any political parties and that more students from colleges and universities in central and southern Taiwan will join their ranks.
If they are dispersed again, Chen said, they plan to break into teams of two and stage the sit-in in front of various government agencies.

Lu urged the students to keep in touch with their schools and their parents. He also instructed police and security guards at the memorial hall to heed the safety of the students, ensure a clean environment and coordinate with National Taiwan University Hospital to send doctors to check their health.
Tsai Huang-lang, DPP whip at the Legislative Yuan, urged the protesters Monday to return to school and leave the election disputes to the judicial authorities.
He also urged the KMT and the PFP to join him in appealing for the students to return to school.
Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that chasing away the students represents disrespect for local government and is likely against the law.
He said that as the students have not obstructed traffic or created noise and their numbers are limited, he sees no need to conduct the large-scale dispersal.

Noting that he had earlier issued instructions that the students were not to be disturbed, he lamented that the National Police Administration bypassed him and gave direct orders to Taipei police to make the raid.
Ma noted that he represented the government when he visited the students in the "wild lily" movement of 1990 and said that "there are such activities in every democratic country."

He accused the ruling party of adopting "double standards, " noting that former DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung and his followers in the past staged a sit-in in front of the off-limits Executive Yuan to highlight the cause of a nuclear-free homeland but the Executive Yuan and police took no action against them.

The students, sitting in front of a big banner bearing the slogan "rebirth of wild lily, " wore headbands and masks. They said that the protest will go on indefinitely and they welcomed other students to join them.

They also released a statement that read: We don't care for blue or green, we want truth and we won't allow politicians to use gimmicks to grab power... We are against discrimination and will not allow politicians to incite ethnic hatred to lead Taiwan to bloody Fascist rule... We will fight for a future based on justice and fairness. We want a government that can be monitored and that will not tell its people to shut up."

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE REMAINS VULNERABLE TO TERRORIST ATTACKS: DEPUTY P.M.

TEXT.P: Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong on Sunday drove home just how vulnerable Singapore remains to terror attacks when he revealed what the Jemaah Islamiah (JI) ringleader had told intelligence officials here.

Speaking to about 600 Inter-Racial Confidence Circles (IRCC) members at the Grassroots Club in Ang Mo Kio, Lee said that detained ringleader Ibrahim Maidin had told officials that Singapore is a target because of the millions of Western tourists who visit and the many U.S. and other multinational companies located in the city-state.
"Singapore is being targeted not for what we did, but for who we are," Lee said.

He added that the JI leader also told officials that the real enemy was initially the United States but that when Singapore began cracking down on the Jemaah Islamiah in 2001, it too became the enemy.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DRAFTS BILL FOR FORMATION OF SPECIAL INVESTIGATIVE COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) came up with a draft bill Monday to pave the way for the establishment of a special committee to investigate the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian.

The bill, if passed into law, will allow for the formation of an 11-member investigative committee to probe the election-eve shooting that slightly wounded President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.
According to the draft bill, the special committee will be headed by the president of the Control Yuan, the nation's supreme watchdog body.
It also requires the special investigative committee to complete a thorough probe within three months and come up with a final report to the Legislative Yuan and the Control Yuan.

KMT legislative whip Liao Feng-teh told a news conference that the draft bill is based on the principle of "case legislation." According to a previous interpretation by the Council of Grand Justice, "case legislation" does not violate the Constitution.

"So our draft bill is constitutional, " Liao said, adding that once it clears the legislature, the formation of an independent investigative committee to look into the shooting will be legal and constitutional.

Two weeks have passed since the March 20 presidential election, and Liao claimed that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration has not taken any active steps to clear up the mystery surrounding the shooting.

"To prevent it from becoming an unsolved case, we feel compelled to come up with the draft bill with a view to integrating the resources of the Legislative Yuan, the Control Yuan and the judicial authorities to get to the bottom of the incident," Liao said.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) claim that the March 19 shooting that grazed Chen's abdomen and hit Lu's right knee unfairly affected the election by giving Chen last-minute sympathy votes. Chen won by a wafer-thin margin of 29,518 ballots, or 0.228 percent of some 13 million ballots cast.

Liao said the draft bill has already been sent to the legislature's secretarial department and that the legislature's steering committee is expected to discus whether to include it into the legislative agenda Tuesday.

"We hope the ruling DPP and its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- will not boycott the bill," Liao said, adding that inability to solve the case will cast a shadow on the DPP administration's legitimacy and affect domestic political stability. The opposition "pan-blue alliance" controls a majority in the legislature.

According to the KMT-drafted bill, the independent, interim investigative committee will have 10 members, with the legislative caucuses of various political parties jointly recommending five professionals, the Control Yuan recommending four Control Yuan members and the state public prosecutor-general occupying the 10th seat. The Control Yuan president will serve as convener of the committee.
The draft bill stipulates that the committee should be formed in 10 days following the promulgation of the bill.

According to the bill, the committee must have legal access to all relevant files and documents and is entitled to seal and keep evidence and documents, as well as to question relevant personnel and ask them to undergo physical checkups.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET ASKS TAIPEI CITY TO RETRACT APPROVAL FOR APRIL 10 RALLY

TEXT.P: Out of grave concern that renewed conflict will break out if a mass rally planned by the opposition camp goes ahead this coming weekend, the central government has issued a statement to the Taipei city government asking it to rescind its permit for the event, Executive Yuan spokesman Lin Chia-lung said Monday.

According to Lin, the Executive Yuan has sent an official notification to the city government asking it to push the municipal police department withdraw its approval for the April 10 demonstration in front of the Presidential Office, to be staged by the opposition "pan-blue alliance " of the Kuomintang (KMT) , the People First Party and the New Party.

Reminding Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou of his own promise that he will not allow Taipei to turn into a city of violence, Lin urged Ma to come up with clear-cut measures in view of a fresh mass protest April 10 -- the latest in a string of demonstrations attended by hundreds of thousands of opposition supporters over the disputed March 20 presidential election.
However, Ma, who is also a vice chairman of the KMT, categorically turned down the proposal and argued that the Executive Yuan has no power to demand that the city follows the Cabinet's bidding.

Despite the fact that the "pan-blue alliance" rally held Saturday at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall plaza ended with scattered clashes between "pan-blue alliance" supporters and police on nearby Ketagelan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office, Ma claimed that "the central government must not pass the buck to the Taipei city government with a set verdict."
Ma pointed out that he is willing to re-consider the Executive Yuan's proposal, but stressed that "it has no power over the Taipei city government, which has full power in this regard."
KMT spokesman Tsai Cheng-yuan pledged later the same day that the April 10 rally will begin and end on time and he said that his party will do its best to maintain public order.

At the same time, a spokesman for the Chungcheng Precinct under the Taipei Municipal Police Department stressed that the police will deal with all possible scenarios in compliance with the law. He called on the "pan-blue alliance" to fully cooperate with police to allow for a smooth and peaceful protest.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINES

TEXT.P: New York Times: 7 U.S. Soldiers Die in Iraq as a Shiite Militia Rises Up.

A coordinated Shiite militia uprising against the American-led occupation rippled across Iraq on Sunday, reaching into Baghdad and the sprawling Shiite slum of Sadr City on the capital's outskirts and roiling the holy city of Najaf and at least two other cities in southern Iraq.
Seven American soldiers were killed in Sadr City, one of the worst single losses for the American forces in any firefight since Baghdad was captured a year ago.

Wall Street Journal: U.S. forces closed off the turbulent city of Fallujah on Monday ahead of a major operation against insurgents following the grisly slayings of four American security contractors last week.
U.S. commanders have been vowing a massive response to pacify Fallujah, one of the most violent cities in the Sunni Triangle, the heartland of the anti-American insurgency north and west of Baghdad.

Meanwhile, supporters of an anti-American cleric rioted in four other Iraqi cities on Sunday, battling coalition troops in the worst unrest since the spasm of looting and arson immediately after the fall of Saddam Hussein. At least 22 Iraqis, eight U.S. troops and one Salvadoran soldier died. Hundreds were wounded as fighting raged in Baghdad, Najaf, Nasiriyah and Amarah.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROBE INTO GUN ATTACK ON PRESIDENT HITS SNAG: TAINAN PROSECUTOR

TEXT.P: The probe into the gun attack against President Chen Shui-bian on the eve of the March 20 presidential election has stalled, with no new progress made, a spokesman for the Tainan District Prosecutors' Office said Monday.

Kuo Chen-ni, the prosecutor in charge of the investigation into the March 19 assassination attempt in Tainan City and head of the "3-19 task force" composed of Tainan district prosecutors, told a daily news conference that the task force has found no new evidence related to the shooting.

Pointing out that 114 out of a total of 127 information tips collected by the task force have been ruled out as having any links with the shooting, Kuo noted that the Tainan prosecution authorities are currently engaged in reconstructing the incident and relocating the many Chen supporters who were filmed near the spot by TV crews.

Kuo also claimed that the task force has not yet read a preliminary report carried out by a team of three forensic experts from the United States that visited Tainan City last week to search for evidence under the commission of Dr. Henry Lee -- a worldwide respected Chinese American forensic scientist who will travel to Taiwan in the middle of this month as part of the investigation.

Lee was invited by State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa to assist in the investigation at the request of the opposition "pan-blue alliance, " which claims that the presidential election was unfair and has demanded a recount through legal process, as well as the establishment of an independent committee under the Legislative Yuan to investigate the shooting.

The slight gunshot wound sustained by Chen in his lower abdomen is believed by the opposition to have given Chen a large number of sympathy votes that allowed him to win a second term in office by a very slim margin of 0.228 percent over the "pan-blue alliance" challenger -- opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIAN MISSION TO HOST LANGUAGE PROFICIENCY CONTEST IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Russia's representative office in Taiwan will host a Russian language proficiency contest later this month in a bid to forge mutual understanding and boost two-way exchanges, a spokesman for the mission said Monday.

George Zinoviev, the first deputy representative of the Moscow-Taipei Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission, said that the mission is slated to host the competition April 22 and sponsor relevant activities in cooperation with National Chengchi University, Tamkang University and Chinese Culture University.

Zinoviev expressed his hope that the people in Taiwan will gain a better understanding of Russia's culture and language through the series of activities to lay a foundation for more frequent and closer bilateral ties.
Scores of Russian-learning students from the three universities are expected to take part in the contest, the first of its kind to be hosted by the Russian mission in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTORS NET BUY NT$102 BILLION OF TAIEX VALUE

TEXT.P: From the start of this year until April 2, foreign investors traded in the bourse with a net buy of NT$102.1 billion (US$3.05 billion) recorded, according to the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX).

Foreign investors purchased NT$1.455 trillion worth of Taiwan stocks, and sold NT$943.4 billion worth of them during the period between the first trading day of this year and April 2, resulting in a net buy of NT$102.1 billion.

Based on the TAIEX statistics, the total value of Taiwan stocks held by foreign investors stood at NT$3.1586 trillion, accounting for 21.98 percent of the overall value of the domestic bourse, an increase of NT$119 billion from the level recorded on March 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUNDATION LAUNCHES PROGRAM TO HELP YOUNGSTERS BEAT THE BLUES

TEXT.P: The non-profit John Tung Foundation on Monday invited pop idol singer Jolin Tsai to be the spokeswoman of a fund-raising program to help youngsters to beat the blues.

Yeh Ya-hsin, director of psychological health of the foundation, noted that suicide is the third-leading cause of death of local youth, and that there are at least three percent, or 72,000 out of 2.4 million youngsters in Taiwan, who suffer from depression, and this is a conservative estimate.
The causes of their depression range from pressure from school work, not enough pocket money, and inharmonious relations with friends, Yeh said.

Though there are counseling services in schools, the counselors may not be able to handle the youngsters' depression, and the first task of the "youngsters embracing the sunlight" program will be to set up a support network on campuses, so that the youngsters suffering from depression can be sent to hospitals or so that doctors can be stationed on school campuses.
The second task will be to collect the dreams of the youngsters and provide them with a chance to realize their dreams so that they can derive some positive values from living a happy life.
The third task will be to establish a Web site for youngsters for their emotional outlet so that psychiatrists and psychological experts can provide an immediate online response to their questions.

The foundation will cooperate with the chainstore 7-11 in its fund raising program until the end of June, and the public is urged to donate their small change. The goal is to raise NT$18 million (US$545,454).

DOC.HEADLINE: INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT SHOULD AIM AT CREATING JOBS: INTEL CEO

TEXT.P: The goal of industrial development should be creating new jobs in the future rather than holding work opportunities that were created in the past, Intel CEO Craig Barrett said in Taipei Monday.

It is wrong for people, even the U.S. presidential candidates, to argue how existing job opportunities should be protected, Barrett said, because any industrial development or business company should target creating new jobs in the days to come rather than preserving old ones.

Speaking at a round-table meeting on how to strengthen Taiwan's competitiveness in the global market in the next wave of competition, Barrett said the world as a whole is becoming an increasingly competitive place and no country, including Taiwan, can be spared the harsh competition.

Barrett said that one of the best ways to judge a country's competitiveness is to find out the quality of its education. Educational essence is seen virtually in every area and in the face of a crucial juncture, education factors hold a decisive key to winning or losing.

He said the United States is currently the most competitive country in the world because it has successfully attracted top-notch people from around the world by providing them a framework of an open society.

DOC.HEADLINE: REVISIONS IN TAIWAN RELATIONS ACT A U.S. ISSUE: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: It is up to the United States whether or not the 25-year-old Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) should be revised, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said Monday.

"The TRA, which will turn 25 April 10, is a domestic law of the United States and we, the people of Taiwan, are in no position to comment on anything about U.S. law, " Chien said during a meeting at the Legislative Yuan Foreign Affairs Committee.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will respect any decisions that the U.S. administration or Congress make should the Americans decide to revise the TRA after they reach a consensus on the matter, Chien added.

The TRA, passed by the U.S. Congress and signed into law by President Carter in 1979 after Washington switched its diplomatic ties from Taipei to Beijing, has since served to protect the interests and security of Taiwan and regulate unofficial ties between Taipei and Washington.

Ling-hu Jung-da, deputy director of the foreign ministry's department of North American affairs said recently that the TRA virtually ensures Taiwan the best possible treatment from the United States next to formal diplomatic ties.
"Taiwan would rather the United States keep the TRA intact than revise it, because attempts to do so could lead to 'unexpected results,'" Ling-hu said.

He added that the TRA is not out of date in any way; rather, it has stabilized relations between Taipei and Washington and has prevented the United States from tilting the balance of power in Beijing's favor over the last 25 years.

Noting that some pro-Taiwan U.S. Congressmen tried in vain to push for a Taiwan Security Enhancement Act in 1999, Ling-hu said that any attempts to revise the TRA might backlash and lead to results not intended by the initiators. Therefore, he went on, Taipei prefers "not to fix it if it is not broken."
Actually, Ling-hu said, the TRA gives the U.S. administration considerable leeway in dealing with Taiwan, and can accommodate most attempts on the part of the Congress to promote bilateral ties.

Also at the Legislative Yuan Foreign Affairs Committee meeting Monday, Chien was asked by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Sun Kuo-hua whether U.S.-Taiwan ties have dropped to their lowest point in 20 years since President Chen Shui-bian proposed a nationwide referendum in Taiwan and carried it out March 20.
Chien said that U.S.-Taiwan ties have been "deep and wide, " and he sees the current bilateral relations as "not bad at all."

Meanwhile, Chien said relations between Taiwan and France had apparently hit a snag before March 20 over the referendum issue, but that bilateral ties have gradually been restored. Chien, nevertheless, said that he would rather not disclose the details of the latest developments for fear that Beijing might try again to intervene or undermine them.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved up against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.020 to close at NT$32.949.
A total of US$580 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$32.949 and fluctuated between NT$32.931 and NT$32.975.

DOC.HEADLINE: NON-PROFIT FOUNDATION LAUNCHES YOUTH SUICIDE PREVENTION NETWORK ONLINE

TEXT.P: The John Tung Foundation and the 7-11 chain convenience stores have jointly created an online suicide prevention network to help Taiwan's 2.4 million teenagers cope with depression and keep a positive outlook on life, a spokesman for the foundation said Monday.
The spokesman called for greater social concern for the many adolescents troubled by depression and pointed out that mental illness is already the third-leading cause behind local teenagers' deaths.

Citing the results of a survey made by the foundation, the spokesman reported that as many as 195,000 local teenage boys and girls went online during the Oct. 2002 - Oct. 2003 period to take part in a program aimed at testing whether they are prone to feel upset easily or even all the time.

In a society that is clouded by lingering conflict and instability since the March 20 presidential election, depressed teenagers are a special group that needs adequate consultation and assistance to help them stay away from attempting suicide, the spokesman said.

In an effort to help many local teenagers lead a healthy and normal life instead of just killing time with video games or abusing drugs, the two organizations also have invited Jolin Tsai, a pop music singer and a teen icon, to promote the activity and call for widespread attention to the many depressed young men and young women in Taiwan society.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market moved up Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April rose 199 points to close at 6,692, with 49,188 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May surged 200 points to end at 6,700, with 530 contracts traded, while June futures rose 180 points to finish at 6,700, with 36 contracts finalized.
September futures gained 173 points to close at 6,700, with eight contracts concluded, while December futures rose 139 points to end at 6,661, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,493 for April, 6,500 for May, 6,520 for June, 6,527 for September and 6,522 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also moved up.
April TE futures rose 11 points to close at 276.3, with 12,004 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained 10.30 points to end at 276, with 104 contracts transacted.
June TE futures rose 8.85 points to close at 275.10, with 12 contracts finalized, while September TE futures gained 7.70 to close at 274, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures rose 26 points to close at 1,039, with 13,260 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures gained 25 points to end at 1,040, with 98 contracts traded.
June TF futures rose 22.8 points to finish at 1,036, with three contract transactions, while September TF futures gained 9 points to close at 1,035, with two contracts finalized.
December TF futures rose 27 points to end at 1,043, with 10 contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: 27 KILOS OF LIQUID KETAMINE IN MAINLAND CHINESE LIQUOR BOTTLES SEIZED

TEXT.P: Police said Monday they seized more than 27 kilograms of liquid ketamine and arrested two suspects at Kaohsiung International Airport a day earlier for smuggling the illegal drug in mainland Chinese liquor bottles.

Police reported that they were tipped off in January that a woman drug trafficker surnamed Fu was planning to smuggling ketamine after she saw how popular it was in pubs and that the ketamine in mainland China was cheap and only a controlled substance.
After three months, police were able to learn of Fu's connection and trace the source of the ketamine from the manufacturer in mainland China.
Fu also used women and youngsters to serve as air couriers to bring in the substance in their luggage, police said.

Police further learned that Fu, together with three other women and an eight-year child, left for Zhuhai in Guangdong province via Macau on March 31 and were scheduled to return on Tombsweeping Day, which falls on Sunday this year.

Fu and another suspect surnamed Lee arrived at Kaohsiung's Hsiaokang International Airport Sunday afternoon and were found to have 96 bottles of mainland Chinese liquor in which the ketamine was hidden.

Fu told police that she bought the ketamine for NT$200,000 (US$6,069) from a drug manufacturer in mainland China and then mixed the drug with water and liquor. Fu said she planned to retrieve the ketamine by evaporation.

Although police arrested Fu and Lee Sunday, they requested that the media not report the case since they knew a second batch of air couriers would arrive later. But the group failed to show up, apparently being tipped off.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended the day higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 137.19 points to close at 6,682.73.
The bourse opened at 6,627.23 and fluctuated between 6,684.77 and 6,555.41 during trading.

A total of 6.23 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$150.68 billion (US$4.50 billion), an increase from the previous day's trading session that saw 5.17 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$120.46 billion.

All eight major stock categories posted gains, with electrical shares moving up the most at 2.9 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 2.2 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 1.6 percent, textile issues at 1.4 percent, bank and insurance shares at 1.3 percent, construction stocks at 1.3 percent, foodstuff stocks at 0.5 percent, and cement stocks at 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 666 to 173, with 140 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE CHIEF TENDERS RESIGNATION OVER ELECTION-EVE SHOOTING

TEXT.P: The National Police Administration (NPA) issued a news release Monday, confirming that its director has tendered his resignation to assume responsibility for the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.

The statement said NPA Director-General Chang Ssu-liang offered to resign verbally immediately after the election-eve shooting in which President Chen sustained a flesh wound across his abdomen and Vice President Lu was hit in her right knee.

With mass protests in front of the Presidential Office over the March 20 presidential election outcome ending peacefully, the statement said, Chang tendered his written resignation to Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien Sunday afternoon. The NPA is subordinate to the Ministry of the Interior.

According to the statement, Chang called a meeting of city and county police chiefs last Friday. During the meeting, the statement said, Chang said he would assume full responsibility for the election-eve shooting. He also encouraged all local police chiefs to make continued efforts to maintain law and order in the wake of the presidential election.

During his nine-month stint as head of the NPA, the statement said, Chang has actively promoted police administrative reforms and beefed up police counterterrorism capabilities to enhance public trust in the nation's police force.
Since Premier Yu Shyi-kun has already accepted Minister Yu's resignation over the shooting, Cabinet spokesman Lin Chia-lung said it's up to the new interior minister to decide on Chang's successor.

Lin said Premier Yu will name a new interior minister before May 12 when the Cabinet will resign en masse in line with a constitutional precedent. The Cabinet has traditionally resigned en masse before the inauguration of a new president. President Chen Shui-bian will be sworn in for another four-year term May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
[Turkish Daily News]: [D-day for Cyprus]
Today will be decision-day for Turkey and the Turkish Cyprus on a United Nations plan for a comprehensive settlement to the 40-year-old problem of power-sharing between the two peoples of the east Mediterranean island.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Eight U.S. Troops Killed in Shiite Uprising; Occupation Forces Battle Cleric's Followers As Widespread Demonstrations Erupt in Iraq.
An armed Shiite revolt against the U.S.-led occupation erupted Sunday in Baghdad and other cities across Iraq's normally quiescent south. Nine soldiers, eight of them Americans, were killed, and three dozen were wounded according to U.S. officials, the paper reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOBACCO AND WINE BOARD TO PUT FORWARD PRIVATIZATION PLAN

TEXT.P: Affected by the liberalization of Taiwan's tobacco and wine market with the island's entry into the World Trade Organization Jan. 1, 2002, the Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Board (TTWB) is planning to transform itself into a market-oriented private company.

TTWB Director-General Hwang Ing-san reported at the Legislative Yuan Monday that the TTWB's market share has been decreasing significantly since Taiwan's WTO entry. He added that the TTWB has been facing stiff competition from overseas tobacco and wine companies, particularly those from mainland China.

He pointed out that the TTWB's rice wine market share has declined to eight percent of the nation's total white wine sales, and that counterfeit "Long Life" brand cigarettes from mainland China already hold a 10 percent share of the market in Taiwan.

Hwang said the TTWB will put forward a plan this month that includes a timetable for carrying out its privatization, which he said is needed to increase its competitiveness and make inroads into the mainland Chinese market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK INDEX UP BY 137.19 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground Monday, with the weighted index moving up 137.19 points to close at 6,682.73.
Market turnover amounted to NT$150.68 billion (US$4.50 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Manila Bulletin: GMA marks her birthday in Lubao. LUBAO, Pampanga -- President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo returns to her hometown and birthplace here to celebrate her 57th birth anniversary today with some 5,000 farmers and local government officials as she inaugurates the housing project, "Gloria Village," to benefit indigent families in this province.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Macapagal aide wants CPP 'fronts' out of polls. WHILE THE government wants the Communist Party of the Philippines (CPP) to lay down its arms in favor of electoral struggle, National Security Adviser Norberto Gonzales is seeking the disqualification from the May 10 elections of six party-list groups he considers CPP front organizations.
The Philippine Star: Power struggle hits Poe's KNP. Midway through the campaign period, the machinery of the opposition Koalisyon ng Nagkakaisang Pilipino seems to have bogged down as KNP officials are reportedly locked in a power struggle to control campaign operations.
The Manila Times: Ex-Christians join Abu. At least 20 Christians who have embraced Islam have joined the Abu Sayyaf and its allied groups to replenish its dwindling membership, an official in the police intelligence community said Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER ANNOUNCES RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: Interior Minister Yu Cheng-hsien announced his resignation in a written statement read by one of his aides Monday, saying that he is resigning to take political responsibility for the election-eve assassination attempt against the president and vice president March 19.

Yu said in the statement that as the top official overseeing the National Police Administration, which is under the Ministry of the Interior, he should take full political responsibility for the shooting incident, in which President Chen Shui-bian suffered a flesh wound to his lower abdominal region and Vice President Annette Lu sustained a minor wound to her right knee.

Yu said he voiced his intention of resigning to Premier Yu Shyi-kun on the day of the shooting on March 19 and then submitted a written resignation to the premier Sunday, which he said reflected his determination to quit.

In the written statement, the interior minister said that he keenly hopes the nation's law enforcement authorities will bring the president and vice president's assailant or assailants to justice as soon as possible so that the mysterious shooting can be solved and the truth brought to light.
The minister also expressed his appreciation to all the members of the law enforcement forces for their hard work in maintaining law and order during and after the March 20 presidential election.
He said that he is taking a week-long leave beginning Monday and that during that period, he will await Premier Yu's answer regarding his resignation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 5, or the 16th day of the leap second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1725: Giovanni Casanova, Italian adventurer famous for his amorous conquests, is born.
1793: President George Washington approves plans for new public buildings and roads in the American capital city.
1827: Joseph Lister, British surgeon and discoverer of antiseptic agents, is born. He demonstrated in 1865 that carbolic acid was an effective antiseptic.
1895: Oscar Wilde, the author of the highly successful plays "The Importance of Being Earnest" and "Lady Windemere's Fan," sues the Marquess of Queensberry for libel.
1896: The first modern Olympic Games begin in Athens.
1900: Spencer Tracy, American actor who won an Oscar two years in a row for "Captain Courageous" (1937) and "Boys Town" (1938), is born.
1915: Jack Johnson, the first black world heavyweight boxing champion, losses his title to the "Great White Hope" Jess Willard.
1916: Gregory Peck, American actor noted for both his fine film performances and his work for humanitarian causes, is born.
1941: Allied forces recapture Addis Ababa in Ethiopia during World War II.
1949: The Chinese national government begins talks with Chinese Communists.
1950: The Executive Yuan grants Taiwan authority to carry out self-government by popular elections in counties and cities within two months.
1951: Julius and Ethel Rosenberg are sentenced to death in the United States for giving away atomic weapons secrets to the Soviet Union.
1954: More than 14,000 Chinese Communist POW's in Korea who refused to return to the Chinese mainland take their oath to join the ROC armed forces.
1955: British Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill announces his resignation. He is succeeded by Foreign Secretary Sir Anthony Eden.
1960: The film "Ben Hur" wins 10 Oscars.
1964: Douglas MacArthur, American general who served as U.S. chief of staff and commanded the Allied forces in the South Pacific during World War II, dies at the age of 84. He commanded U.N. forces in Korea until a conflict over strategy led to his dismissal by President Harry S. Truman.
1975: President Chiang Kai-shek passes away in Taiwan at the age of 89.
1976: Howard Robard Hughes, American film producer, aviator, and multimillionaire, dies at the age of 71. He founded Hughes Aircraft Corporation, broke the air speed record in 1935, and flew around the world in record time in 1938.
1976: The National Youth Commission reports helping some 31,000 youths find jobs since its establishment 10 years earlier.
1982: The British task force to oust Argentinian forces from the Falkland Islands sets sail.
1988: Arab gunmen seize a Kuwait Airways Boeing 747 flying from Bangkok to Kuwait. The 111 hostages aboard were freed on April 20 when the hijackers surrendered in Algiers.
1989: A political pact between the independent trade union federation Solidarity and the government of Wojciech Jaruzelski ends Communist rule in Poland.
1990: The Republic of China reestablishes diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Lesotho. Peking (Beijing) severs ties with Lesotho two days later.
1991: President George Bush orders U.S. Air Force transport planes to begin dropping supplies to Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq.
1994: Israel begins to withdraw from the Gaza Strip.
1998: Japan's 3,911 meter-long Akashi Kaikyo Bridge, the world's longest suspension bridge linking the main islands of Honshu and Shikoku, is opened to traffic.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Lin I-hsiung pays a visit to James Soong, chairman of the newly founded People First Party, to seek PFP support for the abolition of the upcoming National Assembly election.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian holds amiable talks with the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, in a landmark encounter at the Presidential Office.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A good honest man, after educating the people for seven years, will be able to lead them to war."

A year-old deal that offers AIDS drugs at a steep discount to 16 countries has been expanded to all the world's poor nations, a key step toward making treatment available to millions of vulnerable patients, the paper said.

The Philippine and Chinese governments yesterday broke ground and launched the first phase of the most awaited North Rail Manila-to-Ilocos project aimed at reviving and modernizing rail transport north of Manila that has been abandoned for a quarter of a century.

THE WARNING of a looming power crisis aired by a private power generation firm was more imagined than real and could be meant to create pessimism amid the heated election campaign, Energy Secretary Vincent Perez said Monday.
The Philippine Star: 'MILF faction harboring Janjalani, JI members' A renegade faction of the Moro Islamic Liberation Front is harboring Abu Sayyaf chieftain Khaddafi Janjalani and 30 Jemaah Islamiyah (JI) militants, possibly without the sanction or knowledge of the MILF commanders who are negotiating peace with the government, Defense Secretary Eduardo Ermita said yesterday.
