Los Angeles Times: 7 U.S. Troops Killed as Shiite Anger Erupts.
Thousands of followers of a virulently anti-American Shiite cleric heeded his calls for an uprising against the U.S. occupation, stroming police stations and government buildings in several major cities and triggering clashes that left at least eight coalition soldiers and 21 Iraqis dead.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO CHANGE METHOD OF APPOINTING LAWMAKERS FOR OVERSEAS COMPATRIOTS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party is set to change the way in which its lawmakers-at-large representing overseas compatriots and Taiwan's aboriginal people are selected, according to a decision reached Tuesday by the party's Central Executive Committee.

Under the new system, these lawmakers-at-large, usually appointed by political parties in proportion to the number of votes the party garners in the legislative elections, will be named by the party chairman with the approval of the Central Executive Committee.

The committee also decided that party members who serve as president, vice president or mayors of municipal cities may double as members of the party's Central Standing Committee -- the party's policy-making body.
The two decisions will take effect after being approved by the the party's National Congress in July.

DOC.HEADLINE: CITING HONG KONG AS EXAMPLE, DPP URGES PEOPLE TO VALUE DEMOCRACY

TEXT.P: Beijing's attempts to suffocate Hong Kong's democracy by denying its people the right to elect their chief executive through a popular election provide sharp contrast between the dictatorship of the Beijing regime and the democracy of Taiwan, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) official said Tuesday.

Noting that Beijing's National People's Congress is set to decide to keep intact the current government system in Hong Kong under which the chief executive of the government is chosen by a group of representatives rather than by the people, Yang Meng-hsun, deputy director of the DPP's Cultural and Propaganda Department said it belies Beijing's 1997 promise of "one country, two systems, " the formula it touted when it took over Hong Kong.

By turning down the Hong Kong people's calls for a popular election of their chief executive, Beijing has exposed its contempt for democracy and its lack of care for the will of the people, which is unimaginable in a democracy, Yang said.
He said the Taiwan people should draw a lesson from Hong Kong that democracy is the country's most valuable asset and the only safeguard upon which it can count.

In order not to damage the country's democracy, Yang urged the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party to settle their disputes with the DPP over the March 20 presidential election through the judicial process.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC FOREIGN MINISTER DECORATED

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Eugene Chien decorated his Dominican Republic counterpart, Francisco Guerrero Prats, with the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon Tuesday for his contributions in promoting bilateral ties.

Guerrero, who arrived that day at the head of a delegation for a five-day visit, will visit Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien and Government Information Office Director-General Huang Hui-chen to learn more about Taiwan's situation in various fields.

During their stay, the delegates will also tour various economic and cultural establishments, including the National Palace Museum, China Steel Corp., China Shipbuilding Corp. and the Taipei World Trade Center.
They are scheduled to leave Taipei April 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEADER BLAMES GOVERNMENT FOR CRISES FACING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan is facing three major crises of constitutional operation, trust and security, and the government should swiftly deal with these in a responsible manner, opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said Tuesday.

Speaking at a press conference after meeting with a visiting delegation of the National Committee on American Foreign Policy (NCAFP) , a United States think tank, Soong said that these crises will lead to regional instability if the government fails to settle them quickly.

Soong, who was the running mate of the failed presidential candidate in the March 20 presidential election, Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, accused President Chen Shui-bian, who won re-election by a slim margin of 29,518 votes out of more than 13 million ballots cast, of handling too slowly the disputes over the election and the election-eve shooting of Chen and Vice President Annette Lu, which he claimed gave Chen a lot of sympathy votes and victory in the hotly contested election.
According to Soong, Chen should be held responsible for the democratic crisis.

The delegation included NCAFP President George D. Schwab, China specialist Donald S. Zagoria and former Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs Winston Lord, as well as UC Berkeley Professor Robert A. Scalapino.
The group came to Taiwan to observe the post-election situation. They also met separately with Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on the same day.

According to the American visitors, Wang said after the meeting, Washington is waiting with great interest for Chen's May 20 inaugural speech, with particular regard for what he will have to say about his "four noes plus one " pledge announced four years ago, his new mainland China policy and writing a new constitution.
The delegation, which is scheduled to leave for Beijing Wednesday, called on both Chen and Lien a day earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENIOR MINISTER URGES YOUNG SINGAPOREANS TO PURSUE THEIR DREAMS

TEXT.P: young S'poreans Singapore, April 6 (CNA) Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said Monday that young Singaporeans are just not street smart enough and are too used to everything going like clockwork.
He challenged them to get out of their protected shells to pursue their passions and dreams.
"If you are totally focused on your studies and other pre-occupations, then perhaps you are sleeping, but not dreaming," he said, adding that "it is time for you to wake up and dream."

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN CHILD RECOVERING WELL AFTER CRANIO-FACIAL SURGERY

TEXT.P: A five-year-old boy from Indonesia who suffers from Von Recklinghausen's disease was recovering well after recent surgery to remove a gigantic tumor covering his face and neck, officials of Tzu Chi Hospital in eastern Hualien said Tuesday.
Chang Yao-jen, deputy director of the hospital, said that as the boy was recovering well, they plan to carry out the second phase of surgery to reconstruct his jaw in two weeks.

The boy, named Novendry, came to Taiwan last month from Indonesia's western island of Padang with the assistance of a group of volunteers from the Taiwan-based Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, who met Novendry when they traveled to the island to offer free medical services.

Novendry, who has suffered from Von Recklinghausen's disease since he was a year old, has been almost blinded in his right eye by the pressure caused by the facial tumor. With his thick facial skin and lips, and protruding teeth, the boy had been cruelly dubbed "hippo boy" by the ignorant Indonesian villagers.
Von Recklinghausen's disease is a genetic disorder of the nervous system that causes tumors.
Tzu Chi officials estimated that Novendry will probably have to stay in Taiwan for two more months to undergo long-term facial reconstruction operations.
Even after the facial reconstruction, Tzu Chi medical team members said, the boy could suffer other facial problems in the years to come. They said his case will require long-term medical planning.

Last year, a teenage boy from Burkina Faso who also suffered from Von Recklinghausen's disease received a series of similar operations at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Linko, Taoyuan, northern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENT GROUP CALLS FOR END TO PARTISAN POLITICS

TEXT.P: A group of students from various universities asked the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) to stop partisan politics Tuesday, claiming the nation is tired of it.

The students, led by Wei Kai-ta from National Chengchi University, said they want democracy, rule of law and a bright future rather than violence, adding that they set up a Web site to air their ideas March 23 and have received the endorsement of more than 20,000 students from universities and colleges around the island in just two weeks.

Dressed in white shirts and colorful scarfs, Wei and other members of his group said that the partisan bickering between the DPP's "pan-green camp" and the opposition's "pan-blue alliance" has continued well after the March 20 presidential election and he claimed it has forced all people in the country to take sides in the dispute.
He urged the two camps to stop their political confrontation and embrace a colorful future for the country which is neither green nor blue.

Legislator Liao Feng-teh, the KMT whip at the Legislative Yuan, lauded the students' efforts to heal the rift between the two political blocs, while his DPP counterpart, Legislator Tsai Huang-liang, said the students' desire is exactly what the DPP has fought for in the past.

In a jab at the KMT and the PFP, Tsai said the two opposition parties' demand for a special committee to probe the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and his administration's handling of the shooting incident is a travesty of the rule of law and that the two parties' repeated calls for rallies to protest the election outcome are likely to cause violence.

In an unrelated story Tuesday, a sit-in fast staged by around 10 students at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall went into its fifth day, with one protester collapsing and being rushed to a nearby hospital for treatment.
The students vowed to keep up their protest until Chen's administration agrees to their demand for a thorough investigation into the shooting.

The shooting, on the eve of the March 20 presidential election, is at the center of a dispute between the DPP and the "pan-blue alliance, " which believes the shooting contributed to Chen's success in winning a second term.

Although the students were driven away by policemen Sunday on the grounds that they had overstayed their protest permit, they returned to the site afterward and were greeted Tuesday by supporters who gave them bouquets of flowers.
Among the supporters was Lien Fang Yu, the wife of failed presidential candidate Lien Chang. She visited the protesters Tuesday afternoon and, without saying a word, placed flowers in front of them.

Answering questions from journalists camped out at the memorial hall, Lien Fang Yu said she felt pain in heart to see the student protesters, who are even younger than her own children. She said she could not understand why the government had not responded to their demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR EARLY END TO POST-ELECTION DISPUTES

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday he hopes that all the disputes over the March 20 presidential election can be resolved through the existing legal system as early as possible.
Yu made the remarks at an annual conference of the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI), one of the largest trade associations in Taiwan.
Yu said he feels regret that confrontation and unease linger in local society more than two weeks after the bitterly fought presidential race.

"I hope both the ruling and opposition camps can refrain from resorting to irrational ways in dealing with election disputes. Let's remain calm and rational and use solely legal means to settle all election disputes.
Noting that the global economic competition is fierce and brutal, Yu said Taiwan cannot afford to lag behind in the current wave of economic recovery.

"Our economy will suffer and the well-being of our posterity will also be affected if we drag feet on reform," Yu warned, adding that the government is actively promoting 10 new major construction projects.

"If all those projects can be implemented with the Legislative Yuan's support, our economic growth rate will largely increase this year and transformation of local industrial structure will also accelerate," he added.

The defeated opposition "pan-blue alliance" presidential candidate, Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, has contested President Chen Shui-bian's narrow re-election victory. In addition to filing lawsuits to nullify the election and call for a new election, Lien's camp has staged large-scale protests at the Presidential Office square. Last weekend's demonstration ended in violence and the camp has applied to stage another one this weekend, causing public misgivings.
Speaking on the same occasion, CNFI President Hou Chen-hsiung said he hopes all domestic political parties can engage in constructive competition instead of power struggle.
"Continued inter-party war of attrition will only Taiwan's competitiveness," Hou warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHOOTING OF PRESIDENT REGARDED AS MURDER ATTEMPT: PROSECUTOR

TEXT.P: The March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian is being regarded as an attempted murder or assassination for the time being, a prosecutor in the southern city of Tainan said Tuesday.

Kuo Chen-ni, a prosecutor at the Tainan Prosecutor's Office who concurrently serves as spokeswoman for a special task force investigating the election-eve shooting, made the remarks while reporting on the progress being made in the case.
Kuo said the investigative panel has collected 130 leads, 116 of which have been ruled out as having anything to do with the case. The remaining 14 leads are still being pursued and scrutinized.

Judging from the available evidence and an analysis of the crime scene, Kuo said she believes that the assailant could have hidden among crowds of cheering supporters while firing shots at Chen and Vice President Annette Lu.

But Kuo said the investigative panel still cannot determine the motivation of the gunman. "We are also not sure whether the shooter's skill was good or bad. In any event, we are not ruling out any possibility at the moment," she added.
The shooting slightly wounded both Chen and Lu. Chen was grazed on the abdomen and Lu was hit in the right knee as they were campaigning in Tainan a day before he was narrowly re-elected March 20.

The defeated contender, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, has demanded that the vote be held again, partly because he insists the shooting unfairly influenced the election. Lien has also insinuated that Chen orchestrated the shooting, although he has provided no evidence to support his claim.
By the same token, however, investigators have yet to find any suspects or solid leads to satisfy the skeptics.

Meanwhile, Dr. Henry Lee, a prominent Taiwanese-American forensic expert, said in a TV interview in the United States that the gunshot that wounded Chen was not self-inflicted and he also claimed that it was not the work of professional assassins.
He said in a the cable TV interview aired Tuesday that he would need to see more evidence before he could comment on other theories about the shooting.
"We can rule out a professional assassination. We can also rule out that it was self-inflicted," Lee told Taiwan's TVBS cable news at a conference in the United States.
"About other (theories) , we have to see the evidence and then exchange opinions, " said Lee, who has been invited by State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa to assist in probing the shooting.

The TV report did not include any explanation from Lee about why he has ruled out a professional hit or a self-inflicted shooting, but Lee said earlier that a professional assassin would have used a more powerful gun and would have aimed at the chest, heart or head.
According to investigators, the handgun used in Chen's shooting was a cheap weapon made in an illegal workshop.
Chen is eager to debunk conspiracy theories that he staged the incident to give him an edge in the tight presidential race.

Lee is leading a group of forensic experts who visited Taiwan last week to analyze evidence and the shooting scene in Tainan. The scientists also examined the open-top jeep Chen and Lu were riding in when they were shot.
Lee is scheduled to arrive in Taipei this weekend to help with the investigation and is expected to issue a final report later this month.

Lee has been involved in several high-profile U.S. cases, including the O.J. Simpson murder trial and the still-unsolved JonBenet Ramsey child abduction and murder case. Recently, he has been involved in record producer Phil Spector's murder case.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO CONDUCT PERSONNEL OVERHAUL IN CABINET, PARTY: AIDE

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will conduct a comprehensive lineup change in the Cabinet and the party in the wake of President Chen Shui-bian's re-election, DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday.

Chang said the ruling party is poised to carry out the personnel changes in an effort to repay its supporters for their backing, which helped Chen win a second four-year term in office in the March 20 presidential election.
Changes will be across the board so as to create the best lineups for both the Cabinet and the party to meet the supporters' high expectations, Chang said.

In the face of an extra national congress of the DPP slated for April 10 and a full national congress planned for July, Chang said that personnel at the party's headquarters and local city and county committees will be adjusted during the April-July period in a gesture of its resolve to do well in the legislative polls at the end of the year, as well as in the city and county chief elections scheduled for next year.

Chang's remarks came after the announcement a day earlier by the Executive Yuan that Pingtung County Magistrate Su Chia-chuan will take over the Ministry of the Interior from Friday, a change that has stirred up widespread speculation as to the extent of a Cabinet reshuffle.

Su will replace outgoing Interior Minister Yu Cheng-shien, who offered to resign to assume responsibility for Chen's shooting during a campaign rally in the southern city of Tainan on the eve of the presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROPOSAL FOR SPECIAL COMMITTEE PUT ON LEGISLATIVE AGENDA

TEXT.P: A bill initiated by the two opposition parties of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) to set up a special committee to look into the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian was put on the Legislative Yuan's agenda Tuesday.
Thanks to the support of the Alliance of Independent Legislators, the two parties succeeded in putting the bill on Friday's session of the full chamber by a vote of 30 to 10 at the Rules Committee.

The KMT and PFP, whose joint ticket in the March 20 presidential election was defeated by President Chen by a narrow margin, suspect the shooting on the eve of election day and the ensuring response made by Chen's administration were political tricks and insisted on naming a special committee under the Legislative Yuan to look into it.

However, Legislator Lee Chun-yi of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, which is opposed to the idea, said his party would request negotiations if the KMT and the PFP, which commands a narrow majority in the legislature between them, tries to refer the bill to related committees for deliberation by a vote on Friday.

In that case, the KMT and PFP won't be able to put the bill to a vote for four months unless a consensus is reached among various parties in the negotiations according to regulations of the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTMENT FLOODING INTO HI-TECH PARK IN NORTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Fueled by an encouraging domestic economic outlook, a large amount of investment has flooded into the Hsinchu Science-based Industry Park (HSIP) in northern Taiwan, the park's management said Tuesday.

Citing statistics compiled by the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Administration, administration Director James J. Lee said that NT$23.9 billion (about US$725 million) -worth of investment expected to be injected by 12 companies at the HSIP was approved by the administration in the first quarter, an astounding increase of 795 percent compared to the year-earlier level.

In addition, applications for capital increment worth NT$3.76 billion by nine companies which are already operating at the HSIP were also approved by the administration in the three-month period, marking a 241.8 percent growth over the previous year's level, Lee said.

According to Lee, other investment projects worth about NT$10.9 billion raised by another 46 companies are awaiting approval, an indication that the current economic recovery has led to strong investment willingness.

However, Lee pointed out that demand to open up shop in the science-based industrial parks in northern, central and southern Taiwan is running high, creating space problems at these compounds, which have been doing their best to lure investment in recent years.
For instance, he said, the HSIP and the Central Science-based Industrial Park (CSIP) in Taichung County succeeded in courting 54 and 32 companies to set up footholds, respectively, last year.

In view of the fast-growing business at these facilities, in which hi-tech companies are provided with a suitable environment and infrastructure for their operations, Lee said that the various park management authorities should step up the pace of drawing up new development plans for these parks.

The HSIP -- Taiwan's first hi-tech stronghold, which has been the major driving force behind the country's economic development over the past two decades -- is aimed at housing IC and semiconductor companies, while the CSIP is mainly geared toward opto-electronic businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
: New York Times: Generals in Iraq Consider Options for More Troops.
American commanders in Iraq are developing contingency plans to send more American forces to the country if the situation worsens.
President Bush said Charlotte, N.C., said that he intended to stick to the June 30 date for giving control of the country to an interim Iraqi government, even as he conceded that the new government's structure had not been settled. He vowed that the violence would be put down.
Wall Street Journal: Many Companies Avoided Taxes Even as Profits Soared in Boom.
More than 60% of U.S. corporations didn't pay any federal taxes for 1996 through 2000, years when the economy boomed and corporate profits soared, the investigative arm of Congress reported.
The General Accounting Office disclosed that corporate tax receipts have shrunk markedly as a share of overall federal revenue in recent years, and were particularly depressed when the economy soured. By 2003, they had fallen to just 7.4% of overall federal receipts, the lowest rate since 1983, and the second-lowest rate since 1934.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW INTERIOR MINISTER VOWS FULL DEVOTION TO JOB

TEXT.P: Interior Minister-designate Su Chia-chuan said Tuesday that he will devote his full energy to his new job after he assumes office Friday.
Su, incumbent magistrate of Pingtung County in southern Taiwan, made the remarks at a news conference held at the Executive Yuan.

Su will fill the post left vacant by Yu Chen-hsien, who resigned Monday to assume political responsibility for the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu in the southern city of Tainan.

The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) is one of the largest government departments, tasked with issues related to public order, fighting crime, civil affairs, social welfare services, land administration and urban planning.
Su said he will work with all MOI staff to improve public order and social welfare. "It's no easy task, but I'll do my utmost to live up to public expectations," he said.
Su said he will come up with a detailed work agenda after consulting with professionals at various MOI departments in line with the principles of policy continuity and creativity.
His first tough decision after assuming office will be choosing a new police chief.

National Police Administration (NPA) Director-General Chang Si-liang has also tendered his resignation to take the blame for the March 19 shooting that grazed Chen in the abdomen and hit Lu in the right knee.

Su said Chang is an outstanding police officer with a down-to-earth work style. "His departure is a great loss to the NPA," Su said, adding that he will consult with Chang and refer to public opinion in selecting a successor.

"Capability, seniority and credentials in police administration, public order maintenance and criminal investigation will be major concerns in deciding Chang's replacement and party affiliation will play no role, " Wu said, adding that he will make a final decision soon after taking up his new post.
Su further said he hopes to cooperate with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou to handle an opposition "pan-blue alliance" protest rally at the Presidential Office square scheduled for April 10.

The Cabinet has suggested that the Taipei city government revoke the permit it issued for the rally, but it remains unclear whether the city government will accept the Cabinet's advice. Under the Municipal Self-Governance Law, it is up to the city government to decide whether to approve such activities.

Su, 48, has been Pingtung county magistrate for six years. Upon his re-election in late 2001, he became the first incumbent county chief to manage to win a second four-year term in Pingtung in two decades.

He has been a National Assembly member and served two terms as a legislator before becoming Pingtung county chief in 1997. At that time, Pingtung was reputed as a hotbed of gangsterism. Su pushed for county administration reform. Through his strong lobbying, the central government lifted a longstanding construction ban on many parts of the island's southernmost county, paving the way for rezoning of farmland and facilitating the county's economic development.
Over the past six years, Su is said to have transformed Pingtung from "a home of gangsters" to "a home of the bluefin tuna fishery and of top-quality bell fruit."

Su set a goal of developing Pingtung into a heartland of tourist and high-tech industries. He has initiated a number of cultural and recreational programs to attract tourists, including the Bluefin Festival and the Kenting Wind Bell Festival. He has also turned the previously military-controlled Tapeng Bay into a new beach resort.

Moreover, he has managed to acquire central government approval for locating many national-level construction projects in Pingtung, including a new-style export processing zone, a biotechnology and agriculture park and a Hakka culture park, to help create jobs and revitalize the economy in the otherwise rural county.
Su's efforts have earned him wide popularity in the county. He also ranks high in many public opinion surveys on the performance of local government chiefs.

According to tallies compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Pingtung County's average household income registered a 10 percent increase last year, the highest growth rate among all cities and counties around the nation.

In the run-up to the March 20 presidential poll, Su had campaigned very hard for Chen's re-election bid. The Chen-Lu ticket garnered nearly 300,000 ballots in the county, outpacing the rival "pan-blue alliance" ticket of Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong by more than 84,000 ballots. Moreover, the county electorate's participation rate in the nation's first referendum, held simultaneously with the presidential election, also exceeded 50 percent.
Political observers say Su's administrative achievements and his outstanding presidential campaign record won him Chen's trust and the important Cabinet post.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTHERN TAIWAN ON HIGH ALERT AGAINST DENGUE FEVER

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan's service center in southern Taiwan urged heightened alert Tuesday against dengue fever and asked passengers returning from Indonesia and Vietnam to keep tabs on their own health.

In view of the continued spread of dengue fever in Southeast Asia, and with the situation in Indonesia and Vietnam especially serious, the service center invited related government agencies to a dengue fever prevention meeting in Koahsiung, southern Taiwan, Tuesday.

Taiwan has so far reported 18 cases of imported dengue fever, but no local cases. The government has activated its dengue fever awareness mechanism, with central and local governments joining hands to check the outbreak of the mosquito-borne disease.

Officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Transportation and Communications, Ministry of Education, Ministry of National Defense, the Council for Economic Planning and Development, the Department of Health, the Environmental Protection Administration, the Council of Labor Affairs, the Central National Health Insurance Bureau and eight cities and counties in southern Taiwan attended the meeting to discuss how to effectively stem the disease.

Tseng Shu-hui, the health department's disease control official, said that Taiwan people traveling to Southeast Asia should avoid mosquito bites, and should take the initiative to seek medical treatment if they develop symptoms of fever upon returning.
Schools and communities should destroy the breeding grounds of mosquitoes before May to cut down on the possibility of infection.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. THINK TANK CALLS ON TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: A major think tank from the United States called on Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou Tuesday to exchange views with him on the post-presidential election situation in Taiwan and cross-strait relations.
The National Committee on American Foreign Policy (NCAFP) members expressed concern about the disputes in the wake of the March 20 presidential election.

The Taipei mayor, who concurrently serves as a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , explained to them about the "pan-blue alliance's" appeal for a recount of the ballots, and its lawsuit to nullify the election.

President Chen Shui-bian won re-election to a four-year term by a razor-thin margin of 29,518 votes against his rival of the "pan-blue alliance," KMT Chairman Lien Chan, out of more than 13 million votes cast.

Lien, claiming the election to be "unfair, " and was marred by voting irregularities as well as an election-eve shooting of the president, which he believed had given the president last-minute sympathy votes and swayed the election in his favor.
The delegation also expressed concern about the development of cross-strait relations after President Chen Shui-bian was re-elected.
Mainland China has basically no trust in President Chen, Ma said, adding that there will be a great many hurdles to be overcome for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to reopen stalled talks.

The delegation included NCAFP President George D. Schwab, China specialist Donald S. Zagoria, and former Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs Winston Lord, as well as UC Berkeley Professor Robert A. Scalapino.
The group came to Taiwan to observe the post-election situation. They called on President Chen and defeated presidential candidate Lien Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOMB HOAX ANGERS PASSENGERS ON BOARD UNI AIRWAYS FLIGHT FOR KINMEN

TEXT.P: A bomb scare on a UNI Airways Corp. flight from central Taichung to the outlying island of Kinmen Tuesday morning was a hoax, but many Taiwan passengers were nevertheless angered at having their trips to mainland China delayed.

The UNI Airway's DH-8 plane with 58 passengers left from Chingchuankang Airport in central Taichung at 9: 55 a.m. and was informed of the bomb threat when it was some 12 nautical miles away from Shangi Airport on Kinmen Island, where it was scheduled to land at 10: 50 a.m.
Police evacuated all the passengers and underwent a thorough security check of the aircraft and passengers' baggage at the Kinmen airport.

Kinmen Air Traffic Control issued an alert after receiving information from UNI Airways that indicated that it had been told that explosives had been planted on board Flight 685 from Taichung to Kinmen.

Kinmen Air Traffic Control immediately activated a set of emergency mechanisms to cope with the situation by dispatching fire engines and a task force of policemen equipped with bomb-disposal equipment to sweep the airplane and the passengers' bags.

After security checks that lasted until around noon, no explosives were found either aboard the aircraft or inside passengers' baggage. The bomb threat was lifted at 11: 40 a.m. and the four fire engines were recalled from the airport.

Although the incident was eventually deemed a hoax, many passengers, mainly Taiwan businessmen preparing to transfer to mainland China via the "mini three links, " were angered by the fake bomb incident and complained bitterly for having to wait for the security check before proceeding with their journeys.

Kinmen and Matsu islands are the key transshipment hubs for a large number of Taiwan businessmen who have to travel frequently between Taiwan proper and mainland China. The two frontline islands maintain direct trade and transport links with Xiamen and Fuzhou ports in Fujian province -- the so-called "mini three links" -- in the absence of full links between Taiwan and the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MANUFACTURERS PREPARING TO TAKE PART IN RIYADH COMPUTER EXPO

TEXT.P: Eighteen Taiwan computer and information technology companies have registered to take part in the 2004 GITEX computer expo scheduled to be held in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia April 18-22, a source from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

The MOFA is rendering assistance to the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) to facilitate CETRA's sponsoring of the Taiwan manufacturers' participation in the GITEX, said Yu Chin-rong, a deputy director of the MOFA's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs.
The MOFA assistance is aimed at bolstering Taiwan's diplomatic and economic ties with friendly countries while helping Taiwan manufacturers explore overseas markets around the world, Yu said.

Yu added that Saudi Arabia is the largest market of information technology products in the Middle East, absorbing some US$4.6 billion worth of IT products in 2003, which was 40 percent of the entire IT market in that part of the world the previous year.

The 2003 GITEX attracted some 70,000 visitors, Yu said, adding that the number of visitors to the show is expected to be larger this year as the economies in the Middle East have been gaining steam in general.

TAIEX Index futures for May dropped 40 points to end at 6,660, with 430 contracts traded, while June futures lost 30 points to finish at 6,670, with 21 contracts finalized.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended the day lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 47.19 points to close at 6,635.54.
The bourse opened at 6,715.90 and fluctuated between 6,744.56 and 6,627.01 during trading.

A total of 6.74 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$159.99 billion (US$4.78 billion), an increase from the previous day's trading session that saw 6.23 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$150.68 billion.

Seven of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with cement stocks moving down the most at 1.5 percent, followed by construction stocks at 0.9 percent, electrical shares and bank and insurance shares both at 0.8 percent, plastics and chemical shares and foodstuff stocks both at 0.7 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.3 percent.
Textile issues moved up 0.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 581 to 251, with 144 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD TO STEP UP PROTECTION OF BLUEFIN TUNA FISHING VESSELS

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Administration (CGA) has stepped up patrols and protection of Taiwan fishing vessels now that the bluefin tuna season has come to southern Taiwan.
CGA officials noted Tuesday that bluefin tuna operations for fishing ships in southern Taiwan and sea areas of the Philippines are in full swing each year between March and June.

In view of the incidents involving disputes between Taiwan and the Philippines fishing boats during the period in recent years - with occasionally resulting in Taiwan fishing ships being impounded and incurring heavy losses, -- the CGA had worked out the protection plan.

The CGA will send large patrol boats to navigate the Bashi Channel twice a week so that they can quickly respond to any incidents related to fishery disputes along the patrol line and maintain order at sea.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO DRUG TRAFFICKERS NABBED AT CKS AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Two men were arrested at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport Tuesday while attempting to smuggle more than seven kilograms of heroin into Taiwan from Indonesia, coast guard officials said.
The two drug traffickers, surnamed Pan and Chunag, packed the 7.59 kilograms of high-grade heroin in Indonesian-style cushions. The two men were traveling as part of a tourist group.

Coast guard officials said they were tipped off earlier this year that a drug trafficking ring was planning to smuggle heroin from Indonesia into Taiwan by air. The ring had originally planned to use fishing boats to smuggle the contraband drug, but it dropped the plan when coast guard authorities began to intensify offshore patrols last November to thwart human smuggling and drug trafficking.

The seized heroin has an estimated street value of NT$75 million, coast guard officers said, adding that law enforcement authorities will continue their investigations into the two traffickers' accomplices in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 6, or the 17th day of the leap second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1199: Richard I, king of England known as "The Lion-Hearted," dies at the age of 42 from an infected wound received while besieging Chaluz Castle during the Crusades. He was captured in Austria in 1192 and held as a prisoner by Holy Roman Emperor Henry VI until England ransomed him in 1194.
1789: George Washington is unanimously elected the first president of the United States.
1814: French Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte is forced to abdicate unconditionally.
1868: Japanese Emperor Meiji establishes the Charter Oath, which was to change the form of government. He also promises an assembly.
1890: Anthony Fokker, Dutch-born American aircraft designer and manufacturer who revolutionized aerial warfare by synchronizing a front-mounted machine gun with the rotations of a propeller, is born.
1896: A modern version of the ancient Olympic Games is opened in Athens, initiated by French aristocrat Baron Pierre de Coubertin, whose goal was to stimulate interest in physical fitness and promote understanding between nations.
1913: The provisional Senate of the Republic of China is dissolved.
1917: President Woodrow Wilson signs a resolution entering the United States into World War I on the side of Great Britain and France.
1933: The Ministry of Finance of the Republic of China orders the implementation of a yuan currency system instead of the tael currency system.
1935: Emperor Henry Pu Yi of Manchukuo, a puppet regime installed by the Japanese, visits Japan.
1938: The ROC armed forces score a major victory over Japan in the battle of Taierchuang, killing more than 30,000 Japanese troops.
1941: German bombers raid Belgrade, killing some 2,500 people. Hundreds of buildings were destroyed during the attack, including the National Library with its countless medieval manuscripts.
1945: U.S. naval forces score a major victory against the Japanese at Kyushu.
1953: Scrap bombs explode on a hillside in Nanshihchiao, Taipei County, killing or injuring more than 300 people.
1963: The Executive Yuan proclaims December 25 "Constitution Day" and a national holiday.
1965: The United States launches Early Bird I, the first commercial communications satellite, from Cape Kennedy, Florida.
1968: Pierre Trudeau becomes prime minister of Canada, succeeding Lester B. Pearson.
1975: Yen Chia-kan, vice president of the Republic of China since 1966, takes the oath of office as the nation's second constitutional president.
1976: Millionaire recluse Howard Hughes dies in a plane while being flown to a hospital, leaving a fortune of US$2 billion.
1976: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo renews his call to communist cadres and mainland China military personnel to rise up against the Maoist regime following the April 5 riots at Tienanmen Square in Beijing.
1993: Two mainland Chinese youths, Liu Bao-zai and Huang Shu-kang, hijack a Southern Airlines' Boeing 757 passenger plane to Taiwan.
1994: A missile hits a plane as it attempts to land in Rwanda, killing all people onboard, including President Cyprien Ntaryamira of Burundi and President Jubenal Habyarimana of Rwanda.
1998 Citicorp merges with Travelers Group Inc., becoming the largest corporation in the world in terms of assets. The new firm is worth more than US$70 billion.
1999: Indonesian President B.J. Habibie assures visiting ROC Economics Minister Wang Shih-kang that his administration will take all necessary measures to protect Taiwan investors in Indonesia.
2000: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bien says that the administration under his leadership will honor all accords and commitments that have already been inked with foreign countries.
2001: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, calls on former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui and expresses his gratitude for Lee's promotion of increased Taiwan-Tibet exchanges during his term in office.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To allow people to go to battle without first instructing them is to betray them."

DOC.HEADLINE: QANTAS TO BE MAJOR INVESTOR IN BUDGET AIRLINE BASED IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Singapore budget travelers will soon be spoiled with choice, as several airlines have started or are planning to offer budget flight services.
Australia's Qantas has said it will launch a new budget airline based in Singapore in a joint venture with Temasek Holdings and two local businessmen.
Temasek is already backing another low cost airline, Tiger Airways, in conjunction with Singapore Airlines, and it is not ruling out making further investments in this fast-emerging market.
Temasek has already held talks with Malaysia's AirAsia, which is looking to spin-off a separate budget carrier in Singapore, but there has not been any news so far on that score.

Qantas is investing S$50 million (US$29 million) to obtain a 49.9 percent stake in a new low-cost airline that may be called Jetstar Asia after Qantas' existing domestic budget carrier. Temasek will have a 19 percent stake.
It is slated to start flying by the end of this year to Asian cities within five hours of Singapore's Changi Airport, becoming the fifth budget carrier to fly out of Singapore.

The other backers are Tony Chew, chairman of diversified group Asia Resource Corp., who will have a 21.1 percent share, and F.F. Wong, chairman of Boustead Singapore, who will own 10 percent. Neither of the two businessmen is new to the aviation industry as they both were previously involved with Myanmar Airways.

The new airline will enter a market that is already crowded with players. Qantas has said it is confident it will get a licence to operate out of Singapore. As for the routes, the airline has said that is up to the authorities to hand out.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE YOUNG SINGAPOREANS TURNING TO MATCHMAKING AGENCIES

TEXT.P: The number of matchmaking agencies in Singapore has grown from less than five a decade ago to more than 20 today.

"Over the years, until the last five years, you can see the pattern has changed. More and more young people have begun to accept matchmaking, " said Hong Poh Chu, director of the matchmaking agency D'Match. She said the agency has successfully married off 1,000 people over the past decade.
On Monday, Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong even recommended matchmaking as a way to give fate a nudge in modern day Singapore.
"This is one industry where the government feels that the more players we have, the better. Maybe we should even consider granting some tax incentives," Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO HOLD RALLIES IN TAINAN TO THANK VOTERS WHO RE-ELECTED CHEN

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will stage one rally each in Tainan City and Hsinying, Tainan County on April 11 to thank those who voted to re-elect President Chen Shui-bian on March 20, DPP officials said Wednesday.

For the sake of security, the DPP officials said President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu will appeared at the rallies in Hsinying and Tainan City alternatively, rather than together, amid tight security.

The two narrowly escaped serious injury from an assassination attempt on March 19 in Tainan City while parading through the streets in an open-top jeep. Chen suffered a flesh wound to his abdomen while Lu was injured in her right knee. No one has yet been arrested.
At the April 11 rally, both Chen and Lu will wear flak jackets and the podium on which they will deliver their speeches will be surrounded with bullet-proof glass, according to DPP officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN URGED NOT TO CHANGE CROSS-STRAIT TIES DRASTICALLY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 6 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian should not make drastic changes to his administration's policy toward cross-Taiwan Strait relations during his second term, former ROC Premier Vincent Siew said in Washington, D.C. Tuesday.

Siew, a vice chairman of Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT), made the remarks at a seminar on the long-term impact of Taiwan's March 20 presidential election in which President Chen narrowly defeated KMT Chairman Lien Chan to win another four-year term.
The seminar was co-sponsored by the Carnegie Foudnation, a U.S. think tank, and Taipei-based Taiwan Strait Exchanges Foundation, with the participation of Taiwan and U.S. scholars and experts.
Siew said Chen's re-election reflects a strengthening of Taiwan identity.

"It also indicates that under mainland China's strong diplomatic and military pressures, the people of Taiwan have actively sought to determine their own future destiny as well as Taiwan's status," Siew said, adding that this trend will have a far-reaching impact on the development of cross-strait relations.
Beijing should not ignore this political reality, Siew said. More important, he said, Beijing should not equal Taiwan identity to support for Taiwan independence.

In his view, Siew said, the majority of Taiwan people want to maintain the current status quo of "neither unification nor independence" and to further strengthen cross-strait economic exchanges in a stable environment.
Meanwhile, Siew said Chen's narrow victory indicates that he should refrain from making radical changes to his administration's cross-strait policy.

IN the run-up to the presidential poll, Chen unveiled his plan to forge a viable mechanism for peaceful and stable interaction with mainland China. Siew urged Beijing to seriously consider Chen's proposal and present its own blueprint for negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: NET FOREIGN CAPITAL INFLOW REACHES US$2.9 BILLION IN MARCH

TEXT.P: As of March, the cumulative net inward-remittance from foreign investors in Taiwan's securities markets totaled US$75.5 billion, with the foreign net inward-remittance reaching US$2.9 billion in March, according to statistics of the Ministry of Finance.

The statistics compiled by the finance ministry's Securities and Futures Commission show that the net inward-remittance from foreign investors in the island's securities markets totaled US$2.2 billion in February.

Commission officials noted that the London-based FTSE Group announced on March 24 that it will upgrade Taiwan to its list of "developed markets, " and on the same day officials of the group visited the commission to learn more about related regulations governing Taiwan's securities markets.
The officials said they will continue communicating with the FTSE Group on several points that the group questioned on foreign investment in the Taiwan stock market.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT LINKS MAY BE EASIER IN NEXT TWO YEARS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait are expected to handle more actively issues with regard to the opening of direct cross-strait transportation, trade and postal services links in the next two years, making the so-called direct " three links" easier, a government official said Wednesday.

Speaking at a seminar on cross-strait ties, Huang Jay-cheng, a vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , said that cross-strait interactions will be more favorable with a less politically sensitive environment in the Taiwan Strait that is expected to appear in the next two years because there will be no nationwide elections during that time.

Beijing has shown great interest in three elections: Hong Kong's legislative elections in September, the United States' presidential election in November and Taiwan's legislative elections in December, Huang noted, adding that the outcome of Taiwan's legislative elections will play an influential role in Beijing's thinking about cross-strait relations.
If cross-strait relations can be maintained with peace and stability, Huang predicted, cross-strait issues will proceed smoothly and will be easier to be settled.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL ELECTRONICS SHOW OPENS AT WORLD TRADE CENTER

TEXT.P: The five-day Taipei International Electronics Show and Taipei International Optoelectronics Show opened Wednesday at the Taipei World Trade Center.

Some 400 domestic and foreign companies are participating in the joint exhibition organized by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) and the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association (TEEMA).

According to statistics compiled by TAITRA, Taiwan manufacturers received export orders worth US$15.04 billion in February, an increase of 34.6 percent over the same month last year. Among the categories, the electronic sector registered annual growth of 56.36 percent.

With the world economic perspectives are promising and Taiwan's exports of electronic products are booming, the organizers of the exhibition are doing all they can to inform foreign buyers about current events in Taiwan's electronics industry.

In addition to exhibiting items including cable television equipment, computers and peripherals, digital cameras, electronic machinery, and illumination devices, there are also several pavilions highlighting the newest technologies in information appliances, wireless broadband applications and nanotechnology applied in electronics.
The visitors can also see high-end DVD products developed locally through the cooperation of the Industrial Technology Research Institute and 29 renowned manufacturers, the organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENT PROTESTERS CALLS FOR NATIONAL AFFAIRS CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: A group of university students who have been staging what they call a sit-in "hunger strike" at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall since April 2 asked Wednesday for a meeting with President Chen Shui-bian and the organization of a national affairs conference.

The students, whose number has dropped from about 10 to four Wednesday told journalists camped outside the memorial hall they hoped President Chen Shui-bian would visit them and exchange views with them.
The students have been taking turns not eating for 12 hours each.

Chen Cheng-feng, a leader of the four said they would drop their requests for Chen to apologize for his manipulation of the mass media, contempt for the Legislative Yuan and the failure of his administration in keeping neutral in the presidential election if he would admit there was political chaos during his first term and apologizes for it.

They also called for a national affairs conference to bring together the country's political leaders to map out improvements for the country in the fields of politics, economy, ties with mainland China and ethnic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT THANKS DOMINICAN REPUBLIC FOR FIRM SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian received Dominican Republic Foreign Minister Francisco Guerrero Prats Wednesday, and expressed his gratitude to the Caribbean country for its firm support of Taiwan in various fields.
Chen said that he will call his Dominican Republic counterpart, Rafael Hipolito Mejia, later the same day to thank Mejia for sending a congratulatory message to him on his re-election on March 20.
Furthermore, Chen added, Mejia also expressed his concern over the election eve assassination attempt on Chen and Vice President Annette Lu that left both with minor injuries.

The Dominican Republic also has rendered its support to Taiwan's bid to join world organizations, including the United Nations and the World Health Organization, Chen noted, citing last September, when the Dominican Republic's representative voiced support for Taiwan's U.N. bid in the organization's General Assembly.

Chen also said that on March 16, both the Senate and the Chamber of Deputies of the Dominican Republic passed resolutions in support of Taiwan's first nationwide referendum, which was conducted on March 20 alongside the presidential election.
Chen wished Mejia success on his re-election bid. The Dominican Republic will hold its presidential election on May 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS, IMPORTS FOR 2004 WILL SET NEW RECORDS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports and imports for 2004 are both expected to set new records of US$150 billion and US$140 billion, respectively, on encouraging growth for the first quarter of the year, a government official reported Wednesday.

Citing statistic compiled by the Ministry of Finance, an official of the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) forecast that the domestic economy will register an all-time high in both outbound and inbound shipments for the whole of this year, boosted mainly by a rebounding world economy.

According to the BOFT official, Taiwan's Q1 exports increased by 22.5 percent to US$39.81 billion over the year-earlier level, while its Q1 imports grew by 31.2 percent to US$37.82 billion, with the country enjoying a trade surplus of US$1.99 billion for the three-month period.
Mainland China and Hong Kong remain the top destination for Taiwan's exports, the official noted.

Meanwhile, Hsu Kuo-chung, director of the Department of Statistics under the Ministry of Finance, said that Taiwan's Q2 exports will exceed the Q1 level to break the US$40 billion level should the global economy continue remaining in a good shape as it is now.
Hsu predicted that orders from the greater China area, Europe and countries in Southeast Asia will expand, while imports from these countries and areas will also grow markedly.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: U.S. Declares Radical Shiite an "Outlaw".
U.S. administrators geared up for a showdown with the anti-American shiite cleric Muqtader Sadr, declaring him an "Outlaw" and making public a warrant for his arrest on charges that he was involved in the slaying of a rival religious leader last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VOWS TO PROTECT FULL FREEDOM OF SPEECH

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday his administration will protect the "100 percent" freedom of speech that the people of Taiwan enjoy today.

Chen made the remarks at a memorial ceremony marking the 15th anniversary of the death of Nylon Cheng, a pro-democracy activist who immolated himself in a drastic move to push for removal of restrictions on freedom of speech during the previous Kuomintang (KMT) administration.
"Although some people say irresponsible speech could lead to social unrest, I would rather see 'excessive' freedom of speech than 'insufficient' freedom of speech," Chen said.

Referring to a raft of allegations against him in the wake of his narrow re-election victory last month, Chen said he will tolerate all those false accusations and harsh criticism instead of "turning back the clock."
"I'm grateful for those who are critical of my policy initiatives or my leadership style and I'll reflect on my words and deeds frequently in the future," Chen said.
Before coming to the Chinpaoshan Cemetery on the outskirts of Taipei to pay tribute to Cheng, Chen said he visited Buddhist Master Sheng Yen, who lives in the vicinity.
"I sought Sheng Yen's illumination and wise counsel. He told me two short stories during our two-hour conversation which offered me fresh inspiration," Chen said.

The first story was related to Buddha Sakyamuni (563-483 B.C.) . According to Sheng Yen, Sakyamuni had often encountered boycotts and opposition from a young monk before he became a Buddha. Even after Sakyamuni's enlightenment, the young monk continued his confrontation with Sakyamuni. Sakyamuni said he was convinced that the monk would also become a Buddha one day. Sakyamuni said the monk's opposition had helped lead to his enlightenment. "Since he can help me become a Buddha, he himself would be able to become a Buddha, too, " Sakyamuni was quoted as having said.

The second story was related to Sheng Yen himself. Sheng Yen recalled that many local Dharma masters once opposed his plan to do advanced studies in Japan. Their opposition prompted a Malaysia-based overseas Chinese to cancel his plan to offer Sheng Yen a scholarship to help finance the study program in Japan. Without the scholarship, Sheng Yen had to redouble his efforts to complete his study program as early as possible to save money.

After Sheng Yen obtained a doctoral degree in Japan and returned to Taiwan, he visited all those who had opposed his Japan study plan to express his gratitude. Some of those Dharma masters were confused by Sheng Yen's move. Sheng Yen told them that without their opposition, he would not have been able to complete his Ph.D. program so quickly.

President Chen said he was moved by these two stories. In the face of disputes over the March 20 presidential election, Chen told many senior members of his ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) present at the memorial ceremony that they should feel grateful.

"We should thank all those who have challenged us. Their questioning and opposition should inspire us to reflect, review and pursue progress. I'll remember these two stories and push myself to reflect and seek continued progress," Chen said.
Since Cheng's death, Chen went on, Taiwan has evolved into a full democracy.

"We have held three direct presidential elections and a nationwide referendum. We have seen the value of Cheng's promotion of freedom of speech and democracy. He sacrificed his life to oppose the previous authoritarian rule. We have come a long way to establish a legal system to ensure full freedom of speech. We should treasure this system," Chen said.

Even though the opposition camp's large demonstrations in protest against what it calls an "unfair" presidential election have created chaos and inflicted huge social costs, Chen said, the government has addressed the issue with respect and tolerance.
"I have found comfort in the fact that we have learned to solve disputes with reason and legal means instead of violence and suppression," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR RATIONALITY, CALMNESS IF APRIL 10 RALLY GOES AHEAD

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun called Wednesday for rationality and calmness in the run-up to a mass rally planned by the opposition on Saturday, stressing that national economic development should not be hampered by politics.

Yu made the call at a weekly Cabinet meeting after hearing a briefing about the April 10 demonstration planned by the opposition "pan-blue alliance," which has vowed to call hundreds of thousands of supporters to protest in front of the Presidential Office against the disputed March 20 presidential election.

Emphasizing that the country's economic development and industrial progress must not be blocked by political unrest at this juncture, Yu urged the opposition leaders to collaborate in forging social and ethnic harmony to maintain law and order in Taiwan.
Any dispute should be settled through a legal process in a society ruled by law, and the people of Taiwan keenly hope that a genuine democratic system takes root in the country, the premier said.
Yu again urged the Taipei City Government to take adequate precautions against all possible scenarios which might break out at the April 10 rally in Ketagelan Boulevard to prevent violence.

A concerned Yu said he was worried that the organizers will be unable to cope with the situation should the emotional public get out of control and attack police as they did in the aftermath of a protest at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall plaza on April 3.

The Executive Yuan has sent an official notification to the Taipei City Government and the Ministry of the Interior asking them to demand that police authorities under their jurisdiction take adequate measures and deploy the necessary forces, he noted.

The premier also urged the students who have been staging a sit-in hunger strike at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall plaza since late night of April 2 to go back to school as quickly as possible, citing his grave concern for their health and study.

The group of about 10 university students started taking turns fasting for about 12 hours each day six days ago, demanding a meeting with President Chen Shui-bian and the establishment of an independent committee to investigate the election-eve shooting of President Chen during a campaign rally in southern Tainan City, among other things.
Chen sustained a flesh wound across his abdomen in the shooting, which has been viewed by the opposition as winning the president enough sympathy votes to be re-elected.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET MAKES PROSPEROUS ECONOMY MAJOR GOAL IN PLAN FOR 2005

TEXT.P: The administration will make economic prosperity and increased competitiveness major goals for next year, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Wednesday.
The premier made the remarks as the Executive Yuan passed a draft plan for administrative work in 2005.

Yu said that the draft is based on four principles unveiled recently by President Chen Shui-bian: unite the people of Taiwan, stabilize cross-strait relations, stabilize society, and ensure a prosperous economy.
In addition, he said the administration will speed up the transformation of the nation's economy so that another "economic miracle" can be achieved.

The administration will also accelerate the promotion of its five-year, NT$500 billion (US$15.15 billion) 10 new major construction projects program, to bring about growth in the areas of culture, education, traffic and communications, and technology and water resources.

Moreover, he said, all government agencies will continue to implement ongoing and upcoming projects to protect national security, continue cracking down on corrupt "black gold" politics, promote the wellbeing of minority groups, pay attention to human rights, promote education and culture, and enhance the welfare of laborers.

He also instructed that all the major platforms unveiled by President Chen during his presidential campaign should be included in the administrative plan for next year and carried out by various government agencies so that the public will be satisfied with the performance of the Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT FAILS TO WIN MAJORITY OF HOKLO VOTES: KMT OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) failed to win a majority of the Hoklo vote -- referring to Taiwan people whose ancestors immigrated here from Fujian Province -- which led to its failure in the March 20 presidential election, a KMT official said Wednesday.

In the second meeting of the party's Central Standing Committee after the March 20 election, Chen Chien-chih, deputy executive director of the party's Policy Coordination Committee, said the KMT garnered only 40 percent of the Hoklo vote, which accounts for nearly 63 percent of the population, while President Chen Shui-bian won 60 percent.
Chen defeated Lien in the election by a margin of less than 30,000 votes out of 13 million ballots cast.

Kuan Chung, president of the KMT-run Institute on Policy Research and Development, supported Chen's claims, saying that opinion polls conducted by his institute showed that Lien and Chen were neck-and-neck among the Hoklo voters in the run up to the election. Following the March 19 shooting in which Chen was slightly injured, the balance was tilted, with Hoklo people, especially women, shifting in large numbers away from Lien to Chen.

Lien who presided over the Wednesday meeting as party chairman said he didn't care about his personal loss or win in the election, but he wants a truth about the March 19 shooting to calm down the KMT supporters.

Lien and his running mate, People First Party Chairman James Soong, have been staging protests in Taipei ever since March 20 to pressure the Chen administration into agreeing to their demands for a committee to be established under the Legislative Yuan to investigate the election-eve shooting of Chen.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is a vice chairman of the KMT, said his city government will defend the people's right to assemble and protest, but he added that the organizers should appeal for public support for these protests with a clear aim and should have pickets on hand to prevent protesters from scuffling with police, as that will cause a backlash in public opinion.

As mayor of the capital city, Ma is caught on the horns of a dilemma. He has to keep order and peace in the city while at the same time allowing the supporters of the KMT to express their frustration with the election.
The Executive Yuan has asked Ma to withdraw a permit for a KMT protest April 10 after some protesters were hurt in scuffles with the police April 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DRAM YIELD WILL GROW BY 35 PERCENT IN 2004: IEK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's yield of dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips this year will reach US$4.3 billion, an increase of 35 percent over last year, officials of the Industrial Economics and Knowledge Center (IEK) under the Industrial Technology Research Institute said Wednesday.

Due to rosy prospects for DRAM, together with manufacturers' continuing to expand their operations to 12-inch fabs, and each DRAM maintaining a price of US$4-US$5, Taiwan's DRAM output is expected to account for over 20 percent of the global market share, according to an IEK report.
Powerchip Semiconductor Corporation in the first quarter of 2004 yielded 22,000 wafers per month in its 12-inch fab and will have reached at least 40,000 units per month by the end of the year.
ProMOS Technologies Inc. produced 14,000 wafers per month in the first quarter and will be turning out 25,000-30,000 wafers per month by the end of the year.
In addition, a new fab joint-venture by Nanya Technology Corporation and Infineon Technologies AG is producing test-run wafers and will have achieved 12,000 per month by the end of 2004.
Based on the IEK report, Taiwan's global market share of DRAM will rank third in the world, behind only South Korea and the United States, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINES

TEXT.P: New York Times: Fierce Fighting With Sunnis and Shiites Spreads to 6 Iraqi Cities.

American forces in Iraq came under fierce attack on Tuesday, with as many as 12 marines killed in Ramadi, near Baghdad, and with Shiite militiamen loyal to a rebel cleric stepping up a three-day-old assault in the southern city of Najaf.
It was one of the most violent days in Iraq since the fall of Saddam Hussein, with half a dozen cities ignited.
Wall Street Journal: Iraq Insurgents Mount Attacks on Many Fronts.

Anti-American insurgents in Iraq mounted multiple, organized attacks against U.S. forces, including a deadly attack on Marines in the central Iraq city of Ramadi, in the biggest military challenge to the American occupation since major combat ended nearly a year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: TASK FORCE PROBING SHOOTING SCREENING OUT MAINLANDERS, EXPATRIATES

TEXT.P: A task force formed to investigate the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu is reviewing video tapes of the rally at which the shooting took place to screen out possible suspects, including mainlanders and expatriates, in the shooting, an official of the National Police Administration (NPA) said Wednesday.

Liu Shih-ling, NPA deputy administrator, said that in addition to local people, the task force is also screening out mainland Chinese arriving in Taiwan and illegal immigrants, as well as "suspicious expatriates."

He made the remarks when he was reporting to the National Defense Committee in the Legislative Yuan on the investigation into the election-eve shooting that left Chen and Lu slightly injured when they were canvassing in Tainan, southern Taiwan on the eve of March 20 presidential election.
The task force has urged the public and television companies to provide all available photos, video tapes and other information to help the probe.

The task force is questioning all those who have been previously convicted with possession of guns in Tainan, as well as radicals, the unemployed, and anyone who is unhappy with the government in neighboring cities and counties, as well as those arriving in Taiwan from mainland China and foreign expatriates.
"We are screening out the suspects and narrowing the field of our investigation," said Liu.

In a related development, security officials said Wednesday at the Legislative Yuan that they did not follow standard security procedures for the president and vice president after the shooting because they were not clear about the situation.

Chiu Chung-nan, deputy commander of a special squad under the National Security Bureau, also said that although their handling of the incident was a fiasco, nothing will be concealed and the NSB will not shirk its responsibilities.
Chiu made the remarks at a legislative appellation session during which legislators pointed out several incidents of negligence on the part of security staff.

Legislators from the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party asked why the security men did not form a human shield to protect the president, why there was no immediate sealing off of the area and why security men did not hear when Lu cried out that the president had been shot and that they should immediately leave the scene. They also questioned why the head security guard, Chen Tsai-fu kept on talking on the phone without noticing the bullet hole that had appeared in the windshield of the open-top jeep in which they were riding.

The noise of firecrackers, which are traditionally fired during election rallies, and the smoke they generated, drowned all other sounds and sights, including Lu's warning, Chiu said, adding that they initially thought the president had been hit by a firecracker, so that a standard procedure was not activated and followed through upon.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO REVIEW PRICE OF ELECTRICITY IN TWO WEEKS

TEXT.P: Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long said Wednesday that the ministry will review electricity prices in two weeks in the face of rising international crude oil and coal prices.
Chen made the remarks at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Energy Committee to screen the budget of Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) for this year.

As the recent hike in international oil and coal prices has resulted in an increase of the cost of electricity generation, Chen said that the ministry will have a total review on the price of electricity and the impact a price adjustment will have on the local economy and industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AGRICULTURAL GOODS APPEAL TO FOREIGN BUYERS: TAITRA

TEXT.P: Taiwan agricultural goods have great appeal for foreign buyers, as scores of them from Asia and Europe attended a procurement seminar organized by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) Wednesday at the Taipei World Trade Center, according to a TAITRA spokesman.

More than 30 foreign buyers and importers from chain stores and supermarket groups in Hong Kong, mainland China, Japan, South Korea and Britain seized the opportunity to purchase local agricultural products, the spokesman said, adding that Taiwan businesses should also be encouraged to grab the opportunity.

Wednesday's seminar was just a warm-up for a series of similar activities slated for June through October in cooperation with hypermarkets in Hong Kong, mainland China, Singapore and Japan to promote Taiwan fruit and vegetables, the spokesman revealed.

Oriental City, a popular shopping center in northern London, has also for the first time sent officials to purchase locally grown produce at the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture-sponsored event, according to the spokesman. Other foreign-based business concerns, including APPOLO and City Super from Hong Kong and Lotte from South Korea, also dispatched buyers to the event.

Oriental City now sells some 25,000 items of Asian origin in its supermarket, from countries that include mainland China, Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, Japan and South Korea, an Oriental City executive said. However, only a few products from Taiwan, such as noodles and condiments, are shelved there, he pointed out.
According to the Oriental City official, the area in which the shopping center is located has a large Asian population that is very interested in food from Taiwan.

Oriental City registers an average monthly customer turnout of about 10,000 and a business turnover of US$9.5 million recorded last year solely by its supermarket. It encompasses restaurants, a shopping mall and a supermarket.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFEATED CANDIDATE WITHDRAWS LAWSUIT CALLING FOR NEW ELECTION

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" said Wednesday it has temporarily withdrawn a lawsuit that sought to nullify the bitterly contested March 20 presidential election.

Lawyers of the defeated "pan-blue alliance" presidential candidate, Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, said the withdrawal of the election nullification suit was mainly aimed at avoiding interference with the proceedings of another alliance lawsuit that demands an annulment of the election result and a recount of all ballots cast in the election.
The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) filed the election result nullification lawsuit with the Taiwan High Court March 29 and the election nullification lawsuit April 5.

The first petition calls on the court to nullify incumbent President Chen Shui-bian's re-election victory and hold a recount. The second petition asks the court to declare the whole election invalid so that a new one can be held.

In Lien's first lawsuit, the defendant was listed as the president, while his second lawsuit targeted the Central Election Committee (CEC) and local-level election commissions in various cities and counties around the country.

Opposition lawyers said their decision to temporarily withdraw the second lawsuit was based on concerns that the judges might order recounts in both cases, increasing the confusion. A separate panel of judges would have had to handle the second petition and might have ordered a recount as an interim step in deciding whether there were enough irregularities to order a completely new election.
"If the court decides to have simultaneous recounts in both cases, and if the recount methods are different, then they could interfere with each other," said opposition lawyer Lee Yi-kuang.

Lee said the plaintiff plans to re-file the election nullification suit before April 10. By that time, he said, the plaintiff and the defendant in the first lawsuit should have reached an agreement on the recount method.

The High Court held a hearing last Friday on the first lawsuit and gave the two sides five days to sort out terms for the requested vote recount. Chen has already endorsed a complete vote recount, but the two sides have yet to reach agreement on who should pay for the recount and on several other technical details. The two sides were required to present their recount proposals to the High Court Wednesday.

According to the plaintiff's proposal, opposition lawyers said they want judges, not election staff, to play a key role in the recount. They claimed that judges are more likely to be impartial than election staff.

The lawyers also want the recount to be detailed, with judges poring over each disputed ballot, comparing the rolls of registered voters with the names of voters who actually cast ballots. The president favors having election workers handle the recount.
"We want judges to certify each disputed ballot," said opposition lawyer Yu Ta-wei.

Opposition lawyers said they know this could slow down the process, going against opposition demands for a quick recount made shortly after the election. "Even though this recount method will need more time and manpower, we think it's worth the investment, " said Yu.

Chen defeated Lien by only 29,518 ballots, or 0.228 percent out of more than 13 million cast, after an election-eve assassination attempt on the president that Lien claims swung the March 20 poll in Chen's favor.
