DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG SHOWS NATURE OF BEIJING REGIME: CABINET SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: If Hong Kong had Taiwan's democracy, it would not be at the disposal of another regime, the Cabinet spokesman said Wednesday.

Lin Chia-lung made the remarks in the wake of a ruling by mainland China that Hong Kong must get Beijing's blessing before trying to change the way it selects its leader and its lawmakers -- giving the Beijing authorities more power over such matters than is spelled out in the Basic Law, Hong Kong's mini-constitution.

The Standing Committee of mainland China's National People's Congress put forth the ruling in an interpretation of the territory's constitution, a move viewed by many Hong Kong people as an attempt to quash growing calls for full democracy.
"One should see clearly the nature of the Beijing regime from this matter," Lin said, adding that the mainland will never agree to the existence of a democratic Taiwan.
Lin said that the mainland's implementation of the "one country, two systems" formula it uses to govern Hong Kong has proved to be fake and anti-democratic.
As the mainland tries to smear Taiwan's democracy, likening its democratic development to "Taiwan independence and violence, " Hong Kong provides a good comparison of the two systems, Lin said.
He said it is obvious that if Beijing will not allow even partial democracy in Hong Kong, it will never allow full democracy in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO ENTICE U.S. INVESTMENT IN AUGUST

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou is scheduled to visit the United States in August to entice investment from the hi-tech sector, a Taipei city government official said Wednesday.
Ma is planning to visit San Diego, Boston and Pennsylvania, where many world renowned hi-tech industries are located, to market Taipei's investment environment, the official said.

He will focus on enticing leading companies in the wireless communications, venture capital and biotechnology sectors, and will encourage them to sign letters of intent and set up Asian operational hubs, or R&D centers in the city, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM SHOWS WILL OF THE PEOPLE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen claimed Wednesday that Taiwan's first nationwide referendum "reflects clearly" the Taiwan people's position regarding the military threat from mainland China.

The referendum was conducted alongside the March 20 presidential election, with voters being asked whether Taiwan should buy more anti-missile systems amid the mainland's increasing missile threat and whether the island should negotiate a "peace and stability" mechanism with mainland China for future interaction between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Only 45.12 percent of the 16 million eligible voters cast ballots in the referendum, so it failed to pass the 50 percent threshold of total voters to be considered valid.

In a seminar organized by Taiwan Advocates, Yao noted that more than 90 percent of those who cast their ballots said "yes" to both questions, which he claimed "indicates clearly" to the world community that the Taiwan people would choose to fight the mainland missile threat rather than keeping silent as they have in the past.
Yao said more referendums will be held in the future, although he added that consensus must be reached on a sound referendum system that can last."

According to Huang Kun-hui, vice chairman of Taiwan Advocates, a total of 7.45 million eligible voters cast referendum ballots, exceeding the 6.57 million votes received by President Chen Shui-bian in the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Under fire in bloody uprising.
American, British and other coalition troops were struggling to maintain control of Iraq as the uprising spreads.
Financial Times: Murdoch shifts listing to US.
News Corporation, the media group led by Rupert Murdoch, is to move its primary stock market listing from Australia to the US, marking the end of an era for the company founded by the media mogul's father 50 years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Lithuania's President Ousted by Parliament.
Lawmakers removed Lithuanian President Rolandas Paksas from office in a narrow vote Tuesday because of his ties to a businessman who police said was linked to the Russian mob, ending the worst political crisis in the Baltic state's recent history.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUJIAN CHILD SAVED FROM HUMAN TRAFFICKERS VIA ONLINE CHAT

TEXT.P: A teenage girl from Fuzhou, the capital of the southern mainland Chinese province of Fujian, who was abducted to Taiwan by cross-strait human traffickers April 2, has been rescued by law enforcement officers in southern and northern Taiwan working in concert.
Relying totally on the Internet and information technology, the Kaohsiung county police managed to discover where Lin Ling, 13, was being held captive by her abductors, and went to her rescue.

Noting that Lin, a sixth grader at an elementary school in Fuzhou City, did not come voluntarily to Taiwan to work in the sex trade, Kaohsiung county police said the child should be sent back under an arrangement to be made by Taiwan's intermediary body, the Straits Exchange Foundation, and its Beijing counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

The story of Lin's Taiwan ordeal began on the night of April 5 when a resident of Fengshan, Kaohsiung County, went to the Fengshan Police Department for help, claiming that a friend of his living in Fuzhou had called him to say that his 13-year-old daughter had been abducted to Taiwan, probably by members of a "snake-head" ring planning to sell her to an underground brothel in Taiwan.

According to the Fengshan resident, surnamed Cheng, the only thing he knew besides the fact that Lin Ling had been abducted to Taiwan, was that Lin had sent S-O-S signals to her schoolmate, Weng Shi, via an online chat engine called QQ, over the last several days.
Through Cheng, the Kaohsiung county police were able to contact Weng, and from that child, they managed to connect with Lin Ling, also via QQ.

The police officers were thrilled when they received their first response from Lin Ling. Their excitement, however, was soon dissipated as Lin had no idea where she was and could not identify her location due to the tight control imposed on her by her Taiwanese abductors.

While keeping waiting for new messages from Lin, the police called for help from specialists from an information technology teaching institute and a telecommunications company in an attempt to trace the spot from where Lin's QQ messages were being transmitted.
By early Tuesday morning, the police and the IT experts had finally pinpointed Lin's location -- a room in a residential building in Hsinchuang, Taipei County.
They immediately contacted their counterparts in Taipei County, who immediately raided the building and saved the girl.

According to Lin, she and several of her schoolmates went to play near Mt. Fuzhou April 1, where she was first conned by several men who persuaded her to "have fun somewhere else." She was then forced aboard a fishing boat headed for Taiwan.
Lin's parents only became aware that their daughter was missing two days later and called for help from their friends in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved down against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, losing NT$0.066 to close at NT$32.924.
A total of US$642 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$33.000 and slid to a low of NT$32.910 during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GEARING UP TO ATTRACT JAPANESE TOURISTS

TEXT.P: In an all-out effort to attract Japanese tourists to Taiwan, the private sector and the government have joined forces to work toward that aim, a tourism industry source said Wednesday.

Affected by the situations in both Taiwan and Japan, Taiwan must do its best to upgrade its attractions and inject new incentives to its promotional campaigns aimed at courting Japanese tourists, the source said.

To achieve the objective set by the government of luring more than 1 million tourists from Japan this year, Taiwan has to display a greater attraction and appeal in the face of a decline in Japanese tourist arrivals, the source added.

Since the beginning of this year, the number of Japanese tourists to Taiwan has been dropping. Statistics compiled by the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications show that the number of tourist arrivals from Japan fell by 38 percent and 32 percent in January and February, respectively, as compared to the previous year's levels.
The number for March is not expected to improve due to Taiwan's heated March 20 presidential election and the problems arising from the disputed results, the source predicted.

Tseng Chien-hsun, secretary-general of the Taiwan Visitors Association, claimed that according to tourist agencies in Japan, many Japanese people living in rural areas are still very concerned about whether severe acute respiratory syndrome is still spreading in Taiwan.

This, he said, is an indication that Taiwan has to further enhance and improve its promotional activities in Japan, particularly in small- and medium-sized cities, such as Kobe and Hiroshima, Tseng said, pointing out that such a campaign should be very intensive in every corner in the Japanese market.

According to Tseng, few groups composed of Japanese farmers and livestock raisers -- once the bulk of Japanese tourists to Taiwan -- have traveled to Taiwan for pleasure trips since foot-and-mouth disease broke out here several years ago.
The Taiwan Visitors Association will set its sights on this sector this year in line with the government's campaign, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATOR URGES REVIEW OF ENERGY POLICY

TEXT.P: A legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged the government Wednesday to convene a national energy conference to review energy policies.

DPP Legislator Lai Chin-ling made the remarks at a seminar held at the Legislative Yuan by a civic group known as the No Nuke Taiwan Union. Participants in the seminar included President of the Taiwan Association of Unveristy Professors Wang Tu-fa, Taiwan Environmental Protection Union Vice President Chen Ming-hua and No Nuke Taiwan Union Convener Cheng Hsien-you, as well as representatives from other environmental protection groups.

Lai said that due to insufficient global stocks of petroleum, the cost of petrochemical raw materials are bound to rise and in comparison, the cost of recyclable energy will be low. If the government continues to develop recyclable energy, costs could be cut even further, he said.

He said that currently, Taiwan's annual spending on recyclable energy at NT$3 billion (US$90.63 million) is too low and that the government should spend more on such recyclable energy such as thermal energy, tidal and solar power.

Amid the call for recyclable energy, Wu Huang, vice executive secretary general of the Energy Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said that the development of alternative energy sources in Taiwan is "not so good."

He said that recyclable energy can make energy supplies more stable and meet environmental protection needs. If the administration can effectively develop recyclable energy, the sun and wind will provide the most potential, and he added that wind-generated electricity will be the most economically efficient.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER NSB CHIEF ALERTED U.S. AFTER MARCH 19 SHOOTING

TEXT.P: Former National Security Bureau (NSB) Director Tsai Chao-ming informed the United States of the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu shortly after it occurred, an NSB official confirmed Wednesday.
Chiu Chung-nan, deputy commander of the NSB's Special Service Center, made the confirmation at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Defense Committee.

During the meeting, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lu Hsiu-yen asked Chiu whether then-NSB Director Tsai telephoned the U.S. authorities after Chen and Lu were shot on the campaign trail in the southern city of Tainan a day before the March 20 presidential election.
To the best of her understanding, Lu Hsiu-yen said, Tsai made phone calls to Washington, D.C. and the U.S. Pacific Command in Hawaii during an emergency trip to Tainan right after the shooting.

In response, Chiu said that Tsai made many phone calls on his way to Tainan, including informing the opposition "pan-blue alliance" presidential and vice presidential ticket of KMT Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong, as well as former President Lee Teng-hui, of the shooting.
Chiu said Tsai also called the U.S. Pacific Command but he declined to elaborate.
An NSB source later confirmed that Tsai indeed called Washington and the U.S. Pacific Command.
"The main purpose of the calls was to remind the U.S. authorities to keep alert to mainland China's activities after President Chen and Vice President Lu were shot," the source said.
Tsai resigned last week to assume political responsibility for the shooting that slightly wounded both Chen and Lu. Chen was grazed on the abdomen and Lu was hit in her right knee.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. FORENSIC EXPERT INVITES COLLEAGUE TO ACCOMPANY HIM TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, April 6 (CNA) (By Chiang Ying and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Renowned Chinese-American forensic expert Henry Lee has invited another seasoned expert Charles Illsley to accompany him to Taiwan and help look into the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, sources said Tuesday.

Illsley, with years of experience in criminal investigation, excels in finger-printing and laser technology. Lee will rely on an alternative light source (ALS) technology -- a new method developed by Illsley to search for any tiny amounts of chemicals or other substances that cannot be detected by the naked eye. For example, ALS can detect blood stains even after they have been washed away or coated with paint.

Sources said that ALS has played an important role in criminal investigations in the United States and that evidence collected at crime scenes by the technology has been important in many criminal court cases.

With the assistance of the ALS technology, Lee hopes to shed light on the truth behind the election-eve shooting in which the president's lower abdomen was grazed by a bullet and the vice president suffered a minor wound to her right knee. Taiwan police have still not arrested anyone in connection with the assassination attempt.

Lee was invited by State Public Prosecutor General Lu Ren-fa to come to Taiwan to help in the investigations after the opposition "pan-blue alliance" called for an independent investigation committee to be set up to look into the incident. The opposition camp has said that the shooting incident won last minute sympathy votes for the incumbent president in the close March 20 election.

At the commission of Lee, a trio of U.S. forensic experts had come to Taiwan last week for two days to collect information and examine the scene of the shooting for clues. They also visited the hospital where the President Chen was treated and called on him at the Presidential Office March 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 7, or the 18th day of the leap second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1348: Charles IV, king of Bohemia, founds Prague University, the first university in central Europe.
1827: John Waller, a chemist in northern England, sells the first matches, which he invented.
1928: Chiang Kai-shek resumes the Northward Expedition at the order of the National Government.
1932: A National Emergency Conference in Loyang decides on continued resistance against Japanese aggression.
1934: Mahatma Gandhi suspends his campaign of civil disobedience against British rule in India.
1945: The Yamato, Japan's largest battleship, is sunk by U.S. aircraft carrier warplanes.
1947: Henry Ford, American car manufacturer, dies at the age of 84. He developed a gasoline-powered automobile in 1893, founded the Ford Motor Company in 1903, and mass-produced the Model T from 1908 to 1927.
1948: The World Health Organization (WHO) is founded in Geneva.
1953: Dag Hammarskjold, Swedish diplomat and political leader who won the 1961 Nobel Peace Prize posthumously, succeeds Trygve Lie as secretary-general of the United Nations.
1954: Jackie Chan, Hong Kong movie star who is noted for his action films, is born.
1963: The Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia is set up with Marshal Tito as president for life.
1969: Traffic courts are set up in Taipei City and other locations around Taiwan to begin handling traffic violation cases.
1976: Simon Kuznets, 1971 Nobel Prize winner for economics, arrives in Taipei for a three-week-visit.
1976: The Communist Party of China's Political Bureau decides at a meeting to appoint Hua Guofeng as premier and to depose Deng Xiaoping as deputy premier after riots in Beijing.
1976: Hishan M. Nazer, Saudi Arabian minister of planning, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1978: U.S. President Jimmy Carter backpedals on building the Neutron bomb.
1979: The International Olympic Committee decides the ROC can retain its membership while admitting Communist China as a new member.
1981: Voters in the Philippines approve a new constitution, giving President Ferdinand Marcos sweeping powers.
1987: U.S. President Ronald Reagan announces that American diplomats will not occupy the new embassy in Moscow until he is sure that it is secure against Soviet eavesdropping.
1989: Cheng Nan-jong, the person in charge of the "Era of Freedom" magazine, immolates himself after refusing arrest for involvement in an insurrection case.
1989: The Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee announces that ROC athletic teams and organizations will participate in international sports events held on the mainland under the name "Chinese Taipei."
1990: Communist China launches a U.S.-made telecommunications satellite into orbit.
1998: Indonesia and the International Monetary Fund agree on a package of measures to get a US$43 billion bailout package on track.
1999: Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chiao Jen-ho urges the government to step up its international publicity drive to buttress global awareness of the Republic of China.
2000: Almost two-dozen founding members of the hard-line Independence Party announce their decision to drop out of the party because they say that the party has completed its mission.
2001: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, receives a set of CNA file photos, including one showing he in the arms of his mother along with his father and his elder brother.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When there is justice and order in the government of the country, to think only of pay is dishonorable. When there is no justice and order in the government of the country, to think only of pay is also dishonorable."

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENT PROTESTORS URGED TO RESPECT PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A group of students who staged a sit-in fast to demand an investigation into the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian should give the president "due respect" and not insist on meeting the president on their terms, a Chen aide said Thursday.

Huang Chih-fang, director of the Public Affairs Department at the Presidential Office said at a news conference Thursday that the president is head of state and president of all the people, not only the president of the protesters. He therefore deserves the protesters' due respect, Huang said.

Chen has decided to exchange views with 40 to 50 student leaders from various schools at a theater in Taipei Monday. The president hopes the student protestors will join the others at the meeting, Huang went on.

He said the timing of the meeting was fixed after consulting the president's schedule, adding that any changes would cause inconvenience to both the president and the other students invited to the meeting, Huang said.

He made the statement after the student protesters at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall insisted that the president come to see them before April 9, when they were set to end their fast, rather than have the protesters join the other students in Monday's meeting.

The make-up of the protesters has been changing ever since it started April 2. Three of the five original strikers collapsed and were rushed to hospital before Wednesday. One has left the protest and only one remains. The others are newcomers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI, MIT FORM INDUSTRIAL UPGRADING ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: The Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) and the Media Lab of Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) signed a memorandum Thursday to form a working group to elevate the upgrading creative abilities of local industry.

The working group named "Next Consortium" will be composed of Hsueh Wen-chen, director of the ITRI's creation center, and Walter Bender, chief executive of MIT's Media Lab, as well as several entrepreneurs from different spectrums.

ITRI President Johnsee Lee said the working group will strengthen communications between local industries in order to promote strategic alliances between different sectors and will seek collaboration between academia and industry to provide a unique environment for exploring basic research and applications.
Nicholas Negroponte, founder of MIT's Media Lab, said that through the alliance, the different industries can jointly share the risk in the process of research.

DOC.HEADLINE: 66 FISHERMEN RESCUED FROM BOAT FIRE OFF KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A total of 66 fishermen, most of them from mainland China, have been rescued from a fishing vessel that caught fire off the southern port city of Kaohsiung Thursday afternoon, according to officials of the National Rescue and Coordination Center.
The southern Pingtung County's Tungkang Port-registered vessel caught fire while it was ferrying mainland fishermen back to the mainland from Tungkang, the officials said.

A total of 67 people were aboard the 78-ton fishing boat-turned ferry, or so-called "floating hostel, " of whom only the captain and chief officer are Taiwanese and the remaining 65 are from the mainland.
Air force and coast guard rescue squads deployed helicopters and rescue vessels immediately after being informed of the incident, while nearby fishing boats also offered help.
As of press time, the officials said, only one of the 67 people aboard the boat remained missing and the rescue operation was continuing.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHOOTING PROBE SHOULD BE CONDUCTED BY JUDICIAL AUTHORITIES: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance's" proposal to form an investigation committee under the Legislative Yuan to probe the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu is unconstitutional, government spokesman Lin Chia-lung said Thursday.

Lin noted that the government has already established a special investigation group composed of judicial agencies to look into the assassination attempt and said the idea of the opposition conducting a referendum to solicit public support to form a legislative investigation committee is against the law.
Both Chen and Lu were slightly injured in the election-eve shooting.

The "pan-blue alliance" ticket of Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong was defeated by Chen in the March 20 election by a slim margin of 0.228 percent, or less than 30,000 votes. Many "pan-blue alliance" supporters believe that the shooting gave Chen many sympathy votes, while the "security mechanism" triggered by the shooting deprived many military servicemen and policemen of their right to vote.

The issue has resulted in serious political turmoil, evidenced by a string of large-scale protests in front of Presidential Office and astudent sit-in demanding the "truth" in the aftermath of the presidential poll.

Lin said the alliance's committee would invite Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien to be convener, with legislators, members of the Control Yuan and State Public Prosecutor General Lu Ren-fa as members, which Lin pointed out would violate the Constitution.

Lin also announced that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party is planning to promote a public-sponsored referendum alongside the year-end legislative elections, with four issues to be discussed, including halving the number of seats in the legislature, the fate of the controversial fourth nuclear plant, Taiwan's entry to the World Health Organization, and the management of political party assets.
According to the Referendum Law, the president, the Legislative Yuan and the public can sponsor a referendum.

However, Lin said there are many defects in the Referendum Law, such as a too-high threshold in terms of the percentage of voters needed to sponsor a referendum and that issues related to constitutional amendments have been excluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASEAN POISED FOR STRONGEST GROWTH SINCE FINANCIAL CRISIS: MINISTERS

TEXT.P: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations' (ASEAN's) economies are poised this year to witness their strongest growth since the 1997-1998 Asian financial crisis, the region's finance ministers said at the annual ASEAN meeting held Wednesday.

"We expect our region to continue its growth momentum in 2004 with a projected gross domestic product growth of 5.5 percent to 5.9 percent," the ministers said in a joint statement at the end of their one-day summit.

The ministers painted a buoyant picture of the region's growth prospects after seven years of major setbacks that began with the financial crisis and included terrorist attacks and the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and bird flu.
"Growth is expected to be broad-based, with both domestic and external demand providing the impetus for expansion, " the joint statement said.
Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, in a keynote speech at the one-day summit, said the economies of most ASEAN members had recovered strongly from the setbacks in recent years.
"ASEAN has taken quite a few hard punches in the last few years. Although we might have been bruised, we are far from being knocked out," said Lee, who is also the finance minister.

"Now, most ASEAN economies are on the mend. Economic growth has been strong in many countries. Exports are growing, and stock markets are up... ASEAN is now back on its feet and up and running again," he said.
Meanwhile, the ministers also said that they had made progress in efforts to liberalize the financial sector, a crucial pillar of ASEAN's ambitions to create a common market by 2020.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER STUDENT MOVEMENT LEADERS CALL FOR SWEEPING REFORMS

TEXT.P: A group of former student movement leaders issued a statement Thursday demanding that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) launch all-out reforms in the face of what they claimed is mounting chaos in society following the March 20 presidential election.

About a dozen student leaders of the 1900 "wild lily" movement -- who now hold high positions in the government and academic spectrums, such as Academic Sinica assistant researcher Fang Yun, Council for Hakka Affairs Secretary-General Yang Chang-chen and various DPP party members -- jointly endorsed the statement in view of the many disputes in the wake of the election.

Describing self-reflection and continued reforms as the best response to new challenges, they demanded that the DPP assume responsibility for the "rising discontent in society" related to a wide range of issues that include the consequences of the March 20 referendum results, electoral, educational, fiscal and parliamentary reforms, and a new constitution.

At a time when Taiwan is plagued by confrontation, distrust and rifts, they urged the country's leaders and political parties to take full accountability to help the people mend the widening gap if society is to continue advancing.

"The people's discontent and pain should awaken their consciousness to push for a new agenda of continued and comprehensive reform in the beginning of a new stage in Taiwan's democratic development," they said.

They appealed for joint efforts from all the political parties and private organizations to strengthen Taiwan's democratization at this juncture when the country's democratic course is at a crossroads.

"All the political parties and civilian groups concerned about Taiwan's democratic development should forswear their strife and bickering to devote their energy to building common benefits for our children and the younger generation," they said.

Looking back over the past four years, the DPP should be held accountable, at least for the increased rifts among Taiwan's ethnic groups and a deterioration in government service quality, they claimed.

Should a political party fail to respond to the deep public expectations in these fields, it should be recorded by history and eventually deemed as a loser even though it grabs power, according to the former student leaders.

Emphasizing that collective learning and contemplation is the driving force behind society's progress, they appealed to all the political parties to stop fighting and expressed their strong hope that 2004 will be viewed as a proud watershed in Taiwan's long-term pursuit of peace, freedom and unity.

DOC.HEADLINE: MATRA WINS DAMAGES CLAIM AGAINST TAIPEI RAPID TRANSIT DEPARTMENT

TEXT.P: The France-based Matra Armaments and Telecommunications Company has won damages of more than NT$1.1 billion (US$30.07) pluses interest from the Department of Rapid Transit systems under the Taipei city government, according to ajudgment rendered by the Taiwan High Court Thursday.

In a reversal of a judgment it made three years ago, the court determined that the statue of limitations on the arbitration award won by Matra is 15 years rather than five years applied in the previous trials, and thereby the award is still valid and capable of being exacted.

The Taipei rapid transit department, which had successfully rejected the damages claim in two previous trials, was astounded by the latest twist in the trial and department chief Fan Liang-hsiou said he will appeal to the Supreme Court.
The case arose from a construction contract won by Matra in the late 1980s to build a mass rapid transit system from Mucha to downtown Taipei.

After the construction was finished, Matra won an arbitration award of NT$1.1 billion in 1993 for damage caused to the company by the foot-dragging of the city government in performing its part of the construction contract.
The rapid transit department filed a lawsuit in an attempt to have the award thrown out, but failed in 2000 after having exhausted all avenues of appeal over a period of seven years.
The department then filed another lawsuit claiming that a five year statute of limitations on the award had elapsed by 1998.

The rapid transit department was successful in defeating Matra in the first two trials, but the Supreme Court threw out the judgment of the lower court and ordered a retrial by the Taiwan High Court, which judged in favor of Matra.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE COLLEGES, COAST GUARD BLASTED FOR GENDER DISCRIMINATION

TEXT.P: Three public institutions -- the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) , National Police University and Taiwan Police College -- came under fire Thursday for having recruitment policies that discriminate against women.

At a news conference, senior executives of major women's rights groups showed pamphlets issued by the three institutions concerning their recruitment plans to back up their gender discrimination claims.

Quoting the data shown in the pamphlets, the women's rights activists said the number of women to be admitted to National Police University and Taiwan Police College account for only 7.89 percent and 7.09 percent, respectively, of the total number of available places.
The percentage falls far below the required level set forth in the General Equality in Employment Law, the activists noted.
"We feel regret that the three public units have failed to abide by the gender equality law, " said You Mei-nu, president of the National Federation of Taiwan Women's Associations.
Noting that legislation alone is not enough to ensure gender equality, You said enforcement is equally important in substantiating the ideals of gender equality.

According to the CGA's plan, this year it will recruit 60 male administrative clerks and 10 female clerks, as well as 75 offshore male patrol officers. Women to be recruited account for only 6.9 percent of the total. The CGA has restricted the number of female staff to be recruited on the grounds that the working environment and job planning are "tough and not suitable for women."

You, a lawyer, said the CGA's stated reasons fail to justify its restrictions on women's rights to pursue a career in coast guard service. You said women hopefuls can file complaints with local labor affairs offices and that major women's groups will offer legal counseling and litigation assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT AGREES TO MEET HUNGER STRIKE STUDENTS MONDAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has agreed to meet a group of hunger-striking college students Monday, a legislator coordinating the meeting said Thursday, but the students who are protesting against the nation's political turmoil are unhappy that the president will not meet them earlier.
Legislator Lo Wen-chai, accompanied by National Chengchi University Professor Feng Chien-san, visited the students at their Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall sit-in at around 5 a.m.

Lo, who was one of the students that initiated the "wild lily" student movement in 1990, listened to the students' views and conveyed them to Chen at the Presidential Office. He said Chen was "very concerned about the health of the students and would like to meet with them to discuss national affairs and hear their views."
Lo said that since the students do not want the meeting to take place at the Presidential Office, the venue and the issues to be discussed will be open without preconditions.

The students who attend the meeting will not be confined to those who have staged a hunger strike at the CKS Memorial Hall over the past few days. Only one student per school will be allowed to attend the meeting, which is expected to last for one or two hours.
The number of participating students will be limited to between 40 and 50 and the meeting will be open to the public so that those who cannot participate will be able to observe the proceedings.
Upon hearing the news, the striking students expressed their discontent and demanded an earlier meeting.

The students, who had originally decided to end the hunger strike Friday night out of concern for the health of the students -- two of whom collapsed Tuesday -- said they would continue until the president gives a substantial goodwill response.

A student surnamed Keng from Soochow University also read a five-point statement in which she claimed that after nearly a week of hunger strike, the majority of the students were nearing the point of breakdown, and accusing Chen of ignoring their appeal.
Lo expressed regret over the students' dissatisfaction, pointing out that "the president has agreed to meet and they have achieved their aims."

Lo said that he was surprised to learn that when the president agreed to a meeting, they wanted to continue their hunger strike indefinitely. He was "dismayed" by the development and "had no stance to convince the president to change the time of the meeting."

The students began their hunger strike April 2, saying that the "wild lily" student movement of 14 years ago was their "spiritual guide." They are protesting against the ethnic divisions in society and demanding the truth about the March 19 shooting of Chen and Vice President Annette Lu that the defeated "pan-blue alliance" believes gave Chen last-minute sympathy votes and victory in the bitterly contested March 20 election. Chen won by a narrow margin of 29,518 votes out of more than 13 million votes cast.
The students have aroused concern, with some members of the public expressing pain at seeing the students "harming themselves" to press for their ideals.

In March 1990, college students staged a sit-in at the CKS Memorial Hall that lasted for more than one month to push for constitutional reforms and express their discontent over senior legislators who had not faced election since their first terms in mainland China prior to 1949. The Legislative Yean underwent a comprehensive election in 1992.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH COURT TO DISCUSS ELECTION LAWSUIT AGAIN NEXT MONDAY

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court said Thursday it will hold a closed-door meeting next Monday to discuss how to conduct a recount of ballots cast in the March 20 presidential election.

High Court spokesman Wen Yao-yuan said the three judges handling the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" lawsuit to nullify the presidential election result will meet with lawyers of the two feuding parties to hash out technical details regarding the recount.

The defeated "pan-blue alliance" presidential candidate, Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, filed the petition to annul President Chen Shui-bian's narrow re-election victory and for a vote recount March 29.

The judges have already given the feuding parties five days to iron out their disputes about how to retabulate the votes. The deadline passed Wednesday, but the two sides have yet to come to terms on some critical points.

Both sides have agreed on a full retally of the more than 13 million ballots cast in the election, including the examination of a record 330,000 invalid ballots -- triple the number in the last presidential election. Chen defeated Lien by a narrow margin of 29,518 votes.

The two sides have yet to reach agreement on other details, including who should pay for the recount and the retallying methods to be used. Wen said Monday's meeting will focus on procedures and methods for the recount.
"After the negotiations yield an agreement, the court tribunal will announce whether to hold a recount, as well as the scope and method of a recount," Wen told reporters at a news conference.
He further said the court will announce its decision on the recount April 13 at the earliest.

One of the disagreements between the feuding parties is over the scope of the recount. Lien's attorneys want judges to match the names of the 13 million voters who cast ballots with the roster of eligible voters, but the president's lawyers only want to do a simple recount of the ballots and an examination of the 330,000 ballots deemed invalid.

Chen's lawyer, Wellington Koo, told reporters that the law governing recounts only requires that the ballots be retallied and inspected. The voters' names don't need to be double-checked with the roster of eligible voters, he added.
"If they insist on inspecting the roster, they need to present evidence of fraud," Koo said.

In addition to the election result nullification lawsuit, Lien's lawyers have also filed a separate suit with the High Court aimed at nullifying the entire election so that a new one can be held. They first filed the election nullification lawsuit April 5, but withdrew it Wednesday only to refile it hours later after making revisions.

"We don't want to see two recounts that might produce different outcomes so we decided to revise our election invalidation suit saying a separate recount is not necessary, " said Huang Shan-shan, a lawyer for Lien.

The lawsuit claims that the Central Election Commission should have postponed the election after the shooting of Chen on the eve of the March 20 poll, and that it was illegal for a referendum to be held alongside the poll.
Analysts see little chance of a new election but say a recount is much more likely since it has Chen's consent.

Lien also seeks an "independent" inquiry into the election-eve shooting, a demand that Chen has rejected, although he has allowed U.S. forensic experts, including world-renowned forensic scientist Dr. Henry Lee, to assist in forensic examinations.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party has proposed a draft bill to pave the way for the establishment of a committee under the Legislative Yuan to investigate the shooting that slightly wounded Chen and Vice President Annette Lu. Lien alleges that the incident unfairly swayed the election result in Chen's favor. The "pan-blue alliance"-controlled Legislative Yuan will discuss the bill Friday.

If the bill fails to clear the legislature, the opposition alliance will push for a referendum on the issue. The alliance will also mobilize some 200,000 supporters to demonstrate at the Presidential Office square in downtown Taipei Saturday, the alliance's third large protest since the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROCSAT-2 TO HELP IN NATURAL DISASTER CONTROL MISSION

TEXT.P: The National Space Program Office (NSPO) and the Natural Disaster Center under National Chengkung University (NCU) forged a joint venture Thursday on the prevention of natural and environmental hazards by using images that will be captured by a Taiwanese satellite.
NSPO Director Lee Lo-chuan and Natural Disaster Center head Hsieh Cheng-lun signed the cooperative agreement on behalf of their respective organizations.

Under the terms of the pact, the two sides will cooperate in applying high-resolution real-time images captured by ROCSAT-2 to the prevention of natural catastrophes and environmental hazards, Hsieh said.

ROCSAT-2 is slated to be launched at between 1:47 a.m. and 2:10 a.m. April 10 Taipei time from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California if local weather conditions permit. The satellite's launch has been delayed several times for various reasons after it was transported from Taiwan to the United States in early December last year.

ROCSAT-2 is designed for practical application purposes as part of the government's 15-year space technology development plan implemented in 1991 and focusing on three satellites with different missions. ROCSAT-1 was launched in 1999 and ROCSAT-3 is scheduled to lift off in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: FALUN GONG PRACTITIONERS TO MARCH IN NEW YORK SATURDAY

TEXT.P: Several thousands Falun Gong practitioners from around the world will hold a parade in New York's Chinatown April 10 with the aim of highlighting the organization and the persecution it suffers in mainland China.

On April 25 five years ago, thousands of Falun Gong practitioners made an appeal to Beijing's State Council regarding the unfair treatment and atrocities imposed on practitioners there, but the appeal generated a series of even more severe government crackdowns, according to the Falun Dafa Information Center.

Saturday's parade will start in Foley Square near City Hall, pass through Chinatown and end at Columbus Park. It will include demonstrations of Falun Gong practices and meditations, photo displays of persecuted practitioners, and traditional activities such as Chinese lion dances.
Some 3,000 practitioners from more than 60 countries around the world are expected to take part in the demonstration.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE AIRLINES SET TO EXCEED FULL-YEAR PROFIT TARGET

TEXT.P: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is on course to exceed its full-year profit target of S$600 million (US$352 million) for 2003, SIA chief executive officer Chew Choon Seng said Wednesday.

SIA is expected to unveil its full year results on May 14. Despite the upbeat assessment, the airline will still concentrate on cutting costs in order to improve profitability and compete with emerging low-cost airlines.

After suffering its first-ever quarterly loss, of S$312 million, during the April-June 2003 period, SIA has been enjoying steady growth over the last two quarters. In the nine months to December, the airline earned S$371 million in profit.

New York Times: U.S. Increases Efforts to Put Down Sunni and Shiite Fighters.
The Iraqi uprising against the American-led occupation intensified Wednesday and spread to new parts of the country, with United States forces increasing their efforts to put down Sunni and Shiite combatants.
Pentagon officials in Washington signaled that they would probably delay bringing home as many as 25,000 troops as scheduled and probably move reinforcements to the south.
Wall Street Journal: Shiite Militiamen Control Parts Of Three Iraqi Cities.
Militiaman loyal to an anti-U.S. Shiite cleric controlled large swaths of three Iraqi cities Thursday after clashes with U.S.-led coalition forces, while U.S. Marines backed by airstrikes fought insurgents for the second day around a mosque complex in the Sunni Muslim stronghold of Fallujah.
Fighting this week has left 35 Americans and at least 459 Iraqis dead. This includes more than 280 Iraqis killed since the Marines' siege against insurgents in Fallujah, west of Baghdad, began early Monday said Taher Al-Issawi, the director of the city's hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: VATICAN CONDEMNS BEIJING FOR DETENTION OF CATHOLIC BISHOP
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, April 7 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: In a rare and strongly worded-statement, the Vatican condemned Beijing Thursday for the detention of a Catholic bishop in the mainland, criticizing the action as "unacceptable."

According to foreign wire service reports, the bishop, Jia Zhiguo, was taken away from his home in the northern city of Zhengding, Hebei province, about 250 kilometers southwest of Beijing, Tuesday by government agents who gave no explanation for the detention.
Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro Valls said in the statement that this is again another case of a member of the Roman Catholic Church being deprived of personal liberty without legal explanation.
The statement added that in a country that boasts of religious freedom and says that it is ruled by law and respects human rights, this kind of action is extremely unacceptable.

According to Navarro, Jia has been in jail for a total of 20 years. Some religious sources said that Jia has been repeatedly arrested for his refusal to accept government demands to affiliate himself with the Communist Party-controlled Catholic Patriotic Association, which rejects Vatican authority over several issues such as the naming of bishops.
This was the second case in about a month, following the detention of Bishop Wei Jingyi by public security officials in the northeastern province of Heilongjian in early March.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORENSIC EXPERT HENRY LEE TO ARRIVE IN TAIPEI APRIL 9

TEXT.P: World-renowned Chinese-American forensic expert Henry Lee is expected to arrive in Taiwan Friday to help investigate the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.

The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said Thursday that it will compile all information related to the shooting for Lee's team, which will include ballistics expert Charles Illsley, who developed an alternative light source technology that enables the detection of trace evidence invisible to the naked eye.

CIB officials said that when a trio of forensic experts, which included Cyril H. Wecht, who was involved in the investigation of the assassination of U.S. President John F. Kennedy, came in late March, police provided them with information regarding the bullets that were recovered, blood samples, and crime scene reconstructions.

Lee, who commissioned the trio to come to Taiwan because he was engaged with other matters and couldn't come earlier, reportedly had a meeting with the three men via a teleconference prior to his departure from San Francisco to Taiwan.
They discussed evidence they had collected during their stay in Taiwan, but said that their two-day stay in Taiwan was too short and they weren't able to see enough evidence.

The trio talked with the CIB, visited the crime scene in Tainan, southern Taiwan and the Chi Mei Medical Center where the president and vice president were treated after being shot and slightly injured. They also called on President Chen at the Presidential Office March 30.

Lee, who has been involved with several high-profile cases in the U.S. including O. J. Simpson's murder trial, was invited by State Public Prosecutor General Lu Ren-fa to help with the investigation, which has made no major progress so far with no suspects and few clues.

His arrival is eagerly awaited as the public hopes he can help solve the shooting on the eve of the March 20 presidential election, which saw President Chen win by only 29,518 votes out of more than 13 million votes cast against his sole rival Lien Chan of the "pan-blue alliance."

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" has claimed that the election was marred by voting irregularities and the mysterious shooting, which gave Chen last-minute sympathy votes and handed him the victory in the bitterly contested election.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUIT AND WIN CAMPAIGN OFFERS CASH PRIZES TO SMOKERS WHO QUIT

TEXT.P: The International Quit&Win 2004 campaign will start on May 2, with the top prize worth NT$600,000 (US$18,237) waiting for smokers who kick the habit, officials of the Department of Health under the Taipei City Government said Thursday.
The biennial International Quit&Win began in 1994 endorsed by the World Health Organization and the National Public Health Institute of Finland.
Taiwan joined the competition first in 2002, with 23,096 pairs of people (one smoker and one family member who witnesses) participating.

Follow-up studies showed that among the 23,096 Taiwanese participants, 37.2 percent of them succeeded in quitting smoking for a whole year, far more than the world average of 20 percent compiled by the WHO.
The officials noted that participants who have succeeded in refraining from smoking from May 2 to May 29 will have chances to win big prizes by a lucky draw.

The campaign will be open to adults older than 18 who have smoked for more than one year. Anyone who is interested can obtain related information at all health institutions around the island or visit the Web site: www.quitandwin.org.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMANY URGED NOT TO SUPPORT EASING OF ARMS SALES BAN TO CHINA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed the hope Thursday that Germany will not support an easing or lifting of a European Union ban to sell arms to mainland China that was imposed in the wake of the Tiananmen Massacre in Beijing in 1989.

President Chen made the remarks when he met Klaus Rose, head of a Germany-Taiwan friendship group from the federal parliament, at the Presidential Office. Rose arrived in Taipei Sunday for a six-day visit.

The president took the chance to thank Rose first for the hospitality extended to Chen's wife, Wu Shu-chen, when she visited Germany in July 2003 to help open a National Palace Museum exhibition there.

Noting that the Germany-Taiwan friendship group is one of the largest groups in the parliament, with 59 members, the president expressed his appreciation for the group's support and assistance to Taiwan under Rose's leadership, especially in cultural exchanges and trade cooperation.

Noting that the exhibition of National Palace Museum artifacts was successful, the president said that a Prussian cultural heritage foundation from Germany will have an exhibition in Taiwan after May.

In terms of trade exchanges, the president pointed out that Taiwan is the third-largest trading partner of Germany in Asia, while Germany is the largest trading partner of Taiwan in Europe, with bilateral trade hitting US$10 billion last year.

Taiwan manufacturers have been active in taking part in trade fairs in Germany, with the number of manufacturers taking part in the prestigious Cebit exhibition in Hanover exceeded those from other countries for the sixth consecutive year.
The president also said that he was concerned that some countries in the European Union are trying to lift or east the arms sales ban on mainland China.
He said that the ban was imposed because of the poor human rights record in the mainland. So far, Beijing has not improved its human rights record to warrant lifting the ban, he claimed.
He expressed the hope that Rose would use his influence in the parliament by urging his country not to ease or lift the ban.

The president also is concerned about Germany's intention to sell a plutonium factory to mainland China, saying that Beijing could someday use it to produce nuclear weapons, therefore jeopardizing world peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET SCHEDULED TO RESIGN EN MASS ON MAY 12

TEXT.P: The current Cabinet will resign en mass in its weekly meeting on May 12 in the wake of the election of the Republic of China's 11th-term president and vice president, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday.

Yu made the remarks to local media after having taken part in a ground-breaking ceremony of a 12-inch silicon wafer plant launched by ProMOS Technologies at the Central Science-based Industrial Part in Taichung County.

In line with the ROC's constitutional requirement, the Executive Yuan has to make its offer to resign en mass before President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu will be sworn in for a second term in office on May 20, Yu said.

The premier also urged the outside world not to speculate over the Cabinet's new lineup but called on the public to join forces with the government to improve the country's economy and carry out a wide range of reforms.

Cabinet spokesman Lin Chia-lung revealed on Monday that the upcoming Cabinet reshuffle will be conspicuous as part of the government's efforts to meet high public expectations for a progressive society ruled by law.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL WEB SITE WILL HELP FARMERS TACKLE OVERSUPPLY

TEXT.P: Local farmers will soon be able to better cope with production oversupply as an agricultural goods Web site will open for them to distribute and sell their products on the Internet, an official of the Changhua Farmers' Association said Thursday.

Liao Chen-hsien, secretary-general of the Changhua Farmers' Association, the key promoter of the Web site, which will begin operations soon in cooperation with private businesses, said that the main purpose of the launch of the service is to provide farmers with an adequate environment to sell their products directly and conveniently to avoid being exploited in the marketplace.

While Taiwan has developed from an agricultural society into a high tech-oriented economy, farmers nowadays still suffer a great deal of abuses in trying to market their goods, Liao said, adding that the Web site will offer an option for farmers who wish to distribute their products directly.
Web site operators said that they will continue to invite farmers from across Taiwan who are willing to market their produce on the Internet. Farmers can also use the site to look for retailers.
Prices of many locally planted vegetables from central and southern regions, such as cabbage and onions, have dropped markedly in recent weeks as a result of overproduction.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

DOC.HEADLINE: TUNG BLOSSOM OF HAKKA FESTIVAL TO BEGIN APRIL 17

TEXT.P: The 2004 Tung Blossom of Hakka Festival will be held from April 17 through May 16, the Cabinet-level Council for Hakka Affairs (CHA) Chairwoman Yeh Chu-lan announced Thursday.
Yeh said the festival will begin April 17 with a fun-filled ceremony at the West Lake Resort in the northern Taiwan county of Miaoli, a Hakka stronghold.

This will be the third consecutive year that the CHA has organized a tung blossom festival to boost tourism and cultural development in Taiwan's major Hakka communities, particularly those in northern parts of the island.

Yeh said the event generated NT$500 million in business revenues last year and that the festival will be expanded to cover Hakka communities in Taipei, Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Miaoli, Taichung and Nantou counties.

"We have arranged 21 paths for appreciating beautiful tung flowers in full bloom, " Yeh said, adding that the festival offers tourists lavish opportunities to enjoy the scene of "snow in summer" created by the white tung flowers that look like snowflakes.
Yeh said the CHA describes the flower of tung tree as a "blossom of Hakka" because tung trees mainly flourish in Hakka communities in northern Taiwan.

In addition to flower appreciation, Yeh said, the CHA has also planned more than 600 other festivities, including pottery-making, ecological tours, extracting tung seed oil, painting exhibitions, woodcarving shows, photo competitions, Hakka singing contests, Hakka food tasting, and seminars on Hakka cultural heritage and literature. The activities will take place in some 30 townships in northern and central parts of Taiwan.

A number of gift items in tung flower motifs, including lunch boxes and wine, will be marketed in connection with the festival, Yeh said, adding that state-owned Chunghwa Telecom will sell phone cards bearing the motifs of the tung flower.
Yeh said she hopes the annual tung blossom festival can help enrich local cultural activities and promote tourism and economic development in major Hakka communities.
She also encouraged tourists to learn some basic Hakka conversation during their trips to Hakka communities to experience Taiwan's cultural diversity and the beauty of Hakka culture.
More travel tips are available at the Web site www.hakka.gov.tw.

The flourishing of tung tree, also known as tung oil tree bearing the academic name of aluerites fordii hemi, on the mountain regions in northern Taiwan was described as a "beautiful fallacy" made decades ago.

With a view to cashing in on the thriving demand for wooden furniture materials to be exported to Japan, farmers in Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli areas started planting wutung tree (firmiana simplex, commonly named Chinese parasol tree) in the 1960s. But the difficulty in growing wutung trees later forced many farmers to switch to plant tung trees, which are much easier to take care of. Both trees trace their roots to Yangtze River area in China.
After the Japanese customers discovered the wrong wood and stopped purchases from local suppliers, the tung oil trees were left uncut.
Three decades later, those trees are flourishing with profuse blossoms in spring and have become a major tourist attraction in the Taoyuan-Hsinchu-Miaoli area.

The trees can still be used for carving, furniture and wood pulp. The oil extracted from the seeds was used as a key ingredient for varnish in old days and it remains a must for Hakka people who produce hand-made umbrellas with oil paper.

TAIEX Index futures for May gained 14 points to end at 6,682, with 154 contracts traded, while June futures ended even at 6,680, with 11 contracts finalized.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended the day higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 26.12 points to close at 6,672.86.
The bourse opened at 6,666.73 and fluctuated between 6,690.45 and 6,647.42 during trading.

A total of 4.76 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$108.06 billion (US$3.23 billion), an increase from the previous day's trading session that saw 4.36 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$99.39 billion.

Six of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with construction stocks moving up the most at 1.4 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 1.1 percent, textile issues and plastics and chemical shares both at 0.9 percent, cement stocks at 0.8 percent, and electrical shares at 0.3 percent.
The other two major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff stocks moving down the most at 0.6 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 403 to 387, with 183 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 8, or the19th day of the leap second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
217 AD: Caracalla, or Marcus Aurelius Antonius, the Roman emperor who was obsessed with and sought to imitate Alexander the Great, is assassinated after a bloody reign.
1513: Juan Ponce de Leon, the Spanish explorer who completed the conquest of Puerto Rico, discovers Florida and claims it for the Spanish throne.
1861: Elisha Graves Otis, the American inventor of the passenger elevator which was first installed in 1857, dies at the age of 50.
1902: China's Ching court and Russia reach agreement on the evacuation of Manchuria. After the Boxer Uprising in 1900, Russia took the opportunity to occupy Manchuria. When the troops of the other foreign powers withdrew from Chinese territory, Russia refused to leave Manchuria.
1907: France and Britain sign a convention confirming the independence of Siam (now Thailand).
1914: The Republic of China's first Congress is organized in Beijing.
1913: Brazil officially recognizes the Republic of China, which was founded on Jan. 1, 1912, becoming the first country in the world to do so.
1925: The Australian government and the British Colonial Office offer low-interest loans to encourage 500,000 Britons to emigrate to Australia.
1946: The League of Nations holds its final session in Geneva. It was later replaced by the United Nations.
1958: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower proposes mutual inspection as a means of enforcing the nuclear test ban.
1965: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with the Republic of Dahomey.
1966: Leonid Brezhnev is elected general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party. He later became president of the USSR in 1977.
1973: Dr. Mohammed Abder Rahman Basbeer, minister of communications of Jordan, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1973: Pablo Picasso, the Spanish artist who was one of the most prolific and influential artists of the 20th century, dies in his chateau at Mougins at the age of 92. He excelled in painting, sculpture, etching, stage design, and ceramics.
1979: Lee Pao-chen, a noted Chinese musician, dies in Taipei at the age of 73.
1981: Omar Nelson Bradley, the American general who played a major part in the Allied victory in World War II, dies at the age of 88. He commanded the U.S. forces in the Normandy invasion and later led the 12th Army Group as France was liberated.
1986: Clint Eastwood, the screen tough guy famed for his portrayal of "Dirty Harry," is elected mayor of Carmel, a Californian resort town.
1989: More than 60 Soviet submariners die after a nuclear-powered Mike-class submarine refuses assistance from nearby Western merchant ships after catching fire off the coast of Norway.
1990: ROC Economics Minister Chen Li-an and Singaporean Minister of Trade and Industries Lee Hsien Loong preside over the first ministerial-level conference on economic cooperation between the two countries.
1991: The second extraordinary session of the First National Assembly is convened in Taipei to discuss constitutional reforms.
1992: Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat is found alive 12 hours after his plane crashes in the Sahara desert.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa resigns over a loan scandal.
1995: At a meeting of the National Unification Council, ROC President Lee Teng-hui offers a six-point proposal for Taiwan-mainland China relations.
1999: NATO continues airstrikes against Yugoslavia while the eastern European country says its 14-month war against ethnic Albanian separatists is over.
2000: Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa tells U.S. President Bill Clinton that granting mainland China permanent normal trade relations status would give Hong Kong's recovering economy a further boost.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian says while attending the inauguration of Taiwan's Anti-Cancer Federation that a heart full of pleasure is the best medicine against cancer.
Confucius lesson of the day: "A gentleman who only thinks of the comforts of life cannot be a true gentleman."
