DOC.HEADLINE: MASTER SHENG YEN TO CHAIR ZEN SESSION IN SWITZERLAND
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 8 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: World renowned Taipei-based Zen master Sheng Yen is scheduled to preside over a Zen study session in Switzerland in early May, local religious sources said Thursday.

Sheng Yen, founder of the Taiwan Buddhist group Dharma Drum Mountain (DDM) Social Welfare and Charity Foundation, is set to arrive in Switzerland in late April. He will give public sermons on April 30 and May 1 before presiding over a seven-day Zen meditation session to be held at the Beatenberg Zen Center in Bern beginning May 2.

According to Beatenberg authorities, all 70 spots for the Zen meditation session to be chaired by Master Sheng Yen were booked long ago, with some being reserved by Buddhist followers from as far away as Spain and the United States.

Sheng Yen, a Buddhist monk since his formative years who later obtained his doctorate in Buddhist studies in Japan and has since founded numerous Buddhist associations and institutes in Taiwan and elsewhere overseas, has drawn a lot of attention and publicity in Switzerland even before his arrival.

Traveling with some 20 world religious leaders to Israel and Palestine last December, Sheng Yen, a member of the 2003 World Council of Religious and Spiritual Leaders, tried to use the power of religion to bridge the differences among people in the ethnic conflict afflicting region.

Presenting two words -- mercy and wisdom -- Sheng Yen called for the leaderships of both Israel and Palestine to use wisdom to work out solutions to their differences while practicing mercy on all the people in the region regardless of their political affiliation or religion, so as to not let down the people living in the Holy Land.

Sheng Yen and his party met with Palestinian Prime Minister Ahmed Qureia during a symposium held in Jerusalem Dec. 11. After hearing Sheng Yen's preaching, Qureia reportedly applauded enthusiastically and said to his aides that he looks forward to seeing Sheng Yen's suggestions put into practice.

At a colloquium held at the Israeli prime minister's office Dec. 14, Sheng Yen delivered a speech to ranking Israeli officials, including Cabinet officials, parliamentary advisers and government consultants in news and religious affairs.

In his speech, Sheng Yen interpreted Islamic doctrine as stipulating that Jihad -- or holy war -- does not mean to strive to defeat others, but instead to defeat one's own evil thoughts. "This is an idea almost the same as the Buddhist concept of conquering the evil in one's mind," Sheng Yen noted.
Sheng Yen said he hopes that all the followers of Islam, Judaism and Christianity will reach out their hands to one another so that world peace will prevail.

Sheng Yen, author of many books on Buddhism both in Chinese and in English, is respected in Taiwan, mainland China and around the world. As a Zen master, his teachings emphasize that practitioners should in their daily lives be constantly aware of the thoughts circulating in their minds.

Such awareness allows people to simplify their minds and to clearly perceive changes in themselves and in their environment, he said. Wisdom is developed so that people can apply it in their workaday lives to face themselves, grow and dissolve their attachments and enter into a state of "no-self, " according to his teachings.

Sheng Yen has been actively engaged in inter-faith exchanges that advocate and promote religious understanding. His involvement in such global activities includes being a member of the 2003 World Council of Religious and Spiritual Leaders and delivering the keynote address at the 2000 Millennium World Peace Summit of Religious and Spiritual Leaders in New York.

In Taiwan, he founded the DDM Buddhist Association, which now has over one million followers. In the United States, he has been teaching the Buddhadharma since 1975, leading to the founding of two centers, one in New York City and one in Upstate New York.
Sheng Yen's DDMBA made a donation of US$100,000 in post-quake relief aid to Iran immediately after a devastating earthquake struck the historic city of Bam last Dec. 26.

Days later, after dispatching a four-member mission to Bam for a fact-finding trip, the DDMBA launched a fund-raising drive to channel another US$100,000 into Iran to foster children who were orphaned and deprived of schooling by the deadly earthquake.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, April 9 [CNA] The Moscow Times:NATO Chief Promotes Friendlier Ties.
In his first visit to Moscow as NATO secretary-general, Jaap de Hoop Scheffer sought to dispel anxiety over the Western alliance's eastward expansion two weeks ago into former Soviet space with assurances that the bloc wants to work with Russia, not against it.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: U.S. Bombs Mosque in Fallouja.
U.S. forces battling for control of this city bombed a mosque complex after hours of fierce fighting as Pentagon officials said they might extend some soldiers' tours of duty to quell the violence flaring across the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: 11 AGENTS DISCIPLINED FOR MARCH 19 SHOOTING

TEXT.P: A total of 11 officers charged with the safety of President Chen Shui-bian were disciplined Friday for the March 19 shooting of the president in which both he and Vice President Annette Lu were slightly injured.

Notable among them were President Chen's Chief Aide-de-Camp Chen Tsai-fu and his Deputy Chief Aide-de-Camp Sheng Tsai-tien. They were also transferred to less important jobs, according to a statement issued by the National Security Bureau (NSB) which is responsible for the security of the head of the state.

Also disciplined were Lu's Chief Aide-de-Camp Lee Ke-kang and eight other officers and secret agents who either accompanied Chen and Lu at the campaign parade motorcade in Tainan City when the shooting took place or arranged the security affairs for them.
Chiu Chung-nan, a deputy chief for the president's security affairs was also transferred from his current job to a less important post.
All of them are still subject to investigation by the Control Yuan and other law-enforcement organizations to see if they are guilty of dereliction of duty or other crimes, said the statement.
The punishment of the president's aides should be subject to the approval of the president, said the statement.
These security officers were punished nine days after Tsai Chao-ming, the former director of the National Security Bureau resigned to take responsibility for the incident.
The statement said the NSB has drawn lessons from the incident and has revamped its work to ensure the security of the head of state.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN SEE TAIPEI AS IN ANARCHY: INTERIOR MINISTER

TEXT.P: New Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan told Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou Friday that people in the south of Taiwan have the impression that Taipei is in anarchy with protesters usurping control of law and order.

Su, formerly Pingtung County magistrate, made the statement in a meeting with Taipei Mayor Ma over a planed rally by supporters of the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party in Taipei on Saturday.

Su said that people in southern Taiwan can't understand why protesters in Taipei were able to take control of the boulevard in front of the President Office for nearly a week after the March 20 presidential election, and why the city government didn't rein them in.

The minister, who assumed his new post as head of the interior ministry only two hours before the meeting, told Ma that Taiwan is a democratic country that settles disputes through its judiciary system, so why should people in Taipei vent their grievances through demonstrations rather then seeking remedies via the legal process. "Does that mean we should go back to the primitive time and fight disputes out with fist or hoes," Su asked.
Ma told Su the protesters gathered in front of the Presidential Office to press their demands and simply driving them away without addressing their claims would not have calmed them down.
The minister shot back: "I am not in a position to talk with you about politics. I am talking about law."

The minister said the central government would respect Taipei citizens' right to assemble for political reasons as well as City Hall's authority to approve such events; however, he urged Ma's city government to be sure it can deal with any violence arising from the Saturday rally before it becomes intolerable for residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE MISSION MAKES GOOD SALES IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 9 (CNA) (By Huang Chin-chin & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: A trade mission specializing in household products and utensils from Taiwan concluded Friday a successful five-day sales mission to Japan, according to an official of Taiwan's representative office in Tokyo.

Kao Jung-chou, economic division chief of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan, said that the mission, composed of representatives of 62 Taiwan companies, won confirmed orders worth a total of US$1.26 million on site in three exhibitions held in Osaka, Nagoya and Tokyo.

The three exhibitions attracted visits by 1,700 Japanese buyers, Kao noted, adding that the visiting exhibitors also obtained follow-up business opportunities with an estimated combined value of US$7.72 million.

Kao attributed the mission's success to various creative and practical items and utensils it brought to Japan, such as solar powered lanterns, automated trash cans, special style mosquito nets and convenient machines for making noodles.
The mission was jointly organized by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council and the Importers and Exporters Association of Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Manila Bulletin: Pope leads Holy Week rites. A year on from the start of a worsening conflict in Iraq which it tried desperately to prevent, the Vatican yesterday reiterated its call for United States-led coalition forces to be replaced by United Nations (UN) peacekeepers as Pope John Paul II began a series of ceremonies marking Holy Week.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Good Friday, no publication. ROUND-THE-CLOCK surveillance is in place for local extremists and their foreign trainers and financiers, President Macapagal-Arroyo announced Wednesday.
The Philippine Star: Good Friday, no publication. President Arroyo will create a task force of Muslim police to hunt suspected terrorists in Metro Manila and allay fears of persecution in the Muslim community, Malacanang said yesterday.
The Manila Times: Good Friday, no publication. MALACANANG on Wednesday ruled out relief for workers through a wage increase. The President's spokesman, Ignacio Bunye, said what the Palace has in mind is noncash benefits for workers, which officials are now discussing.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO REVISE RULES FOR PRELIMINARY NOMINATIONS FOR LEGISLATORS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will hold an extra-party congress Saturday to revise its method of nominations in its preliminaries for legislators at large, a DPP spokesman said Friday.
President Chen Shui-bian, who also serves as DPP chairman, Premier Yu Shi-kun and other ranking government officials with DPP membership will take part in the gathering, the spokesman said.

According to the DPP official, the major issue for discussion in the gathering will focus on a change to the party's method of nominating candidates representing overseas Taiwan people and the aboriginal population at home in the party's preliminaries prior to the legislative polls in December.

In addition, party members will also vote on a party rule adjustment to allow the president, vice president and Taipei and Kaohsiung city mayors to double as members at the party's policy-making Central Standing Committee, he added.
Chen is slated to give a speech during the extra-party congress, while DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung will call a news conference to make public the results of the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OPTICAL COMMUNICATION INDUSTRY GROWING FAST

TEXT.P: Taiwan's optical communication industry is growing fast and poised to play a greater role in the world market if locally made key components and materials possess superior quality, an expert said Friday.

Liu Yung-sun, director of the Opto-Electronics and Systems Laboratories under the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI), made the remarks in a forum jointly sponsored by the ITRI and the Taiwan Optical Communication Industry Alliance.
Specialists from world famous companies, such as Telcordia, Lucent, Intel and Alcatel, also gave keynote speeches and discussed the industry's latest development trends.
According to Liu, the domestic industry has expanded quickly in recent years, with 96 companies now engaged in the sector, a jump from 39 companies five years ago.

Although the domestic industry now owns a stronger technology and a more competitive marketing network thanks to its past experience as a major contractor for many world-class big companies, Liu pointed out that Taiwan companies still need to upgrade the quality and supply chain of their key parts, components and materials.
Taiwan companies must further enhance the image and the quality of their products to meet buyers' requirements, he suggested.

An investigation made public by ElectroniCast Group shows that global demand for optical devises in 2003 rose by between 10 percent and 15 percent, while demand in 2004 will increase by between 25 percent and 30 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEEPING THE PUBLIC SAFE IMPORTANT TO NEW INTERIOR MINISTER

TEXT.P: New Minister of the Interior Su Jia-quan said he will give priority to fighting crime and maintaining law and order to provide a stable environment for economic development and political reform.
Su made the remarks at a changeover ceremony where he accepted the ministry's official seal from his predecessor, Yu Cheng-hsien. The event was witnessed by Minister-without-Portfolio Yeh Chun-jung.
Yu resigned Monday to assume political responsibility for the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu in the southern city of Tainan.
Su, who was magistrate of Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung, said the incident compelled him to list cracking down on crime and safeguarding public order as his top priority.

Su said his wife is a graduate of Central Police University. "As the dependent of a police officer, I'll work to improve welfare services for police and upgrade their dignity and self-confidence as well as enhance public trust in police officers," he added.
While pledging to uphold good existing policies and measures, Su said he will also scrap or amend outdated policies.
"I hope to inject more creativity, entrepreneurship and vitality into the Ministry of the Interior," Su said.

In addition to fighting crime, Su said he will also prioritize several other tasks, including narrowing the gap between rural and urban areas, formulating a fair and just social welfare policy and strengthening convenient digitalized services for the public.

Shortly after taking office, Su met with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou to exchange views on how to maintain order at the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" protest rally at the Presidential Office square this weekend.

Su said the central government respects people's right to assembly and demonstration. "But we hope the Taipei City Government can quickly and properly handle unexpected incidents during the rally. In any event, we want the rally to end as scheduled, " Su told Ma.
In response, Ma said the city government will do its utmost to ensure that the event proceeds peacefully and orderly.

It will be the "pan-blue alliance's" third large protest rally since the March 20 presidential election in which the alliance's candidate, Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, narrowly lost to incumbent President Chen Shui-bian. The alliance claimed that the election-eve shooting of Chen unfairly swayed the outcome in Chen's favor.
Su, 48, has been Pingtung County magistrate for six years. Upon his re-election in late 2001, he became the first incumbent county chief to win a second four-year term in Pingtung in two decades.

He has been a National Assembly member and served two terms as a legislator before becoming Pingtung County chief in 1997. At that time, Pingtung was reputed to be a gangster stronghold. Su pushed for county administration reform. Through his strong lobbying, the central government lifted a longstanding construction ban on many parts of the island's southernmost county, paving the way for rezoning of farmland and facilitating the county's economic development.
Over the past six years, Su was said to have transformed Pingtung from "the home of gangsters" to "the home of bluefin tuna fishing and top-quality wax apples."

Su set a goal of developing Pingtung into a heartland of tourism and high-tech industries. He has initiated a number of cultural and recreational programs to attract tourists, including the Bluefin Festival and the Kenting Wind Bell Festival. He has also turned the previously military-controlled Tapeng Bay into a new beach resort.

Moreover, he has managed to acquire central government approval for locating many national-level construction projects in Pingtung, including a new export processing zone, a biotechnology and agriculture park and a Hakka culture park to help create jobs and revitalize the economy in the otherwise rural county.
Su's efforts have earned him wide popularity in the county. He also ranks high in many public opinion surveys on the performance of local government chiefs.

According to tallies compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Pingtung County's average household income registered a 10 percent increase last year, the highest growth among all cities and counties around the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROPOSAL FOR LEGISLATIVE PROBE INTO MARCH 19 SHOOTING SCUTTLED

TEXT.P: A draft bill proposed by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) for a committee set up under the Legislative Yuan to probe the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and the ensuing government response were scuttled at the Legislative Yuan Friday by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its political ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).
Both camps called in all their lawmakers for a vote on the proposal.

Although the KMT-PFP "pan-blue alliance," which commands a narrow majority of 112 seats in the 223-seat legislature, succeeded in pushing through a resolution to refer the bill to related committees for deliberation -- the so-called second reading -- the TSU took issue with the idea of investigating the government's response to the March 19 shooting, while the DPP raised objections to the idea of forming a special committee to probe the shooting.
As a result, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who is a KMT vice chairman, ruled a four-month negotiation period among the various parties, as is usual for such disputes.

In anticipation of this result, "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers produced placards reading "seeking truth" and "what does Chen Shui-bian fear? " and shouted slogans to show their anger at being thwarted.

Speculating that the shooting might have been a political scheme aimed at boosting Chen's popularity on the eve of the presidential election, the KMT and PFP are eager to set up a committee under the Legislative Yuan to look into the incident, even though such cases fall under the authority of the Judicial Yuan.
Legislator Tsai Huang-liang, the DPP caucus whip at the Legislative Yuan, pointed out that the proposal is doomed to fail because it is unconstitutional.

Tsai said his party will press for a plebiscite in conjunction with the year-end legislative elections on the reform of the Legislative Yuan, the abolishment of the fourth nuclear plant, Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization, and a bill for handling the KMT's ill-gotten assets.

Legislator Ho Ming-hao, secretary of the TSU caucus at the legislature, said his party would support the KMT-PFP proposal if the two parties would support the enactment of a bill to govern the handling of the disputed KMT assets.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Signs That Shiites and Sunnis Are Joining to Fight Americans.
Officials fear that the growing uprising against the occupation in Iraq is forging a new level of cooperation between Shiite and Sunni Muslims.
The Wall Street Journal: In Iraq, Bush's Options Are Unappealing.
Bush faces a series of difficult choices on how to contain the violence in Iraq while making the continuing U.S. military presence tolerable to both Iraqis and Americans.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL CULTURAL AFFAIRS CHAIRWOMAN RETURNS FROM FRANCE

TEXT.P: Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs Chairwoman Tchen Yu-chiou returned to Taiwan Friday after concluding a five-day visit to France.

Tchen, whose major purpose in France was to give a keynote speech called "France to Asians" at the invitation of the Institut de France, said that future cultural exchanges between the two countries will focus on preservation of cultural heritage and promotion of modern arts.
Tchen was also warmly greeted by the French Ministry of Culture, which invited her to visit la Grotte Chauvet, a pre-historic cave in southern France under restoration.

"I was so deeply moved and impressively touched to see the art creation so well preserved in the cave of some 30,000 years ago," she said and expressed her hope for more frequent and closer exchanges between Taiwan and France on the conservation of cultural heritage and relics.
French expertise is capable of providing Taiwan with professional experience and known-how in the protection and conservation of its own cultural treasures, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRENGTHENING TRA IMPLEMENTATION MORE CRUCIAL THAN REVISION: MOFA

TEXT.P: Strengthening the implementation of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) is more important than revising the law itself, Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Kau Yin-mao said Friday.
Kau made the remarks while attending a seminar to mark the 25th anniversary of the enactment of the TRA, which was signed into law by former U.S. President Jimmy Carter April 10, 1979.

Speaking at the seminar sponsored by Legislator Parris Chang of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party at the Legislative Yuan, Kau said that with the law going into its 25th year, some have proposed a revision, but he pointed out that there would be positive and negative aspects to a revision.
He said that if the TRA is revised, it should be done in order to strengthen Taiwan's national identification and try to upgrade the development of bilateral relations.
However, if Taiwan were to propose too many revisions, the United States could also reduce its protection of Taiwan under the TRA, he said.
Legislator Chang for his part said that the TRA acts as a protection umbrella for Taiwan and that Taiwan has had security and economic development over the past 25 years because of the TRA.
The TRA has also made great contributions to Taiwan's democratic development, he said.

On the issue of a TRA revision, Chang noted that former U.S. President Ronald Reagan listed "no revision of the TRA" in a list of six assurances to Taiwan in 1982. "This is why Taiwan should also be very careful about seeking revisions," Chang said.
Chang said that if that Pandora's box is opened, the U.S. could also make revisions that have unfavorable repercussions for Taiwan.

But Liao Hung-hsiang, a researcher of the Taiwan Research Institute, a local think tank, said that with the changing times, the Taiwan of today is different from that of 25 years ago, so it is necessary to try to persuade Washington to review the TRA and pass a bill to make up for the TRA's deficiencies. He added that the most crucial aspect of the revisions should be the display of a "paramilitary alliance relationship" between Taiwan and the United States.
Meanwhile, Kau said that chances of the European Union lifting an arms sale embargo against mainland China are slim.

Kau said that while EU members such as France and Germany indeed intend to lift the embargo that was imposed in the wake of the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989, the EU will base its decision on the views of the majority of members.

As the EU will be increased from 15 to 25 member countries from May 1, the decision making process will be even more complex, so the chances of the ban being lifted will not be great, despite efforts by the mainland to have it lifted.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PROCESSING ZONE ADMINISTRATION ENTICES INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Economic Processing Zones (EPZs) are geared toward diverse business operations, Economic Processing Zone Administration Director-General Joseph Y. Chou said Friday.
EPZs, which are no longer just OEM (original equipment manufacturing) -oriented, can now provide a low-cost, high-yield environment for diverse business development, said Chou at a press conference.

The zones will be transformed into focusing on core industries such as semiconductors and opto-electronics, as well as being free trade port zones for global marketing, Chou continued, adding that seminars designed to attract investment will be held April 13, 15 and 27 in southern Taiwan, central Taiwan and northern Taiwan, respectively.

Chou indicated that the EPZs around the island attracted around NT$8.52 billion (US$254 million) in the first quarter of 2004, reaching 28.39 percent of the 2004 budget of NT$30 billion (US$896 million) and representing growth of 20 percent year-on-year.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION TO INITIATE FORMATION OF COMMITTEE TO PROBE SHOOTING

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party said Friday that it can complete at a rally Saturday the initiation stage of establishing a "truth committee" to investigate the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.
KMT spokesman Justin Chou said it is expected that the initiation will be completed in one day and that the collection of the required number of signatures will be completed in a week.

The "pan-blue alliance" is scheduled to stage a major rally with the theme of "fight for truth through referendum." Judging from the number of people attending "pan-blue alliance" rallies in Taipei recently, the initiation process can be completed in one day alone, said Chou.

According to the Referendum Law passed in late November, a referendum proposal must first have the support of 0.5 percent of the electorate to make it an issue, after which the names of more than 5 percent of the voters must be collected to make it a valid proposal.
Chou said that the alliance will not "rule out holding the referendum simultaneously with the year-end legislative elections."
The March 19 shooting in which Chen and Lu were slightly injured is at the center of the dispute between the "pan-blue alliance" and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The alliance, whose candidate, KMT Chairman Lien Chan, lost the election to Chen by a narrow margin of 29,518 votes out of more than 13 million cast, believes the election-eve shooting played a role in bringing Chen last-minute sympathy votes that helped him win the bitterly contested election.
In a related development, the opposition Taiwan Solitary Union, a DPP ally, said that it will hold a night-time rally Saturday in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan to celebrate Chen's victory.

TSU Chairman Huang Chu-wen will speak at the rally, although a scheduled television hookup with former President Lee Teng-hui -- the TSU's "spiritual leader" -- was scrapped to avoid "pan-blue alliance" supporters creating disturbances at the rally.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI LEADS PAKISTAN 2:0 IN DAVIS CUP

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei took a leading position of 2: 0 against Pakistan Friday in the 2nd round playoffs of the Davis Cup 2004 Asia/Oceania Zone Group I being held in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan.
Chinese Taipei tennis player Lu Yen-hsun, who ranks 110th in world tennis listings, defeated Pakistan's Asim Shafik 6-0, 6-1, 6-0 in the first individual match.
Meanwhile, Wang Yeu-tzuoo overpowered Aqeel Khan 6-2, 6-1, 4-6, 6-2.
The tournament will continue through April 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNDERPRIVILEGED GROUPS CALL FOR GREATER GOVERNMENT, SOCIAL ATTENTION

TEXT.P: Various civic organizations representing underprivileged and minority people issued a joint statement Friday calling for greater attention from the government, political parties and society as a whole.
The organizations ranged from groups concerned with elderly and disabled people to those devoted to grassroots workers and mentally challenged children.

Calling on the government and political parties to listen to their voices and get to know of their discontent and unease, they said it will be impossible to build a just and fair society if a rational and righteous system is not established.

They demanded that those in power heed their concerns and devise a set of mechanisms to distribute social resources on a fair and impartial basis, regardless of the economic status, political ideology, educational background, ethnic grouping and physical condition of the recipients.

Only in a society in which differences are fully respected can the rifts in Taiwan be repaired and cured, they insisted, urging both the ruling party and the opposition camp to forswear political strife, forge good policies and create social harmony for the sake of the common interest of all.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER OFFERS TO RESIGN

TEXT.P: A Cabinet official confirmed Friday evening that Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien has offered to resign.
The official said Chien tendered his resignation to Premier Yu Shyi-kun at 2 p.m. that day.
According to the official, Chien has insisted on stepping down, but Yu was still considering the situation and had yet to decide whether to accept Chien's resignation.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DEPLOYS B-52S IN GUAM TO COPE WITH NORTH KOREAN SITUATION: MOFA

TEXT.P: A U.S. decision to deploy six B-52 bombers on Guam is mainly aimed at coping with the North Korean situation, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau said Friday.
Kau made the remarks in response to a press inquiry about his views on the recent U.S. announcement that it will again deploy B-52 bombers on Guam.
Kau said the U.S. decision does not have any direct relations with the Taiwan Strait situation.
After the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, Kau said, the United States is now focusing its attention on North Korean issues with the aim of maintaining peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.

"The B-52 deployment is part of the U.S. efforts to strengthen Asia-Pacific security measures. It is mainly related to the situation on the Korean peninsula and does not directly relate to cross-Taiwan Strait ties," Kau said.
Touching on the resignation of American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen, Kau said personnel reshuffles are a normal procedure in any government.
Noting that the United States has a well-crafted administrative system, Kau said a single personnel change will not affect its policy line.
"We need not be overly worried about the AIT personnel reshuffle, " Kau said, adding that Shaheen's departure will in no way affect Taiwan-U.S. relations.
AIT is a quasi-official U.S. organization authorized to handle relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
As to the possibility of the European Union lifting its ban on selling arms to mainland China, Kau said the proposal is not expected to be approved soon.

Kao said some E.U. member states, such as France and Germany, indeed intend to lift the mainland China-bound arms export ban. However, according to the E.U.'s decision-making style, the proposal must obtain the approval of all E.U. member states. Moreover, Kau said, the number of E.U. members will expand from the current 15 to 25 May 1.
"By then, the E.U. deicion-making procedure will have become even more complicated. Against this backdrop, I don't think the arms ban lifiting proposal can be passed any time soon," Kau added.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENT PROTESTERS WANT TO MEET PRESIDENT IMMEDIATELY

TEXT.P: A leader of a group of student protesters who have launched a sit-in "fast" since April 2 said Friday that they were not planning to attend a meeting at a theater with President Chen Shui-bian April 12, but wanted the president come to see them at their sit-in that very day.

Chen Cheng-feng, who was rushed to National Taiwan University Hospital due to fatigue but who later returned to the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex where the protest is taking place, said the Presidential Office's offer of an April 12 meeting with the president has blurred the focus of the students' protest and their cause.

Chen demanded that the president come to see the students at the CKS complex before Saturday, when they were set to end their so-called "fast" -- which involves them doing without meals for several hours at a time.

"The president is welcome to come to have a dialogue with us today, no matter how late it is, " Chen said, adding that "all of the people here are students and the president should not be afraid of seeing them."

According to Huang Chih-fang, a Presidential Office spokesman, the president has decided to exchange views with 50 student leaders from various colleges and universities next Monday and has expressed hope that the protesters, who number about 20, will join the other students at the meeting.

Chen pointed out that the student protesters are not politicians and what they are pursuing is not the same as the goals chased by the country's politicians. All they want is peace and reconciliation in Taiwan society, he said, adding that the protesters are not afraid of being labeled and that they are not accepting any donations.

He also reduced the original five demands of the students to just two -- that political leaders from the two rival camps that contested the March 20 presidential election should apologize to the people for causing political chaos and social restlessness, and that an independent "truth probing committee" should be established to conduct an investigation into the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.

Chen claimed that "some 70 percent of the people" in Taiwan have demanded the truth about the election-eve assassination attempt and he added that President Chen himself has said that he wants to know the truth too. He provided no statistics to support his claim.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO REAFFIRM CROSS-STRAIT PEACE, STABILITY IN INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will say that he is dedicated to the pursuit of cross-Taiwan Strait stability in his May 20 inauguration speech, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Friday.

MAC Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong said the MAC is working on the cross-strait relations part of President Chen's speech, the major gist of which will be the pursuit of cross-strait peace and stability.
The MAC is also keeping close tabs on U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney's visit to mainland China next week, Chen continued.

Observers have said that the main points of Chen's inaugural address will be on mending fences with the United States, which expressed serious concern about the first national referendum initiated by Chen, as well as cross-strait relations and ethnic harmony in Taiwan.

Government agencies, including the National Security Council under the Presidential Office and the MAC, have been instructed to collect views and suggestions at home and abroad to use in preparation of a draft of the inauguration speech.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved up against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.030 to close at NT$32.940.
A total of US$529 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.970 and slid to a low of NT$32.886.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTHERN TAIWAN FACING WATER SHORTAGE

TEXT.P: Water reserves at various major reservoirs in southern Tainan County have dropped to dangerously low levels as a result of continued dry weather over the past few months, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Friday.

Tsengwen Reservoir -- Taiwan's largest -- is facing a historic 30-year low, with its water level coming to about 172 meters as of Thursday, only some 1.2 meters away from the lowest level at which it can maintain normal operations. At present, it holds about 5.2 million cubic meters of water.

Despite the fact that it rained the previous night in the Tainan area -- 20.5 millimeters in Tainan City and 43.5 millimeters in Tainan County -- the amount was far from sufficient to bring relief to the reservoirs in the region.
At the same time, the water level of the nearby Wushantou Reservoir stood at 44.87 meters, representing reserves of 9.57 million cubic meters.

The situation at the Nanhua Reservoir, which supplies water to the Chiayi and Kaohsiung areas, was better, with its water level standing at 163.52 meters, with more than 66 million cubic meters contained.
Nanhua reservoir authorities said that normal water supplies are expected to last through May before being supplemented when the typhoon season begins in June or July.
Taiwan has been troubled by a continued dry spell in recent years, with northern regions being most affected. However, rainfall from late January to early February brought some relief.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG HOPING TO SOLICIT CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHT SERVICES

TEXT.P: The heads of Taichung city and county decided Friday to push for using Taichung as a gateway for charter flight services between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait during the next Chinese New Year holiday.
Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu and Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng reached the consensus when they held a coordination meeting in Taichung City, central Taiwan.

Pointing out that although Taichung County has no big hotels or major restaurants, it has rich tourism resources, Hu said that the city and county should pool their resources to draw up and promote plans for tourism resources.

He said that with the inauguration of the Chingchuankang International Airport last month, China Airlines, the nation's largest carrier, has expressed interest in operating charter flights to Okinawa and Hong Kong and he expressed hope that during the Chinese New Year, the airport can offer cross-strait charter flight services.
Huang also said that with the cooperation between city and county, the two could be promoted to the fullest extent.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM IS A BASIC CIVIL RIGHT: MAYOR MA

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Friday The opposition "pan-blue alliance" is eligible to initiate a referendum to authorize the Legislative Yuan to form a special committee to investigate the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian.
"Referendums are a basic civil right and can be held so long as they proceed in strict accordance with the law," Ma said.

Ma made the remarks after the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) announced a day earlier that it would begin to collect endorsement signatures for its "referendum for truth" proposal Saturday when the alliance will stage a protest rally at the Presidential Office square in downtown Taipei.

The "pan-blue alliance" will mobilize at least 200,000 supporters to demonstrate at Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office in protest against what it calls the unfair March 20 presidential election. It will be the alliance's third large protest since the bitterly fought election in which the alliance's candidate, KMT Chairman Lien Chan, narrowly lost to incumbent President Chen Shui-bian. The alliance claimed that the mysterious election-eve shooting unfairly swayed the result in Chen's favor.

Ma, who concurrently serves as a KMT vice chairman, said the Taipei City Police Headquarters will be responsible for maintaining order at Saturday's rally to ensure that the event ends smoothly and peacefully. Violent clashes between riot police and some radical "pan-blue" supporters erupted during last Saturday's protest rally.
Ma said he has asked the "pan-blue alliance" authorities to join forces with city police to maintain order and prevent a recurrence of violence at this weekend's demonstration.

Asked about his views on the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's plan to initiate referendums on four critical issues to be held alongside the year-end legislative elections, Ma said he is not opposed to such a plan so long as the referendums are held in accordance with the provisions of the Referendum Act promulgated last November.

DPP sources said Thursday that the party plans to initiate referendums on four issues -- halving the number of legislative seats, scrapping the nation's fourth nuclear power plant now under construction, joining the World Health Organization, and enacting a special statute to deal with the KMT's ill-gotten party assets.

DOC.HEADLINE: RENOWNED FORENSIC EXPERT HENRY LEE ARRIVES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: World renowned Chinese-American forensic scientist Dr. Henry Lee and four other experts arrived in Taiwan Friday to help look into the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.

The forensic expert said the team will examine all physical evidence concerning the shooting as well as visit Tainan City in southern Taiwan where the shooting took place and the Chi Mei Medical Center where the president and vice president received treatment after being wounded.
"We will let the evidence speak for itself," Lee stressed.
He also said that as some time has passed since the shooting, he will probably not visit the president to observe his wound but will review carefully the medical treatment record and related photos.

Lee, who has come to Taiwan at the invitation of State Public Prosecutor General Lu Ren-fa, said that his task is purely to examine the physical evidence and that his political views are not an issue, referring to allegations that he is an opposition "pan-blue alliance" supporter.

Having been involved in forensic work for 45 years, Lee said, he has maintained good relations with both the Democratic and Republican parties in the United States and has made friends with members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as well as the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party in Taiwan.
"My work in Taiwan will be purely to examine the physical evidence, " Lee said, adding that he will have no part in the investigation into the motives of the assailant or assailants.

Noting that there are some 26,000 murder cases and around one million sexual assault and robbery cases in the United States every year and that many of them remain unsolved due mainly to insufficient evidence, Lee said Taiwan's presidential election-eve shooting will probably remain unsolved if there is not enough evidence gathered.

Accompanying Lee are Charles P. Illsley, who developed an alternative light source technology that is used to detect trace amounts of substances that are invisible to the human eye, as well as crime scene special photographer Calvin D. Ostler, legal consultant Austin J. McGuigan, and his special assistant Dr. Jacob S. Loke.

Lee's arrival is eagerly awaited as the public hopes he can help solve the shooting on the eve of the March 20 presidential election, which saw President Chen win by a razor-thin margin of 29,518 voces out of more than 13 million votes cast against his sole rival Lien Chan of the "pan-blue alliance."

The "pan-blue alliance" has claimed that the election was marred by voting irregularities and the mysterious shooting, which gave Chen last-minute sympathy votes and handed him the victory in the bitterly contested election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 9, or the 20th day of the leap second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1241: Batu Khan, grandson of Genghis Khan, leads his Mongol horsemen to victory over the Teutonic Knights at Liegniz, Silesia.
1626: Sir Francis Bacon, English philosopher, essayist, courtier, jurist, and statesman, dies at the age of 65. His writings include "The Advancement of Learning," and the "Novum Organum," in which he proposed a theory of scientific knowledge based on observation and experiment that came to be known as the inductive method.
1667: The world's first art exhibition opens in Paris, and lasts for 15 days.
1682: La Salle, the title of Robert Cavelier, the French explorer of North America who claimed Louisiana for France in 1682, reaches the Gulf of Mexico after traveling down the Mississippi River.
1865: Confederation Gen. Robert E. Lee surrenders to Union Gen. Ulysses S. Grant at the Appomattox Courthouse in Virginia, ending the U.S. Civil War.
1926: Tuan Chi-jui resigns as provisional chief executive of the Republic of China.
1928: Islam is no longer recognized as the state religion of Turkey.
1940: German troops invade Norway and Denmark.
1942: American and Filipino forces on Bataan surrender to the Japanese after a four-month siege.
1957: Egypt announces the opening of the Suez Canal after the withdrawal of invading troops from Great Britain and France from Port Said.
1961: The Republic of Vietnam holds its first presidential elections with Ngo Dinh Diem elected as president.
1963: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill is proclaimed an honorary U.S. citizen at the White House.
1965: The ROC and the United States conclude in Taipei an accord to establish a Sino-American fund for economic and social development in Taiwan.
1969: The Concorde, the supersonic passenger jet, makes its maiden flight from Bristol to Fairford in England.
1973: Hedley Donavan, editor-in-chief of Time magazine, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1973: Lt. Gen. Thomas K. McGebee, commander of the U.S. Aerospace Defense Command, arrives in Taipei from Bangkok for a three-day visit.
1974: Nguyen Van Kieu, newly elevated Vietnamese ambassador-extraordinary and plenipotentiary, presents a copy of his credentials to ROC Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan.
1976: The fifth congress of the Federation of Asian Photographic Arts opens with 200 representatives from South Korea, the Philippines, India, Indonesia, Sabah and the ROC attending.
1976: Bernard B. Matawali, permanent secretary of the Ministry of Agriculture of Malawi, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1988: Mainland China's National Peoples Congress names Li Peng as premier.
1990: The Democratic Forum of Hungary sweeps to power in elections, after 40 years of communism.
1991: Georgia declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1998: More than 100 Muslim pilgrims are crushed to death in a stampede at the Haj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia.
2000: Paraguay's first flower exhibition center is inaugurated in the Central Province city of Caacupe, with Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Macchi and Republic of China Ambassador to Asuncion Liu Ting-tsu cutting the ribbon.
2001: Former Republic of China Vice President Shieh Tung-min passes away at the age of 95 at his home in a suburb of Taipei from cardial infarction.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When there is justice and order in the government of the country a man may be bold and lofty in the expression of his opinions as well as in his actions. When, however, there is no justice and order in the government of the country, a man may be bold and lofty in his actions, but should be reserved in the expression of his opinion."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REITERATES COMMITMENT TO TAIWAN RELATIONS ACT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 9 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department released a written statement on the eve of the 25th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), reiterating its strong commitment to the act and saying the Taiwan people can count on the United States' reliable policies toward East Asia and the Taiwan Strait area.
The TRA was adopted by Congress on April 10, 1979, to act as the legal basis for U.S. relations with Taiwan after Washington switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

"The Taiwan Relations Act has made a vital contribution to ensuring peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, and it provides a strong framework to help ensure Taiwan's security, " the statement said.

"The U.S. is strongly committed to fulfilling its obligations under the act. The traditional bonds of friendship between the people of the United States and the people of Taiwan remain strong and vibrant. The people of Taiwan can count on the United States to pursue a steady and constructive policy toward East Asia and the Taiwan Strait area," it added.

The statement was issued at a time when U.S. Vice President Richard B. Cheney is preparing to depart for East Asia to visit several countries in the region. He is scheduled to head to mainland China for three days after his planned visits to Japan and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW X-RAY SYSTEM TO SPEED UP LUGGAGE CHECKS AT CHANGI AIRPORT

TEXT.P: A new X-ray system that the Singapore government hopes will speed up the process of luggage inspection at Changi Airport is scheduled to be up and running by year's end.
Airport security officers now check all bags with either hand-held or mobile X-ray scanners, but this practice will soon be a thing of the past.
The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore plans to introduce 35 sets of advanced X-ray scanners to replace the old method of inspecting luggage.
While the older X-rays can only provide a two-dimensional image of objects, the new machines are able to scan the luggage from various angles.
The new system, which has a price tag of S$80 million (US$47 million) , will be introduced in phases at both of Changi Airport's terminals.

DOC.HEADLINE: LATEST TECHNOLOGY USED TO IMPROVE ASSISTED REPRODUCTION SUCCESS RATE

TEXT.P: Doctors in Singapore are using the latest techniques in key-hole surgery to correct medical problems in men and women who have trouble conceiving.
Coupled with less expensive day surgery, childless couples may now have a better chance of having a baby.

Channel NewsAsia found out at an international symposium on the future of in-vitro fertilization (IVF) that using technology like ultra-sound imaging has almost doubled the success rate of couples trying to babies.
Not only are Singaporeans getting married at a later age, they are also postponing having children -- leading to a declining fertility rate in the city-state.

But there are some who also have problems conceiving because of medical reasons. These range from sperm problems to ovulatory dysfunctions. Local fertility expert Dr. Christopher Chen has seen more than 1,000 male patients who have swollen varicose veins at their genitals. This prevents them from producing healthy sperm, while hundreds of women need to remove fibroids or cysts in their wombs.
Non-intrusive surgeries to correct such problems can now be performed as day surgery, and patients can be back at work about three days later.
But the biggest breakthrough is the use of existing ultra-sound imaging technology to track the process of Assisted Reproduction Technology (ART) and IVF.

Dr. Chen says the technology helps fertility experts better monitor the reproductive systems of patients as well as the fertilization process, thereby improving the success rate of couples using artificial methods to conceive.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATOR NAMED NEW FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Legislator Chen Tang-sun of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has been appointed by Premier Yu Shyi-kun to take over the post of minister of foreign affairs, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan announced Saturday.
Lin Chia-lung made the announcement after the premier met Chen at his official residence.
Yu will introduce the new foreign minister to the media at a press conference to be held Sunday morning, Lin added.

Chen, who served as magistrate of Tainan County in southern Taiwan 1993 to 2000 before being elected legislator, will succeed outgoing Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien, who offered to resign a day earlier over the departure of American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairperson Therese Shaheen -- the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.

"Shaheen was a good friend of Taiwan and a bridge between Taiwan and the U.S. State Department, and we appreciate her contribution to Taiwan-U.S. relations, " Chien told a news conference Friday afternoon.
In the resignation of Shaheen, Chien said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs had been guilty of dereliction of duty and insufficient supervision in some places.
Chen, 68, obtains a Ph.D. degree from Purdue University of the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR ORDERS DISPERSAL OF VIOLENT PROTESTERS

TEXT.P: Riot police turned water cannons on angry supporters of the defeated "pan-blue alliance" presidential candidate Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan as they tried to storm barbed-wire barricades outside the Presidential Office Saturday.
Riot police took the action with the consent of Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, a KMT vice chairman, Taipei City Government spokesman Wu Yu-sheng said.

Ma agreed to the municipal police headquarters' decision to turn water cannons to angry demonstrators after they threw bottles, tables and chairs at barbed-wire barricade as the earlier peaceful rally of some 80,000 people turned violent in the evening.

It was the third large protest rally organized by the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) since Lien lost to incumbent President Chen Shui-bian in the bitterly fought March 20 presidential election by a razor-thin margin of 29,518 votes.

Lien and his running mate, PFP Chairman James Soong, led the crowd to Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office in downtown Taipei to demand the formation of an independent committee to investigate the "mysterious" election-eve shooting of President Chen. Lien claimed that the shooting unfairly swayed the election in Chen's favor, and insinuated that the shooting might have been staged for sympathy votes.
Although "pan-blue alliance" organizers announced that the rally ended at 6 p.m., some demonstrators declined to leave the site and then later tore down several barbed-wire barricades.
In a speech delivered at the rally earlier in the day, Lien said President Chen has shied away in the past three weeks and ignored the people's demands for "truth of the shooting."

"This is not a long-term strategy," Lien told the crowd. Lien said sympathy votes swung the election and wanted an impartial investigation into the mysterious shooting, in which Chen was slightly wounded.

The president has rejected the demand for the establishment of an independent committee under the Legislative Yuan to investigate the shooting on the grounds that creation of such a body violates the constitutional principle of division of power.
The "pan-blue alliance" is now moving to push for a referendum to be held alongside the year-end legislative elections for setting up the proposed independent investigative committee.

Speaking at Saturday's rally, Lien's running mate PFP Chairman James Soong said if Chen fails to approve the proposal for creating an independent investigative committee, the "pan-blue alliance" plans to stage another large protest rally on the eve of Chen's inauguration for a second four-year term on May 20.

Chen was gashed across the stomach and Vice President Annette Lu was wounded in the knee when an unknown assailant with a homemade handgun fired two bullets at them as they campaigned in an open-top jeep in the southern city of Tainan on March 19. Police have so far not arrested any suspect.

World-renowned Chinaese-American forensic expert Henry Lee, a veteran of such high-profile cases as the O.J. Simpson murder trial, joined the probe this week and recreated the crime scene in Tainan on Friday night using lasers to trace the path of the bullets.

Lee said he found 20-30 tiny glass fragments on the dashboard and floor of the jeep, which prove the bullet that struck Lu was fired from the right side. His team also found machine markings on the bullets and casings that Lee said needed further study. His findings allay some suspicions the shooting was faked.

Lien has filed two lawsuits -- one to invalidate Chen's victory and order a recount, and the other to nullify the election and order a new one -- citing a record 330,000 invalid ballots, alleged voting irregularities, the March 19 shooting and other factors.
Analysts say a recount is almost certain since Chen has consented to one but a new election is unlikely.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI DEFEATS PAKISTAN IN DAVIS CUP

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei defeated Pakistan Friday after winning the doubles match in the second day of the 2nd round playoffs of the Davis Cup 2004 Asia/Oceania Zone Group I being held in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan, to secure its victory with a 3:0 lead.
Chinese Taipei tennis players Lu Yen-hsun and Wang Yeu-tzuoo beat their Pakistani rivals, Aqeel Khan and Asim Shafik, 6-2, 6-1 and 6-4 in the match.

Lu, who ranks 110th in world tennis listings, defeated Shafik 6-0, 6-1, 6-0 a day earlier in the first singles match and Wang Yeu-tzuoo overpowered Aqeel Khan 6-2, 6-1, 4-6, 6-2, giving the Chinese Taipei a 2:0 up.
The tournament will continue through April 11, but the remaining two singles matches will not change the tournament results.
The Chinese Taipei kept its berth in the Davis Cup Asia/Oceania Zone Group I with the triumph.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINES

TEXT.P: New York Times: Bush Was Warned of Possible Attack in U.S., Official Says.

President Bush was told more than a month before the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, that supporters of Osama bin Laden planned an attack within the United States with explosives and wanted to hijack airplanes, a government official said Friday.

The warning came in a secret briefing that Mr. Bush received at his ranch in Crawford, Tex., on Aug. 6, 2001. A report by a joint Congressional committee last year alluded to a "closely held intelligence report" that month about the threat of an attack by Al Qaeda, and the official confirmed an account by The Associated Press on Friday saying that the report was in fact part of the president's briefing in Crawford.
Wall Street Journal: U.S. Retakes Most of Kut; Two More Soldiers Killed.
U.S. forces Friday said they had retaken most of Kut, an important southern Iraqi city, from a rebellious Shiite militia, on what was the first anniversary of the fall of Baghdad.

Two U.S. soldiers were killed in Baghdad Friday. One died when insurgents attacked a convoy transporting fuel at the capital's main western entrance, the military said. An Iraqi driver in the convoy was also killed.
At least 643 U.S. soldiers have died in Iraq since the war began in March 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOPICS AT MEETING BETWEEN PRESIDENT AND STUDENTS NOT TO BE LIMITED

TEXT.P: The planned meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and student leaders from around the nation for March 12 will not be confined to certain topics, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party official said Saturday.

DPP Legislator Lo Wen-chia, who is also director in charge of youth affairs in the party, noted that as the president is willing to talk with the students on any subject, the meeting is much anticipated.

The meeting had originally been planned for the students engaged in a hunger strike at Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall calling for an end to the ethnic split in Taiwan society and the truth behind the election-eve "mysterious" shooting of Chen and Vice President Annette Lu during a campaign activity on March 19, in which both were slightly injured. Many believe that the shooting won many sympathy votes for Chen and contributed to his re-election.
The students ended their hunger strike Saturday after nine days on the suggestion of doctors but decided to launch an indefinite sit-in protest for their cause.

Although these students have expressed their unwillingness to attend the meeting as they expect it will have nothing to do with their appeals, the meeting will be held as scheduled, Lo said. He added that nearly 100 student leaders from around the island will attend the meeting to be held at a performing arts center in downtown Taipei.

Lo said that as a wide range of topics are expected to be discussed at the meeting, he has also invited several government officials, including Education Minister Huang Jung-tsun, Interior Minister Su Chia-quan and Cabinet-level National Youth Commission Chairwoman Lin Fang-mei.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PASSES NOMINATION RULE REFORM PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) passed a proposal Saturday to reform its nomination rules for at-large legislative seats.
The proposal, initiated by a group of young and middle-age legislators, was passed at a DPP extraordinary party congress chaired by President Chen Shui-bian in his capacity as DPP chairman.

The new nomination rules will be implemented in the upcoming intraparty primaries for the year-end legislative elections. At-large legislative seats are alloted among major political parties in proportion to the number of ballots they garner in regional-seat elections.
According to the new rules, DPP candidates for at-large legislative seats will be divided into two categories -- political group and academic/expert group.
Candidacy for the political group will be decided in terms of the results of both voting by DPP members to be held in May and a series of follow-up public opinion surveys.

Candidacy for the academic group will be decided by a nomination commission with the endorsement of the DPP's Central Executive Committee. The nomination commission will be composed of seven to nine members appointed by the party's chairman with the endorsement of the Central Executive Committee.

The new rules also include a provision that the nominees in the academic/expert group must be those who support the DPP's charter and platform and have clearly contributed to the DPP and society as well.
For years, the DPP has been criticized for cronyism in the nomination of candidates for at-large legislative seats, with family members of influential party elders dominating the nomination list.

With a view to promoting women's political participation, the new rules set a quota for women hopefuls. To cultivate senior parliamentary leaders, the new rules lift a two-term ceiling for at-large seats.
It was also decided at the congress that the nomination rules for the academic/expert group will be applied to nomination for candidates for overseas representative seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LAUNCHES MASSIVE RALLY DEMANDING TRUTH ABOUT SHOOTING

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party launched a massive rally Saturday in front of the Presidential Office, demanding the truth about the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.
According to the Taipei Municipal Police Department, some 80,000 "pan-blue alliance" supporters gathered at the venue at 3: 30 p.m.

In addition to the 2,200 police officers sent by Taipei Police Department, the central government's National Police Administration also sent some 2,500 police officers, while some 6,000 police officers stationed around the country were on standby for any emergency situation that might arise.

Supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" are demanding the truth behind the election-eve assassination attempt against President Chen and Vice President Lu during a campaign activity in Tainan, southern Taiwan, in which both were slightly injured.

The "pan-blue alliance" ticket of Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong was defeated by Chen and Lu in the March 20 election by the slim margin of just under 30,000 of the more than 13 million votes cast. Many believe that the shooting won many sympathy votes for Chen, while the "security mechanism" triggered by the shooting deprived many military service members and police officers of their right to vote.

Failing to obtain a clear explanation about the "mysterious" shooting, the "pan-blue alliance" is now planning to push for a referendum to seek the public's support for the formation of an "investigation committee" under the Legislative Yuan to probe the March 19 shooting of Chen and Lu.

Lien, Soong, as well as the KMT's two vice presidents -- namely Wang Jin-pyng, who concurrently serves as the Legislative Yuan president, and Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, and several "pan-blue alliance" legislators also attended the rally, urging the public to support the establishment of such a committee.
According to the Referendum Law, the signatures of more than 5 percent of eligible voters must be collected to validate the opposition alliance's proposal.
After the rally, the opposition alliance will seek supporters' signatures to propose such a referendum, which they plan to hold alongside the year-end legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OFFICIAL SAYS PARTY NEEDS TO OBTAIN MAJORITY IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) needs to obtain a majority of seats in the Legislature in the legislative elections later this year so that it can carry out its promises to the Taiwan people, a DPP official said Saturday.

Speaking at an interim party congress held in Taipei, DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said that the ruling party will push ahead with legislative reform and the writing of a new constitution for Taiwan over the next four years, and thus make Taiwan a "normal democratic nation."
"Only by the DPP obtaining a majority of seats in the Legislative Yuan can these historic missions be accomplished," Chang claimed.

Speaking on the same occasion, Vice President Annette Lu said in her capacity as a DPP member that deepening Taiwan's democracy, governing according to the law and constructing the country based on human rights will be the three major missions to be accomplished by the ruling party over the coming years.
The DPP has fulfilled two historic missions in the past -- namely ending authoritarian rule in Taiwan and making a peaceful power transfer between political parties happen, she added.

Speaking at the congress as a guest, Huang Chu-wen, chairman of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), called for cooperation between his party and the DPP in December's legislative elections to obtain a combined majority in the 225-seat Legislature. The TSU is an ally of the DPP in the "pan green camp."
More than 300 party representatives attended the congress which was called to revise the DPP's nomination process in its primaries for legislator-at-large candidates.

According to a proposal approved by the DPP's Central Executive Committee, legislators-at-large, who are appointed by political parties in proportion to the number of votes the party garners in the legislative elections, will be named by the party chairman with the approval of the Central Executive Committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU SCIENCE PARK POWER BACK ON AFTER HOUR-LONG OUTAGE

TEXT.P: Operations at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, Taiwan's high-tech heartland, have returned to normal after an hour-long power outage early Saturday morning, industry sources said.

The power outage hit companies at the Hsinchu park's third-phase expansion area at 7: 30 a.m. and lasted for nearly an hour. Major companies in the area, including Macronix International Co. and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC), were affected by the unexpected outage.
As the outage also caused an abrupt severe voltage drop in power supply in other parts of the park, industry sources said, operations at many companies in those areas were also affected.
According to the sources, nearly all of the 300-plus companies in the Hsinchu park were affected by the power outage.
But Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) said the power outage mainly affected seven large electronics companies as well as 21 other high-voltage and 54 low-voltage power users in the park.

Taipower said the outage might have been caused by an inappropriate closure of production facilities at a company inside the park for annual maintenance. "We are still probing the cause in order to determine who should take responsibility for the outage, " a Taipower official said.
All of the seven large electronics firms in the park, including Macronix and TSMC, said the outage has not caused serious financial losses and will not affect their normal operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS DECIDE TO LAUNCH INDEFINITE SIT-IN

TEXT.P: The college students on a hunger strike at Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall to demand the truth about the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian ended their hunger strike Saturday after nine days at the suggestion of doctors but also decided to launch an indefinite sit-in for their cause.

Two of the students read a statement, saying that they had hoped President Chen would meet with them by this past Friday to gain a better understanding of their appeals but that the president failed to do so. Claiming that the president has not shown any concern for the well-being of their young bodies, the students said they had lost all hope of meeting with him.

Although they expressed thanks to the president for his invitation to them to join the March 12 meeting between himself and some 50 student leaders from around the nation, the students said that the meeting has nothing to do with their appeals and they therefore have decided to launch an indefinite sit-in protest.

The students are calling for an end to the ethnic split in Taiwan society and the truth behind the election-eve assassination attempt against Chen and Vice President Annette Lu during a campaign activity in Tainan, southern Taiwan, in which both were slightly injured.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" ticket of Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong was defeated by Chen and Lu in the March 20 election by the slim margin of just under 30,000 of the more than 13 million votes cast. Many believe that the shooting won many sympathy votes for Chen, while the "security mechanism" triggered by the shooting deprived many military service members and police officers of their right to vote.

The issue has resulted in serious political turmoil, evidenced by the string of large-scale protests in front of the Presidential Office and the student sit-in demanding the "truth" in the aftermath of the presidential election.

Chen Cheng-feng, a leader of the sit-in students, said they joined in the protest on their own and do not belong to any political party and do not hope to cause any ethnic confrontation. He said they will not initiate contact with "pan-blue alliance" supporters who have scheduled a massive protest nearby later in the day for the same cause.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SHOULD REFORM TO RESPOND TO MAINSTREAM PUBLIC OPINION: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should insist on reform in the wake of the March 20 presidential election in order to respond to mainstream public opinion.
Chen made the remarks while presiding over an extraordinary party congress in his capacity as DPP chairman.

Noting that the DPP campaigned on a platform of "Believe in Taiwan, Insist on Reform" in the run-up to the election, Chen said his re-election indicates that the commitment to reform has received resounding support in local society.
To live up to public expectations, Chen said, the DPP should carry out intraparty reform after winning the presidential election.
In his view, Chen said, the road to deepen and normalize Taiwan's young democracy can be accomplished in three stages.

"We have realized our first-stage goal by winning the 2004 presidential election, and now we must step up efforts to realize our second-stage goal by capturing more than half of the seats to be up for grabs in the year-end legislative elections," Chen said.
In the third stage, Chen said, the DPP wants to write a new constitution suitable for Taiwan's present situation.

"We have scheduled putting the proposed new constitution to a referendum in 2006, " Chen said. "Now that we have again won the presidency, we must accelerate preparations for the year-end legislative elections in order to control a majority in the Legislative Yuan to facilitate implementation of our reform agenda and complete '100 percent' transition of power between different political parties."
Stressing that unceasing intraparty reform is the best way to guard against corruption, Chen said the DPP must not stop its reform drive after the recent election victory.

"Even though the path of reform is usually winding and bumpy, the DPP should not be daunted by any challenge and should instead serve as a driving force behind Taiwan's reform and progress, " Chen said, adding that reform is the DPP's commitment to the 23 million people of Taiwan.

As the first step for intraparty reform, Chen said, the DPP must overhaul its nomination rules for at-large legislative seats which are alloted among major political parties in proportion to the number of votes they garner in regional-seat elections.
"We should revise our nomination rules for at-large legislative seat candidacy in order to attract more talent to join our ranks and win more voter support," Chen urged.
Several proposals regarding the nomination rule changes will be put up for discussion at the half-day extraordinary party congress which began at 1 p.m. Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA ALLOWS TAICHUNG AIRPORT TO HANDLE INTERNATIONAL CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) will allow the newly inaugurated Taichung International Airport in central Taiwan to handle international charter flights on a limited and conditional basis, CAA officials said Saturday.

CAA director-general Chang Kuo-cheng said the agency originally planned not to allow Taichung International Airport to handle international charter flight services in the short term, except for three international charter flights to Tokyo, Phuket Island in Thailand, and Palau on its inaugural day, due to the limited space in its hangars for larger airplanes. The airport was inaugurated March 5 this year.

However, Chang added, residents in central Taiwan have expressed a strong desire that the only international airport in central Taiwan be allowed to handle more international charter flights, and furthermore, to open charter flight services between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait for the next Chinese New Year.

Although the agency plans to allow international charter flight services out of the airport, Chang said, there have been conditions attached so as not to affect the domestic flights operating from the airport. International flights must depart earlier in the morning than domestic flights and arrive at the airport after all domestic flights for the day have done so.

On the public's calls for cross-strait flight services for the Chinese New Year period, Chang said this is not an issue for the CAA to decide. He added that if the government gives the green light, there won't be any technical problems for the CAA in implementing it.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE URGED TO TOLERATE AND RESPECT ONE ANOTHER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 9 (CNA) (By W.J. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top official in the United States on Friday urged overseas Chinese to tolerate and respect each other in the wake of Taiwan's controversial presidential election March 20.

Chen Chien-jen, Taiwan's representative to the United States, made the remarks in response to media questions regarding the seriousness of the split within local overseas Chinese communities after the election.

Admitting that serious disunity exists in the local Chinese communities, the representative said that the problem has been complicated by mainland China's attempts to take advantage of the situation to gain more support from the local Chinese communities.
As Taiwan society has become deeply divided between the rival pan-green and pan-blue camps, the split has also appeared in overseas Chinese communities in the United States, he said.

Both overseas Chinese affairs and foreign affairs are an extension of internal affairs, the envoy said, adding that the mood within the overseas Chinese communities could be a reflection of the current situation within Taiwan.

Promising that his office will do its utmost to help promote harmony among those within the overseas Chinese communities in the United States who have different views and stances, the representative also urged the members of these communities to have open minds and tolerate and respect one another.
He also called for leaders in all areas of Taiwan society to use their influence to promote social harmony as this will also facilitate unity within Chinese communities abroad.
