DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 10, or the 21st day of the leap second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1512: James V of Scotland, who became king at the age of 17 months, is born. He allied Scotland with France against the English.
1810: Pirate chieftainess "Dragon Lady" Cheng Yi-sao surrenders herself and the 1,800 junks under her command to China's Ching court.
1814: British and Spanish forces defeat Napoleon's army at the Battle of Toulouse, leading to his abdication and exile to the island of Elba the next day.
1829: William Booth, the British religious leader who founded the Salvation Army with his wife Catherine Mumford Booth and who served as its first general, is born.
1847: Hungarian-born American journalist Joseph Pulitzer is born. The newspaper publisher owned newspapers in St. Louis and New York City and established and endowed the Pulitzer Prizes for achievements in journalism and literature.
1858: Chinese Governor-General Ye Ming-chen of Canton and a prisoner of Britain, dies in Calcutta during an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing in 1858.
1898: France obtains concessions from China's Ching court.
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected president of the Republic of China.
1932: German general and politician Paul von Hindenburg is re-elected president of the Weimar Republic with 19 million votes to Adolf Hitler's 13 million. He appoints Hitler chancellor in 1933.
1938: More than 99 percent of Austrian voters in a referendum cast their ballots in favor of a merger with Germany.
1944: Brigadier General Charles de Gaulle, who is number one on the hit list of the collaborationist Vichy government of Marshal Petain, becomes commander-in-chief of all the Free French forces.
1946: Japan holds general elections with women voting for the first time.
1953: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the resignation of Taiwan Governor Wu Kuo-chen and names Yu Hung-chun as his replacement.
1958: Dr. Hu Shih assumes office as president of the ROC's Academia Sinica.
1960: The U.S. Senate passes the Civil Rights Bill.
1963: The USS Thresher, an American atomic submarine, sinks in the northern Atlantic, killing all 290 aboard.
1971: Ethnic Chinese hold a mass rally in Washington, D.C., to show their support for the protection of a disputed territory known to the Chinese as the Tiaoyutai Islands.
1972: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Tonga.
1972: The United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty banning biological warfare.
1976: Miguel Urrutia Montoya, director of the national planning department of the Republic of Colombia, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1979: U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs legislation permitting continued commercial and cultural relations between the American government and the ROC following the break in their diplomatic ties.
1980: Mainland China and the Soviet Union end a friendship pact they signed in 1950.
1983: U.S. President Ronald Reagan's Middle East peace plan collapses when King Hussein of Jordan fails to reach an accord with the Palestine Liberation Organization on the terms of the deal.
1986: The United States conducts a nuclear test in the Nevada desert.
1991: Georgia becomes the latest of the Soviet republics wishing to break away from central control.
1996: Mainland Chinese Premier Li Peng's visit to France is marred by a diplomatic wrangle with his French counterpart Alain Juppe over human rights in Beijing.
2000: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on David Dean, former Taipei director of the American Institute in Taiwan.
2001: The 13th annual convention of the Overseas Chinese Council in Asia opens in Osaka, Japan, with more than 400 delegates from the Asia-Pacific region participating.
2002: Vice President Annette Lu wins a civil suit against the Taipei-based Journalist weekly, for damage to her image arising from a false report carried by the magazine.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who possesses moral worth will always have something to say worth listening to, but a man who has something to say is not necessarily a man of moral worth."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ANNOUNCES NEW FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun announced Sunday that Legislator Chen Tan-sun of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has been appointed new minister of foreign affairs, replacing Eugene Chien, who tendered his resignation last Friday.

Speaking at a press conference, Yu described Chen, a U.S.-trained scientist-turned-lawmaker, as an appropriate substitute for Chien, and asked for support from everyone so that Chen can lead Taiwan's diplomatic front to a broader horizon.

Yu said that Chen demonstrated shrewd initiative and execution power during his eight-year stint as magistrate of the southern county of Tainan between 1993 and 2001. During the period, he was ranked by public opinion polls as the top county chief, enjoying the highest approval rating among all magistrates in Taiwan in five years, Yu added.

Yu said he and Chen share mixed feelings about Chen's climb of the ladder of success -- from a student activist blacklisted by the then-Kuomintang government to a popularly elected magistrate, a legislator and now a foreign minister.

For his part, Chen, who was chairman of the Taiwanese Association of America, the World Federation of Taiwanese Associations and the Formosan Association for Public Affairs, said he has never harbored thoughts of becoming foreign minister.
Accepting his appointment, Chen lauded his predecessors, including outgoing Chien, for having laid a solid foundation for him to start with as a newcomer.

Chen said he will not be a new broom after assuming his post and will take advantage of the experiences of his predecessors. However, he said he will use creativity and take new initiatives in reviewing Taiwan's diplomatic ties with its 20-odd allies in efforts to broaden the country's diplomatic horizon.

There are many ways to do this, Chen went on, adding that the best way for Taiwan is to enable the head of state to travel out of the country to visit allies and friendly countries that maintain no formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan.

Chen, 68, holder of a PhD from Purdue University in the United States, also served with the Department of Commerce of the U.S. federal government for 19 years before returning to Taiwan at the beginning of the 90's.

At the press conference, Yu also praised Chien as a capable and brilliant foreign minister who has given an outstanding performance, particularly in Taiwan's efforts to establish a representative office at the headquarters of the European Union and in President Chen Shui-bian's landmark visit to the United States, with which the Republic of China maintains no formal diplomatic relations.

Chien offered to resign last Friday over the departure of American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen -- the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

"Ms. Shaheen was a good friend of Taiwan and a bridge between Taiwan and the U.S. State Department, and we appreciate her contribution to Taiwan-U.S. relations, " Chien told a news conference last Friday.
In Shaheen's resignation, Chien said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs had been guilty of dereliction of duty and insufficient supervision.

Yu also said that excellent government officials with ability and integrity will not be left idle and that new Cabinet assignments will be announced after May 12, when the Cabinet will resign en masse before the May 20 inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR EXPECTED TO HOVER BETWEEN 32.8-33.0 AGAINST GREENBACK

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar is expected to hover around the 32.8-33.0 mark against the U.S. dollar this week after experiencing a wave of fluctuations last week fueled largely by a depreciating yen and a rising U.S. dollar, banking sources said Sunday.
The local currency could continue to lose steam against other major foreign currencies in the coming days due to a temporary halt to the depreciating yen, the sources said.

The new Taiwan dollar ended at 32.940 against the greenback last Friday, which represents a marked fall of NT$0.011 from the week-earlier level of 32.929. The loss in value was mainly prompted by the depreciating yen, which finished at 106.3 against the U.S. dollar, and a lackluster local bourse.

For the time being, the volatile political situation at home caused by continuing protests over their presidential election defeat by "pan-blue alliance" supporters will play a key role in the new Taiwan dollar's short-term levels, they said, adding that the local currency will not see dramatic fluctuations and foreign exchange traders maintain their wait-and-see attitude.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HOLDS RALLIES IN TAINAN TO THANK VOTERS WHO RE-ELECTED CHEN

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) held one rally each in Tainan City and Hsinying, Tainan County Sunday to thank those who voted to re-elect President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.
Addressing the gatherings attended by several thousands supporters, President Chen promised to construct Taiwan into a complete, normal and modern democratic nation by continuing reform programs.

He encouraged the DPP supporters to continue to help his party win more than half of the seats in the legislature in the December's legislative elections so that it can carry out its commitment to reform.

The president, who doubles as DPP chairman, also urged the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong to accept the results of the March 20 presidential election in which he won re-election by a slim margin of 0.228 percent or 29,518 votes out of the 13 million cast and let the election disputes be settled through judicial channels.
For the sake of security, President Chen and Vice President Lu appeared at the rallies in Hsinying and Tainan City alternatively amid tight security.
Both Chen and Lu wore flak jackets and the podium on which they delivered their speeches was surrounded with bullet-proof glass.

The two narrowly escaped serious injury from an assassination attempt on March 19 in Tainan City while parading through the streets in an open-top jeep. Chen suffered a flesh wound to his abdomen while Lu was injured in her right knee. No one has yet been arrested for the election-eve attack.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENT PROTESTERS WILL NOT ATTEND MEETING WITH PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A group of students who have been staging a sit-in protest at the Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) Memorial Hall have decided not to attend a meeting planned Monday by President Chen Shui-bian with student leaders from across Taiwan in Taipei, group leader Chen Cheng-feng said Sunday.

Chen Cheng-feng said that the protesters have reached a final decision to not take part in Monday's meeting with the president, in which nearly 100 student leaders from universities and colleges from around the country will exchange views on a broad range of issues with the president and the education and interior ministers.
Although they have demanded a meeting with the president, Chen said that they will not participate in Monday's meeting, which he said is not the right kind of meeting.

He added that the students protesting at the CKS memorial hall have created a "social forum" to explain their stance on the various appeals they have raised and that they welcome the general public to interact with them at the platform.

Meanwhile, more than half of the dozen student protesters have quit a so-called "fast" but will continue the sit-in at the plaza, while the remaining four or five students are determined to continue doing without food for several hours at a time as they have been doing since they started their protest April 2.

The students have a variety of demands, including the establishment of what they call a"truth committee" to investigate the March 19 shooting of the president and Vice President Annette Lu and the drafting of an anti-discrimination bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC TRAVEL INDUSTRY SHOWS SIGNS OF RECOVERY

TEXT.P: Although the disputes over the March 20 presidential election still cast a shadow over the political situation at home, the domestic travel industry has showed noticeable signs of recovery, a tourism source said Sunday.
At a time when both outbound and inbound travel remains affected by the disputes, tourism at home has rebounded and is expected to become more prosperous in the coming months, the source said.

For instance, the occupancy rate at hotels in the eastern Hualien area averaged lower than 50 percent in March, but the ratio has increased to about 60 percent or 70 percent, the source said, forecasting that travelers will pay more than 100 million visits to tourist spots and resort facilities around Taiwan this year.

The source attributed the increased popularity of domestic travel to an improved quality in both the software and hardware of many tourism-related businesses. The Internet in particular, he pointed out, provides effective and swift access for travelers looking for services and information.
In contrast, outbound and inbound travel has remained sluggish since the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in the first half of last year, according to the source.

As a result of the lingering uncertainties over ties between Taiwan and mainland China and the re-election of President Chen Shui-bian, mainland-bound tourist travel might further decline, he said. Businessmen now form the bulk of Taiwan travelers heading for the mainland.

At the same time, long-haul pleasure trips to the United States and Europe also remain lackluster because of grave security concerns among the public, while travel to destinations in Southeast Asian countries has increasingly lost its appeal for Taiwan tourists.
However, outbound travel to Northeast Asian countries, especially Japan, has been on the rise, he noted.
Meanwhile, inbound travel has been the most affected by a wave of recession hitting the domestic tourism industry, he pointed out.

Many tourist groups from neighboring countries have put off or canceled their trips to Taiwan, especially those from Japan, because of various reasons, ranging from last year's SARS outbreaks to the recent political unrest.

To reverse this trend, the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has launched prominent campaigns overseas to lure foreign tourists to Taiwan, as part of the government's agenda under "Challenge 2008, " a six-year national development plan, the source said.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI FESTIVAL HELD IN TAOYUAN

TEXT.P: Nearly 10,000 foreign laborers had a great time taking part in a traditional Thai Songkran festival in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan Sunday.
The annual event -- the sixth sponsored by the Taoyuan county government to help relieve the homesickness of the many foreign workers in that county -- was held at the Taoyuan "big egg" stadium.
During Songkran, Thai people spray water or throw buckets of water at each other to symbolize washing away the misfortunes of the past year and ushering in the new year.
Sunday's event also included performances of Thai music and dance, as well as stalls selling delicious Thai food.

Singers Jonas from the Netherlands and Christy from Sweden, who are well-known in Thailand because they have lived there for a long time, sang traditional Thai folk songs and greeted the participants in Thai.
The highlight of the event came when the fire department dispatched tenders that sprayed water cannons, much to the delight of the participants.

A Songkran beauty contest and transvestite competition, which were very popular in past years, were scrapped this year, but the event still attracted many curious Taiwanese and foreign laborers from neighboring Taipei and Hsinchu counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CRITICIZES ORGANIZERS OF OPPOSITION-LED PROTEST IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun criticized the organizers of an April 10 opposition-led mass protest in Taipei that ended in violence Sunday, saying that they failed to control the protesters.

Yu also called on opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, who have challenged the results of the March 20 presidential election, to allow the election disputes to be settled through judicial channels.

Lien and Soong, who formed the opposition "pan blue alliance" ticket, lost the presidential poll to President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu by a narrow margin of 29,518 votes out of more than 13 million cast.
Yu said that the organizers of the demonstration should be blamed for the violence that left nearly 100 people injured, including police officers, demonstrators and innocent bystanders.
The organizers should have been capable of controlling the participants in their rally, Yu said, adding that the "irresponsible politicians" involved in the gathering should be condemned.
The premier expressed the hope that Saturday's protest would be the end of all "irrational activities" and that society will be allowed to get back onto the normal tack.

The protest, organized by the KMT-PFP alliance in front of the Presidential Office, was to call for the establishment of a legislative investigation task force to look into the March 19 shooting of Chen and Lu.
Lien and Soong led the crowd to Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office to demand the formation of a special committee under the Legislative Yuan to investigate the shooting.
Lien claims that the shooting unfairly swayed the election in Chen's favor, and insinuated that the shooting might have been staged in order to gain sympathy votes.
The rally of some 80,000 people, which began peacefully, turned violent in the evening after the organizers of the event announced an end to the gathering.
Riot police clashed with angry protestors who tried to storm barbed-wire barricades outside the Presidential Office.

The violence ran through early Sunday morning, with riot police using water cannons against protestors in efforts to disperse them after they began throwing bottles, rocks and ball bearings, and wielding flag poles and clubs.
The police said that 96 people were injured in the clashes, including 55 police officers.
The police arrested 13 initiators of the violence, of whom six were found to have criminal records. They also confiscated slingshots, rocks, gas cans and handicraft knives.

Responding to criticism by "pan blue alliance" supporters for the police handling of the dispersal, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is a KMT vice chairman, defended the actions as "necessary and according to the law." However, he admitted that there is room for improvement in police methods of handling violent protests.
Minister of the Interior Su Chia-chuan also affirmed the measures and actions taken by the Taipei city government and the police in dealing with the incident.
It was the third large protest rally organized by the "pan-blue alliance" since Lien lost to incumbent President Chen in the bitterly fought March 20 presidential election.

The Nation: IRAQ / Fighting rages on as US offers truce.
Street fighting erupted in Baghdad yesterday and sporadie gunfire echoed across Fallujah despite a new US truce offer and an effort by Iraqi officals to secure a peace deal with insurgents in the western city. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: RARE HISTORICAL TAIWANESE POSTAGE STAMPS UNEARTHED IN ITALY
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, April 11 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Two rare historical Taiwanese postage stamps carrying the name "The Taiwan Republic" in Chinese issued in the late Ching Dynasty were recently unearthed in Italy and have been obtained by a Republic of China official posted in Rome, philatelic sources said Sunday.

The "Sole Tiger, Taiwan Republic" stamps, believed to have been issued in 1895 by a then-nascent republic government in Taiwan led by self-styled militia leader Liu Yung-fu in Tainan, southern Taiwan, are said to have appeared in a stamp-collecting exchange market in Rome several weeks ago.
The stamps, known by oriental stamp collectors as the "Sole Tiger" stamps, are almost legendary, so seldom are they seen.

The pair of stamps, each bearing a picture of a tiger and the name of the Taiwan Republic in blue-green and light pink, respectively, lay in the Rome market for weeks without arousing attention from collectors as none of them knew Chinese, until a Taiwan liaison official came across the stamps and snapped them up on the spot.
According to the Taiwanese, surnamed Lin, the two stamps have greater value to the people of Taiwan in terms of the island's contemporary history than the stamps' market value.

The two stamps can serve as a mirror on history through which the people of Taiwan can look back at what happened on the island more than 100 years ago and how the Han people, Hakka people, Japanese and other foreigners fought among themselves for the island.

According to historical archives, Liu Yung-fu (1837-1917) , originally an opium trader between the highlands on the border of Vietnam and Canton, molded his followers into a well-disciplined band skilled in martial arts and ruled an effectively independent fiefdom on the Sino-French border in the 1860s and beyond.

Although initially regarded as a rebel leader by the Ching court, Liu parlayed his way into favor by fighting for the tribute kingdom of Vietnam against the assertive French from 1873 and 1884. After returning to Canton in 1885, Liu and his Black Flag militia proved a problem for the Ching Court, which welcomed the opportunity to dispatch Liu to Taiwan in 1895 with the lure of creating his own tribute state there.
Liu and his famed Black Flag troops arrived in southern Taiwan in early 1895, only months before Taiwan yielded to Japan colonialism in April that year.
As a result of the Sino-Japanese War the Ching Court was forced to cede Taiwan to Japan upon the signing of the Shimonoseki Treaty April 17, 1895.

Liu established the Taiwan Republic in Tainan on July 31, 1895, shortly prior to the Japanese invasion. The Taiwan Post Office was also established during that period, although it lasted for only 80 days. The "Sole Tiger" stamps are believed to have been issued during that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 ILAN GREEN EXPO CLOSES

TEXT.P: The 2004 Ilan Green Exposition at Wulaokeng, a scenic area in Suao township in the northeastern county of Ilan closed Sunday after attracting around 400,000 visitors.
Ilan County Magistrate Liu Shou-cheng said that the expo highlighted content and quality, focusing on education and environmental protection, which set it apart from other floral expos in Taiwan.

The expo this year received high acclaim on all eight of its theme halls featuring flowers, ferns, frogs, turtles, mildew, ethnic foods, glass and displays on the environment and ecology through solar energy and wind power, said Liu.
The annual expo is the fifth consecutive show of its kind to be sponsored by the Ilan county government, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT, VICE PRESIDENT SUFFERED GUNSHOT WOUNDS: FORENSICS EXPERT

TEXT.P: A renowned forensics expert invited to Taiwan to help investigate the March 19 presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu said Sunday that they did indeed suffer gunshot wounds.
Dr. Henry Lee made the remarks at a press conference held at the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) prior to his departure after a whirlwind two-day stay.

He said that the two bullets collected at the shooting scene in Tainan, southern Taiwan bore traces of clothing fibers and windshield glass, which Lee said shows that they were the two bullets that hit Chen and Lu. Chen was grazed on the lower abdomen, while Lu received a scratch to her knee.

At the press conference in which Lee summarized the forensic evidence examination, he spoke on his team's progress with the bullets and the shells, the clothing worn by the president and vice president when the incident took place, an examination of their wounds, the bullet hole in the windshield of the jeep in which they were riding when they were shot, and a reconstruction of the trajectories of the bullets.
He said that judging from glass shards found in the jeep, the bullets came from outside the jeep -- some skeptics believe bodyguards riding in the jeep shot the president.

Showing pictures of Chen's bloodstained clothing, he said that there was little actual blood on the jacket and that some of the large blotches on Chen's jacket and shirt were in fact a petroleum-based ointment.

Chen has said that after being shot, he thought he had been hurt by one of the firecrackers that the crowd was igniting to greet him, so he asked his bodyguards to help him apply ointment to the wound.
Lee determined that the two bullets used in the shooting appear to have been home-made in the same illegal workshop because they bear similar marks left by machinery or tools.

He suggested that CIB forensic personnel should trace the machine marks, carefully examine the ingredients of the gunpowder used, and conduct trial shooting on clothing and windshield glass. He also said that the attacker used a semi-automatic weapon.
He was unable to speculate as to whether the shooting was carried out by a professional killer.

Lee would not respond to questions of whether there is a possibility that the shooting was staged to win last-minute sympathy votes for Chen, saying only that he expressed his stance before coming to Taiwan that he is "coming to examine the physical evidence and not to conduct a criminal investigation." Before his arrival, some had doubted his impartiality, pointing out his support of the opposition "pan-blue alliance."

He added that the knowledge that many people in Taiwan are pinning their hopes on his being able to shed more light on the case has made the case "the most daunting in terms of difficulty and pressure" since he started forensics work.
Lee said he will further examine the evidence when he returns to the United States.
He was very positive about the performance of the CIB, saying that it kept the evidence intact and that the "physical evidence collected has not been contaminated or replaced."
Lee, who was involved in such high-profile cases as the O.J. Simpson murder trial, was invited by State Public Prosecutor General Lu Ren-fa to help with the case.

Upon his arrival in Taiwan Friday morning, he went straight to the Presidential Office to examine the president's wounds. He then went to the CIB to listen to a briefing on the shooting and examine the evidence, traveling later to the Chi Mei Medical Center in Tainan County where the president sought medical treatment after shooting, where he viewed X-rays of the president. He went to the scene of the shooting in Tainan City later, where he determined a possible attack location by using a laser pointer.
He returned from Tainan to Taipei Saturday afternoon and went straight to the vice president's residence to examine her wound.
After a dinner hosted by the state public prosecutor general, he continued to discuss the case with his team.

Accompanying him were Charles P. Illsley, who developed an alternative light source technology that is used to detect trace amounts of substances that are invisible to the human eye, as well as crime scene special photographer Calvin D. Ostler, legal consultant Austin J. McGuigan, and his assistant Dr. Jacob S. Loke.
Lee said that during his two-day hours in Taiwan, he had slept for only 90 minutes and was "practically exhausted. "

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR MACAU OPENS TAIPEI-CHENGDU ROUTE VIA MACAU

TEXT.P: Air Macau inaugurated a route between Taipei and the mainland Chinese city of Chengdu via Macau Saturday, providing the first flight between Taipei and Chengdu that does not require passengers to transfer between aircraft during the Macau stopover, according to a spokesman for the aviation company.

Air Macau uses the 178-seat Airbus 321 plane on the five-hour flight the spokesman said, adding that the carrier will ply the route on a twice weekly basis, increasing to four flights per week during the July-October peak period.

The major purpose of the new route is to serve Taiwan businessmen who have to travel frequently between Taiwan and the mainland. Chengdu in Sichuan Province is a major investment destination for businessmen from Taiwan exploring new horizons in the mainland's vast southwestern region.
Air Macau also opened a Shenzhun-Taipei route via Macau March 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: AWC MAKE A PITCH FOR ""LOVE AND PEACE"" ENDORSEMENT IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: The Association of World Citizens (AWC) will end an activity described as a "love and peace endorsement" in front of the Taichung railway station Sunday.
The Taiwan branch of the AWC, a non-government organization, started the activity April 1 and has obtained in excess of 60,000 signatures.
The AWC also invited an Indian folk dance troupe currently in central Taiwan to perform traditional Indian dances in an effort to attract more people on the activity's final day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOTELIERS PAMPER GUESTS WITH STATE-OF-THE-ART TVs

TEXT.P: Taiwan 5-star hotels are enhancing in-room entertainment by replacing conventional TVs with plasma display panel (PDP) TVs or thin film transistor-liquid crystal display (TFT-LCD) TVs, hoteliers said Sunday.
The Hotel Evergreen Laurel Hotel in Taipei was the first to adopt top-notch 42" PDP TVs in some of its rooms, followed by the Westin Taipei hotel.
The Hotel Royal Taipei, after procuring the right to re-lease, decided to entirely renovate its rooms and add large size TFT-LCD TVs in its chain of hotels throughout Taiwan and Mauritius.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 11, or the 22nd day of the leap second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1713: France cedes Newfoundland and Gibraltar to Britain.
1775: James Parkinson, the British physician who defined Parkinson's disease, a progressive disease of the nervous system also called paralysis agitans or shaking palsy, is born.
1814: Louis XVIII accedes to the throne as Napoleon Bonaparte abdicates and is banished to the island of Elba under the Treaty of Fontainebleau.
1893: Dean Acheson, the U.S. politician and secretary of state who helped to formulate the Truman Doctrine and the Marshall Plan and who promoted the setting up of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), is born.
1899: Spain transfers control of the Philippines to the United States.
1919: The International Labor Organization is founded in Geneva in affiliation with the League of Nations to improve living standards and working conditions.
1926: American horticulturist Luther Burbank dies at the age of 77. He developed countless new varieties of fruits, vegetables and flowers, including the Burbank potato and the Shasta daisy.
1935: Dust storms wreak havoc in the so-called "Dust Bowl" states of Kansas, Colorado, Wyoming, Oklahoma, Texas and New Mexico in the United States.
1945: U.S. forces capture the German towns of Essen and Weimar and liberate the Buchenwald concentration camp near the end of World War II.
1950: The Bank of Taiwan issues its first lottery.
1950: China lodges a complaint with the United Nations against Soviet aid to the Chinese communists, the Soviet invasion of China and Soviet violation of the U.N. Charter.
1951: U.S. President Harry Truman relieves Gen. Douglas MacArthur, the World War II hero who accepted the Japanese surrender in Tokyo Bay in 1945, of all his command, including that of U.N. forces in Korea.
1957: Singapore is granted self-government by the United Kingdom.
1969: Taiwan's Executive Yuan approves the "Guidelines for the Population Policy of the Republic of China."
1970: The government of Prime Minister Lon Nol announces abolishment of the monarchy and proclaims Cambodia a republic.
1974: U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, leading a party of 19, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the Sino-Honduran Fishery Technical Cooperation Agreement.
1976: An ROC education mission headed by Education Minister Y.S. Tsiang leaves for the Middle East on a visit.
1976: Col. Carlos Humberto Romero, secretary of defense and pacific security of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1978: The Taiwan Province Black Foot Disease Control Center is inaugurated in Peimen Village, Tainan County.
1979: A combined force of Ugandan exiles and Tanzanian troops captures the Ugandan capital of Kampala, ending the eight-year rule of Idi Amin.
1981: Chen Ta, a noted singer of Taiwanese folk songs, dies at the age of 76.
1994: U.S. President Bill Clinton orders trade sanctions against Taiwan in accordance with the Pelly Act.
1995: Chen Yun, one of Communist China's leading veteran hardliners and one of its leading economic planners, dies in Beijing at the age of 90.
1997: Turin Cathedral is engulfed by flames, but firefighters manage to save the famous Turin Shroud.
2000: Foreign ministers of the 113-member Non-Aligned Movement endorse the Philippine-led regional code of conduct in the South China Sea to promote peace and stability in the region.
2001: The Executive Yuan signs an agreement with the Netherlands Trade and Investment Office (NTIO) in Taipei to enact regulations to prevent double taxation on Dutch people working in Taiwan as well as those from Taiwan in the Netherlands.
2002: The European Parliament passes a pro-Taiwan resolution urging mainland China to dismantle missile deployment against Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A moral character always has courage; but a man of courage is not necessarily a moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE ECONOMY SURGES 7.3% IN FIRST QUARTER

TEXT.P: Singapore's real gross domestic product (GDP) in the first quarter 2004 increased by 7.3 percent over the same period in 2003, the government said Monday.
This represents the fastest year-on-year growth since the fourth quarter of 2000.
Growth was broadbased, supported by improvements in both the manufacturing and services industries, the Trade and Industry Ministry said in a statement.
On an annualized quarter-on-quarter basis, real GDP rose by an estimated 11 percent, maintaining the same strong growth momentum as the previous quarter, the ministry said.

"In light of the strong growth in the first quarter and the favorable external environment, especially in the IT markets, the GDP growth range for the whole year is likely to be higher than the current forecast of between 3.5 percent and 5.5 percent," it said.
The ministry said it will release its revised annual growth forecast and full quarterly GDP figures next month.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE CENTRAL BANK TO TIGHTEN POLICY

TEXT.P: In a surprise move, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said Monday that it will tighten policy by shifting from neutral to allow a modest and gradual appreciation of the Singapore dollar.
The central bank said it made the decision because of the strong growth in the Singapore economy and rising inflation.
Most economists had expected Singapore to continue with a neutral monetary policy until the next policy statement in October.

The MAS said it was shifting from a zero percent appreciation path to a policy of modest and gradual appreciation of the Singapore dollar, starting from the mid-point of the current policy band. However, it added that the width of the band will remain unchanged.
The central bank also revised upward its inflation forecast for this year from between 0.5 percent and 1.5 percent to between 1.5 percent and 2 percent.

"Consumer price inflation has trended up in recent months, averaging 1.4 percent year-on-year for the January-February period this year, compared to 0.5 percent and 0.7 percent in the last two quarters of 2003, respectively," the MAS said.
It said the increase largely reflected supply-side factors, including the effects of global commodity-related price increases and Singapore's goods-and-services tax hike in January 2004.

Los Angeles Times: Memo Cited Fears of Attacks in U.S.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP BRINGS LIBEL SUIT AGAINST KMT

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) brought an action of libel against the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Monday on the grounds that KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng claimed Saturday that the riots that took place that night in front of the Presidential Office after a protest rally called by the KMT was stirred up by DPP members who mingled with the KMT supporters.
The lawsuit was brought by DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTRY WORKING ON AMENDMENTS TO REFERENDUM LAW

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) is working on amendments to the Referendum Law to lay the groundwork for a referendum on at least four issues along with the year-end legislative elections, Vice Minister of the Interior Lee Chin-yung said Monday.

In a briefing for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party caucus at the Legislative Yuan, Lee said the ministry has already laid down 10 proposals to improve the Referendum Law, which was enacted by the Legislative Yuan in March.

According to the MOI's proposal, the number of sponsors needed to initiate a referendum should be cut, the criteria for an effective referendum should be relaxed, the Legislative Yuan's right to start a referendum should be abolished, and the Referendum Proposal Committee -- which duplicates the function of the Central Election Committee -- should be scrapped.

Furthermore, the vice minister said, an article in the Referendum Law that requires all Constitutional amendments be approved by the people through referendum should be rescinded as it usurps the power of the National Assembly, which is the only organization with the authority to vote on amendments to the Constitution.

Since the DPP intends to put at least four issues to referendum in conjunction with the year-end legislative elections, Lee said the revision of the Referendum Law is high on the MOI's agenda. He promised to submit a set of draft amendments to the Legislative Yuan by mid-May.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUNS, AMMUNITION SEIZURES LAST YEAR SET RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: Illegal guns and ammunition seized last year set a four-year high, according to statistics released Monday by the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB).

The statistics were revealed as an investigation into the shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu on the eve of the March 20 election still has made no major breakthroughs and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" is demanding that the "truth of the incident" -- which it claims swayed the election in Chen's favor -- be uncovered.

The statistics show that the CIB seized 2,643 illegal guns and 31,239 rounds of ammunition last year. Compared with the year-earlier level, the number of gun seizures increased by 680, while the amount of ammunition seized increased by 6,575 rounds.
Of the guns, 1,363 were homemade, accounting for 51.57 percent of the total, while police- and military-issue guns numbered 1,210.
The tallies show that the number of homemade guns has hovered at around 1,000 for the last four years, at 1,130 in 2000, 1,009 in 2001, 970 in 2002, and a surge to 1,363 last year.
The more powerful police- and military-issue guns seized in 2000 numbered 703, with 621 seized in 2001, 883 seized in 2002 and a new high of 1,210 seized last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL PARTIES MUST SET UP SPECIAL ACCOUNTS TO ACCEPT DONATIONS

TEXT.P: A political donations bill enacted March 31 means that all political parties, political groups and political aspirants must set up special accounts and register with the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, to accept donations.

So far, two political parties -- the opposition Kuomintang and the New Party -- and nine legislators who intend to take part in the year-end legislative elections have completed the registration process.
Under the bill, political figures are not allowed to accept political donations during non-election periods and only those who intend to run in an election can do so.

The bill also stipulates the period in which donations can be accepted, with the president allowed to accept political donations up to one year before his term expires, legislators allowed to accept donations up to 10 months before their term expires, and elected mayors, city councilors, magistrates and county councilors allowed to accept donations up to eight months before their term expires.
According to the bill, if the political donation accepted is not directly remitted into the special account, the recipients must deposit the donation into the account within 15 days of receipt.

The bill also stipulates that the maximum individual donation to one political party or group per year cannot exceed NT$300,000 (US$8,982). Donations to different parties or groups cannot exceed an accumulated NT$600,000 per year. Individual donations to individual political aspirants cannot exceed NT$100,000 a year while individual donations to more than one political aspirant cannot exceed NT$200,000 per year in total.

For-profit businesses can donate no more than NT$3 million to a single political party or group annually, while donations to more than one political parties or groups cannot exceed NT$6 million annually in total. Corporate donations to more than one political aspirant cannot exceed NT$2 million annually in total.
If political parties or aspirants accept donation prior to approval, they will face prison terms of no more than three years and could also be fined between NT$200,000 and NT$1 million.
Donations collected by political parties can be channeled to political aspirants, the Control Yuan said, with no upper ceiling.

Political donation bill was passed amid high-profile revelations by several figures, including disgraced former Tuntex Group Chairman Chen You-hao, that they made political donations to various political figures, which sparked heated debate about the practice.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSBC ADJUSTS ECONOMIC GROWTH FORECAST TO 6.5 PERCENT FOR 2004

TEXT.P: The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corp. (HSBC) has adjusted upward its forecast on Taiwan's economic growth to 6.5 percent for this year, HSBC officials said Monday.

According to an HSBC report, the officials said, the adjustment is based on Taiwan's rapid economic recovery, its solid manufacturing sector and the diminishing impact of the March 20 presidential election disputes on the confidence of businesses and consumers.
The election disputes are apparently to be settled rationally, the London-based international banking giant predicts in its report.
In addition, the report says there are many indications that Taiwan's domestic demand has been increasing.
The HSBC originally estimated that Taiwan's gross domestic product would increase by 5 percent this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS WILLINGNESS TO MEET WITH OPPOSITION LEADERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed his willingness Monday to meet with two opposition leaders unconditionally for exchanges of views on wide-ranging topics.
Chen made the reaffirmation during an unprecedented meeting with a group of university student leaders at the Red Chamber Theater in Taipei's Hsimenting shopping district.

"I'm willing to talk with Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong at any time of their convenience. The venue can be outside the Presidential Office. We need not set any preconditions. So long as we can sit down to talks, we'll be able to narrow our gap and reduce misunderstanding and misjudgment," Chen said.

Chen and Vice President Annette Lu narrowly defeated the Lien-Soong ticket to win a second four-year term in the bitterly fought March 20 presidential election. Lien and Soong have contested the result with sometimes violent street protests and two lawsuits.

Lien told the 130-plus student representatives from major universities around the country that he is willing to meet with groups from all walks of life before his May 20 inauguration for another presidential term.

"I'm more than willing to listen to different voices and iron out differences with the opposition camp. I want to be the president of all the 23 million Taiwan people, not of just the 6.47 million voters who voted for me in the election," Chen said.

In response to students' criticism that divisive rhetoric made by Chen and other ruling party politicians during the presidential campaign had hurt social harmony, Chen assured the students that he and his party would reflect on their rhetoric and work to narrow the widening gap between different political parties and ethnic groups.

"We do have a crisis and it's something the ruling party and I need to review and to address, " Chen said. "We are all proud of Taiwan, and we have no need to pigeon-hole people. We all love Taiwan and we shouldn't try to paint someone black or red."
As part of the efforts, Chen said he will push relevant government agencies to organize a conference to discuss issues regarding ethnic equality in education, language and cultural development.
Chen further said he believes that love and tolerance are the best way to defuse ethnic divisions and promote social harmony and internal unity.
"Taiwan is a great country. The Republic of China is a big family. If our country is divided, we can never stand up in the international community," Chen said.
He also promised that he will push for the holding of a national youth affairs conference after the May 20 inauguration.

Meanwhile, Chen promised to adopt a low-tuition fee policy, offer students a greater say in the formulation of education policy, further ease unnecessary restrictions on campus freedoms, and allow students to hold referendums on major education or school issues.
Chen further promised to develop Taiwan into a major hub for non-governmental organizations (NGOs).

"My administration will organize more international conferences or activities and encourage young people to work as interns at major NGOs," Chen said, adding that he hopes Taiwan can join the World Health Organization in two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROGRESS MADE IN RECOUNT MECHANISM PLANS

TEXT.P: Progress was made at a court hearing Monday on the method for recounting the ballots cast in the March 20 presidential election.

After two and a half hours of negotiations before the Taiwan High Court, attorneys representing the two election tickets agreed in the lawsuit concerning the validity of the presidential election that the votes to be re-examined should include all valid votes for both tickets, all invalid ballots, all unused blank ballots and the result reports from each polling station.

The lists of qualified voters and lists of overseas voters who returned to Taiwan to cast ballots will only be examined as a formality and will not affect the re-count. However, if there is any obvious evidence of irregularities in the lists, representatives of both sides can ask the court for a further investigation afterward.

The court insisted that the people appointed by the respective parties in the lawsuit to supervise the re-count must be attorneys or probation attorneys in practice, and asked both sides to present a list of attorneys they can retain before Friday.

Given there are more than 13 million ballots cast in more than 10,000 polling stations around the country, lawyers for both sides admitted they will have problems retaining enough attorneys so quickly.
Even if both sides come up with lists of attorneys, the recount is not expected to begin until mid-May, according to an anonymous judiciary official close to the lawsuit.

The retained attorneys, the official said, should first join clerks and bailiffs from district courts around the island for training in Taipei to familiarize themselves with the rules for judging the validity of votes and the practices in the recount.
After the training, the attorneys will team up with court clerks and bailiffs to conduct the recount, the judicial official went on.

The lawsuit was brought by the defeated presidential candidate, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, and his running mate, People First Party Chairman James Soong, after they lost by a slim margin to the incumbent President Chen Shui-bian and his running mate, Vice President Annette Lu.
Citing what they claim to be irregularities in the election, Lien and Soong challenged the fairness of the election and demanded a recount.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO KMT-PFP JOINT CAMPAIGN IN LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS: KMT LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) , which between them fielded a joint ticket in the March 20 presidential election, will not campaign jointly in the year-end legislative elections, a KMT lawmaker said Monday.
Instead, the two parties will work out the maximum number of candidates they will name in every constituency and campaign on their own, said Legislator Shyu Jong-Shyong.
Shyu said there is a consensus for the move among KMT lawmakers

He made the comment after a meeting between Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan and a vice chairman of the Kuomintang, and a group of KMT lawmakers. Shyu said he recommended during the meeting that the KMT and PFP leaders should admit that they bungled the March 20 presidential election and should do away with an existing six-man policy-making group composed of members of both parties.
Wang was quoted as telling the KMT lawmakers that KMT Chairman Lien Chan will meet with party lawmakers in batches, beginning Wednesday, to exchange views with them on the legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTION DISPUTES RELATED TO FLAWED MEDIA REPORTING: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian claimed Monday that the disputes over his re-election victory are related to flawed reporting by some electronic news media during the vote-counting procedure.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with Columbia University President Lee C. Bollinger, who is currently on a speaking tour of Taiwan.

In addition to offering his congratulations on Columbia's 250th founding university, Chen exchanged views with Bollinger on freedom of the press and media responsibility. Bollinger will deliver a speech on challenges and opportunities for news media in the era of globalization during his Taipei visit.
Chen told his guest that Taiwan still has much to learn in terms of upgrading the news media's sense of moral responsibility while defending press freedom.

Taking the disputed March 20 presidential election as an example, Chen said some cable television stations reported too hastily on vote tabulation in order to attract audiences amid the fierce ratings competition.

"Some of them didn't base their reports on the ballots actually tallied by the Central Election Commission (CEC) and instead based their reports on the results of exit polls they conducted. Because those exit polls were not correct, their vote-counting reports failed to reflect the CEC's actual tabulation, thus misleading the audience and opposition politicians," Chen said.
Chen also said he hopes Columbia will continue its cooperative research projects to with local academic bodies, including those aimed at upgrading media professionalism and moral responsibility.

Chen narrowly defeated his sole challenger, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, in the March 20 election -- a result that Lien has contested with two lawsuits while his supporters have resorted to sometimes violent street protests.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SCHOLARS CALL FOR NEW CROSS-STRAIT FRAMEWORK TO AVOID CONFLICT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 12 (CNA) (By Lin Wen-chi and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Two noted American scholars have urged both sides of the Taiwan Strait to establish a new long-term stable cross-strait framework to avoid conflict.

David Lampton, director of China studies at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, and Kenneth Lieberthal, professor of political science at the University of Michigan, made the appeal in an article titled "Heading off the Next War" that appeared in the Washington Post Monday.

The article said that President Chen Shui-bian's March 20 re-election highlights the fact that the framework that has buttressed peace in the Taiwan Strait for decades is disintegrating and that changes in Taiwan, as well as some of Beijing's counterproductive behavior, are undermining its foundations.

"Unless an improved framework is adopted soon, war across the strait will become increasingly probable, with the United States likely to be drawn into it, " the article claimed. "No matter who would `win' such a conflict, the consequences for China, Taiwan, America and Northeast Asia would be dire," it continued.

"The conundrum is stark, " the article said, noting that Taiwan sees itself as an independent sovereign country, while the mainland has staked the legitimacy of its regime on not allowing Taiwan juridicial stature as a sovereign country. And the U.S. has for more than three decades been committed to a "one China" policy, combined with a threat to become militarily involved if Beijing uses force to effect a resolution of cross-strait issues.

U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney will visit the mainland Tuesday, the article noted, and he is expected to "follow the traditional American path of recommending cross-strait dialogue and warning of severe consequences should military conflict flare."
The article urged Cheney to also "signal to both Beijing and Taipei that America is prepared for new thinking in the search for peace and growth in the region."
According to the article, the reality is that "there is no final resolution to cross-strait issues that the two sides are likely to reach peacefully for decades."

The major effort, it said, should shift to "establishing a stable framework across the strait for a long period -- counted not in years but in decades." For such a framework to be effective, all sides must agree on its fundamentals and its minimum duration, and they must seek the support of the international community in reinforcing it.
Under such an arrangement, Taiwan could continue to assert its independent sovereign status, but would not take the additional step of turning de facto independence into de jure independence.
The mainland could continue to assert that there is only one China of which Taiwan is a part, but it would have to give up its threat to use force to change Taiwan's status, it said.

"On this basis, Beijing and Taipei would agree on terms for expanded international space for Taiwan, including the island's involvement in global and regional international organizations, " the article said.

Beijing and Taipei would also agree to engage in "confidence-building measures" to reduce concerns about potential conflict, and the United States and others would commit to "play appropriate supporting roles if tensions across the strait diminish" that would include reducing military sales to Taiwan, it said.

The United States, Japan and the European Union would also guarantee that "they will not recognize an independent Taiwan during the framework period and that all would regard Beijing's unprovoked use of force against Taiwan as a matter of the gravest immediate concern," the article went on.

However, the article admitted that even a "modest framework will be very difficult to establish, " although it called for "courageous initiatives" from leaders in Beijing, Taipei and Washington and "considerable diplomatic skills" to put it into place.

The article concluded by saying that the "foreseeable alternatives are too destructive for responsible leaders to avoid taking a serious look -- and soon-- at ways to get things off a very dangerous track."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES PANAMANIAN GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian received two high-ranking government officials from Panama Monday at the Presidential Office and thanked them for the congratulations conveyed by Panamanian President Mireya Elisa Moscoso Rodriguez upon his March 20 re-election.

During a meeting with Panamanian Foreign Minister Harmondio Arias and Minister of Economy and Finance Noberto Delgado, Chen also noted that Moscoso was the first head of state to congratulate him following the election.
Chen told his guests that he deeply treasures the cordial and solid Taiwan-Panama relations and expressed his hope for eternal friendship between the two countries.

Arias also conveyed Moscoso's concern over Chen's condition after he was shot on the eve of the election. He further told Chen that Moscoso plans to personally lead a high-profile delegation that will attend Chen's May 20 inauguration.
Panama is a long-term Central American diplomatic ally of the Republic of China, despite strong pressure from Beijing to build formal ties.
Chen and Moscoso signed a free trade agreement in August last year in Taipei -- the first accord of its kind that Taiwan has ever forged with a foreign country.
Chen also headed a large mission that traveled to Panama in November 2003 to participate in a ceremony held in Panama City to mark the nation's centennial.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER RECEIVES OUTGOING HAITIAN ENVOY

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun received outgoing Haitian Ambassador Lafontaine Saint-Louis Monday at the Executive Yuan and praised him for his contributions to the promotion of relations between the Republic of China and the Caribbean nation.
Yu said that Saint-Louis made a great deal of effort to promote bilateral ties during his tenure as Haitian ambassador to Taiwan over the past more-than two years.
The premier expressed the hope that Saint-Louis will continue to promote ROC-Haiti relations after returning home and that he will remember Taiwan as his "second home."
Saint-Louis has been assigned by the Haitian government to a new post and is scheduled to depart Taiwan in a few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOTED MAINLAND CHINESE SURGEON TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese surgeon who came to fame in Taiwan after successfully treating a critically injured Taiwan-born TV anchorwoman, will visit the country later this week, a physician-turned-lawmaker said Monday.
"Ling Fong will arrive this Friday or Saturday to deliver a speech at an international medical conference to be held in Taipei, " said Legislator Kao Ming-jian of the opposition People First Party.
Ling will be a keynote speaker at the 7th Asian-Oceanian International Conference on Skull Base Surgery scheduled to open this weekend, Kao said.

Ling headed a five-member medical team at Xuanwu Hospital in Beijing that treated Tanya Liu, a former anchorwoman for Hong Kong-based Phoenix Satellite TV, who barely survived a London train crash in May 2002.

Liu was pronounced brain dead at one point in London, but she managed to pick up a pen and write her name about five months after she was transferred to Xuanwu Hospital, where she received neurosurgery and rehabilitation treatment from Ling's team.
Liu is currently convalescing in Taiwan and is scheduled to return to work at Phoenix TV in the near future, having almost fully recovered from her injuries.

Liu was on the train with her friends Wu Chia-ching and Lin Chia-hsin, both Taiwan-born television journalists. Seven people died, including Wu and Lin, and more than 70 were injured in the accident, which was caused by faulty carriage couplings.
According to Kao, Ling will travel to Hong Kong with Liu to attend a charity fundraiser after attending the medical conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN SAYS HE WILL NOT SHUN ELECTION RESPONSIBILITIES

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan pledged Monday that he will assume full responsibility for his part in the March 20 presidential election as soon as all the facts concerning the disputed election have been clarified.

Speaking at a news conference held at the KMT headquarters, Lien said that the election has not yet ended and that investigators are still struggling to dig out the facts surrounding various key issues that resulted in what Lien claims was "an unfair election."
The KMT chairman said that he will continue working toward clarification and that he will be wholly accountable for the final election result.

Lien promised to push for a transfer of power within the KMT regardless of the eventual outcome and said that he actually initiated a move in this direction before the presidential election. He added that the legislative elections in December will provide a good chance for the party to undergo the power transfer.
Looking to the future, he went on, the KMT is poised to launch adjustments to trim its structure across the board while seeking to recruit new blood.
Turning to the question of whether the KMT is facing an ideology rift, Lien claimed that such a problem does not exit in the party, as those who betrayed the party left it four years ago.

Describing the KMT as the major driving force behind Taiwan's progress, stability and prosperity over the past 50 years, he said that the KMT has fully devoted its energy to building Taiwan for the sake of its people's well-being.

KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng echoed Lien's remarks by making clear his determination to also resign to take responsibility. Lin vowed that he will immediately step down from his post as long as the truth is discovered.
Lien and his running mate, People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, claim that the election was unfair and fraudulent and immediately lodged two lawsuits to nullify the election.
Supporters of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" formed by the KMT, PFP and the New Party have staged a series of sometimes violent mass rallies in Taipei to protest the disputed election.

They are demanding a vote recount, to which President Chen Shui-bian has already agreed, and a legislative investigation into the election-eve shooting of Chen, which they claim unfairly swayed the poll in Chen's favor.
Lien lost to Chen by a very slim margin of 29,518 votes out of more than 13 million ballots cast in the bitterly contested presidential poll.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHRISTIAN GROUPS TO PRAY FOR ETHNIC HARMONY FOR 50 DAYS

TEXT.P: Major Christian churches in Taipei launched a prayer drive Monday in an effort to promote social harmony in the wake of the bitterly fought March 20 presidential election.
More than 100 Christians from various churches gathered at a Presbyterian church adjacent to the Legislative Yuan in downtown Taipei early in the morning to pray for peace and harmony in Taiwan.
The one-hour prayer meeting was the first of a series of similar services to be held at the church over the coming 50 days.

During the fiery and bruising presidential campaign, voters were divided over their political preferences and even Christian churches were divided into pro-"pan-blue alliance" and pro-"pan-green camp" groups.

The political divisions became even more serious after incumbent President Chen Shui-bian narrowly defeated the "pan-blue alliance" presidential candidate, Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan. Lien has contested the election result with sometimes violent street protests and two lawsuits.

Rev. Chou Lien-hua took the initiative to invite major churches in Taipei to hold a joint prayer service at the Chinan Presbyterian Church each morning until May 30 with a view to promoting social harmony and internal unity.

"We must pray for this piece of land because our country is divided after the election. Not only are offices and families divided over politics, even Christian churches have also been divided, " Chou said at the prayer gathering. "I earnestly hope that this series of prayer meetings can help mend political and ethnic divisions."
Speaking on the same occasion, Pastor Lee Yao-pin said Taiwan is so small that it cannot afford to see divisions over political, ethnic and regional differences.
"We must learn to pray for the political party or individual politicians we hate most in line with the biblical teaching of 'praying for your foes,'" Lee said.

Except for a small group of aboriginal tribes, most of Taiwan's 23 million people are ethnic Chinese, with the population divided into two sub-ethnic groups: the "mainlanders" -- those whose families fled to Taiwan when the Chinese communists took over the mainland in 1949 -- and the "native Taiwanese" -- whose ancestors began arriving in Taiwan in the 17th Century or earlier.

The mainlanders, who make up about 15 percent of the population, largely support the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party, and their support base is in northern Taiwan.
The native Taiwanese control the south and they tend to favor President Chen's Democratic Progressive Party and the smaller Taiwan Solidarity Union, which jointly form the "pan-green camp."
The mainlanders traditionally support eventual unification with mainland China, while the native Taiwanese lean more toward formal independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION BUDGET TO APPROACH 10 PERCENT OF GNP: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said during a meeting with students in Taipei Monday that the education budget will approach 10 percent of the GNP.
During the dialogue with about 130 college and university students, Chen said that the 10 percent figure is the government's goal, even though resources for education are limited.
Based on government statistics, present spending on education accounts for around 4.39 percent of the GNP.
Chen promised the students that he will exert all his efforts into boosting the education budget to keep up with the budget for hi-tech spending.
The meeting covered a wide range of topics, including constitutional reform, referendum, ethnic harmony, education, language and cultural development.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush Says Brief on Al Qaeda Threat Was Not Specific.
President Bush said on Sunday that the intelligence briefing he received on Al Qaeda one month before the Sept. 11 strike contained no specific "indication of a terrorist attack" on American soil. He also defended the adequacy of his response to the warnings that terrorists in the United States might be planning hijackings.
Mr. Bush, in his first public remarks since the release of his top-secret briefing Saturday evening, played down the urgency of the information he was given at his ranch 36 days before terrorists flew airplanes into the World Trade Center, the Pentagon and a field in Pennsylvania. In doing so, Mr. Bush echoed the testimony last week by his national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, before the commission investigating the attacks, which had pushed for the release of the briefing.
Wall Street Journal: Cease-Fire Holds in Fallujah, As Talks Continue.
Gunfire was largely silenced Monday in the second day of a truce in Fallujah, where doctors said 600 Iraqis, including many civilians, were killed in the past week's U.S. Marine siege of Sunni insurgents. In the south, the military suggested it is open to a negotiated solution in its showdown with a radical Shiite cleric.
But additional U.S. forces have been maneuvering into place around Fallujah, and the military has warned it will launch an all-out assault on the city if talks there between pro-U.S. Iraqi politicians and city officials -- which were continuing Monday -- fall through.

Iraqi soldiers refused to fight in the week-long battle for Falluja, the epicentre of the rebellion against coalition occupation, the US military leadership in Baghdad admitted yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER-DESIGNATE LISTS U.N. AND WHO ENTRY AS TOP PRIORITIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's entry into the United Nations and the World Health Organization are top priorities, said Legislator Chen Tan-sun, who has been tapped by Premier Yu Shyi-kun to be the nation's new foreign minister.

In a farewell party held by his Democratic Progressive Party co-workers Monday at the Legislative Yuan, Chen said he was surprised by the twists and turns of life, noting that he lived in exile overseas for many years for advocating Taiwan's independence, but now he will work as the country's foreign minister.

He refused to comment on news reports that Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council, will be named as the country's representative to Washington, saying he has not yet taken office and was not in a position to make any remarks.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOCIAL SECURITY TOP TASK: NEW INTERIOR MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan vowed Monday that he will do his best to improve social order while serving as head of the ministry.

Su made the remarks during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan, with lawmakers raising questions surrounding the shooting of President Chen Shui-bian on the eve of the March 20 presidential election.
It was Su's debut at the legislature after taking over the post from his predecessor, Yu Chen-hsien, last Friday. Yu offered to resign to assume responsibility for the shooting.

Stressing that law and order play a pivotal role in a country's economic development, the new interior minister made it clear that maintaining good order in society will be the centerpiece of the agenda of his ministry and pledged that he would rather step down should no progress be made in this field.
In response to questions from lawmakers of opposition parties about the attack on Chen, Su said that no one wants to see any action that could endanger the life of the president.
As the nation's top chief in home affairs, Su said he will ask the president and vice president not to appear together in public activities.

President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu were injured in an assassination attempt on March 19 during a campaign rally in southern Tainan City. The two were standing together in an open-top jeep waving to supporters along the road when they were hit by two bullets. One grazed Chen's lower abdomen and the other hit Lu's right knee.

The shooting was widely viewed by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" as an orchestrated drama to win sympathy votes for Chen. The president succeeded in his re-election bid by winning over the "pan-blue alliance" candidate, Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, in the presidential election by a margin of only 0.228 percent.
The narrow margin prompted the opposition camp to demand a vote recount and the establishment of an independent "truth committee" under the Legislative Yuan to investigate the shooting.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTORS NET BUY NT$122.6 BILLION OF TAIEX VALUE

TEXT.P: From the start of this year until April 9, foreign investors traded in the bourse with a net buy of NT$122.6 billion (US$3.66 billion) recorded, according to the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX).
Foreign investors purchased NT$1.111 trillion worth of Taiwan stocks, and sold NT$988.1 billion worth of them during the period between the first trading day of this year and April 9.

Based on the TAIEX statistics, the total value of Taiwan stocks held by foreign investors stood at NT$3.228 trillion, accounting for 22.26 percent of the overall value of the domestic bourse, an increase of NT$69.6 billion from the level recorded on April 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VOWS TO ADDRESS ETHNIC DIVISION ISSUE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday he and his ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will reflect on their presidential campaign strategy and consider how to narrow political and ethnic divisions.
Chen made the pledge during an unprecedented meeting with a group of university student leaders at the Red Chamber Theater in Taipei's Hsimenting shopping district.
In the meeting, some students claimed that divisive rhetoric made by Chen and other DPP politicians during the presidential campaign had hurt social harmony.

During the presidential campaign, Chen often assured voters that he wouldn't cave in to Beijing, and he often questioned his sole challenger Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's willingness to stand up to Beijing. Some observers feel that political and ethnic divisions have become even more serious after Taiwan-born Chen narrowly defeated mainland China-born Lien.
President Chen assured the students that he and his party would reflect on their rhetoric and work to narrow the widening gap between different political parties and ethnic groups.

"We do have a crisis and it's something the ruling party and I need to review and to address, " Chen said. "We are all proud of Taiwan, and we have no need to pigeon-hole people. We all love Taiwan and we shouldn't try to paint someone black or red."
As part of the efforts, Chen said he will push relevant government agencies to organize a conference to discuss issues regarding ethnic equality in education, language and cultural development.
Chen further said he believes that love and tolerance are the best way to defuse ethnic divisions and promote social harmony and internal unity.

Except for a small group of aboriginal tribes, most of Taiwan's 23 million people are ethnic Chinese. But the population can be divided into two sub-ethnic groups: the "mainlanders" whose families fled to Taiwan when the Chinese Communists took over the mainland in 1949, and the "native Taiwanese" whose ancestors began arriving the island in the 17th century or earlier.

The mainlanders, about 15 percent of the population, have largely supported the opposition KMT and its ally People First Party, and their support base is in northern Taiwan. The native Taiwanese control the south, and they tend to favor Chen's DPP and the smaller Taiwan Solidarity Union.
The mainlanders have traditionally supported eventual unification with mainland China, while the native Taiwanese lean more toward formal independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO PUSH POLITICAL APPOINTEES TO PUT ASSETS INTO TRUST

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Monday that it has proposed a package of revisions to the Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law that will require the president and other senior officials to put their assets into blind trust.

TSU Legislator Chen Chien-ming said that before the March 20 presidential election, both President Chen Shui-bian and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" presidential candidate, Kuomintang Lien Chan, had publicly supported the proposal that political appointees be required to put their family assets into trust.

"Now that the election is over, we should take concrete steps to substantiate the proposal, " said Chen Chien-ming, who concurrently serves as party whip of the TSU, a political ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

According to the TSU-drafted revision package, the president, vice president, as well as presidents of the five yuans, and other senior political appointees should put their family assets into blind trust. The assets to be put into trust cover those owned by the public functionaries themselves as well as those owned by their spouses and underage children.
Chen Chien-ming said the TSU-drafted bill doesn't require elected representatives, including legislators, to put their assets into trust because elected representatives do not enjoy pension benefits.
He said the TSU hopes the Legislative Yuan's steering committee can discuss the draft revision bill Tuesday so that the bill can be included into the legislative agenda for the current session.

In the run-up to the presidential election, first lady Wu Shu-chen's stock trading activities came under fire. President Chen acknowledged that even though Taiwan has not enacted a law to ban the first lady from trading stocks, such activities were inappropriate. He made a public apology for his wife's stock trading activities and promised to put his family assets into blind trust after the March 20 presidential election.
Chen won re-election by a slim margin 0f 29,518 votes -- a result his opponent has contested with street protests and two lawsuits.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN MEETS WITH COLLEGE STUDENTS FOR DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met with about 130 college and university students Monday for dialogue, marking the first meeting of its kind in Chen's nearly four years as president.
Chen said that although he is not bound by law to take part in interpellation sessions at the Legislative Yuan, he is sincerely willing to be questioned by the students.
"Today, I am here to hear your voices and even your criticism, " Chen said to the students from 44 student groups in various colleges and universities around the country.
"You don't have to worry that my purpose is to gain your favor or win your hearts, " he told the students. "Instead, I will touch my own heart and be sincere in listening to you."
He said the age difference between himself and the students is not a problem in terms of understanding each other. "What is important is people's attitude," he added.
Chen told the students he thinks they are much "taller" than a lot of the politicians, many of whom he said have displayed below standard performances.

The president also said later that he found the students he met with to be very eloquent and to have strong arguments. He said these students were by no means below those students who have continued their sit-in in front of Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall and who turned down his invitation to join Monday's dialogue.
The student protesters had turned down President Chen's invitation to join Monday's meeting on the grounds that the arranged meeting "would blur the focus of their protest and their cause."

The two major demands of the student protesters are that political leaders from the two rival camps that contested the March 20 presidential election should apologize to the people for causing political chaos and social restlessness, and that an independent committee should be established to conduct an investigation into the March 19 election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.
Monday's meeting between Chen and the students from 44 student groups around the island was organized by the Presidential Office as a way of increasing mutual understanding.

Prior to the meeting, some 10 student groups jointly released a statement in which they said that the students would not be used by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" as a tool and that they would not try to gain favor with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party either.

The four-point announcement stated that student activities are beyond political boundaries, that student movements are self-motivated, that politicians creating havoc in the country should be forced to step down, and that a just and fair society should be built in Taiwan.

Also taking part in Monday's meeting were Education Minister Huang Jung-tsun, Interior Minister Su Chia-chuan, National Youth Commission Chairwoman Lin Fang-mei and Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lo Wen-chia.
