DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 12, or the 23rd day of the leap second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1606: The Union Jack becomes the United Kingdom's official flag.
1860: Vajirananavarorasa, prince and patriarch of Buddhism in Siam, is born. He institutionalized Thai Buddhism.
1861: The U.S. Civil War breaks out as Confederate forces under Gen. Pierre Beauregarde take Fort Sumter in Charlestown harbor, South Carolina.
1927: The Kuomintang starts a "purification" movement by expelling communist members.
1945: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt dies in office at the age of 63. Vice President Harry S. Truman is sworn in as his successor.
1949: The 37.5 Per Cent Farm Rental Reduction Program goes into effect in Taiwan.
1953: The Legislative Yuan passes a bill submitted by President Chiang Kai-shek, extending the term of office for legislators by an additional year, to May 7, 1954.
1958: The first national meeting for commending "Good Men and Good Deeds" is held at Chung Shan Hall in Taipei.
1961: The Russians put the first man into space when cosmonaut Yauri Gargarin is launched in the Vostok I space vehicle for a single orbit of the earth.
1963: Indonesian forces launch an armed attack against Malaysia as part of a new policy of confrontation.
1966: Cheng Wan-fu, former chairman of the "Taiwan Democratic Party" and a leader of the "Taiwan Independence Movement" in Tokyo, returns to Taipei after 20 years of self-imposed exile in Japan.
1973: Deng Xiaoping, who was purged during the Cultural Revolution, resumes his position as the vice premier of Communist China.
1973: Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1974: Economic Affairs Vice Minister K.S. Chang, leading a group of government officials and businessmen, depart for San Francisco to attend a Sino-U.S. conference on economic relations.
1974: Tsinghwa University completes the installation of its second nuclear reactor for research purposes. This is the fourth research reactor installed in Taiwan.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan calls on the people to carry out the Last Testament of the late President Chiang Kai-shek.
1975: Taipei building contractors pledge NT$1 million to start a fund-raising campaign for the proposed Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
1979: Taiwan's first geothermal power plant formally begins operations.
1981: Joe Louis, American prize fighter, dies at the age of 67. He held the heavyweight title for nearly 12 years (1937-1949), successfully defending it a record 25 times.
1981: Columbia, the world's first reusable space shuttle, is launched at Cape Canaveral.
1983: China Airlines inaugurates its regular flight service to Amsterdam as the first step toward establishing worldwide commercial air services.
1989: Honduran President Jose Azcona Hoyo and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1994: The Mainland Affairs Council decides to suspend all cultural and educational exchanges with the mainland until Beijing provides reasonable and satisfactory explanations for the Qiandao Lake tragedy of March 31 in which 24 Taiwan tourists were killed.
1996: The Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, are declared the world's tallest buildings.
2000: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew meets with Guenter Rexrodt, a former German economics minister, to exchange views on bilateral relations between the two countries.
2001: an IBM-Linux Development Center is inaugurated in Taiwan. The center will provide local individual and group users with system testing, technical exchanges, experience sharing and training on using the Linux operating system.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are wise men who are not moral characters; but a fool is never a moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE PILOTS FORCED TO LAND F-5F ON BELLY

TEXT.P: The pilot and co-pilot of an ROC Air Force F-5F jet fighter were forced to land their plane on its belly Tuesday morning at an air base in central Taiwan when the plane's landing gear failed to open, the Air Force General Headquarters reported.
Neither of the pilots was injured, and the twin-seat F-5F was not damaged in the incident which occurred at 10:38 a.m.
Air Force General Headquarters officials said an investigation has begun into the incident.

F-5Es and F-5Fs used to form the backbone of the ROC Air Force prior to the recent commissioning of the second generation of jet fighters. The F-5F fighter is still used as part of Taiwan's air defenses and for training pilots.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 FISHERMEN DIE, 4 HOSPITALIZED AFTER EATING POISONOUS SEA SNAILS

TEXT.P: Two fishermen, including a Taiwan national and a Philippine citizen, aboard a Taiwan fishing vessel died while four others were hospitalized possibly as a result of eating a poisonous kind of sea snails.

The six crewmen aboard the Tainan-registered fishing vessel "Chao Hsin" were operating in waters near Tungsha (the Pratas) about 240 nautical miles southwest of the Kaohsiung coast when the incident occurred.
The Coast Guard Administration was alerted by the military rescue command center Monday night about the situation. The fishing vessel was directed to dock at Tungsha Island.

A Tungsha cutter then transported the body of Philippine crewman Jocson Greg Dasmarinas, as well as the five sick crew men, including Taiwan fisherman Wang Yu-ta, who was already in a coma, to Tunghsa Hospital.
Wang later died, but the four others were in stable condition after receiving emergency medical treatment.

The Air Force base in Pingtung, southern Taiwan, sent a CI-130 Hercules Transport aircraft to Tungsha Tuesday morning to bring back the two bodies and the four sick crewmen. The crewmen were later transported to Chang Kung Memorial Hospital in Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Economy chalks up sizzling 7.3% growth in 1Q in Singapore.
Singapore's economy surprised with red-hot 7.3 per cent growth in the first quarter of this year from the same period last year, the fastest expansion since late 2000.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore economy surges 7.3% in Q1, outlook brightens.
Singapore's economy is surging ahead faster than expected, with gross domestic product growing an estimated 7.3 percent in the first quarter from a year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Cheney promises U.S. will help Japan bring hostages home.
U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney told Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi on Monday that Washington would do its best to help rescue three Japanese nationals being held hostage in Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: U.S.Looks for New Solution in Cease-Fire.
A Patchy cease-fire took hold in this battle-torn Fallouja as U.S. officials said they were seeeking "political" solutions to pacify the area and, elsewhere in the country, disband a militia loyal to a virulently anti-American cleric.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER SECURITY OFFICIAL DENIES LEAKING SECRETS TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A retired senior officer from the National Security Bureau (NSB) claimed Tuesday that he went to work in mainland China because he did not know he was forbidden by law from visiting the mainland even after retirement, but he added that would be prepared to subject himself to investigation to prove he did not leak classified information to the mainland authorities.

Pan Hsi-hsien, the former chief of the personnel office at the National Security Bureau, said he returned to Taiwan April 10 and is confident that he has done nothing to harm either the NSB or the country.
He said he regretted embarrassing the NSB and making it a target of criticism.
Pan, who holds the military rank of major general, caused an uproar in 2000 when the NSB found he had gone to work at a Taiwanese plant on the mainland months after retiring from the NSB.

Pan was detained by Beijing's public security officials for questioning after his background was revealed by Taiwan's media. He said his travel documents were seized by public security officials and was not able to leave until early this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEADERS TO BE INVITED TO ATTEND PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office will follow protocol by inviting leaders of opposition political parties to attend President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inauguration ceremony for another four-year term, the chief aide to the president said Tuesday.

Chiou Yi-jen, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said that the opposition leaders to be invited will include Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) James Soong, who formed the "pan blue alliance" ticket and lost the March 20 presidential election to Chen and Vice President Annette Lu by a narrow margin of 29,518 votes out of more than 13 million cast.
Chiou said that the president's inauguration will be accompanied by a series of carnival-style celebrations around the country that will kick off on the eve of the ceremony.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) plans to organize a large-scale celebration rally in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung on the evening of May 19, another gathering of 500,000 people to be held at the plaza in front of the Presidential Office alongside the president's inauguration ceremony and a large-scale gala party in northern Taipei County on the evening of May 20.

Noting that the president's inauguration is an important ceremony, Chiou said that all the participants in the ceremony and the gala party to be held in front of the Presidential Office will have to obtain invitations extended by various organizers for the sake of security.
Security work will be coordinated and shared by the central government and the Taipei city government according to the law, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WANTS RIOTERS BROUGHT TO JUSTICE QUICKLY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged law enforcement authorities Tuesday to bring to justice quickly the rioters who clashed with police April 10 in Taipei.

After being briefed on the clashes by newly appointed Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan in a meeting of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) Central Standing Committee, Chen, who is also DPP chairman, said the law enforcement authorities should prosecute those responsible to the fullest extent of the law to show the government's determination to maintain stability and order.

Chen said his party regrets that some 100 people -- about half of them policemen -- were injured in the nearly twelve-hour confrontation between supporters of the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party and police in the square in front of the Presidential Office.
He expressed gratitude to the policemen who stopped the rioters from bursting into the Presidential Office and drove them away early Sunday.
Chen said he empathized with the feelings of the KMT/PFP "pan-blue alliance" followers after their joint ticket in the presidential election was defeated, and he defended their right to expression.

"However, our tolerance toward different opinions and our receptiveness to criticism should not be misunderstood. We will not appease rumormongers given to stirring up confrontation and dividing the society," Chen said, adding that "freedom of speech is protected by law but is not above the law."

"The DPP prefers to refer all questions about the March 20 presidential election to the judiciary and will cooperate with investigators looking into the disputes. We will respect the results of the investigation."

The "pan-blue alliance" has organized rallies to protest what they call the "unfairness" of the presidential election almost every weekend since March 20. Their followers have refused to disperse after the rallies ended and instead, have confronted police in fruitless attempts to storm the Presidential Office.
The April 10 rally was the latest and most violent, in which 13 people were arrested.

Meanwhile, in a related story, Chen Hung-ta, a spokesman for the Public Prosecutors' Office at the Taipei District Court, said prosecutors at his office are looking into the riots that have followed every pan blue alliance rally since March 20.
Chen said there are always about 20 prosecutors posted to the police command center to monitor the situation whenever the KMT and PFP have called in their supporters for rallies.
"Whoever led the riots will be held to account regardless of their status or political affiliation," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CHIEF AIDE-DE-CAMP TO PRESIDENT NAMED

TEXT.P: Maj. Gen. Shen Po-chih, an assistant vice minister of national defense, was named as the chief aide-de-camp to the president Tuesday, according to a statement issued by the Presidential Office.
He succeeds Chen Tsai-fu, who was disciplined and transferred after the March 19 assassination attempt on President Chen Shui-bian.
Meanwhile, Maj. Gen. Ho Yung-chien, a commander of military police, was named as Shen po-chih's deputy, replacing Shen Tsai-tien, who was also disciplined and transferred after the March 19 incident.
The new appointments will take effect April 16, according to the statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANATOMICAL EXHIBITION OF HUMAN BODIES TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: An anatomical exhibition of plasticized human bodies will open April 21 at the National Taiwan Science Education Center in Taipei, the organizers said Tuesday.

On display at the "Body Worlds" exhibition will be 25 human bodies, about 200 samples of human organs and two animal bodies, all of which have been treated with plastination techniques, center officials said.
Similar exhibitions have been held in 24 cities in nine countries around the world and have attracted more than 14 million visitors, they added.
The exhibitions have made an invaluable contribution to society by making visitors more responsible for their own bodies after they have a better understanding of how it is structured.

According to an academic survey, they explained, 80 percent of the visitors said that they came away with a better understanding of the human body, while 54 percent of them said they will pay more attention to their health.
The "Body Worlds" exhibition in Taipei will run through Oct. 24, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT BLASTS CONSPIRACY THEORIES ABOUT SHOOTING

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Tuesday that it was a miracle she survived her March 19 shooting, but she added that she deplores the conspiracy theories that the unsolved attack has spawned.
Lu made the remarks while meeting with a group of international affairs and defense strategy scholars from Singapore. It was Lu's first meeting with foreign guests since the election-eve shooting.
"What I regret most is not the shooting itself but the suspicions raised by some people. I thus suffered a second blow, " Lu told her guests.

Lu and President Chen Shui-bian were shot while they were parading in a motorcade in the southern city of Tainan on the last day of campaigning ahead of the March 20 presidential election. One bullet grazed Chen's stomach and another hit Lu's right knee. No suspects have been arrested and no solid leads have been discovered.
Lu said "various miracles" enabled her to survive with only a minor injury when the bullet hit her knee after piercing the windshield of the open-top jeep she was riding in.

The Chen-Lu ticket won the election by a narrow margin and the defeated ticket of Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong has insinuated that the president might have staged or faked the shooting to win sympathy votes. Lien has contested the results with sometimes violent street protests and two lawsuits, even though he has so far provided little evidence to back up his "unfair election" allegations. Lien has demanded that what he calls an "independent" commission be created under the Legislative Yuan to investigate the shooting.

After examination of the physical evidence and a painstaking recreation of the crime scene, a team of U.S. experts headed by renowned forensics scientist Dr. Henry Lee have said the wounds were not self-inflicted and were caused by bullets rather than knives, as some conspiracy theorists have speculated.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDENT REPRESENTATIVES TO RETURN FROM U.N. SUMMIT

TEXT.P: A group of students from Taiwan universities will return home Wednesday after concluding a university student summit sponsored by the United Nations in New York, a spokesman for the privately run King Car Education Foundation said Tuesday.

The 23 students took part in the five-day "mock U.N." meeting by teaming up with their peers from Thailand and the Republic of Guinea to discuss resolution packages on issues of grave public concern related to regional conflict, peace, the environment, children and women, human rights and economic and social progress, with groups from other countries, the spokesman said.
Although the students had to use English to express their views and feelings in the summit, he said that their wit and calm performance gained rounds of applause from the audience.
Their participation in the event also provided an opportunity for more than 3,000 university students from around the world to gain an understanding of Taiwan's desire to enter the U.N., he added.
The 23 students will hold a news conference after returning to Taipei to share their experience with the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: THOSE ACCEPTING POLITICAL DONATIONS FROM ABROAD TO FACE PRISON TERM

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan said Tuesday that it will craft a mechanism to audit whether any domestic political party, political group or individual political aspirants have accepted political contributions from abroad.

According to the newly enacted Political Contributions Law, political parties, political groups and individual political aspirants are prohibited from accepting financial contributions from citizens, organizations and institutions in foreign countries, including mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau. Infraction of this ban is liable to a maximum five-year prison term.

Hsieh Yu-nan, a Control Yuan department chief in charge of public functionary assets declarations, said the Control Yuan -- the nation's supreme watchdog body -- will join forces with the Ministry of the Interior to establish an auditing mechanism and work out audit rules to prevent donation recipients from unwittingly breaking the ban.

Hsieh suggested that local political parties, political groups or individual hopefuls intending to run for public office hand over any donations from unidentified sources to the national coffers to avoid breaking the Political Contributions Law.

Under the law, the amount of political donations from unidentified sources should not exceed 10 percent of the total declared amount. Recipients of unlawful donations must hand over the funds to relevant administrative agencies within two months.

The new law also stipulates that political parties, political groups and individual political aspirants must set up special bank accounts for political donations and must register them with the Control Yuan.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party, the main opposition Kuomintang and the opposition New Party, as well as some 20 legislators who intend to seek re-election in the year-end legislative elections have completed the registration process.
According to the law, individual politicians are not allowed to accept political contributions during non-election periods and only those who intend to run in an election can do so.

The law also prescribes the period in which donations can be accepted, with the president allowed to accept political donations up to one year before his term expires, legislators allowed to accept donations up to 10 months before their term expires, and elected mayors, city councilors, magistrates and county councilors allowed to accept donations up to eight months before their term expires.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAW REVISIONS WILL ENHANCE TAX-FREE, TAX REBATE SCOPE

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved various law amendments Tuesday designed to enhance the scope of products that can take advantage of tax-free and tax-rebate treatment.

The revisions to the Customs Duties Law were made in conjunction with a set of rules regulating the Taiwan-Panama Free Trade Agreement and the Kyoto Protocol with the aim of promoting free trade pacts and customs affairs cooperation between Taiwan and other countries.

Under the terms of the newly revised law, a wider range of products will be allowed to enjoy tax exemption or tax rebate treatment, such as medicines and facilities for disease control, as well as emergency rescue equipment for both men and animals, regardless of whether they are imported by the government or donated by foreign countries.

In an effort to cooperate with the global anti-terrorism campaign, customs officials will also now be allowed to inspect goods transshipped in Taiwan, with the inspection costs to be borne by the transporter.

At the same time, the re-entry tax exemption period enjoyed by products shipped to other countries for repair, maintenance or processing will be extended to up to one year, while the daily surcharge for those goods overstaying their permission at customs offices will be raised to NT$200 (US$6.09) from the current level of NT$18.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT TO GIVE COURT TESTIMONY

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui is expected to testify in court Wednesday in the trial of Hsu Ping-chiang, a former chief accountant of the National Security Bureau (NSB).
Lee has been summoned as a witness and is expected to testify behind closed doors at the Taipei District Court.
Lee is the last of a series high-profile witness, including former Foreign Minister Jason Hu and former NSB Director Ting Yu-chou, to bear testimony in the case.

Hsu stands accused of diverting NT$250 million (US$10.5 million) from a secret slush fund managed by the NSB to Taiwan Research Institute (TRI) President Liu Tai-ying in 1999. According to the charges against him, Liu used some of the money to finance the institute and the rest to line his own pockets.

The money was paid by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to the NSB as reimbursement for a political donation made in 1994 by then-President Lee Teng-hui to South Africa's ruling African National Congress using the secret NSB slush fund.
Hsu argued that he acted on the orders of late NSB Director Yin Tsung-wen and that Yin was basically acting on Lee's instructions.
As president at the time, Lee was also chairman of the National Security Council, which is the immediate superior of the NSB.
After his term as president expired in 2000, Lee became chairman of the TRI.

Hsu, along with the NSB's chief cashier at the time, Liu Kuan-chun, are the only two to have been indicted in the case, but Hsu is the only one to stand trial as Liu fled the country before investigators could catch him. (Maubo Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush Sees Need for Reorganizing U.S. Intelligence.
President Bush said Monday that "now may be a time to revamp and reform our intelligence services, " opening the way for consideration of changes at the C.I.A., the F.B.I. and other agencies.
Expanding the powers of the director of central intelligence and establishing a domestic intelligence agency like the MI5 in Britain are among ideas now circulating in Washington as the independent commission looking into the attacks holds hearings and prepares to make its own recommendations.
The president's comments are an indication that he is turning attention to intelligence matters at a moment when the Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are under intense criticism.
Wall Street Journal: Gunmen Attack U.S. Convoy Heading to Najaf, Killing 1 Soldier.
Gunmen attacked a large convoy of U.S. troops heading toward Najaf with gunfire and roadside bombs, killing one soldier and wounding two others and an American civilian contractor, officers in the convoy said Tuesday.
A U.S. Apache helicopter, meanwhile, was burning on the ground outside Fallujah, and witnesses said it had been hit by a rocket from the ground.
Coalition forces also came under mortar attack and fought militiamen off at a water distillation plant in Najaf.
Senior U.S. military officials in Iraq have asked for more troops to battle insurgents, who are increasingly targeting aid workers and army contractors.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO SET UP SPECIAL ACCOUNT TO ACCEPT POLITICAL DONATIONS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) applied Tuesday to the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, to set up a special bank account in which to deposit political donations.

The move follows the March 31 implementation of a political donations bill that requires all political parties, political groups and political aspirants to receive political donation only through the special accounts and to obtain prior approval to open the accounts from the Control Yuan.
Chang Hung-ming, the DPP's cashier, said that with the new bill, soliciting donations will be made more difficult.

Chang noted that under the new bill, individuals can make a maximum donation to one political party or group of NT$300,000 (US$8,982) per year, while corporate donations cannot exceed NT$3 million per year.
Chang claimed that the new bill makes it more difficult for parties to get donations, as some individuals or corporations will not like to be seen as supporters of the ruling party.
Under the new bill, all revenues other than party fees are counted as political donations.
The bill stipulates that political parties can receive political donations at any time, but individual political aspirants can only receive donations during election periods.
Seven legislators from the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), a DPP ally, also registered with the Control Yuan that day to set up a special donations account.
Meanwhile, Vice Interior Minister Lee Chin-yung said that political aspirants cannot receive political donations from companies run or financed by political parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: HP TAIWAN TO SETS UP FIRST RFID CENTER IN ASIA-PACIFIC REGION

TEXT.P: Hewlett-Packard Co. (HP) announced Tuesday it would be setting up a Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) Center of Excellence in Taiwan, the first in the Asia-Pacific region.

Rosemary Ho, HP Taiwan's managing director, said at a news conference that the RFID center will cooperate with Quanta Display Inc. to usher in the RFID project for the information technology sector, and with the Industrial Technology Research Institute to drive forward international standards, know-how exchange and develop resolution schemes for diverse sectors, especially in information technology, retailing, auto making, and pharmaceuticals.

HP initially introduced RFID skills into the supply chain three years ago, Ho said, adding that since HP is now the biggest user with abundant experience, clients will benefit by way of the center's help.

The global RFID market is expected to grow from US$1 billion in 2002 to between US$3 billion and US$4 billion in 2008, and between US$15 billion and US$25 billion in 2015, said Lucien Repellin, the HP global RFID leader, adding that their global RFID clients include Wal-Mart, P & G, FedEx, DHL, Nestle, and Unilever.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTREPRENEUR PROMISES US$3.03 MILLION TO HELP PAY FOR VOTE RECOUNT

TEXT.P: A successful Taiwan entrepreneur based in the United States has said that he would donate NT$100 million (US$3.03 million) to help pay for the recount of the March 20 presidential election votes.

The two contestants of the election have agreed to a vote recount, although they still differ on who should pay the expenses, with the ruling "pan-green camp" saying that the opposition "pan-blue alliance," who asked for the recount, should foot the bill, while the "pan-blue alliance" wants the government to pay.

David Sun, co-founder of Kingston Technology Corp., one of the largest memory module manufacturers in the world, said through his friend, Hsu Cheng-ki, that he hopes to end the post-election turmoil quickly by speeding up the recount so that peace and order can return to Taiwan as soon as possible.
Although Sun has said that his political leanings favor the "pan-blue alliance, " his intention to donate the money is non-political.

Sun was quoted as telling Hsu that he worried about the continued disturbances in post-election Taiwan. When he saw Taiwan protesters clashing with police April 10 on TV at his Los Angles home, he was heartbroken and couldn't help but want to do something for the country.
According to Hsu, Sun wants to help speed the vote tallying so that the rivalry between the ruling and opposition parties can end quickly.

Sun reportedly told Hsu that Taiwan was still in turmoil after the election, and that the unstable political situation will "affect Taiwan's international image and damage the confidence of foreign investors, and as an ordinary citizen who cares for Taiwan's future economic prosperity" he's willing to make the donation.

Scott Chen, vice president of Kingston Technology's Asia Pacific business division, said Tuesday at the company's Taiwan branch in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, that he was "not surprised by Sun's move."
Chen said that some of the company's staff also said that they would like to chip in to pay for the recount.
Chen said that Sun will donate the money in his own capacity, and the money will not be to publicize the company or to save on taxes.
Chen said the money will be turned over to an "impartial third party," as Sun's mother is a Christian, the company will contact the Presbyterian Church to handle the money.
Meanwhile, the Presbyterian Church in Taiwan, which is now convening a four-day conference in Changhua, central Taiwan, said the church has yet to receive formal notification about the donation.

Lin Chung-cheng, a church official, said that as far as he understands, the donation is not for any specific political party or organization, but was given out of a hope that Taiwan people can put aside their divisions and hatred after the election and move forward in reconciliation.

President Chen Shui-bian won by a small margin of 29,518 votes out of the more than 13 million cast against his rival, Lien Chan of the "pan-blue alliance." But Lien has yet to concede defeat because of what he said was an "unfair election" that was marred by voting irregularities and an election-eve shooting which the supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" believe swayed the election to Chen's favor in the bitterly contested election.

Sun and his co-founder, John Tu, became millionaires when they sold a large chunk of their memory chip-making company in 1996 and made headlines worldwide when they decided to share US$100 million of the windfall with workers, roughly at 450 at the time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURIST ARRIVALS FALL FAR BELOW TARGET

TEXT.P: The number of tourist arrivals fell far below the projected target in the first quarter of this year because of political factors, travel sources said Tuesday.

The government has designated 2004 as the "Year of Tourism" for Taiwan with an aim of attracting at least 3.2 million tourists. However, the number of tourist arrivals in the first quarter declined significantly from the year-earlier level. Tourism Bureau Director Su Cheng-tien has admitted that it's a very difficult task to realize the goal of attracting 3.2 million tourists this year.
According to Tourism Bureau tallies, tourist arrivals numbered 212,854 in January and 221,020 in February, down 10.58 percent and 14.98 percent, respectively, from the same months of last year.
In March 2003, the number of tourist arrivals reached 258,128. This year's figure has yet to be formally tallied, but a preliminary tabulation also showed a downward trend.
Japan has traditionally been a main source of tourists to Taiwan, but the number of Japanese visitors declined by more than 30 percent in the first two months of this year.
Japanese citizens made 53,350 visits and 61,006 visits to Taiwan in January and February, respectively, marking a 38 percent and 32 percent drop from the year-earlier levels.

Tourist industry sources said the sometimes violent protest rallies in front of the Presidential Office organized by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) after the March 20 presidential election have discouraged Japanese citizens from making sightseeing trips to Taiwan.

As the period from April 29 through May 3 is traditionally known as a "golden week" for overseas pleasure trips for Japanese people, many local travel agencies originally expected to receive a large numbers of tour groups from Japan.

However, the sources said, Japanese news media's prominent coverage of recent "pan-blue alliance" street rallies in protest against what it called the "unfair" presidential election has prompted many Japanese tour groups to cancel their Taiwan-bound travel plans.

According to the sources, 12 travel agencies and tourist hotels have sent a joint petition to Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou asking him not to approve "pan-blue alliance" applications for street rallies in the city any more for the sake of "rescuing" Taiwan's battered tourist industry. Duplicate copies of the petition letter were also sent to the Legislative Yuan and headquarters of the KMT, the PFP and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

The "pan-blue alliance" presidential candidate KMT Chairman Lien Chan narrowly lost to incumbent President Chen Shui-bian in the bitterly fought March 20 presidential election. Lien has since contested Chen's re-election victory with street protests and two lawsuits.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Security the loser in Athens race.
Anti-terror security for the Athens Olympics has been dangerously compromised by building delays and experts fear that a device could be planted amid the chaos.
Financial Times: US commander in Iraq says that he needs more troops.
General John Abizaid, the commander of US forces in the Middle East, has asked the Pentagon for two additional combat brigades in response to the widespread rebellion in Iraq, reversing a year-long trend of reducing the US military presence there.

DOC.HEADLINE: PINGPU ETHNIC GROUPS SUMMIT SCHEDULED TO BE HELD IN TAINAN IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Anthropologists have said that at least one-third of Taiwan's population have the blood of "Pingpu" groups -- aboriginal people who lived in low-lying areas around the island, many of whom intermarried with Han Chinese.
Just like their languages and cultures, the "Pingpu" aboriginal people are now very hard to identify and people in Taiwan generally believe that "Pingpu" people no longer exist on the island.

In an effort to distinguish the identity of "Pingpu" people and recover or retain their cultures, the Tainan County Government decided to sponsor the "Taiwan Pingpu Ethnic Groups Summit" meeting in October, inviting representatives from "Pingpu" groups from around the island and anthropological researchers to take part, officials from the Tainan County Bureau of Cultural Affairs said.

According to ethnic archives, Taiwan's "Pingpu" people used to be roughly divided into 10 different groups, including the Ketagalan in the Taipei area, the Kavalan in the eastern Ilan area and Siraya in the southwest area of Tainan.
The remnants of these groups have been working to establish the identity of their respective tribes and refuse to accept the notion that their tribes have died out.

In Tainan County, in particular, part of the "Pingpu" Siraya culture has continuously been observed by "Pingpu" offspring. For example, "night worship" rituals have been practiced annually by residents in Tahnei and Tongshan to worship their ancestors.
In the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park complex, there is even a "Siraya Boulevard, " indicating that people there still have a strong identity of their aboriginal origins.

The government currently divides Taiwan's aboriginal people into 10 major mountain tribes and 10 "Pingpu" groups. While elements of the languages and cultures of the 10 mountainous races have been maintained, most of the native languages of the "Pingpu" people have died out, with no traces remaining.
The 10 mountainous races include the Atayal, Amis, Bunun, Saisiat, Tsou, Puyuma, Rukai, Paiwan and Dawu tribes.

Taiwan's indigenous people could either have originally come from the southern part of China or from the vast region called the Austronesian-language area, which spans from Madagascar eastward across the Indian and Pacific oceans to Easter Island, and from Taiwan southward to New Zealand.
In a new theory developed in Australia and New Zealand in recent years, anthropologists believe that Taiwan is the place where the Austronesian-language people originated.

Professor Geoffrey Chambers of Victoria University in Wellington, New Zealand, believes that the Maori people and other Polynesian peoples of the Pacific "island-hopped" from Taiwan through the Philippines and Indonesia to West Polynesia. From there, he says, they traveled to the islands of East Polynesia and then southwest, eventually settling in New Zealand.
Among Taiwan's mountain tribes, the Saisiat and the Atayal are believed to have migrated to Taiwan some 3,000 years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20TH DENGUE FEVER CASE CONFIRMED TO BE IMPORTED FROM PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: The Health Department's Center for Disease Control (CDC) reported Tuesday the 20th dengue fever case this year, confirming that this latest case was imported into Taiwan by a Tainan County citizen's wife from the Philippines.
CDC officials said that the woman returned to Shanhua township, Tainan County April 2 after a visit to her hometown in the Philippines.

After suffering some symptoms related to dengue fever, the woman took the initiative and reported to the local health authority in Shanhua saying that she might have contracted dengue fever. Her case was confirmed April 5, Wu Ping-hui, a CDC section chief, said.
The Shanhua case increased the number of dengue fever cases involving foreign brides in Taiwan to five so far this year. Of the total, four were Vietnamese wives and one Philippine wife, Wu said.
As of Tuesday, a total of 106 suspected dengue fever cases have been reported around Taiwan this year, with only 20 being confirmed as dengue fever.
All of these 20 confirmed dengue fever cases were imported, with seven originating from Indonesia, seven from Vietnam, four from the Philippines and one each from India and Thailand, Wu added.

Wu called for stepped-up education to foreign spouses from Southeast Asia and Taiwan citizens who wish to visit Southeast Asian nations about dengue fever and its prevention and treatment, pointing out that dengue fever has continuously been spreading in that part of the world and the situation in Indonesia and Vietnam has become especially serious.

In order to check the outbreak of the mosquito-borne disease, the Department of Health sponsored a conference on the prevention of dengue fever in early April, with health authorities from eight cities and counties in southern Taiwan participating.
Wu also called for the Taiwan public to keep tabs on their own health regularly and keep their residence environments clean as one of the ways to stem the disease.
Schools and communities should also destroy the breeding grounds of mosquitoes to cut down on the possibility of infection, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved down against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, losing NT$0.086 to close at NT$32.798.
A total of US$830 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.884 and slid to a low of NT$32.750.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HOPES HIS DEPUTY CAN STAY

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun hoped that Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i will continue to stay at his post after the latter tendered his resignation, a Cabinet spokesman said Tuesday.

The premier made the comments during a 90-minute meeting with the vice premier Monday afternoon, according to Cabinet spokesman Lin Chia-lung. Lin Hsin-i tendered his resignation to both President Chen Shui-bian and the premier at the end of March.
The vice premier said in his resignation letter that after four years of efforts in the government, he was glad to see the economy rebound and that he felt that his task at this stage was concluded.
Lin Hsin-i, who served as vice chairman of China Motor Corp. before taking the job as the economic affairs minister, said that he is now hoping to return to business.

The premier told Lin Hsin-i that he wanted to rely on the vice premier's expertise in economic affairs, but as Lin Hsin-i is adamant about leaving his post, the premier reported to President Chen and will now respect the president's decision on the new personnel, spokesman Lin said.
The spokesman stressed that before President Chen's inauguration on May 20, the Cabinet will resign en masse, and there is no question of individual resignations.

The vice premier concurrently serves as the chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD). Earlier reports said that he will no longer serve concurrently as the CEPD head when the Cabinet considers the line-up of the Cabinet after the March 20 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD TO EARMARK NT$200 MILLION FOR R&D HUB IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) will earmark NT$200 million (about US$6.1 million) this year for the establishment of an innovation and research and development hub in southern Taiwan, according to a spokesman for the CEPD.

The decision was made during a CEPD meeting Monday in which officials got together to study the effects of the "Challenge 2008, " a six-year national development plan and set new objectives for the coming phases, the spokesman said.

Citing CEPD Vice Chairwoman Ho Mei-yueh, the spokesman said that the innovation and R&D center planned for southern Taiwan will be located inside the Southern Tainan Science-based Industrial Park, as a similar establishment in northern Taiwan has obtained initial achievements.

The major purpose of the innovation and R&D hub in southern Taiwan is to attract companies from the private sector to open shop and train 1,000 hi-tech researchers, the spokesman quoted Ho as saying. The government-funded Industrial Technology Research Institute will take the initiative to set up a foothold there.

The CEPD's innovation and R&D hub plan has successfully courted 21 multinationals and 66 domestic concerns to set up their research centers in Taiwan since its inception in 2002 and it aims to see 140 R&D centers opened by private businesses across the country, CEPD officials said.

TAIEX Index futures for May gained 41 points to end at 6,850, with 1,179 contracts traded, while June futures rose 14 points to end at 6,824, with nine contracts finalized.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended the day higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 16.55 points to close at 6,794.33.
The bourse opened at 6,824.23 and fluctuated between 6,838.86 and 6,766.87 during trading.

A total of 7.99 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$184.31 billion (US$5.5 billion), an increase from the previous day's trading session that saw 6.74 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$156.55 billion.

Seven of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with cement stocks moving up the most at 2.9 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 1.9 percent, foodstuff stocks at 1.7 percent, plastics and chemical shares and textile issues both at 0.8 percent, construction stocks at 0.4 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.1 percent.
Electrical shares ended even.
Gainers outnumbered losers 442 to 382, with 148 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATURALIZED CITIZENS ON THE DECLINE

TEXT.P: A total of 1,465 foreigners were naturalized as Republic of China citizens last year, down 4.44 percent from the 2002 level, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Tuesday.

MOI officials attributed the decline mainly to a significant decrease in the number of voluntarily naturalized citizens. In 2003, only 85 foreigners were voluntarily naturalized as ROC citizens, marking a 59 percent drop from the year-earlier level.

Since the ROC Nationality Law was largely revised in 2000, the conditions for naturalization have become more stringent. As a result, the officials said, the number of naturalized citizens has been dwindling steadily.
In 2003, only 54 foreign men were naturalized as ROC citizens, accounting for a mere 3.69 percent of the total, while female naturalized citizens made up 96.91 percent or 1,411.

The MOI tallies also showed that foreign wives of local men formed the bulk of naturalized citizens in 2003, accounting for more than 80 percent or 1,340. The figure marked a 7.63 percent rise from the 2002 level.

Among those who were naturalized last year, 408 hailed from Vietnam, 317 from Cambodia, 264 from Indonesia, 193 from the Philippines, 135 from Myanmar, and 93 from Thailand. Marriage was the main reason for their naturalization.
Meanwhile, MOI officials said 869 ROC citizens lost their nationality last year, up 6.76 percent from the year-earlier level.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER TO STAY AT POST NO LONGER THAN MAY 19

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min will remain at his current post until May 19 at the very longest, a spokesman for the defense ministry said Tuesday.
Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng made the remarks in response to reports that Tang had retracted his resignation and had agreed to stay on.

Tang earlier tendered his resignation, citing a serious eye illness as the reason. But reports have said since that the government wants him to stay, some even saying that former President Lee Teng-hui called Tang to ask him to consider political stability and not to leave.
But Huang said that Tang is adamant about resigning because of his eye problem.

Huang said that Tang developed eye problems after his strenuous efforts in relief work in the wake of the Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake. Doctors say that Tang will require long-term follow-up treatment and time to recuperate.

"Minister Tang still believes that it is not appropriate for him to continue as the head of national defense," Huang said, adding that Tang will stay no longer than the day before the presidential inauguration to pass the baton to the next chief.

The Cabinet started to consider its line-up after the March 20 presidential election that saw President Chen Shui-bian win another four-year term. So far, interior and foreign affairs ministers have been replaced.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA AIRWAYS TO PURCHASE EIGHT BOEING 777-300ER JETLINERS

TEXT.P: EVA Airways, Taiwan's second largest air carrier, announced Tuesday that it will purchase eight Boeing 777-300ER jetliners at a price tag of US$1.491 billion.
An EVA spokesman said representatives from the two sides will sign a formal contract for the deal in Taipei Thursday.

EVA signed a contract with Boeing in June 2000 for the purchase of seven 777 series of jetliners, including three 777-200LRs and four 777-300ERs, plus an option for purchasing eight more 777-type passenger jets, the spokesman explained.
"We have decided to make use of the option and purchase the additional eight planes," he said.
Delivery of the seven planes ordered in 2000 will begin next year, he added.
The Boeing 777-300ER can accommodate up to 310 passengers and is suitable for flights to the U.S. West coast and destinations in Oceania and Asia.

Erkel, the North Caucasus coordinator for Medecins Sans Frontieres, or Doctors Without Borders, was freed after 20 months in captivity early Sunday in Dagestan.

The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Macapagal now leads Poe, says latest survey. IT'S STILL a "very close fight," but President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo has finally gained a lead over actor Fernando Poe Jr., breaking the statistical tie that both had found themselves in the past two months, a private polling firm said Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 13, or the 24th day of the leap second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1732: Frederick North, the English prime minister who introduced the Tea Act that led to the "Boston Tea Party," is born. His policies finally led to Britain's loss of America.
1743: Thomas Jefferson, the third president of the United States, is born. He drafted the Declaration of Independence in 1776. His presidency was marked by the purchase of the Louisiana Territory from France in 1803 and the Tripolitan War from 1801 to 1805.
1862: France and Annam (now Vietnam) sign the Treaty of Shanghai, annexing the province of Cochin China to France.
1898: Prompted by the success of the Meiji Reformation in Japan, Kang Yu-wei initiates a reform movement and submits a report to Emperor Kuang Hsu of China's Ching dynasty, requesting government reformation.
1904: In the Russo-Japanese War, a mine sinks the flagship of the Russian fleet at Port Arthur (Lushun) in northeastern China, killing 600.
1906: Samuel Beckett, Irish dramatist and winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1969, is born.
1919: British troops under the command of Brig. Gen. Dyer open fire on some 380 followers of Mohandas K. Gandhi in an incident known as the Amritsar massacre.
1939: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini's forces invade Albania.
1941: Japan and the Soviet Union sign the Soviet-Japanese Neutrality Pact in Moscow.
1945: Allied bombers launch massive bombing raids over Japan, destroying a large part of Tokyo.
1960: The construction of an atomic reactor at Taiwan's National Tsinghwa University in Hsinchu, the first of its kind in Southeast Asia, is completed.
1964: Sidney Poitier wins an Oscar for his performance in Ralph Nelson's "The Lilies of the Field," becoming the first black actor to receive the award.
1966: Iraq's President Abdul Salam Arif is killed in a helicopter crash.
1978: Communist China and Portugal formally sign a "joint statement" that clears the way for the return of Macao to Beijing on Dec. 20, 1999.
1980: Twenty-three-year-old Spanish golfer Severiano Ballesteros becomes the first European and also the youngest person ever to win the U.S. Masters in Augusta, Georgia.
1982: U.S. Secretary of State Alexander Haig returns to Washington following failed attempts in London and Buenos Aires to settle the Falkland Islands dispute.
1988: Hainan Island becomes the 23rd province and the fourth "special economic region" of mainland China under communist rule.
1990: The Soviet Union admits that its secret police was responsible for the 1940 systematic murder of 1,500 Polish army officers at Katyn, Poland.
1995: The Ukraine agrees to close the Chernobyl nuclear reactor by 2000.
1995: Lang Chin-shan, known as "China's father of photography," dies at the age of 104.
1999: Willi Stoph, chairman of the Council of Ministers of the former German Democratic Republic, dies at the age of 84.
2000: The World Trade Organization ranks Taiwan as the world's 14th-largest exporting country and the 15th largest importing country in terms of merchandise in 1999.
2000: The International Monetary Fund ranks the people of Taiwan as the 18th richest people in the world, with the nation's annual per capita income based on purchasing power parity expected to reach US$16,854 in 2000.
2001: U.S. Congressman David Wu (D-OR) arrives in the Republic of China at the head of a four-member delegation making a five-day visit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is affection, exertion is made easy; where there is disinterest, instruction will be neglected."
