DOC.HEADLINE: ONLY MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS SHOULD HAVE FINGERPRINTS TAKEN: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese who immigrate to Taiwan through their marriage with local people will have their fingerprints taken by local authorities, Johnnason Liu, vice chairmen of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said Wednesday.

In a denial of local news reports that all mainland Chinese who visit Taiwan should record their fingerprints, Liu said the newly revised Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area borrows an article from the Exit and Immigration Law to require mainland Chinese who come to Taiwan to reunite with their family members to have their fingerprints taken when they apply for permits for residency.
This requirement also applies to foreigners who want to take residence in Taiwan or be naturalized, and, therefore, is not a form of discrimination against mainland Chinese, Liu said.

Although a detailed plan to carry out the program was already worked out and promulgated by the Ministry of the Interior on April 8, Liu said fingerprint identification equipment, which is vital to the whole program, is not yet in place, and thereby it is impossible to begin on April 11 as reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO CELEBRATE GLOBAL YOUTH SERVICE DAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan will join 150 countries around the world in celebration Saturday of Global Youth Service Day, which falls between April 16 and 18, according to a statement issued by the National Youth Commission Wednesday.

In a ceremony organized by the commission at Lin's Garden in Panchiao, Taipei County, a young singer, Chang Feng-chi, will release a song composed by him for the Global Youth Service Day, and prizes will be awarded to writers who won a contest for articles promoting volunteerism.

At the same time, students from nine junior high schools in Taipei County will serve as voluntary guides at various museums and historical spots in the neighborhood of their schools to promote young people's participation in community service, and to foster their passion for their own communities.
The Global Youth Service Day is an annual global event organized by Youth Service America and the Global Youth Action Network.

Beginning from 2000, the event has spread to 150 countries around the world. They celebrate, recognize, and mobilize the year-round contributions of young people to build their communities and their world through voluntary service.
Taiwan joined the event in 2001 with the National Youth Commission as the country's coordinator, and has celebrated the Global Youth Service Day from 2002.

In the last two years, the commission has started more than 1,300 community service programs and has drawn more than 20,000 young people to render their service, according to the statement of the commission.
This year, the statement said, there are more than 8,000 young people from 460 groups enrolled in programs initiated by the commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO CONTINUE PROMOTING PARLIAMENTARY DIPLOMACY

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau said Wednesday that parliamentary diplomacy has contributed much to the Republic of China's foreign relations.
Kau made the remarks in a report delivered at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting on Taiwan's parliamentary diplomacy.
Because of Beijing's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, Kau said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) faces many difficulties in carrying out its official missions.
As parliamentary exchanges are more flexible, Kau said, parliamentary diplomacy has formed an integral part in Taiwan's diplomatic work.

In 2003, Kau said, 600 parliamentarians from various countries, including those that do not maintain diplomatic ties with the ROC, visited Taiwan. Among them, 179 were from Asia-Pacific countries, 39 from West Asian countries, 27 from Africa, 160 from Europe, 40 from North America and 155 from Central and South America.
Between September 2003 and January this year, 14 groups of ROC lawmakers made goodwill visits to major countries around the world to promote bilateral relations.

"The MOFA will continue to invite more influential foreign lawmakers to visit Taiwan while helping our legislators to visit other countries and take part in international conferences and various activities to cement bilateral relations," Kau said.
Through the MOFA's efforts, Kau said, 48 pro-Taiwan parliamentary groups in 42 countries have been formed in the past few years to help boost Taiwan's relations with those countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: 13 FOREIGN HEADS OF STATE TO ATTEND MAY 20 PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: Presidents or vice presidents from 13 diplomatic allies of the Republic of China have decided to travel to Taiwan to attend the May 20 inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian, an official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday.

According to DPP Vice Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan, 13 foreign heads of state have already promised President Chen that they or their deputies will take part in his inauguration as the ROC's 11th-term president slated for May 20 in Taipei.

Lee cited President Chen as saying that these presidents or vice presidents made the promise via telephone calls he made to them in recent days to thank them for their concern over his wounds sustained in the March 19 assassination attempt.

Apart from countries maintaining diplomatic ties with the ROC, non-diplomatic allies will also dispatch envoys to take part in the presidential inauguration, Lee said, adding that Therese Shaheen, former chairwoman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , will also be invited to attend the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN VOWS TO LEAD KMT TO WIN YEAR-END LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Wednesday he will do whatever he can to lead the party to win an many legislative seats as possible in the year-end elections.
Lien, who narrowly lost to incumbent President Chen Shui-bian in the March 20 presidential election, made the pledge while meeting with a group of KMT legislators.
It was the first of a series of Lien's planned meetings with incumbent KMT lawmakers over the next few days to discuss the party's strategies for the year-end legislative elections.
Lien said the upcoming legislative elections are crucial to the party's survival.
"It will be a life or death battle for us. We must gear up to win the battle. We cannot afford to lose," Lien was quoted as having told KMT lawmakers.

Encouraged by winning the presidential election, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is now setting its eye on winning more than half of the seats in the Legislative Yuan. The DPP now controls 87 seats in the legislature, compared to the KMT's 68 seats.

As the KMT and its ally -- the People First Party -- jointly control half of the legislative seats, the DPP administration has had a hard time implementing its reform agenda during Chen's first four-year term. The DPP has vowed to win more than half of the seats in the year-end legislative elections. One of DPP's strategies to realize this ambitious goal is to court promising KMT legislative hopefuls to join its ranks and run for legislative seats under its banner.
In the face of this situation, Lien said the KMT must make all-out efforts to prevent such a miserable scenario from happening.
"If our national resources are controlled by a handful of people, our democratic system will be at stake, " Lien said.

Noting that the KMT founded the Republic of China nearly a century ago and has made Taiwan a stable, prosperous and democratic island during its 54-year rule, Lien said the KMT should not be daunted by its current setbacks.

"We must stand united and work hard to expand our grassroots power base and inject new blood and vitality into our party apparatus, " Lien said, adding that the KMT must not let the DPP control both the administrative and legislative branches.
He further said election lawsuits, legislative elections and intra-party reforms will be the KMT's three most important tasks at the current stage.

"All these must be carried out simultaneously, " Lien said, adding that the party must review its overall structural problems as well as decision-making and grassroots mobilizations to make necessary improvements and upgrade operational efficiency.
Lien said he remains confident of the KMT's prospects for staging a comeback to power.

Lien has contested Chen's narrow re-election victory with sometimes violent street protests over the past three weeks and has also filed two lawsuits to nullify the election result and have the votes recounted.
Claiming that the March 19 shooting of President Chen unfairly swayed the election result in Chen's favor, Lien is now pushing for an independent inquiry into the shooting.

Lien said he will begin an islandwide speaking tour later this month to seek popular support for the KMT's proposal that a referendum be held alongside the year-end legislative elections to pave the way for the establishment of a special committee under the Legislative Yuan to investigate the shooting, which slightly wounded Chen and Vice President Annette Lu.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH MINISTER CONFIRMS RESIGNATION OF CDC HEAD

TEXT.P: Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) Minister Chen Chien-jen confirmed Wednesday a report about the resignation of Center of Disease Control Director-General Su Ih-jen.
Chen said that he has approved Su's resignation and submitted it to the Executive Yuan.

According to Chen, Su offered to quit the post in line with his own career plans. The DOH minister claimed that Su has several times made it clear that he would resume his research work at the National Health Research Institute, a DOH-affiliated research unit, as soon as he steps down from the post on May 19 as scheduled.

When asked about his own career, Chen was highly reserved and said only that he will resign along with other Cabinet members on May 12 in a weekly Executive Yuan meeting as Premier Yu Shyi-kun has made public.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL TOURISM OPERATORS EYEING ASIA FOR MORE VISITORS

TEXT.P: Luring people from Asia, particularly South Korea, to visit Taiwan should be the focus of local tourist agents, according to industry insiders.
Arrivals from Hong Kong and Macau have remained steady, although Japanese visitors are on the decline, they said.

Tourism operators pointed to signs that tourist arrivals in Taiwan this year may not be as good as expected, although the Tourism Bureau has set 2004 as "Taiwan tourism year" with the aim of attracting 3.2 million foreign visitors.

Statistics released by the Tourism Bureau showed that foreign arrivals in the first quarter are not as high as expected, especially Japanese tourists, who have been the top source of foreign Visitors. Their numbers have declined by more than 30 percent on average.

This means that Japanese tourist groups have yet not returned to Taiwan since the island was hard hit by severe acute respiratory syndrome between March and June 2003, and that only individuals and small groups have come to Taiwan.

The operators said that although the government has no lack of money in promoting tourism in Japan, the result has been very limited. Therefore, they think that it is better not to rely on a single market.
They also stressed the importance of the government adopting measures to facilitate foreign visitors, saying that the effect is almost immediate, citing South Korea as an example.

After Taiwan and South Korea severed diplomatic relations in August 1992 and the subsequent disruption of direct air links, they said that it was more difficult for South Koreans to come to Taiwan because of visa procedures and air transportation. Nowadays, with charter flight services and no-visa treatment, arrivals have grown rapidly.

The operators said that people from South Korea make 15,000 visits to Taiwan on average every month, and this is expected to continue to grow to make South Korea the third-largest source of tourists in Taiwan.
The number of mainland Chinese, including professionals, coming to Taiwan showed a decline because of political reasons, they noted.

The operators said that the government-set goal of 3.2 million visits will require more active promotion and the reduction of other unfavorable factors, although they will be content to welcome 2.5 million visitors judging from the present situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: RIOTERS FROM APRIL 10 RALLY MUST BE BROUGHT TO JUSTICE: PREMIER YU

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun urged law enforcement authorities Wednesday to bring to justice rioters who clashed with police in Taipei on the night of April 10 after a rally organized by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP).

In a written statement read by Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i at a weekly Cabinet meeting, the premier, who began a three day of leave of absence Wednesday, said his administration won't let rioters who attacked police with Molotov cocktails and iron bars go without paying for their crimes.
He also condemned the leaders of the KMT and PFP for urging their supporters to take to the streets even though they were unable to prevent them from running riot.

Demonstrations -- including the one on April 10 -- orchestrated by the two opposition parties to protest what they called the unfair presidential election on March 20, have damaged the nation's tourism, economy and competitiveness and have dampened foreign investors' enthusiasm for the country, the premier said in his statement.
He urged the opposition parties to resolve their disputes stemming from the election through legal processes without disturbing social order and stability.

After the permitted time for the Saturday, April 10 rally had passed, many protesters refused to disperse. The time was extended from 6 p.m. to 10 p.m., but a stubborn mob remained. They confronted police in front of the Presidential Office for nearly 12 hours, during which some 100 people were injured in scuffles with police.

Also in his statement, the premier asked the Taipei Power Company (Taipower) to find the cause of an hour-long power outage on April 10 that affected the Hsinchu Science-based Industry Park, causing an estimated NT$1.5 billion in losses to the roughly 350 companies there.
Yu praised Taipower for restoring the electricity to the park quickly, but urged the company to find out what caused the outage and to prevent such an occurrence from happening again.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOTED MAINLAND CHINESE NEUROSURGEON ARRIVES IN TAIPEI FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: Ling Fong, a mainland Chinese neurosurgeon, who came to fame in Taiwan after successfully treating a critically injured Taiwan-born TV anchorwoman, arrived in Taipei Wednesday for a four-day speaking tour.

Ling headed a five-member medical team at Xuanwu Hospital in Beijing that treated Tanya Liu, a former anchorwoman for Hong Kong-based Phoenix Satellite TV, who barely survived a London train crash in May 2002.
Speaking at a news conference held shortly after her arrival for her first-ever visit to Taiwan, Ling said she integrated Western and traditional Chinese medical expertises to treat Liu.
Ling also stressed that Liu had never been brain dead. "A brain-dead person can never be cured," she said.
Stunned by her achievements in treating Liu, some of Ling's fans have called her a "magic doctor." But a modest Ling said she is just a doctor.

Liu was pronounced brain dead at one point in London, and British doctors gave up efforts to treat her. But Liu managed to pick up a pen and write her name about five months after she was transferred to Xuanwu Hospital, where she received neurosurgery and rehabilitation treatment from Ling's team.
Ling said the British doctors' announcement might be based on a different medical philosophy. She repeated again that Liu was absolutely not brain dead two years ago.
As to her Taiwan itinerary, Ling said she was invited by a local medical research foundation to deliver two speeches. She will also visit Shin Kong Wu Ho Su Memorial Hospital in suburban Taipei.
Moreover, Ling will serve as a keynote speaker at the seventh Asian-Oceanian International Conference on Skull Base Surgery scheduled to open this weekend.

Ling was greeted by Liu, who is currently convalescing in Taiwan, at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport -- Taiwan's main gateway. Ling said she is very glad to see Liu in good health and good spirits.

Liu was on the ill-fated train with her friends, Wu Chia-ching and Lin Chia-hsin, both Taiwan-born television journalists. Seven people died, including Wu and Lin, and more than 70 others were injured in the accident, which was caused by faulty carriage couplings.
Liu is scheduled to return to work at Phoenix TV in the near future, after having almost fully recovered from her injuries.
Sources said Ling will travel to Hong Kong together with Liu to attend a charity fundraiser after her current Taipei visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARLIAMENTARY GROUP FROM SENEGAL VISITS KAOHSIUNG CITY COUNCIL

TEXT.P: A group of parliamentarian members from Senegal -- a west African diplomatic partner of the Republic of China -- paid a visit to the Kaohsiung City Council Wednesday.
The delegation was warmly greeted by council speaker Tsai Chien-hsing and other councilors.
In addition to issues on bilateral political, economic and cultural exchanges, the two sides also exchanged views on their countries' election systems and two-way fishery cooperation.
The Senegal parliamentarian members hailed Taiwan's democratization and thanked the long-term agricultural and economic assistance the ROC government has extended to their country.
They also expressed their hope of serving as a bridge to enhance mutual understanding and communications and voiced their support for Taiwan's bid to join international organizations.

According to Tsai, Kaohsiung's Chiencheng fishing port and Senegal's capital port city of Dakar maintain sisterhood ties and the two ports signed a cooperative pact last year to bolster bilateral cooperation.
Under the term of the agreement, the Dakar Port now serves as a supply, repairs and maintenance base for many fishing vessels from Taiwan catching tuna in the North Atlantic.
Tsai said that he is very willing to visit Senegal to pay back the guests' warm friendship toward Taiwan.
The Senegal parliamentarian mission traveled to Taiwan at the invitation of the ROC government, which has launched a series of drives to promote civil exchanges with friendly countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO DO VOLUNTEER WORK ON INAUGURATION DAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will engage in volunteer work, as he has done for the past several years, after the May 20 inauguration celebration rally concludes, Presidential Office officials said Wednesday.
The officials said it has not yet been decided where the president will go or what work he will do.

Chen began to take part in ceremonial volunteer work in 2001, exactly a year after his inauguration for his first presidential term. That year, he did some sweeping as community service. In 2002 he visited a hospital in Luotung, Ilan, and in 2003, he visited the Leshan Institution in Taipei County.
On January 25, 2002, he designated May 20 as the annual "Taiwan volunteer day."
Chen not only advocates "voluntarism in Taiwan, " but has put the ideals into action, the officials said, adding that this year will be no exception.

The scale of this year's inauguration ceremony will be bigger than that of four years ago, with 500,000 expected to attend rallies and ceremonies. Several national leaders, political dignitaries and groups of well-wishers are also expected to come. For safety reasons, traffic control areas will be expanded and all invited guests will have to present their invitation cards to be able to enter the square in front of the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEELUNG HARBOR OPERATION VOLUME IN MARCH INCREASES

TEXT.P: The operation volume recorded at Keelung Harbor in March increased from last month and year-on-year, with the loading and unloading volume of containers and bulk cargo the most significant, the Keelung Harbor Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications announced Wednesday.
The loading and unloading volume of bulk cargo was recorded as 8.53 million pay tons, an increase of 16.28 percent from the previous month and a rise of 7.54 percent year-on-year.
The loading and unloading volume of containers totaled 180,574.75 TEUs (twenty-foot equivalent units), an increase of 14.3 percent from last month and a rise of 3.19 percent year-on-year.

Among them, imported containers stood at 83,506.75 TEUs, an increase of 18.95 percent from a month ago and a rise of 6.63 percent year-on-year, while exported containers accounted for 78,140 TEUs, an increase of 9.87 percent from last month and a rise of 1.23 percent year-on-year.
Transshipped containers, however, accounted for 18,928 TEUs, an increase of 13.64 percent from the previous month but a decrease of 2.87 percent year-on-year.
A total of 831 vessels entered the harbor in March, an increase of 9.92 percent from the previous month and a rise of 8.77 percent year-on-year.

Operation volume for the period from January to March also grew, with the loading and unloading volume of bulk cargo recorded as 22.6 million pay tons, an increase of 6.45 percent from the same period of last year, while the loading and unloading volume of containers totaled 0.49 million TEUs, an increase of 5.48 percent year-on-year.
In addition, 2,338 vessels entered the harbor between January and March, an increase of 14.83 percent from the same period of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush Asserts 'We Must Not Waver' on Terror or Iraq.
President Bush vowed on Tuesday night that the United States would not bow to the surge of violence in Iraq, saying that to change course in the face of mounting attacks would betray the Iraqi people and embolden America's enemies around the world.
Mr. Bush strongly reiterated his commitment to transferring sovereignty in Iraq back to Iraqis on schedule on June 30 despite the spike in resistance there.
Wall Street Journal: U.S. Will Prevail, Hold to Timetable In Iraq, Bush Says.
President Bush said he wouldn't back down from the challenges of Iraq and offered no hint he would alter his approach there, despite a recent surge of violence that has boosted U.S. casualties and heightened criticism of the president's war plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT TESTIFIES IN TRIAL OF NSB OFFICER

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui testified behind closed doors in court Wednesday in the trial of Hsu Ping-chiang, a former chief accountant of the National Security Bureau (NSB).
Lee testified as a witness and answered questions from prosecutors before Hsu was brought into court to read the transcript of Lee's testimony.
As Hsu questioned part of Lee's testimony, the judges presiding over the hearing allowed him to confront Lee in the court for nearly an hour.
Lee is the last of a series high-profile witness, including former Foreign Minister Jason Hu and former NSB Director Ting Yu-chou, to bear testimony in the case.

Hsu stands accused of diverting NT$250 million (US$10.5 million) from a secret slush fund managed by the NSB to Taiwan Research Institute (TRI) President Liu Tai-ying in 1999. According to the charges against him, Liu used some of the money to finance the institute and the rest to line his own pockets.

The money was paid by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to the NSB as reimbursement for a political donation made in 1994 by then-President Lee to South Africa's ruling African National Congress using the secret NSB slush fund.
Hsu argued that he acted on the orders of late NSB Director Yin Tsung-wen and that Yin was basically acting on Lee's instructions.
As president at the time, Lee was also chairman of the National Security Council, which is the immediate superior of the NSB.
After his term as president expired in 2000, Lee became chairman of the TRI.

Hsu, along with the NSB's chief cashier at the time, Liu Kuan-chun, are the only two to have been indicted in the case, but Hsu is the only one to stand trial as Liu fled the country before investigators could catch him. (Maubo Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Crime cheks cost taxpayers extra Â£150m.
Home Office officials have landed the taxpayer with a grossly underestimated bill over a disastrous contract with an agency that checks people working with children and the vulnerable.
Financial Times: EU move to win trade deal.
The European Union plans to splinter opposition to its Common Agricultural Policy this week by offering members of Mercosur, the Latin American customs union, a deal aimed at winning their support in the Doha trade round.
The move is designed to weaken pressure on the EU to lower its farm trade barriers by, in effect, buying off Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay with the offer of preferential trade concessions. These countries have been among the fiercest adversaries of Brussels in the global trade talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREANS AWARE OF CHALLENGES POSED BY GLOBAL COMPETITION: STUDY

TEXT.P: Singaporeans are ready to accept pay cuts and "flexi-wages" based on performance, according to a recent study by the Manpower Ministry.

The study showed that workers are aware of the challenges posed by global competition. Over 70 percent of the 2,500 people who took part in the study said they are prepared to take pay cuts because of the bad economic situation, while six in 10 workers understand the need for retrenchment. A majority also said that they can accept the idea of "flexi-wages."
Job seekers have also adjusted their expectations, being more willing to apply for jobs in different industries and for jobs that require weekend work, according to the study.
Still, with the economy looking up, over 70 percent of those who participated in the study said they are confident they would be able keep their job over the next 12 months.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORTS,IMPORTS IN MARCH HIT RECORD HIGH: CBC

TEXT.P: Exports and imports in March hit a record high for this year, the Central Bank of China (CBC) announced Wednesday.

Exports earned US$16.91 billion in foreign reserves in March, while imports cost US$16.51 billion. These higher figures were due to increased demand for commodities and raw materials caused by a globally rebounding economy, according to the CBC statistics.
This worked out at a trade surplus of US$402 million in March, with exports accounting for an increase of 26.2 percent and imports showing an increase of 37 percent year-on-year.

For the period from January to March 2004, exports stood at US$47.1 billion, an increase of 26.4 percent, while imports stood at US$42.04 billion, a rise of 26.9 percent, from the same period of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU WELCOMES KMT LEGISLATIVE HOPEFULS TO JOIN RANKS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Wednesday that opposition Kuomintang (KMT) members intending to participate in the year-end legislative elections are welcome to join its ranks and run for legislative seats under its banner.
TSU legislative whip Chen Chien-ming said the TSU will campaign on a platform of expanding Taiwan consciousness and Taiwan national identity for the legislative elections.

While the TSU cooperated with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) during the just-concluded presidential election, Chen said, the TSU will define itself as a "loyal opposition party" in the run-up to the legislative elections.

"We'll present our own financial, economic, cultural and social reform agenda to distinguish the TSU from the DPP and to attract those who agree with our national reform vision and ideals to join our ranks," Chen explained.

Noting that elections provide good opportunities for political parties to seek popular support for their concepts and platforms, Chen said the TSU will take advantage of the legislative elections to expand its power base and secure new allies.

The TSU now controls 12 seats in the Legislative Yuan, but Chen said the party hopes to garner more than 15 percent of the votes in the legislative elections so as to secure 30 seats in the new legislature to be inaugurated early next year.

Stressing that a rising Taiwan identity contributed to President Chen Shui-bian's re-election, Chen said he is convinced that the additional 1.5 million ballots Chen garnered in the March 20 poll over the number of ballots he netted in the 2000 election could be a guarantee for the TSU's success in the legislative elections.

The TSU was formed about three years ago, with former President Lee Teng-hui as its "spiritual leader." Incumbent TSU Chairman Huang Chu-wen and several other senior party officials are former KMT members.
Chen said the TSU welcomes KMT members who share the values of national reform and a "Taiwan first" stance to join its ranks and run for legislative seats under its banner.

In the 2001 legislative elections, the TSU nominated 39 candidates. Chen said the party plans to nominate 40 candidates this time, with one or two for each constituency. For some constituencies, such as the outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu, Penghu and Taitung, the TSU will not field candidates, Chen added.
As for the TSU's relationship with the DPP, Chen said the two parties have yet to discuss any joint strategies for the legislative elections.

"The TSU doesn't rule out the possibility of forming a strategic alliance with the DPP for the elections. We may adjust our cooperative strategies in terms of distinctive conditions in various constituencies," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERWORK DEATH CRITERIA CAN BE LOWERED: LABOR COUNCIL

TEXT.P: The criteria for deciding when a death is the result of overwork could probably be lowered if there were precedents in other countries that could be used as reference, a Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) official said Wednesday.

Lin Chin-chi, director of the CLA's Department of Labor Safety and Health, said the standard for reaching a verdict of death by overwork, known in Japan as karoshi, would not be based solely on work hours and that other occupational factors should also be included when such a case is judged.
Lin said the CLA will not reject opinions from any private organization or specialist group on criteria for death by overwork when considering revisions to the existing regulations in this regard.

The CLA official made the remarks in response to several private groups, which lodged a protest to the CLA headquarters Wednesday against the government's harsh standards for judging when death is the result of overwork.

An official of the Taiwan Association for Victims of Occupational Injuries (TAVOI) said that it is unacceptably harsh that the CLA regulates that an overwork verdict can only be applied when an employee has worked for 24 hours continuously before dying or has worked for over 16 hours every day one week before dying.

A spokesman for the Confederation of Taipei Trade Unions also pointed out that the CLA criteria are too narrow, as they relate largely to the diseases as cause of death, but barely mention any reasons concerning working conditions and other social and psychological factors that could be involved.
Many causes of death, including heart attack, stroke and suicide, can be the results of pressure derived from overworking, but are excluded from the CLA criteria, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPA DEPUTY TO BECOME NEW NATIONAL POLICE CHIEF

TEXT.P: National Police Administration (NPA) Deputy Director-General Shieh Yin-tang will assume office as Taiwan's highest ranking police officer Thursday, a spokesman for the Ministry of the Interior announced Wednesday.
Shieh, 55, will take over from Chang Shi-liang, who offered to step down to assume responsibility for the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.

Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan will preside over Shieh's swearing-in ceremony at the NPA headquarters and will also award Chang a ministry citation in recognition of his efforts and contributions over the past nine months while serving in the post.
Chang, the most short-lived national police chief, has applied for retirement.

The failed assassination attempt on Chen has stirred up a series of personnel changes amid grave public concern over the security of the head of state. Su took over the Ministry of the Interior last Friday from his predecessor Yu Cheng-hsien, who also resigned to assume responsibility for the shooting.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY SHOULD BE INAUGURATED ON SCHEDULE: THSRC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first high-speed railway should be inaugurated in October 2005 as scheduled, despite some financial hitches, Taiwan High Speed Railway Corp. (THSRC) President Liu Kuo-chih said Wednesday.

Despite the fact that THSRC has had bumpy performance in its fund-raising efforts and the company has only recently been hit by an international arbitration body for massive damages to its former partner, THSRC will try its utmost to catch up with the building schedule so that the high-speed railway system can be inaugurated Oct. 31, 2005, Liu said during a meeting at the Legislative Yuan Transportation Committee.
Liu added, however, that he is not 100 percent positive that the high-speed railway system will be completed on time, as there are still too many uncertainties surrounding the huge project.

After failing to secure necessary funding of NT$10 billion (US$303 million) by the end of February for part of an increment in corporate capital, THSRC has consulted its banking consortium and reached a new agreement that THSRC will raise NT$7.5 billion by the end of July, followed by another NT$10.2 billion by the end of September and a further NT$10 billion before Nov. 30 to finance the development of the railway.

Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san, who was also present at the legislative meeting, said that so far, the high-speed railway development has not stalled because of the funding difficulties.

However, he added that if the THSRC cannot raise enough funds in the days to come, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications will have no choice but to buy out the project at a cost of at least NT$100 billion.
Meanwhile, the THSRC management has been mulling whether to accept or appeal an arbitration award wherein it is ordered to pay US$73.04 million in damages to its former partner, Eurotrain.

THSRC teamed up with the Eurotrain consortium in 1996 to vie for the right to construct the island's first high-speed railway, but ditched Eurotrain for Japan's Shinkansen consortium in 1999 after it won the US$16 billion contract in 1997, on the grounds that Eurotrain charged too much for its system and refused to become a THSRC partner.
Eurotrain filed for arbitration with the International Chamber of Commerce in New York in 2001.
The development of the high-speed railway, the world's largest BOT (build-operate-transfer) project currently under construction, was launched in July 1998.

When the new railway is inaugurated, it will take less than 90 minutes to travel from Taipei in the north to Kaohsiung in the south and it will become the backbone of a mass rapid transportation network for western Taiwan.

The 345-kilometer railway will connect eight metropolitan areas between Taipei and Kaohsiung, the two biggest cities on the island. It will be able to transport at least 300,000 passengers daily when it becomes fully operational.

Infrastructure, including broadband communication systems, are being built in special zones in the vicinity of the high speed railway stations at Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Taichung, Chiayi and Tainan to facilitate the formation of special business complexes in the five cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market moved up Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April rose 97 points to close at 6,920, with 41,317 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May gained 71 points to end at 6,921, with 2,641 contracts traded, while June futures rose 11 points to end at 6,835, with 15 contracts finalized.
September futures gained 71 points to close at 6,921, with seven contracts concluded, while December futures rose 60 points to end at 6,900, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,823 for April, 6,850 for May, 6,824 for June, 6,850 for September and 6,840 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also moved up.
April TE futures rose 7.3 points to close at 287.5, with 7,986 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained seven points to end at 287, with 808 contracts transacted.
June TE futures rose six points to close at 287, with 12 contracts finalized.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures rose 2.2 points to close at 1,071, with 8,757 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures gained four points to end at 1,072, with 1,168 contracts traded.
June TF futures ended even at 1,068, with one contract transaction, while September TF futures gained 4.6 points to end at 1,076, with six contracts finalized.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: DETAINING MAINLAND STOWAWAYS PUTS FINANCIAL BURDEN ON TAIWAN: CIB

TEXT.P: The large number of mainland Chinese stowaways detained at centers across Taiwan has created a heavy financial burden for the government, a spokesman for the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said Wednesday.

With the launch of an across-the-board campaign to clamp down on illegal immigrants from mainland China, many mainland stowaways have been seized and detained by police and coast guard authorities, the spokesman said.

However, the mainland side's reluctance to take them back has generated serious expenses for the Taiwan authorities, who have to maintain their needs here such as personnel costs, transport fees, as well as spending on clothes, meals, medical care and insurance fees, the spokesman said.

Citing statistics compiled by the bureau, he reported that Taiwan repatriated a total of 2,237 illegal immigrants to the mainland in 14 groups last year. In the first two months of this year, 674 people were sent back.
However, some 2,155 people still remain detained -- 1,132 at the eastern Ilan detention center, 1,011 at the northern Hsinchu detention center and 12 at the center on Matsu Island, he pointed out.
Meanwhile, the police authorities warned that more and more young mainland women have illegally sneaked into Taiwan to make money in the sex industry.

CIB statistics show that 577 female mainland stowaways were arrested in 2001, with the number picking up to 1,393 and 1,962 in 2002 and 2003, respectively. In 2001, 259 mainland women were nabbed by police for prostitution, while the number rose to 642 in 2002 and 894 in 2003.

In 2001 and 2002, women aged between 16 and 30 formed the largest group of mainland female stowaways arrested in Taiwan, but a total of 1,233 mainland female stowaways detained last year were in the 16-20 age group, while 96 children aged below 15 years were caught, the same tallies show.
Police said that many women from the mainland who legally enter Taiwan also engage in the sex business through fake marriages with Taiwan men. "This problem is getting worse," they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO RESUME CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE AFTER MAY 20

TEXT.P: Mainland China should squarely face up to Taiwan's democratic development and resume dialogue with the country after President Chen Shui-bian's inauguration for a second four-year term May 20, Cabinet spokesman Lin Chia-lung said Wednesday.

Lin made the remarks after the Taiwan Affairs Office of mainland China's State Council claimed earlier in the day that Taiwan's timetable for holding a referendum on the formulation of a new constitution is tantamount to a schedule for pursuing de jure Taiwan independence.

In democratic countries, Lin said, constitutional reform is a matter of course. Mainland China should not viciously distort Taiwan's constitutional reform plan as a plot to pursue formal independence, he added.
Since Taiwan is a democratic country, Lin continued, Taiwan's future political development hinges on its mainstream public opinion.

Noting that Chen won a second term by securing slightly more than half of the votes cast in the March 20 presidential election, Lin said Beijing's leaders should squarely face up to this reality and resume cross-strait dialogue in order to forge peaceful and stable cross-strait ties.
As Chen had campaigned on a platform of strengthening Taiwan's separate identity, Lin said, Chen's re-election indicates that Taiwan identity has received majority support in local society.

Taiwan has come a long way in political democratization, Lin went on, adding that from the lifting of martial law to legislative reform, direct presidential elections and the first-ever referendum last month, Taiwan has earned much acclaim from home and abroad for its democratic reform.

Lin said he is convinced that Taiwan's experience can serve as reference for mainland China's future political reform. Against this backdrop, he said, the mainland should refrain from distorting Taiwan's planned constitutional reform as steps toward formal independence.

Warning that spiteful criticism and allegations will only bring about more confrontation and animosity, Lin said Beijing should show "more sincerity and inclusiveness while reducing distortion and criticism" so that cross-strait relations can enter a new stage of reconciliation and rapprochement.

As to Beijing's claim that Chen's "one country on each side the Taiwan Strait" advocacy will gravely hinder cross-strait exchanges and delay the opening of direct cross-strait shipping and air links, Lin said the obstacles to direct cross-strait transportation links lie in Beijing's hegemonic attitude toward Taiwan.
"We have consistently adopted an open-minded and pragmatic attitude toward cross-strait ties, and we hope Beijing can refrain from 'politicizing' the direct shipping and air link issue, " Lin said.

Chen has announced a plan to write a new constitution suitable for Taiwan's present status quo to be put to a referendum in 2006 for implementation in 2008. Even though Chen has on many occasions stressed that formulation of a new constitution will be carried out on the principle of "no change to Taiwan's present status quo" and has nothing to do with Taiwan independence, the Beijing authorities still consistently distort it as a timetable for promoting Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended the day higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 85.85 points to close at 6,880.18.
The bourse opened at 6,772.42 and fluctuated between 6,880.18 and 6,772.42 during trading.

A total of 7.51 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$181.15 billion (US$5.41 billion), a decrease from the previous day's trading session which saw 7.99 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$184.31 billion.

Four of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with electrical shares moving up the most at 2.3 percent, followed by foodstuff stocks at 1.1 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.6 percent, and textile issues at 0.5 percent.

The other four major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 1.5 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.5 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.2 percent, and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 480 to 346, with 149 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK INDEX UP BY 85.85 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground Wednesday, with the weighted index moving up 85.85 points to close at 6,880.18.
Market turnover amounted to NT$181.15 billion (US$5.41 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN POLICY TO REMAIN LARGELY UNCHANGED: VICE MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's foreign policy will remain largely unchanged even though a new foreign affairs minister has been appointed, Vice Foreign Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau said Wednesday.

Kau said he does not see the nation's foreign policy changing significantly as a result of the changeover. However, he added that the question of how Taiwan's overall foreign policy will be directed depends on the decisions to be made by the incoming minister.

He noted that Foreign Minister-designate Chen Tan-sun is a statesman with a pragmatic approach. "I believe that pragmatism will secure Taiwan substantive progress on its diplomatic front at a time when the country is facing increasing challenges in the international community," he added. Chen will assume office Friday.

The vice foreign minister made the remarks during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan, where opposition legislators questioned him about the government's foreign policy and Taiwan's relations with the United States in the wake of President Chen Shui-bian's re-election.

Kau said he does not think that ROC-U.S. bilateral ties have dropped to their "all-time low ebb" as some politicians have claimed, although he added that there is always room for improvement in the bilateral ties.

In response to a question about his possible appointment as Taiwan's top representative to the United States to succeed outgoing Chen Chien-jen, Kau said that he has been "ordered" many times by his wife to "retire and go home" and that he would do so if given the chance.

Nevertheless, he added that if his superiors require him to be the top liaison officer to the United States, he will not shirk his duties, saying that it is every citizen's responsibility to serve their country.

Kau declined to speculate on who will be appointed to the post of top ROC representative to the United States, saying that the authority to decide lies with the ROC president. He added that it also requires the consent of the U.S. government.
He said that the MOFA has provided President Chen with a "short list" of candidates for the post, adding however that the MOFA is not in a position to dictate the president's decision on the matter.

The people on the "short list" include Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, Taiwan's top representative to the United Kingdom Tien Hung-mau, Presidential Office Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, Vice Foreign Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau, and Legislators Parris Chang and Hsiao Bi-khim from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
Kau declined to say anything further when asked whether any other individuals not on the "short list" are being considered for the post.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
[Turkish Daily News]: [Turkish military: Final say rests with Parliament, Turkish Cypriots]
Chief of General Staff Gen. Hilmi Qzkok said on Tuesday that Turkey's Parliament and the Turkish Cypriot people have the final say on the proposed Cyprus deal shaped by the Annan plan, adding that "we wholeheartedly believe that they will make the right decision."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, April 14 [CNA] The Moscow Times:Russian Captives Freed in Baghdad.
Eight Russian and Ukrainian workers were freed Tuesday in Baghdad after being kidnapped about 12 hours earlier by Iraqi insurgents. Their quick release was partially attributed to Russia's opposition to the U.S.-led invasion of Iraq, but Moscow still urged the 500 to 1,000 Russians working in the country to leave promptly.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPUTY PROMOTED TO HEAD OF NPA

TEXT.P: National Police Administration (NPA) Deputy Director-General Hsieh Yin-tang was promoted Wednesday by newly appointed Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan to NPA director-general, succeeding Chang Ssu-liang, who resigned recently.

Hsieh, 55, a graduate from National Central Police University, has been the NPA deputy director-general since 2001. He had also served as director of the Kaohsiung Municipal Police Department, NPA chief supervisor, and No. 2 police officer at the former Taiwan Provincial Government.
A devout Buddhist, Hsieh is known for maintaining his neutrality in politics over the past years. He has been highly praised by his superiors for his integrity and abilities.
NPA Director-General Chang tendered his resignation April 4 to take responsibility for the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.
In the election-eve assassination attempt in Tainan City, southern Taiwan, President Chen sustained a flesh wound across his abdomen, while Vice President Lu suffered a minor wound to her right knee.

During his nine-month stint as head of the NPA, Chang has actively promoted police administrative reforms and beefed up police counter-terrorism capabilities to enhance public trust in the nation's police force.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: U.S. forces set to strike militia in Najaf.
American forces prepared Tuesday to attack militia loyal to fugitive radical Shiite Muslim cleric Muqtada al-Sadar in the holy city of Najaf.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 14, or the 25th day of the leap second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1629: Christiaan Huygens, the Dutch physicist and astronomer, is born. He discovered Saturn's rings in 1655, pioneered the use of pendulum in clocks in 1657, and formulated Huygens' principle.
1865: US President Abraham Lincoln is failing fast after being shot in the back of the head at point-blank range by actor John Wilkes Booth, a Confederate fanatic, at the Ford Theater in Washington, D.C. He died the next day and was succeeded by Andrew Johnson.
1889: Arnold Toynbee, British historian and author of a 12-volume work entitled "A Study of History," is born.
1903: The typhus vaccine is discovered by Dr. Harry Plotz in New York.
1912: The Titanic strikes an iceberg and sinks in the North Atlantic, killing 1,500 people.
1941: Condemning the Soviet-Japanese Neutrality Pact, Foreign Minister Wang Chung-hui of the Republic of China declares that Outer Mongolia and the northeastern provinces are Chinese territory and that the Soviet-Japanese statement is not binding on China.
1945: US bombers pound Japan's Imperial Palace during World War II.
1949: The Taiwan provincial administration announces a decision to carry out the "37.5 Percent Farm Rental Reduction" and the "Land-to-the-Tiller" policies.
1956: USS Saratoga, a US Navy aircraft carrier which joined the fleet in 1927 as the largest warship in the world, is formally decommissioned.
1956: The first videotape is demonstrated in Chicago.
1962: French Prime Minister Michel Debre resigns and is succeeded by Georges Pompidou.
1971: The new Tourism Bureau of the Ministry of Communications is inaugurated in Taipei.
1972: The first satellite observation station in the Republic of China is inaugurated at National Cheng Kung University.
1973: President Nguyen Van Thieu of the Republic of Vietnam leaves Taipei for home after a three-day visit.
1973: Dr. Jesus Soto Amesty, chairman of the Venezuela Senate Foreign Policy Committee, arrives in Taipei for a ten-day visit.
1975: Sikkim abolishes its monarchy and seeks full Indian statehood.
1976: A total of 3,460 students from 642 middle schools compete in the Taiwan Area Games.
1977: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces severance of diplomatic relations with the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan.
1982: Armed bandit Lee Shih-khe robs the Land Bank of Taiwan's Kuting Branch in Taipei City of more than NT$5 million, a major criminal case at that time.
1988: The Soviet Union ends its intervention in Afghanistan and allows its troops to withdraw.
1993: On International Women's Day, a Chinese newspaper asks 100 women what they would most like to be. Sixty say that they want to be men.
1994: Two US F-15 fighters shoot down two American helicopters over northern Iraq killing 26 people.
1999: Pakistan test-fires a 2,000-km range ballistic missile.
2000: Ovidio Manuel Barbosa Pequeno, the new Sao Tome and Principe ambassador to the Republic of China, presents his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui.
2001: A four-member U.S. Senate delegation led by Sen. Phil Gramm (R-TX) arrives in Taipei to begin a three-day visit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To be poor without complaining is not easy; but it is easy to be rich without being proud."

The taxman has increased the annual value of HDB flats for the first time in 14 years, a revision that will double the number of home owners paying property tax.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore Govt increase it's flats property tax within 3 years.
Increases are the first in 14 years and will be phased in over three years; 3, 4 and 5-room flats get discounts for two years.

The Manila Bulletin: Tax filing deadline today. Individual and corporate earners are reminded to file their income tax returns for 2003 today as the Bureau of Internal Revenue (BIR) warned that there will be no deadline extension for late filers.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Roco:'Tell it to the wind, I am not quitting'. ALTHOUGH he left a mere 10 hours after announcing his decision to seek medical treatment in the United States, Raul Roco was able to put his house in order.
The Philippine Star: Roco back in two weeks. Ailing presidential candidate Raul Roco will return in two weeks to fight President Arroyo in the May 10 elections, his campaign manager said yesterday.
The Manila Times: P100-M TV deal hounds Bro. Eddie Eddie Villanueva, the televangelist and candidate for president, may have violated a multimillion-peso contract by holding on to the majority control of a religious-oriented television network despite an agreement to relinquish it to a partner outfit.

The Japan Times: AL-Sadr extends olive branch; Bodies found in Iraq may be missing U.S. civilians.
Four bodies have been found in Iraq, possibly the remains of private contractors missing since an assault on their convoy outside Baghdad amid a wave of kidnappings of up to 40 foreigners in Iraq.

DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Bush Vows to Finish Job in Iraq,Stands by Timetable.
Against a backdrop of widespread violence in Iraq, President Bush insisted that U.S. troops were making progress in restoring order to the country and that "we must not waver"from plans to return sovereignty to the Iraqi people on June 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE EXPERIENCES 1-HOUR BLACKOUT

TEXT.P: About 80,000 households and businesses in Singapore experienced a power outage for about an hour late Tuesday night when a cable at a substation short-circuited.
The blackout, which occurred at about 11: 30 p.m., hit the northwestern part of Singapore.

Singapore's last major blackout happened Aug. 5, 2002, when a computer glitch caused seven power plants to trip, resulting in a 90-minute power failure during the day in several parts of the city-state.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE PROBE SECRET SHARE HOLDINGS OF LATE TYCOON

TEXT.P: The Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) of Singapore has begun investigating the secret share holdings of the late billionaire Khoo Teck Puat.
The involvement of the white-collar crime busters comes after nearly three weeks of investigations by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Singapore Exchange (SGX).

That investigation was launched after the trustees of Khoo's estate made a shock disclosure last month that he may have misled regulators and investors for years by deliberately under-reporting the extent of his control in several listed companies.
Khoo, who died in February of this year at the age of 87, was one of Singapore's wealthiest men.
Source close to the Khoo family yesterday sought to downplay the significance of the CAD's involvement, saying that it was routine and that its investigation does not aim to cover any new ground.

DOC.HEADLINE: SERVICES OF PUBLIC SERVANTS APPROVED BY MAJORITY: SURVEY

TEXT.P: More than 70 percent of the Taiwan people polled recently are satisfied with services provided by public servants, according to results of the survey released Thursday by the government.

The survey conducted by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission under the Executive Yuan shows that 74 percent of the respondents approve of the quality of services overall, while 70 percent of those polled are satisfied with the manners demonstrated by public servants in telephone calls.

Among the 17 categories of public services, those of the environmental agencies ranked top, with 76 percent of the respondents satisfied, followed by postal services with a 75.8 percent satisfaction rate and telecommunications with a 68 percent approval rating.
On the negative side, the survey shows, traffic police top the list with 19 percent of the respondents dissatisfied with their services.
The survey was carried out March 29-30 with 1,127 valid samples randomly selected by telephone and a margin of error of 2.9 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN AIDE LAUDS OPPOSITION DECISION TO USE LEGAL MEANS IN DISPUTE

TEXT.P: An aide to President Chen Shui-bian lauded an opposition People First Party (PFP) decision Thursday to stick to legal means to settle their election disputes.

Huang Chih-fang, the director of the Department for Public Affairs under the Presidential Office, said Taiwan has a sound judiciary system to deal with the opposition's questions about the March 20 presidential election and the opposition should let justice run its course rather than organizing protests to press their demand for a vote re-count.

As a president elected by the people, Huang said, Chen will be inaugurated to his second term May 20 as scheduled, an event that won't be affected by the opposition's questions about the election results.

He made the comment after the PFP Caucus at the Legislative Yuan threatened to ask the court to stop Chen assuming office May 20 if there has been no ruling on a lawsuit brought by PFP and its election partner, the Kuomintang (KMT), to invalidate the election.

Meanwhile, Lee Ying-yuan, the deputy secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said the court will not grant PFP's request, adding that the president has done his best to cooperate with investigators to clear up the election disputes.
In a related development Thursday, KMT Chairman Lien Chan told the Tokyo-based Asahi Television Station that there are hints suggesting the March 19 shooting of Chen was a political ploy.

Shortly after the shooting took place, Lien claimed, the DPP and many unlicensed radio stations in southern Taiwan began circulating the rumor that the KMT and PFP colluded with Beijing to assassinate the president. They also used campaign cars to hand out prepared leaflets to this effect, he claimed.
As a result, he said, Chen won the election by a narrow margin the next day.
Lien claimed that the opposition's questions about the fairness of the election are well-grounded and he repeated his party's calls for a thorough investigation into the March 19 shooting.
However, Lee Ying-yuan denied Lien's claims.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12 HEADS OF FOREIGN STATES TO ATTEND PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: A total of 12 heads of foreign states have confirmed that they will attend President Chen Shui-bian's inauguration for his second four-year term slated for May 20, outgoing Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said Thursday.
Speaking at a farewell party hosted by Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials in his honor, Chien said that the invitations to three other heads of foreign states are awaiting confirmation.
Chien encouraged MOFA officials to do their best to help his successor, Foreign Minister-designate Chen Tan-sun, to organize the inauguration and make it perfect.

Chien offered to resign last Friday over the departure of American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen -- the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

"Ms. Shaheen was a good friend of Taiwan and a bridge between Taiwan and the U.S. State Department, and we appreciate her contribution to Taiwan-U.S. relations, " Chien told a news conference last Friday.
In Shaheen's resignation, Chien said MOFA had been guilty of dereliction of duty and insufficient supervision. He did not elaborate.
Chien is to hand over the ministry's helm to Chen Tan-sun at a changeover ceremony to be held Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. VP CARRYING NO MESSAGE FROM VATICAN TO BEIJING: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Vatican has not asked U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney to relay a request for Beijing to strike up diplomatic ties with the Holy See, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

Kao An, the deputy director of MOFA's Department for Information and Cultural Affairs, said that Tu Chu-sheng, Taipei's ambassador to the Vatican has been assured by the State Department of the Holy See that Cheney has not been asked to serve as a messenger, as had been reported by wire services Thursday.

Noting that the Vatican and Beijing cannot straighten out their differences over the Vatican's power to appoint bishops in mainland China, Kao said that "it is weird that the Vatican would sidestep this long-standing question and offer to establish diplomatic ties with Beijing."

As the wire story attributed its story to an anonymous U.S. official accompanying Cheney on his trip to the mainland, Kao suggested that either the official was unaware of the sticking point in negotiations between the Vatican and Beijing or the correspondent who wrote the story made a mistake.

Kao said his ministry would reserve its response to Cheney's tour of the mainland until Washington has briefed Taipei on the issue. Washington has promised to keep Taiwan informed of Cheney's contacts with mainland leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISTRIBUTION COMPANIES HOPE FOR CROSS-STRAIT DIRECT LINKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has great potential to serve as a global distribution center, but the opening of full direct transport links with mainland China is the key issue in its bid to achieving this status, business executives said Thursday.

Executives from world famous express delivery companies -- Germany-based DHL, U.S.-based FEDEX, U.S.-based UPS and Britain-based EXCEL -- and representatives from the local industry made the call at a seminar sponsored by the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) to collect opinions and proposals from the private sector about the government's goal to build Taiwan into a global distribution hub.

Huang Chung-jen, chairman of the Republic of China Distribution Association, hailed the government's hub goal as the correct path, but he also issued a reminder that mainland China, Hong Kong and Singapore are strong competitors in this field and urged local businesses to build brand consciousness.

Citing Yangming Marine Transport Corp. Ltd. and Evergreen Marine Corp. Ltd. as examples, Huang said that the two Taiwan-based shipping firms, each with a world-class reputation, are capable of helping the country move a big step closer toward its distribution hub dream if they effectively consolidate their transnational supply chains in cooperation with the many Taiwan companies operating in mainland China and Taiwan's e-commerce clout.

Taiwan stands a good chance of becoming an international distribution center if this is done, Huang said, but he pointed out that in addition, direct transport links between Taiwan and the mainland must be established.
DHL Taiwan General Manager Yang Fei agreed with Huang's viewpoint.

Claiming that Taiwan's geographic location and cheaper operational costs are far beyond comparison with Hong Kong, Singapore and Japan, Yang contended that direct cross-Taiwan Strait transport links would enable Taiwan to definitely gain the upper hand over other countries in the region.
Taiwan's status as the world's 17th-largest foreign trader and a prime supplier of information industry-related products in the world market are other advantages that it possesses, Yang noted.

However, he stressed that full and direct cross-strait transport, trade and postal services are of maximum importance as to whether or not Taiwan can be a global distribution hub. He urged the government to pay special heed to the direct transport issue and called for a cut in government sector red tape.

Putting aside the sensitive cross-strait ties issue, government officials attending the seminar promised to do what they can to improve the existing practices, including easing rules in order to shorten the documentation process.

Scores of officials from the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, Bureau of Foreign Trade, Industrial Development Bureau, Ministry of Finance and Ministry of Transportation and Communications also took part in the gathering.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO ASK COURT TO BAN MAY 20 PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition People First Party (PFP) said Thursday it plans to ask the Taiwan High Court to ban the May 20 presidential inauguration if the two election lawsuits are not concluded before that day.

PFP legislative whip Hsu Yuan-kuo claimed that since the "pan-blue alliance" presidential and vice presidential candidates -- Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong -- have contested the election result with two lawsuits, incumbent President Chen Shui-bian is not eligible to take the oath for a second term before the lawsuits are settled.

Chen defeated Lien by a slim margin of 29,518 ballots in the March 20 presidential election. Claiming that the election-eve shooting of Chen unfairly swayed the result in Chen's favor, the Lien-Soong ticket has filed two lawsuits to nullify Chen's re-election victory and to annul the entire election so that a new one can be held.
The High Court has held two hearings on the election result nullification lawsuit and is expected to begin a full-scale judicial vote recount early next month.
Hsu said if the court fails to settle the lawsuits before May 20, the president-elect should not formally assume office.

Hsu said the "pan-blue alliance's" lawyers are studying relevant regulations and plan to file a petition with the High Court in early May demanding that the court ban Chen from being sworn in for a second four-year term.

However, under the President and Vice President Election and Recall Law, lawsuits regarding election results should be settled within six months. During the court proceedings, the president-elect and vice president-elect formally announced by the Central Election Commission (CEC) can take office as scheduled. The CEC announced March 26 that Chen and Vice President Annette Lu won the March 20 poll.

Hsu said that although the law does not prescribe that the plaintiff of an election lawsuit can petition the court to ban the inauguration of a president-elect, the court should not reject the "pan-blue alliance's" petition, because many disputes involved in the just-concluded presidential election have never happened before.
Presidential Office spokesman James Huang refrained from commenting on the PFP's planned petition, saying that the Presidential Office would not comment on any specific lawsuit.
Instead, Huang said Chen will take the oath May 20 for a second four-year term in line with the law.
Huang further said he is pleased to see the "pan-blue alliance" willing to resolve the election disputes through the judicial system.

In the past few weeks, the "pan-blue alliance" has staged sometimes violent street protests against the election outcome. The alliance first demanded a vote recount and later a redo of the election and the formation of a special committee under the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan to investigate the March 19 shooting that slightly injured Chen and Lu.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTELLIGENCE UNIT MUM OVER REPORTS ABOUT BEIJING SPY CRACKDOWN

TEXT.P: The Military Intelligence Bureau (MIB) stayed buttoned up Thursday amid reports from Hong Kong that Beijing cracked down on a Taiwan spy ring before the March 20 presidential election, arresting several officers of the People's Liberation Army.

An anonymous MIB officer said his bureau was perusing the report and has not yet figured out why the reports claim that the People's Liberation Army officers supposedly detained by Beijing for unknown reasons were spying for Taiwan.
