DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER CHAIRS CHANGEOVER CEREMONY AT NPA HEADQUARTERS

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Su Jia-Chyuan presided Thursday over a changeover ceremony in which Shieh Yin-tang took over the post from Chang Shi-liang to become the nation's highest-ranking police officer.
Hsieh became the director-general of the National Police Administration (NPA) after taking over the official seals from Su and Chang at the ceremony held at the NPA headquarters.

Su thanked Chang for his contributions in the post over the past nine months and encouraged Shieh to do his best to improve public order, particularly in taking effective measures to clamp down on the rampant Internet and cell phone fraud rings.
Shieh was formerly Chang's deputy and has also served as head of the Kaohsiung Municipal Police Department.

Chang, the shortest-serving NPA chief, offered to step down and applied for retirement to assume responsibility for the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, who suffered slight injuries during a campaign rally in southern Tainan City.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUPPORTERS OF RIVAL CAMPS URGED TO SHOW RESTRAINT DURING INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou urged supporters of the "pan-green camp" and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" Thursday to exercise self-restraint during the May 20 inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian.
Ma made the remarks in response to suggestions by city councilors from the opposition New Party that the central government should change the venue of the inauguration ceremony.

The Presidential Office has planned a 500,000-strong celebration rally in the square in front of the Presidential Office and has asked Taipei city government to block off the roads in the surrounding area for five consecutive days.
Councilors Lee Chin-yuan, Fei Hung-tai, Chang Chung-tien and Pan Fai-chung raised questions at the Taipei City Council about the Presidential Office's request.

They said the area proposed for traffic control is too big and the period is too long, which will affect the lives of Taipei citizens. In addition, the inauguration could also trigger protests from the "pan-blue alliance " that the police might not be able to handle.

They asked for "a truce" between the "pan-green" and "pan-blue" camps and expressed hope that Ma will suggest in an Executive Yuan meeting that the venue of the inauguration be changed to within the Presidential Office or to Linkou Stadium in suburban Taipei.

The mayor said that he favors a "true, " peaceful and rational activity. He said that if there are clashes at the president's inauguration ceremony, they will have an adverse effect on Taiwan's future.

He urged restraint from both the ruling and opposition camps, although he pointed out that the venue of the inauguration is not for the city to decide. He said that he will communicate as much as possible and cut the impact on traffic to the minimum.

Councilman Han also said that he will propose in next week's city council meeting that Ma and City Council Speaker Wu Pi-chu decline invitations to attend the inauguration ceremony unless "the truth" of the March 20 presidential election is unveiled.
"If the city council adopts a resolution, whether it is binding or not, I'll give it serious consideration," Ma said.

Supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" have staged several big rallies, the latest one April 10 ending in violence, against what they perceive as an "unfair" election marred by voting irregularities and the election-eve shooting of Chen, which they said swayed the bitterly contested election in his favor.
Chen won by a narrow margin of 29,518 votes out of more than 13 million cast against Lien Chan of the "pan-blue alliance."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Sept. 11 Panel Cites C.I.A. for Failures in Terror Case.
An interim report by the Sept. 11 panel's staff offered a stinging assessment of the C.I.A. was made public during a hearing at which Mr. Tenet, the director of central intelligence since 1997, disclosed that he had little contact with President Bush during much of the summer of 2001, a period when intelligence agencies were warning of a dire terrorist threat.
Mr. Tenet testified that he had no contact at all with Mr. Bush in August, the month in which the president received a C.I.A. report suggesting that terrorists of Al Qaeda were already in the United States and might be planning a domestic airplane hijacking.
Wall Street Journal: With '80s Tactics, U.S. Fund Shakes Japan's Cozy Capitalism.
"U.S. Fund On Wild Rampage, " declared a headline in a Japanese news magazine. A U.S. fund's takeover attempt of two Japanese companies has caused more than 200 other companies, many fearing that they may be next, to increase their own dividends in the past three months. Some also are scurrying to investm ent bankers and securities lawyers for advice on avoiding a potential takeover.
The uproar signals the arrival in Japan of American-style capitalism and the loud voice it gives shareholders. As in the U.S. in the 1980s when hostile takeovers and corporate raiders thrived, a lot of executives are decrying the development as a destabilizing force, fearing it puts too much power in the hands of financiers looking for a short-term payday. On the other hand, as in the U.S., it could spur companies to be more efficient and accountable.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE INVESTMENTS NEEDED FOR PUBLIC CONSTRUCTION: VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i has urged government departments involved with public construction projects to attract private investments to meet the NT$100 billion (US$3.03 billion) goal a year, according to officials of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

Lin requested various departments at a meeting on the promotion of private participation in public construction projects Wednesday to map out public construction projects in 2005 for private investments while planning yearly budgets, said the officials, adding that those projects will be scheduled under the Executive Yuan's mid-term programs.

According to the Executive Yuan's statistics, the CEPD officials said, out of the 13 cases with contracts already signed, private investments stood at NT$15.3 billion. Among the 15 cases still being processed, private investments had reached NT$23.6 billion, the official continued, adding that a total of 15 cases are still open for bidding; however, they are expected to rake in private investments of up to NT$42.9 billion

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA URGES ROC CITIZENS TO AVOID IRAQ OVER SECURITY CONCERNS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has issued a travel advisory against Iraq because of the mounting insurgency there, a senior MOFA official said Thursday.

"Iraq has been listed as a highly dangerous area in which to travel, " MOFA's West Asian Affairs Department Deputy Director Lin Chin-chung said, adding that local people should not travel to Iraq for the time being.

Lin said the MOFA has crafted a three-level travel warning system for countries that have bad public order, an unstable political situation, backward infrastructure construction and terrorist activities. Under the system, a yellow color means a low-level travel warning, orange means medium-level and red means extremely dangerous. Lin said Iraq falls in the highest-tier category.
In recent weeks, Lin said, many foreign civilians, including humanitarian relief workers, have been kidnapped by Iraqi insurgents and most of those hostages remain unaccounted for.

Quoting MOFA intelligence reports, Lin said that as the United States is scheduled to return governing power to the Iraqi people by June 30, various Iraqi political factions have stepped up preparations to gain power. Many of them have kidnapped foreigners to use as bargaining chips in negotiations with the 12 countries that have deployed peacekeeping forces in Iraq.

Noting that the Iraq situation is not expected to stabilize in the near future, Lin advised local people not to go to Iraq for the time being. No Taiwan expatriates live in Iraq at the moment, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES OPPOSITION LEADERS TO FACE DEFEAT SQUARELY

TEXT.P: The leaders of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (DPP) should have the courage to face the truth and the fact that it lost the March 20 election, an official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Thursday.

Lee Ying-yuan, DPP vice secretary-general, made the remarks after KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong said that they would not attend the May 20 inauguration ceremony of President Chen Shui-bian, who won by only 29,518 votes out of more than 13 million ballots cast.
Lien and Soong were running for president and vice president as an alliance of their parties.

Instead, Lien and Soong reaffirmed that the government should establish an independent committee before May 20 to look into the election-eve shooting of President Chen, which left him lightly injured and which they deemed unfairly swayed the bitterly contested election in Chen's favor.

Lee said that in past elections, if the DPP lost an election, the party chairman would take responsibility, compared with the KMT's approach, which reviews its grass-root support and its decision-making process.

He noted that the DPP respects the difference of various political parties, but he said that, "As party leaders, they should be close to the people's will, " adding that they "should have the courage to face the truth, " and that when legislators demand that the defeat be accepted squarely, they should not shift the focus. Lien recently began a series of meetings with KMT legislators to review the election result and discuss the year-end legislative elections.

Noting that world-renowned forensics expert Dr. Henry Lee had concluded that the president sustained gunshot wounds on the eve of the election, he urged Lien and Soong to accept the fact that the shooting was not fake as some claimed in an attempt to win last-minute sympathy votes.

Lien and Soong should learn a lesson from President Chen when he lost to Ma Ying-jeou in the Taipei City mayoral election in 1998, during which time Chen appealed to his supporters to throw their support behind the elected Ma, Lee said.

Lee's remarks followed that of Tseng Wen-tsang, a DPP deputy director in charge of party promotion, who said that both Lien and Soong had been invited to attend the inauguration and urged the two to show "grace" in attending.
Lien and Soong ran separately against Chen in the three-way presidential election in 2000, and both failed to show up at his inauguration ceremony after the defeat.

DOC.HEADLINE: HENRY LEE TO MAKE FOLLOW-UP REPORT ON SHOOTING OF PRESIDENT SOON

TEXT.P: World-renowned forensics expert Dr. Henry Lee is expected to give a follow-up report on the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said Thursday.

Lee, who visited Taiwan April 9-11 and examined the wounds of the president and vice president, visited the scene of the shooting and the Chi Mei Medical Center in Tainan, southern Taiwan, gave a preliminary report before his departure.
Lee then brought back the information he collected to his Connecticut laboratory for further analysis.
CIB officials said that Lee could make his follow-up report Sunday morning Taipei time.

Lee set up a re-enactment of the shooting in Tainan focusing on the trajectory of the bullet, the speed of the vehicle carrying the president and vice president and the possible "hot zone" where the shooter would have been likely located.

Before leaving Taiwan, Lee confirmed that the president and the vice president sustained gunshot wounds and the bullet was shot from outside the open-top jeep that the president was riding in on the eve of the March 20 presidential election, dashing the claims by some political pundits that the shooting was faked to win last-minute sympathy votes.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" has held a series of rallies, the latest one on April 10 that ended violently, since the March 20 election to protest what they perceived as an "unfair election, " which it said was marred by voting irregularities and the shooting, which it claimed swayed the bitterly contested election in President Chen's favor.
Chen won by only 29,518 out of more than 13 million votes cast, against his rival, Lien Chan.

State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa invited Lee to come to Taiwan, hoping that his expertise would help shed more light on the case and end the controversy. Police still have no suspects and few if any major leads in the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA PAYING HEED TO UPGRADE EXPORT QUALITY OF FISH

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) has taken steps to tighten control over chemical residuals in certain domestically raised fish to upgrade quality and increase exports, a spokesman for the COA said Thursday.

Setting its sight on the locally raised mouth breeders, a common and popular fish in Taiwan, the COA's Fisheries Administration called a meeting a day earlier in southern Chiayi County to discuss the issue, the spokesman said.

Experts from the government, the academic sector and mouth breeder raisers from Chiayi, Tainan and Yunlin areas got together to mull measures and a development strategy for business, the spokesman added.

It was decided at the meeting that the COA will set up a national tracking system to monitor the quality of the country's fisheries exports through the whole process, covering upstream to processors and distributors in the middle stream and foreign traders in downstream, an official from the Chiayi County government said.

At the same time, authorities will also educate local fish raisers to increase their knowledge and know-how over the correct use of chemicals and collect more samples from local fishery ponds, he added.

About half of Taiwan's 85,000 metric tons of mouth breeders were exported last year, but its outbound shipments to the European Union were detected by EU authorities to have contained chemical substances, dealing a heavy blow to local fish raising businesses which are clustered mainly in central and southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE-AMERICAN TECHNOLOGY MEN WANT REST OF DONATION GOING TO CHARITY
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angles, April 14 (CNA) (By Lu-sheng Chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Two successful Chinese-American entrepreneurs in technology said Wednesday that any money that they have donated to cover the expenses of recounting the presidential votes in Taiwan that is left over should go to charity to promote ethnic harmony.

John Tu and David Sun, co-founders of Kingston Technology Corp., one of the leading memory module manufacturers in the world, decided to donate NT$100 million (US$3.03 million) earlier this week to help pay for the recount of the March 20 presidential election, hoping to end the controversy soon so that society can return to normal.

Sun and Tu, after learning from the Central Election Commission that the recount would cost about NT$31.1 million, spoke through Hsu Sheng-chang, the company's vice president of technology, and instructed him to earmark the money above that needed for the recount to go to charities, especially to those that will promote ethnic harmony.
Hsu said that the donation aims to bring the election disputes to a swift conclusion.

"Ethnic groups have been divided after the election, and the generosity and forbearance among the people has been destroyed, but with the passage of the time, the wounds should be healed through tolerance and rationality," Hsu said.

Sun and Tu lamented that although nearly one month has passed since the presidential election, which saw President Chen Shui-bian win another four-year term by a small margin against Lien Chan of the opposition "pan-blue alliance, " controversy has continued over the result.

Supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" have staged several large protest rallies against what they perceived as an "unfair election" which they claimed was marred by voting irregularities and the election-eve shooting of President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu. The latest rally on April 10 ended in violence.

The protestors demanded a ballot recount as well as the establishment of an independent committee to investigate the shooting that they said swayed the election in Chen's favor. Although both candidates agreed to a recount, they remain differed on who should pay for it, with the ruling "pan-green camp" saying that Lien's alliance, which ask for the recount in the first place, should foot the bill, while the latter wants the government to pay.
Sun said that the NT$100 million is a non-political donation and has nothing to do with his pro- "pan-blue alliance" sentiments.

Sun and Tu became millionaires when they sold a large chunk of their memory chip-making company in 1996 and made headlines and envy of every company employee worldwide when they decided to share US$100 million of the windfall with workers, roughly 450 at the time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES PLUNGE

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices snapped a three-session winning streak Thursday, closing 2.1 percent lower on profit-taking after a strong rally a day earlier.

The weighted price index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange, the market's key barometer, lost 143.39 points to close at 6,736.79 on a market turnover of NT$ 199.33 billion (US$6.03 billion) . More than 7.62 billion shares changed hands during the trading session.
Thursday's drop more than erased the previous day's gains, but market analysts said high trading volumes over the past few days indicate tthat he bourse is consolidating ahead of its next leap.
Losers outnumbered gainers 686 to 189, while 94 issues ended the day unchanged.

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down 2.3 percent; foodstuff stocks down 3 percent; plastics and chemical shares down 0.7 percent; cement shares down 2.8 percent; construction stocks down 3.5 percent; pulp and paper issues down 1.5 percent; bank and insurance shares down 2.1 percent, and textile stocks down 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN HAS PUT FAMILY ASSETS INTO TRUST: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has honored his campaign promise of putting his family assets into trust, Presidential Office spokesman James Huang said Thursday.
Chen promised on the campaign trail that he would put his family assets into blind trust after the March 20 presidential election.
Huang said Chen's accountant and lawyer already finalized initial preparatory work and entrusted Chen's assets to a local bank's trust department Wednesday.

"The president's accountant will brief the press on the trust amount, trust company and relevant management terms later this month, " Huang said, adding that as asset trust involves a lot of detailed professional knowledge, he is not in a position to address the details regarding Chen's asset trust contract.

Responding to press reports that first lady Wu Shu-chen failed to report a January stock trading deal to the Control Yuan's public functionaries asset declaration department, Huang said the unintentional omission was mainly caused by an accountant's negligence.
Huang said Wu has not engaged in stock trading since Jan. 16. The undeclared stock trading deal of NT$21.46 million was struck before Jan. 16.

"Because of staff changes at the accountant's office, the deal was not reported to the Control Yuan. The accountant has confessed to the fault, " Huang said, adding that the accountant would report the deal to the Control Yuan later in the day.

According to the Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law, senior officials and their spouses who conduct stock trading worth more than NT$10 million within two months must report it to the Control Yuan, the nation's supreme watchdog body.

In the run-up to the presidential election, the first lady's stock trading activities came under fire. President Chen acknowledged that even though Taiwan has not enacted a law to ban the first lady from trading stocks, such activities were inappropriate. He made a public apology for his wife's stock trading activities and promised to put his family assets into blind trust after the March 20 presidential election.

On Monday, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) proposed a package of revisions to the Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law that would require the president and other senior officials to put their assets into blind trust.

According to the TSU-drafted revision package, the president, vice president, as well as presidents of the five yuans, and other senior political appointees should put their family assets into blind trust. The assets to be put into trust cover those owned by the public functionaries themselves as well as those owned by their spouses and underage children.
It remains unclear when the Legislature will begin screening this revision bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 15, or the 26th day of the leap second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1865: Andrew Johnson is sworn in as the 17th president of the United States following the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.
1912: The British luxury liner the Titanic sinks after hitting an iceberg during its maiden voyage to New York. More than 1,500 people are feared drowned in the icy waters of the North Atlantic.
1923: Insulin is made available for general use by diabetics when Canadian physiologist Sir Frederick Grant Banting shares a 1923 Nobel Prize for the discovery of insulin.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces, organizes the Republic of China government in Nanjing.
1942: Japanese artillery blasts U.S. positions on Corregidor in the Philippines.
1945: Art treasures looted by the Nazis, including paintings by Rubens, Goya, Raphael, and Leonardo da Vinci, are found in an Austrian mine shaft.
1949: The Chinese communists demand ROC government acceptance of their eight-point proposal by April 20, following talks which began in Beijing on April 5.
1952: U.S. President Harry S. Truman signs a peace treaty between the United States and Japan.
1958: The first meeting of independent African nations is held in Accra, Ghana.
1959: U.S. Secretary of State John Dulles resigns due to illness. The American diplomat and politician pursued a policy of opposition to the USSR largely through military and economic aid to American allies.
1966: A team of American virologists develops a vaccine for German measles, known medically as rubella.
1971: President Joseph Desire Mobutu of Congo and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1971: London and Beijing agree to the reopening of a telephone link between London and Shanghai which had been closed for 22 years.
1975: Praising the late ROC President Chiang Kai-shek as "an old friend and a great leader," Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller of the United States arrives in Taipei to attend the National Memorial Services for the generalissimo.
1975: ROC Premier Chiang Ching-kuo reveals President Chiang's last written instruction to him. The late leader told his eldest son to assume full responsibility for the fate of the nation without regard to his personal fate.
1976: India and Communist China resume diplomatic relations.
1976: Dr. Alfredo Lamaison, a member of the State Council of Uruguay, and Arg Gustave Nicolich, president of National University, arrive in Taipei for a nine-day visit.
1980: Jean-Paul Sartre, the French writer and philosopher who declined the 1957 Nobel Prize for literature, dies in Paris at the age of 74. A leading existentialist, he wrote literary works such as the autobiographical novel "Nausea" and the play "No Exit," as well as philosophical volumes that include "Being and Nothingness."
1988: President Kim Il Sung receives 43,000 gifts as he celebrates his 76th birthday in style. The North Korean dictator died in 1994.
1989: Hu Yaobang, former general secretary of China's Communist Party, dies of a heart attack in Beijing at the age of 73. A democracy movement is launched by Beijing University students following his death.
1989: Ninety-five soccer fans are crushed to death and 200 injured at Sheffield's Hillsborough Stadium in Britain's worst-ever sports disaster.
1994: The Uruguay Round of talks on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) concludes with ministers from more than 100 of the world's trading nations signing the GATT pact, the biggest market-opening treaty in history, and also with the announcement of the setting up of the World Trade Organization (WTO).
1996: The United States and Japan announce the closure of six more U.S. military facilities on Okinawa.
1997: The first locally-developed Ching Kuo tactical combat aircraft wing, a second generation ROC Air Force warplane, is founded at the Chingchuankang air force base in Taichung.
1998: Pol Pot, former Khmer Rouge leader, dies of a heart attack.
2000: Republic of China Defense Minister Tang Fei, who has been designated as the next premier by President-elect Chen Shui-bian, checks into Veterans General Hospital to undergo a thymoma operation.
2001: At least four persons are killed and more than 40 injure in an accident involving two buses near Encore Garden in Taichung, central Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man looks upwards in his aspirations; a fool looks downwards."

DOC.HEADLINE: REMAKING SINGAPORE COMMITTEE DECLARES ITSELF PROUD OF ACHIEVEMENTS

TEXT.P: Nine months after its report to the government, the Remaking Singapore Committee on Thursday declared itself proud to have played "midwife" to a bundle of policy changes.

Of the 74 proposals the committee made last July, aimed mainly at relaxing rules in many spheres of life in the city-state, 60 have received a nod from the government, while two are still under review, and the remaining 12 have been rejected.

"I think Singapore needed to change, and Singapore has changed, and it will need to continue changing, " said Minister of State for National Development Vivian Balakrishnan, who serves as the chairman of the Remaking Singapore Committee
"I was more keen on making sure that the avenues and the stimulus for change and the signals for change continue to be heard, and the ability to change continues within the government," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO NOMINATE 92 CANDIDATES FOR LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will nominate 92 candidates of constituencies for the December's legislative elections, a DPP official said Friday.

Lee Ying-yuan, deputy secretary-general of the DPP, said that the party's candidate nomination and campaign strategy panel for the legislative elections set the figure at a meeting held earlier the same day.

Lee said that the number will not be subject to a conspicuous change in the future and that he told this to Huang Chu-wen, chairman of Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), which is the DPP's political ally.

Although President Chen Shui-bian won his re-election in the March 20 presidential election by obtaining more than 6.47 million votes, or 50.12 percent of the total and 1.5 million votes over the amount he got four years ago, Lee noted that the DPP will take a conservative manner in nominating candidates for legislators by taking its real political resources into consideration.

The DPP is expected to win at least 80 seats for legislators of constituencies based on the election rate of the last legislative elections in 2001, for which the DPP nominated 83 candidates of constituencies, Lee said.

If this is the case, he added, the DPP will seize at least 20 seats of legislators-at-large which will be elected proportionally with the number of votes obtained by political parties in the elections.

Based on the estimation, he went on, the DPP and the TSU that is expected to win more seats in the year-end legislative elections than the 13 it has now in the legislature, will certainly control more than half of the 225 seats in the legislature after the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MINISTERS VOW TO CHECK RAMPANT FRAUD, HOAX KIDNAPPINGS

TEXT.P: Two Cabinet ministers unanimously vowed Friday to curb the rampant acts of fraud and hoax kidnappings in a move underlining the government's determination to fight crime.

Speaking at a conference of the country's senior prosecutors in Hsinchu City, northern Taiwan, Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan called law enforcement officials in the country to launch an all-out fight against the fraud and hoax kidnappings.
He suggested the prosecutors of the nation prosecute offenders of these crime as "rogues" who are punishable by heavier sentences under a special law.
Coincidentally, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan made similar remarks during a visit to the Criminal Investigation Bureau in Taipei Friday morning.

Flanked by the newly appointed national police chief, Hsieh Yin-tang, Su urged the police of the country to make curbing fraud as their top priority, saying that many of his friends have fallen victim to this widespread crime.
In a common set-up, the fraudsters will pretended to be tax men calling the victim by phone, asking them to use their ATM card to take their tax returns.
If the victims fall for this, they will actually transfer their money to a bank account used by the fraudsters.

Also, fraudsters will pose as hospital workers asking people by phone to transfer money to a bank account "because their family members were in the hospital's intensive care ward after a traffic accident." Imprudent people transferred the money via ATM machines and rushed to the hospital only to find that it was a hoax.
The pretext used by the fraudsters also includes hoax kidnapping.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMPANIES HAVE CHANCE TO PARTICIPATE IN REBUILDING IRAQ

TEXT.P: The U.S. Department of Commerce is offering chances to Taiwan companies at a symposium in Seoul called to apprise Asian companies of the business opportunities in rebuilding Iraq, according to the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).

An anonymous TAITRA official said there are only 28 placements for Taiwan businessmen to attend the April 28 symposium in Seoul, and those companies that are interested should contact the TAITRA before April 23.

Citing estimates made by American research institutes, the official said Iraq is 30 years behind its neighboring states in infrastructure, and will need US$35.81 billion for reconstruction between 2004 and 2007.

This includes US$12.12 billion for the electricity-supplying system, US$7.19 billion for medical care and education, US$6.84 billion for the water-supplying system and garbage disposal, US$3.4 billion for transportation and telecommunications, US$3.02 billion for agriculture and US$1.83 billion for housing and municipal administration, the official said.

There is virtually no chance for ordinary countries to have a finger in the pie of rebuilding Iraq except for the Western powers or those who have chipped in with forces in the U.S.-led military attack against Iraq, said the official.

The only chance for Taiwan firms is to bid on the subcontracts farmed out by the prime contractors, and the Seoul symposium is aimed at offering companies in Asia opportunities to join in Iraqi construction as subcontractors.

During the symposium, the participants can understand their chances of landing subcontracts, familiarize themselves with the bidding process, and meet with the U.S. prime contractors that are trying to outsource their contract works.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTMENT FLOCKING TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Foreign investment continued flocking to Taiwan in recent weeks despite the fact that political woes over the disputed March 20 presidential election are not yet over, government authorities reported Friday.

The Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs made the report after having approved capital worth a total of US$412 million funneled by four famous multinationals into their Taiwan investment plans in a meeting held earlier the same day -- the first of its kind in the wake of the presidential election.

The figure is about the level of the US$468 million worth of foreign capital channeled into Taiwan during the period between late February 20 and April 4, a spokesman for the commission said, adding that it is an indication that the willingness of foreign investors in the domestic market has not been affected by the current political situation at home.

One among the five foreign companies was the Germany-based Infineon Technologies Holding B. V., which put US$124 million in capital investment into a company funded by Infineon, while the Sweden-based Aktiebolaget Skf put an additional US$42 million into its affiliate in Taiwan, the spokesman said.
An application by a Hong Kong-based company to inject capital worth NT$75 million for its Taiwan operations was also approved, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATOR URGES PRESIDENT TO WORK TO DEFUSE ETHNIC DIVISIONS

TEXT.P: An outspoken legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged President Chen Shui-bian Friday to "do something" to rein in worsening ethnic divisions and disharmony in the wake of the March 20 presidential election.
Shen Fu-hsiung, a physician-turned-lawmaker, made the appeal at a news conference, dubbed the "love Taiwan presentation."

Noting that he is convinced that an overwhelming majority of local residents love Taiwan, Shen said the DPP should not make "love Taiwan" its campaign theme or platform for the year-end legislative election.
"All politicians, particularly DPP members, should refrain from taking advantage of this topic," Shen urged.

As a ruling party, Shen went on, the DPP should not use differences over policy toward mainland China, feelings toward mainland China and the time of immigration from mainland China as standards to measure whether an individual person loves Taiwan or not.

Since there is not an objective and scientific method to gauge the depth and breadth of "love for Taiwan," Shen said, the DPP should not bring up this topic in its campaign literature or rallies in the run-up to the December legislative elections.

"As the DPP chairman, President Chen is obligated to 'do something' to mend ethnic divisions which have become very serious after the presidential election, " Shen said, adding that Chen should order all party members intending to run in the year-end legislative elections to refrain from campaigning on a "love Taiwan" platform and from bringing up ethnic issues.

During the presidential campaign, Chen often assured voters that he wouldn't cave in to Beijing, and he often questioned his sole challenger Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's willingness to stand up to Beijing. Some observers feel that political and ethnic divisions have become even more serious after Taiwan-born Chen narrowly defeated mainland China-born Lien.

Except for a small group of aboriginal tribes, most of Taiwan's 23 million people are ethnic Chinese. But the population can be divided into two sub-ethnic groups: the "mainlanders" whose families fled to Taiwan when the Chinese Communists took over the mainland in 1949, and the "native Taiwanese" whose ancestors began arriving on the island in the 17th century or earlier.

The mainlanders, about 15 percent of the population, have largely supported the opposition KMT and its ally, the People First Party, and their support base is in northern Taiwan. The native Taiwanese control the south, and they tend to favor Chen's DPP and the smaller Taiwan Solidarity Union.
The mainlanders have traditionally supported eventual unification with mainland China, while the native Taiwanese lean more toward formal independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC MINISTRY HELPS DOMESTIC CARGO CARRIERS TO USE INTERNET

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs is pushing local cargo carriers to use the Internet to reduce their operational costs.

Noting that the cost of cargo transportation accounts for 17 percent to 18 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP) , compared to 14 percent to 15 percent in advanced countries, the officials of the ministery said the more the cost of cargo transportation as apercentage of the GDP, the less competitive is the whole industry.

Furthermore, the officials said, government statistics show that foreign firms made up 15 of the top 20 air carriers in Taiwan in 2001, with a market share of 77 percent between them, which means local cargo carriers need to strengthen their competitiveness and expand their operational scale with the government's aid and guidance.

As a way of remedying the situation, the officials said the ministry has contracted the Taipei Computer Association to help domestic cargo carriers make good use of the Internet for business, which will significantly reduce their operational costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE SETS UP TASK FORCE TO OVERSEE PUBLIC TRANSPORT SECURITY

TEXT.P: The Singapore government has set up a high-level ministerial committee to ensure maximum security of the public transport system after the Madrid train bombings last month.
Transport Minister Yeo Cheow Tong said Thursday that establishing the committee reflects the government's concerns over the continuing terror threat that Singapore faces.

The Madrid train bombings last month which killed 202 people reinforced the need for increased security on public transport systems, Yeo told a media briefing after reviewing on site safety measures at an MRT station.

Some of the more visible measures already implemented by the committee include putting up posters at subway stations urging commuters to alert authorities of any suspicious items or bags, and the broadcasting of similar messages over the public announcement system at subway stations.
Public transport operators will also be required to place uniformed security guards at strategic locations.
Yeo said the committee, which will include officials from the defense, home affairs and transport ministries, will operate on an ongoing basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTBOUND TRAVELERS DECLINE OVER SARS, TERRORIST ATTACKS

TEXT.P: The number of outbound travelers declined by more than one million in 2003 from the previous year because of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreaks and the 911 terrorist attacks in 2001, government sources said Friday.
According to statistics compiled by the National Police Administration (NPA) , Taiwan citizens made 5.92 million overseas visits in 2003, down 1.32 million from the year-earlier level.

The number of travelers to Hong Kong and Macau -- major transit stops for mainland China-bound visitors -- as well as those to Japan, North America and Southeast Asian countries all registered negative growth, NPA tallies showed.

As Hong Kong, Macau and mainland China were all gripped by SARS between March and June last year, the number of Taiwan travelers to those regions dropped to 2.7 million from 3.6 million registered in 2002.

Partly because of the 911 terrorist attacks, NPA officials said, the number of Taiwan visitors to Southeast Asia declined to 1.2 million from 2002's 1.5 million; the number of travelers to Japan fell to 730,000 from 2002's 800,000; and the number of North America-bound visitors dropped to 570,000 from 2002's 660,000.

South Korea was the only exception. The number of Taiwan visitors to South Korea jumped from 120,000 in 2002 to 180,000 last year mainly because of the rising popularity of South Korean soap operas among local TV audiences, NPA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Q1 PRODUCTION VALUE OF BASIC METAL INDUSTRY SETS NEW HIGH: REPORT

TEXT.P: Fueled by soaring prices of steel goods at home and abroad, the output value of Taiwan's basic metal industry set a new quarterly high of NT$298.9 billion (US$9.05 billion) for the first three months of this year, according to a report made public Friday.

The figure represents an annual 20.7 percent growth rate and it will further pick up in the fourth quarter after hovering around the first quarter level in the second and third quarters, reported the Industrial Technology Information Service (ITIS), a project funded by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Standing firm on the rebounding trend since 2002, the world's steel industry put out a total of 970 billion tons of crude steel last year, up by 7.53 percent from the 2002 level, the report said.

In Taiwan, the overall production value of its basic metal industry totaled NT$1.075 trillion in 2003, marking an annual growth rate of 19.9 percent, according to the report. It forecasts that its 2004 production value will increase by 18 percent to NT$1.264 trillion.

Taiwan out put 9.43 million tons of steel in the first quarter, only up by 0.4 percent over the previous year's level. Its 2004 full-year production level is predicted at 38.62 million tons, a 1 percent annual increase rate.

The ITIS estimates that Taiwan's steel businesses will reap a handsome earning this year thanks to voracious demand from both the domestic and foreign markets, especially that from mainland China in the fourth quarter.

The price of steel products has markedly soared in the international market since December 2001 until now, except for last year when severe acute respiratory syndrome and the United States-led war against Iraq broke out in the first half.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITALIAN MISSIONARY WINS MEDICAL AWARD

TEXT.P: Chech Felice, vice president of St. Mary's Hospital in the northeastern Taiwan county of Ilan, has won this year's government-sponsored Medical Award for his dedicated services to local underprivileged people.

The Italian Catholic father came to Taiwan 33 years ago at the age of 28. He first worked in Taiwan's island county of Penghu for six years and then came to work at St. Mary's Hospital in Ilan's Lotung township.

Over the past 27 years, Felice has actively promoted community preventive medical services and cared for aboriginal and disadvantaged people in the Ilan area where agriculture, fishing and tourism form the backbone of the economy.
Felice recalled that he has followed the lead of many other missionaries of the Order of the Ministers of the Sick, also known as the Camillians to work in remote and backward areas.
"Before my arrival, many of my Camillian colleagues had already worked in Penghu and Ilan to help improve local people's lives, public health and medical services," Felice said.
Since his arrival in the coastal town of Lotung, Felice said he has devoted much energy in promoting community preventive medical services.
Felice organized a medical team to offer door-to-door medical services for those who were unable to go to hospital to see a doctor.
"No matter how far away or how difficult to reach a patient may be, we try to show our concern and offer them attentive medical treatment," Felice said.
Over the years, Felice has also led medical teams to offer free physical checkups, including blood pressure, blood sugar and cervical tests, in residential communities around Ilan County.

In view of the insufficient medical resources in the Ilan area, Felice has spent a great deal of time raising funds for building a new medical center at St. Mary's Hospital to treat patients of serious diseases. Thanks to his strenuous efforts, construction on the center began early this year and the new center is scheduled to be inaugurated by 2007.

The 61-year-old missionary said he has made medical services a personal hobby. "I have found great interest in offering medical services for needy people and over the past decades I have overcome numerous difficulties in accomplishing my job as a religious preacher and medical volunteer," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW FOREIGN AFFAIRS MINISTER DESCRIBES HIS IDEAL U.S. REPRESENTATIVE

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Chen Tan-sun said Friday that it would be appropriate to finalize the selection of a new representative to the United States before the May 20 inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian.
Chen made the remarks after meeting with the media shortly after taking over the post from the outgoing foreign minister, Eugene Chien.

Chen noted that diplomatic work between Taiwan and the United States is important, saying that an ideal representative should have excellent language ability and social skills, as well as an understanding of American culture.

Asked about who will replace the incumbent representative, Chen Chien-jen, who has said that he will step down before May 20, Chen did not answer directly, pointing out that he had only been in the job for 10 minutes.
On reports that the government is eying Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen for the job, Chen said that he learned from reports that Tsai is not enthusiastic about the idea.
However, he added that there will be national leaders and foreign dignitaries attending the May 20 inauguration ceremony and that it would be best to have decided upon a candidate by that time.
As to whether Therese Shaheen, former chairwoman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), will be invited to the inauguration, he said that the "matter needs further study."

Shaheen, one of the most friendly AIT chairperson toward Taiwan, stepped down in early April amid reports that the Bush administration had ordered her dismissal after a long bout of policy disagreements and questions about her management ability at the institute.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.S. Open to a Proposal That Supplants Council in Iraq.
The Bush administration accepted on Thursday the outlines of a United Nations proposal to dissolve the Iraqi Governing Council installed last year by the United States and replace it with a caretaker government when Iraqi sovereignty is restored on July 1.
Administration officials said that the proposal by Lakhdar Brahimi, the special United Nations envoy in Iraq, to create a new government of prominent Iraqis had many details to be worked out, but that for now it was acceptable to President Bush.
Wall Street Journal: How Insurance Spat Further Frayed U.S.-French Ties.
In a highly humiliating move, the French government was recently forced to plead guilty in U.S. District Court in California to fraud in connection with French bank Credit Lyonnais's 12-year-old acquisition of the U.S. insurer. It was a costly admission: The plea negotiated with American prosecutors came with a $770 million fine -- the biggest criminal settlement in U.S. history.
Credit Lyonnais admitted it had circumvented laws barring it from owning a U.S. insurer by using a consortium of French investors to buy Executive Life and its ailing bond portfolio. When the bonds rebounded, the bank and French billionaire Francois Pinault reaped a $2.54 billion profit. France itself also was tarnished because a French government agency admitted it had helped cover up the fraud.
The case has tracked the steep decline in French-American relations during the Bush administration. Initially seen as an obscure affair, the dispute became so charged that it aggravated the rift between Paris and Washington opened by last year's diplomatic clash over Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HOPING TO KEEP VICE PREMIER, CABINET SECRETARY-GENERAL

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun is hoping that Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i and Executive Yuan Secretary-General Liu Shih-fang will be kept in their posts in the upcoming new Cabinet, the Executive Yuan spokesman said Friday.
Lin Chia-lung quoted the premier as saying that Lin, a business executive of a motor company before he was invited into the Cabinet, is a rare talent who would be difficult to replace.
The premier will also meet with Liu Saturday to try to persuade her to stay, Lin said.

Lin said that over the past two years, the Cabinet under the three leaders has operated smoothly, with Yu setting the course, Lin coordinating financial and economic affairs and Liu in charge of communication and implementation.

If Lin and Liu insist on leaving, the premier will respect their wishes, but in the future, the roles of the premier, vice premier and secretary-general will be to run the various work divisions and complementary principles in the most efficient manner possible, the spokesman said.

Asked if two other female Cabinet-level officials -- Council for Hakka Affairs Chairwoman Yeh Chu-lan and Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu -- will be promoted to vice premier positions to replace Lin if he insists on leaving, the spokesman said only that the premier will promote more female Cabinet members, giving them more power in the decision making process.
Lin's words came as the Cabinet prepares to resign en masse according to the Constitution prior to President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inauguration.
The interior minister and the foreign affairs minister have already been replaced, while National Defense Minister Tang Yiau-min has also expressed his wish to step down.

DOC.HEADLINE: DAUNTING VOTE RECOUNT BEGINS CRUCIAL STEP

TEXT.P: The daunting task of recounting the March 20 presidential election votes began a crucial step Friday after the rival camps presented name lists of their representatives that will take part in the recount process.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) presented the Taiwan High Court with the names of 312 lawyers, while President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu presented a list of around 400 lawyers.

Chiang Chi-chun, one of the "pan-blue alliance" lawyers, said that the alliance will provide additional lawyers in the next few days because the alliance cannot be sure if all lawyers will be able to go through the long counting process.
He estimated that if a recount team can tally 4,000 votes a day, it will take about 14 days to complete the recount of more than 13 million votes cast.

Lee Yi-kuang, the "pan-blue alliance" lawyer who presented the name list, also presented his views on the standard for verifying votes -- especially three stamp patterns that the Central Election Commission (CEC) has designated as "invalid" votes -- and expressed the hope that district courts will first list the contentious votes that the court can determine later.

Accounting to the prior consensus reached between the rival teams, each recount team of around eight people will comprise one lawyer or trainee lawyer from each of the rival teams, representatives from a district court (judge, court clerk, recording clerk or bailiff), and representatives from the CEC.
The Taiwan High Court will coordinate with the two rival teams on matters concerning the recount in the next few days.

Meanwhile, a Chinese-American entrepreneur who promised to donate NT$100 million (US$3.03 million) to pay for the vote recount so that post-election disputes could end quickly has decided to commission a private judicial reform committee to handle the money.

Representatives of David Sun, co-founder of Kingston Technology Corp., and the reform committee, signed a contract Friday stating that the committee will use the money after the High Court finalizes the details and expenses of the recount.
The KMT-PFP requested a judicial recount rather than an administration recount by the CEC because it distrusts the CEC, claiming that it wavered in the runup to the March 20 presidential election.

The recount is one of two demands by the "pan-blue alliance" since its candidate, Lien Chan, lost the election by a narrow margin of 29,518 to President Chen Shui-bian. The other demand is to nullify the presidential election.

Supporters of the alliance have since staged several often violent mass rallies to protest what they perceive as an "unfair election" marred by so-called voting irregularities and the election-eve shooting of Chen and his running mate, Vice President Annette Lu. The shooting swayed the election in Chen's favor, they claim.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW FOREIGN MINISTER OUTLINES VISION, AGENDA

TEXT.P: New Foreign Affairs Minister Chen Tan-sun said Friday he will uphold "three insistences" in performing his duty as the nation's diplomatic chief.

"The three insistences are maintaining our nation's sovereign status, maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and participating in international cooperative projects to fulfill our international obligations," Chen said at a changeover ceremony.

Chen, a U.S.-trained physicist who entered domestic politics after he returned to Taiwan in the early 1992 after working for almost 20 years in the United States, also said at the ceremony that he has long dreamed of integrating government and private resources to let the world know that there is an island country in the West Pacific called the Republic of China, which has stood firmly against giant communist China.

In the changeover ceremony, Chen took the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official seals from his predecessor, Eugene Chien, who resigned last week as a result of fallout surrounding the resignation of American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen, the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties.

Chen, who has been a legislator and two-term magistrate of the rural southern Taiwan county of Tainan, said that in the face of mainland China's suppression, Taiwan's diplomatic work is always fraught with tough challenges and difficulties.
"I'll exercise prudence in carrying out my mission, " Chen said, adding that he will use passion, energy and perseverance to fulfill his duties.

Chen further expounded on his insistence on maintaining Taiwan's sovereign integrity, stressing that after undergoing three direct presidential elections, as well as the first-ever transition of power between different political parties in 2000, Taiwan has become a "100 percent" democratic country.
With the deepening of democracy, Chen said, the people of Taiwan have reached a consensus on "Taiwan first" and on a Taiwanese identity.

During his stint as foreign affairs minister, Chen said he will do his utmost to promote Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and other major international organizations and non-government organizations (NGOs) , as well as working to upgrade Taiwan's international profile.

Noting that maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait is not only "Taiwan's insistence" but also a common policy in the international community, Chen said stable and peaceful cross-strait relations are critical to Northeast Asian and Southeast Asian security.

"Maintaining cross-strait peace and stability is not only in Taiwan's interest but also in the international interest," Chen said, adding that Taiwan will strengthen its security dialogues and cooperation with the United States, Japan and Southeast Asian countries in order to safeguard regional peace and prosperity.
Moreover, Chen said, Taiwan's democratic experience and achievements are precious assets for Taiwan to forge cooperative ties with major countries around the world.
"The MOFA-affiliated Taiwan Foundation for Democracy can be a good conduit for promoting international cooperation in democratic reform and development," he added.

In the future, Chen said, the MOFA will work to expand Taiwan's participation in international cooperative programs in the security, trade, economic and democratic development fields in order to contribute to world peace and prosperity.

Speaking on the same occasion, Chien noted that the heads of state of 12 of the ROC's diplomatic allies will travel to Taiwan to attend President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inauguration for a second four-year term.

"They will come here to witness Taiwan's progress in democratic development, " Chien said, adding that he is convinced that the MOFA will score even more diplomatic achievements under his successor's stewardship.
At the changeover ceremony, Chen presented a "diplomacy medal" to Chien in recognition of his contributions to the promotion of Taiwan's foreign relations during his two-year stint.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GDP TO GROW BY 5.4 PERCENT FOR 2004: ESCAP
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 16 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) will grow by 5.4 percent and 4.9 percent for 2004 and 2005, respectively, according to a report released Friday by the United Nations-affiliated Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (ESCAP).

According to the report, Taiwan's economy will perform better in these two years. The country's GDP increased by 3.3 percent in 2003, while mainland China and South Korea registered growth of 9 percent and 3 precent, respectively. The mainland's fast growth did not pay off the poorer ratios posted by Taiwan and South Korea last year, with the region's GDP averaging a ratio lower than the 2002 level of 6.4 percent.

In contrast, the overall outlook for economic development in the Asia-Pacific region this year is optimistic, the report says, adding that the economies of Taiwan and South Korea are steadily recovering but pointing out that political situations may affect their economic performance.

The economies in East Asia and Northeast Asia, including mainland China, Hong Kong, Mongolia, South Korea and Taiwan, will register an average GDP growth of 6.6 percent for 2004, with mainland China expected to outperform others with an 8.5 percent growth rate.

However, the report warns that continued snowballing financial deficits are an issue of major concern in the short term for countries in the region. A cumulative public debt will result in stronger pressure to push up key interest rates and lead to greater investment risks.
The ESCAP suggests that Asia-Pacific countries launch fiscal reform across the board to lower their debt levels in comparison with their GDP growth rates.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE MISSION TO VISIT SAUDI ARABIA IN MAY
DOC.DATELINE: Ankara, April 16 (CNA) (By Paul Kuo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A business and industrial mission from Taiwan is scheduled to visit Saudi Arabia from May 6 to promote bilateral economic ties, the English-language Arab News reported Friday.

The Taiwan business and industrial mission, to be comprised of executives from 43 manufacturing companies and officials from the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) and electrical and electronic business associations, will mainly take part in the 2004 GITEX computer expo scheduled to be held in Riyadh April 18-22.

The 2003 GITEX attracted some 70,000 visitors, TAITRA officials said, adding that the number of visitors to the show is expected to be larger this year as economies in the Middle East have been building up steam in general.

The Taiwan mission, which will also include traders and suppliers of rubber products, auto parts, furniture, construction materials, hardware and machinery, will also visit the west Saudi Arabian city of Jidda to explore export markets, including neighboring Iraq, according to the report.

Saudi Arabia is the largest market for information technology products in the Middle East, absorbing some US$4.6 billion-worth of IT products in 2003, which was 40 percent of the entire IT market in that part of the world the previous year.
Two-way trade between Taiwan and Saudi Arabia surged a whopping 69.12 percent in 2003 over the preceding year to reach US$4.64 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved down against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, losing NT$0.040 to close at NT$32.975.
A total of US$660 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$33.086 and slid to a low of NT$32.961.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market moved up Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April rose 79 points to close at 6,828, with 38,826 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May gained 82 points to end at 6,832, with 6,733 contracts traded, while June futures rose 126 points to end at 6,826, with 22 contracts finalized.
September futures gained 80 points to close at 6,849, with five contracts concluded, while December futures rose 35 points to end at 6,830, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,749 for April, 6,750 for May, 6,700 for June, 6,769 for September and 6,795 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also moved up.
April TE futures rose 3.05 points to close at 283.05, with 7,311 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained 3.5 points to end at 283.5, with 2,042 contracts transacted.
June TE futures rose 5.8 points to close at 284.8, with nine contracts finalized.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures rose 15 points to close at 1,055, with 10,508 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures gained 17 points to end at 1,056, with 4,152 contracts traded.
June TF futures lost 12 points at 1,050, with five contract transactions, while December TF futures gained 12.2 points to end at 1,064, with one contract finalized.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET MAY RESIGN EN MASSE AHEAD OF SCHEDULE: AIDE

TEXT.P: The Cabinet will resign en masse one or two weeks ahead of the originally scheduled date of May 12, Executive Yuan spokesman Lin Chia-lung said Friday.
The Cabinet headed by Premier Yu Shyi-kun was originally scheduled to resign en masse May 12 in line with constitutional precedents prior to the presidential inauguration.

President Chen Shui-bian, who won the hotly contested March 20 presidential election by a narrow margin of less than 30,000 votes out of more than 13 million ballots cast, will be sworn in for another four-year term May 20.
To allow the new Cabinet line-up enough time to get started, Lin said, Yu has proposed to Chen that the sitting Cabinet resign earlier than scheduled.
The new Cabinet will consequently be announced earlier too, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended the day higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 81.41 points to close at 6,818.2.
The bourse opened at 6,750.29 and fluctuated between 6,840.75 and 6,729.16 during trading.

A total of 7.17 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$184.91 billion (US$5.52 billion), a decrease from the previous day's trading session, which saw 7.62 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$199.33 billion.

Seven of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 2.4 percent, followed by foodstuff stocks at 1.7 percent, electrical shares and bank and insurance shares both at 1.6 percent, textile issues at 1 percent, construction stocks at 0.8 percent, and cement stocks at 0.2 percent.
Plastics and chemical shares, however, lost 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 575 to 222, with 173 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD RULES OUT POSSIBILITY OF SHORT-TERM INFLATIONARY PRESSURE

TEXT.P: Despite soaring commodity prices in the domestic market, there will be no problem of inflation in the short term, a spokesman for the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Friday.

Citing the results of an assessment carried out by the CEPD's Economic Research Department, the spokesman said that a 10 percent hike in steel prices will result in a 0.85 percent increase in commodity wholesale prices, particularly in the industrial sector. At the same time, a 10 percent price hike in petroleum-related products will lead to a 0.4 percent rise in consumer product prices, he added.

Although oil and steel prices have surged since the beginning of this year in Taiwan, the CEPD official said that the issue will only have a limited impact on domestic commodity prices and he ruled out the feasibility of inflation in the coming months.

But he called on the public not to speculate, especially on the prices of staple commodities, and said that the government will continue to closely monitor the price of retail packages of rice, soybeans and toilet paper to stop any unreasonable price jumps in the domestic market.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CLOSELY MONITORING REPORTED BEIJING SPY CRACKDOWN

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) will closely monitor developments in a reported new mainland Chinese crackdown on Taiwan espionage activities in mainland China, a senior official said Friday.

MAC Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong was responding to Hong Kong media reports that Beijing uncovered a Taiwan spy ring shortly before Taiwan's March 20 presidential election, arresting at least three Taiwan intelligence agents and several People's Liberation Army (PLA) officers.
Noting that intelligence work is basically strategic warfare, Chen said that media reports on the issue are usually not factual.

"We'll keep a close watch on whether the report has any political implications, " Chen said, adding that intelligence warfare often involves using various ploys and misinformation to divide or sow seeds of discord in the enemy camp.

According to the Hong Kong media reports, two senior PLA air force officers were arrested last month on charges of furnishing Taiwan with information about mainland China's new generation of Su-27 and Su-30 jetfighters and other military intelligence.

The Military Intelligence Bureau (MIB) under the Ministry of National Defense declined to comment on the reports, but an anonymous MIB officer said Thursday that his bureau was perusing them and has not yet worked out why the reports claim that senior PLA officers supposedly detained by Beijing were spying for Taiwan.
Mainland China arrested several Taiwanese businessmen late last year on charges of spying for Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HAS NO INTENTION TO AMEND TRA: STATE DEPARTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 15 (CNA) (By K.Y. Liu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A senior U.S. State Department press officer on Thursday reiterated that the U.S. government has no intention of amending the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) despite Beijing's requests that the act be abolished.
Adam Ereli, deputy spokesman of the State Department's Bureau of Public Affairs, made the comments while responding to media questions raised at the Foreign Press Center in Washington, D.C.
Mainland Chinese leaders appealed to U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney during his recent visit to Beijing that the U.S. administration should abrogate the TRA and cease arms sales to Taiwan.

Pointing out that the TRA is a U.S. law and that U.S. sales of defensive weapons to the island have proceeded under the framework of American law, the official said that the United States does not have any intention of altering the act.

In response to questions regarding the Taiwan leadership's intentions of amending the ROC Constitution by 2006, Ereli said that the U.S. administration has not discussed the issue with Taiwan's government nor received any explanation related to the issue from Taipei.
As to the Taiwan leadership's push to hold a referendum on a new constitution for the island by 2008, Ereli said that U.S. opposition to the island's holding of such a referendum remains unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY EXPECTED TO GROW 4.99 PERCENT FOR Q2

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy is expected to grow by 4.99 percent for the second quarter of this year, given that the domestic economy has continued to regain momentum, the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research (CIER) reported Friday.
The domestic economy registered brisk growth of 5.58 percent for the first quarter of this year, largely as a result of the strong recovery in the global economy, CIER President Chen Tian-jy said.

Chen said that since the beginning of this year, the global economy has witnessed several interesting developments, including the apparent rebounding of Japan's economy following ten years of stagnation.
Taiwan's economy, according to Chen, has begun to pick up steam since the third quarter of 2003, with its fourth quarter growth topping those of its "Asian Dragon" counterparts.
Taiwan's first quarter growth of 5.58 percent is the highest quarterly growth since the third quarter of 2000, Chen added.

Although second quarter growth will be strong, it is expected to be slightly lower than the previous quarter's because of the post-election social unrest which has been reflected in a volatile stock market. The volatile bourse has in turn adversely affected investors' confidence and consumers' willingness to spend, he added.

The CIER has estimated Taiwan's economic growth for the whole of 2004 at 4.26 percent. The figure could turn out to be higher if Taiwan's exports, particularly high-tech products, continue to boom in the months to come, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILAN GOVERNMENT REGISTERS TIAOYUTAIS AS PART OF TAIWAN TERRITORY

TEXT.P: Ilan County Government has recently formally registered the uninhabited Tiaoyutai island group as territory under the Republic of China's jurisdiction.

The registration, with the National Property Bureau, of the island group located some 200 kilometers east of Ilan's coast has caused concern in the local government of the southern Japanese island of Okinawa, which claims that the Tiaoyutais, known as the Senkaku Islands in Japan, are part of Japanese territory.

Ilan County Government officials said Friday that the registration was made in accordance with a Ministry of the Interior (MOI) plan, adding that if there are any disputes or controversies over the matter, they should be settled by the MOI or the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
The officials from the Ilan County Land Administration Office said the Ilan county government will respect any decisions made by the central government on the matter.
The Tiaoyutai islets, located between Taiwan and Okinawa, are claimed by Taiwan, mainland China and Japan.
China ceded the Tiaoyutai island group to Japan in 1895 at a time when the last Chinese imperial dynasty, the Qing dynasty, was in sharp decline and losing territory to aggressive foreign powers.

After World War II, the islands were put under U.S. control, at which time the ROC government demanded their return. In 1972, however, the United States returned the islands to the Japanese government -- a decision that governments and patriotic groups on both sides of the Taiwan Strait continue to protest.

The Ilan County Land Administration Office incorporated the Tiaoyutai islets under the jurisdiction of the Toucheng township government in the northeastern county of Ilan in February of this year to signify the ROC's sovereignty claim over the island group.

Responding to the Ilan county government's move, the Japanese government recently reiterated its sovereignty claim over the Tiaoyutai island group and submitted a written statement on the matter to the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs on April 14.

Yu Lien-hsing, director of the Ilan County Land Administration Office, said the Ilan government registered the Tiaoyutai islands under the county government's jurisdiction in accordance with regulations stipulated by the Ministry of the Interior.
Yu said he believes that if there are any international disputes or controversies over the island group, the MOI and the MOFA will handle the issue appropriately and through diplomatic channels.

According to Yu, the southern port city of Kaohsiung, when hosting the Taiwan Games in 1990, decided to include the Tiaoyutai islands as one of the stops in a nationwide torch relay. Current Premier Yu Shyi-kun, who was Ilan magistrate at that time, led the Ilan torch relay team to the Tiaoyutai islands and reclaimed Taiwan's sovereignty over the island group.

DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Japanese hostage trio freed in Iraq; Handover to Muslim clerics ends ntghtmare week at gunpoint.
Three Japanese civilians taken hostage last week by gunmen in Iraq were freed Thursday and arrived safely at the Japanese Embassy in Baghdad, government officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 869 LOST ROC CITIZENSHIP IN 2003

TEXT.P: A total of 869 people lost their Republic of China citizenship in 2003, up 6.7 percent from the year-earlier level, according to statistics released by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) Friday.

Most of those who lost their ROC citizenship did so as a result of acquiring citizenship in another Asian country, MOI tallies showed. A total of 479 were naturalized as Japanese, 106 became South Korean nationals, and 83 became Singaporean citizens. A further 69 were naturalized as Germans, and 51 became Americans.
By gender, 334 of those who lost their ROC citizenship last year were male and 535 were female.

In terms of reasons, 533 of those who lost their ROC citizenship did so to voluntarily gain citizenship in another country; 225 did so by being naturalized in a foreign country through marriage; and 105 were naturalized in another country along with their parents.

DOC.TEXT:
Bangkok Post:TRANSPORT / Subway evacuated as train brake fails.
Passengers were evacuated from Bangkok's first subway system yesterday after a train developed problems with its braking system and gave off smoke. About 200 passengers headed for emergency exits. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: New Target and Tone; Message Shows Al Qaeda's Adaptability.
Osama bin Laden's psychological operations campaign against the United States took a surprising turn yesterday with the release of an audio message that is modern, tactical and nearly diplomatic in tone, and that addresses Europeans rather than Muslim devotees, counterterrorism experts and intelligence officials said, the paper reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 16, or the 27th day of the leap second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1828: Francisco Jose de Goya, Spanish artist whose paintings and etchings reflected the political and social turmoil of his time, dies at the age of 82.
1850: Madame Marie Tussaud, Swiss founder of the famous waxworks museum in London, dies at the age of 89.
1889: Sir Charles Spencer Chaplin, known as "Charlie," film actor and comedian much loved for his portrayal of a tramp in baggy pants and bowler hat, is born in Britain. His productions include "The Kid," "The Gold Rush," and "The Great Dictator."
1912: American pilot Harriet Quimby becomes the first woman to fly the English Channel.
1917: Vladimir Ilyich Lenin returns to Russia after three years of exile in Zurich.
1923: Japanese Crown Prince Hirohito arrives in Keelung for an inspection tour of Taiwan, which is under Japanese rule.
1925: In honor of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who died in Peking on March 12, 1925 at the age of 59, the Kwangtung Provincial Government changes the name of Hsiangshan County, the place of birth of Dr. Sun, to Chungshan County.
1941: German troops enter Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, and the main synagogue is destroyed.
1948: The Organization for European Economic Co-operation (OEEC) is established in Paris by Western European nations in accordance with the Marshall Plan.
1960: The Taiwan Provincial Government begins the implementation of labor insurance regulations by establishing the Labor Insurance Bureau.
1972: Yasunari Kawabata, Japanese writer who won the 1968 Nobel Prize for literature, commits suicide at the age of 73. His novels, including "Thousand Cranes," often concern alienated, lonely individuals in search of beauty and purity.
1972: The Apollo 16 mission is launched from Cape Kennedy, Florida, to make the fifth manned moon landing.
1975: The communist Khmer Rouge seize Phnom Penh, capital of Cambodia.
1978: A tornado strikes the eastern state of Orissa in India, killing some 180 people.
1981: The Kaohsiung C.K.S. Cultural Center is inaugurated.
1982: Queen Elizabeth proclaims Canada's new constitution, severing the colonial links with Britain.
1985: The first test tube baby in the Republic of China is born at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei.
1990: In London, Freed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela publicly thanks the world for its support during his 26-year imprisonment by the South African government.
1998: Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot is reported dead of a heart attack in his Cambodian jungle stronghold at the age of 73. During his four-year reign of terror some two million Cambodians died.
1999: Former opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang is blasted by other DPP members for his recent remarks on plebiscites and Taiwan independence.
1999: A field hospital donated by Taiwan opens at the Stenkovee refugee camp outside Skopje, Macedonia.
2000: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian says that "maintaining peace and stability and safeguarding the interests of Taiwan are the highest goals and moral obligations" for him as president.
2001: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu urges to form an alliance to facilitate manpower, capital and cultural exchanges, as well as to promote human rights and regional peace.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men in old times educated themselves for their own sakes. Men now educate themselves to impress others."

The Washington Post: Captured U.S. Soldier Is Shown On Arab TV, U.S. Joins Fallujah Talks, Rebuffs Iran in Najaf.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE, MALAYSIAN BOURSES EXPLORING COOPERATION

TEXT.P: The Singapore and Malaysian stock exchanges are exploring ways to cooperate amid signs of warming relations between the two states under the new leadership of Malaysian Prime Minister Abdullah Badawi.
Talks began following a recent Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Finance Ministers meeting in Singapore where leaders encouraged the region's exchanges to strike up alliances.

Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange CEO Yusli Mohamed Yusoff has said that this may even include cross listing of companies. As for Malaysia, Prime Minister Abdullah is advocating more private sector cooperation.
Just recently, Singapore's investment holding company Temasek took a minority stake in Telekom Malaysia, one of Kuala Lumpur's biggest listed blue chips.

And just this week, the Singapore Exchange (SGX) signed memorandums of understanding with the Shanghai and Shenzhen bourses to work together more closely. The SGX already conducts cross trading with its counterpart in Australia.

The senior official at the centre of the university exam-leak scandal seems to have contradicted his earlier statements when testifying before the House committee on education yesterday, a Chulalongkorn academic critic of the official said.
