The Straits Times: Tighter rules for phone chatlines
Telephone chatline operators will have to clean up their act to help prevent more youngsters from falling prey to sexual predators. New rules that take effect on June 1 compel operators to remove sexually explicit messages, exclude users below 18, compile blacklists of users who have left abusive or offensive messages and share them with other operators.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore Govt tightens rules on telephone chatline operators from June 1
Under the new code, to be introduced through a new law on June 1, operators must "remove sexually explicit or offensive messages on their services that are accessible to the public, " the authority said.

While missteps by the CIA and FBI have come under harsh public scrutiny by a commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks, the independent panel is quietly amassing evidence of a decade of failures by a third institution: the Pentagon.

TEXT.P: New York Times: Missing G.I. Seen on Tape Provided by Iraqi Captors

An American soldier who has been missing for a week since his fuel convoy was attacked west of Baghdad was seen on a videotape on Friday being held captive by six armed and masked men. The family of the soldier, Pfc. Keith Maupin, 20, of Batavia, Ohio, confirmed his identity.
A voice speaking in Arabic on the tape, first shown on the Arab news network Al Jazeera, said Private Maupin was being held to trade for Iraqi prisoners of the Americans.
Wall Street Journal: Ernst & Young Gets Six-Month Suspension

An administrative law judge on Friday ordered that Ernst & Young LLP be suspended from accepting new publicly registered audit clients for six months, in a case brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission's enforcement division over alleged auditor-independence issues involving the New York accounting firm and former audit client PeopleSoft Inc. The judge further ordered that Ernst pay $1.7 million in restitution, plus interest. Ernst & Young on Friday said the firm will not appeal the judge's decision to the full SEC., though it had previously argued that its conduct was appropriate and met professional standards. The company said it is "fully committed'' to working with the SEC-approved independent consultant it must hire under the judge's order to oversee its policies and internal controls.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Bush backs Blair on UN.
The American President gave the go-ahead for the United Nations to assume control of the next stage of Iraq's future yesterday as he and Tony Blair (the British prime minister) insisted that they would see the job through.
Financial Times: Bush and Blair woo the UN.
The United Nations will have a "central role" in Iraq, George W. Bush, US president, and Tony Blair, British prime minister, promised on Friday, as they insisted that they would not be deflected from their mission to transform the Middle East.
The two leaders, who just over a year ago broke with the UN to launch the Iraq war, gave a strong endorsement to Lakhdar Brahimi, the UN envoy to Iraq, to shape the Iraqi governing authority after the US restores sovereignty on June 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS GEAR UP TO FORMULATE NEW PARTY POLICY GUIDELINES

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will push the party to review its charter, platform and action guidelines in order to further consolidate and expand the party's support base, party sources said Saturday.

After President Chen Shui-bian won a second four-year term in the March 20 presidential election, many DPP heavyweights have pledged to accelerate intraparty reform so that the party can live up to public expectations and grip on power for a long period of time.

While winning more than half of seats in the year-end legislative elections is a critical step to realize that goal, party sources said, many DPP lawmakers are also gearing up to formulate new proposals and concepts to address many issues facing the country.

Legislator Tuan Yi-kang, who concurrently serves as convener of the DPP's New Wave faction, said the New Wave faction has begun to mull many critical issues, including the party's future development direction as well as the nation's future development and ideological development.
Tuan said the faction will come up with proposals regarding revisions to the party's charter, platform and action guidelines later this year.

"We'll then consult with members of other DPP factions to forge a consensus on various critical issues," Tuan said, adding that he hopes the party can present new vision and new policy initiatives after the year-end legislative elections.

Legislator Lo Wen-chia, a member of the DPP's Justice faction, said that in the face of new situation in the wake of the presidential election, the DPP should use an even more delicate ways to forge a national consensus on major policy issues. He suggested that DPP lawmakers organize a series of seminars to publicize the party's new ideals and new vision.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLY MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS SHOULD HAVE FINGERPRINTS TAKEN: NPA

TEXT.P: The National Police Administration (NPA) said Saturday that only mainland Chinese who come to Taiwan to reunite with their family members or to settle in Taiwan through their marriage with local people will be required to have their fingerprints taken by local authorities.
The NPA was commenting on mainland Chinese and South Korean press reports that Taiwan will fingerprint all mainland Chinese visitors.

"The reports were not correct," an NPA official said, adding that ordinary mainland Chinese citizens or professionals who come to Taiwan for short visits will not be required to have their fingerprints taken.

The official said the newly revised Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area borrows an article from the Exit and Immigration Law to require mainland Chinese who immigrate to Taiwan to be fingerprinted when they apply for residency permits.

"This requirement also applies to foreigners who want to take permanent residence in Taiwan or be naturalized, and, therefore, is not a form of discrimination against mainland Chinese," the official explained.

He further said the NPA's Exit and Immigration Bureau has asked the Cabinet to use its reserve funds to purchase the fingerprint identification equipment so that the bureau can begin to take fingerprints of legal mainland immigrants in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VISITS POPULAR MATSU TEMPLE IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian paid a visit to Chen Lan Kung Temple in Taichung County in central Taiwan Saturday to thank Matsu -- the Chinese goddess of the sea -- for her blessings in helping him win re-election.

Chen's visit to Chen Lan Kung, one of Taiwan's most popular Taoist temples dedicated to Matsu, came at the beginning of the deity's annual pilgrimage to a sister temple in Chiayi County's Hsinkang township.

In the run-up to the March 20 presidential election, Chen visited Chen Lan Kung to pray for Matsu's blessings. At the time, he promised to visit the temple again if he won re-election. Chen defeated the opposition "pan-blue alliance" candidate Lien Chan by a razor-thin margin.
Chen said Matsu is the first deity that he has come to know since his childhood.

"For centuries, Matsu has protected fishermen from both sides of the Taiwan Strait. She is also a common guardian of the 23 million Taiwan people. With a common belief in Matsu, all Taiwan residents will stand united and work together for the nation's development and prosperity," Chen said.
He also reaffirmed his commitment to "unifying Taiwan, stabilizing cross-strait relations, promoting social harmony, and revving up the economy" during his second four-year term.

Chen was accompanied by Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan, Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan, Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng, and Chen Lan Kung Temple Chairman Yen Ching-piao, who is also a legislator, during his visit to the temple in Taichung County's Tachia township.
The Chen Lan Kung Matsu icon's annual pilgrimage to Feng Tien Kung Temple in Hsinkang has become a major religious, tourist and cultural event in central Taiwan.

During the eight-day journey which will span four counties, namely Taichung, Changhua, Yunlin and Chiayi, a number of religious rituals and traditional dance performances will be presented at major temples in the four counties. Tens of thousands of Matsu followers will accompany the deity on the journey.
In connection with the Matu pilgrimage, the Taichung County Government has organized an annual international cultural and tourism festival to boost regional economic and cultural development.

At Saturday's opening ceremony, 11 local and foreign music and dancing troupes, including those from Australia, Japan, Africa, India, Tibet and Latin America, performed exotic music and dances along a thoroughfare to Chen Lan Kung.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD WORK HARD ON STRENGTHENING COMPETITIVENESS: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: A high-raking official on mainland China affairs said Saturday that Taiwan should strengthen its domestic economy and competitiveness amid the growing globalization and mainland China's magnetic effect in attracting foreign investment.
Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council, made the remarks at a symposium on the nation's economic and trade policies toward mainland China held in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

With the globalization of mainland Chinese enterprises having a great impact on many industrialized countries, Tsai said Taiwan should maintain stable cross-strait ties and an internal balance, including ethnic harmony and a narrow gap between the rich and poor and among the different regions of the island, in the face of the fierce global economic competition.

On the much anticipated cross-strait direct transport links, Tsai said she is concerned that the links will make the strong even stronger and the weak even weaker, as well as accelerate the relocation of Taiwan enterprises to the mainland.

Analyzing the March 20 presidential election, Tsai noted that the Taiwan people's democratic maturity has overcome the political unrest resulting from the controversial election, adding that if the island's economic maturity can overcome its political turbulence, then Taiwan will be considered as a model among democratic countries.

However, Tsai admitted that a split has developed in Taiwan society -- between the north and the south, judging in terms of ethnicity and technological levels. She stressed that the government should try its best to mend the differences in order to further strengthen the country's competitiveness so that time will stand on Taiwan's side in the economic battle between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TUNG BLOSSOM FESTIVAL KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The 2004 Tung Blossom Festival kicked off Saturday with a fun-filled ceremony at the West Lake Resort in the northern Taiwan county of Miaoli, a Hakka stronghold.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Council for Hakka Affairs (CHA) Chairwoman Yeh Chu-lan said this year's Tung Blossom Festival promises to be bigger and better than ever, with more than 600 cultural events to be held in 32 Hakka communities in Hsinchu, Taoyuan, Miaoli, Taichung, Nantou and Taipei counties.

This is the third consecutive year that the CHA has organized a tung blossom festival to boost tourism and cultural development in Taiwan's major Hakka communities, particularly those in the northern parts of the island.
Yeh said tung trees have steadfastly watched over the mountains and hills where the Hakka people have historically made their homes in Taiwan.

"Tung trees have always been a part of Hakka culture, so we have 'adopted' the tung blossom as a symbol of Hakka culture, " Yeh said, referring to the choice of tung flowers as the focus of the festival.

The trees, also known as paulownia trees in English, used to be an important source of income for the Hakka, Yeh said, adding that through the festival, the CHA hopes that tung trees will once again bring prosperity to Hakka communities. Last year's festival drew an estimated 180,000 tourists and generated NT$500 million in business revenues.
This year, Yeh said, the CHA has arranged 21 paths for appreciating beautiful tung flowers in full bloom.
"The festival offers tourists lavish opportunities to enjoy the scene of 'snow in summer' created by the white tung flowers that look like snowflakes," Yeh said.

In addition to flower appreciation, Yeh said, the CHA has also planned a variety of other festivities, including pottery-making, ecological tours, tung seed oil extracting, painting exhibitions, woodcarving shows, photo competitions, Hakka singing contests, Hakka food tasting, and seminars on Hakka cultural heritage and literature.
Yeh said the festival is the result of collaboration among various government departments, local administrations and corporate sponsors.
"We hope the annual tung blossom festival can help enrich local cultural activities and promote tourism and economic development in major Hakka communities," Yeh said.
She also encouraged tourists to learn some basic conversational Hakka during their trips to Hakka communities to experience Taiwan's cultural diversity and the beauty of Hakka culture.

The opening ceremony began with a traditional Hakka drum performance. Yeh then led other senior officials attending the ceremony, including Taiwan Provincial Government Chairman Lin Kuang-hua, Vice Minister of the Interior Lee Chin-yung and Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Chang Chia-chu, in greeting Mother Nature with tung flowers and praying for Taiwan's well-being.

After the opening ceremony, several Hakka singers and child choirs sang Hakka folk songs to entertain tourists. Some Hakka poets presented their own creations praising tung flowers and the beautiful scenery in and around Hakka communities.

This year's Tung Blossom Festival will last through May 16. Couples will be able to get married in a group ceremony with a tung flower theme. A number of gift items in tung flower motifs, including lunch boxes and wine, will be marketed in connection with the festival. State-owned Chunghwa Telecom will sell phone cards bearing the motifs of the tung flower. More travel tips are available at the Web site www.hakka.gov.tw.

The flourishing of tung trees, also known as tung oil trees and bearing the academic name of aluerites fordii hemi, on the mountain regions in northern Taiwan was described as a "beautiful fallacy" made decades ago.

With a view to cashing in on the thriving demand for wooden furniture materials to be exported to Japan, farmers in the Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli areas started planting wutung trees (firmiana simplex, commonly named Chinese parasol tree) in the 1960s. But the difficulty in growing wutung trees later forced many farmers to switch to planting tung trees, which are much easier to take care of. Both trees trace their roots to the Yangtze River area in China.
After Japanese customers discovered it was the wrong kind of wood and stopped purchasing from local suppliers, the tung oil trees were left uncut.
Three decades later, the trees are flourishing with profuse blossoms in spring, having become a major tourist attraction in the Taoyuan-Hsinchu-Miaoli area.

The trees can still be used for carving, furniture and wood pulp. The oil extracted from the seeds was used as a key ingredient for varnish in olden days, and it remains a must for Hakka people who produce hand-made umbrellas with oil paper.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR ON NEW E.U. MEMBERS TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A seminar aimed at preparing local companies for venturing into the markets of the ten soon-to-be members of the European Union will open April 22, economics officials said Saturday.

Angela T. Chu, director general of the Industrial Development and Investment Center under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said next month's entry of 10 new members into the European Union, namely Cyprus, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Slovakia and Slovenia, will make it the world's largest economic entity, with a population of 450 million, a gross domestic product of US$10.4 trillion, and a trade volume of US$4.8 trillion.

The entry of the ten countries will bring about direct trade opportunities totalling 10 billion euros (US$83.8 billion) for the current E.U. members, and the newcomers' sound industrial infrastructure and cheap workforce will inevitably squeeze out some outside competitors.
In order to break into the E.U. market, non-E.U. countries may have to invest in E.U. states. In this case, the 10 newcomers offer a favorable option, according to Chu.

Among the 10 newcomers, the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland, which boast good industrial infrastructure and a high-quality workforce, have been the first choice of many current E.U. member states when considering investing overseas, Chu said.

The Czech Republic is known for its textile, machinery and car-manufacturing industries, while Hungary is famous for its machinery industry, and Poland has well-developed textile and machinery industries, Chu continued.
Many Taiwan companies have already set up plants in these three countries as a bridgehead in exploring the E.U. market, Chu said.

In order to encourage Taiwan businesspeople to venture into the new horizons of the European Union, Chu said, his office is organizing the seminar to introduce the business environment in the new E.U. member states.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDIA MONITORING GROUP URGES BOYCOTT OF TV STATIONS

TEXT.P: A self-proclaimed media monitoring group called for a boycott in response to reckless news reporting by TV stations regarding the March 20 presidential election and the protests in Taipei that followed.

Huang Wei-wei, a leader of the Audience Alliance for Media Monitoring and a professor at National Chengchi University, said that local TV stations unanimously inflated their vote counts for the two candidates in the March 20 election during their live broadcasts of the vote-counting process in attempts to show falsely that they were ahead of other stations in summing up the results.

Furthermore, the alliance said that many TV stations extensively covered the post-election protests in front of the Presidential Office while neglecting many other important news stories. Their unbalanced coverage of the incidents gave people a false perception that the country was slipping into chaos, sending the stock market into a nose dive and hurting the economy, it said.

Naming CtiTV and ERA News TV as the most serious offenders, the alliance urged advertisers not to run commercials on the two stations between 4 p.m. and 10 p.m. from April 26 to May 15 as a form of protest.
The alliance also urged the public not to buy anything advertised during the above period on the two stations to press the two stations to mend their ways.

Liao Fu-hsun, the director of the CtiTV news department refused to comment on the alliance' accusation, while Tai Chung-jen, a deputy editor-in-chief at ERA News, said the station has responded to similar criticism before and won't bother repeating it.

DOC.HEADLINE: 13 ILLEGAL MAINLAND CHINESE IMMIGRANTS SEIZED OFF EASTERN COAST

TEXT.P: Thirteen illegal mainland Chinese immigrants were seized in waters off Taitung County in eastern Taiwan early Saturday, coast guard authorities said.

It marked the first time that human smuggling rings, also known as "snakeheads, " have been discovered trying to smuggle mainland Chinese immigrants into Taiwan via the island's eastern coast, officials said.

All of the seized immigrants are women, with the youngest being only 17 years old. Two of them had on a previous occasion been repatriated after being found to have come to Taiwan through marriage of convenience to engage in the sex trade.

The skipper of the fishing boat that ferried the illegal immigrant group to Taitung, identified as Cheng Chi-ming, was detained for questioning. Criminal investigators said they will try to track down a man nicknamed A-sheng who had allegedly organized the smuggling operations.
The 13 illegal mainland immigrants are being detained at the Taitung Police Bureau's detention center and awaiting repatriation.

Last summer, six female mainlanders attempting to enter Taiwan illegally were thrown overboard by human smugglers off Tunghsiao in northwestern Taiwan to evade pursuing coast guard patrol ships. Tragically, all six drowned.

Coast guard authorities have since launched a "snakehead"-hunting project and stepped up patrols in waters off the island's west coast. Coast guard officials said they had received tips showing that snakeheads planned to smuggle illegal mainland immigrants into Taiwan from the east coast.
"We have heightened our alert and intensified patrols in both the western and eastern coastal regions to crack down on smuggling of humans and contraband goods," said a coast guard official.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SUPPORTERS SAID NOT VERY WILLING TO CARRY ROC FLAGS MAY 20

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DDP) official said Saturday that as far as he knows, DPP supporters don't have much willingness to carry Republic of China flags during the president's inauguration ceremony set for May 20.

Liang Wen-chieh, deputy director of the DPP's Policy Research Department, made the remarks in response to proposals made by DPP lawmakers that supporters of the party carry national flags at the inauguration ceremony as a move to contribute to ethnic harmony which has been strained since the controversial March 20 election which President Chen Shui-bian won by a slim margin.

The DPP official noted that holding national flags has nothing to do with ethnic problems and that it is hard to convince the party's supporters to accept a national flag which is very similar to the flag of the rival Kuomintang, which ruled Taiwan for half a century before losing the 2000 presidential election to the DPP.
Liang said the DPP legislators' proposal can be discussed, but added that the DPP supporters haven't expressed much willingness to accept it.

Ethnic divisions in Taiwan society have been exacerbated in almost every election, with politicians differentiating for their own political gain between "native Taiwanese" and mainlanders who came to Taiwan in 1949 after the Chinese civil war and their offspring.

The "mainlanders" are traditionally supporters of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party, while the "native Taiwanese" are inclined toward the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and Taiwan Solidarity Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION TO MEET WITH CHIEF OF EUROPEAN BANK
DOC.DATELINE: London, April 16 (CNA) (By Han Nei-kuo & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A delegation headed by Tien Hung-mao, Taiwan's representative to London, will meet with Jean Lemierre, president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) , on Saturday to discuss ways of promoting bilateral cooperation.

The delegation, consisting of financial officials and diplomats from Taiwan, will also attend the 13th annual meeting of the EBRD in London from Sunday to Monday, including its Board of Governors' meeting, business forum and donors meeting.
Tien said before the meeting that Taiwan shares the EBRD's aim of promoting democracy and the market economy and looks forward to closer cooperation with the EBRD on the basis of reciprocity.

Founded in 1991 following the collapse of communism in Eastern and Central Europe, the EBRD has used the tool of investment to help build market economies and democracies in 27 countries from central Europe to Central Asia.

Taiwan agreed to cooperate with the EBRD in 1991, and it has donated more than US$21 million to the bank since that time. The funds have helped the EBRD to expand its operations and given Taiwan the valuable opportunity to rub shoulders with EBRD members. Taiwan was able to set up an office within the EBRD in February of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ASKS TO JOIN CHINA-U.S. WTO CONSULTATION MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 16 (CNA) (By C.S. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has asked to attend a China-U.S. consultation meeting on semi-conductor value added tax (VAT) set for April 27 in Geneva, but it has not yet received any response from Beijing, a well-placed source in Geneva said Friday.
The source said that Beijing has not yet agreed to the participation of Taiwan or several other WTO members, including the European Union, Japan and Mexico, as third parties.

Washington has requested the consultation meeting in accordance with the WTO's Dispute Settlement Agreement, claiming that mainland China has violated the organization's rules of "national treatment."

"National treatment" is defined as any citizen of a party to a contract that signs an agreement or a treaty having the same rights and legal protections as citizens of any other party to the contract.

Despite the fact that mainland China-made and designed semiconductors enjoy tax rebate treatment of up to 14 percent in mainland China, Beijing has imposed a VAT of 17 percent on semiconductor products from other countries, the source said.

The source said that Yen Ching-chang, Taiwan's permanent representative to the WTO, sent a letter on behalf of Taiwan's government to delegations of the United State and mainland China in Geneva as well as to the WTO's dispute settlement body at the beginning of this month asking to attend the consultation meeting as a "third party."

A trade official of Taiwan's permanent mission to the WTO said Friday that Taiwan's request to participate in the consultation meeting is significant for Taiwan's semiconductor industry as well as cross-strait interactions within the WTO.
Taiwan attaches great importance to participation in the consultation meeting since the island is one of mainland China's main suppliers of semiconductor products, the official added.

Statistics show that last year, Taiwan's semiconductor exports to mainland China amounted to US$1.8 billion and that the growth rate of the island's semiconductor exports to mainland China in the past three years was 13.9 percent, 181.6 percent and 105.1 percent respectively.

Although interaction between Taipei and Beijing in the WTO has not been smooth since the two became members of the organization, the official said that he would not predict whether mainland China would refuse Taiwan's request to attend the consultation meeting for political reasons.

He said that as of Friday, the mission had still not received any response from the mainland Chinese delegation in Geneva, adding that several other WTO members that hope to join the meeting are also awaiting Beijing's reply.

Nevertheless, an observer in Geneva said he thinks a political dispute could occur if Taiwan is excluded from the consultation meeting while the European Union, Japan and Mexico are allowed to join the meeting.

[Turkish Daily News]: [Pressure builds on 'oxi' flank]
International community has stepped up pressure on Greek cypriots opposing a U.N. plan to reunify the island before its becoming a European Union member on May 1 as Turkey is appealing to the EU for clerer assurances that Turkish Cypriots will not be the party to be punished because of Greek Cypriot rejection.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 17, or the 28th day of the leap second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1421: More than 100,000 people drown when the sea breaks through a dike in Dort, Holland.
1790: American public official, writer, scientist, and printer Benjamin Franklin dies at the age of 84. He played a major part in the American Revolution, negotiated French support for the colonies, signed the Treaty of Paris and helped draft the US Constitution.
1824: The United States and Russia define respective rights in the Pacific Ocean and on the northwest coast of America.
1894: Nikita S. Krushchev, Soviet politician, is born. As Soviet leader he denounced Stalin and thwarted the Hungarian Revolution of 1956. He was deposed in 1964 for his failure to improve the Soviet economy.
1895: The Treaty of Shimonoseki is signed, compelling the Ching court to pay a huge indemnity, open its seaports, recognize the independence of Korea, and cede the Liaoning Peninsula, Taiwan and the Pescadores to Japan.
1897: During a revolt in Ottoman-held Crete, war breaks out between Greece and the Ottoman Empire.
1906: A Pacific cable between China and the United States is completed.
1938: Chang Kuo-dao, governor of the Chinese communist government that controls the region comprising Shensi, Kansu and Ningsia issues a statement in Hankou distancing himself from the Chinese Communist Party.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt approves initial military aid US$45 million for China.
1946: Communist troops enter Changchun, Kirin Province, in northeastern China.
1950: The Chinese Women's Anti-Aggression League is formally inaugurated.
1964: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs issues a statement severing diplomatic relations with The Congo.
1968: U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson meets with South Korean President Park Chung Hee in Honolulu, pledging U.S. protection for noncommunist Asia.
1971: Egypt, Syria and Libya sign an agreement to form a confederation.
1971: East Pakistanis declare their homeland an independent nation which they rename Bangladesh. Sheik Mujibur Rahman serves as the nation's first prime minister.
1973: President Lon Nol of Cambodia announces the resignation of his Cabinet.
1980: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) accepts mainland China as a member, and the Republic of China is forced to pull out of the organization.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Council passes a proposal to allow teachers and staff of public schools to travel to the Chinese mainland for family visits.
1992: Legislative proceedings are completed for the National Employment Act, which is to serve as the basis for employment of foreign nationals in the Republic of China.
1994: Mainland China's public security unit announces it has solved a criminal case in which 24 Taiwan tourists were killed at Qiandao Lake on March 31, 1994.
1995: Fire breaks out at a KTV on Hankou Street in Taipei, killing 12 people and seriously injuring 14 others.
1996: U.S. President Bill Clinton signs a joint declaration on security cooperation with Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto pledging to maintain American military levels in Japan and elsewhere in Asia.
1999: An ROC humanitarian relief delegation returns to Taipei after a visit to Macedonia to express concern and offer assistance to ethnic Albanian refugees from neighboring war-torn Yugoslav province of Kosovo.
2000: The Year 2000 Trend Setting & Technology Conference is held in Taipei with more than 100 experts and industrialists from home and abroad participating.
2000: The Republic of China Finance Ministry allows two local insurance companies to set up offices in mainland China, marking the first mainland foray for the island's insurance industry.
2001: The Taipei Bank is chosen over four other hopefuls by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to issue both traditional and computerized charity lotteries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man is ashamed to say much; he prefers to do more."

DOC.HEADLINE: BLOOD DONATION CAMPAIGN MARKS 30TH YEAR IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Chinese Blood Donation Association and Chinese Blood Services Foundation celebrated 30 years of free blood donations Sunday with various activities held at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei, as well as with citations for the most prolific donors.

Tsai Pei-huo, president of Taiwan branch of the Red Cross Society, established the Chinese Blood Donation Association Taiwan on April 19. 1974, opening the era of blood donation without payment in Taiwan.

Chang Kuo-shen, 48, was cited for making the most donations in his life. Chang, from Tainan, southern Taiwan, and currently working in the transportation service trade, has made 805 donations since he started regular donations on May 2, 1977.
Wang Chiu-Chuan. 45, was the No. 1 woman blood donor, making 605 donations since May 30, 1986.

Huang Lien-chung and of his family members were also cited for being a "model blood-donating family, " because the four members of the Huang family have been active in blood donations with Huang himself making 228 donations.
In addition to the citations, there were also pavilions providing free health checks, attracting large crowds.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, EBRD OFFICIALS MEET FOR BILATERAL CONSULTATION
DOC.DATELINE: London, April 17 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan official delegation met with senior officials from the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) Saturday to discuss ways of promoting bilateral cooperation.

Tien Hung-mao, Taiwan's representative in London, and EBRD Chairman Jean Lemierre and their respective group members reached a consensus after a brief meeting, agreeing that Taiwan will render assistance to the EBRD in facilitating development of small- and medium-sized enterprises in countries that the EBRD are helping financially.
The meeting was held on the eve of the annual meeting of the European Bank's Board of Directors.

Lemierre thanked Taiwan for its assistance in developing market economies in former communist countries in Central and Eastern Europe. He said it is keenly hoped that both sides will continue to bolster the bilateral cooperation in years to come.

Lemierre said he was in Taiwan three years ago. Although it was a short eight-hour visit, he said, he had an opportunity to gain a better understanding of Taiwan's economic strength and its willingness to share.
He said he has also visited mainland China and there he was impressed with an energized economy and fast-growing industrial development.
Tien, in turn told Lemierre that about 70 percent of mainland China's information technology products have been churned out by Taiwan-invested manufacturing companies.
Tien invited Lemierre and other EBRD ranking officials to visit Taiwan in the latter part of May to take part in President Chen Shui-bian's inauguration ceremony and to view again Taiwan's vibrancy.

The Taiwan delegation, consisting of financial officials and diplomats, will also attend the 13th annual meeting of the EBRD in London from Sunday to Monday, including its Board of Directors' meeting, a business forum and a donors meeting.

Tien said before the meeting that Taiwan shares the EBRD's aim of promoting democracy and market economies and looks forward to closer cooperation with the EBRD on the basis of reciprocity. Founded in 1991 following the collapse of communism in Eastern and Central Europe, the EBRD has used the tool of investment to help build market economies and democracies in 27 countries from Central Europe to Central Asia.

Taiwan agreed to cooperate with the EBRD in 1991, and it has donated more than US$21 million to the bank since that time. In May 2003, Tien and his Taiwan delegation attended the EBRD annual meeting held in Tashkent, Uzbekistan. During which, Tien, on behalf of Taiwan, endorsed an agreement with Lemierre, committing one million euros to an EBRD fund to finance infrastructure development in Mongolia.

Taiwan funds have helped the EBRD to expand its operations and have given Taiwan the valuable opportunity to rub shoulders with EBRD members. Taiwan was able to set up an office within the EBRD in February of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AUTHORIZED TO HOST 2007 PATA CONFERENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, April 18 (CNA) (By Chiang Yuan-chen & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been authorized to host the 2007 annual conference of the Pacific Asia Travel Association (PATA) , an official with Taiwan's Tourism Bureau stationed in Seoul said Sunday.

Wang Jen-teh said that Su Cheng-tien, director-general of the bureau, has obtained the rights for Taiwan to organize the event after briefing Taiwan's preparations and programs elaborated for the purpose in the 53rd PATA annual conference being held on Jeju Island, South Korea.
After watching a DVD play that introduces Taiwan, Wang noted, Peter de Jang, president of the conference, announced that the 56th PATA annual conference slated for 2007 will be held in Taiwan.

Some 2,000 representatives from 77 countries are participating in the conference which was opened Sunday and will run through April 22. The main topic of the meeting is "Tourism is everybody's business".
PATA, founded in Hawaii in 1951, is the recognized authority on travel and tourism in the Asia-Pacific region and has more than 17,000 members.

The largest international organization of its kind usually has its annual conference held in a different country each year. Taiwan registered as a member in 1957 and sponsored the 18th annual conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAR ACCESSORY MISSIONS TO EXPLORE EUROPEAN, NORTH AMERICAN MARKETS

TEXT.P: To help Taiwan makers of key parts and accessories gain business from world leading car makers, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will organize two missions to explore the European and North American markets, a spokesman for the semiofficial trade promotion body said Sunday.

One mission is slated to head for destinations in Europe in late April, while the other will depart for North American countries in early May, the TAITRA official said, adding that they will visit top car makers, such as MG-Rover and Ford Motor Company, and leading local manufacturers of key parts and accessories in search of business and cooperation opportunities.

Claiming that Taiwan's makers are fully capable of putting out high quality goods and of serving as prime suppliers to world-class automobile companies, the officials said forging business alliances with foreign companies will allow them to further upgrade their research and development abilities and make a greater profit at a time when their earnings are squeezed as a result of fierce competition at home.
The TAITRA has designated the car accessory sector as one of its key promotions this year, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Hamas Appoints New Leader After Killing.
The militant group Hamas appointed a new chief in the Gaza Strip early Sunday, but refused to reveal his identity after Israel assassinated the second Hamas leader in less than a month.
Abdel Aziz Rantisi was killed in a missile strike on his car Saturday, part of its declared campaign to wipe out the Islamic militant group's leadership ahead of a planned Israeli withdrawal from the Gaza Strip. Two of Rantisi's bodyguards were also killed.
Rantisi was killed less than a month after Israel assassinated Hamas founder Sheik Ahmed Yassin. The group's Damascus-based leader Khaled Mashaal -- whom Israeli officials on Sunday also threatened to kill -- reportedly instructed the group to keep the name of its new Gaza leader secret.
Wall Street Journal: Hamas Leader Is Killed in Israeli Missile Attack.
Israel assassinated Hamas's Gaza leader, Aabdel Aziz Rantisi, in a missile strike on his car Saturday, part of its declared campaign to wipe out the Islamic militant group's leadership ahead of a planned Israeli withdrawal from the territory. Two of Mr. Rantisi's bodyguards were also killed, and five pedestrians were wounded.
Hamas secretly appointed a new Gaza Strip chief early Sunday, but refused to reveal his identity after Israel assassinated two of the group's top leaders in less than a month, Hamas sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ORDERS ADVANCED OCEAN BOTTOM SEISMOMETERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has ordered four advanced ocean bottom seismometers from the United States to help measure quakes taking place at sea, a researcher from the nation's highest research institute said Sunday.

Kuo Pen-yuan, deputy director of the Institute of Earth Sciences of Academia Sinica, said that Taiwan has an adequate number of earthquake observation stations on land, and substantial results have been achieved in the research of earthquakes, plate structures and movements, but it lags in measurements of earthquake taking place at sea.

Kuo noted that there were records of disasters on land brought about by quakes at sea off eastern Taiwan, most notably the incident that took place in March 2002, when a quake measuring 6.8 on the Richter scale took place 10 kilometers deep at sea and scores of kilometers off Hualien, eastern Taiwan, resulting in the crane for the Taipei 101, the world's tallest building which is still under construction, to fall to the ground, killing four people.
"This shows that Taiwan's measurements of temblors at sea is not sufficient, and that it has to step up the information collection of quake at seas, " Kuo said.

In addition, he said that eastern Taiwan sits on the joint of the Euro-Asian and the Philippines plates, and that the plate movement is one of the major reasons for quakes, and the rupture of the faults at sea is what the seismologist want to know most about.
Kuo said that Academia Sinica is cooperating with Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution of Massachusetts to build the four ocean bottom seismometers.
The construction of the four seismometers is expected to begin this September, and they will be shipped back to Taiwan at the end of the year.

Kuo said that the initial plan calls for the four seismometers to be placed 4,000 meters deep at sea and 150 kilometers off eastern Taiwan, and they would probably be placed in the southern Taiwan Strait, and off the cities of Taitung, Hualien and Ilan.
The Academia Sinica will work with colleges and universities to decide the exact locations, the use of the information as well as the strengthening of international cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEEKS SINGAPORE COOPERATION IN DISTRIBUTION INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: To cope with the rapidly changing economic situation both at home and abroad, Taiwan is seeking cooperation from Singapore to promote the distribution industry to expand mutual business opportunities, a source said Sunday.

Taking advantage of Taiwan's strategic position and strong manufacturing capabilities, the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the semiofficial Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) have planned a seminar for April 22 in which industry executives of the two countries will get together to try to create cooperative ventures, a spokesman for the TAITRA Kaohisung office said.

To create new horizons for the continued survival and development of Taiwan's businesses, Taiwan has the potential to transform from a world manufacturing powerhouse to a business operations hub in East Asia, thanks to its key location and a strong industrial base, the spokesman said.

Kaohsiung, the largest city in southern Taiwan, is specially suited for promotion of the distribution industry because of its various ports and export processing zones and a planned free port trade zone at the Kaohsiung Port, he noted.

With this aim in mind, the BOFT and the TAITRA have taken a concerted move to sponsor the seminar for the domestic distribution industry in the hope of helping it catch up on the world's latest trends and get to know the expertise to become a competitive user of e-commerce in order to develop it into a full-dimensioned and service-oriented sector, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRA DOCUMENTS ON DISPLAY IN WASHINGTON, D.C. FOR 25TH ANNIVERSARY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 18 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States is sponsoring an exhibition at the National Press Club in Washington, D.C. to observe the 25th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA).

Assisted by the U.S. Library of Congress, the Republic of China's representative office based in the U.S. capital is displaying all important transcripts, documents and information about the legislation of the TRA, including its entire contents along with photos, White House statements, remarks by U.S. lawmakers, news reports and an ROC national flag.

The office is sponsoring the exhibition as part of its efforts to help the international community gain a better understanding of the TRA, in particular its significance in Washington-Taipei-Beijing relations.

More than 20 U.S. congressmen also held a party at a Senate hall to commemorate the TRA's 25 anniversary, with Senate majority leader Bill First and House majority leader Thomas D. DeLay taking part and giving a speech.

In addition, the House's International Relations Committee is slated to hold a public hearing on the TRA April 21 to mark its 25th anniversary, in which Committee Chairman Henry J. Hyde, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs James Kelly, former American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Richard Bush and various leading U.S. experts on cross-Taiwan Strait ties will testify at the meeting.

The TRA was signed into law April 10, 1979 by former U.S. President Jimmy Carter as the country's basic policy framework toward Taiwan after Washington switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in late 1978.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR TO REGAIN MOMENTUM GRADUALLY: BANKING INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: In the wake of last week's fluctuations as a result of the U. S. dollar's marked rise, the new Taiwan dollar will regain momentum gradually this week, sources from the banking industry said Sunday.

The local currency is expected to regain strength against the greenback this week in the 32.85-33.05 range this week, as the rebounding trends of the U. S. dollar are likely to slow down in the days ahead due to a lower than expected consumer price index made public Friday by the U.S. authorities, the sources said.

Against a strongly appreciating Japanese yen early last week, the new Taiwan dollar once gained in value against the U.S. dollar jumping to a three-year high of 32.798 during a trading session. But an appreciating U.S. dollar prompted by the release of optimistic U.S. economic indexes later the same week pushed down the Japanese yen to lose in value at 109 against the greenback.

A depreciating Japanese yen also brought down the value of the new Taiwan dollar, which fell from 32.8 against the U.S. dollar to below the 33 mark. The local currency lost a total of NT$0.217 in value against the greenback Wednesday and Thursday, with it closing NT$0.04 higher at 32.975 Friday.
With a weaker Japanese yen pegging to a stabilizing U.S. dollar this week, the new Taiwan dollar will remain largely unchanged and gradually regain momentum, the sources forecast.

As Taiwan's Central Bank of China has not intervened to decide the local currency's value in recent weeks, the sources predicted that it will still adopt a hands-off policy in the foreseeable future as long as the new Taiwan dollar fluctuates within a reasonable range.
Should the Japanese yen remains stable at between 106 and 109 against the U.S. dollar, the new Taiwan dollar will also remain little changed as well, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PROPOSES CABINET TO RESIGN EN MASSE MAY 5

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun has presented a proposal to President Chen Shui-bian that his Cabinet will resign en masse on May 5, Executive Yuan spokesman Lin Chia-lung said Sunday.
Yu also hoped that Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i and Secretary-General of the Executive Yuan Liu Shih-fang will continue to stay at their current posts in the next Cabinet line-up, the spokesman added.

With regard to speculations by outsiders on the next Cabinet line-up, Lin said that Yu will make reports on the matter to the president and will start to consult with possible candidates for Cabinet members after the president agrees with Yu's proposals for any changes.
The Cabinet was originally scheduled to resign en masse May 12 in line with constitutional precedents prior to the presidential inauguration.
Yu proposed to the president that the sitting Cabinet resign earlier than scheduled to allow the new Cabinet line-up more time to get a head start.

President Chen, who won the hotly contested March 20 presidential election by a narrow margin of fewer than 30,000 votes out of more than 13 million ballots cast, will be sworn in for another four-year term May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: CITY GOVERNMENT SOLICITS PRIVATE INVESTORS FOR TAIPEI CULTURAL CENTER

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government is soliciting builders for the Taipei Cultural Center, which is envisaged as a modern and multifunctional center for art and cultural activities.

In order to pool the financial strength and creative resources of the private sector to the prospective cultural center, the Taipei City Government has decided to allow private investors to build the center on a build-operate-transfer (BOT) basis, said Liao Hsien-hao, director of the Cultural Affairs Bureau of Taipei.
If everything goes smoothly, Liao said, the cultural center is expected to be built and open to public utilization by June 2008.

The Taipei Cultural Center planned by the city government will be a 400,000 sq. ft. compound comprising a 1,500-seat music hall, a 1,000-seat theater, a 1,000-seat concert hall, a museum, a tourist hotel, a gym, several restaurants and other facilities for commercial activities, Liao added.
First-stage investment in the cultural center will be around NT$11.4 billion (US$345.45 million), Liao noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MRT EXPANSIONS NOT TO BE INTERRUPTED: TRTC MANAGEMENT

TEXT.P: None of the Taipei mass rapid transit (MRT) system's expansion projects will be affected even if the budget plan for the 10 New Major Construction Projects, under which the MRT expansions are included, fails to clear the legislative floor this session, Taipei MRT authorities said Sunday.

Officials from the Democratic Progressive Party-ruled administration said Sunday that they are confident that the five-year, NT$500 billion (US$15.15 billion) budget plan for the 10 New Major Construction Projects will be passed by the Legislative Yuan before this current session wraps up in early June.
Yet opposition legislators have sworn to boycott budgets for some of the projects, saying that those project plans are "illegal and unconstitutional."

The Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC) authorities said Sunday that the central government has committed NT$17.71 billion (US$536.66 million) for this fiscal year to aid the development of new lines or extensions of existing lines of the Taipei MRT system.

Of the total, only NT$2.46 billion will be financed by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, while the bulk of the budget, or NT$15.25 billion, will be allocated by the central government under the five-year, NT$500 billion budget plan.

The development of new lines and extensions of the Taipei MRT system that are supposed to be financed by the five-year, NT$500 billion budget plan include new lines connecting Taipei City and Taipei County's satellite cities of Hsinchuang and Luzhou; new lines connecting Taipei City and Neihu, Tucheng and Hsiaopitan; and extensions of the existing Hsinyi line and Sungshan line.

The TRTC authorities said that if the 10 New Major Construction Projects budget plan is not passed at the Legislative Yuan, the MRT company will ask the Taipei Municipal Bureau of Finance to borrow the due amounts from local banks to finance the MRT construction so that planned projects will be carried out as scheduled.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 18, or the 29th day of the leap second month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1480: Lucrezia Borgia, the illegitimate daughter of Pope Alexander VI, is born in Italy. She was married three times by the age of 18 to further her father's political ambitions.
1906: An earthquake devastates San Francisco, killing more than 1,000 people and making 300,000 others homeless.
1925: The first world women's exposition is opened in Chicago.
1927: The national government is established in Nanking by the Kuomintang.
1933: Fighting spreads in northern China as several strategic passes along the Great Wall fall to the Japanese.
1942: Planes from a U.S. aircraft carrier bomb Tokyo for the first time. They were commanded by Lt. Gen. James Doolittle.
1943: Isoroku Yamamoto, a Japanese naval officer, is killed when his plane is shot down by U.S. warplanes over the Solomon Islands. He planned Japan's naval strategies during World War II, including the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941.
1946: The League of Nations is formally dissolved.
1948: By a two-thirds majority, the first National Assembly approves temporary provisions granting emergency powers to the president during the ongoing anti-Communist campaign.
1949: The Republic of Ireland is formally proclaimed in Dublin.
1954: Gamal Abdel Nasser becomes prime minister of Egypt.
1955: Albert Einstein, the German-born American theoretical physicist who won a Nobel Prize in 1921 for his explanation of the photoelectric effect, dies at the age of 76. His specific and general theories of relativity revolutionized modern thought on the nature of space and time and formed a theoretical basis for the exploitation of atomic energy.
1968: Army officers in western Africa's Sierra Leone take over the government, dissolve the Legislature and suspend the constitution.
1977: A boat capsizes near Suao Port in eastern Taiwan, killing 32 college students and teachers on board and injuring 16 others.
1980: The former Rhodesia becomes independent Zimbabwe under President Canaan Banana.
1982: Monaco's Prince Rainier III and his wife, Princess Grace Kelly, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1988: The Republic of China Red Cross Society begins forwarding mail from Taiwan residents to mainland China.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Council under the Executive Yuan decides to permit Taiwan citizens to gather news and make films in mainland China.
1998: Official talks between South and North Korea end with the two sides failing to resolve a dispute over aid to the starving North and the reunion of separated families.
1999: A GIO-produced documentary featuring the relationship between the year of one's birth and the 12 animals in the 12-year cycle of the Chinese calendar wins a gold medal at the Houston International Film Festival.
2000: Tainan-based National Cheng Kung University signs an academic cooperation contract with Japan's Kanazawa Industrial University.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on U.S. Senator Frank Murkowski (R-Alaska) for his contributions to promoting bilateral relations between the ROC and the United States.
2001: The Tainan District Court approves a prosecution request to hold Tainan City Mayor George Chang incommunicado over his alleged involvement in a governmental land-requisition scam.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man may be known in three ways which I am not able to show in my own person. As a moral man he is free from anxiety; as a man of understanding he is free from doubt; and as a man of courage he is free from fear."
