DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION TO UNDERLINE SOLEMNITY, PEACE, HAPPINESS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inauguration for a second term will stress solemnity and peace, coupled with hope and happiness, but will not emphasize the party's contest against the opposition Kuomintang, an official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Monday.
DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan said Chen wishes to have a simple inauguration ceremony, but he added that the party will consult public opinion before making any decisions.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN URGES LEGISLATURE TO ACT ON BUDGET FOR MAJOR PROJECTS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan urged the Legislative Yuan Monday to approve during this legislative session its request for NT$500 billion (US$14.98 billion) over five years for 10 major projects.

Lin Chia-lung, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan, said that if the legislature cannot reach a decision during this session, then the Executive Yuan hopes it will hold an extraordinary session to discuss the budget.
As long as the Legislative Yuan approves the budget, the Executive Yuan will not mind if the total amount of the budget is somewhat cut, Lin added.

Noting that half of the budget will go to transportation projects, Lin said that if the budget is scuttled by the Legislative Yuan, some of the country's important transportation projects will be affected, including the construction and expansion of mass rapid transit systems in Kaohsiung and Taipei.
In that case, Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei said, the two municipal cities will have to finance the construction with their own funds.
However, the local government's budget would only be able to fund construction for a couple of months, after which the construction would grind to a halt, Tsai warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER REFUTES REPORTS ABOUT GOING TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i said Monday that it is unlikely that he will pursue another career in mainland China after he steps down from his civil service post.
Lin, who concurrently serves as chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , made the remarks after a CEPD meeting to refute media reports that he might go to the mainland.
"It is impossible for me to go in the capacity of a businessman and pursue another career there," Lin said.

As a civil servant, he said, he had to report to the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) before he could even accompany his wife on a pilgrimage to mainland China's Putuo Mountain, so it would not be possible for him to obtain permission to work there after stepping down.

Lin, a successful businessman before he was invited to enter politics, declined Premier Yu Shyi-kun's invitation to stay on in his post, saying that the economy is on a rebound and that he feels his task at this stage has been completed.

Sources in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said that it is possible Lin might be asked to serve as a presidential adviser or as chairman of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

The sources said that the present SEF chairman, octogenarian Koo Chen-fu, has expressed his desire to step down because of his age. Lin's wide connections in the business world, and his familiarity with government policies during his term as vice premier, would make him a suitable candidate for the post left vacant by Koo's retirement.
In addition, Lin is not a DPP member, which would be more acceptable to the mainland leadership, the sources said.
Yu's Cabinet will resign en masse May 5 according to tradition before the May 20 presidential inauguration. The new Cabinet lineup has largely been mapped out.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Court Freezes All Yukos Property.
The legal noose around Yukos tightened last week after a court banned the oil giant from selling or transferring any assets -- including its shares in Sibneft -- during hearings into a beefed-up claim by tax officials for nearly $3.5 billion in back taxes.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TO KEEP WATCHFUL EYE ON INFLATION

TEXT.P: Singapore's labor chief Lim Boon Heng said Monday that the city-state's economy is improving but that a watchful eye must be kept on inflation.

The NTUC secretary-general said the government is optimistic about Singapore's economic growth for 2004, but he added the government will keep a close watch on the cost of living and inflation, especially with mainland China's growth and the rise in oil prices.
Advance gross domestic product estimates released last week showed the economy grew 7.3 percent for the first three months of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPORTS LOTTERY MIGHT BE ISSUED SOON: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that the time for issuing a sports lottery is approaching and that related government agencies should map out relevant policies soon.
Chen made the remarks when he met over lunch with representatives of the Chinese Professional Baseball League, including League President Chen He-tung and leaders of six professional baseball teams.

The president said that he was gratified to learn that after the integration of the two major leagues, fans have paid more than 1 million visits to baseball games and that ticket revenues have grown by 115 percent.
He added that baseball fans now are most concerned with the performance of the Chinese Taipei baseball team in the upcoming Athens Olympics.

The baseball representatives suggested issues that need to be addressed concerning the development of baseball in Taiwan, including the dilapidated stadium and how to lay a solid framework for baseball games.

In response to their suggestions, Chen said that the four top priorities will be to issue a sports lottery, build new stadiums, deregulate and encourage enterprises to sponsor baseball games, and offer tax incentives for businesses sponsoring sporting activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILLING TO HELP REBUILD IRAQ: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan is very willing to take part in the reconstruction program led by the United States in Iraq as part of its efforts to assist in rebuilding a democratic Iraq, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Richard Shih said Monday.

Shih made the remarks in response to an invitation from the American Institute in Taiwan that welcomes Taiwan-based companies to take part in a seminar sponsored by the U.S. Department of Commerce April 28 in Seoul to seek cooperative opportunities as subcontractors with four main contractors based in the United States -- Lucent Technologies, Louis Berger, Parsons and Flour-AMEC.
Although there are only 28 placements for companies headquartered in Taiwan to attend the Seoul seminar, Shih pointed out that many domestic firms have shown keen interest in presenting themselves.

Taiwan appreciates the goodwill gesture made by the United States and will be very happy to see Taiwan companies participate in Iraq's reconstruction, Shih said, adding that Taiwan is determined to gain a presence in the task along with other countries as part of its support for the global anti-terrorism campaign.

According to the MOFA spokesman, only 63 countries -- those which backed the attacks initiated by the United States on Iraq last year -- will be offered the opportunity to take part in the reconstruction program.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMITTEE RESERVES DECISION ON EXTENDING FINANCIAL RESTRUCTURING FUND

TEXT.P: A committee at the Legislative Yuan decided Monday not to grant a request from the Ministry of Finance to renew the lifespan of the Financial Restructuring Fund for another year.
Instead, the Finance Committee suggested negotiations among the various parties involved on whether the fund should be kept for another year after its three-year lifespan falls due in July.
Several opposition legislators expressed doubts about the function of the fund, claiming that it should not take the place of deposit insurance.

Set up in June 2001, the restructuring fund was aimed at bailing out insolvent domestic banks. Vice Minister of Finance Susan Chang said that the fund has rescued 44 failed banks from bankruptcy by paying off NT$89.8 billion (US$2.72 billion)-worth of bad loans, but he noted that there are still several insolvent banks that need to be dealt with, making it necessary to extend the fund for another year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CONCERNED ABOUT VIETNAM TOUR GROUP VISITING SPRATLY ISLANDS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has expressed concern about a trip by a Vietnamese tour group to the disputed Spratly Islands, a MOFA spokesman said Monday.

Richard Shih said the ministry has called the director of the Vietnam Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei to urge him to convey to the Vietnamese government the message that it should exercise self-restraint so as not to trigger regional tensions.

Wire reports said that Vietnamese government announced March 25 that it had decided to open the disputed archipelago to tour groups, drawing concern from Taiwan, mainland China, Malaysia, the Philippines and Brunei, all of which claim all or part of the island group.

Reports said that a boatload of Vietnamese -- including 60 tourists and 40 "invited" officials left a port in the southern business capital of Ho Chi Minh City Monday for the inaugural voyage to Hanoi's military outposts in the Spratly Islands, which straddle vital shipping lanes and fishing grounds and are believed to contain vast oil and gas reserves.

Shih said the MOFA sent messages between late March and early April to its Vietnam representative office -- the Taipei Economic & Cultural Office in Hanoi -- to express the government's concern and to reaffirm that Taiwan has sovereignty over the archipelago.

Lin Sung-huan, director-general of MOFA's Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, also called the director of the Vietnam Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei twice to express the concern, to be told that it is purely a tourism activity and that the Vietnamese government has no intention of triggering regional tensions.
Taiwan maintains a manned military outpost on Taiping Island, the largest of the island group.

Shih said the MOFA also expressed regret that Taiwan is excluded from a multilateral mechanism between the members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and mainland China, a situation it described as "most inappropriate."

Taiwan urges ASEAN to address the fact that it is one of the claimants and should help it join the multilateral mechanism so that the concerned parties can find solutions to disputes through peaceful dialogue in a rational and self-restrained manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INSURANCE FIRMS ALLOWED NEW ACCESS TO INVEST IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance granted new access Monday for Taiwan-based insurance companies wishing to edge into the mainland China market by easing the rules to allow local firms to invest in their mainland counterparts through shareholding.

Chen Wei-lung, deputy director of the ministry's Department of Insurance, said that the rule change was decided after a ministerial consultation with the Taiwan-based Central Bank of China, the Mainland Affairs Council and the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

The new measure has been approved by the Executive Yuan and takes immediate effect, Chen said, adding that it is the latest in a series of relaxations allowing domestic insurance firms to set up offices, branches and affiliates on the mainland.

From now on, Taiwan-based insurance companies can invest in their mainland-based counterparts through buying their shares, Chen said. However, he added that an annual total ceiling worth NT$2 billion (US$60.6 million) is imposed on Taiwan insurers who wish to do so, in line with related requirements set by both the Taiwan and mainland authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: BSA LAUNCHES PETITION TO SHOW SUPPORT FOR IPR PROTECTION

TEXT.P: The Business Software Alliance (BSA), the Information Service Industry of the ROC (CISA) , the Taipei Computer Association and the Kaohsiung Computer Association jointly launched a one-week petition campaign Monday to show support for intellectual property rights (IPR) in a response to World IP Day, which falls on April 26.

Tsai Lien-sheng, head of the Intellectual Property Office under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, CISA Secretary-General Chang Kuo-hung and various other dignitaries took the lead in signing the petition.

BSA Chairman Sung Hung-ti said that the development of the software industry is crucial to whether Taiwan can be transformed into a knowledge-based society and that the future of the industry hinges on whether the government will provide incentives to encourage creativity and respect the development of intellectual property.

BSA officials said that government expenditure on information was US$451 million in 2001, accounting for 0.69 percent of the government's total expenditure, lower than Japan's 2.41 percent and the 1.14 percent of the United States.

Government expenditure on information in 2001 accounted for 0.78 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP), quite low compared with 4.05 percent in the United States, 3.76 percent in Britain, 2.42 percent in the European Union as a whole and 2.17 percent in Germany, the official said.

The signatories of the petition, who are hoping to collect at least 10,000 signatures, said they hope that related expenditure on information could reach 1 percent of the government's total expenditure and 2 percent of the GDP within three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM DENIES REPORTS ABOUT WTO CONCERNS OVER ADSL FEES

TEXT.P: Chunghwa Telecom Co. Chairman Ho-Chen Tan said Monday that the company has not received news of concern on the part of either the World Trade Organization (WTO) or any individual WTO member states about its broadband ADSL service rates.
Ho-Chen was commenting on newspaper claims that some multinational business groups have filed complaints with the WTO about Chunghwa Telecom's high ADSL service rates.
"The report was not factual, " Ho-Chen said categorically.

He further said the state-owned company is planning to open 8M (megabyte) ADSL services from June 1 at prices lower than those charged in Japan. At the moment, Japan's NTT Co. exacts about NT$1,450 for 8M ADSL services.
"Our 8M service rate will be announced after consulting with the Directorate General of Telecommunications," said Ho-Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SCHOLAR URGES ROC PRESIDENT TO SLOW DOWN ON CONSTITUTION PLAN

TEXT.P: A noted U.S. expert on China affairs said in Taipei Monday that he thinks President Chen Shui-bian should slow down the timetable for formulating a new constitution for Taiwan.

Ross Terrill, a professor at Harvard University's Fairbank Center for East Asian Research, is in Taipei to attend a seminar on Northeast Asia's future political and military development. Terrill was scheduled to meet with Chen Tuesday.

Terrill said in an interview with CNA that he will suggest that Chen slow down the pace of introducing a new constitution because "writing a new constitution is not as simple as giving the people a new car or a new house."

Chen has said on several occasions since his March 20 re-election that he will honor his campaign promise to write a new constitution in 2006 for implementation in 2008 through a referendum. Beijing has blasted Chen's plan as it regards the plan as a step toward declaring Taiwan independence or permanent separation from mainland China -- a move that could provoke a military attack by Beijing.
If Beijing does attack Taiwan, Terrill said, it would certainly inflict grave losses to the mainland, a worst-case scenario that is unlikely to happen in the foreseeable future.
Nevertheless, he said, Taiwan must still maintain its self-defense capabilities.

Since Chen has pledged to be a president for all the Taiwan people, Terrill went on, he must take the well-being and mainstream opinion of all Taiwan people into account while carrying out his reform agenda.
Even though Taiwan indeed needs a new constitution suitable for its present status quo, Terrill said, Beijing's leaders do not necessarily understand this need.
For mainland China, Terrill said, a change to Taiwan's Constitution would affect Beijing's theory that Taiwan is an integral part of the mainland.
For Taiwan's long-term development, Terrill said Chen should give priority to addressing Taiwan's social and economic development issues for the moment.
Although Chen won re-election by slightly more than half of the vote, Terrill said, he must first ascertain the people's true aspirations before moving toward writing a brand new constitution.
Meanwhile, Terrill went on that he does not think the U.S. government will forever insist on its "one China" policy.
He said developments in Hong Kong since its return to Beijing's rule have prompted some politicians in Washington, D.C. to dislike talking about "one China" any more.
Terrill further said the U.S. government has consistently stressed that Taiwan's future, regardless of unification or independence, should be determined by the people of Taiwan themselves.

As to whether the result of the U.S. presidential election this November will affect Taipei-Washington ties, Terrill said that if Senator John Kerry wins the election, Taiwan will have to be wary of Kerry's previous statement that he feels the "one country, two systems" formula would be good for Taiwan. Numerous opinion surveys have shown that Beijing's "one country, two systems" unification scheme is unacceptable to the majority of Taiwan people.
If incumbent President George W. Bush wins re-election, Terrill said, Taiwan-U.S. interaction will remain cordial.

Terrill was previously regarded as a pro-Beijing scholar, but his view on China changed fundamentally after the 1989 Tiananmen massacre in which Beijing used tanks to crush a student-led pro-democracy demonstration. Terrill then wrote a book titled "The New Chinese Empire, " which was nominated for the Los Angeles Times' annual book award.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANK LAW REVISED TO ACCOMMODATE ELECTRONIC CASH

TEXT.P: A committee at the Legislative Yuan introduced an amendment to the Law for Central Bank of China Monday to accommodate the possible issuance of electronic cash.

The Finance Committee of the Legislative Yuan adopted the proposal by Legislator Yin Nai-ping of the opposition People First Party to add a paragraph to the revised Law for the Central Bank of China to give the bank the authority to issue electronic cash.

Yin said the amendment, which was not initiated by the central bank, will lay the groundwork for dealing in electronic cash through e-commerce via the Internet, although the bank has no intention of launching any kind of electronic cash, such as prepaid credit cards, e-wallets, or value-stored cards.

Although some local banks have issued value-stored cards for their customers to pay parking fees or other small-ticket items, most local people still prefer to use paper currency, an anonymous bank official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY TO PHILIPPINES ISSUES TRAVEL WARNING FOR PHILIPPINES
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, April 19 (CNA) (By Emerson Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to the Philippines Wu Shin-hsing warned the Taiwan people Monday to avoid the Philippines in the wake of an attack on a building in Manila in which a foreign oil firm is located.

Wu issued the call after suspected communist guerrillas fired a rocket-propelled grenade a day earlier at a building in the Makati business district in which oil firm Philipinas Shell Petroleum Corp. is housed. The ROC representation -- the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Manila -- is just a few meters away from the building.

Wu warned the Taiwan people not to visit the Philippines in the run-up to its May 10 presidential and general elections, saying that the political situation and public order have become increasingly unstable.
Meanwhile, security measures in the buildings in which the ROC representative office and private staff residences are accommodated have been strengthened, he added.

Since December last year, a total of 114 people have been killed in election-related violence, while another 124 have been injured, the Philippine police authorities reported last week, pointing out that 31 of the violent incidents have taken place in the greater Manila area.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONETARY AUTHORITY OF SINGAPORE SHIFTS FOCUS TO MANAGING RISKS

TEXT.P: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said Monday it is shifting slightly away from its regulatory approach to a greater focus on managing risks within the banking system.

The MAS, Singapore's de facto central bank, said it would let a major financial institution fail if it were to get into financial trouble, under a supervisory approach outlined in a paper released Monday.
In issuing its latest mission statement, the MAS spelled out its objectives of supervision, the functions it performs, and the principles that guide its supervisory approach.
A key theme of the statement is that all stakeholders have a shared responsibility to achieve a sound and progressive financial services sector.

It said its supervisory approach is aimed at making it clear that as long as risks are well managed, financial institutions can have greater freedom to offer more diverse and complex products and services.

DOC.HEADLINE: CULTURAL AFFAIRS OFFICIALS VISIT HOLY SEE

TEXT.P: Council for Cultural Affairs Vice Chairman Wu Mi-cha and other officials visited the Vatican Museums and the Italian Culture Department Monday to observe its documentation storage procedures.
Wu and his group arrived in Rome April 17 for a four-day visit.
They will pay a visit to the Holy See's library to exchange views on secret filing before leaving for Germany April 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: 89-YEAR-OLD TAKING ANOTHER GO AT QUITTING SMOKING IN CONTEST

TEXT.P: Some may joke that it's never too late to start smoking, but for 89-year-old Huang He-ping, it's never too late to quit.
Huang is the oldest participant in Taipei's "quit and win" competition aimed at getting people to stop smoking cigarettes.

Huang said Monday that as a smoker for the past 73 years, "I've quit smoking more than 300 times, but haven't succeeded yet in really stopping." He said that this time might be the one, given that there is a big case prize as an incentive.

Huang, who worked as reporter and policeman when he was young, said that the high pressure of the two jobs started him smoking. He used to smoke a pack and half of cigarettes a day, and still smokes around a dozen cigarettes daily.

"Quitting smoking is like writing an article, and one has to undergo some excruciating trial, " Huang said, adding that the best way to quit smoking is to go to public places where you can't bother others with your smoking. But the urge to smoke surfaces later, he added, when you get back home or go outdoors.
He said that going cold turkey has never worked for him and only led to heavier smoking. Cutting back gradually is Huang's advice.

Huang's wife said that her husband did quit smoking several times, but could only manage to abstain from tobacco for four or five days at a stretch. She said that the "quit and win" competition has given him the motivation to "give it a try one more time."
The Taipei event is one of the "quit and win" competitions held islandwide in conjunction with the World No Tobacco Day on May 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW REGULATIONS HELPING TREE PROTECTION IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: One year after the implementation of Taipei's tree-protection regulations, the city's Cultural Affairs Bureau is happy to see that the concept of protecting trees is more widespread among the public.
A tree protection committee inaugurated last August has convened several meetings and reviewed 23 cases, saving a great many old trees in the process.

Committee members recalled their first case, which involved the Shihpai Elementary School in Peitou when the school and a construction company decided that they would fell six small-leaf figs to make way for new classrooms and underground parking lots.
However, scholars and experts intervened and after discussions, saved the six trees, proving that campus construction can co-exist with green resources.

The most notable case of community involvement involved the protection of an old tree in Chitung Street. Two elementary school students wrote to Liao Hsien-hao, then director of Taipei's Cultural Affairs Bureau, and attached with the letter the signatures of local community residents and arts and literary figures. Their efforts helped a 50-year-old lungan tree from being cut down by a construction company.

Liao met with environmental experts, elementary school students, and community representatives to exchange experiences in protecting trees Monday in a press conference marking the first anniversary of the passing of the tree-protection regulations.

He said that the bureau is now mulling several measures to help trees, including setting up a file for protected trees, nurturing and training of tree rangers, preserving green resources of old Japanese dormitories, and planning trails by old trees in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH CONDUCTING SURVEY ON HEALTH OF BABIES BORN TO FOREIGN BRIDES

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) said Monday it is conducting a large-scale survey on the health situation of infants born to foreign and mainland Chinese brides married to Taiwan men.

"The survey is expected to help us clarify misinformation or misperceptions about health conditions of babies born to foreign and mainland brides, " said an official with the DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion.

There have been media reports that foreign and mainland brides are more likely to give birth to physically or mentally-challenged children. "Such reports may be just a result of bias," the official said.

Quoting official tallies, the official said, 244,228 new births were reported in 2002, of which 242,105 were live births. Among the newborns, 8 percent weighed less than 2,500 grams and 9 percent were prematurely born.

In the same year, 31,296 mainland and foreign brides gave birth and 31,124 of them were live births. Among live babies born to foreign and mainland brides, only 6.6 percent weighed below the standard and 6.8 percent were prematurely born.
In 2001, the officials said, the ratios of live births and premature births by mainland and foreign brides showed similar trends to those recorded in 2002.
Between 2001 and 2002, the official said, babies born to foreign and mainland brides accounted for 10 percent to 12 percent of the total newborns.

Official tallies showed that the ratios of stillbirths and premature births by Taiwan-born brides were all higher than the ratios recorded by mainland and foreign brides during the same period, the official noted.

He said this phenomenon could be attributed in part to the fact that the average childbearing age of Taiwan women has become older than previously while foreign and mainland brides are generally younger.

With a view to clarify an apparently biased perception that mainland and foreign brides are more likely to give birth to handicapped or mentally-challenged children, the official said the Bureau of Health Promotion is conducting a mass survey on health conditions of babies born to foreign and mainland brides.

"We should avoid classifying foreign and mainland brides in terms of unfounded speculation or misperception. Pigeon-holing will only prevent us from helping people overcome language barriers and assimilate into local society," the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY TO MALAYSIA SURE OF PUBLIC ORDER IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, April 19 (CNA) (By Y. P. Chin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia Representative Wu Wen-ya called on the Malaysian people Monday to visit or invest in Taiwan as in the past, as public order is fine in Taiwan.
Wu made the remarks at an alumni gathering attended by social elite of Chinese original who are graduates from Taiwan-based universities.

Giving his assurances that the political situation in Taiwan has fully stabilized and that there is no need to worry about public order, Wu urged Malaysians to visit and to invest in Taiwan as they did in the past because everything has returned to normal following the recent disputes over the March 20 presidential election.

According to Wu, bilateral trade and investments between Taiwan and Malaysia have been close and steady. Taiwan is Malaysia's fifth-largest trading partner, while Malaysia is Taiwan's eighth-largest trading partner.

Last year, the two-way trade totaled US$7.8 billion, up by 7.1 percent over the 2002 level with Malaysia enjoying a trade surplus of US$3 billion. The figure for the first three months of this year hit around US$2.1 billion, thanks to an economic recovery taking shape in both countries since the fourth quarter of last year.

In 2003, Malaysia approved US$1.06 billion worth of Taiwan investments, an increase of 14.7 percent over the 2002 level. Taiwan's accumulative investment totals US$9.4 billion, making the island the third-largest foreign investor in Malaysia only after the United States and Japan.

Wu hailed the outstanding performance in Malaysia of the Chinese elite with educational backgrounds in Taiwan, especially their roles in boosting trade and economic exchanges between the two countries, and he also thanked them for their efforts in promoting the rights of ethnic Chinese in Malaysia.

In a similar meeting in Malacca, Wu also appealed for support of the participants and asked them to get backing from the Malaysian government for Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO). Taiwan is applying to enter the world body as a health entity, which he pointed out has nothing to do with the dispute related to Taiwan's sovereignty.
The WHO is slated to hold its 57th General Assembly on May 17 in Geneva.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SECRETARY-GENERAL LIN FONG-CHENG QUITS OVER ELECTION LOSS

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng quit Monday to take responsibility for the party's failure in the March 20 presidential election, according to a KMT official.

The anonymous KMT official said Lin submitted his letter of resignation Monday morning to KMT Chairman Lien Chan and took a leave of absence from Tuesday to give Lien a free hand in reshuffling the KMT leadership.
Lien ran on the KMT ticket for president but lost to incumbent President Chen Shui-bian by a slim margin. Lin was his chief of staff.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROFESSOR DENIES BEING NAMED TAIWAN REPRESENTATIVE TO HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 19 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Political science professor Byron S. J. Weng with National Chi Nan University in central Taiwan denied Monday that he has been appointed to be Taiwan's new representative to Hong Kong.

Weng, formerly a professor with the Chinese University of Hong Kong and currently an adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, denied a report carried in the Hong Kong Economic Journal Monday that he has been appointed by the Taiwan authorities to replace Chang Liang-jen, managing director of Chung Hwa Travel Service, Taiwan's de facto liaison office in Hong Kong. Chung Hwa Travel Service is an agency under the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.
Responding by phone about the report, Weng gave a direct denial, saying, "There is absolutely no such thing."
In addition, Chung Hwa Travel Service Managing Director Chang Liang-jen also denied the report, describing it as a fabrication.
Chang declined to comment on any allegations regarding any changes, saying only that presently he is focusing his energy and attention on operations of the Chung Hwa Travel Service.

Weng was one of the members of an official delegation sent by President Chen to Europe in January this year to explain the president's efforts to have a nationwide referendum held in March amid concerns expressed by major powers around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved down against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, losing NT$0.05 to close at NT$32.925.
A total of US$460 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.975 and slid to a low of NT$32.915.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTED PESTS POSING INCREASING THREAT TO TAIWAN AGRICULTURE

TEXT.P: A tiny intruder from mainland China is costing pear-growers in Taiwan dearly this year and consumers may be paying more at the grocery store for the fruit soon.

Cacopsylla qianli -- first brought into Taiwan in 2001 by fruit growers when illegally importing pear seedlings from mainland China -- is eating out pear blossoms in major pear orchards across Taiwan, literally nipping pear growth in the bud for this season, agriculture sources said Monday.

Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine (BAPHIQ) of the Council of Agriculture (COA) has responded by putting about 4,800 hectares of pear orchards under a pest prevention program.
The pear-damaging pest is far from the only problem in Taiwan.

Pomacea canaliculata, or golden apple snails, which were misguidedly introduced into Taiwan as a potential food resource more than 20 years ago, have become one of the most deadly pests in Taiwan's rice paddies and other aquatic plantations.

Golden apple snails have caused so much damage to Taiwan crops that even a NT$130 million (US$3.93 million) COA annual budget has made little difference. The problem is so sever that the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum has decided to convene an international symposium on Pomacea canaliculata control and prevention in Taiwan this coming October.

Mikania micrantha Kunth, a vine-like plant that is known as the "green cancer" and was inadvertently imported in 1970, has been causing major biological damage to Taiwan's forests ever since. The weed spreads rapidly, blanketing the canopies of any other plant and effectively blocks the host from receiving enough light to survive.

The Pine Wood Nematode, an imported quarantine pest infesting pine trees and causing wilt disease, has been threatening the healthy forestation of pine trees in mountainous areas around the island, agricultural sources said.
Fire ants, a newcomer first identified in Taiwan only last October, are now directly affecting people, animals, plants and crops.
Among many others, those pests and species have not only caused great damage to local crops, they have also hampered normal development of the entire ecology of Taiwan.

Yeh Ying, BAPHIQ deputy director, attributed the increasing intrusion of imported pest species into Taiwan's environment and agriculture mainly to increasing globalization, closer exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China, and the fact that people in Taiwan have been active travelers overseas.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Monday are as follows:
The China Times:
The Control Yuan plans to impeach Examination Yuan members over civil servant examination disputes.
The United Daily News:
WTO expresses concern about high ADSL charges.
The Liberty Times:
The United States begins recording flow of weapons sold to Taiwan in order to prevent them from being leaked to China.
The Taiwan Daily:
President Chen meets with TSU Chairman Huang Chu-wen to discuss legislative election strategy.
The Central Daily News:
KMT blames Chen for widening ethnic divisions.
The China Post:
Major projects bill to be passed: gov't.
The Taiwan News:
Israel assassinates Hamas leader.
The Taipei Times:
KMT shields Ma against Soong snipe.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN VOWS TO UPGRADE TAIWAN-U.S. TIES IN MEETING WITH MONTANA GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday Taiwan has consistently attached great importance to its relations with the United States and that he will work even harder during his second four-year term to further boost bilateral ties.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with Montana Governor Judy Martz who is heading a delegation of Montana State officials on a trade promotion visit in Taiwan.
"We treasure our relations with the United States. In the next four years, we'll make continued efforts to further upgrade Taiwan-U.S. relations," Chen told his guest.
He further said his administration will make its communications channels with U.S. authorities even smoother than before.

"In the coming four years, I'll focus on promoting economic development and political reforms. In any event, we hope that Taiwan's success story will be an asset, rather than a liability, for the United States," Chen stressed.
For her part, Martz congratulated Chen on his re-election and invited Chen to visit Montana in the near future.

Martz, an accomplished ice skater, was previously Montana's first female lieutenant governor. She was finally elected as the state's first female governor. Chen lauded Martz for her achievements in creating jobs, promoting educational reforms and controlling budget deficits during her tenure.

Chen said Montana has maintained cordial relations with Taiwan. He expressed his gratitude for the passage of resolutions by the Montana State Senate and State House of Representatives last year in support of Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization.

Taiwan is Montana's fifth-largest trading partner. Montana has maintained a representative office in Taipei since the early 1980s. A Taiwan trade delegation signed a preliminary agreement on procurement of wheat from Montana during its visit to the U.S. state last year.

"All these point to close trade ties between Taiwan and Montana," Chen said, adding he believes that Martz's current visit will contribute to further growth in Taiwan-Montana trade and economic cooperation.

New Minister of Foreign Affairs Mark Chen was also present at the meeting. It marked the first time that Mark Chen has accompanied a foreign dignitary to see President Chen since Mark Chen assumed office last Friday.

Mark Chen, a U.S.-trained physicist-turned-politician, had worked at the U.S. federal government for many years before he returned to Taiwan in the early 1990s. President Chen said Mark Chen's appointment shows Taiwan's determination to further upgrade its relations with the United States.

Mark Chen succeeded Eugene Chien, who resigned over fallout surrounding the recent resignation of the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of official diplomatic ties -- American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen.
Douglas Paal, director of the AIT Taipei office or the de facto U.S. ambassador to Taiwan, was also present at President Chen's meeting with Martz.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 19, or the first day of the third month of the Year of Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1832: Jose Echegaray y Eizaguirre, Spanish dramatist, mathematician, statesman and Nobel laureate, is born.
1853: Russia claims to be the protectorate of Turkey in a prelude to the Crimean War.
1882: British naturalist Charles Darwin dies at the age of 73. He revolutionized the study of biology with his theory of evolution based on natural selection. His most famous works include "Origin of Species" and "The Descent of Man."
1906: French chemist and physicist Pierre Curie is run over and killed in Paris at the age of 47. He and his wife Marie shared the 1903 Nobel Prize for fundamental research into radioactivity.
1928: Japanese troops occupy Shantung Province in northern China.
1942: Chinese Expeditionary Forces led by Gen. Sun Li-jen capture Yenangyuang in northern Burma, rescuing more than 7,000 British and Burmese troops from Japanese encirclement.
1948: The first National Assembly elects Chiang Kai-shek as the Republic of China's first president under the new ROC Constitution, garnering 2,430 out of 2,704 votes.
1956: Prince Rainier of Monaco marries American screen actress Grace Kelly in Monte Carlo. Over 1,200 guests attend the televised Catholic wedding ceremony.
1959: The Dalai Lama, the Tibetan leader fleeing a Communist Chinese invasion of his country, finds sanctuary in India.
1960: South Korean President Syngman Rhee is toppled in a nationwide pro-democracy student uprising that was protesting election fraud.
1966: Australian troops leave Sydney to join American forces in Vietnam.
1974: The Blood Donation Association of the Republic of China is inaugurated.
1975: India's first satellite is launched by a Soviet rocket.
1977: ROC Education Minister Tsiang Yien-si resigns to take responsibility for an incident in which 32 college students and teachers were killed when their boat capsized near Suao Port in eastern Taiwan. Tsiang was succeeded by Li Yuan-zu.
1992: Dutch Minister of Foreign Trade Yvonne van Rooy visits Taipei to seek stronger bilateral relations.
1993: A total of 87 Branch Davidian cult members, including their leader David Koresh, are killed when federal agents storm their compound in Waco, Texas, after a 51-day standoff. Nine other members are freed.
1995: A huge truck bomb destroys the Alfred P. Murrah government building in Oklahoma City, killing 168 people and injuring more than 400 others.
1995: Malawi President Bakili Muluzi pays a state visit to Taipei.
1997: The S.S. Sheng Da, a mainland China container freighter, steams into Kaohsiung Port on its maiden voyage, becoming the first ship to sail directly to Taiwan from the mainland in 48 years, and completing a historic crossing of one of the world's great political divides.
1999: Tsai Shun-fa, 52, known as "Bean Curd Papa," is honored by Premier Vincent Siew for donating blood 495 times over 20 years.
1999: The Republic of China-Swaziland Conference on Economical and Technological Cooperation opens in Taipei.
2000: Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, says that if Beijing bullies Taiwanese doing business in mainland China, it will hurt both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian promises that his administration will help the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau transform itself into a "National Bureau of Investigation."
2001: Former ROC Premier Vincent Siew says that he will file an application with the government for a visit to mainland China to pitch for the formation of a "common market" across the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be not concerned that men do not know you; be concerned that you have no ability."

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY LAUNCHES ANNUAL HAN KUANG EXERCISES

TEXT.P: The military has launched routine annual training exercises to evaluate the nation's defense capabilities in the face of mainland China's mounting military threat, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Tuesday.

Speaking at a regular news conference, MND spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said the maneuvers, codenamed Han Kuang 20, will test the joint operations command mechanism of the armed forces over a seven-month period.

"The drills, designed to test coordination among the different branches of our armed forces, started in mid-April and are due to end in November, " Huang said, adding that the focus of this year's Han Kuang exercise is to gauge Taiwan's ability to crush the enemy's attempt to wage a quick war.
The maneuvers will include a computerized war game, live-fire drills and missile testing, said Maj. Gen. Lee Chieh-chia, joint operations head at the deputy chief of the general staff's office.

Lee said the computerized war game will be held in late June, with the National Defense University acting as the enemy and providing simulated mainland Chinese assault strategies. The simulated war game will be based on the estimated military capabilities of Taiwan and the mainland China by 2006, he added.

He further said that war of the future will be non-linear, non-contact and asymmetric in form. "It's very likely that mainland China will invade Taiwan with a surprise attack, " he said, adding that various kinds of new weaponry will be tested in the war games.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INSTRUCTS LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES TO CURB CRIME

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian instructed law enforcement agencies Tuesday to do their best to curb crime, especially fraud and false kidnappings.

Speaking at a weekly meeting of the Central Standing Committee of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in his capacity as DPP chairman, Chen said that the recent widespread cases of fraud and hoax kidnappings using telephone networks have caused panic among the general public and have seriously affected people's daily lives.

Law enforcement agencies, including the police and the prosecutors' offices, should make concerted efforts to fight these forms of crime and bring the perpetrators to justice without mercy, Chen directed.

With regard to the rioting in the aftermath of the March 20 presidential election, Chen urged law enforcement authorities to investigate the cases and bring swiftly to justice those who tried to create chaos in society under the guise of democracy.

Along with the approaching legislative elections to be held in December, the law enforcement authorities should also increase their efforts to eliminate vote-buying in order to create a sound environment for clean elections.
The rule of law is the foundation of a democratic society, the president stressed, adding that the basic rights of the people must be protected.
He also called on supporters of the opposition "pan blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) to allow the election disputes to be settled by the judicial authorities.

The "pan blue alliance" supporters have staged a series of sometimes violent protest rallies in the wake of the presidential poll, which they describe as "unfair" after their candidate, Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, lost to Chen by a slim margin of 0.22 percent or 29,518 votes out of more than 13 million cast.

DOC.HEADLINE: Q1 TELECOMMUNICATIONS INDUSTRY OUTPUT VALUE TOPS NT$88 BILLION

TEXT.P: The production value of the domestic telecommunications industry in the first quarter hit NT$88.86 billion (US$2.7 billion), up by 28.9 percent over the previous year's level, the Industrial Technology Information Service (ITIS) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Tuesday.

The wireless telecommunications sector posted a strong annual growth rate of 37 percent with an output value of NT$57.88 billion, while the broadband sector also grew by 16.1 percent to NT$30.98 billion, according to the ITIS -- a project funded by the MOEA.

Boosted by an economic recovery around the world, global demand for telecommunications facilities is set to surge, fueling the production value of the domestic industry to increase by 35 percent to NT$421.21 billion for the whole of 2004, according to the ITIS forecast.

The wireless telecommunications sector is expected to enjoy a 47 percent annual growth rate in production value, which will hit NT$292.38 billion for the whole of this year, while the figure for the broadband sector is estimated to expand by 10.7 percent to NT$124.83 billion, the ITIS report predicts.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER NAVY CHIEF ACQUITTED OF SHIELDING CORRUPT SUBORDINATES

TEXT.P: The former commander-in-chief of the navy, retired Adm. Yeh Chang-tung, who was indicted for smothering a case of corruption on the part of two junior officers during his term as navy chief, was acquitted Tuesday of the charge of shielding corrupt subordinates.

The Taipei District Court ruled that Yeh did not bring the two junior officers to justice because their trial, even in a military court at that time, would have exposed the navy's secret purchase of four minesweepers from Germany and might have spoiled the whole deal to the detriment of the country.

Furthermore, the judgment said, a military prosecutors' investigation at that time concluded that the behavior of the two junior officers did not constitute a crime and therefore, the admiral's decision to discipline the two and force them to retire was not unreasonable.

The charge against one of the two junior officers in the case, retired Commander Yuan Yu-fan, was thrown out because he was still a naval officer when he committed the alleged crime and was under investigation by the navy. Therefore, he is beyond the jurisdiction of the civilian courts, according to the judgment of the Taipei District Court.

The other officer, retired Lieutenant Commander Peng Chi-kang, was acquitted on a charge of corruption on the grounds that he had "no idea" that 2,600 German marks he shared with Yuan were illegal gains.
The case arose from the navy's purchase of four minesweepers from Germany in 1986.
As an officer involved in the deal, Yuan embezzled some 7,000 marks between 1991 and 1992 and gave 1,300 marks to Peng, who helped him withdraw the money from a British bank.
Yeh was indicted in 2001 for covering up for Yuan and Peng.
However, the case was only a sideshow in prosecutors' search for alleged kickbacks involved in the country's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates from France in 1991.
In that case, the alleged kickbacks have remained elusive, despite a four-year investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE OUT OF 5.5 COUPLES IN MIXED MARRIAGE: DGBAS

TEXT.P: One out of every 5.5 couples who got married in the first quarter of this year in Taiwan are mixed, either foreigner and Taiwanese or mainland Chinese and Taiwanese, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Tuesday.

A total of 46,416 couples got married in the first three months of 2004, up by 4.5 percent compared to the previous year's level, according to DGBAS statistics. A total of 3,568 Taiwan residents married spouses from the mainland, Hong Kong or Macau during the period, while 4,929 tied the knot with foreigners, mainly women from countries in Southeast Asia.
A majority of foreign brides who have applied to be naturalized as Republic of China nationals are from Vietnam and Cambodia, the tallies show.

In 2003, 1,465 foreigners received ROC citizenship, with 1,360 of them getting naturalized through marriage to Taiwanese men or women, marking a 4.4 percent fall from the 2002 level. Of the 1,306 foreign husbands and wives, 408 and 317 are from Vietnam and Cambodia, respectively.

In addition, 15,161 couples got divorced during the three-month period, the statistics point out. A total of 2,155 Taiwan residents divorced their spouses from Greater China, while 803 divorced their spouses from other foreign countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CITIZEN SEEKS HELP TO STAY IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An American citizen who has overstayed his resident certificate in Taiwan for eight years and faces the threat of deportation sought the assistance of a Taichung county councilor Tuesday to help him obtain permanent residency or citizenship in Taiwan.
George Laverne Jennings Jr., 28, said he is willing to give up his American citizenship so long as he can legally stay in Taiwan to care for his Taiwanese mother.

Jennings, who has lived in Taichung County's Tantzu township in central Taiwan with his mother for many years, visited Taichung County Councilor Lin Chu-wang Tuesday to ask for his help in resolving the residency problem.

Jennings was born in Colorado in 1976 to an American father and a Taiwanese mother. His father, a soldier stationed at Chingchuankang airbase in central Taiwan, married his mother in Taichung in 1971 and the couple returned to the United States in 1975.
Jennings' mother took him back to Taiwan after his father died in 1984. He has since lived in Tantzu and has completed elementary, junior high and senior high school education.

His residence certificate expired eight years ago, but he never paid any attention to the matter and the residency issue surfaced only after he went to see a doctor recently and came to learn that he was not covered by the national health insurance program.

Some people have suggested that Jennings, who is nicknamed "Hsiao Hai," should apply for ROC citizenship, but he must first resolve his overstay issue. According to the nation's newly revised naturalization law, Jennings has to leave Taiwan for eight years before he can come to Taiwan again to apply for ROC citizenship.

Lin said Jennings is a very filial son and has assisted his mother, now in her 60s, in managing a barber's shop. Lin said he hopes the relevant government agencies can help Jennings resolve his residency and identification problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG PEOPLE LOSING CONFIDENCE IN BEIJING: SURVEY
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 20 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The people of Hong Kong have lost confidence in Beijing following a ruling by its National People's Congress (NPC) on their demand for electoral reform in the special administrative region, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday.

According to the poll results made public by the University of Hong Kong, a set of confidence indexes toward the central government in Beijing among the people of Hong Kong have all dropped since the NPC ruled that any political reforms in the former British colony must be approved in advance by Beijing, including their demand to directly elect their chief executive and all lawmakers.

The poll finds that 29 percent of the people surveyed -- a rise of 6 percent compared to a similar survey carried out in February -- claim they have no confidence in the future of Hong Kong, a contrast to 58 percent who hold the opposite view.
About 28 percent of the respondents said they have confidence in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region government -- a fall of 6 percent from the February survey.

At the same time, 38 percent of the respondents said that they believe in the central government in Beijing, a 5 percent decline from the February level, while 25 percent said that they do not believe in the Beijing regime, an increase of 3 percent, the survey shows.

In addition, some 37 percent -- a rise of 10 percent -- said they do not have confidence in the "one country, two systems" formula put into practice for Beijing's rule of Hong Kong, while 50 percent expressed confidence in the system.
The poll was conducted in the middle of this month and surveyed a total of 1,022 local residents.
The ruling passed by the NPC prompted about 20,000 people to take to the streets April 11 in Hong Kong to protest Beijing's refusal to hear their clamor for electoral reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPTOELECTRONICS TO REACH NT$1 TRILLION PRODUCTION VALUE THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: the production value of the domestic optoelectronics industry in 2004 will be over one trillion new Taiwan dollars (US$30.3 billion) , according to a report by the Industrial Technology Information Services (ITIS) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Production value in the first quarter of 2004 will reach NT$234.16 billion, an increase of 19.1 percent year-on-year, with the whole year's value to account for NT$1 trillion, a rise of 33.4 percent from the previous year, according to the ITIS.

Based on the ITIS forecast, flat panel displays will have the biggest operation value and the highest growth due to the global economic recovery and fifth-generation TFT-LCD (thin film transistor liquid crystal display) and STN-LCD (super twisted numeric liquid crystal display) production lines. The production value in the first quarter of this year stood at NT$132.33 billion, an increase of 27 percent year-on-year, with estimated annual value up to NT$551.87 billion, a surge of 63.6 percent from the previous year.

In the optoelectronics components field, the production value in the first quarter of 2004 amounted to NT$9.69 billion, a rise of 15.9 percent year-on-year, with estimated yearly value of NT$52.8 billion, an increase of 34.7 percent from 2003, attributable to expanded production of white and blue LEDs (light emitting diodes) and the increasing popularity of digital imaging.

The optical storage sector is also performing well, as Japanese competitors in DVDs and DVD drives have ceased production and subcontracted Taiwan manufacturers. The annual production value will be up to NT$276.19 billion, a rise of 12.7 percent from a year earlier.

The optical input field is also performing optimistically thanks to high demand for digital cameras and steady consumption of scanners and PC cameras. The first quarter of 2004 accounted for NT$30.89 billion, an increase of 12 percent, with estimated yearly value standing at NT$124.07 billion, an increase of 9.4 percent from the previous year.

The optical output field, however, might not do so well, as the fax machine business is declining, although ink printers are still popular. The first quarter of 2004 saw NT$5.69 billion in production value, a decrease of 3.2 percent year-on-year, with estimated value this year at NT$24.07 billion, a drop of 9.4 percent from a year earlier.
