DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO FLESH OUT NEW CONSTITUTION PLAN IN INAUGURAL SPEECH

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will expound on his plan to write a new constitution for Taiwan in 2006 in his inaugural speech to be delivered May 20, Minister of Foreign Affairs Mark Chen said Tuesday.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with lawmakers of the opposition People First Party (PFP) . The meeting marked the first time the new foreign minister had visited the PFP legislative caucus since he assumed office last Friday.
During the meeting, PFP legislators expressed concern about the president's insistence on formulating a new constitution.

To the best of his understanding, Chen said, the president's new constitution initiative will be carried out under the cardinal principle of safeguarding the Republic of China's sovereign status with no fundamental change to Taiwan's present status quo.

"Writing a new constitution is basically aimed at making the existing Constitution more reasonable and complete, " Chen said, adding that the president is expected to flesh out his new constitution plan when he takes the oath May 20 for his second four-year term.

President Chen has said on many occasions before and after the March 20 presidential election that he wants to rewrite the Constitution to restructure the government and make it more streamlined and efficient. According to the president's plan, the new constitution would go into effect May 20, 2008, when the next president takes office.

PFP lawmakers said they are concerned about the plan because Beijing regards a new constitution as a step toward de jure Taiwan independence -- a move that could provoke a Beijing attack on the island.

Touching on the ROC's foreign policy, Chen said continuity and predictability are critical features of a country's foreign policy. Therefore, he said, the nation's foreign policy will not change significantly in the coming years.

The minister assured the PFP lawmakers that he will promote the nation's external relations in line with the principles of safeguarding the ROC's sovereign status, maintaining peace in the Taiwan Strait and participating in major international organizations and activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEGOTIATIONS AMONG VARIOUS PARTIES ON LEGISLATIVE REFORM ABORTED

TEXT.P: Political negotiations among various parties at the Legislative Yuan over the downsizing of the legislature did not begin Tuesday because of the absence of lawmakers from two leading opposition parties, the Kuomitnang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP).
Representatives of the two parties didn't show up at all, although they had agreed in principle to cut the number of the seats in the legislature by a half.

Legislator Yu Ching, one of the two Democratic Progressive Party representatives to the negotiations said unless the negotiations were completed before April 23, the chance of passing a constitutional amendment proposal to halve the number of lawmakers in this legislative session would be slim, so is the likelihood of having an election of a National Assembly along with the year-end legislative elections.
Only the National Assembly has the power to vote on constitutional amendment proposals.

Other negotiations over a proposal by the KMT and PFP to set up a committee at the Legislative Yuan to examine the government's response to the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian was stalled too because of the opposition of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).
TSU Legislator Chen Chien-ming said his party would back the two opposition parties' idea only if they would support the formation of a committee to examine the KMT's ill-gotten assets.

However, these parties did agree to set up a committee to review the government's decision in choosing a company to operate an electronic toll-charge system on the country's two freeways, and another committee to review decisions by the Ministry of Finance to take over eight failed credit cooperatives.
The two committees will be composed of lawmakers from different parties in proportion to their seats in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN TO CONTINUE MINE CLEARING TO HELP PROMOTE TOURISM

TEXT.P: Kinmen will continue minesweeping operation along the seashore of the outlying islets of Kinmen to help the development of its tourism industry, Kinmen County Government officials said Tuesday.

The officials said that mines were deployed to defend mainland China's attack on Kinmen, but with the easing of cross-strait relations after the opening of direct trade and transportation links between Kinmen and Fujian province in 2001, the mines have become obstacles to develop local tourism.

At the requests of the Kinmen county council, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) has since 1998 cleared 16 mined areas covering 65,000 square meters, and will again review mine clearing in the offshore areas of the islets.
According to the MND plan, it will appropriate NT$468 million (US$14.1 million) between 2006 and 2008 to clear 15 mine areas, including 12 in Kinmen and three others in the outlying island of Matsu.

Officials from the Kinmen County Government and Garrison Command on Tuesday began an inspection tour of the outlying islets of Kinmen, hoping to set a priority for mine cleaning so that the operation will coordinate with the local development.

The Kinmen Garrison Command said that the next wave of mine clearing will cover around 317,000 square meters, and that the tourism development and safety of residents will be the top consideration in deciding which areas will be cleared first.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY WILL ACT ACCORDINGLY ON VIETNAM TOURISTS TO SPRATLYS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense will act in line with the government's policy regarding the Vietnamese government's sending tourists to the disputed Spratly Islands in the South China Sea, an defense ministry spokesman said Tuesday.

Military spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng made the remarks in the wake of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs statement Monday to convey the government's serious concern about the tourist ship carrying 60 tourists and 40 invited officials to Hanoi's military outposts on the Spratly Islands after leaving port from Ho Chi Minh City.

Foreign ministry officials said that the ministry has called Hoang Nhu Ly, Vietnam's representative in Taipei, twice to urge him to convey to the Vietnamese government the message that it should exercise self-restraint so as not to trigger regional tensions.
Huang noted that the foreign ministry has expressed its stance to Vietnam and that the defense ministry will act according to government policy.
He stressed that the ministry has a contingency plan "to protect our territorial claims."

On the complaints by the Coast Guard Administration, which is in charge of the defense of the Spratly Islands, that the air defense equipment and ammunitions left by the Republic of China military are old and dilapidated, he said the ministry will address the issue.

Wire reports said the Vietnamese government's announcement in late March that it had decided to open the disputed archipelago to tour groups, has drawn concern from Taiwan, mainland China, Malaysia, the Philippines and Brunei, all of which claim all or part of the island group.

Former Minister of the Interior Yu Chen-hsien traveled to the uninhabited Chungchou Reef in August 2003 to raise a national flag of the Republic of China in a show of Taiwan's territorial claim over the Spratly Islands, which straddle vital shipping lanes and fishing grounds and are believed to contain vast oil and gas reserves.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH MINISTER TO LEAD LOBBY GROUP TO WHA ANNUAL MEETING

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Chen Chien-jen is scheduled to lead a mission for Geneva next month to lobby for international support for Taiwan's bid to become an observer of the World Health Assembly (WHA).

Chen's official delegation, as well as several Taiwan groups, will be in Geneva to enhance the lobby drive during the 57th annual conference of the WHA, marking the eighth time in a row that Taiwan will try to become a WHA observer.

Government sources declined to disclose Chen's exact itinerary in Geneva on the grounds that Beijing is expected to continue this year to obstruct Taiwan's bid to join the WHA -- the highest decision-making body of the World Health Organization (WHO) -- as an observer.

According to Wu Shu-min, chairman of the private Foundation of Medical Professionals Alliance in Taiwan, more than 100 people from Taiwan, including officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, are expected to go to Geneva this year to amplify Taiwan's bid to obtain observer status at the WHA.

American Congressman Steve Chabot, a Republican from the state of Ohio, submitted a draft bill to the House of Representatives March 24, saying it is absolutely imperative that Taiwan joins WHO activities after the island was hard hit by outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and bird flu, and advocated that Taiwan be admitted into the WHO family at least as an observer.

Meanwhile, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs official said that at least five of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies will publicly support Taiwan's WHA bid during the annual conference to be held in Geneva May 17-22.

Health representatives of the Gambia, Burkina Faso, Malawi, Senegal and Chad will speak during the assembly meeting in support of Taiwan, said Chang Pei-chi, director of MOFA's Department of African Affairs.

MOFA spokesman Richard Shih also said Tuesday that the Republic of China is a sovereign state and the notion of taking part in the WHO or WHA activities as a member or an observer is a consensus reached by all political parties and all walks of life in Taiwan.
Shih added that Taiwan's WHA bid is a humanitarian issue which should not be politicized by any group of people in the world.

Taiwan's WHA bid failed for the seventh time in May 2003 when the 56th annual conference of the WHA opened in Geneva and the WHA Steering Committee refused to put the issue of Taiwan's WHA status on its agenda.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NATIONALS IN IVORY COAST SAFE: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Twenty-eight Republic of China nationals residing in Ivory Coast are safe and sound, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Tuesday.

Chang Pei-chi, director-general of the foreign ministry's Department of African Affairs, made the remarks after recent bloody clashes between the ruling and the opposition parties after the latter staged a large-scale protest March 26 in Abidjan.

Chang said the tensions in Ivory Coast are eased, and the foreign ministry has asked the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Far East Trade Service, Inc. branch office in Ivory Coast to closely monitor development and if it deteriorates, the office will start contingency plans to protect the ROC nationals.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved up against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.020 to close at NT$32.945.
A total of US$591 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$33.000 and fell to a low of NT$32.935.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPROVING U.S.-TAIWAN RELATIONS A TOP PRIORITY: VICE PRESIDENT LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Tuesday that one of the key priorities of the government will be to strengthen bilateral relations with the United States.
Lu made the remarks when she met with Washington State Lieutenant Governor Brad Owen and other leaders of the state legislature.

Asked about priority tasks of the government after the March 20 presidential election, which saw President Chen Shu-bian and Lu win another four-year term, the vice president spoke of the strengthening of relations with the United States.
She also spoke of the quick return to peace and normality on Taiwan's political scene.

Post-election rows have persisted because Lien Chan of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" has yet to concede defeat in what he claimed was a "unfair election" marred by voting irregularities and an election-eve shooting of the president and the vice president that he said swayed the bitterly contested election in Chen's favor. Chen won by a razor-thin margin of 29,518 votes out of more than 13 million cast.
Taipei also hopes to work with Beijing toward promoting cross-strait peace and stability, the vice president said.

She also took the chance to thank the treatment given to her and her entourage last year when she passed through Washington State, and said that she was especially touched to see Seattle Port Authorities raise the national flag of the Republic of China.
Lu said she hoped that Owen's visit will help increase the understanding and support of Taiwan, and further substantial exchanges between Taiwan and the United States.
Owen noted that his state has close ties with Taiwan and is the 11th-largest trading partner for Taiwan, while Taiwan is the fifth-largest trading partner of Washington State.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPLACEMENT ENVOY TO UNITED STATES STILL UNDECIDED: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: New Minister of Foreign Affairs Mark Chen said Tuesday that a candidate to replace the outgoing representative to the United States, Chen Chien-jen, has yet to be decided.
Chen made the remarks when he called on the caucuses of the ruling and opposition parties in the legislature to solicit their support of the work of the ministry.

Chen said that there are many things to consider in appointing a replacement for outgoing Chen Chien-jen, who has made known his intention to leave before the May 20 presidential election, and the Presidential Office has yet to make a decision.
Chen earlier said that his ideal candidate would be one who has excellent language and social skills, and is well versed in American culture.

On reports that the government wants Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council, to serve as the new envoy to the United States, he said that he has yet to talk with Tsai about the matter.

Legislator Chien Lin Whei-jun of the Taiwan Solidarity Union wondered about the suitability of some of the current diplomatic personnel, pointing out that they had not fully explained the real situation of Taiwan to the countries in which they are stationed.
Chen said that the foreign ministry will make an overall review of the situation, saying that if the diplomatic personnel cannot defend Taiwan's sovereignty, they would be "useless" to their country.

On Taiwan's eighth bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO), Chen said that the United States and Japan will be more active than past years and that Japan could propose for Taiwan to be included in the world health body.
"The situation will be more optimistic than in past years, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 20, or the second day of the third month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1526: Baber, or Zahir ud-Din Mohammed, leads 2,000 Moguls to victory over 10,000 Muslims and 100 elephants under Ibrahim at the battle of Panipat. The conqueror of India later captured Delhi and Agra and founded the Mogul dynasty.
1657: Jews in New Amsterdam (now New York City) are granted equal rights and privileges as citizens.
1836: The U.S. Congress officially separates the western part of the Michigan Territory, creating a new zone known as the Wisconsin Territory.
1859: Holland concludes a treaty granting Portugal the right to govern the eastern part of Timor as well as Atauro Island and Oecussi.
1889: Adolf Hitler, house painter and subsequently German dictator who founded the National Socialist (Nazi) Party and was the architect of World War II, is born in Austria.
1908: Taiwan's West Coast Railway Trunk Line from Keelung to Kaohsiung, with a total length of 405 kilometers, is opened to traffic.
1916: The Taipei Yuanshan Zoo is inaugurated.
1933: President Franklin D. Roosevelt removes the United States from the gold standard.
1944: Britain's Royal Air Force drops a record 4,500 tons of bombs on Germany in a single raid.
1945: Soviet troops penetrate Berlin defenses.
1950: The Taiwan Garrison Command Headquarters is established, with Gen. Sun Li-jen serving at its first commander.
1957: Japan protests against nuclear testing by the Soviet Union.
1968: Pierre Elliot Trudeau of the Liberal Party becomes the 15th prime minister of Canada.
1970: President Richard M. Nixon announces the withdrawal of 150,000 U.S. military personnel from South Vietnam.
1974: The Republic of China announces the termination of Taiwan-Japan flights by China Airlines and Japan Airlines after Japan and mainland China sign an air pact in Beijing.
1978: Soviet warplanes force an off-course South Korean airliner down in the Soviet Union near the Arctic Circle, killing two passengers aboard and injuring 13 others.
1984: Britain announces that its administration of Hong Kong will cease in 1997 when the colony is returned to mainland China.
1986: A reservoir bursts and floods a Sri Lankan town, killing 100 people and making some 20,000 families homeless.
1990: Soviet troops storm Lithuania's state printing works after Mikhail Gorbachev cuts off 85 percent of gas supplies to the rebellious republic.
1996: World leaders meeting in Moscow agree to cooperate on increasing nuclear safety.
1999: Taiwan's Council of Agriculture rejects a call from South Korea for a resumption of reciprocal trade in fruit between the two countries.
1999: Defense Minister Tang Fei denies a U.S. media report that the Republic of China plans to develop medium range missiles.
2000: Central News Agency President Bill Wang says that CNA will shortly add a commercial information databank to its Internet services.
2000: National Yang Ming University President Tseng Chih-lang announces that he has decided to accept President-elect Chen Shui-bian's offer of the post of education minister in the new administration.
2001: Japanese Foreign Minister Yohei Kono announces that Japan will issue a visa to former ROC President Lee Teng-hui to seek medical treatment for his heart condition.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who does not anticipate deceit nor imagine untrustworthiness, but who can readily detect their presence, must be a very superior man."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market moved up Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April rose 30 points to close at 6,839, with 21,650 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May gained 45 points to end at 6,840, with 24,224 contracts traded, while June futures rose 25 points to end at 6,830, with 30 contracts finalized.
September futures gained 48 points to close at 6,850, with five contracts concluded, while December futures rose 37 points to end at 6,851, with four contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,809 for April, 6,795 for May, 6,805 for June, 6,802 for September and 6,814 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also moved up.
April TE futures rose 1.65 points to close at 283.65, with 4,536 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained 1.65 points to end at 283.35, with 5,342 contracts transacted.
June TE futures rose 0.4 points to close at 283.65, with four contracts finalized, while September TE futures lost 1.75 points to close at 282, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures gained 11.4 points to close at 1,071.4, with 5,323 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures gained 11.8 points to end at 1,065.8, with 9,668 contracts traded.
June TF futures rose 10 points to close at 1,065, with four contract transactions, while December TF futures rose 11 points to end at 1,080, with one contract finalized.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLAN TO LIFT BAN ON MAINLAND CAPITAL STILL UNDER SCRUTINY: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) is still weighing the possibility of opening the door to mainland Chinese investment capital, Cabinet spokesman Lin Chia-lung said Tuesday.

Lin was responding to a newspaper report that the ROC government has decided to open the door to inbound mainland Chinese investments in three stages and that the first stage, including allowing mainland banks to open liaison offices in Taiwan, will begin shortly after President Chen Shui-bian's inauguration for a second four-year term on May 20.

"The MAC has yet to finalize the new 'open door' policy initiative, " Lin said, adding that the Ministry of Finance is expected to call an interministerial meeting in the near future to further discuss relevant issues.

Commenting on the report, MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said the issue regarding whether to allow mainland Chinese banks to open liaison offices in Taiwan cannot be addressed until after a statute governing inbound mainland Chinese investments is enacted.
"Without such a statute, we have no legal basis to screen applications by mainland banks for opening liaison offices in Taiwan," said Tsai.

She also said it is the MAC's established policy to start to deal with issues regarding whether to allow mainland Chinese financial institutions to set up footholds or liaison offices in Taiwan only after a comprehensive legal framework for inbound mainland investments is formulated.
As to when such a statute or legal framework can be ready for implementation, Tsai said relevant government departments are still working on various technical details.
Tsai further said the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, hopes that the package of rules can be finalized and promulgated as early as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICA TO CONTINUE 90-DAY, VISA-FREE TREATMENT TO TAIWAN: MOFA

TEXT.P: South Africa's 90-day, visa-free treatment to Taiwan residents will stand, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Chang Pei-chi, director-general of the foreign ministry's Department of African Affairs, noted that the Pretoria government had originally granted the preferential treatment to Taiwan residents who hold the Republic of China passports, but after heavy pressure from mainland China -- whose citizens do not enjoy the same treatment, although the mainland has formal diplomatic relations with South Africa -- South Africa was forced to cancel the favorable visa situation for ROC nationals.

Another factor in the decision was that some illegal mainland Chinese immigrants had traveled to South Africa with forged ROC passports. Pretoria therefore decided to scrap the 90-day, visa-free treatment to Taiwan residents.

But the change was met with steep opposition, and the South African high court ruled on April 6 that the revocation of the visa privileges for ROC nationals must be rescinded, leaving the 90-day, visa-free treatment intact.
The foreign ministry will continue to follow the situation very closely, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended the day higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 20.79 points to close at 6,799.97.
The bourse opened at 6,837.56 and fluctuated between 6,856.98 and 6,790.57 during trading.

A total of 6.1 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$149.46 billion (US$4.46 billion), a decrease from the previous day's trading session that saw 6.69 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$169.35 billion.

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 1.2 percent, followed by textile issues at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.3 percent, and electrical shares at 0.1 percent.

The four other major stock categories posted losses, with construction stocks moving down the most at 1 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.3 percent, foodstuff stocks and pulp and paper issues both at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 436 to 348, with 179 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Terror arrests foil 'football bomb plot'.
Ten people were arrested in a series of armed police raids yesterday amid fears that Islamic militants were plotting to bomb a Premiership football ground or a shopping centre in Manchester.
Financial Times: Shell puts crisis blame on 'human failings'.
Top executives at Royal Dutch/Shell were aware that the group was overstating its oil and gas reserves for nearly two years before the news was made public, the Anglo-Dutch oil giant disclosed on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.S. Gives Leaders in Falluja a Chance to End the Insurgency.
After days of talks and threats of a militar y showdown, American officials agreed Monday to call off an offensive in the flash point city of Falluja if civic leaders can persuade insurgents there to turn in their heavy weapons.
The agreement was the first firm sign that at least one of two serious standoffs with anti- American insurgents -- in Falluja, west of the capital, and in the Shiite holy city of Najaf, to the south -- might be resolved peacefully. But the possibility of renewed fighting in Falluja remained real, as United States officials expressed skepticism that Iraqi civic leaders could actually persuade the insurgents to disarm.
Wall Street Journal: McDonald's CEO Died Suddenly of a Heart Attack.
McDonald's CEO Jim Cantalupo died suddenly of a heart attack. The restaurant chain's board quickly named Charlie Bell to succeed Cantalupo who had executed the most dramatic turnaround in McDonald's history.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Spain's new leader orders troops to pull out of Iraq. Zapatero fulfils pledge as U.N. control denied.
Spain's new prime minister ordered Spainish troops to pull out of Iraq as soon as possible, fulfilling a campaign pledge to a nation still recovering from terrorist bombings that al-Qaeda militants said were in reprisal for Spain's support of the war.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Casino decision in 6 to 9 months.
The Singapore Government will decide in about six to nine months whether it will allow a casino in Singapore, after wide consultation and careful study of its social and economic implications, Parliament heard on Monday.
The Lianhe Zaobao: More foreign-born kids to get citizenship.
Singapore Parliament yesterday approved changes to the constitution that will enlarge the pool of overseas-born children who enjoy the right to Singapore citizenship by descent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC DISCOVERS NEW DYSENTERY CASES AMONG TAIWAN TOURISTS TO BALI

TEXT.P: Authorities from the Center for Disease Control (CDC) on Tuesday reported fresh cases of dysentery among Taiwan tourists who recently returned from trips to the Indonesian resort island of Bali.

Three Taiwan citizens, who visited Bali between March 25 and April 1, were confirmed by CDC laboratories to have contracted bacillary dysentery, said Lai Ming-ho, chief of the CDC's quarantine and disease prevention division.
The three tourists -- belonging to two Taiwan tourist groups with a total of 39 people -- have been given treatment and placed under observation.
Twenty-six other of the tour group members have been tracked down and have tested negative for dysentry, while the remaining 10 have yet to be examined, Lai said.

Bali, one of the most popular destinations for Taiwan tourists, attracts about 400,000 Taiwanese visitors per year. It remained popular even during the height of the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak early last year.

The dysentery outbreak in Bali has scared some Taiwan tourists away from the resort island since last November after 111 Taiwan tourists were confirmed to have contracted the disease. However, the number of Taiwan visitors to Bali has picked up again this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SEES INTRAPARTY UNITY AS MOST IMPORTANT: WANG

TEXT.P: The most important thing for the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) for the moment is to maintain intraparty unity, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday.

Wang, who concurrently serves as a KMT vice chairman, was commenting on appeals by some senior KMT members for an intraparty personnel reshuffle in the wake of the March 20 presidential election, in which KMT Chairman Lien Chan narrowly lost to incumbent President Chen Shui-bian.

As Lien has contested the election result with two lawsuits, Wang said the presidential election has not yet truly ended. Therefore, Wang said, he supports Lien's insistence on no intraparty personnel reshuffle until after the election vote recount and the completion of the election-eve shooting investigations.

Lien has filed lawsuits in an attempt to nullify the election result and the entire election so that a new one can be held. The Taiwan High Court is handling the election result nullification lawsuit, and it has yet to decide how the ballots cast in the election should be recounted.

Lien is also pushing for a referendum on whether a special committee should be formed to investigate the shooting of President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu on the eve of the election. Lien claimed that the shooting, which slightly wounded Chen and Lu, unfairly swayed sympathy votes in Chen's favor. No suspect in the mysterious case has so far been arrested.

Wang said the vote recount issue and the investigation of the mysterious March 19 shooting have involved onerous tasks. If the KMT reshuffles its senior cadres right now, Wang said, newcomers may not be familiar with relevant affairs.

Even though the KMT will not change its senior party officials, Wang said, the party will still make adjustments regarding the duties of some of its senior cadres so that the party can handle both election-related disputes and intraparty reforms more efficiently and step up preparations for the year-end legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Singapore MRT worksite collapse wrecks Nicoll Highway.
A massive collapse of a Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) construction site yesterday afternoon wrecked a stretch of Nicoll Highway in Singapore, which will now be closed for many months.
The Lianhe Zaobao: One dead, 3 missing as part of Singapore's Nicoll Highway collapses.
The collapse of a temporary wall in a tunnel area caused a section of road on Singapore's Nicoll Highway to cave in, leaving a gaping hole the size of a basketball court.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Bangkok Post: Entrance exam leax/ Voradej moved to new post.
Voradej Chandarasorn, secretary general of the High Education Commission, has been moved to a new post as secretary general of the Education Council, as the university extrance examination lead controversy rages on. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Iraqi mediator optimistic about Fallujah ceasefire; Honduras to join Spain in pulling out troops.
An Iraqi mediator voiced optimism Tuesday about prospects for implementing the ceasefire accord in the Sunni Muslim bastion of Fallujah as Honduras announced it was joining Spain in withdrawing its troops from Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Bush Picks Envoy to Iraq.
President Bush said he would appoint his United Nations envoy,John D. Negroponte,ambassador to Iraq after the formal end of U.S. military occupation on June 30,tapping a hardened career diplomat and troubleshooter to oversee the deep U.S. role in the country. (Lu-sheng Chu)

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES DRAFT BILL ON AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH INSTITUTE

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved in its weekly Cabinet meeting Wednesday a draft bill for the establishment of a national agricultural research institute.

Under the draft bill, Cabinet officials said, the proposed institute will integrate the existing nine research institutes under the Council of Agriculture (COA) to become a legal unity under the Executive Yuan with the aim of upgrading the nation's agricultural research ability and the competitiveness of the agricultural sector as well.

The nine COA institutes are the Taiwan Agriculture Research Institute, Taiwan Forestry Research Institute, Taiwan Fisheries Research Institute, Taiwan Livestock Research Institute, Taiwan Agriculture Chemicals and Toxic Substances Research Institute, National Veterinary Research Institute, Taiwan Endemic Species Research Institute, Taiwan Tea Experiment Station and Taiwan Seed Improvement and Propagation Station.
The draft bill will be referred to the Legislative Yuan for screening.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOKY0-BEIJING RELATIONS WORSENING: MAC REPORT

TEXT.P: Relations between Japan and mainland China have been worsening in light of the fact that Tokyo has decided to reduce economic assistance to Beijing, according to a monthly report compiled by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.

Given that mainland China has been enjoying rapid economic growth, the report says, Japan has decided to reduce its assistance to Beijing by 20 percent a year based on this year's aid of 96.7 billion yen (US$896 million) . The difference will be transferred to mainland China's neighboring countries, such as India, Vietnam and Central Asian nations, it adds.
In reality, it says, Japan made the decision due to its concern over mainland China's growing national strength, which has cast a shadow of threat over the Japanese people.
Beijing won sympathy from the Japanese people in the early 1980s when it started open and reformation programs, the report notes.

However, it goes on, along with an increasing consciousness of constructing a rich country and strong military power among mainland China's official and private sectors since the beginning of this century, the Japanese people worry that the mainland Chinese threat has been intensifying.

Japanese Foreign Minister Yoriko Kawaguchi said in a March 30 Cabinet meeting that Japan's foreign aid should serve its national interests and diplomatic purposes. Therefore, she said, the Japanese government will pay more attention to the strategic value of its foreign aid.

Facing new developments in Tokyo-Beijing ties, the report states that mainland Chinese authorities have started seeking more assistance from European nations to offset the difference in Japanese aid cuts by Tokyo.
To achieve this goal, it says, Beijing will eventually grant more business opportunities to European nations at the expense of Japan.

The indications show that Tokyo-Beijing ties have been slowly unraveling and will not be improved in the near future, the report says, adding that the rivalry of their strategic interests is expected to be heightened.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Pentagon Drafts Iraq Troop Plan to Meet Violence.
The Pentagon has drawn up plans to send fresh troops quickly to Iraq in case it decides it must keep 135,000 or more American soldiers deployed beyond July, senior officials said Tuesday.
The Pentagon's contingency plans for summer, fall and beyond were driven partly by the lack of new foreign troops and the unexpected difficulties of training Iraqi forces.
Wall Street Journal: Blasts Hit Basra Police Stations, Killing at Least 55, Injuring 238.
A series of explosions ripped through three police stations and a police academy in the southern Iraqi city of Basra Wednesday, killing at least 55 people, including some 10 schoolchildren, and injuring at least 238, officials said.
Three near-simultaneous blasts targeted police stations at rush hour in Basra. At about the same time, a fourth explosion ripped through the police academy in the Basra suburb of Zubair. An hour later another blast targeted the same police academy.
Forty-five people were killed in the police station blasts and 10 were killed in the police academy explosions, officials and witnesses said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH KOREAN DELEGATION VISITS KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A South Korean delegation headed by governor of the province of Chungcheongnam-do, Sim Dae-pyung, met Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh Wednesday to strengthen exchanges between the two sides.

Hsieh noted that in addition to the movie industry, South Korea has many other sectors that Taiwan people can learn from, such as those in political, legal and administrative pursuits, and he hoped that Sim's visit will strengthen mutual understanding.
Sim, with abundant experience in government administration, also gave a lecture on administrative affairs for the employees of the Kaohsiung City Government.

Hsieh, who visited South Korea last November, said that Kaohsiung City, in southern Taiwan, has experienced notable improvements during the last few years, not only in city infrastructure establishment but also in its political position.
Besides, Hsieh went on, Kaohsiung City can also offer valuable experiences on intercity exchange programs among various international cities.

Sim, who also congratulated Hsieh for his successful campaign efforts in southern Taiwan for President Chen Shui-bian's re-election, expressed the hope that both sides can strengthen cultural exchanges in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH TO ORGANIZE ACTIVITIES MARKING WORLD HEALTH DAY

TEXT.P: "Road safety is no accident" will be the theme of activities held at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei April 24 to mark the annual "World Health Day," which is backed by the World Health Organization (WHO) , according to the Department of Health (DOH) Wednesday.
The public and government officials will jointly take part in the activities to underscore the importance of road safety.

The first 100 families and individual residents applying to participate in the road safety program, including a signature endorsement activity, will receive a gift from organizers, a spokesman for the Cabinet-level DOH said.
"World Health Day" is celebrated each year on April 7 in WHO member states to emphasize significant public health issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHIEF MEETS NEW MINISTER OF THE INTERIOR

TEXT.P: Director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Douglas Paal met new Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan Wednesday for a talk on a variety of topics.

Paal said it was a courtesy call, while Su said Paal's visit is to express thanks to the National Police Administration under the ministry for its protection of AIT, the de facto embassy of the United States in Taiwan in the absence of official ties between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Manila Bulletin: GMA offers self for scrutiny. President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo yesterday offered to submit herself to public accountability and scrutiny should her socalled "pro-poor, six-point promise" fails inside the six-year term she is seeking in the coming May elections.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Poe warns Lacson time fast running out. ACTOR Fernando Poe Jr. is getting impatient over delays in the holding of talks with rival opposition presidential candidate Panfilo Lacson, warning that all may be too late if unification efforts drag beyond the end of the month.
The Philippine Star: Cojuangco repels gov't move to take over SMC. San Miguel Corp. (SMC) chairman and chief executive officer Eduardo "Danding" Cojuangco has fended off a government bid to seize control of the food and beverage giant.
The Manila Times: Comelec mixes up signals. With 19 days to go before May 10, election officials are giving mixed signals on the magnitude of the problems that still confront them.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH SUPERMARKET GROUP TO INCREASE PURCHASE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The French supermarket group Nature et Decouvertes plans to increase its purchases in Taiwan, the company's purchasing manager, Jean-Jacques Martin, said Wednesday.

Nature et Decouvertes, which has 64 branches around France, boasts of an annual trade volume worth US$150 million, with its products ranging from gifts and gardening equipment to bath accessories and kitchen utensils.
Being one of the biggest supermarket group in France, Nature et Decouvertes purchased 30 percents of its merchandise from Asia each year.

Martin noted that although the group bought less from Taiwan in comparison to mainland China, it reaped more from its purchases from Taiwan due to the high-quality and superior design of Taiwan-made products.
In addition to expressing the group's hope to increase its purchases in Taiwan, Martin also suggested Taiwan trade promotion agencies try to attract European purchasers to visit Taiwan.
"When they come here, Shanghai and Hong Kong will no longer be their only option," Martin said.

Huang Wen-jung, a department chief of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , admitted that it has been hard for Taiwanese enterprises to explore European markets due to the large geographic distance between both sides.

With the efforts of TAITRA's office in Paris, Martin came to Taiwan on a fact-finding mission and decided to increase the group's purchases of Taiwan-made products, including bath ware, kitchen utensils and travel items.
According to Huang, Martin will attend the 2004 Taipei International Gift and Stationery Spring Show that starts Thursday.

Huang noted that the unreliable quality of mainland Chinese gift items has forced many purchasers to shift their orders from the mainland to Taiwan, and he urged local companies to present their high-quality and best-designed products to secure the gift market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HIGH COURT SAYS VOTE RECOUNT TO START BEFORE MAY 10

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court on Wednesday ruled that the vote recount of the March 20 presidential election will be started before May 10, and will hopefully be completed within 10 days.

This means that the vote recount demanded by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) could be completed by May 20, or the inauguration day of President-elect Chen Shui-bian, who won the election by a small margin of 29,518 votes out of more than 13 million cast.
Because of the continued bickering between the two election teams over the procedures in conducting the vote recount, some have said that the recount could drag on beyond inauguration day.
The court ruling came after the second hearing on a lawsuit brought by the KMT-PFP ticket, in which the election teams were invited to voice their views on the vote recount.

The court also coordinated on such matters as the criteria for determining the validity of the ballots, the teams available to monitor the recount, the details of the recount proceedings, as well as the estimated expenditure calculated by the Central Election Commission (CEC) for the recount.

Lawyer Tsai Yu-ling, who represents the "pan-blue alliance," said after emerging from the meeting that the judges ruled that the recount could begin before May 10, and added that the entire procedure should be able to be completed within 10 days.

Tsai said that the court hopes that the plaintiff, or the KMT-PFP ticket, would first tender a deposit of NT$60 million (US$1.83 million) . The money should be pay by May 5. The figure is not an actual indication of the expenses to be incurred, and any surfeit will be returned, while a shortfall will have to be covered should such a contingency arise.

Chiang Chih-chun, another lawyer from the KMT-PFP ticket, pointed out at the meeting that three stamped ballots that the CEC believes are invalid would have been considered valid were they counted under the previous President and the Vice President Election and Recall Law.
These ballots, Chiang went on, should be views as disputed, and left for the court to decide on their validity, although lawyers representing President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu disagreed.
The CEC has listed seven examples of stamped ballots as valid, while displaying 26 examples of stamped ballots it says are spoiled.

On the differences, the court ruled that two out the three stamped ballots will be listed as disputed votes and left for a judge to decide their validity, while it will ask for the CEC to send officials to the court to explain why it listed the third one as invalid in the first place.
The court also ruled that it would convene the last hearings on the lawsuit April 28 to make sure that both teams agree with the recount procedure and criteria for determining valid votes.
The CEC officials will attend the last hearing to help certify the criteria in determining valid votes, the court said.

The court will also ask the two parties in the lawsuit to provide their final lists of lawyers that can be sent to the district courts around the island to help with the recount, while the venue of the vote recount will be in the hands of various district courts, according to Tsai.

The recount team, each of which will be comprised of one representative from each rival team and officials from the court and the CEC, will be in charge of the daunting task of recounting the more than 13 million votes cast.
The lawsuit was brought by defeated presidential candidate Lien Chan of the KMT and vice presidential candidate James Soong of the PFP after they lost to President Chen and his running mate.

More than 330,000 invalid votes, or more than 11 times the margin separating the winner from the loser, were found in the election, with some attributing the phenomenon to stricter CEC criteria in determining the validity of the ballots and some attributing it to a group's exhortation before the election for voters to protest the poor quality of the two candidates by intentionally casting invalid ballots.

Lien sand Soong, citing what they claimed to be voting irregularities, challenged the fairness of the election and demanded a recount in the lawsuit. All votes in the ballot boxes have been sealed by the court pending a recount.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP LU TO SERVE AS ENVOY FOR SALVADORAN PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu will serve as the Republic of China's envoy to attend the inauguration of Salvadoran President-elect Antonio Saca on June 1, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Richard Shih said Wednesday.

Shih made the announcement after President Chen Shui-bian issued a decree on the appointment and added that the foreign ministry has begun a wide range of preparations for the delegation that will accompany Lu to the event.

Meanwhile, Koo Kuan-min, a prominent and much-respected senior presidential advisor, will participate in the 25th founding anniversary of the Republic of the Marshall Islands slated for May 1 on behalf of President Chen, Shih said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES QUICK BUDGET ALLOCATIONS FOR 10 NEW CONSTRUCTION PLANS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun called Wednesday for quick passage of bills and extra budgets for the Cabinet's "10 New Construction Plans" program at the legislature for the sake of the country's progress and development.
Yu made the remarks after hearing a report on the program at a weekly Cabinet meeting, according to spokesman Lin Chia-lung.

Urging unity from the various political parties to take concrete measures to help promote the country's major development plans, Yu was quoted by Lin as stressing that the "10 New Construction Projects" program will not only give a new lease on life to the domestic economy and to the development of less developed regions of Taiwan, but will also lay a solid foundation for its sustainable development.

As the projects are designed to be scattered around the northern, central and southern regions, infrastructure development across the country will thus be better balanced and create fresh demand for local development, Yu was quoted as explaining.
According to Lin, the premier described the projects as a race against time and appealed for quick legislative cooperation to secure Taiwan's competitive edge.

Should the budgets for the projects fail to pass the Legislative Yuan, it will have a negative impact on the building and extending of the mass rapid transit systems in Taipei and Kaohsiung, the development of a traffic network surrounding the Taipei Port and a planned Guggenheim museum in Taichung, Lin quoted Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics Director-General Liu San-chi as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC TO UNVEIL TELECOMMUNICATIONS MARKET REFORM PLAN IN JUNE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun ordered relevant government agencies Wednesday to come up with a digital and telecommunication industries reform program by the end of June.
Yu issued the directive after listening to a report on state-owned Chunghwa Telecom Co.'s plan to lower ADSL and network link service charges at a weekly Cabinet meeting.
The premier acknowledged Chunghwa's price reduction plan, but he added that it is just a first step to much-anticipated telecommunications market reform.
"We must make continued efforts to create an environment for fair competition among digital and telecommunication service operators, " Yu said.

He further said that the government's digital industry policy is based on two basic principles -- offering Internet users low-price, high-quality services and creating a fair competition environment to boost the development of digital and telecommunication industries.
After the lowering of ADSL and network link charges, Yu said he hopes Chunghwa Telecom will consider whether mobile phone short message fees can also be lowered.

He also ordered Minister-without-Portfolio Tsai Ching-yen to guide the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) and other relevant government agencies in formulating a comprehensive plan for telecommunication market reform by the end of June.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTER TO ATTEND APEC MINISTERIAL MEETING IN CHILE

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Huang Rong-tsun will attend an education ministers meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum scheduled to open in the Chilean capital of Santiago April 29 for a two-day run.
This is the third time that education ministers from all APEC member economies have met to discuss cooperative projects in education and cultural development.
In the previous two meetings, education ministers from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait had simultaneously taken part in multilateral discussions on education-related topics without any hitches.

Huang will leave Taipei Thursday for the United States where he will chair a meeting of ROC cultural officials stationed in seven U.S. cities and two Canadian cities to review their past work and chart a future work agenda. After the meeting, Huang will then travel to Santiago for the APEC ministerial-level conference which will focus on the theme of skills for the coming challenges, including learning one another's languages, stimulating learning in math and science and developing Information Technology to support teaching and learning communities.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO STRENGTHEN SECURITY FOR PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: Cabinet spokesman Lin Chia-lung said Wednesday that the government will make proper arrangements to prevent any conflict during the May 20 presidential inauguration ceremony.
Lin made the remarks in response to rumors propagated on the Internet that some radicals might form a "suicide-like" squad to launch attacks on the May 20 presidential inauguration.

Lin noted that the Taipei city government has promised to cooperate in safeguarding social order on that day and that some people have suggested that the government downsize the scale of the celebrations, including cutting the number of guests to be invited to the ceremony.

Refusing to accept their failure in the March 20 presidential election, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party have launched several sometimes violent rallies in front of the Presidential Office over the last month, demanding a vote recount and the "truth" about the election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, which the opposition believes won many sympathy votes for Chen.

Lin noted that the violent rallies have not only damaged the country's image, but will also harm the public's right to rally, adding that the government will also strengthen intelligence-collection to prevent any incidents.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO TAIWAN FISHERMEN RETURN FROM DETENTION IN PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: Two Taiwan fishermen who were detained in the Philippines for nearly a year finally returned home Wednesday.

Hung Hsing-shan, skipper of the Chinshengta fishing boat based out of Liuchiu, in Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung, and Peng Fei-lung, the first engineer aboard the ship, broke down in tears when they met with their families at Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan.

They were the last two Taiwan fishermen to be released by the Philippine authorities. A total of eight Taiwan fishing boats were detained by the Philippine coast guard last spring for alleged poaching in its 200-mile exclusive economic zone. Six of the ships managed to flee last April when a typhoon hit the northern Philippine island of Luzon.
Huang Chi-huang, skipper of the seventh boat, the Manchitsai, was released by the Philippine authorities last October with the assistance of the Republic of China's representative office in Manila.

The Chingshengta sank after Hung, Peng and the seven Indonesian crewmen were detained in a Philippine prison. Philippine judicial authorities finished a probes of the case earlier this month and agreed to release them Tuesday.
Hung and Peng said they appreciate all the assistance the ROC representative office in Manila has given to them over the past year.
As Taiwan's 200-mile economic zone overlaps with that of the Philippines, fishing disputes are common, particularly during the bluefin tuna fishing season from April through June.

DOC.HEADLINE: RIVAL TICKETS DIFFER ON CRITERIA FOR DETERMINING VALID VOTES

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court held a second hearing Wednesday concerning a lawsuit brought by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" over the March 20 presidential election.

The court invited the rival election teams to air their views on the vote recount, including the coordination on the criteria for determining the validity of ballots, the teams that will monitor the recount and details of the recount proceedings, as well as the estimated expenditure calculated by the CEC for the recount.

Chiang Chi-chun, a lawyer representing the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party, said after the closed-door meeting that the criteria for the recount should be in line with the provisions listed in the Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Law and that disputed ballots should be left for judges to decide if they are valid.
But Ku Li-hsiung, a lawyer representing President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, did not agree.

Chiang said that Article 60 of the President and Vice President Election and Recall Law stipulates clearly that ballots should be smeared beyond recognition to be counted as spoiled votes. If they are only partially smeared and can still be read, they should be counted as valid.
Also, a judge should determine if ballots are valid or invalid, Chiang said.
He said that the recount should take place in court, as there is video equipment and bailiffs there to maintain order, which he claimed would make it safer and more convenient than other places.

The "pan-blue alliance" also claims three stamped ballots that the Central Election Commission (CEC) believes are invalid should be counted as valid under the President and Vice President Election and Recall Law, Chiang said.
Those ballots, he went on, should be counted as disputed and left for the court to decide on their validity.
"The KMT-PFP is willing to comply with the CEC's regulations on the determination of other ballots," Chiang said.
The CEC has listed seven examples of stamped ballots as valid, while displaying 26 examples of stamped ballots it says are spoiled.

However, Ku pointed out that the rules were set before the start of the race, which would apply equally to both sides. If the KMT-PFP ticket has any misgivings about the criteria for determination set by the CEC, it should have raised them prior to the election, he noted.
"If the KMT-PPF still wants to discuss the criteria for determination now, the start of the recount will be pushed even further back, and we can't accept that," Ku said.

In addition, he noted that his clients have provided a list of 486 names of lawyers or probation lawyers to the court as part of the recount team, while the "pan-blue alliance" has made a list of more than 300.
He suggested that those who take part in the recount representing rival teams be expanded from lawyers to other professionals, including accountants, in order to speed up the recount.

The recount team, each of which will be comprised of one representative from each rival team and officials from the court and the CEC, will be in charge of the daunting task of recounting the more than 13 million ballots cast.

The lawsuit was brought by defeated presidential candidate Lien Chan of the KMT and vice presidential candidate James Soong of the PFP after they lost by a narrow margin of 29,518 votes to President Chen Shui-bian and his running mate, Vice President Annette Lu.

More than 330,000 invalid votes, or more than 11 times the losing margin, were registered during the original count, with some attributing the phenomenon to stricter CEC criteria in determining the validity of votes and some attributing it to a group's exhortation before the election to cast spoiled votes to show their discontent with both camps.
Lien and Soong, cited what they claim to be voting irregularities in the election, challenged the fairness of the election and demanded a recount in the lawsuit.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 TAIWAN OUTPUT OF CELLPHONES ESTIMATED AT 553 MILLION UNITS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's output of cellphones will reach 55.3 million units this year, representing a 24 percent increase over the 2003 level, according to a report by the Industrial Technology Information Service (ITIS) -- a project funded by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

The output volume will account for 11 percent of the global cellphone market, the ITIS report forecast. Since the beginning of this year, key parts and components suppliers have been unable to meet demand, forcing manufacturers to adjust labor divisions and market deployment strategies for the second half of this year, it said.

Taiwan put out NT$34.32 billion (US$1.04 billion) worth of cellphones in the first quarter of this year, down by 6 percent from the fourth-quarter value of last year but up by 44 percent over the previous year's Q1 level, it reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF NEW FIRST GRADERS FALLING DUE TO DECLINING BIRTHRATE

TEXT.P: The number of first graders enrolling in elementary schools this autumn will fall below 300,000 for the first time due to the nation's declining birthrate, the Ministry of Education (MOE) said Wednesday.
According to an MOE estimate, about 284,000 children will enter elementary schools for the first time this year, down 37,000 from the 2003 level.

MOE officials said the number of first graders will continue to drop in the coming five years except for 2006, when the number will rebound to more than 290,000. The number of first graders will fall even further, to below 250,000, in 2008.

To cope with this trend, the officials said, the MOE plans to reduce the number of students in each class with a view to upgrading the teaching quality. When the number of students drops below 30, the officials said, city and county governments can consider cutting the number of classes in specific schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT FORMS SPECIAL POLICY COMMITTEE TO FACE FUTURE CHALLENGES

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) announced Wednesday that it will establish a special policy committee to handle party reforms and its own investigation into the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan made the announcement during a party Central Standing Committee meeting.

Lien said he will supervise the committee, which will be divided into four subgroups responsible for policy making, an investigation into the election-eve assassination attempt on Chen and Vice President Annette Lu, the campaign for the year-end legislative elections, as well as party reforms.

The "pan-blue alliance" ticket of Lien and People First Party Chairman James Soong was defeated by Chen and Lu in the March 20 election by a slim margin of under 30,000 of the more than 13 million votes cast. The opposition believes the shooting won many sympathy votes for Chen, while the security mechanism triggered by the shooting deprived many military service members and police officers of their right to vote, although they have consistently been unable to provide evidence to support their claims.

At a time when the "pan-blue alliance" is seeking an annulment of the election through judicial process and its supporters have launched several massive, sometimes violent rallies to demand a vote recount and the "truth" about the shooting, some voices from the KMT have called for a reshuffle of the party's leadership.
However, Lien stressed that unity is now the only hope for the party and he urged high-ranking party officials to stay and face the challenges instead of resigning.

Claiming that the KMT does not care about victory or failure in the election, but about sound democratic development, Lien said Taiwan cannot afford to lose its hard-won democracy, peace and prosperity and expressed optimism that there will be justice in society.
He promised to introduce new blood to the party, reconstruct the party and carry out reforms.

Meanwhile, KMT Vice President Ma Ying-jeou, who is also Taipei mayor, urged party members to stay united and to cooperate with the People First Party and New Party to fight a "beautiful war" in the legislative elections.
The "pan-blue alliance" plays a decisive opposition force in the nation's legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved up against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.076 to close at NT$33.021.
A total of US$715 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$33.096 and fluctuated between NT$33.126 and NT$32.966.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIFTING OF IMPORT BAN ON INDONESIAN WORKERS POSTPONED: CLA

TEXT.P: The lifting of an import ban on Indonesian workers will be postponed indefinitely because the Indonesian government has yet to sign a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Taiwan on relevant affairs, a labor official said Wednesday.

Kuo Fang-yu, director of the Employment and Vocational Training Administration under the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) , said the council originally expected to sign the MOU with the Indonesian labor department within three months of a visit to Indonesia by CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu in late January.

However, Kuo said, the Indonesian government has so far not sent any official to discuss the new labor agreement issue with the CLA. As Indonesia is busy with parliamentary and presidential elections, Kuo said, it is not expected to finalize the MOU signing issue by the end of this month.
Against this backdrop, Kuo said, the CLA cannot lift the Indonesian labor import ban at the end of April as originally scheduled.

After Chen's Indonesia visit, the CLA announced that Indonesian workers whose maximum three-year work permits would expire between Feb. 2 and May 1 could apply to the CLA for a temporary three-month extension.
"Now that the Indonesian labor import ban cannot be lifted as scheduled, those Indonesian workers must leave Taiwan before May 1," Kuo said.

According to a CLA estimate, Kuo said, more than 700 Indonesian citizens now working in Taiwan will now have to leave the island before May, despite being told earlier that they could stay, due to the delay in the MOU signing.
Kuo said only a few points in the agreement still need further negotiations.

"Whether the ban can be lifted will depend on whether the Indonesian government will send representatives to discuss the issue with us, " Kuo said, adding that the timing for resolving the issue will become clearer after Indonesia's parliamentary and presidential elections this summer.

The CLA suspended labor imports from Indonesia in August 2002 for a host of reasons, including the high absconding rate of Indonesian workers, Indonesia's demand that local manpower agencies deduct "guarantee" money from Indonesian workers' salaries on its behalf, and Indonesia's failure to abide by the CLA's demand to lower foreign labor brokerage fees.
In 2002, more than 90,000 Indonesian citizens legally worked in Taiwan, but the number had declined to about 49,000 as of the end of March as a result of the import freeze.

At the invitation of the Indonesian labor department, CLA Chairwoman Chen visited Indonesia to look into improvements in Indonesia's labor export administration. She told a news conference after her return that she was satisfied with Indonesia's progress in labor export administration and that she planned to sign a new labor agreement with her Indonesian counterpart in three months to pave the way for the lifting of the import ban.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market moved down Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April fell 15 points to close at 6,824, with 10,577 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May lost eight points to end at 6,832, with 18,541 contracts traded, while June futures dropped 18 points to end at 6,824, with 44 contracts finalized.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,839 for April, 6,840 for May, 6,842 for June, 6,835 for September and 6,846 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, ended mixed.
April TE futures lost 2.6 points to close at 281.05, with 1,965 contracts traded, while May TE futures fell 1.35 points to end at 282, with 4,849 contracts transacted.
June TE futures dropped 1.5 points to close at 282, with three contracts finalized.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures gained 19 points to close at 1,090.4, with 4,461 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures gained 18 points to end at 1,083.8, with 12,635 contracts traded.
June TF futures rose 23.4 points to close at 1,084.8, with 12 contract transactions, while December TF futures rose 10 points to end at 1,090, with one contract finalized.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended the day higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 10.28 points to close at 6,810.25.
The bourse opened at 6,801.75 and fluctuated between 6,844.74 and 6,792.15 during trading.

A total of 5.73 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$137.02 billion (US$4.09 billion), a decrease from the previous day's trading session that saw 6.1 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$149.46 billion.

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 3.1 percent, followed by textile issues at 2.9 percent, bank and insurance shares at 1.7 percent, cement stocks at 0.4 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.2 percent.

The three other major stock categories posted losses, with foodstuff stocks moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 0.6 percent, and electrical shares at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 428 to 388, with 151 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOTAL LUNAR ECLIPSE EXPECTED EARLY MORNING MAY 5

TEXT.P: Taiwan stargazers are excited at the prospect of being able to watch a total lunar eclipse in early hours of May 5 if weather conditions allow, authorities from the Taipei Municipal Observatory said Wednesday.

People who miss the eclipse -- expected to occur at between 2: 24 a.m. and 6: 12 a.m. -- will have to wait for another three years for the next total lunar eclipse, scheduled to occur Aug. 8, 2007, observatory officials said.

Totality, which will be easily visible to the naked eye and is expected to last for about one hour and 17 minutes, will see the entire moon turn fiery red, a rare and spectacular phenomenon, the officials said.
The last total lunar eclipse visible in Taiwan took place Jan. 10, 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ZEN MASTER TO TEACH IN AUSTRALIA
DOC.DATELINE: Sydney, April 21 (CNA) (By Liu Yu-min and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: World renowned Taipei-based Zen master Sheng Yen is scheduled to give four teaching sessions in Australia beginning Thursday in Sydney, religious sources said Wednesday.

Invited by the University of Sydney's School of Buddhism Studies and other academic and religious organizations in Australia, Sheng Yen will give three speeches in Sydney and one in Melbourne on his first "tour of enlightenment" in Australia.
In addition to the teachings, Sheng Yen will also preside over a ceremony to proclaim several followers Buddhists and illuminate them with his enlightenment.

In his first speech to be held on the campus of the University of Sydney Thursday, Sheng Yen will analyse the relationship between "mental freedom and intelligent freedom," while in the second speech, to be held later that day at the university, he will speak on "inner and outer peace -- my spiritual journey."
At the same venue, Sheng Yen is expected to speak on "Zen and inner environmental protection" on Friday.
His fourth speech, entitled "Zen and a pure land for humans, " will be held in Melbourne Sunday.
Sheng Yen, a member of the 2003 World Council of Religious and Spiritual Leaders, is also an academic and educator who holds a doctorate and has written more than 140 books on religion.

Answering questions about Taiwan's just concluded presidential election upon his arrival in Sydney, Sheng Yen said all political figures should bear mercy in their hearts and minds like a Buddhist or any other religious follower.
A politician, particularly a head of state, should treat everybody, including those who did not vote for him, equally without any element of partiality, Sheng Yen added.
Prior to coming to Australia, Sheng Yen has been in Singapore, where he offered his enlightenment and illumination to Buddhism followers there.

Sheng Yen, founder of the Taiwan Buddhist group Dharma Drum Mountain (DDM) Social Welfare and Charity Foundation, is set to arrive in Switzerland at the end of April to preside over a Zen study session.
He will give public teachings on April 30 and May 1 before presiding over a seven-day Zen meditation session to be held at the Beatenberg Zen Center in Bern beginning May 2.
According to Beatenberg authorities, all 70 spots for the Zen meditation session were booked long ago, with some being reserved by Buddhist followers from as far away as Spain and the United States.

Traveling with some 20 world religious leaders to Israel and Palestine last December, Sheng Yen tried to use the power of religion to bridge the differences among people living in regions with ethnic conflict.

Presenting two words -- mercy and wisdom -- Sheng Yen called for the leaderships of both Israel and Palestine to use wisdom to work out solutions to their differences while practicing mercy on all the people in the region regardless of their political affiliation or religion, so as to not let down the people living in the Holy Land.

Sheng Yen and his party met with Palestinian Prime Minister Ahmed Qureia during a symposium held in Jerusalem Dec. 11. After hearing Sheng Yen's teaching, Qureia reportedly applauded enthusiastically and said to his aides that he looks forward to seeing Sheng Yen's suggestions put into practice.

At a colloquium held at the Israeli prime minister's office Dec. 14, Sheng Yen delivered a speech to ranking Israeli officials, including Cabinet officials, parliamentary advisers and government consultants in news and religious affairs.

In his speech, Sheng Yen interpreted Islamic doctrine as stipulating that Jihad -- or holy war -- does not mean striving to defeat others, but instead to defeat one's own evil thoughts. "This is an idea almost the same as the Buddhist concept of conquering the evil in one's mind," Sheng Yen noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSES MAY SCALE DOWN INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Despite the fact that Taiwan's investment in mainland China rose markedly in March on a year-to-year basis, a government agency has forecast that domestic businesses will slow their pace of investment in the mainland for various reasons.

Citing a monetary tightening move expected to be adopted soon by the mainland authorities to cool off its overheated investment and economy, a spokesman for the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said that increasing power shortages might also give Taiwan investors who are mulling new investment plans in the mainland cause for concern.
Taiwan companies should pay special heed to the two issues when considering whether to launch new investment or funnel additional capital into the mainland, the spokesman said.

Mainland-bound investment worth US$596.6 million by Taiwan businesses was approved by the commission last month, up by 29.51 percent compared to the previous year's level, according to statistics compiled by the commission. The figure brought the combined value for the first quarter of this year to US$1.292 billion, an increase of 16.09 percent year-on-year.

At the same time, direct investment by overseas Chinese in Taiwan last month reached US$414.36 million, an expansion of 34.41 percent over the year-earlier level. Q1 investment by overseas Chinese in the domestic market totaled US$768.86 million, up by 28.11 percent on an annual basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD INCREASES BUDGET TO TRAIN E-GENERATION MANPOWER

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) has decided to increase its budget by NT$450 million (US$13.6 million) to fully carry out a program for training e-generation manpower.

The new budget allocation was made during a recent CEPD meeting called to review the effects of the program and two other projects -- cultural development in local communities and the promotion of the creative culture industry -- which form parts of the "Challenge 2008" six-year national development plan, a CEPD official said.

The extra money brings the total budget allocated for the program to NT$11.402 billion, part of which will be used to serve as funds for scholarships for Taiwan students doing research abroad or vice versa and for cultivating professional elite for promising industries, as well as for sport activity exchanges and setting up a life-long learning system for foreign spouses of Taiwan people, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10 ILLEGAL MAINLAND CHINESE IMMIGRANTS NABBED

TEXT.P: Ten female illegal mainland Chinese immigrants and three Taiwanese men aboard a Taiwan fishing boat were arrested off central Taiwan early Wednesday morning, according to a report by the Coast Guard Administration (CGA).
CGA officials said that they were tipped off recently that the Tainan-registered fishing boat Sheng Hsin would be picking up female illegal immigrants offshore.

Two CGA cutters spotted the Sheng Hsin at around 4: 30 a.m. four nautical miles off Lukang in Changhua County. After a chase, coast guard officials intercepted the boat and both Lee Ming-lang, captain of the ship, and crewmember Wang Cheng-feng admitted that they were transporting illegal mainland immigrants.
CGA officers found the 10 women -- four of whom are minors -- hiding in the cramped cabin of the ship.

The women come mainly from the mainland hinterland, including Jiangxi, Hubei, Henan, and even as far as Xinjiang provinces. Most of them claimed not to realize that they would be engage in prostitution after arriving in Taiwan.

The Taiwan man who was also arrested was Chen Cheng-hsiung, 41, from Ilan. He told the CGA that he traveled to the mainland as a tourist and paid NT$20,000 (US$608) for the trip back to Taiwan on the Sheng Hsin.
Police found nearly five kilograms of what they suspected was amphetamine but Chen denied being a drug courier.
CGA officials said that after Tombsweeping Day -- which fell on April 4 this year -- is the high season for illegal immigrants, and they will continue to be on guard against them.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS FORMATION OF SUPRAMINISTERIAL ANTI-FRAUD MECHANISM

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun has ordered the formation of a supraministerial mechanism to crack down on fraud rings, Cabinet spokesman Lin Chia-lung said Wednesday.
Yu issued the directive after listening to a report on the domestic crime situation, particularly the increasing number of fraud cases, at a weekly Cabinet meeting, Lin said.

According to Lin, Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan said at the meeting that as the reported fraud cases involve complicated operations ranging from figurehead bank accounts and false phone calls to cross-Taiwan Strait coordination, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) and the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) alone cannot be relied upon to solve such cases.
Su suggested that a supraministerial task force be formed to take charge of the anti-fraud campaign.

"Responding to Su's recommendation, Premier Yu ordered the formation of a supraministerial task force to facilitate policy coordination and formulation of effective fraud-fighting measures, " Lin said.

The new task force will be headed by Minister-without-Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung, Lin said, adding that the team will be made up of officials from the MOJ, the MOI, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and the Government Information Office.

"In addition, the premier expressed his hope that the existing special task force headed by State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa can step up investigations into major fraud cases in order to maintain law and order and allay public anxiety over mounting reports of such criminal cases," Lin said.
Many local people, including Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan, have fallen victim to fraud crime, which includes rampant use of counterfeit credit cards and elaborate ATM card scams.

Justice Minister Chen declared an all-out war on local fraud rings last week and on Chen's instructions, Lu formed a special task force to guide fraud-fighting operations. The panel is composed of top officials from police, investigation and prosecution authorities.

Dr Rowan Williams (the archbishop) accused (Prime Minister) Tony Blair of eroding public trust in Britain's political system yesterday as he launched a wide-ranging attack on the style and conduct of the Government.
