DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH MANUFACTURERS URGED TO COOPERATE WITH TAIWAN COUNTERPARTS
DOC.DATELINE: London, April 20 (CNA) (By N.K. Han and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China representative to Britain Tien Hung-mao has urged British manufacturers to cooperate with Taiwan manufacturers to tap the business opportunities in mainland China.

Tien made the remarks when he addressed the sixth joint meeting of the Taiwan-Britain business council and the Britain-Taiwan business council which opened its two-day meeting in London Tuesday. More than 100 delegates from Taiwan and Britain are attending the meeting, including a Taiwan delegation of some 30 members led by Leslie Koo, chairman of China Synthetic Rubber Corp.

Noting the closer interdependence between Taiwan and mainland China, Tien said that there are more than 700,000 Taiwan businesspeople operating on the mainland and that they have invested between US$100 billion and US$120 billion there. Cross-strait trade has also grown to US$50 billion per year, he added.

The large number of Taiwan businesspeople have accumulated rich experience and knowledge in dealing with mainland Chinese officials over the years, Tien said. He added that they also enjoy the convenience and advantage of sharing the same language and culture with China.
For this reason, if British manufacturers make Taiwan a springboard or join hands with Taiwan businesspeople, they will be able to better tap the business opportunities on the mainland, Tien said.

He said he believes that the trade relations between Taiwan and Britain will become ever closer, noting that more and more Taiwan students studying in Britain have returned to Taiwan and that they are expected to play the role of a bridge between the two countries.
It is estimated that the number of Taiwan students studying in Britain has exceeded 13,000.

ROC Vice Economics Minister Yin Chii-ming, who is currently visiting Britain, said on the same occasion that because of the bilateral cooperation between private enterprises in the two countries and the government's encouragement over the past decade, Taiwan-Britain economic relations have grown rapidly, making Britain the third largest trade partner of Taiwan in Europe.

He cited statistics showing that two-way trade between Taiwan and Britain reached US$4.3 billion last year, up 0.8 percent from the figure in 2002. Although bilateral trade growth slowed over the past two years because of the global economic slump, bilateral trade began to register double digit growth in the first two months of this year, with both imports and exports recording a strong rebound.

Yin also said that Taiwan has invested US$400 million in Britain, while Britain has invested US$2.3 billion in Taiwan, including in the chemical, pharmaceutical, financial, insurance and large supermarket sectors.

Yin will attend the 11th Taiwan-U.K. trade talks Wednesday, during which the Taiwan delegation is expected to discuss with their British counterparts no-visa treatment for Taiwan manufacturers and Taiwan businesspeople operating in Britain, as well as simplification of work permit procedures for Taiwan businesspeople in Britain.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSBC POSTS PROFITS OF NT$160 M FOR Q1

TEXT.P: China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) continued to post profits in the first quarter of this year, with the figure for the quarter estimated to hit NT$160 million (US$4.85 million), corporate sources said Wednesday.

In a preliminary estimate, CSBC management said, the just-privatized shipbuilder registered business turnover of NT$3.77 billion for the first three months of this year, reaching about 90 percent of the company's target for the period. However, the estimated profit of NT$160 million is 172.7 percent of the company's target, it added.
The figure is encouraging given the fact that the former state-run shipbuilder had been running in the red for decades.
Following the adoption of a "rejuvenation program" in 2001 to cut the payroll and increase productivity, the debt-ridden company began turning a profit in the latter months of the following year.
Under the "rejuvenation program, " one first-grade department and 50 second-grade units were phased out, and 2,280 staff members were cut, while those who stayed experienced a 35-percent pay cut.

To cope with cut-throat competition in the sluggish global shipbuilding market, the CSBC has also streamlined personnel management and tightened quality control to ensure stable production and punctual delivery.

The CSBC was fully privatized at the end of 2003. Benefiting from market-oriented principles and as a result of continuously streamlining personnel structure and upgrading research and development capabilities, the company registered net annual profits of NT$500 million in 2003, well above its target of NT$280 million for the year.

In the face of rising steel prices, the only way to continue to ensure competitiveness in the world market and sustainable growth is for the company to strictly follow the "lean and mean" policy, the management said.

The CSBC -- builder of the eighth Cheng Kung-class frigate, which is patterned after the U.S. Perry-class frigate, but better -- is now fully booked with orders until 2007, with the orders totalling over NT$50 billion.

With its shipbuilding technology ranked 27th in the world and its welding technology in the top five, the CSBC will spare no efforts in acquiring opportunities to join the development and production team that will jointly build the eight submarines that the United States has promised to sell to Taiwan, the management said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 21, or the third day of the third month of the Year of Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1634: Jan van Riebeeck, Dutch naval surgeon and founder of Cape Town, South Africa, is born.
1898: The United States declares war on Spain.
1910: Mark Twain, pen name of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, American author and humorist, dies at the age of 74. He drew on his childhood along the Mississippi River to create masterpieces of humor and sarcasm, including "Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
1926: Elizabeth II, Queen of England since 1952, is born.
1930: Fire breaks out at the Ohio state penitentiary, killing 355 people.
1935: An earthquake hits central and northern Taiwan, killing some 3,000 people.
1937: Steamships formally begin plying a regular weekly route between Shanghai and San Francisco.
1946: British economist John Maynard Keynes dies at the age of 63. He proposed that high unemployment, being a result of insufficient consumer spending, can be relieved by government-sponsored programs.
1948: Republic of China troops evacuate Yenan.
1949: The Chinese communists resume an all-out offensive and cross the Yangtze River.
1954: The United States flies a French battalion to Indochina to defend Dien Bien Phu, which is overrun by Vietnamese forces three weeks later.
1957: Taiwan voters go to the polls for the third time to elect county magistrates, city mayors and provincial assemblymen.
1958: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly building in Wufeng, Taichung County, is inaugurated.
1960: Brazil moves its capital from Rio de Janeiro to Brazilia, the brain-child of President Juselino Kubitschek.
1966: The ROC and Dahomey resume diplomatic relations.
1971: Haitian dictator Francois Duvalier, known as "Papa Doc," dies at the age of 64. Elected president in 1957, he declared himself president for life in 1964 and ruled in an authoritarian manner until his death. He was succeeded by his son Jean-Claude, who fled the country in 1986 after widespread civil unrest.
1975: South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu resigns after denouncing the United States as untrustworthy.
1987: Terrorists detonate a bomb near the main bus station in Colombo, Sri Lanka, killing and injuring more than 400 people.
1989: More than 10,000 workers and students clamoring for democracy and human rights march from campuses to converge on Tiananmen Square in Beijing in defiance of official warnings against anti-government protests.
1997: An advance contingent of communist Chinese troops enter Hong Kong in preparation for the July 1 handover of the British crown colony to communist China.
1998: Seoul drops efforts to receive Japanese compensation for women held as sex slaves during World War II and says it will pay the surviving women.
1999: A survey conducted by the Switzerland-based Business Environment Risk Intelligence ranks Taiwan as the least risky area for investment in the world.
1999: Renowned local writer Su Hsueh-lin, winner of the Chungshan Literature Prize and the National Literature Prize, dies at the age of 104.
2000: Taiwanese "Go" player Wang Li-cheng wins the title of "Go Sage," the highest title and honor for any Go professional in Japan.
2000: Tsai Ying-wen, an advisor to the National Security Council and a professor at National Chengchi University, is confirmed chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.
2001: A pro-unification organization urges Taiwan's three main opposition parties to monitor the Democratic Progressive Party-led government to prevent Taiwan from "marching toward independence."
Confucius lesson of the day: "A good horse is considered so not because of its mere brute strength but because of its moral qualities."

DOC.HEADLINE: 12 FOREIGN HEADS OF STATE TO ATTEND MAY 20 INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: Twelves foreign heads of state will come to Taipei to attend the May 20 inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian, besides three foreign premiers, one governor and five envoys, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Thursday.

At a tea party thrown for local journalists, the minister listed the reception of foreign guests for the May 20 inauguration as one of his major jobs at the moment, adding that his office has invited all former chairmen of the American Institute in Taiwan, including Therese Shaheen, who resigned early this month, to attend the inauguration.

Many countries which do not have diplomatic ties with Taiwan will also have delegations present at the inauguration and will therefore give Taiwan a good chance to cement its unofficial ties with these countries, Chen said.
His other major task at present is Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization, which is scheduled to hold its annual conference in Geneva May 17, Chen said.

Noting that both Australia and the United States have voiced their support for Taiwan's participation in the WHO as an observer, the minister said the chances for Taiwan's success in its bid are better than ever, but the public should not feel depressed "even if we fail again," as persistent efforts are needed, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES U.S. OFFICIALS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged U.S. officials Thursday to visit Taiwan and gain a better understanding of the country's policy toward mainland China.

Tsai Huang-lang, a DPP caucus leader at the Legislative Yuan, made the remarks after James Kelly, U.S. assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, issued a warning toward President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday at a hearing held at the International Relations Committee under the House of Representatives.
Kelly called on Chen to exercise "restrained leadership" and not to treat the mainland's military threats as empty words.

"Pushing for independence carries the potential for a response from (mainland China) , a dangerous, objectionable and foolish response that could destroy much of what Taiwan has built and crush its hopes for the future," Kelly said.

In the face of the stern warning from Washington following Chen's March 20 re-election, Tsai said that Kelly apparently does not understand Chen's basic stance toward the mainland and he suggested that U.S. officials pay more visits to Taiwan to forge better mutual understanding and communication on the island's policy toward the mainland.

The president has said repeatedly that his plan for a new constitution in 2006 is not equal to a timetable for de jure Taiwan independence, that he does not intend to change Taiwan's status-quo and that he will not violate the "four noes plus one" pledge outlined in his inaugural speech of May 20, 2000, Tsai noted.

At the same time, Hwang Yih-jiau, a spokesman for the opposition People First Party, said Kelly's statement reflects the deep U. S. worries about the danger of what he claimed is the DPP's pro-independence stance.

Hwang urged the DPP not to mislead the Taiwan people in terms of Washington's remarks and compromise Taiwan's security by engaging in word games. He called on Chen to pay heed to the U.S. concern over what he said is Chen's "covert seeking of Taiwan independence through a new constitution" so as to avoid conflict in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATION ON CARE FOR ELDERLY TO BE ENACTED BY 2006: MOI

TEXT.P: A law designed to provide care for the elderly will be enacted before 2005, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan said Thursday.

In an interview with the Central News Agency, the minister said the proposed legislation will provide medical care for elderly people who suffer from chronic diseases, thereby giving them fewer worries in their old age.
Su also said the current NT$3,000 monthly allowance offered by the government to the elderly is not enough to ensure that the country's senior citizens can have a basic standard of living.

The Ministry of the Interior has worked out a national pension program under which the participants are required to pay a premium of NT$600 per month in exchange for the right to a monthly pension of between NT$7,000 and NT$8,000 in their old age, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CONSTITUTION PLAN NOT INDEPENDENCE TIMETABLE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's plan to write a new constitution for Taiwan in 2006 is part of his efforts to deepen and consolidate Taiwan's young democracy, Presidential Office spokesman James Huang said Thursday.

Huang made the remarks after James Kelly, U.S. assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, warned against Taiwan pursuing formal independence at a hearing of the House International Relations Committee in Washington, D.C. a day earlier.
Huang said the Presidential Office would not comment on Kelly's testimony. "But we are willing to further explain our stance on our constitutional reform plan," he added.

Quoting Chen, Huang said the plan to formulate a new constitution will be carried out in line with the principle of no change to Taiwan's political status quo and is by no means a timetable for pursuing de jure Taiwan independence.

Over the past four years, Huang said, Chen has faithfully abided by his "four noes plus one" pledge outlined in his 2000 inaugural speech. "The president has never backed off from his promise during his four-year term," Huang said.

The "four noes plus one" pledge refers to no change to the Republic of China's national title and flag, no holding of a referendum on Taiwan independence or unification with mainland China, no enshrinement of the "two states theory" in the ROC Constitution and no abolishment of the National Unification Council.

After Chen was re-elected in the March 20 presidential election, Huang said, he has said on numerous public occasions that his top priority for his second four-year term is to unify Taiwan, stabilize cross-Taiwan Strait relations and boost economic development.

Although Chen has said Taiwan needs a new constitution to resolve legislative gridlock and make its political system more efficient, Beijing views it as a step toward independence -- a move that could provoke a military attack by the mainland.

Huang said the government will step up publicity and continue communications with the ROC's allies and the international community so that they can come to a better understanding of the gist of Taiwan's new constitution plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTRY POISED TO TRIM CLASS SIZES FOR FIRST GRADERS

TEXT.P: Class sizes for first graders at Taiwan's elementary schools will be gradually trimmed to 30 students from the current level of 35, a spokesman for the Ministry of Education said Thursday.

The decision to cut class sizes was made during a meeting with education officials from local city and county governments, according to Wu Tsai-shun, director of the ministry's Elementary Education Department.

Wu said the planned measure will be included in a five-year education promotion program and will kick off in the 2005 academic year should various conditions be met -- no reduction in the total class number, no slashing of teacher numbers and no extra financial burden on local governments.
The policy adjustment is mainly the result of a decrease in first grade enrollment at elementary school due to a declining birthrate.

Statistics compiled by the ministry show that about 284,000 first graders will be enrolled at nationwide elementary schools this autumn, a fall of 37,000 from the previous year's level. It will be the first time that the number of new first graders has dropped below the 300,000 mark.
A continued decline in student numbers is also set to have a major impact on the country's secondary and higher educations, a ministry official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER CONFIDENT IN CLAMPDOWN ON FRAUDSTERS

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan said Thursday that he is confident the government's all-out drive to clamp down on fraud rings will reduce the number of scams being perpetrated in Taiwan.
Su made the remarks during an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency.

Pointing out that the government has worked out a set of inter-ministerial mechanisms to move in collusion with the National Police Administration, Su expressed his confidence that scams, usually mounted by fraud rings via the Internet, telephones and cellphones, will be wiped out.

The interior minister said that many of his friends and relatives have also been approached by fraudsters and he vowed to stamp down hard on those who prey on the gullibility of others. "People are entitled to lead a life free from fear, "he noted.

In addition to the police clampdown and the government's campaign to build public awareness of the scams orchestrated by fraud rings, Su said that Premier Yu Shyi-kun has also called for the establishment of an inter-ministerial task force to revise relevant laws.

Officials from the Ministry of Justice, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Mainland Affairs Council and the Government Information Office will be involved in the task force, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER CONFIDENT OF SOLVING ELECTION-EVE SHOOTING

TEXT.P: Interior Minister Su Jia-cheyuan said Thursday he is confident of getting to the bottom of the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.
Su, a former Pingtung county magistrate who assumed his current post about two weeks ago, made the remarks in an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency.

Noting that the shooting marked the first time that the Republic of China's head of state has ever been shot, Su said the government will do its utmost to bring to justice the assailant or assailants.

Both Chen and Lu were slightly injured in the shooting, which defeated opposition "pan-blue alliance" presidential candidate, Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, claims unfairly swayed sympathy votes in Chen's favor in the March 20 presidential election. No suspect has been arrested and criminal investigators have been unable to collect any solid leads.

However, Su said the National Police Administration (NPA) under the Ministry of the Interior has been working hard on the case. "I'm confident that we'll be able to solve the case, " he said optimistically, although he would not set a timetable for solving the case.
Su also defended the NPA's ongoing campaign against organized crime, saying it is routine work and not politically motivated.

Police began a new crackdown on organized crime after a "pan-blue alliance" April 10 protest rally on Ketegalan Boulvard in front of the Presidential Office in downtown Taipei ended in violence, with many police officers and "pan-blue" supporters sustaining injuries.
Su said the campaign is aimed at maintaining law and order. "We hope the new crackdown will discourage gangsters from sabotaging public order and disturbing social stability."

After the election, the "pan-blue alliance" has organized several sometimes violent protest rallies to contest President Chen's narrow re-election victory. In addition, the alliance has filed two lawsuits to nullify the election result and the entire election so that a new one can be held.

In the face of the post-election disputes, Su said the NPA still has two tough challenges ahead -- a vote recount that the Taiwan High Court is set to begin by May 10, and the May 20 presidential inauguration.

"I'll see to it that all police staff cooperate with other law enforcement officers closely to maintain public order and prevent any unexpected disturbances so that the recount and the presidential inauguration can proceed smoothly and peacefully," Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP TO ATTEND INAUGURATION CEREMONY OF EL SALVADOR PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu will attend the inauguration ceremony of El Salvador president-elect Elias Antonio Saca, an official of the Presidential Office said Thursday.
James Huang, director of the Department of Public Affairs at the Presidential Office, said Saca was elected president in the March 21 , and is scheduled to assume office on June 1.
President Chen Shui-bian telephoned Saca April 2 and both leaders expressed congratulation to each other for winning their presidential elections, Huang said.

Saca invited Chen, who won the March 20 election, to visit his country for the inauguration, but Chen, thinking that the day is too close to his own May 20 inauguration ceremony and that he will play host to a score of national leaders and dignitaries from other countries during that time, it may not be suitable for him to travel to El Salvador.
The president said that when the time is right, he will definitely visit the Central American nation, according to Huang.

In order to highlight the importance attached to El Salvador by his administration, Huang said that President Chen had designated Vice President Lu to represent him to attend Saca's inauguration ceremony.
Lu's itinerary is still on the drawing board, and there is no further details, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. ENCOURAGES CROSS-STRAIT TRADE, TRANSPORT LINKS: U.S. OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 22 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States encourages both sides of the Taiwan Strait to engage in direct trade, postal and transportation links, as it will be a win-win situation for the two sides to step up economic exchanges, a United States official said Wednesday.

James A. Kelly, assistant secretary of state for East Asia and Pacific Affairs, made the remarks at a hearing on the 25th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act at the House International Relations Committee.

Kelly said the reasons Taiwan hesitates to implement cross-strait direct links may include worries that overreliance on the mainland could potentially produce a crisis. In addition, Taiwan also worries that direct links could speed up the outflow of Taiwan industry, worsening its unemployment problem.

Though it is not completely unfounded that Taiwan worries about the hollowing out of its industry, Kelly said Taiwan should also see the issue in a broader perspective. Cross-strait trade is not conducted in a vacuum, but is part of global trade, and the world economy is in nature interdependent, he added.
He pointed out that 25 percent of Taiwan's exported products go to the mainland, and a great majority of those products then go from the mainland to the world after assembly.

Kelly said that the reason that Beijing authorities dare not impose economic sanctions on Taiwan is because if a crisis develops across the Taiwan Strait, the damage to the mainland may be as bad as to Taiwan, and this is why mainland China fired missiles in waters off Taiwan between 1995 and 1996, but dared not impose economic sanction on Taiwan.

Taiwan has a sound economic structure, trade policies, solid economic basis, good educational system, a dynamic industrial structure based mainly on small- and medium-sized enterprises. and it is currently moving toward the areas of biotechnology, optoelectronics and nanotechnlogy, he added.

But Kelly also urged Taiwan to conduct financial reforms, improve the investment environment, and implement its pledges made before entering the World Trade Organization, saying that Taiwan has much room for improvement in the area of the protection of intellectual property rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VOWS TO MAKE TAIWAN NUCLEAR-FREE ISLAND

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed his commitment Thursday to building Taiwan into a "nuclear-free, green-silicon island."

Chen made the reaffirmation at an national environmental protection meeting jointly organized by scores of local non-governmental organizations (NGOs) dedicated to protecting the ecology and wildlife.
Due to insufficient knowledge about nature, Chen said, Taiwan's ecology was seriously damaged during the previous Kuomintang administration.

Since taking office in 2000, Chen said his administration has adopted a different way of thinking and different strategies to achieve a balance between environmental protection and economic development.
In 2002, Chen said, the Legislative Yuan passed an environmental protection basic law, which sets an ultimate goal of making Taiwan a nuclear-free, high-tech island.

Noting that Taiwan is the first Asian country to declare a determination to scrap the use of nuclear energy, Chen said his administration will push for early decommissioning of the island's three existing nuclear power plants and the half-built Fourth Nuclear Power Plant.
Meanwhile, Chen said, his administration plans to hold a national conference in the near future to discuss policies on sustainable national development and exploration of new energy resources.
Chen further said his administration will refer to major conclusions reached at the ongoing NGO environmental protection meeting in formulating future national development guidelines.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HOPES EARLY RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE: U.S. OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 21 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States hopes that both sides of the Taiwan Strait begin formal talks again soon, although it will not force Taiwan to go to the negotiating table, a U.S. official said Wednesday.

James A. Kelly, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, made the remarks when he testified at a hearing marking the 25th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act at the House International Relations Committee.

Kelly said that the United States is not a direct participant in cross-strait disputes, but is keenly interested in creating an environment conducive to a peaceful resolution of cross-strait issues. For this reason, the United States has maintained strong relations with both Taipei and Beijing.

According to the "six assurances" made to Taiwan during the Reagan administration, the United States will continue to sell defensive weapons and provide services to Taiwan, as a safe and confident Taiwan will be encouraged to engage in political exchanges and dialogues with mainland China.
But the United States hopes that Taiwan will not mistake such supports as giving it a blank check to boycott dialogues with Beijing, he said.

Kelly also said that in President Chen Shui-bian's May 20, 2000 inaugural speech, he expressed his desire to resume stalled cross-strait dialogue without preconditions and laid out the "four noes plus one" pledge, which includes no referendum on the status of the nation.

Kelly noted that President Chen will face many challenges over the next few years, and the best way to deal with the crisis arising from mainland China will be to promote democracy, ensure economic growth, upgrade the wellbeing of the people, as well strengthen Taiwan's security.

Similarity, Beijing will face tough challenges, he said, in terms of overcoming poverty and backwardness, establishing the rule of law, starting the process of political reforms, and encouraging openness.
Therefore, if there is a clash, the result of reforms over the past years, and the international respect that goes with them will all go down the drain, he said.
He stressed that if war erupts in the Taiwan Strait, both sides will retrogress for scores of years.
For the sake of bilateral interests, Taipei and Beijing should resume dialogue without preconditions.

He suggested that in the absence of political dialogue, both sides can start by strengthening financial exchanges, allowing direct sea and air transportation links, increasing private contacts, establishing a confidence-building mechanism between the two sides, and upgrading the quality of communications on both sides to reduce the chances of misunderstandings.

The "six assurance" in 1982 say that the United States will not agree to set a time for ending arms sales to Taiwan, will not agree to hold prior consultations with the Chinese Communists on arms sales to Taiwan, will not play a mediation role between Taipei and Beijing, will not revise the Taiwan Relations Act, has not altered its position regarding sovereignty over Taiwan, and will not exert pressure on Taiwan to enter into negotiations with Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGES PRESIDENT CHEN TO HEED U.S. WARNING ON INDEPENDENCE

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) urged President Chen Shui-bian Thursday to heed the latest U.S. warning against Taiwan pursuing de jure independence.

KMT legislative whip Liao Feng-teh made the call after James Kelly, U.S. assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, said at a hearing of the House International Relations Committee in Washington, D.C. Wednesday that President Chen should exercise "responsible, democratic and restrained leadership" and take Beijing's military threat seriously.

Kelly pointed out in his testimony that pursuing formal Taiwan independence carries "the potential for a response from [China] -- a dangerous, objectionable and foolish response -- that could destroy much of what Taiwan has built and crush its hopes for the future."

Liao said Kelly's testimony indicates that even though President Chen has repeatedly denied that he's pursuing formal independence or seeking to change Taiwan's political status quo, the international community has a different perception of his words.
In his view, Liao said Taiwan's current crisis lies in inconsistency between PresidentChen's words and deeds.

As Taiwan's largest opposition party, Liao said, the KMT hopes that President Chen can refrain from playing "word games" and can instead seriously consider Taiwan's security in formulating his work agenda and policy initiatives.
Noting that actions speak louder than words, Liao said President Chen should honestly speak his mind and fulfill his duty of safeguarding Taiwan's security and promoting its prosperity.
Liao further said President Chen should take concrete steps to defuse international concerns about his future policies, particularly his plan to write a new constitution for Taiwan.

Since his re-election on March 20, President Chen has reiterated his plan to push for a new constitution by 2006. Chen says Taiwan needs a new constitution to resolve legislative gridlock and make its political system more efficient, but Beijing views it as a step toward independence -- a move that could provoke an attack from Beijing.

In his Wednesday testimony, Kelly also said Washington doesn't agree with a military approach because it would be "counterproductive to China's stated intent to seek a peaceful outcome" over the Taiwan issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 22, or the fourth day of the third month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1500: On his way to India with 13 ships, Portuguese navigator Pedro Alvarez Cabral discovers Brazil and claims it for Portugal.
1724: Immanuel Kant, German idealist philosopher and one of history's greatest thinkers, is born. He argued that reason is the means by which the phenomena of experience is translated into understanding. His classic works include "Critique of Pure Reason" and "Critique of Practical Reason."
1870: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, Russian leader of the Bolshevik Revolution and first leader of Communist Russia, is born.
1904: Robert Oppenheimer, American nuclear scientist who developed the atom bomb, is born.
1915: The Germans use poison gas for the first time on British troops on the Western Front during World War I.
1944: Allied forces land on Dutch New Guinea.
1947: Wei Tao-ming becomes governor of the newly established Taiwan Provincial Government.
1951: The first contingent of officers from the U.S. Military Assistance Advisory Group (MAAG) in Taiwan, arrives in Taipei. Maj. Gen. William C. Chase, the first MAAG chief, would arrive in Taipei later.
1956: Beijing appoints the Dalai Lama as chairman of a committee to prepare Tibet for regional autonomy within Communist China.
1961: The construction of the Taipei Chunghua Bazaar is completed with Gov. Chow Chih-jou of Taiwan Provincial Government presiding over the inauguration ceremony.
1969: American surgeons conduct the first human eye transplant.
1973: President Hammer de Roburt of the Republic of Nauru and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1974: A Pan American Airlines passenger plane crashes in Bali, Indonesia, killing 107 people.
1975: The first batch of Vietnamese refugees arrive on the western coast of the United States, as South Vietnam falls to the communists.
1980: S.S. Don Juan, a vehicle ferry, collides with a car float and sinks near Mindoro Island in the Philippines, killing some 1,000 people.
1984: Medical researchers working in the United States and France identify a type of human cancer virus that may be the causative agent in the killer disease Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS).
1991: The second extraordinary session of the First National Assembly passes, at its sixth plenary meeting, the Additional Articles of the Constitution of the Republic of China and approves the abolishment of the Temporary Provisions Effective During the Period of Communist Rebellion.
1992: Gasoline that leaked from a nearby refinery explodes in the sewer system of Guadalajara, Mexico, killing more than 200 people and injuring over 600 others.
1993: The Legislative Yuan ratifies a 1989 ROC-U.S. copyright agreement and passes amendments to the ROC's copyright law that go into effect April 26.
1993: Tongan Prime Minister Baron Vaea and Madame Vaea visit the Republic of China.
1994: Former U.S. President Richard M. Nixon dies of a stroke at the age of 81. He visited mainland China in 1972 and established detente with the USSR. When Congress recommended three articles of impeachment for Nixon's involvement in the Watergate scandal, he resigned from office Aug. 9, 1974.
1999: Visiting President Kirsan Nikolayevich Ilyumzhinov of the Kalmykia Republic meets with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and expresses interest in creating sisterhood ties between the Russian state and Taipei.
2000: The newly founded People First Party calls for a halt in revamping the ROC Constitution by the National Assembly, branding the draft amendments unconstitutional.
2000: The ROC Foreign Ministry formally approves the appointment of Chen Kuo-huang, director of the Foreign Ministry's Western Asian Affairs Department, as ambassador to Palau.
2001: Nobel laureate Yang Chen-ning is honored as the outstanding alumnus of the century in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, by his alma mater National Tsinghua University.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When the rulers encourage education and good manner, the people are easily amenable to government."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ENCOURAGES STUDENTS TO PURSUE SPORTSMANSHIP OVER VICTORY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian encouraged young students Friday to pursue sportsmanship rather than victory in sports.

Addressing the opening ceremony of the 2004 National Middle School Student Sports Games in Hualian, eastern Taiwan, Chen said that sportsmanship is more valuable and more precious than winning, although it is important for an athlete to have the intention, determination and preparedness to win in competitions.
Chen exhorted all participants of the games to follow the rules and to respect the judgment of officials of the games.

The games provide a venue for student athletes to demonstrate their physical strength and sports skills, Chen stressed, adding that success cannot be achieved simply, but only through persistent efforts, accumulated experiences and lessons learned from failures.
More than 8,500 middle school student athletes from across the country are attending the annual games, which will run through April 29. They will vie for 800 gold medals in 16 events.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT ORDERS IN MARCH HIGHEST SINCE LAST DECEMBER

TEXT.P: The value of export orders received by Taiwan manufacturers reached US$17.24 billion in March, a record high since last December, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Friday.
MOEA officials attributed the growth mainly to the economic recovery in Europe, the United States and several Asian countries.
The value of export orders for Taiwan represented an increase of US$3.75 billion over the same period last year, or an annual growth of 27.81 percent.

Cumulatively, the value of export orders received by Taiwan manufacturers in the first quarter totalled US$46.21 billion, an increase of US$8.54 billion over the same period last year, representing an annual growth of 22.6 percent.

Export orders for Taiwan registered new records in products related to electrical goods and electronics, basic metals, machinery, and plastic and chemical goods. The electrical and electronic industry received extra export orders worth US$630 million over the same month of last year, an annual increase of 163.4 percent.
The United States, Hong Kong, Japan and European countries continued to be the major outlets for Taiwan's exports, demanding more of the island's electronic and telecommunications products.

Chang Yaw-tzong, director-general of MOEA's Statistics Department, noted that due to the continued economic recovery around the world, the IMF has recently readjusted global economic growth from 4.1 percent to 4.6 percent, which is expected to bring more export orders for Taiwan.

Expecting stronger investment and consumption on the island, Chang also predicted a double-digit growth for export orders for Taiwan in the second quarter, if the domestic economy is not affected by non-economic factors.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PREMIER MEETS WITH MAINLAND CHINESE PRESIDENT AT FORUM
DOC.DATELINE: Boao, Hainan, April 23 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China (ROC) Premier Vincent Siew met with mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao at a welcome banquet for attendants to the 2004 annual conference of the Boao Forum for Asia (BFA), which will be held on Hainan Island, mainland China, from Saturday to Sunday.

Siew is an economic adviser to ROC president, Chen Shui-bian, and is the chairman of the private Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation. He attended the forum in his private capacity and met with Hu along with other attendants to the conference.

Before the banquet, president of the forum and former Philippines President Fidel V. Ramos told a news conference that the theme of the annual conference is "Asia Searching for Win-Win: An Asia Open to the World."

Noting that the conference has drawn some 1,000 attendants from 26 sponsoring states of the forum, including mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao, Czech Republic President Vaclav Klaus, Cambodia Prime Minister Hun Sen, Pakistan Prime Minister Mir Zafarullah Khan Jamali, former U.S. President George Bush, former Australia Prime Minister Robert Hawke and others.

Besides Vincent Siew, more than a dozen Taiwan businessmen will be present at the forum, such as Morris Chang, chairman of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company; and Kao Chin-yen, chief executive official of the Uni-President Group.

Long Yongtu, secretary-general of the forum and vice minister of foreign trade and economic cooperation of mainland China, said at a news conference Friday that he hopes the forum will provide a valuable chance for business leaders from Taiwan, Hong Kong and the mainland to exchange views.

Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee Hwa and Macau Chief Executive Edmund Ho Hau-wah attended Friday's welcome banquet and will take part in Saturday's opening ceremony during which Hu Jintao is expected to deliver a keynote speech.

Founded in 2001, the BFA is a non-governmental, non-profit, regular and open international forum with a fixed venue. Promoting high-level dialogue on regional issues such as economic development, population and the environment, the BFA is aimed at helping deepen mutual understanding and cooperation among Asian countries, and strengthen ties between Asia and the rest of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: SRI LANKA WILLING TO DEVELOP NON-OFFICIAL TIES WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Boao, Hainan, April 23 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Sri Lanka is willing to develop non-official ties with Taiwan, said Sri Lanka's former commerce minister Kingsley T. Wickramaratne Friday.

Wickramaratne who was on Hainan Island, mainland China for the Boao Forum of Asia between Saturday and Sunday said that bilateral trade between Sri Lanka and Taiwan is growing despite the absence of diplomatic ties.
As a long-standing friend of mainland China, Wickramaratne said his country sticks to the "one-China" policy and is, therefore, unable to have official ties with Taiwan.
Noting that Taipei and Colombo have non-official trade offices in each other's capital, Wickramaratne said the offices should expand their roles by promoting bilateral exchanges beyond trade.
Wickramaratne said mainland China's significant investment in Sri Lanka gives Beijing a presence there much greater than that of Taiwan, which only trades with Sri Lanka.
Taiwan may increase its presence in Sri Lanka by investing there, Wickramaratne said, listing tourism, hospitality, agriculture and the garment-making industry as ideal sectors for Taiwan investors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME NOT YET RIPE TO OPEN BOURSE TO MAINLAND CAPITAL: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The government doesn't have any plan to open the local bourse to mainland Chinese capital at the moment, Securities and Futures Commission Chairman Ting Ke-hua said Friday.
Ting made the remarks at a breakfast meeting with legislators of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).

During the meeting, TSU legislators asked whether the government is planning to open the door to mainland Chinese investment capital in order to forge a friendly atmosphere ahead of President Chen Shui-bian's inauguration for a second four-year term on May 20.

In response, Ting said the government has no intention of opening the local stock market to mainland Chinese investors any time soon. At the moment, he said, foreign institutional investors are required to sign a note ensuring that they would not use mainland capital in their investments in the Taiwan stock market.

Speaking on the same occasion, Liu Teh-hsun, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, said the government's approval of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp.'s application to built a wafer plant in mainland China has been processed in line with the law. He also said the government has yet to work out a timeframe for opening even more sophisticated electronics industries, such as memory chip testing and packaging, to invest in mainland China.

Meanwhile, Vice Finance Minister Chang Hsiu-lien said nine Taiwan life insurance and property insurance firms have been permitted to open a total of 11 representative offices and three subsidiaries in mainland China.

With a view to helping local insurers tapping into the mainland insurance market, Chang said the government is planning to allow local insurance companies to buy into mainland Chinese insurance companies.

In the initial stage, Chang said, local insurers' total investment in the mainland insurance market should not exceed NT$2 billion and the investment amount should also not exceed 40 percent of their domestic paid-in capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES TAIPAN PEOPLE TO TAKE PRECAUTIONS AGAINST SARS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun urged local people Friday to adopt all the government-suggested preventive measures against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) to keep the contagious disease out of the country.
Yu's remarks were made during a ceremony to bestow awards to excellent medical personnel, following the report on Thursday of two SARS cases in mainland China.

Yu noted that in view of the two reported SARS cases -- one in Beijing and the other in Anhui province -- the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) convened an emergency SARS prevention meeting Friday and announced that it will upgrade from Saturday the alert level against SARS to Level A, in which all inbound and outbound passengers are required to have their temperatures taken and to fill out SARS questionnaires, and those passengers arriving from SARS-affected areas should exercise health-management, including regular hand-washing and temperature-taking.
The DOH has designated four levels of alerts against SARS -- namely, Zero, A, B, and C -- with C representing the highest level of alert.
The premier noted that the DOH has made all available preparations against SARS, and urged the public not to panic but follow the prevention measures suggested by the government.

Meanwhile, Cheng Wen-tsan, a deputy director of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's communications department, said the DPP hopes that mainland China-originated SARS cases will not affect the travel plans people wishing to attend Taiwan's May 20 presidential inauguration.

Cheng noted that although the party does not hope that the epidemic will lead to a limitation or cancellation of large-scale gatherings, the party will respect all the decisions made by the Center for Disease Control (CDC) of the DOH.
Cheng added that Taiwan already has much SARS prevention experience since the SARS outbreaks on the island last spring, and he thinks the CDC will handle the situation well this time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHEFS EXCEL IN CHINESE COOKING CONTEST
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 23 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A delegation of five chefs from Taiwan excelled in a Chinese cooking contest held in Singapore Friday, with one member winning the "best chef" award among contestants from various Asian countries.
The contest was part of the Food and Hotel Asia 2004 exhibition in Singapore and was the first time that a Chinese cooking contest had been included in the expo.
To demonstrate the special flavors of Chinese food and promote exchanges of food culture, some of the best chefs in Asia were invited to participate.

Seven delegations from Singapore, Malaysia, South Korea and Taiwan sent teams to compete in the contest, in which each contestant had to prepare eight dishes of banquet food for 10 people in three hours.

A 130-member delegation organized by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council also exhibited a variety of Taiwanese food and drink at the four-day exhibition, which drew more than 10,000 buyers from around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABORIGINAL PEOPLE APPEAL TO LEGISLATURE FOR LAND

TEXT.P: A group of representatives of aboriginal communities around the island took to the streets Friday to express their concern that their traditional lands -- which have been handed down from generation to generation -- might be taken away as a result of a change in government regulations.

Accompanied by independent Legislator May Kao-Chin, the aboriginal representatives -- who came from Wulai rural township and Hsinchu County in northern Taiwan and Hualien County in the east -- lodged an appeal at the Legislative Yuan, asking that the legislature do something to stop the Ministry of the Interior from approving an amendment to the regulations governing reservation lands.

Should the amendment be approved, non-aboriginal people who have been illegally using land originally reserved for the aboriginal people, will be allowed to use or own the land they have taken, according to Kao-Chin.

If the amendment is approved, Kao-Chin said, some 11,000 hectares of reserved land will be taken from the aboriginal people who rely solely upon it as their only means of making a living. "The aboriginal people are becoming the people of no land," she warned.
The amendment is an explicit violation against the Statute of Mountainous Lands Conservation and Utility, aimed at protecting virgin or underdeveloped lands, she said.
She added that the amendment is also poised to renege the "partnership relations pact" that President Chen Shui-bian has forged with the country's aboriginal citizens.
The aboriginal group then proceeded to the Executive Yuan to voice their opposition to the amendment plans.

In related news, the Ministry of the Interior published its latest aboriginal census Friday, noting that as of the end of March, the number of aboriginal people totaled 447,000 in the Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu Area, constituting 2 percent of the entire population of the Republic of China.
Meanwhile, the aboriginal population has increased by 22.6 percent over the past 10 years, far greater than the average of 6.8 percent posted by the non-aboriginal population.

According to the census results, nearly half of the country's aboriginal people now call Hualien, Taitung and Pingtung counties their home. Of the total, some 88,000, or about 19.6 percent, live in Hualien County; 79,000, or about 17.6 percent, are in Taitung County; and 54,000, or roughly 12.1 percent, live in Pingtung.

The government currently divides Taiwan's aboriginal people into 10 major mountain tribes and 10 "Pingpu" groups. While elements of the languages and cultures of the 10 mountainous races have been maintained, most of the native languages of the "Pingpu" people have died out, with no traces remaining.

Anthropologists have said that at least one-third of Taiwan's population have the blood of "Pingpu" groups -- aboriginal people who lived in low-lying areas around the island, many of whom intermarried with Han Chinese.
The mountainous races include the Atayal, Amis, Bunun, Saisiat, Tsou, Puyuma, Rukai, Paiwan and Dawu tribes.

Taiwan's indigenous people could either have originally come from the southern part of China or from the vast region called the Austronesian-language area, which spans Madagascar in the east, across the Indian and Pacific oceans to Easter Island, and from Taiwan southward to New Zealand.
In a new theory developed in Australia and New Zealand in recent years, anthropologists believe that Taiwan is the place where the Austronesian-language people originated. (Deborah Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUNG DPP LAWMAKERS MULLING WAY TO DEFUSE ETHNIC DIVISIONS

TEXT.P: A group of young lawmakers from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) suggested Friday that the party explicitly recognize Chinese culture as an important part of Taiwanese culture to help boost ethnic harmony.

The lawmakers, including Tsai Huang-lang, Chen Chi-mai, Lee Wen-chung, Kuo Cheng-liang, Chuo Jung-tai and Lo Wen-chia, also suggested that the DPP define itself as the "ruling party of the Republic of China" to enhance public recognition of the DPP's role in today's Taiwan.
The six legislators, all in their 30s, met Thursday to discuss measures to defuse mounting political and ethnic divisions in the wake of the March 20 presidential election.

During the presidential campaign, President Chen Shui-bian often assured voters that he wouldn't cave in to Beijing, and he often questioned his sole challenger Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's willingness to stand up to Beijing. Some observers feel that political and ethnic divisions have become more serious after Taiwan-born Chen narrowly defeated mainland China-born Lien.

Except for a small group of aboriginal tribes, most of Taiwan's 23 million people are ethnic Chinese. But the population can be divided into two sub-ethnic groups: the "mainlanders" whose families fled to Taiwan when the Chinese Communists took over the mainland in 1949, and the "native Taiwanese" whose ancestors began arriving on the island in the 17th century or earlier.

The mainlanders, about 15 percent of the population, have largely supported the opposition KMT and its ally, the People First Party, and their support base is in northern Taiwan. The native Taiwanese control the south, and they tend to favor Chen's DPP and the smaller Taiwan Solidarity Union.
The mainlanders have traditionally supported eventual unification with mainland China, while the native Taiwanese lean more toward formal independence.

Legislator Lo said they have reached consensus on some major divisive issues and will present their common views to the Presidential Office, the Cabinet and DPP headquarters to serve as reference in future policy formulation.

The DPP was founded in Taiwan as opposed to the opposition KMT which moved from mainland China to Taiwan in 1949 and had ruled Taiwan for more than five decades until May 2000. The DPP used to promote de jure Taiwan independence. With a view to expanding its support base, the DPP passed a "Resolution on Taiwan's Future" in 1999, which defines Taiwan as an independent sovereign state with an official title of the "Republic of China." At the time, the DPP had not yet come to power.
Although the DPP won the presidency in 2000, many people, particularly those from the opposition camp, still perceive it as a pro-independence party intending to build a "Republic of Taiwan."

Lo said that since President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu were re-elected in the March 20 election strictly in line with ROC law, the DPP should clearly define itself as the ruling party of the ROC.
"The DPP has been in power for four years and will remain in power for the coming four years, we should step up publicity to win wide public recognition as the ROC's ruling party," Lo said.
Moreover, Lo said the DPP should separate culture from politics in defining relations across the Taiwan Strait.

"From the viewpoint of politics, Taiwan is not part of the People's Republic of China. But from the viewpoint of culture, Chinese culture is an integral and essential part of Taiwanese culture. Our language, Chinese script and Buddhist culture all come from China. This an undeniable fact. By recognizing the role of Chinese culture, the DPP will become more inclusive and may be able to attract more supporters," Lo said.

Worried about ethnic divisions, DPP Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung also urged President Chen last Firday to ban DPP politicians from kaing "love Taiwan" a campaign theme in the year-end legislative election.

Shen, a physician-turned-lawmaker, said he is convinced that an overwhelming majority of local residents love Taiwan. Therefore, he said, the ruling DPP should not make "love Taiwan" its campaign theme or platform any longer.
"All politicians, particularly DPP members, should refrain from taking advantage of this topic," Shen urged.

As a ruling party, Shen went on, the DPP should not use differences over policy toward mainland China, feelings toward mainland China and the time of immigration from mainland China as standards to measure whether an individual person loves Taiwan or not.

Since there is not an objective and scientific method to gauge the magnitude of a "love for Taiwan," Shen said, the DPP should not bring up this topic in its campaign literature or rallies in the run-up to the December legislative elections.

"As the DPP chairman, President Chen is also obligated to 'do something' to mend ethnic divisions which have become very serious after the presidential election, " Shen said, adding that Chen should order all party members intending to run in the year-end legislative elections to refrain from campaigning on a "love Taiwan" platform and from bringing up ethnic issues.

New York Times: Commission to Allow Insurance Cuts for Retired Employees.
The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission voted Thursday to allow employers to reduce or eliminate health benefits for retirees when they become eligible for Medicare at age 65.
Employers and some labor unions supported the change, saying it would help preserve coverage for early retirees. But AARP, which represents millions of Americans age 50 and older, strenuously objected.
The new rule creates a potentially explosive political issue, because it will create anxiety for many of the 12 million Medicare beneficiaries who also receive health benefits from their former employers.
Wall Street Journal: Google Is Expected to Announce Plans for Initial Public Offering.
Internet-search pioneer Google Inc. plans to announce within days that it will push forward with an initial public offering, according to people familiar with the matter.
The announcement is linked to the fact that Google will soon be required to disclose publicly more information about its business, under a Securities and Exchange Commission rule triggered after closely held companies surpass a certain size. Google is expected to have to make such disclosures as early as next week. Lawyers have said that the disclosure requirements can be a trigger for companies to list their shares.
Any IPO would likely come as the technology market has rebounded from its lows, Internet companies have seen their shares rise, and revenue, particularly from advertising, has returned. Google couldn't be filing for an IPO at a more opportune time: the company is the No. 1Web-site destination for Internet search. It has expanded its offerings in recent months, most recently with the test launch of a free e-mail service.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS URGES PUBLIC TO AVOID MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged the public Friday to refrain from traveling to mainland China after reports of two suspected cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) there.
The SARS cases were the first to be reported on the mainland following the outbreaks that lasted from early last year until the summer.

Lee Chun-yi, DPP legislative whip, expressed concern about the two infected mainland residents, but at the same time expressed regret that the mainland authorities failed to immediately inform Taiwan of the cases.
Lee noted that the atypical pneumonia caused heavy losses in Taiwan last year, including 37 deaths, and claimed this was because of Beijing's deliberate hiding of the SARS outbreaks on its territory.

The Department of Health has announced a heightening of its SARS alert level from Zero to A from Saturday, which will include mandatory daily temperature-taking in schools and kindergartens, while passengers arriving from mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau will be instructed to exercise health-management measures.
DPP Legislator Tsai Huang-liang also suggested that Taiwan residents should refrain from traveling to the mainland to avoid being infected.
Lee also said he would suggest to the Presidential Office that mass rallies should be scaled down to minimize the chances of transmission during such rallies.

As for a planned cerebration rally of 500,000 people on the May 20 inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian, there are no plans for any changes, although the caucus will ask the Presidential Office to give it second thoughts.

Lee also urged the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party not to become "addicted to mass rallies." He was referring to the several mass protest rallies staged by the alliance in the wake of the March 20 presidential election, which the defeated opposition claims was "unfair."

DOC.HEADLINE: MONUMENT TO LABOR TO BE ERECTED AT TAIPEI 101

TEXT.P: A monument commemorating the value of work will be erected at the Taipei 101 complex, also known as the Taipei Financial Center, in Taipei's Hsinyi district, labor rights activists said Friday.

It will be Taiwan's first monument to be commissioned and erected by major local labor organizations and business corporations to promote safety and health at work, said Huang Hsiao-ling, secretary-general of the Taiwan Association for Victims of Occupational Injury (TAVOI).
Construction of the monument, to be named "Partners, " will get underway April 28, which is also World Day for Safety and Health at Work, Huang said.

She further said the monument will also be dedicated to the memory of the six workers who died in an accident during construction of the 101-storey Taipei Financial Center, the world's tallest building.
"We hope the monument construction project will help arouse public awareness of the importance of promoting workplace safety and health," Huang said.

Quoting official tallies, Huang said more than 60,000 local workers died in occupational accidents between 1957 and 2002, while nearly 300,000 workers became disabled due to occupational injuries during the same period.
Huang said 168 countries around the world stage memorial services annually on World Day for Safety and Health at Work in remembrance of those who died in occupational accidents.

To push the government and corporate managers to pay more heed to workplace safety and health, Huang said the TAVOI and several other labor rights groups will jointly organize a series of activities, including an exhibition of paintings created by occupational injury victims, a musical featuring the plight of occupational injury victims and a seminar on overwork issues in the run-up to April 28.
Huang said the TAVOI will also press the government to amend the existing occupational injury protection law to offer victims better benefits and assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SALT INDUSTRIAL CORP. HAS FAITH IN BECOMING BIG BRAND NAME

TEXT.P: The state-controlled Taiwan Salt Industrial Corp. has faith in its ability to become an international big brand name of diverse products, TSIC Chairman Cheng Pao-ching said Friday.

Cheng made the remarks after signing an OEM contract with Minntech Corp. of the United States, a leading medical device manufacturer. Under the terms of the contract, the TSIC will produce hemodialysis solutions for Minntech, while the latter will help introduce TSIC's cosmetic products to the global market.

Pushed by Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization and its planned privatization, the TSIC has been dedicated to business diversification in the last few years, launching new products ranging from cosmetics and health foods to laser printer components.
Not only have many local cosmetic users switched to TSIC products, Minntech also expressed keen interest in selling TSIC's cosmetic products with medical applications.
Cheng revealed that the TSIC will also launch cosmetics for men in the near future, and he said he has great confidence in the company's products on the world market.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN MAINTAINING GUARD AGAINST SARS: HEALTH OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Kinmen has never let down its guard against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) , with passengers arriving at Kinmen airport and harbor having their temperatures taken since last year, health officials of the outlying island said Friday.
The officials made the remarks after the Department of Health announced Friday a heightening of the alert level from Zero to A in the wake of two reported suspected SARS in mainland China.
The DOH has designated four levels of SARS precaution -- Zero, A, B, and C -- with C representing the highest level of alert.

Level A means that all inbound and outbound passengers are required to have their temperatures taken and to fill out forms stating that they have not been in contact with suspected cases. All passengers arriving from mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau have additionally to exercise health-management, including regular hand-washing and temperature taking, while all government agencies and institutions are advised to conduct temperature taking measures.

Also under Level A, all elementary and high schools, kindergartens and nurseries around the island should take their students' temperatures every day. Moreover, hospitals and SARS monitoring stations around Taiwan are required to report their SARS prevention situation every week to the DOH.

Kinmen is one of the two outlying islands that have close exchanges with mainland China after direct trade, postal and transport links, or the "mini three links" with Fujian province were established in 2001. The other is Matsu.
Kinmen health official Chen Tien-shun said that temperature-taking measures for inbound and outbound tourists have never stopped since the outbreaks of SARS in Taiwan early last year.

Chen said that Kinmen has maintained a level A alert because of its proximity to the mainland, adding that since March this year, all Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland, not just Taiwan businessmen in Fujian Province, have been able to travel between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait via the "mini three links" channel, so that the officials have to be more cautious.

Yen Chi-heng, an official of the DOH's Center for Disease Control, said that infrared thermal imaging machines were installed at the harbor and airport to measure temperatures, and arriving passengers have to fill out health forms. If an arriving passenger is detected to have a temperature of over 38 degrees, he or she will be sent to Kinmen county hospital for further checkups.
Taiwan was hit hard by SARS between March and June last year, resulting in incalculable trade and economic losses, as well as 37 fatalities.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES MAINLAND CHINA TO REFRAIN FROM CONCEALING SARS CASES

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) urged the mainland Chinese authorities Friday to refrain from concealing cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) now that the potentially fatal flu-like disease is showing signs of resurgence.

Chen Ming-tong, vice chairman of the MAC, Taiwan's top mainland China policy planning agency, said the latest two suspected SARS cases -- one in Beijing and one in the west-central province of Anhui -- were only made known several days after they came to light, underlining once again the mainland authorities' habit of withholding information on SARS and other epidemic diseases.
Chen said such concealment, presumably aimed at protecting the mainland's international image, is putting people's lives at stake and risks harming the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

The latest two reported cases -- one involving a nurse working in a Beijing hospital and the other involving an unidentified resident of Anhui Province -- are the first to be reported since the initial outbreak of the disease there subsided last summer.

To cope with policies adopted by the Department of Health, which has upgraded Taiwan's epidemic prevention mobilization level against SARS from level Zero to level A, the MAC has also activated a series of SARS-prevention measures that will begin Saturday.

The measures include that people entering Taiwan from mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau will be required to conduct self-health control; that all inbound and outbound passengers will be required to have their temperatures taken; and that the MAC will try to obtain quick and first-hand information about the SARS situation in mainland China via the MAC-authorized office in Hong Kong and the intermediary Straits Exchange Foundation.

The MAC also appealed to Taiwan citizens who have traveled to the mainland to tell their doctor about their travel history if they develop fever so as to facilitate the control and treatment of the communicable disease.
The MAC is also hastening to have more copies of an anti-SARS handbook printed so that mainland-bound visitors can use them to ensure a safer trip to the mainland, Chen said.

The recurrence of SARS underlines once again the imperative of cross-strait cooperation in battling epidemic diseases, given that people from the two sides of the strait have increased their interactions by leaps and bounds, Chen noted.

He added that it is the mainland authorities' responsibility to quickly notify Taiwan whenever a SARS case is reported on the mainland, given that the two sides are now inextricably close, both economically and socially.

In view of the fact that SARS is communicable in closed transportation vehicles such as planes and ferries, authorities from the two sides should communicate further between themselves about details of cross-strait transportation links, Chen said.
Chen noted, however, that an outbreak of SARS should not be an obstacle preventing both sides from beginning talks on direct cross-strait transportation links.

Pointing out that direct cross-strait transportation links talks hinged upon the willingness of Beijing, Chen said Taipei has long been ready and that the talks can start at any time, so long as Beijing is willing.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND ACTIVATES SARS PREVENTION MECHANISM

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Friday it has ordered military units to take the temperature of every service member during morning and evening roll calls every day as part of its efforts to prevent severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreaks.
Maj. Gen. Lu Li-chun, director of the MND's Medical Affairs Bureau, made the remarks after attending a supraministerial SARS prevention meeting organized by the Department of Health (DOH).

The meeting came after two suspected cases of the potentially deadly disease were reported in mainland China. It was decided at the meeting that Taiwan's epidemic prevention mobilization level against SARS will be upgraded from Level Zero to Level A from Saturday.
In fact, Lu said, the military has continued to implement temperature-taking and self-health management measures since early January with a view to preventing a SARS comeback.

"Now that the DOH has decided to launch the level A SARS prevention campaign, the MND will continue its twice-daily temperature-taking and self-health management measures to stem any possible SARS outbreak in military barracks, " Lu said, adding that his bureau will also strengthen its monitoring of relevant epidemic developments.
The health authorities have a four-level SARS alert system -- Zero, A, B, and C -- with level C being the highest level of alert.

Level A means all inbound and outbound passengers are required to have their temperatures taken and to fill out SARS questionnaires. All passengers arriving from mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau have to exercise health-management, including regular hand-washing and temperature-taking, while all government agencies and institutions are advised to conduct temperature taking.

Also under level A, all junior high and elementary schools, kindergartens and nurseries around the nation should take their students' temperatures every day. Moreover, hospitals and SARS monitoring stations around Taiwan are required to report their SARS situation every week to the DOH.

Two new suspected SARS cases were reported in mainland China Thursday -- a 20-year-old nurse in Beijing and a 26-year-old woman in the eastern province of Anhui. Mainland Chinese health officials said they have isolated at least five others who reported suffering fevers -- a key SARS symptom -- and are monitoring scores more.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN SMUGGLING HEROIN IN SHOES NABBED AT AIRPORT

TEXT.P: A Taipei resident attempting to smuggle more than 500 grams of heroin into Taiwan from mainland China in his shoes was arrested at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Thursday night, coast guard officials said Friday.
The 32-year-old man, surnamed Huang, packed the heroin into eight plastic sacks and hid them in the soles of his shoes.
Coast guard officers based in Kaohsiung said they were tipped off in early March that a drug trafficking ring was planning to smuggle heroin from mainland China to Taiwan by air or by fishing boat.
Huang, who has been brought to Kaohsiung for questioning, said he purchased the heroin in Zhuhai City, Guangdong Province, for his personal consumption.
The police found that Huang, who has a criminal record that includes theft and drug-trafficking convictions, has traveled to Guangdong many times over the past several years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 23, or the fifth day of the third month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1616: William Shakespeare, English playwright and poet whose body of works is considered by most as the greatest in English literature, dies at New Place at the age of 52.
1616: Miguel de Cervantes, Spanish writer best known for his classic satirical novel "Don Quixote," dies at the age of 69.
1873: The Dutch war against the Sultan of Achin begins in northwest Sumatra, Indonesia.
1895: Russia, Germany and France protest the ceding of Chinese territory to Japan.
1897: Lester Pearson, Canadian prime minister from 1963-1968, is born. He won the 1957 Nobel Peace Prize for his part in settling the Suez crisis.
1919: Peking Teachers High School for Girls is formally established.
1928: Shirley Temple Black, American child star who went on to become the U.S. ambassador to Ghana, is born. As Shirley Temple, she was an immensely popular child actress of the 1930s, starring in films such as "Wee Willie Winkie" and "Bright Eyes."
1935: Joseph Stalin officially opens the Moscow underground rail system.
1945: U.S. and Soviet forces meet at Torgau in eastern Germany.
1946: Hsia Kai-chun, noted writer of modern Chinese literature, dies in Shanghai at the age of 63.
1949: Government forces of the Republic of China evacuate Nanking.
1962: In the biggest-ever "ban the bomb" demonstration, some 150,000 people rally in London's Hyde Park.
1965: The Soviet Union launches its first communications satellite.
1965: President Charles de Gaulle of France emphasizes his opposition to the United States' Asian policies by withdrawing French units from naval maneuvers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization.
1969: A Los Angeles jury decides that Sirhan B. Sirhan should be sent to the gas chamber for the murder of Sen. Robert Kennedy in June 1968.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford declares the Vietnam War is over as panic grips Saigon after the South Vietnamese regime's Cabinet resigns.
1985: The Industrial Technology Research Institute successfully develops an amorphous-silicon solar battery of high commercial value.
1986: National Taiwan University Hospital separates a pair of 14-day-old Siamese twins, saving the life of one of the girls. The twins set a record for being the youngest to be separated.
1990: Li Peng, premier of mainland China, arrives in Moscow for a visit, becoming the most senior Beijing leader to tour the Soviet Union in 26 years.
1991: Tens of thousands of striking Soviet workers fill the streets in Minsk on the eve of the Communist Party plenum.
1997: After 26 days of occupation by rebels, Peru's government launches a sudden attack on the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima, freeing 71 hostages. Three soldiers, one hostage and all 14 guerrillas die in the attack.
1999: State-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. inaugurates a phalaenopsis plant in Costa Rica, with scores of ranking Costa Rican government officials attending the ceremony.
2000: Former U.S. Assistant Secretary for East Asia and Pacific Affairs Winston Lord visits People First Party Chairman James Soong to exchange opinions on the Taiwan Strait situation.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian and Vice President-elect Annette Lu kick off an island-wide tour to express thanks to their supporters in the March 18 presidential election.
2001: Computer chip giant Intel signs a memorandum of cooperation with the Industrial Development Bureau and the Technology Department under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is one who sets himself seriously to order his conversation aright."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FIRMS REAP REWARDS AT ASIAN FOOD SHOW
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 24 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: More than 90 Taiwan firms that participated in the Food and Hotel Asia 2004 exhibition held in Singapore have obtained fruitful results, receiving orders worth US$1.2 million, a Taiwan trade official said Saturday.
"The figure does not include potential orders worth more than US$4 million, " said Liu Hsi-wei, a department chief of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).
A total of 99 Taiwan firms participated in the four-day exhibition, the ninth-largest delegation from around the world.
According to Liu, the organic products of several Taiwan firms were popular at the show, with five buyers expressing strong interest.
Taiwan-cultivated rice is another favorite for Singaporeans. However, exports to Singapore have encountered several trade barriers imposed by the Singaporean government, Liu added.
The four-day exhibition, which drew tens of thousands of visitors from around the world, concluded Friday.
