DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 24, or the third day of the third month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1731: Daniel Defoe, British journalist, novelist and economist, dies at the age of 71. His works include "Robinson Crusoe" and "Moll Flanders."
1800: The U.S. Congress votes to set up a congressional library.
1898: Spain declares war on the United States after receiving a U.S. ultimatum to pull out of Cuba.
1919: Chan Tien-yu, a railway pioneer in China, dies in Hankou at the age of 59.
1941: Hsieh Chin-yuan, a Chinese hero in the War of Resistance Against Japan, is assassinated at the age of 37. The ROC Army regimental commander led his "800 Brave Fighters" in a heroic battle against invading Japanese troops at a warehouse in Shanghai. Shanghai was captured by the Japanese on Nov. 11, 1937, after three months of fierce fighting.
1946: The ROC government postpones the convention of the National Assembly set for May 6, 1946.
1948: Lin Hsien-tang is appointed head of the Historical Research Commission of Taiwan Province.
1955: The Bandung Conference ends with five Asian states condemning colonialism by both the West and the Soviet Union.
1963: "Liang Shan-po and Chu Ying-tai," a movie directed by Lee Han-hsiang, premieres in Taipei and receives a warm welcome from a large audience.
1965: The Indonesian government formally takes control of all foreign companies in the country.
1967: Soviet cosmonaut Vladimir Komarov plunges to Earth and dies when parachute straps on his Soyuz craft get tangled.
1970: Vice Premier Chiang Ching-kuo arrives in New York for a visit and survives an assassination attempt in front of his hotel by a pro-Taiwan independence radical.
1970: Mainland China launches its first satellite, the Dong Fang Hong, into orbit.
1970: The Food and Fertilizer Technology Center of the Asian and Pacific Council is inaugurated in Taipei.
1974: A 16-member Orient Trade Mission of the U.S. Pacific Northwest International Trade Council, led by William Martin, president of the council, arrives in Taipei for a three-day business trip.
1975: Thousands of Vietnamese refugees are flown to Guam as communists move rapidly in their takeover of South Vietnam.
1976: The 1976 convention of 4-H Clubs opens in Taipei with more than 300 delegates taking part.
1981: A train encounters a landslide while on its way to Mt. Ali in Chiayi County, killing 10 passengers and injuring 19 others.
1986: Wallis Simpson, Duchess of Windsor, for whom a British king gave up his throne amid great controversy, dies in Paris at the age of 89.
1986: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Chu Fu-sung and Paraguayan Foreign Minister Carlos Augusto Saldivar sign an extradition treaty in Taipei on behalf of their respective governments.
1990: West and East Germany agree to set July 2 as the date for economic union, a prelude to full political unification.
1996: Russian President Boris Yeltsin meets with his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, at the start of a visit to Beijing.
1997: The head of states of Russia, mainland China, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan sign a pact on troop reduction along the former Sino-Soviet border.
2000: The ROC National Assembly begins to fade into history after it downgrades itself to a virtual ceremonial organization without much power by passing a series of constitutional amendments during a third reading.
2001: Competition at the Second Asian Physics Olympiad kicks off in Taipei with 81 senior high school students from 12 countries participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man sometimes also meets with distress; but a fool, when in distress, becomes reckless."

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA CHAIRWOMAN RULES OUT IMPORT OF WORKERS FROM MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairwoman Chen Chu said Saturday that she will not lift a ban on imports of mainland Chinese blue-collar workers during her stint as the nation's top labor administrator.
Chen made the pledge in a speech delivered at a special class for graduate students at National Sun Yat-sen University in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
With a view to protecting the employment rights of Taiwanese workers, Chen said Taiwan's job market will not be opened to mainland blue-collar workers so long as she is in her current post.

Chen's promise came after the county government of the offshore defense outpost of Kinmen, which lies closer to mainland China's Fujian Province than to Taiwan, began pushing the CLA to permit the import of mainland laborers to Kinmen.
In her speech, Chen also said the CLA is working ahrd to realize its goal of setting up a vocational training and job placement center in each township around Taiwan.

"The one-township-one-footfold plan is aimed at letting every unemployed worker receive unemployment subsidy and suitable vocational training so that they can return to the job market again," Chen said, adding that the CLA will further integrate job training resources and commission professional institutes to assist in manpower training.

Chen said the CLA will also streampline job placement services to ensure that disadvantaged groups, including indigenous people, divorced women with young children and middle-age unemployed workers, receive suitable job opportunities.

Noting that reducing the number of foreign workers has been one of the toughest tasks for the CLA, Chen said the number of foreign workers in the construction and manufacturing industries has declined, but the number of foreign caregivers has continued to increase due to humanitarian considerations.

"If we cut the number of foreign caregivers, more than 110,000 local families with disabled family members will face even more hardships and difficulties," Chen said, adding that the CLA is still figuring feasible measures to resolve relevant issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PITCHES FOR TRUST

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the opposition "pan-blue alliance" Saturday to heed the legality and legitimacy of its methods while contesting the result of the March 20 presidential election.

Chen won re-election by a slim margin of 29,518 votes out of the more than 13 million ballots cast in the poll -- a result that defeated "pan-blue alliance" presidential candidate Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan has contested by bringing two lawsuits, while his supporters have engaged in sometimes violent street protests.
Addressing a joint opening ceremony for classes at the Ketagalan Academy, Chen said that in democratic society, people are eligible to express their opinions.

"What I'm worried about is the reasons for and methods of the protests. I'm convinced that the majority of our people disagree with the use of the national flag to attack police officers. Nor would they agree to protesters storming the Central Election Commission and police offices under the shield of the national flag," Chen said.

"Pan-blue alliance" supporters have staged a string of protests over the past month, several of which have turned violent. In the worst case two weeks ago, protesters targeted police with gas bombs and slingshots, leading to clashes with police that left more than 140 people injured.
Stressing that patriotism cannot justify violent acts, Chen said social stability and national progress are extremely important in a democratic society like Taiwan.

Chen further said he firmly supports a legal settlement to election disputes, but he added that he is very worried about how government authority can be enforced if there is no trust in the judiciary, investigators, physicians or even internationally renowned forensic experts.

The KMT-led "pan-blue alliance" has filed two lawsuits seeking to nullify the election results and even the entire election so that a new one can be held. Chen has agreed to a full-scale vote recount even though the "pan-blue alliance" has provided little evidence of any voting irregularities. The Taiwan High Court has tentatively decided to start the vote recount by May 10 so that the work can be completed by May 20, when Chen will be sworn in for a second four-year term.
It remains unclear how the "pan-blue alliance" will respond if the recount fails to reverse the result.

Meanwhile, the alliance has been pushing the government to form an investigative committee under the Legislative Yuan to probe the unsolved election-eve 19 shooting that slightly injured Chen and Vice President Annette Lu. The alliance argues that the shooting unfairly swayed sympathy votes in Chen's favor and has even insinuated that the shooting was staged, again, without any supporting evidence.

In fact, law enforcement authorities have already formed a special task fore to investigate the shooting, with State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa as its convener. The task force has invited renowned U.S. experts, including renowned Chinese-American forensic scientist Dr. Henry Lee, to assist in examining the physical evidence gathered from the scene of the shooting.
The "pan-blue alliance" is still reluctant to drop its allegations against the shooting, even though the U.S. forensics experts have largely ruled out any possibility that the shooting was staged.

Chen said all these disputes indicate that there is still ample room for improvement in Taiwan's young democracy. "Trust is the bedrock of democratic development. We'll pursue not only a tangible democratic system but also intangible democratic culture, quality and way of life," he added.

The Ketagalan Academy was founded by Chen last year to nurture a new generation of leaders in various fields. Chen said at Saturday's ceremony that the school is aimed at cultivating leadership talent that can contribute to Taiwan's democratic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVERAL DPP LAWMAKERS TO JOIN ADMINISTRATION: PARTY OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Several lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) are expected to join the administration during President Chen Shui-bian's second term, a senior DPP official said Saturday.

The official, who asked not to be named, confirmed a local newspaper report Saturday that DPP Legislator Luo Wen-chia will fill the vacancy left by Yeh Chu-lan as chairman of the Council for Hakka Affairs after Yeh is promoted to the post of deputy premier.
Meanwhile, Legislator Cho Jung-tai will replace Chen Che-nan as deputy general-secretary of the Presidential Office.

Legislator Chen Chi-mai, who served as spokesman for the DPP legislative caucus and was said to replace Lin Chia-lung as spokesman for the Executive Yuan in the same report, confirmed that he has been approached for a possible job in the administration, but said that no specific offer had been made to him thus far.

The anonymous DPP official said there is a consensus among the DPP leadership that more capable party lawmakers need to be groomed into future party leaders by broadening their horizons with experience of service in the government.

However, Legislator Yeh Yi-jin denied a report that she will be recruited into the new Cabinet as head of the National Youth Commission, saying it is not her plan and that she has commitments to her constituents in Tainan.
Instead, Yeh said, she will enter the year-end race for another term in the Legislative Yuan. She denounced the report as a plot to ruin her re-election campaign.
Minister without Portfolio Chen Chi-nan, who was said to take over the Council for Cultural Affairs in the report, said he has not yet been consulted.
However, he went on, "as a member of the ruling team, I will do whatever job is assigned to me."

DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung denied that he was tapped to be president of the Control Yuan, pointing out that the term of the incumbent chief of the Control Yuan has not yet ended and that the report is mere newspaper speculation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ON ALERT AGAINST SARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan raised its alert against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) Saturday after Beijing confirmed two cases a day earlier in mainland China, in addition to two already reported suspected cases and one possible fatality.

Health officials began taking the temperatures of inbound passengers at the country's international airports. Those who show an abnormally high temperature on a thermal imaging system will be asked to undergo temperature-checking with an ear thermometer, according to the Department of Heath.

Passengers arriving from Beijing and Anhui -- the two regions where the latest SARS cases were found -- will be required to complete an investigation form at the airport and will be subject to daily checks by medical workers via telephone for at least 10 days to ensure that they have not developed SARS symptoms.
As no cases have yet been reported in Taiwan so far, outbound passengers are not required to have their temperatures taken, the health officials said.
Similar precautionary measures are being taken at local hospitals, with thermal imaging equipment set up at entrances.

Medical staff are required to wear surgical masks in hospitals and those who have visited Beijing or Anhui recently have been asked to take their own temperature twice a day and alert medical staff if they develop fever that is typical of SARS.
Health authorities also suggested that the public wash their hands frequently, which is an easy and effective way to destroy the coronavirus that causes the disease.

Department of Health Minister Chen Chien-jen said there are plenty of surgical masks and gowns to meet one month's-worth of heavy demand should the disease develop into an epidemic, or between six month's- and a year's-worth in the preliminary stages.

He estimated that the number of SARS cases on the mainland will surge to between 30 and 300, given that a virus-carrier traveled between Beijing and Hefei in Anhui Province before being admitted to a hospital in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMISTS ESTIMATE LITTLE IMPACT ON ECONOMY FROM SARS

TEXT.P: Although a resurgence of suspected cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in mainland China has prompted Taiwan to upgrade its alert level against the disease, several economists forecast Saturday that it is not expected to cause a major impact on the local economy.

Taiwan activated a level A alert against SARS Saturday in the wake of a report of two suspected SARS cases on the mainland -- one in Beijing and the other in Anhui Province. It was the first such case so far this year after SARS outbreaks last spring.

Kung Ming-hsing, a section director of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, noted that as Taiwan already has mechanisms and preparations for the fight against the flu-like disease, he predicted that this time, Taiwan's economy will suffer much less than it did last year.
Fortunately, Kung said, the areas where the new SARS cases appeared are not traditionally the main areas where Taiwan companies set up their mainland operations.
However, Kung added that if the mainland government makes the SARS situation there more transparent, the impact on Taiwan will be much smaller.
Meanwhile, Chou Chi, a department director of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, said it remains to be seen whether the SARS situation will worsen on the mainland.

If the mainland authorities cancel a traditional long vacation for laborers in early May due to the epidemic, it will affect Taiwan's exports of certain items there, as many people use the holiday period to buy "hot" consumer goods such as mobile phones.

Last May, when SARS cases were rampant on the mainland, the government canceled the holiday in order not to further propagate the epidemic, resulting indirectly in the decrease of sales of some Taiwan-made products.
However, Chou said that in comparison with the worldwide SARS panic last year, this time both the government and the public in Taiwan are more prepared for a possible resurgence of the disease.

President Bush and his senior national security and military advisers are expected to decide this weekend whether to order an invasion of Falluja, even if a battle there runs the risk of uprisings in the city and perhaps elsewhere around Iraq.
Administration officials said that in Camp David President Bush planned consultations in a videoconference with the military commanders who are keeping the city under siege.

As Mr. Bush discusses strategy for Falluja, administration and senior military officials portray his choices as dismal. One senior official involved in the discussions said that "the question now is whether there is a way to go in with the most minimal casualties possible."
Wall Street Journal: Bombings at Iraqi Oil Terminals Leave Two U.S. Sailors Dead.

Suicide boat bombings targeting Iraq's key oil industry forced the closure of two major terminals in the Gulf for several hours, but the facilities resumed work loading tankers on Sunday, Iraq's top oil marketing official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-CANADA SEMINAR AGREES TO COOPERATION ON FUEL BATTERY

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Canada co-sponsored a seminar last week in Vancouver in which government officials and experts from the two countries unveiled their research results and agreed to forge two-way cooperation on new energy sources, according to officials of the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC).

In the symposium attended by officials and specialists from the NSC, the Industrial Technology Research Institute and Canada's National Research Council, a total of 16 research reports were made public and 12 cooperative ventures on the latest developments to use fuel batteries as an alternative energy source were agreed upon, the officials said.
The officials said that they are happy that Taiwan-Canada scientific cooperation has made a big step toward closer collaboration in view of the keen interest displayed by the two sides.

The exploration of the expertise on using fuel batteries as a new energy source is a key development area covered by the government's "Challenge 2008" -- a six-year national development plan aimed at transforming Taiwan into a country in which high technologies and environmental protection can co-exist, they noted.
According to the NSC officials, the seminar was the first ever of its kind held by the government, academic and industrial sectors of the two countries.
Richard Normandin, vice president of Canada's National Research Council, gave a speech on the occasion and called for more frequent substantial exchanges between the two countries.

Attendees from Taiwan, including professor Chen Fa-lin with National Taiwan University, also paid a visit to the Canada National Research Council's fuel battery laboratory and Power Tech and Greenlight Power Technologies, two companies devoted to the development and services of fuel battery, as part of their efforts to better understand the world's most advanced technologies in the field.

DOC.HEADLINE: RIGHT PERSON IN RIGHT POST IN NEW CABINET: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun will reshuffle the Cabinet by "putting the right person in the right post" regardless of their political affiliation, Cabinet spokesman Lin Chia-lung said Sunday.

Lin made the remarks in an apparent rebut to widespread media speculation that claimed that various Cabinet-level members who are widely assumed to be supportive of the opposition camp will be replaced in the upcoming Cabinet reshuffle with President Chen Shui-bian's re-election on March 20.
Describing such reports as incorrect and unfair, Lin called on the media not to speculate over the Cabinet reshuffle and stressed that the administration led by Yu is running smoothly.

"The outside world should refrain from doing this so as not to hurt the feelings of some people, " Lin said, pointing out that the premier has phoned various officials named by the media to ease their concern and encourage them after learning of the reports.

Hsieh Fa-ta, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, Lee Chien-chuan, vice chairman of the Council of Agriculture, and Chang Juu-en, Environmental Protection Administration minister were recently singled out by the local media as very likely to be replaced in the upcoming Cabinet personnel changes for reasons of their political affiliation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 78-YEAR-OLD WOMAN HAS FALSE ALARM OVER SARS

TEXT.P: A 78-year-old woman returning from mainland China thought she was affected with severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), but wasn't.
The woman, surnamed Huang, lives in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan and she travels frequently between Taiwan and mainland China. She returned from Shanghai only four days ago.
She was feeling unwell and developing a slight fever after her return. Afraid that she might have been affected with SARS, she called for assistance Sunday morning.
An ambulance rushed her to Taoyuan Hospital, but doctors found that her fever had subsided and that her symptoms did not match that of the atypical pneumonia, so she was released in the afternoon.
Taiwan was hit hard by SARS between March and June last year, resulting in 37 deaths and heavy economic losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES PASSAGE OF CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS BEFORE CABINET RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: Taipei, April 25 (CAN) The Legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Sunday that the Cabinet should only resign en masse after the passage of the 10 major construction projects in the legislature.

Ker Chien-ming, DPP whip in the legislature, said that if the ruling and opposition parties, after four months of consultations which will end April 30, still cannot reach an agreement on the expansion of the public construction investment bill, which will provide the legal basis for the five-year, NT$500 billion (US$15.15 billion) construction projects, then it will have to put the bill to a vote.
He said that only after the bill is passed can the legislature start to review the special budgets for the construction projects.

He noted that the Executive Yuan was to resign en masse May 5, and that the line-up of the next Cabinet will assume office May 20 when President Chen Shui-bian is sworn in for a second term in office.

But he said that Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who concurrently serves as the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) vice chairman, and other KMT legislators have questioned the necessity of passing the bill because Premier Yu Shyi-kun's Cabinet will be a "guardian Cabinet" during the transition period.

Believing that the public construction projects have to be carried out continuously and that they should not be affected by the Cabinet change, Ker said that if the Cabinet resigns en masse too early, it will give opposition parties excuses to challenge the legality of passing the bill.
Meanwhile, Lin Chia-lung, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan echoed Ker's view that the construction projects should be passed soon.

Responding to reports that the KMT legislative caucus is not ruling out the possibility of reviewing the special budget for the construction projects only after the inauguration of President Chen May 20, Lin urged the opposition to set a timetable.
He reaffirmed that although the Cabinet will resign en masse, which is a formality under the Constitution, administration work will not be interrupted.
Lin said that the projects will provide a chance for reconciliation between the ruling and the opposition parties after the bitterly contested March 20 presidential election.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun hopes to call on Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang, and hopes that Wang can coordinate a meeting between the ruling and opposition parties for a speedy review of the 10 construction projects, according to Lin.

Lin urged the opposition Legislative Yuan caucus to set a timetable for approving the projects this session, which ends in May, and "we will respect it." If the timetable is not adhered to, the opposition parties "will have to take responsibility," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONSCIOUSNESS AT CORE OF NEW POLITICAL LANDSCAPE: CNA CHIEF
DOC.DATELINE: Frankfurt, April 24 (CNA) (By Liao Yi-jun & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: The rise of people's identification with Taiwan has been a decisive factor in the shift of Taiwan's political landscape, Su Tzen-ping, chairman of the Central News Agency, said Saturday in Frankfurt.

Addressing a meeting of the German Chapter of the Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace, Su said many opinion polls in Taiwan have shown that the number of Taiwan residents who identify themselves as Taiwanese has been increasing, while the number of those who identify themselves as Chinese has been decreasing.

The trend was borne out in the result of Taiwan's March 20 presidential election that saw President Chen Shui-bian, an advocate of a Taiwan-centric consciousness, win re-election with more than 6.47 million votes, up nearly 1.5 million votes over the figure he obtained four years ago, Su noted.

Basically, Su went on, there exists no conspicuous difference between the public policies of the "pan green camp, " who support Chen, and the opposition "pan blue alliance" of Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan.

Furthermore, he added, given Beijing's insistence in its "one-China" principle and intervention by the United States in cross-Taiwan Strait issues, the policies related to Taiwan's independence or its unification with mainland China by both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the KMT have few differences.

What does make them different is that political evolution in Taiwan has been moving toward the "pan green camp" since the lifting of martial law in 1987, due to the emergence of a consciousness of Taiwan identity, Su told the nearly 100 participants at the meeting.

Any division of ethnic groups in Taiwan derives from the rivalry of national identity, Su said, suggesting that how to deal with this problem will be an important issue for the future of Taiwan's democratic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTEGRATING MAINLAND, TAIWAN SEMICONDUCTOR INDUSTRIES KEY: TSMC CHIEF
DOC.DATELINE: Boao, Hainan, April 25 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and mainland China's semiconductor industries, if efficiently integrated in technology and production, will become global industry leaders in 10 years, Taiwan's semiconductor industry patriarch Morris Chang said Sunday.

Chang, chairman of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) , made the remarks while speaking at an entrepreneurs summit meeting Sunday morning. The summit is part of the 2004 annual conference of the Boao Forum for Asia (BFA), which is currently being convened at the scenic southern Chinese resort island of Hainan.

Speaking about business cooperation, corporate brand names and economic globalization, Chang said that 19 years ago, when he first arrived in Taiwan from the United States, he saw Taiwan's advantage in developing intelligence-driven high technology, such as semiconductor manufacture.

A large pool of hard-working and highly skilled workers -- many of them holding master's or doctoral degrees in sciences or technologies, was Taiwan's advantage in developing high-technology-based industries nearly two decades ago, and today, a similar competitive edge is being found in mainland China, Chang noted.
Over the past decade, he said, Taiwan's semiconductor industry has been developing dynamically in terms of silicon wafer processing, the building of systems frameworks, testing and marketing.

Chang pointed out, however, that the industry soon faced its market boundaries as the domestic market in Taiwan is too small. Comparatively, he added, the domestic market in mainland China is much bigger, helping push back market boundaries for the development of the semiconductor industry.

If Taiwan's semiconductor industry is tied with its mainland Chinese counterpart, the industry's competitiveness will double, making it an invincible competitor in the world's semiconductor market, Chang said.

Chang, who himself has invested a semiconductor processing plant in mainland China, said the mainland Chinese semiconductor industry is now a rival as well as a partner to TSMC, which he said is not at all lacking competitors from the United States and South Korea.
TSMC has posted an average of 30 percent growth in annual business turnover over the past 10 years and similar growth is likely to average about 20 percent in the following years, Chang forecast.

Some 1,000 political, business and industrial leaders from around the world are attending the 2004 annual conference of the Boao Forum for Asia. Prominent figures include mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao, former Philippines President Fidel V. Ramos, Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee Hwa, Macau Chief Executive Edmund Ho Hau-wah, Czech Republic President Vaclav Klaus, former U.S. President George Bush and former Australia Prime Minister Robert Hawke.
Delegates from Taiwan to the conference include former Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew and Kao Chin-yen, founder and CEO of the Uni-President Group.

Founded in 2001, the BFA is a non-governmental, non-profit, regular and open international forum with a fixed venue. Promoting high-level dialogue on regional issues such as economic development, population and the environment, the BFA is aimed at helping deepen mutual understanding and cooperation among Asian countries, and strengthen ties between Asia and the rest of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HOPES REVISED LAW WILL ENABLE REFERENDUM TO TRIM LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will seek to revise the Referendum Law first and then hold a referendum to reduce the size of the legislature at the end of this year, a Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator said Sunday.

Tsai Huang-liang, DPP whip in the legislature, said that it appears that the opposition Kuomintang is not opposed to revising the law, so the chances are good that the legislation can be passed before the end of the current legislative session, which ends on the last day of May.
The Ministry of the Interior recently asked that the Referendum law, which was passed in late November, be amended to include the right of the people to initiate constitutional amendment proposals.
Currently, only the legislature can propose constitutional amendments. They are then turned over to the National Assembly, which would subsequently meet to vote on the issue.
The DPP hopes to hold a referendum along with the December legislative elections on halving the 225-seat Legislature using a revised referendum law, Tsai added.

Meanwhile, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), an ally of the DPP, said that as long as the Referendum Law is revised and stipulates clearly that the people have the right to initiate constitutional amendment proposals, the party will immediately submit several amendment proposals.

Lee Hsien-jen, a TSU official, said that the revisions mulled by the Ministry of the Interior are largely the same as those of his party. Both advocate that the public should have the right to initiate constitutional amendment proposals and that there is no need for a referendum review committee, but they disagree on the percentage of people that must endorse a proposal and establish a referendum.
He said that if the thresholds are lowered, the right to call for a referendum could be abused; therefore, more discussion on the issue is needed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN BEING MONITORED FOR SARS AFTER RETURNING FROM BEIJING WITH FEVER

TEXT.P: A Taiwan man returning from Beijing with a fever has been quarantined and is under observation, although lab tests indicate that he is not infected with severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and his fever has subsided, Su Ih-jen, director-general of the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health (DOH), said Sunday.

The man, surnamed Hung, was found to have a temperature of over 38 degrees Celsius upon arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Saturday and is currently under medical observation at a Taoyuan hospital.

Su said although the temperature of the researcher of a private biotechnology company has dropped to a normal level, the hospital will continue to monitor him until 11 p.m. Sunday to make sure that he has not contracted SARS.

If Hung, who was in Beijing between April 19-24 and had visited a lab where one of the latest SARS cases was reported, does not have a fever or any other symptoms in the 24 hours after his return to Taiwan, he will be allowed to leave the hospital and go home, Su said.
Lab results were negative for SARS, showing that Hung was probably not infected, Su said.

The DOH and the CDC jointly sponsored an emergency news conference at 11: 20 p.m. Saturday to notify the public and the world medical community on how Taiwan's health care personnel will deal with the situation.
This is the first case of an individual being monitored for possible SARS infection since the outbreaks of the potentially-fatal flu-like disease in mainland China subsided last summer.

The Department of Health (DOH) upgraded Taiwan's epidemic prevention mobilization level against SARS from Level Zero to Level A from Saturday after Beijing confirmed two SARS cases a day earlier in mainland China, in addition to two already reported suspected cases and one possible fatality.

Under the activated Level A SARS alert mechanism, all inbound and outbound passengers are required to have their temperatures taken and to fill out SARS questionnaires. All passengers arriving from mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau have to exercise self-health management, including regular hand-washing and temperature-taking, while all government agencies and institutions are advised to conduct temperature-taking.
The CDC sponsored a follow-up news conference Sunday morning to further keep Taiwan society and the world medical community abreast of the condition of Taiwan's latest suspected SARS case.

Chou Chih-hao, deputy director-general of the CDC, said the center has contacted Hung's six corporate colleagues who were traveling with him to Beijing for meetings with their counterparts in mainland China on biotechnology business and told them to begin self-health management against possible SARS infection.

The CDC has also informed the Taipei office of the Hong Kong-based Cathay Pacific Airways to have passengers who were seated six rows nearest to Hung's seat on flight CX 402 from Hong Kong to Taipei to start self-health management as well, Chou added.
The DOH has a four-level SARS alert system -- Zero, A, B, and C -- with level C being the highest level of alert.

Also under Level A, all junior high and elementary schools, kindergartens and nursery schools around the nation should take their students' temperatures every day. Moreover, hospitals and SARS monitoring stations around Taiwan are required to report their SARS-related health situations every week to the DOH.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MARCH JOBLESS RATE HITS 34-MONTH LOW OF 4.45 PERCENT: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate fell to 4.45 percent in March, the lowest monthly level since June 2001, according to the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

There were about 452,000 unemployed people across Taiwan in March, down 0.16 percent, or 16,000 people, and down 0.63 percent from the previous month's level and from the year-earlier level, respectively, a census carried out and made public over the weekend by the DGBAS showed.
Taiwan's Q1 unemployment averaged 4.53 percent, down 0.56 percent from the level posted for the same three-month period last year, the report showed.
At the same time, around 971,500 workers were hired across the country last month, an increase of 29,000 people over the February level and a large jump of 201,000 people year-on-year.

DGBAS officials attributed the improved March unemployment rate -- the lowest level in nearly 34 months -- to a steadily recovering economy across the globe, which has spurred strong demand for both inbound and outbound shipments.

The officials claimed that employment in the domestic market will continue to improve in the months ahead, despite the fact that a large number of college and university students in summer will seek to enter the workplace and push up the country's unemployment rate.

Taiwan's jobless rate for the whole of this year will be lower than 5 percent at around 4.7 percent to 4.8 percent, they estimated, adding that the figure is expected to further drop by 0.1 percent should a government initiated "public service employment program" be extended when its year-long implementation period expires on June 18.

Compared with neighboring countries in Asia, Taiwan's joblessness is about the same level of Singapore's 4.5 percent and better than Hong Kong's 7.2 percent. South Korea has an unemployment rate of about 3.4 percent, while Japan posts a 5 percent jobless rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 25, or the 7th day of the third month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1744: Anders Celsius, Swedish astronomer who devised the Celsius thermometer in 1742, dies at the age of 43.
1859: Under the direction of Ferdinand de Lesseps, the construction of the Suez Canal begins. It was opened 10 years later on Nov. 16, 1869.
1874: Gulielmo Marconi, Italian engineer and inventor who shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in physics, is born. He became the first person to transmit long-wave radio signals across the Atlantic Ocean, doing so in 1901.
1895: Lai Ho, a noted Chinese writer of anti-Japanese literature, is born in Changhua.
1898: The U.S. Congress passes a joint resolution declaring war on Spain over events in Cuba.
1912: The Chung Kuo Ke Ming Tung Meng Hui is reorganized as the Kuomintang.
1925: Field Marshal Paul von Hindenburg becomes the second president of Germany's postwar Weimar Republic.
1927: After the national government in Nanking announces a purification movement that will entail the expulsion of Chinese communists, the communists meet in Wuhan and decide to set up a Soviet-style regime.
1930: Construction of the Chianan irrigation canal is completed.
1941: The United States and the United Kingdom sign in Washington separate but parallel agreements with China for stabilizing China's national currency. The United States provides US$50 million and the United Kingdom provides five million pounds.
1942: An accident at a coal mine in Benxi, located within Japanese-occupied China, kills 1,549 workers in the world's worst mining disaster.
1945: Delegates of 45 nations, including the Republic of China, meet in San Francisco, Calif., to organize the United Nations.
1946: The foreign ministers of the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France meet in Paris to discuss the signing of a peace treaty with Germany.
1956: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with Haiti.
1962: The United States successfully launches its Saturn rocket, the largest in the world at the time.
1965: President Lyndon B. Johnson sends U.S. troops to the Dominican Republic to maintain order after rebel followers of Juan Bosch try to seize power.
1971: T.V. Soong, former president of the Executive Yuan, dies in San Francisco at the age of 77.
1971: Some 200,000 anti-Vietnam War protesters march on Washington, D.C.
1973: The Chinese National Baseball Team leaves Taipei for Manila to take part in the 10th Asian Cup Tournament.
1974: Portugal's dictator Marcelo Caetano is overthrown in a bloodless military coup. He surrenders to Gen. Antonio de Spinola, who becomes president the following month.
1982: The last Israeli soldier leaves Sinai, ending 15 years of Israeli occupation of the peninsula.
1989: Japanese Prime Minister Noburu Takeshita announces plans to resign over the "Recruit Affair," the country's biggest political scandal in decades.
1994: Tsutomu Hata becomes Japan's 51st prime minister.
1995 Ginger Rogers, American dancer and actress, dies at the age of 83. She is particularly noted for her partnership with Fred Astaire in several motion pictures, including "Swing Time," "Flying Down to Rio" and "Roberta."
2000: President Lee Teng-hui bestows a medal on Steve Forbes, president and CEO of U.S.-based Forbes Magazine, in recognition of his long-term contribution to the promotion of exchanges and coorperation between the Republic of China and the United States.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says that the ROC government will take steps to develop the island into a "competitive country with a knowledge-based economy" within five years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The ancient Emperor Shun was perhaps the one man who successfully carried out the principle of no-government. For what need is there really for what is called government? A ruler needs only to be earnest in his personal conduct, and to behave in a manner worthy of his position."

DOC.HEADLINE: SARS SUPPLIES SUFFICIENT: DOH

TEXT.P: There are sufficient supplies of medical materials nationwide in Taiwan's efforts to prevent or battle an outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), an official of the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health (DOH) said Monday.

Current stocks of N95 surgical masks, protective gear and other SARS-prevention supplies nationwide are sufficient for use by medical institutions around the country and for the general public for a period of 30-45 days, said Shih Wen-yi, a CDC deputy director-general.

More precisely, Shih said, the country now has a stock of 4.12 million N95 masks -- sufficient for use for 30 days islandwide in the event of activation of "Level C" in the DOH's SARS mobilization mechanism. "Level C" represents the highest level of alert.

In addition, Shih said, Taiwan now has a stock of 3.11 million protective outfits and gear, 13.46 million ordinary surgical masks, and 11.44 million general flat masks. These supplies are sufficient for use for a period of 30-45 days in the event of "Level C" being activiated.
The preparedness of SARS quarantine wards, including hospital negative-pressure ward beds, is also under constant monitoring, Shih added.

The CDC began to take full inventory of the country's SARS-fighting medical supplies again over the weekend after fresh cases of SARS were reported in mainland China, with which Taiwan citizens have maintained close and frequent exchanges.
Taiwan was hit hard by SARS between March and June last year, resulting in 37 deaths and heavy economic losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: THIRD SARS TEST CONDUCTED ON MAN RETURNING FROM BEIJING

TEXT.P: Health authorities decided Monday to take yet another throat secretion sample from a man who visited Beijing last week and developed a fever upon returning to Taiwan to confirm that he has not been infected with the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) virus.

This is the third time that a throat secretion sample from the researcher who works at a private Taiwan biotechnology company is tested for SARS since his return Saturday evening. The first two tests were negative.

The researcher, surnamed Hung, has been quarantined and put under observation at a Taoyuan hospital since he was discovered to have a temperature higher than 38 degrees Celsius Saturday evening upon returning from his week-long visit to Beijing.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director-general of the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health (DOH), said Monday that the researcher will be allowed to leave the hospital and go home if his temperature remains normal, he shows no other SARS-related symptoms, and he tests negative for the SARS virus. The results of the third test are expected to come out after 4 p.m., according to Shih.

The reason Hung is being tested three times is that previous cases have shown that SARS symptoms sometimes resurface after a person's temperature returns to normal and the person is declared SARS free, said CDC Director-General Su Ih-jen during a press conference held Sunday.

While in Beijing between April 19-24, Hung visited a lab where one of the latest SARS cases in mainland China had been reported. His case has drawn much attention from Taiwan's health authorities as it has occurred at a time when the potentially fatal flu-like disease has been showing signs of resurgence on the Chinese mainland, particularly in Beijing, since last week.

The DOH and the CDC jointly sponsored an emergency news conference at 11: 20 p.m. Saturday to notify the public and the world medical community on how Taiwan's health care personnel will deal with the situation.
This is the first case in Taiwan of an individual being monitored for possible SARS infection since the outbreaks of the atypical pneumonia in mainland China subsided last summer.

The DOH upgraded Taiwan's epidemic prevention mobilization level against SARS from "Level Zero" to "Level A" from Saturday after Beijing confirmed two SARS cases a day earlier in mainland China, in addition to two already reported suspected cases and one possible fatality from the disease.

Under the activated "Level A" SARS alert mechanism, all inbound and outbound passengers are required to have their temperatures taken and to fill out SARS questionnaires. All passengers arriving from mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau have to exercise self-health management, including regular hand-washing and temperature-taking, while all government agencies and institutions are advised to conduct temperature-taking.
The CDC sponsored a follow-up news conference on Sunday to further keep the Taiwan public and the world medical community abreast of the situation regarding Taiwan's latest suspected SARS case.

Chou Chih-hao, deputy director-general of the CDC, said the center has contacted Hung's six corporate colleagues who had been traveling with Hung to Beijing for meetings with their counterparts in mainland China on biotechnology business, and has told them to begin self-health management against possible SARS infection.

The CDC has also informed the Taipei office of Hong Kong-based Cathay Pacific Airways to have passengers who were seated within six rows of Hung's seat on flight CX-402 from Hong Kong to Taipei to start self-health management as well, Chou added.
The DOH has a four-level SARS alert system -- Zero, A, B, and C -- with level C being the highest level of alert.
Taiwan was hit hard by SARS between March and June last year, resulting in 37 deaths and heavy economic losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAKKA AFFAIRS COUNCIL CHIEF-DELEGATE CONFIRMS HIS NEW POST

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker Lo Wen-chia confirmed Monday that he has accepted Premier Yu Shyi-kun's offer to head the Council for Hakka Affairs.
Noting that he has been in politics for 10 years, Lo said he would like to do more for the country by serving in a Cabinet position.
Lo will replace Yeh Chu-lan, who is reported as having been promoted to the post of vice premier.

Meanwhile, Changhua County Magistrate Wong Chin-chu said she had turned down earlier in the day an offer by Yu to serve as minister of education, adding she has a commitment to her supporters in her constituency and would rather serve out her current term.
Lawmaker Yeh Yi-jin also said she had rejected a chance to work in the Cabinet during a meeting with Yu.

The lawmaker said she would prefer to run in Tainan County for another term as lawmaker and has her sights set on the magistrateship of Tainan County after the incumbent magistrate Su Huan-dji has served out his term.
Lin Chia-lung, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan, said Yu will keep consulting three or four DPP public officials per day in search of capable people for his new Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-PANAMA TRADE INCREASES SHARPLY

TEXT.P: Trade between Taiwan and Panama increased sharply to US$75.78 million in the first quarter of this year, up 273 percent year-on-year, according to statistics released Monday by the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT).

During the January-March period, the statistics show, Taiwan exported US$69.28 million-worth of goods to Panama and imported goods worth US$6.5 million from the Central American nation, an increase of 258 percent and 574 percent, respectively, over the previous year's levels.
BOFT officials attributed the rapid growth to the enactment of the Taiwan-Panama free trade agreement that was put into effect at the beginning of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP SUES INCUMBENT, FORMER PRESIDENT FOR SLANDER

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) sued President Chen Shui-bian and former President Lee Teng-hui Monday for slander, claiming compensation of NT$60 million (US$1.51 million).

PFP official Chang Hsien-yao said Chen and Lee defamed the PFP by branding protests called by the PFP and Kuomintang (KMT) against what they call an "unfair" presidential election between March 20 and March 27 as "unsuccessful coup d'etat."
Chang said his party asked the two to apologize before 3 p.m. Monday but the request was brushed aside by both men.

A lawyer for the party noted at a press conference called to announce the action that the incumbent president is exempt from criminal lawsuits but will have to answer the charge after his term falls due in 2008 and will "not be free from his civic responsibility now" if he is found guilty of slander.
Lee was named in the suit as a defendant for making similar accusation separately.
The lawyer challenged Chen and Lee to come up with evidence to verify their accusations or plead guilty to slander.

Huang Chih-fang, director of the Department for Public Affairs under the Presidential Office, was also named as a defendant in the lawsuit because he defended Chen's accusation by arguing that the president was only describing the situation during the protests.
The KMT did not participate in the lawsuit but its officials and lawmakers launched a broadside at the president.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan was quoted by KMT spokeswoman Kuo Shui-chun as dismissing the coup d'etat claim as "absolute nonsense."

By describing the legal protests as a military coup d'etat, Kuo said, "the president is insulting the country's armed forces and negating the country's democracy, which guarantees to the people the right to express their opinions through demonstrations."

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who is also a vice chairman of the KMT, said the accusation of military coup d'etat is a serious one and that the president is undermining his credibility by trying to debase the opposition with inflated accusations.
Ma Ying-jeou, the mayor of Taipei and also a KMT vice chairman, said the president should support his accusation with evidence or acknowledge that it was a slip of tongue and withdraw it.
Lawmaker Liao Feng-teh, the KMT caucus legislative whip, said Chen and Lee were exaggerating to scare the people.

KMT Legislator Huang Teh-fu said the president is trying to debase the opposition and should be called to account for this. However, he said his party has no plans to join the PFP in the suit against Chen.

Chen's Democratic Progressive Party took the lawsuit in its stride. Cheng Wen-tsan, a DPP official, said his party welcomes the PFP's legal action as it will give the court a chance to uncover the truth.

Claiming that PFP Chairman James Soong said during the protest that he would lead his supporters to storm the Presidential Office, and the Lien has accused Chen of "stealing the government, " Cheng said that whether these extreme remarks give any clues as to their attempts to stage a coup d'etat should be determined by the judicial system.

Huang Chu-wen, chairman of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, which is made up of followers of Lee, said Lien and Soong should subject themselves to judicial investigation to see if they were attempting a coup d'etat.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHORT-TERM JOBS TO CONTINUE TO HELP RELIEVE UNEMPLOYMENT SITUATION

TEXT.P: An employment expansion program that has helped relieve the jobless situation will continue, Cabinet officials said Monday.

The officials said that between June and December 2003, the government provided short-term jobs to 72,000 people under the program and they estimated that the program helped drive down the average jobless rate by 0.23 percent in 2003.
In view of the good results of the program, the Executive Yuan believes there is a need to continue the program, although the goal this time will be to employ 40,000 people.
The officials estimated that providing 40,000 people with six-month work opportunities will cost the government NT$7 billion (US$212.12 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SUPPORT FOR NEW TAIWAN CONSTITUTION HAS LIMITATIONS: AIT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: There are limitations to the United States' support for Taiwan's plan to change the Constitution, an official of the American Institution in Taiwan (AIT) said Tuesday.

David J. Keegan, deputy director of the Taipei Office of the AIT -- the de facto American embassy in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic relations -- made the remarks at a tea party held at the Ministry of the Foreign Affairs to mark the 25th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA).

Keegan said that the United States, a strong ally of Taiwan, is not certain about the means to change the Constitution and that if Taiwan misunderstands the limited support level from Washington, or the scope of the change goes beyond Washington's expectations, then the United States will not support it, he said.
Keegan was referring to President Chen Shui-bian's pledge that he will push for the writing of a new constitution in 2006 through referendum and implement it in 2008.
Chen has stressed repeatedly that the move has nothing to do with seeking independence as Beijing claims, but is aimed at deepening democracy and making the government more efficient.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEED FOR PANIC ABOUT SARS: DOH

TEXT.P: About 10 passengers per day arriving in Taiwan from mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau over the past few days have been found to have been running fevers, but there is no need for the public to panic, an official from the Department of Health (DOH) said Monday.

Su Ih-jen, director of the DOH Center for Disease Control, made the remarks after Taiwan activated a heightened alert system against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in the wake of reports of atypical pneumonia cases on the mainland, with one suspected fatality.

Taiwan upgraded its SARS alert lever from Zero to A last Saturday. Among the precautionary measures included in the level A alert are temperature-taking for all inbound and outbound passengers and the distribution of health forms to passengers arriving from the mainland, Hong Kong and Macau.

"Each day, around 10 passengers arriving from mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau have fever, and one or two of them, after examination by doctors at the airport, will be sent to a nearby Taoyuan hospital for further checkups," Su said.

He noted that according to standard procedure at the airport, doctors advise those with fever to don a surgical mask and go home to rest, or else they send them to the hospital for further examination.

Moreover, Su pointed out, not only SARS patients have fever, with those who suffer from influenza, dengue fever or malaria also displaying similar symptoms. He added that during outbreaks of influenza, 30 to 50 people with fever can be expected to pass through the airport a day.

The health official also said that a researcher surnamed Hung who returned from mainland China and was sent to a hospital for further observation was a special case because he had visited a lab in Beijing that had been sealed because of a SARS scare. Hung was released from hospital Monday afternoon.
Meanwhile, a 36-year-old man surnamed Peng was sent to a Taoyuan hospital for observation after he returned from the mainland via Zhuhai, in Guangdong Province.
The man was tested three times and was found to have a temperature of more than 38 degrees Celsius each time. However, he was later determined to be suffering from tonsillitis rather than SARS.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA HAILS TRA CONTRIBUTION TO CROSS-STRAIT STABILITY

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco Hwang hailed Monday the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) as the major stabilizer to security across the Taiwan Strait over the past 25 years.

Hwang made the remarks at a tea party held at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) headquarters in Taipei to observe the 25th anniversary of the TRA. David J. Keegan, deputy director of the Taipei Office under the Washington-based American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), jointly chaired the gathering with Hwang.

The TRA has served as the framework for the United States in its dealings with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries after Washington switched recognition from Taipei to Beijing in early 1979. The TRA was signed into law April 10 that same year by former U.S. President Jimmy Carter.

Praising the TRA as having made a great contribution to maintaining cross-strait peace and security, Hwang also expressed his admiration for the vision, insight and wisdom of its drafters in today's fast-changing world.

Despite the many changes in the global situation that have taken place over the past 25 years, the TRA still provides an adequate and flexible legal basis for two-way contact and exchanges, Hwang said.

For his part, Keegan reiterated the United States' "one China" policy and claimed that the TAR, together with the three joint communiques inked by Beijing and Washington, have built the core principles for Washington in its dealings with the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Over the past 25 years, the TRA has helped create a stable and secure environment in the West Pacific, contributing tremendously to security and stability in the region, Keegan said and voiced his hope that it will also be able to offer access for settlement to the disputes between Taiwan and mainland China.

He also pledged that the United States will continue to govern its arms sales to Taiwan and help the island safeguard itself in conjunction with the TRA, while seeking to push for the rekindling of Taipei-Beijing dialogue.
AIT is responsible for Washington's dealings with Taipei in the absence of formal diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCOSE OPENS FIRST ASIAN BRANCH IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The International Council on Systems Engineering (INCOSE) set up Monday its first Asian branch in Taiwan at the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) in northern Hsinchu County.

Elmer Hsu, general director of the ITRI's Center for Aerospace and System Technology (CAST) , presided over the opening ceremony, with INCOSE representative Dr. Joseph Kasser and Boeing Corp. executive Eugene L. Beckles witnessing the event.
According to Hsu, systems engineering serves as a critical indicator in gauging a country's scientific progress.

Although some domestic industries have earned listings in the world's top ranks, Hsu said that the country's large-scale systems engineering projects, such as the north-south high speed rail network, the mass rapid transit systems in Taipei and Kaohsiung, nuclear power plants and aerospace projects, all fall short of world-class levels.

In a bid to lay a sound foundation for scientific exploration through technology transfer and international cooperation, the Ministry of Economic Affairs thus persuaded INCOSE to set up a branch at the government-funded ITRI as a platform for training talent in this field for Taiwan, which is a key segment of the government's ambitious plan to build the country into a "green silicon island, " Hsu explained.

Hsu said he is optimistic about closer exchanges between Taiwan companies and their foreign counterparts in the field of systems engineering, which will help upgrade the domestic sector's international competitive edge and help slash operational costs and promote added value for many knowledge-based businesses.
INCOSE is the sole global authoritative organization promoting the application of an interdisciplinary approach and the means to enable the realization of successful systems.

INCOSE members include many heavyweight government bodies and companies from countries across the globe, including the United States' NASA and Boeing Corp., as well as Japan's Mitsubishi Engineering Corp. and France's European Aeronautic Defense and Space Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR LAWMAKERS SUMMONED IN CONNECTION WITH MARCH 26 RIOTS

TEXT.P: The Taipei Prosecutor's Office summoned four legislators from the opposition People First Party (PFP) Monday in connection with the rioting that took place in front of and inside the Central Election Commission (CEC) March 26.

All four legislators -- Chiu Yi, Lee Ching-hua, Lin Huei-kuang and Feng Ting-kuo -- denied that they incited the rioting and subsequent clashes between police and protesters that led to several injuries.

The four were present among the protesters who gathered outside the CEC building as the commission was about to formally announce the results of the March 20 presidential election in which President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu won re-election against their rival "pan-blue alliance" ticket of Lien Chan of the Kuomintang and James Soong of the PFP.

Based on evidence collected on that day, along with video clips provided by several TV stations, police believe that the legislators violated articles 135 and 136 of the Criminal Code concerning interference in the implementation of official duty (stopping the CEC from posting the election results) and the mobilizing of a mass rally to interfere with official duty.
Chiu said he had "no regrets" about a series of actions, including sits-in and rallies, between March 20 and 26, but claimed he never led or incited people to break into the CEC.
"My appeal was that the election result was too close and would require a vote recount, as well as the suspension of the promulgation of the election results," he said.
By law, the CEC had to announce the official election results one week after the election, or March 26.
Feng claimed that he asked the public not to destroy anything when he saw people smashing the doors and windows of the CEC.
"The law authorities, instead of looking into the shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, are looking into us," he said, adding that "this is stark political persecution."
Lin also claimed that he did not incite the crowd and challenged the police to produce evidence or stop fitting him up.

Lee claimed that he only went to the CEC to request that it not publish the election results, as the ballot boxes had been sealed for a recount and the "pan-blue alliance" had filed lawsuits to nullify the election and the election results, citing voting irregularities and the election-eve shooting that it believes swayed the results in Chen's favor in the bitterly contested election.
Chen won by a narrow margin of 29,518 votes against Lien Chan out of more than 13 million votes cast.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNCIL OF CULTURAL AFFAIRS UNVEILS WEBSITE ON CONFUCIAN TEMPLES

TEXT.P: The Council of Cultural Affairs (CCA) introduced its Web site on Confucian temples Monday as part of its efforts to introduce traditional culture using new technology.

CCA Chairwoman Tchen Yu-chiou said at a press conference that the Taiwan Confucian Temple Web site was completed in March this year, compiling tens of thousands of pieces of digital information, including video and audio information. It will also include 3D displays, animations and a database.
Tchen said that in order to improve understanding of history and national historical sites, the council has appropriated NT$5 million (US$151,515) for the site.

The council is hoping that through the creative use of the collected information on Confucius -- China's most esteemed and revered sage for his teachings -- and the historic documents of Confucian temples in Taiwan, the Web site will display the life of Confucius and the history of Taiwan's Confucian temples.
Taiwan's first Confucian temple was built in Tainan in 1665.

Tchen said that the site will not only introduce 16 Confucian temples in Taiwan but will also feature Confucian temples in mainland China and in East Asian and Southeast Asian countries such as Japan, South Korea and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINES

TEXT.P: New York Times: Truce Extended in Falluja Siege, and Talks Go On.

Negotiators extended a shaky cease-fire in the volatile city of Falluja on Sunday for at least two more days, defusing the threat of an imminent Marine assault. But the American occupation authority said Shiite rebels in the holy city of Najaf were stockpiling weapons in mosques, shrines and schools, creating a "potentially explosive situation."

A spokesman for the occupation authority said it had learned from Najaf residents that insurgents following Moktada al-Sadr, the fervently anti-American cleric, were gathering arms, apparently to defend themselves against 2,500 American soldiers who have encircled the city. The spokesman said the occupation authority was urging people in Najaf to retake control from Mr. Sadr and his militia, the Mahdi Army.
Wall Street Journal: Sanofi to Swallow Aventis in a Deal Set at $65 Billion.
France's largest drug maker, Aventis SA, Sunday agreed to be swallowed by its smaller rival, Sanofi- Synthelabo SA, for about 55.2 billion, or $65 billion in cash and stock.
The French government succeeded in producing what it had long desired: a French national champion in a strategically important industry, the fast-growing and highly competitive drug business.

With Aventis succumbing to Sanofi's sweetened offer, the combination of the two will form the world's third-largest pharmaceuticals company, behind Pfizer Inc. and GlaxoSmithKline PLC, with a market capitalization of around 90 billion and a stable of leading drugs such as Sanofi's stroke-prevention treatment Plavix, sleeping pill Ambien and cancer therapy Eloxatin. The new company would also boast Aventis's allergy pill Allegra, anti-blood-clotting drug Lovenox and cancer medicine Taxotere.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO RESIGN EN MASSE SOMETIME BETWEEN MAY 5-12: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The upcoming Cabinet reshuffle may take place between May 5 and May 12 and the current Cabinet is expected to resign en masse during that period, Cabinet spokesman Lin Chia-lung said Monday.

The current Cabinet will resign en masse sometime between May 5-12 in line with the announcement of the new Cabinet and pending a resolution as to whether the 10 New Construction Projects put forward by the Executive Yuan will clear the Legislative Yuan by the end of May, Lin said.
The Executive Yuan will remain flexible on the exact date as to when to resign en masse, Lin said.

In response to the rhetoric by the opposition camp that they may put off the budget screening for the construction projects beyond the end of May, Lin appealed for collaboration from the opposition parties to complete the task as quickly as possible.
According to the Cabinet spokesman, Premier Yu Shyi-kun has started contacting and meeting several hopefuls for Cabinet-level posts in recent days as the May 20 presidential inauguration approaches.

The premier will pay equal importance to the issues related to gender, ethnicity, power transfer and talent recruitment and exchanges when trying to build a new line-up in the administration that he will continue to lead, Lin explained.

In addition to efforts to recruit more capable women leaders for key government posts, talent individuals of Hakka and other aboriginal groups as well as younger political elite will also be targeted, he pointed out, adding that the premier will do his best to create a new and efficient Cabinet, focusing on smooth administrative operations and interactions among all government agencies.

He said that functions and capabilities of the broadly defined financial and economic agencies, such as the Council for Economic Planning and Development, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of Finance, the Council of Agriculture and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications will be largely enhanced and upgraded.

At the same time, promotion in the fields of education, culture, technologies and human resources and the forging of public consensus will be focal points high of the agenda of President Chen Shui-bian during his second four-year term, he said, adding that the government will also pay a greater heed to bettering social welfare programs and improving law and order.

DOC.HEADLINE: SARS REPORTS CAUSE CONCERN FROM TAIWAN TOURISM INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: The reappearance of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in mainland China has poured cold water on Taiwan's tourism industry. Tour operators are holding their breath to see if the situation worsens and adversely affects their business, according to an industry source.

Since three suspected SARS cases were reported over the weekend in Beijing and Anhui province, domestic tourism agencies are praying that the situation there does not deteriorate and cause an adverse impact on Taiwan's outbound and inbound travel at a time when the domestic industry is trying hard to get on its feet after being dealt a heavy blow by the disease a year ago, the source said.
Taiwan-based tourism agencies specializing in mainland-bound travel are particularly concerned, as now is a peak time for their business, the source noted.

He added that nearly 30 percent of the mainland-bound Taiwan tourists have canceled their trips upon learning of the SARS reports, and it forecast that the ratio will increase above 50 percent should the situation both in the mainland and Taiwan change noticeably.
Nevertheless, he pointed out that the SARS impact on Taiwan's mainland-bound travel this time is unlikely to be so serious as it was last year, except for trips to Beijing.
If the mainland's SARS situation gets worse, domestic tourism agencies may first consider stoping organizing trips to Beijing, according to the source.

The spread of SARS would also affect inbound travel to Taiwan, he said, reminding the public of the fact that many tourism-related businesses have not yet regained their vigor in the wake of the SARS outbreaks last year as a result of a large drop in inbound travelers to Taiwan, in particular those from Japan.

At a time when many factors remain unclear in the international and the domestic market, such as the possibility of terrorist attacks, domestic travel will become increasingly popular among the people of Taiwan, the source said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market moved down Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for May fell 30 points to close at 6,720, with 21,922 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June lost 32 points to end at 6,728, with 57 contracts traded, while September futures dropped 49 points to end at 6,702, with 17 contracts finalized.
Next March futures gained 20 points to end at 6,755, with 10 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,750 for May, 6,760 for June, 6,751 for September, 6,759 for December and 6,735 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also moved down.
May TE futures fell 0.8 points to close at 279, with 4,837 contracts traded, while June TE futures lost 1.3 points to end at 279.1, with 19 contracts transacted.
September TE futures dropped 0.5 points to close at 281.5, with two contracts finalized, while next March TE futures lost 1 point to end at 280.5, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
May TF futures fell 6.2 points to close at 1,053.4, with 5,575 contracts changing hands, while June TF futures lost 5 points to end at 1,053, with 16 contracts traded.
September TF futures dropped 0.4 points to close at 1,053.6, with two contract transactions, while December TF futures lost 0.8 points to end at 1,065, with two contracts finalized.
Next March TF futures dropped 1 point to close at 1,077, with one contract concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended the day lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 37.4 points to close at 6,710.7.
The bourse opened at 6,752.9 and fluctuated between 6,775.67 and 6,704.58 during trading.

A total of 4.26 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$107.63 billion (US$3.21 billion), a decrease from the previous day's trading session that saw 4.99 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$127.61 billion.

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff stocks moving down the most at 3.9 percent, followed by textile issues at 1.9 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.7 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.7 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.6 percent, cement stocks at 0.5 percent, and electrical shares at 0.4 percent.
Construction stocks, however, rose 2.9 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 650 to 187, with 126 stocks remaining unchanged.

The Lianhe Zaobao: More tie-ups with China schools soon.
More Singaporean students and teachers could soon go on exchange programmes in China as Singapore looks to increase the number of schools with links there from 40 to 100 by the end of next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 26, or the eighth day of the third month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1452: Leonardo da Vinci, Italian painter, engineer, scientist and one of the most versatile artists of the Renaissance, is born. As a painter, he is best known for "The Last Supper" and "Mona Lisa."
1885: Britain occupies Port Hamilton, Korea.
1925: Paul von Hinderburg, German general and politician, is elected president of the Weimar Republic. He appointed Adolf Hitler as chancellor in 1933.
1946: Chinese communist troops take over Harbin and Tsitsihar as Soviet forces evacuate.
1954: The United Nations meets at Geneva and insists on free elections in Korea.
1960: The construction of the East-West Cross-Island Highway in Taiwan is completed.
1966: Mt. Kelud erupts in Java, Indonesia, killing some 1,000 people.
1971: A White House commission recommends that Communist China be brought into the United Nations, with the Republic of China on Taiwan retaining its membership.
1972: The eleven-member Chinese track and field team returns from Manila after winning 11 gold, 2 silver and 4 bronze medals in the three-day Philippine National Open Track and Field Championships.
1975: The Embassy of the Republic of China in Saigon suspends operations.
1975: Shortly before the fall of Saigon, former South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a temporary stay before going into exile in the United States.
1976: The Fourth Asian Writers Conference of International P.E.N. opens with some 90 leading writers in Asia, Europe and America attending.
1976: The government of the Republic of China and the government of the Republic of South Africa announce the elevation of their consulates general to embassy status.
1976: Brig. Gen. Dan A. Brooksher of the U.S. Air Force arrives to replace Brig. Gen. David O. Williams Jr. as chief of staff of the U.S. Taiwan Defense Command.
1983: Explosions occur in buildings occupied by the Central Daily News and the United Daily News in Taipei.
1984: U.S. President Ronald Reagan and his wife Nancy leave for a trip to mainland China.
1986: A nuclear reactor at the Chernobyl plant in the Ukraine explodes, spreading a radioactive cloud across Europe and causing grave pollution. It was the world's worst nuclear accident.
1989: Mainland students march to central Beijing to protest government statements condemning their campaign for democracy.
1994: A China Airlines A300-600 Airbus crashes at Nagoya airport in Japan, killing 264 aboard. There were only seven survivors.
1996: Communist China, Russia and three former Soviet republics sign a treaty aimed at reducing tensions along their common borders.
1997: Peng Zhen, a senior leader of Communist China, dies in Beijing at the age of 95.
1999: NATO planes destroy the Zezeljev railway bridge in Novi Sad during the Kosovo war.
2000: Rodolfo T. Reyes, the new defacto Philippine representative to the Republic of China in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
2000: ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian pays a visit to former Premier Hau Pei-tsun for talks on a wide range of issues.
2001: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs congratulates Junichiro Koizumi on his election as Japanese prime minister.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be conscientious and sincere in what you say; be earnest and serious in what you do: in that way, although you might be in barbarous countries, you will get along well with men."

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD FRIGATE CARRIES OUT RESCUE IN PHILIPPINE WATERS

TEXT.P: A Coast Guard Administration (CGA) patrol frigate on Monday rescued six crew members of a Taiwan fishing boat which ran aground on an isle in Philippine territorial waters three days ago, CGA sources said Tuesday.

The 600-ton patrol frigate "Hualien" received instructions from the CGA's southern Taiwan operations center Monday morning to go to the rescue of the Pingtung-based fishing boat "Hsingyifu" which ran aground Sunday on an isle near the Batan Islands -- the Philippines' northernmost island group.

After obtaining permission from the Philippine authorities, the "Hualien" entered Philippine waters and rushed to the Batan Islands, rescuing all six crew members of the "Hsingyifu," including Taiwanese skipper Chen Tai-long, a Taiwanese engineer, as well as one Indonesian and three mainland Chinese fishermen, at around 3 p.m. Monday.

After the boat ran aground, the skipper radioed the Tongkang Fishermen's Radio Station for help, which in turn informed the National Rescue and Relief Command Center about the emergency. The center notified the CGA southern Taiwan operations center to carry out rescue operations.

Chen said that while they were awaiting help in fear because they were in Philippine territorial waters, they were attacked by stone-throwing Philippine locals and robbed. Chen said he was even ordered at gun-point to leave his boat at one point.
Fortunately, the CGA patrol frigate came to their rescue and brought all of the crew members back to Kaohsiung Harbor. The crew arrived in Kaohsiung Tuesday morning.
