In its biggest ever deal, Singapore Power (SingPower) will buy the entire assets of energy company TXU Australia from its Texas-based parent TXU Corp for A$5.1 billion (US$3.7 billion) - in a deal that took just more than a month to stitch up.

DOC.HEADLINE: 8 NATIONS TO ATTEND WORLD UNIVERSITY BASEBALL CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: A total of eight countries have confirmed that they will attend the 2004 World University Baseball Championship to be held in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan from July 23 to Aug. 1, organizers of the event said Tuesday.

Officials of the organizing committee said that in addition to Taiwan, which will compete under the name of Chinese Taipei, the United States, Japan, South Korea, Indonesia, the Czech Republic, Brazil and Canada have confirmed their presence at the championship.
The organizers said the are continuing to correspond with Cuba and Italy to encourage them to also take part.
The championship, authorized by the International University Sports Federation, will be the second of its kind to be held in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MAKES PITCH FOR NEW CONSTITUTION TO SCANDINAVIAN FRIENDS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made a pitch for a new constitution to a group of Scandinavian parliamentarians Tuesday.

In a speech delivered via teleconference to the Nordic Conference on Taiwan held Tuesday in Copenhagen, Denmark, Chen said the new constitution, expected to be ready in 2006, should be worked out through the consensus of the various political parties, should embody the people's opinion, and should be approved by the people through a referendum.

The president called for the Scandinavian states -- Denmark, Norway, Finland, Iceland and Sweden, to press the European Union not to lift a ban on arms sales to mainland China before Beijing withdraws its missiles targeting Taiwan.
He also urged the five states to support Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization, because participation in the international community should be a basic human right.
Taiwan shares Scandinavia's belief in democracy, human rights and peace, and deserves its support, Chen said.

The Nordic Conference on Taiwan brought 30 parliamentarians from the five Scandinavian states, including Jens Hald Madsen, chairman of the International Committee in the Danish Parliament, Swedish parliamentarian Gunnar Axen, Norwegian parliamentarian Tround Helleland, Finnish parliamentarian Kalevi Lamminen, and Icelandic parliamentarian Magnus Stefansson.
Taiwan's representative to Denmark Chang Ping-nan, and Senior Advisor to the President Peng Ming-min were invited to attend the conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIOU I-JEN TO MEET WITH U.S. OFFICIALS: STATE DEPARTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 26 (CNA) (By W.C. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A U.S. State Department spokesman confirmed Monday that a high-level envoy sent by President Chen Shui-bian will meet with U.S. officials during his visit to Washington, D.C.

Spokesman Richard Boucher, who made the remarks while responding to media questions at a daily briefing, declined to comment on whom Presidential Office Secretary-General Chiou I-Jen will meet with and what issues will be discussed during the meetings.
Boucher said the United States would handle any request for meetings in accordance with its usual practices.
"One of our usual practices is not to comment on these visits, nor to try to talk about what we may discuss with the representatives of Taiwan when we meet with them," he added.
Asked whether Chiou will meet with Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage, the spokesman responded that he does not know, only saying that he knows that Chiou will meet with U.S. officials.
In response to questions regarding whether Chiou's visit is by Taiwan's request, Boucher said: "I believe so, but I'm not certain."

Chiou, who is the first senior Republic of China official to visit Washington since President Chen's re-election in the March 20 presidential poll, arrived in New York Sunday night. He is scheduled to fly to the U.S. capital Monday.
Boucher also declined to comment on questions raised regarding President Chen's recent remarks that the opposition parties tried to initiate a coup in the wake of the March 20 election.
"I am not going to get involved in political charges in Taiwan, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTERS GAINING POPULARITY IN TAIWAN: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Computers have become very popular in Taiwan, with 70 percent of households having one, according to the results of a survey published Tuesday by the government.

The survey, conducted by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission under the Executive Yuan from April 12-13, shows that 52 percent of the respondents know how to surf the Web, of whom 84 percent use computers at home.
Meanwhile, 41 percent of the respondents are aware that the government is promoting a policy of "computerized government" and 53 percent have sought information from government Web sites.
Of those who use government Web sites, 36 percent use them for buying train tickets, 28 percent for reporting tax returns, 25 percent for information services and 11 percent for paying traffic fines.
The survey of public opinion on a computerized government, with 1,099 valid samples, had an error margin of 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY DENIES COUP ALLEGATIONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) insisted Tuesday that the military remained politically neutral throughout the election period and that the so-called "coup" issue is non-existent in the military.

MND spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng made the remarks a day after the opposition People First Party (PFP) filed a slander suit against President Chen Shui-bian, who claimed over the weekend the the opposition camp planned a coup after his re-election victory in the March 20 election.

"Some say the opposition's protests from March 21 through 27 was an aborted coup d'etat, " Chen said while addressing an anniversary celebration ceremony at Chiayi Senior High School in southern Taiwan.
Speaking at a regular MND news conference, however, Huang said the military has consistently remained loyal to the government.

"It is a consistent position of the military to maintain neutral and not to involve itself in politics, " Huang said. "The military belongs to the country rather than to any particular political party or individual politician. This will remain unchanged no matter which party comes to power."
Huang also dismissed as "an unfounded, subjective judgment" a Jane's report that mainland China can take Taiwan within seven days.

"My observation is that the writer of the article did not have a full understanding of the cross-Taiwan Strait situation and the current state of our combat preparedness, " Huang said, adding that the military can safeguard national security.

Tens of thousands of supporters of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the PFP staged sometimes violent protests after Chen defeated the "pan-blue alliance" presidential candidate, KMT Chairman Lien Chan, by a slim margin.

The opposition argues that an election-eve shooting that left Chen and Vice President Annette Lu slightly injured unfairly swayed sympathy votes in Chen's favor. The opposition has filed two lawsuits demanding a recount and nullification of the entire election.
The Taiwan High Court has ruled that a full-scale recount should begin May 10 at the latest, in order to be finished before Chen's scheduled May 20 inauguration for a second four-year term.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO NAME 90-ODD CANDIDATES FOR LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) decided Tuesday to name 91-93 candidates for the year-end legislative elections, including 88 candidates selected through primaries, and three to five candidates drafted by the party authorities.

In a meeting of the DPP's Central Executive Committee, the party decided to put up 31 candidates as potential legislators-at-large, which are appointed by political parties in proportion to the number of votes the parties garner in the elections.
The committee also decided that DPP candidates who are elected as lawmakers will have to promise not to compete for chances to run on DPP tickets for chiefs of cities and counties in 2005.
The ruling party, which commands 87 seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan, has the largest legislative presence, although it is still 26 seats shy of a simple majority.

However, since President Chen Shui-bian won the March 20 presidential election with more than 50 percent of the vote, the party is looking forward to also boosting its presence in the Legislative Yuan.

Chen, who doubles as DPP chairman, told Tuesday's meeting that the number of candidates in the legislative elections should be increased to reflect the party's ambition of controlling the Legislative Yuan.
Meanwhile, as Kaohsiung City is set to select 17 councillors in a by-election, the DPP's Central Executive Committee decided to enter 10 candidates in that race.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDEPENDENT LAWMAKERS TO FORM POLITICAL MOVEMENT

TEXT.P: Ten independent lawmakers decided Tuesday to enter the year-end legislative elections as a political movement and vowed to win more than 15 seats.
Legislator Yen Ching-piao, convener of the 10-member Alliance of Independent Legislators, said the new movement will be titled the "Non-partisan Liberal Alliance."
The paperwork for launching the new movement will begin by the end of May and the party will formally founded Sept. 30, he said.

The movement will name no more than one candidate in each constituency in the legislative elections, in hopes of winning more than 5 percent of the votes, which is the threshold for political parties seeking government grants.

Legislator Tsai Hao, who is a member of the Alliance of Independent Legislators, said all 10 of the alliance members will stand for re-election in the legislative elections, which will put paid to speculation that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party is trying to win over the alliance's support in the legislature by offering its members Cabinet positions or seats in the Control Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA EARMARKS BUDGET FOR OVERSEAS SALE OF TAIWAN FARM PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: In a bid to improve the marketing of Taiwan produce around the world, the Council of Agriculture (COA) will allocate NT$2.2 billion (US$66.67 million) for a three-year global promotion campaign starting this year, COA Chairman Lee Ching-lung said Tuesday.

Lee made the remarks during a visit to central Yunlin County, where he inspected fruit and vegetable cooperative farms and a flower cultivation and study center. The COA head praised the fine quality of the many locally produced farm products on display.

Saying that the money will be used over the coming three years to step up the marketing and distribution of Taiwan vegetables and fruit in the world market, Lee added that the COA's first-phase efforts will be aimed at Japan.
The COA plans to promote up-scale Taiwan produce such as Oolong tea, orchids, mangoes and sea bream, in the Japanese market, one of Taiwan's leading export markets, Lee added.

In view of the adverse impact of Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization on the domestic industry, Lee said that exploring foreign markets will be a key outlet for Taiwan's farmers. He added that the COA is projecting to open distribution centers in Southeast Asian countries and in mainland China in the coming phases of the plan.

Another COA official said he is confident that Taiwan farm produce will become increasingly fashionable in Japan, as long as quarantine, marketing and distributing measures are adequately addressed in order to entice quality-conscious Japanese customers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD EASE U.S. CONCERN OVER NEW CONSTITUTION: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan should do its best to assuage U.S. concern over its plan to craft a new constitution in 2006, and try hard to address both national and U.S. interests while engaging in the issue, Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen said Tuesday.
Chen made the remarks to local media during a visit to the Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center in southern Tainan County.

In the face of deep U.S. concern over possible complications that Washington thinks may arise from a new Taiwan constitution in 2006 that President Chen Shui-bian has repeatedly pledged since his March 20 re-election, the foreign minister said that Taiwan must fully explain its stance as an independent sovereignty to the United States while seeking not to damage the interests of a long-term ally.
"Taiwan should do what it has to do and take into account its own interests, as well as those of its ally," Chen said.

David J. Keegan, deputy director of the Taipei office of the Washington-based American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , said a day earlier at a tea party held at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs that "there are limitations to the U.S. support" for Taiwan's plan to hammer out a new constitution in 2006.
AIT is responsible for U. S. dealings with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations after the two nations suspended ties in 1979.

Keegan's statement came after U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs James Kelly testified before Congress last week that "pushing for independence carries the potential for a response from mainland China... that could destroy much of what Taiwan has built and crush its hopes for the future." Kelly also urged President Chen to exercise" restrained leadership."

Commenting that Keegan's words do not represent any fresh thinking but are only a reiteration of Kelly's remarks, the foreign minister suggested, however, that the Taiwan authorities, including himself, do their utmost to clarify the misunderstanding between the two countries on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP CALLS FOR GOVERNMENT TO HEED GRASSROOTS WORKERS

TEXT.P: The government should pay adequate heed to issues related to safety at work and should include work safety measures in the new constitution that President Chen Shui-bian wants to write in 2006, officials of a group promoting safety at work appealed Tuesday.

In a petition presented to the Presidential Office, the Taiwan Association for Victims of Occupational Injuries asked President Chen to display his willingness to do so in his May 20 inaugural speech as a means of responding to the minimum demands from the country's grassroots workers, who have over the past century sacrificed their lives and health for national development and progress.

Saying that laborers' safety must be guaranteed in the constitution as a basic national policy to better take care of the country's workers, they claimed that the government still presents a cold shoulder to their interests and well-being, despite the fact that power has been held by different political parties.
During the past five decades, more than 80,000 grassroots workers have been killed in the workplace and nearly 400,000 have sustained crippling injuries or illnesses, they pointed out.

Although government power has been transferred from one party to another, they claimed that workers are just as unfairly treated as they have been in the past and that no changes or improvements have been made by the government.

Pointing to an example to underline their claim, they said that the ratio of workplace security checks remains extremely low -- below 5 percent -- despite the fact that the Labor Safety and Health Law was implemented more than 10 years ago.
This seriously inadequate handling by the government has made the prevention of occupational injuries for workers "impossible, " they claimed.

Stating that Taiwan's grassroots workers have contributed enormously to the country's economic development by sacrificing their own interests, they contended that the nation's leaders now should build a perception that "workers' safety should take precedence over economic progress."

As Chen has repeatedly pledged that he is poised to craft a new constitution by 2006, the officials made clear their feeling that a new constitution will only be effective if it meets public expectations and needs. "Political and empty slogans serve nothing in writing a new and good constitution," they added.

On the eve of April 28 -- International Day of Mourning for Workers -- the country's more than 8 million workers and their families only pray for the humble wish that they can get to work happily, return home safely and be taken care of by the government, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUM-CHEWING MRT COMMUTERS TO BE FINED

TEXT.P: Commuters on Taipei's mass rapid transit (MRT) lines will from now on be banned from chewing gum or betel nuts on the trains and in the MRT stations, according to a package of revisions to the existing MRT law passed by the Legislative Yuan Tuesday.
Under the revised law, gum- or betel nut-chewing MRT commuters can be fined between NT$1,500 and NT$7,500.
Previously, only those who spat gum or betel nut juice on MRT carriages or at MRT stations could be fined.

The newly revised MRT law also stipulates that those who post handbills or distribute publicity brochures on MRT carriages or in MRT stations without prior permission will also be fined between NT$1,500 and NT$7,500.

According to MRT Co. tallies, the company has issued 11,717 tickets since it began to fine rule-breaking commuters in 1999. The fine for each case ranged between NT$1,500 and NT$5,000, and the company has so far collected more than NT$20 million in fines.

More than 90 percent of the cases involved smoking, eating or drinking on MRT carriages, MRT officials said, adding that the number of violations has declined steadily since 2002 thanks to an intensified publicity campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINES

TEXT.P: New York Times: Fierce Battles in Najaf and Falluja Dim Hopes for Accord.

A protracted firefight between marines and insurgents in a Falluja suburb on Monday culminated in American helicopter gunships and tanks firing at a mosque and toppling its minaret, further dimming hopes for a peaceful resolution to the three-week-old siege.

With Iraq's prospects of resuming progress toward a peaceful transfer of sovereignty on June 30 hanging uneasily in the balance, developments in Falluja were echoed by new tensions at Najaf, 100 miles south of Baghdad, which has been the focal point of a separate confrontation.
Wall Street Journal: As Boeing Tries to Put Scandals To Rest, Prosecutors Widen Probe.

Boeing Co., which had begun putting the fallout from its ethical lapses behind it, faces a federal criminal investigation that has expanded into whether it used a rival company's documents to compete for NASA contracts, according to government and industry officials close to the probe.

Investigators are trying to determine whether a former employee of Lockheed Martin Corp. hired by Boeing in 2001 gave his new employer access to documents containing sensitive pricing data. Government officials are increasingly focusing on whether the Lockheed Martin documents affected Boeing's pricing decisions concerning rocket- launch contracts for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and other government customers, according to government and industry officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITAIN CONCERNED ABOUT HONG KONG BEING DENIED UNIVERSAL SUFFRAGE
DOC.DATELINE: London, April 26 (CNA) (By N. K. Han and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: British Foreign Office Minister Bill Rammell on Monday expressed concern that mainland China had denied Hong Kong people of their right of universal suffrage to choose their leader and legislators.

Rammell was responding to a decision by mainland China's National People's Congress (NPC) Monday which bars Hong Kong people from directly choosing their leader in 2007 and all their legislators in 2008.

The decision is inconsistent with the "high degree of autonomy," which Hong Kong is guaranteed under the Joint Declaration which cleared the way for Britain to hand over the former colony to mainland China in 1997, Rammell said.
Rammell said in a statement that he would meet mainland China's ambassador to Britain soon to express concern over the decision.

He also said that he was disappointed that "the NPC has set limits to constitutional development in Hong Kong that are not required by the Basic Law, especially before the Hong Kong government has completed its consultation and put forward proposals for development." The British government continues to hope that early progress can be made towards the Basic Law's ultimate aims of the election of the Chief Executive and all members of the Legislative Council by universal suffrage, at a pace in line with the wishes of the Hong Kong people, he added.
Rammell also said that Britain will continue to follow events closely. "We believe in the prosperity and stability of Hong Kong, which is of great benefit to both China and the UK," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: UK diplomats in mass attack on Blair policy.
Tony Blair faced an unprecedented attack on foreign policy in the Middle East and Iraq yesterday, when dozens of eminent former British envoys jointly wrote a damning letter to Downing Street.
Already under pressure from growing violence in Iraq, where more British troops may be deployed, the Prime Minister is accused of "abandoning" peace efforts between Israel and the Palestinians and of persuing a policy in Iraq "doomed to failure."
Financial Times: Railway win fight over safety.
The Health and Safety Executive looks certain to be stripped of responsibility for rail safety under the government's rail review, after industry submissions came out heavily in favour of handing the job to the Office of Rail Regulation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COUNTY MAGISTRATE RECEIVES HONORARY DOCTORAL DEGREE
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, April 27 (CNA) (By Y. C. Chiang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taipei County Magistrate Su Tseng-chang received an honorary doctoral degree in law from South Korea's Kyungnam University Tuesday.

Su became the third political figure in Taiwan to have received the honor from the school. The first two were Hsu Hsin-liang, a former chairman of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and President Chen Shui-bian.

Park Jae Kyu, president of the university, in bestowing the honor, noted that Su has made "a great contribution to the political development in Taiwan and in the enhancement of the bilateral friendship between Taiwan and South Korea."
After receiving the honorary degree, Su went to Masan Free Trade Zone to visit the company Nokia and learn about the management of the zone. Su will return to Taiwan Wednesday.
Su, who arrived in Seoul Sunday, traveled Monday to Kyungnam province where the university is located.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended the day lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 63.9 points to close at 6,646.8.
The bourse opened at 6,717.52 and fluctuated between 6,720.14 and 6,582.71 during trading.

A total of 4.3 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$107.7 billion (US$3.21 billion) , a slight increase from the previous day's trading session that saw 4.26 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$107.63 billion.

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 3.5 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 2.9 percent, textile issues at 2.2 percent, foodstuff stocks at 2.1 percent, electrical shares at 1 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.9 percent, and construction stocks at 0.6 percent.
Bank and insurance shares, however, rose 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 649 to 172, with 141 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: APPOINTMENTS OF PART OF NEW CABINET LINE-UP DECIDED

TEXT.P: Some new members of the upcoming reshuffled Cabinet have already been decided upon after Premier Yu Shyi-kun consulted several candidates, Executive Yuan spokesman Lin Chia-lung said Tuesday.
It is certain that Tu Cheng-sheng, director of the National Palace Museum, will be named as the education minister, succeeding the outgoing minister, Huang Rong-tsun, Lin said.

Chen Chi-nan, an academic and a researcher with Taiwan's top research institute, the Academia Sinica, will be appointed chairman of the Council for Cultural Affairs, replacing the outgoing chairwoman, Tchen Yu-chiou.

Chen Chuan-shou, president of National Taiwan College of Physical Education, will be appointed chairman of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, succeeding the outgoing chairman, Lin Teh-fu, according to Lin.
A number of other ministers of the current Cabinet headed by Premier Yu are expected to stay on in the upcoming reshuffle.
The current Cabinet is expected to resign en masse between May 5-12 in line with constitutional precedents prior to May 20 when President Chen Shui-bian will be sworn in for another four-year term.
Chen won the March 20 presidential election by a narrow margin of fewer than 30,000 votes out of more than 13 million ballots cast.
To allow the new Cabinet line-up enough time to get started, Lin said, Yu proposed to President Chen that the sitting Cabinet resign earlier than scheduled.
The new Cabinet will consequently be announced earlier too, Lin added.

DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Congressional Oversight of Intelligence Criticized; Committee Members, Others Cite Lack of Attention to Reports on Iraqi Arms, Al Qaeda Threat.
In the fall of 2002, as Congress debated waging war in Iraq, copies of a 92-page assessment of Iraq's alleged weapons of mass destruction sat in two vaults on Capitol Hill, each protected by armed security guards and available to any member who showed up in person, without staff. But only a few ever did, said the paper.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE GROUPS CALL FOR TWO-VOTE LEGISLATIVE ELECTION SYSTEM

TEXT.P: A private legislative reform promotional group said Tuesday that the current Public Functionaries Election and Recall Law should be revised to accommodate a two-ballot legislative election system.

The Legislative Reform Action Alliance said the proposed two-ballot system will allow voters to cast two ballots in legislative elections, with one ballot to elect individual legislators and the other to vote for a political party.

Under Taiwan's current legislative election system, voters can only cast one ballot to elect individual legislators and each constituency usually has several regional seats up for grabs. At-large seats are allotted among major political parties in proportion to the ratios of ballots they garner in regional seat elections.

Ku Chung-hua, the alliance's convener, said this mixed system is candidate-oriented and has many flaws, including a low threshold for an individual candidate to win a regional seat and at-large seat candidates not subject to voter scrutiny.

Although both ruling and opposition parties have come up with legislative reform bills, they are still pending deliberation. Moreover, some of the proposed changes, such as halving the number of legislative seats, require constitutional amendments which involve complicated procedures, including the election of a "functional National Assembly" to endorse the Legislative Yuan-approved amendments.
Against this backdrop, Ku said the alliance hopes the two-ballot election system can be implemented first. The election method change only needs amendments to the election and recall law.

Ku said the alliance has drafted preferred revisions to the election and recall law with four ultimate goals -- fair competition among political parties, strengthening party politics development, expanding underprivileged groups' political participation, and eradication of vote-buying, mud-slinging and other negative campaign tactics.

"We'll visit legislative caucuses of major political parties in the coming days to express our opinions and seek their support, " Ku said, adding that the alliance hopes the proposed two-ballot voting system can be adopted as early as possible to accelerate the much-anticipated legislative reforms.
The alliance groups several reform-oriented associations, including the Taipei Society and the "pan-purple alliance."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN MAYOR TO VISIT POLAND FOR SISTERHOOD RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair departed for Poland Tuesday for an eight-day visit.
One of the main purposes of Hsu's visit will be to establish sisterhood ties with the Polish city of Elblag, which will become the 22nd city with which Tainan maintains a sisterhood relationship.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has recommended that the two cities form the relationship because both cities have many historical sites and they are defined in their own countries as historic cities.
Hsu is expected to arrive in Elblag Wednesday and also visit Gdansk. He will sign the sisterhood agreement with Elblag mayor Henryk Slonina Thursday.

Elblag, with a population of roughly 130,000, is 60 kilometers from Gdansk and is only 50 kilometer from the Russian border. Hsu will be invited to attend a dinner party to celebrate Poland's joining the European Union before returning to Taiwan May 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNAXIS TO BUILD FACTORY, R&D CENTER IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 26 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: UNAXIS, a world-class high-technology corporation in Switzerland, has recently decided to invest NT$ 1 billion (US$ 30.3 million) in building a factory and a research center in Taiwan, a well-placed source said in Geneva Monday.

The source said that the factory and research center, on which construction is expected to begin in June of this year, will directly supply panel equipment and technology for Taiwan-made LCD monitors.

Pointing out that the investment is the largest ever in Taiwan by a Swiss manufacturer, the source noted that a senior staff member of the Swiss corporation responsible for business development has expressed his gratitude for Taiwan's assistance in helping the company carry out its investment plan smoothly.

It has been learned that the new factory and research center will be located in the newest site of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park. UNAXIS will brief the park's administration on its construction plan in the following weeks and will begin construction in June after signing a contract with the administration.

Revealing that UNAXIS will proceed with research and development plans as well as the manufacture of PVD and PECVD products on the island, a Taiwan official stationed in Switzerland said Monday that the company's investment is a big boost in Taiwan's goal of attracting foreign investment.

UNAXIS, which employs some 6,500 staff, has a global reach, with 80 subsidiaries encompassing research, development and production in a total of 25 countries in Europe, Asia and the United States. The corporation has a turnover of more than US$7.6 billion a year.
Switzerland is the fourth largest European source of investment in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD BREAKS LARGEST HUMAN TRAFFICKING RING IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Coast guard officials announced Tuesday that they have cracked the largest ring smuggling mainland Chinese women into Taiwan and have arrested the ring leader and his accomplices.

Hualien coast guard officers, in collaboration with police, conducted six simultaneous raids in Taipei City and Taipei County Monday night, arresting four ring members, two fishing boat skippers and 25 mainland Chinese women.

The six men, including ring leader Tsai Ching-chi, have been turned over to the Hualien Prosecutors' Office for interrogation, while the mainland Chinese women have been sent to detention centers in Ilan County, eastern Taiwan, and Hsinchu County, northern Taiwan.

According to the coast guard officers, Tsai and his smuggling ring, nicknamed the "Liangke Snakehead Ring" by police, had sent scouts to mainland China every month to work with human smuggling rings there to lure young women into prostitution in Taiwan with the false promise of normal jobs.
At least 200 mainland Chinese women have been smuggled by the "Liangke Snakehead Ring" into Taiwan's sex trade over the past several years, coast guard officers said.

Ring members are also known to have performed "trial runs" on the mainland Chinese women before pushing them into underground brothels, resulting in most of the men being infected with sexually transmitted diseases.

Tsai and his accomplices are facing trial for violating organized crime laws, the statue governing the relations between people of the Taiwan area and the mainland area, and the sexual transaction prevention regulations regarding children and teenagers, as well as violations regarding decency, the obstruction of freedmen of movement, the hiding criminals, and document forgery.

In January of this year, Hualien coast guard officials broke the largest human smuggling ring in eastern Taiwan, arresting Chang Yu-chang, leader of the ring nicknamed the "Shuike Snakehead and Human Brokerage Ring, " as well as eight of his accomplices and 12 mainland Chinese women.

The police found that Chang used to be one of the three major brothel operators in northern Taiwan. Because of the rigorous crackdown by police, Chang had turned to Hualien and Taitung to continue his illicit trade last year.

It is also known that the "Liangke Snakehead Ring" has been a major "importer" and "wholesaler" of mainland Chinese prostitutes and has regularly supplied mainland Chinese women to local brothel operators around the island, including the "Shuike Ring."

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO SET UP FOOTHOLDS IN H.K., JAPAN TO PROMOTE AGRI PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) has chosen Japan and Hong Kong as locations to establish footholds to promote Taiwan's agricultural products.

Huang Tsu-ping, director of the COA's International Cooperation Department, who just returned from a visit to Japan, said Tuesday that the COA will set up a trade office in Osaka at the end of this year.

The council is also searching for a suitable place in Tokyo to set up an exhibition hall, Huang said, adding that it has set up an exhibition counter in Hong Kong's Wingon Department Store. He said that if things go well, the council will expand its operations.
For efficient management, private operators will be in charge of the footholds in Tokyo and Osaka, Huang said, adding however that the government will help out.

The Osaka office will concurrently serve a wholesale function, mainly targeting major supermarkets, while the Tokyo exhibition hall will mainly target average consumers, with the aim of enhancing the profile and image of Taiwan agricultural products in Japan, Huang said.

Tai Teh-fang, an economic official of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan, said that Japanese consumers are fond of Taiwanese food, with Taiwan tilapia and Oolong tea enjoying brisk sales in Japan.

Recently, water bamboo and green soybeans from Taiwan have also been winning the hearts of more and more Japanese, Tai said, adding that the council is eyeing promoting mangos, lichees, pineapples, bananas and grapes in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 27, or the ninth day of the third month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1521: Portuguese navigator Ferdinand Magellan is killed by the inhabitants on the island of Mactan in the Philippines.
1791: American painter and inventor Samuel F.B. Morse is born. A portraitist whose subjects included Lafayette, he refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name.
1822: Ulysses S. Grant, the 18th president of the United States, is born. After his victorious Vicksburg campaign, he was made commander in chief of the Union Army and accepted the surrender of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee at Appomattox in 1865, thus ending the Civil War.
1882: Ralph Waldo Emerson, the American essayist, philosopher, and a central figure of American transcendentalism, dies at the age of 78. His poems, orations and essays are regarded as landmarks in the development of American thought and literary expression.
1887: The world's first surgical removal of an appendix, an operation known as an appendectomy, is performed by American surgeon Dr. Thomas Morton in Philadelphia.
1911: An uprising in Canton, China, is foiled when revolutionaries led by Huang Shing are defeated by the local garrison. The battle in Canton is the 10th uprising directed by Dr. Sun Yat-sen after he launched a revolutionary movement against the Ching court in the late 19th century.
1937: The new Golden Gate suspension bridge linking the city of San Francisco with Marin County reaches completion after four years.
1945: The Allies reject peace offers by German S.S. chief Heinrich Himmler, insisting on unconditional German surrender.
1949: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek arrives in Shanghai and reiterates his determination to suppress the communist rebellion.
1950: The British government officially recognizes the state of Israel.
1956: Rocco Marciano, known as "Rocky," the American boxer who won the world heavyweight championship in 1952 and defended it six times, retires as undefeated world heavyweight boxing champion.
1959: Liu Shao-chi is elected "state chairman" of Communist China.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with the Republic of Togo.
1960: Syngman Rhee resigns as president of South Korea, ending his 12-year rule.
1962: Hsieh Chin wins the "best director" award in the first film festival to be held in mainland China.
1972: After a journey to the moon, U.S. Apollo 16 spacecraft carrying three astronauts makes a safe landing in the Pacific Ocean.
1972: Kwame Nkrumah, the Ghanaian president who was deposed in 1966 by a military coup while he was in mainland China, dies in Bucharest, Hungary.
1973: Jordanian Ambassador to the ROC Mutasim Bileisi returns to Amman after a two-year tour of duty in Taipei.
1974: The Academia Sinica Advisory Council votes on a list of candidates for academicians.
1974: The Taiwan Railway Administration and General Electric of the United States sign a contract for the electrification of Taiwan's western trunk line railway. GE will provide 74 locomotives and heavy trucks for the project.
1978: President Mohammed Daoud is killed in a bloody coup and replaced by Afghanistan's first communist ruler, Nur Mohammed Taraki, who proclaims the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan.
1992: The International Monetary Fund and World Bank approve the membership of Russia and 12 other former Soviet republics.
1993: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC Straits Exchange Foundation, and Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, meet in Singapore in what is the first official contact between Taipei and Beijing since 1949.
1997: The world's longest road-rail suspension bridge, linking Hong Kong to its new offshore airport, is formally opened.
1998: Nguyen Van Linh, former general secretary of the Vietnam Communist Party, dies.
1999: Verka Modanu, the Republic of Macedonia's first resident envoy to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume her post.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian says that only mutual trust can bring real peace to the people of both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2001: The first-ever civic group to promote private exchanges between Taiwan-controlled offshore island of Kinmen and mainland China' Xiamen is formally established following the implementation of the "mini three links" with mainland China at the beginning of the year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When you meet the proper person to speak to and do not speak out, you lose your opportunity; but when you meet one who is not a proper person to speak to and you speak to him, you waste your words. A man of intelligence never loses his opportunity, neither does he waste his words."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-BORN GOLFER MEETS CLINTON AT CHARITY MATCH
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, April 27 (CNA) (By Chiang Ying and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-born golfer Henry Liaw met former U.S. President Bill Clinton during a recent charity golf match in Los Angles in which they both competed.
Clinton was full of praise for the 18-year-old golfer, offering his best wishes for Liaw in his golf career.
Matthew S. M. Lee, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco, was also invited to the charity golf event and met with Clinton.

Clinton told Lee that he still has vivid memories of Taiwan from his several visits to the island. He said he is impressed with Taiwan's democratic development and hopes the island will not retreat in the face of any setbacks amid the global trend of freedom and democratization.
Liaw first drew the attention of Clinton when he hit an amazing 12-under-par 58 at Alhambra Municipal Golf Course at the age of 12 in 1998.

An avid golfer since childhood, Liaw has played at least five hours a day since the age of nine. Liaw's record includes winning the 2001 United States Junior Amateur Championship as well as four junior world championships -- in 1996, 1998, 1999 and 2000.

Liaw's parents emigrated to the United States when he was very young. He is now studying at Arizona State University under a full scholarship. The university is famous for nurturing golf talent and boasts such famous graduates as Phil Mickelson, champion of the 2004 Masters.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Bangkok Post:BANGKOK GOVERNOR ELECTION / Pavena quits to run solo.
Chart Pattana secretary-general Pavena Hongsakula resigned from her party yesterday to run for Bangkok governer as an independent candidate, with Thai Rak Thai reportedly set to declare its support for her tomorrow. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Checkpoint controls to go high-tech.
IMMIGRATION authorities will be scanning the passports of all travellers to Singapore by the end of the year with a new $9 million system. Photographs and personal details captured by the system will be automatically checked against a 'blacklist' to keep out wanted criminals, terrorist suspects and anyone else who may be barred from entering the country.
The Lianhe Zaobao: The "bona fida visitor" of China & India entry into Singapore will be more convenient.
Another move being planned by Singappore Government such as "Visa Electronic Transmission System" is increasing the number of firms which can issue the letters of introduction required for Chinese and Indian visitors here for business negotiations. Previously, these letters had to come from Singapore-registered companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Plotters sought 80,000 deaths; Jordan airs al-Qaeda suspects confessions.
Al-Qaeda plotted bomb and poison gas attacks against the U.S. Embassy and other targets in Jordan, suspects confessed in a videotape broadcast on Jordanian state television. A commentator said the plotters hoped to kill 80,00 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Manila Bulletin: Congress ready for canvassing. Congress is now ready for the canvassing of votes for president and vice president in the May 10 elections. The task forces created both by the Senate and the House of Representatives said that after more than a month of coordination, the systems and procedures are all set when Congress sits as the National Canvassing Board to proclaim the winner in the presidential and vice presidential races next month.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Cancer talk hounds Roco. WHEN RAUL Roco, who once fought off prostrate cancer, flies home from the United States on Wednesday, he will be carrying some heavy baggage -- the unclarified status of his health and how to dispel talk that he is seriously ill.
The Philippine Star: Only 1,268 AFP men cast votes. The three-day absentee voting for government employees, police and military personnel began yesterday with zero turnout of policemen and only a handful of soldiers casting their votes ahead of the May 10 elections. The Manila Times: Roco's ticket unravels Signs that the bond holding together the senatorial slate of the Alyansa ng Pag-asa is weakening surfaced a day before its standard-bearer, Raul Roco, arrives from a medical checkup in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE INVESTIGATE EXPLOSION IN SUNGSHAN RAILWAY STATION

TEXT.P: Police are investigating a small explosion Wednesday in the men's restroom in the Sungshan Railway Station, suburban Taipei, according to law enforcement officers.
The explosion occurred at about 7: 02 p.m. and caused no casualties but panicked bystanders, the police said.

A possible connection to four other incidents related to explosives discovered on trains of the Taiwan Railway Administration and explosions in other railway stations since the beginning of this year will be the focus of investigations, the police noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANOTHER DPP LAWMAKER TO SERVE IN CABINET

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Chiu Tai-san will serve in the Cabinet at a yet-unspecified post, spokesman for the Executive Yuan Lin Chia-lung said Wednesday.
Chiu talked with Premier Yu Shyi-kun Wednesday and agreed to be recruited into the government, Lin said.

He will be the fouth DPP legislator to enter into the Cabinet after Tan Sun Chen was named foreign minister, Lo Wen-chia was designated chief of the Council for Hakka Affairs and Chen Chih-mai who was tapped to be the spokesman for the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: OLDER NT$50 COIN NO LONGER LEGAL TENDER AFTER JUNE 30

TEXT.P: The dual-color NT$50 coin will be taken out of circulation by June 30, and people are urged to change any of these coins that they have into another version already in circulation, according to Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC) Wednesday.
The coin to be withdrawn from the market has a picture of the Presidential Office on one side and an orchid on the other.

After July 1, only the NT$50 coin which features the portrait of national founder Sun Yat-sen on one side and the number " 50" on the other will be legal tender because the newer version is harder to counterfeit, according to a bank news release.

To celebrate the inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu on May 20, the CBC is planing to issue a set of memorial coins in both gold and silver. Further details have not been released.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: State's Prisons Declare a Crisis.
California's state prison system has declared a state of emergency and begun triple-bunking prisoners in two-person cells in response to an increase in the number of inmates,which is approaching historical highs.

DOC.HEADLINE: UMC HAS NO PLANS TO SET UP 8-INCH WAFER PLANT IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: United Microelectronics Corp., one of Taiwan's leading chipmakers, has no plans to set up eight-inch wafer plant in mainland China at the moment, a UMC executive said Wednesday.

UMC's Chief Executive Officer Jackson Hu made the remarks after it was announced that Taiwan's other leading chipmaker, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC), had passed the government's second-stage screening for locating an eight-inch wafer plant in mainland China.

Experts at a recent meeting organized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs agreed that TSMC has met the government's requirement that local semiconductor manufacturers who want to invest in eight-inch chip plants in mainland China must first have their domestically made 12-inch wafers reaching the level of "mass production."

According to TSMC, the average monthly 12-inch wafer production of the company has reached more than 10,000 units in six consecutive months, with the monthly production even reaching 15,000 units recently. Meanwhile, the yield rate of its 12-inch wafers also reached more than 85 percent in a period of six consecutive months.
The experts of the screening panel agreed that TSMC's 12-inch wafer production has met the requirement of "economic mass production."
Economists now are wondering whether UMC, which also has the monthly production capacity of 12-inch wafers of more than 10,000 units, will follow TSMC's step.

However, Hu noted that according to government regulations, domestic chipmakers interested in investing in mainland China are not allowed to buy new equipment, but can only relocate their original production facilities in Taiwan to the mainland.
As UMC's production equipment is in full use now, it has no idle facilities to relocate to mainland China, Hu added.

Asked about the increasing threat from mainland China's OEM wafer manufacturers, Hu stressed that first-class chipmakers should have very large investments in developing advanced products, improving yield rates, be dedicated to research and development, as well as protecting their clients' intellectual property rights.
Hu said his company is quite competitive in these areas, expressing optimism on UMC's edge in the face of mainland Chinese competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIB TO SEEK MAINLAND ASSISTANCE IN ANTI-FRAUD CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) under the National Police Administration (NPA) said Wednesday it will seek mainland Chinese law enforcement authorities' assistance in its current campaign against fraud.
Various forms of fraud have recently become rampant in local society. In response to mounting public complaints, the NPA has launched an all-out campaign against fraud.
According to CIB intelligence, fraud rings on both sides of the Taiwan Strait have colluded to swindle local people.

CIB officials said masterminds of fraud rings tend to hide themselves in mainland China's southeastern coastal cities, including Xiamen, Shenzhen and Zhuhai. They have usually directed their accomplices in Taiwan to engage in fraudulent operations through complicated telephone transfers, and their local accomplices then remit money they have stolen from victims' bank accounts using bogus ATM cards or credit cards to mainland China via underground cross-strait channels.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, CIB Director Hou Yo-yi said there are 30 to 40 fraud rings on each side of the Taiwan Strait. Each ring has at least 10 members. Based on these figures, Hou said there are some 1,000 fraudsters targeting local people.
Hou said the NPA has been seeking cooperation with mainland China's public security authorities to crack down on fraud.
In addition, Hou said judicial authorities should mete out harsher punishments for fraud. In the past, fraudsters usually received lenient penalties.
Moreover, Hou said, a new law should be legislated to protect private information or personal data. The new law should include harsh penalties for those who illegally leak personal information.

On Tuesday, police arrested 20 people in the southern port city of Kaohsiung for allegedly selling personal information to fraud rings. The suspects allegedly had illegally obtained information on more than 15 million individuals from local mobile phone companies and financial institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEEKING GREATER INTERNATIONAL SUPPORT FOR ITS WHO BID

TEXT.P: Taiwan is seeking greater international support this year for its bid to join the World Health Organization, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Wednesday.

Following Premier Yu Shyi-kun's instruction to work harder for Taiwan's WHO bid, Chen said that his ministry has been going through a number of different possible scenarios to deal with the upcoming annual meeting of the World Health Assembly (WHA) , the WHO's decision-making body, to be held May 17-22 in Geneva.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has also instructed its outposts abroad to urge their respective host countries to support Taiwan's bid, he added.

What Taiwan is seeking is not only sympathy or a demonstration of support, but also a vote from the WHO member nations when it is necessary, particularly from heavyweight countries, such as the United States, Japan and the European Union member nations, the minister noted.
Chen also urged foreign envoys stationed in Taipei to convey Taiwan's request for support to their respective governments.

Department of Health (DOH) Minister Chen Chien-jen is scheduled to lead a mission for Geneva next month to lobby for international support for Taiwan's bid to become a WHA observer, its eighth attempt in a row since 1997.

Noting that Taiwan's WHO bid should not be considered as political issue, but one concerning health, medicine and humanitarianism, MOFA officials said that Taiwan will appeal to the international community not to use "health apartheid" against its 23 million people.
It will be a challenge to both Taiwan and the international community and a crusade to fight for Taiwan's WHO admission, they emphasized.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION VOTE RECOUNT TO BEGIN ON MAY 10: COURT

TEXT.P: The recount of votes from the March 20 presidential election will begin on May 10, according to a ruling of the Taiwan High Court Wednesday.

A panel of three judges hearing the lawsuit calling for the annulment of the March 20 election also ruled that the validity of individual ballots should be judged according to illustrations provided by the Central Election Committee.
The judges partially granted the plaintiffs' request to photocopy the list of voters, but "not all of them."

The suit was brought by Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, who was defeated in the election by incumbent President Chen Shui-bian by a slim margin, and his running mate, People First Party Chairman James Soong. The two asked the court to annul the election on the grounds that it was unfair, and that a recount was the only way to determine whether their request is well grounded.

Chen's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) opposed the plaintiffs' request to photocopy the lists of all voters, saying it is prohibited by law, and is an affront to all election workers because it implies they were dishonest in conducting the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW LEGISLATION AND AGENCY TO BE USED TO PROTECT PRIVATE INFORMATION

TEXT.P: New legislation will be introduced to protect private information from being used by fraudsters, Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan said Wednesday.

One typical scheme in Taiwan is where a person is directed over the phone to "file for a tax return" using their ATM card. The unsuspecting victim is given complicated instructions over the phone at an ATM terminal such that the individual thinks he is setting up a transfer of funds to his account. In fact, the perpetrator is actually siphoning as much of the victim's money out of the account as he can.
Fraudsters have also been posing as representatives of the National Health Insurance Bureau.
Chen told the Legislative Yuan that the Ministry of Justice has set up a task force to deal with cases such as these.

Furthermore, the ministry will follow the example of other countries by setting up a special agency to protect personal information from leaking to people to whom it does not belong who might use the information to commit crimes.
Because the perpetrators of these crimes generally already have obtained personal information on people, the victims are less suspicious and are more easily taken in, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUNG KMT LAWMAKERS PUSH FOR RELOCATION OF PARTY HEADQUARTERS

TEXT.P: A group of young opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers came up with a package of intraparty reform proposals Wednesday, including relocating the party's headquarters to a more modest building.

The reform-minded legislators, including Jow Bo-yuan, Lo Shih-hsiung, Huang Chien-ting and Kuo Tien-tsai, said the party should move its head office out of its current magnificent building near the Presidential Office in downtown Taipei to show its determination to reinvent itself.

"Our party headquarters is too heavy and too posh. It is incompatible with our current status as an opposition party and our financial situation. We should move out of this elegant building as early as possible to show our resolve to reform, " Jow said at a news conference held at the KMT's legislative caucus office.
At the moment, Jow said, the KMT head office's water and power bills reach NT$6 million a month. "It has become a heavy financial burden for our party," he said.

The young KMT lawmakers also called for streamlining the party apparatus to save expenditures. They suggested that the party largely cut the number of staff members at its headquarters from the current 1,700 to 700 or 800 and recruit young volunteers to work for the party's cause.
The party should also review its pension system, cancel its monthly pension system and preferential interest rates for savings deposits by retired party workers, the young lawmakers said.
By so doing, Jow said, the party will be able to save NT$200 million in salaries and pension payments each month.
Moreover, Jow said, the party should do something about its assets, including its profit-making businesses, as soon as possible.

"We should not let our party assets become the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) 'campaign resources' any more, " Jow said, referring to the DPP's repeated questioning of the KMT's allegedly ill-gotten party assets in the run-ups to nearly all major political elections, including the March 20 presidential election.
Jow also suggested that the party's local chapters be streamlined and transformed into election apparatus.

"The staff members at city and county chapters should be trimmed and the chiefs of local chapters be elected by party members or nominated by party headquarters to be endorsed by party members in the specific cities or counties," Jow said.

Jow said the reform package has been drafted after careful and comprehensive thought. "We'll present the proposals for discussion at the party's new reform panel, " he said, adding that the KMT badly needs sweeping intraparty reform to survive in the rapidly changing Taiwan society.
Commenting on the young KMT lawmakers' party reform proposals, DPP legislative whip Lee Chun-yi said what the KMT has to do first is to return the party's ill-gotten assets to the national coffers.

"In view of promoting healthy party politics, we welcome the KMT's intraparty reform plans. Senior KMT leaders should heed those appeals. But we think the package proposed by Jow's group is not enough to gain popular support," Lee said.
To the best of his understanding Lee said, Jow's group proposes to sell off the KMT's assets.

"This is unacceptable to the general public. The KMT should listen to the DPP's suggestions and return all its ill-gotten party assets to the national coffers," Lee said, adding that it's the most important thing that the KMT should do to improve its image and win the hearts and minds of ordinary voters.

The KMT ruled Taiwan for more than five decades until it lost the 2000 presidential election. KMT Chairman Lien Chan, who ended a distant third in the 2000 election, was defeated again in the 2004 election. However, Lien has so far not conceded defeat and instead has filed two lawsuits to challenge President Chen Shui-bian's narrow re-election victory. The Taiwan High Court is scheduled to begin a vote recount on May 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTERS OF TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINA TO MEET AT APEC MEETING

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Huang Jong-tsun will leave for Chile Thursday to attend an education minister's meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, where he is expected to meet his mainland Chinese counterpart, Zhou Ji.
This is the third time that education ministers from APEC member countries will meet to discuss cooperative projects in educational development.

The meeting will be held in the Chilean capital, Santiago, April 29-30 with a main theme of "skills for the coming challenges." The participant will focus on four key topics: learning one another's languages; English and other languages; stimulating learning in math and science; developing information technology to support teaching and learning communities; and centralizing and decentralizing education systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER-DESIGNATE VOWS TO LIVE UP TO PUBLIC EXPECTATIONS

TEXT.P: Vice Premier-designate Yeh Chu-lan said Wednesday she will do her utmost to help Premier Yu Shyi-kun promote various national development projects.

"As our nation's first female vice premier, I'll do my best to live up to public expectations. I cannot afford to disappoint them, " said Yeh, who currently heads the Cabinet-level Council for Hakka Affairs.

Yeh made the remarks after meeting with Premier Yu Shyi-kun and Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i earlier in the day. Lin, an entrepreneur-turned-politician, has insisted on leaving public service after President Chen Shui-bian's re-election.

Yeh served as a legislator and as minister of transportation and communications before assuming her current post. The post to be left vacant by Yeh will be filled by Legislator Lo Wen-chia of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Yu's Cabinet will resign en masse ahead of May 20, when Chen will be sworn in for a second four-year term. Chen has asked Yu to remain in the premiership and Yu has been organizing a new Cabinet. The new line-up had almost been finalized as of Wednesday. The new Cabinet will be sworn in May 20.
Also decided upon was the new Cabinet spokesman, DPP Legislator Chen Chi-mai, who has agreed to take over the post to be left vacant by Lin Chia-lung.
Chen said Yu asked him earlier in the day whether he is willing to succeed Lin as Cabinet spokesman, to which he replied: "I accept the offer without any hesitation."
A three-term lawmaker, Chen said he will clearly and honestly explain the government's work agenda, policy goals and stances on major public issues.
"I'll be articulate regarding what I can say while remaining tightlipped on what should be withheld. I'll do my best to avoid making any faux pas or slips of the tongue," Chen pledged.

Asked whether his new post will be a boost to his plan to run for the Kaohsiung mayorship in 2006, Chen said he is not planning to run for that post and that his new job has nothing to do with the mayoral election.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT BRINGS SLANDER SUIT AGAINST PRESIDENT, PREDECESOR

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) followed the lead of its political partner the People First Party (PFP) Wednesday in bringing a slander suit against President Chen Shui-bian and former President Lee Teng-hui for branding their protests last month as "an attempted coup d'etat."

Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT's Policy Coordination Committee, told a news conference Wednesday that the lawsuit will be brought in the name of KMT Chairman Lien Chan and six other KMT officials.

Tseng said his party had asked the country's intelligence and law enforcement officials to clarify the previous day that they had no information on any alleged coup attempt and did not alert Chen that the KMT and PFP were trying to engineer a coup when the two parties called in supporters to protest what they claim was unfairness in the March 20 presidential election and demanded a vote recount.

Noting that all the sometimes violent protests between March 20 and March 27 were legally organized, Tseng claimed that Chen was deliberately defaming the two opposition parties by cooking up the accusation that they were trying to overthrow the government with a military coup.
A lawyer for the party went to the Prosecutor's Office at the Taipei District Court soon afterward to file the complaint against Chen.
Former President Lee Teng-hui, who has made similar claims, was also named as a defendant in the lawsuit.

The KMT's action was taken two days after the PFP filed a similar complaint. In that case, the PFP also claimed NT$60 million (US$1.81 million) in damages from Chen and Lee because Chen, as head of state, is sheltered from any criminal suit but can be held liable for damages.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: With 4 Days to Go, EU and Russia Sign Pact.
The European Union and Russia signed an eleventh-hour agreement on the expansion of the EU to Russia's western borders Tuesday after Moscow dropped a demand for a reference to the treatment of Russian-speaking minorities in incoming members Latvia and Estonia.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.N. Envoy Seeks New Iraq Council by Close of May.
The special United Nations envoy for Iraq, offering a speeded-up timetable for the selection of a caretaker government in Baghdad, said Tuesday that the new government should be chosen a full month before sovereignty is transferred on June 30 to give it time to define its authority.
Addressing the Security Council, the envoy, Lakhdar Brahimi, said the month would be necessary for the transitional leaders to reach "crystal-clear understandings" of their relationship to the occupation authority they would replace and to the American military commanders who are to remain in charge of Iraqi security forces.
Wall Street Journal: Regulators Hit Fannie, Freddie With New Assault.
The U.S. government is seeking to tighten regulation of mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, fearing that the two companies have grown so huge that any missteps could panic financial markets.
Because Fannie and Freddie are congressionally chartered companies, many investors assume the government would bail them out in a crisis. Asian central banks and other foreign investors hold about one-third of their debt and have long considered it nearly as safe as U.S. Treasury bonds. But the Bush administration is determined to bury the notion that the U.S. government stands behind Fannie and Freddie.

DOC.HEADLINE: IC INDUSTRY TO RECORD PRODUCTION VALUE OF NEARLY NT$1.16 TRILLION

TEXT.P: With the global economic rebound, Taiwan's IC industry should have rosy prospects, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Wednesday.

The production value of the domestic IC industry this year should reach NT$1,159.8 billion (US$35.14 billion), representing annual growth of 41.6 percent, according to the MOEA's industrial technology information service team under the Department of Industrial Technology.
The team said that the production value of the IC industry, including design, manufacturing, packaging and testing, in the first quarter of 2004 was NT$240.8 billion.

Among them, the production value of design was NT$64.4 billion, representing annual growth of 43.5 percent, manufacturing was NT$130.7 billion, or annual growth of 40 percent, packaging totaled NT$33.4 billion, or annual growth of 34.6 percent, and testing totaled NT$12.3 billion, or 48.3 percent in terms of annual growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPZA APPROVES INVESTMENT PROJECTS WORTH US$115 MILLION IN APRIL

TEXT.P: The Economic Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs approved Wednesday eight investment projects worth NT$3.81 billion (US$115 million) for April.

EPZA officials welcomed the investment in the eight companies at the island's economic processing zones. These enterprises are dedicated mainly to the manufacture of high-tech products, including digital cameras, optical and optoelectronic products, as well as logistic support services for the semiconductor industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: KUOMINTANG MUST GROOM YOUNGER TALENT: TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) should groom younger talent to ensure the healthy development of the party.
Ma, who concurrently serves as a KMT vice chairman, made the remarks on the sidelines of an awards ceremony for model workers.
Saying that the party has not done enough to cultivate new blood, Ma, who is 54, noted that "the KMT should nurture more talent that is 20 years his junior."
He said he is in favor of speedier reforms but opposed to an immediate concession of defeat in the March 20 presidential election.
With the "pan-blue alliance" still contesting the result of the presidential election, "the time to concede defeat has yet to come, " Ma said.

He pointed out that the vote recount has yet to be completed and that "the truth" about the election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu has yet to come to light, adding that many are still working on these two issues and that nothing can be decided until the work is finished.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) , claiming voting irregularities and that the election-eve shooting swayed the bitterly contested election in Chen's favor, has asked for a vote recount and an investigation into the shooting, which police have so far made little progress on.

The popular mayor was responding to remarks by a group of reform-minded young KMT mavericks, including KMT Vice Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung's son Wu Chih-yang, who has expressed his aspiration to run in the year-end legislative elections.

The young Turks, who said at a press conference a day earlier that they are only trying to save a foundering party in disarray, are all members of short-term school conceived by KMT Chairman Lien Chan after his defeat in the 2000 presidential election.

They called for the party to face the defeat squarely and engage in immediate reforms, including the donation of party assets and the direct election of local party chiefs, as well as embrace more youngsters in the party.

Su Chun-pin, an assistant to KMT Legislator Hsyu Jong-shyong, said that no matter what is the result of the vote recount, "one undeniable fact is that President Chen Shui-bian, despite his poor performance over the past four years, took 1.5 million more votes than he did in the last election."
Meanwhile, an official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said the KMT mavericks' call for reform should be encouraged.
Lee Ying-yuan, DPP deputy secretary-general, said that his party respects the views of the KMT young Turks, even though it is not the DPP's business.
But since "political party should be of the public domain," it is a good sign that the younger KMT generation is speaking out for reforms, Lee added.
"For the sake of the healthy development of party politics and mutual competition, society should give them applause and encouragement," he said.

The cry for reform and generational change in the KMT is widespread, but the voice of the young is especially valuable, Lee said, because they pointed out that the "pan-blue alliance" lost 1.5 million ballots, instead of focusing on the margin of 29,518 votes between Chen and his rival, Lien.
Lee urged the leaders of the KMT and PFP to take stock of themselves and accept responsibility for the election performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market moved down Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for May fell 75 points to close at 6,605, with 33,440 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June lost 69 points to end at 6,603, with 225 contracts traded, while September futures dropped 45 points to end at 6,625, with 51 contracts finalized.
December futures lost 56 points to end at 6,616, with four contracts traded, while Next March futures fell 59 points to end at 6,630, with 17 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,680 for May, 6,672 for June, 6,670 for September, 6,672 for December and 6,689 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also moved down.
May TE futures fell 4.25 points to close at 272, with 5,118 contracts traded, while June TE futures lost 4.45 points to end at 272, with 23 contracts transacted.
September TE futures dropped 1.5 points to close at 275, with one contract finalized, while next March TE futures lost 1.1 points to end at 277, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
May TF futures lost 2.8 points to close at 1,053.8, with 8,632 contracts changing hands, while June TF futures fell 5.6 points to end at 1,051.2, with 87 contracts traded.
Next March TF futures dropped 14 points to close at 1,050, with four contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved up against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.037 to close at NT$33.081.
A total of US$470 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$33.171 and fluctuated between NT$33.050 and NT$33.186.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended the day lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 72.05 points to close at 6,574.75.
The bourse opened at 6,636.3 and fluctuated between 6,673.05 and 6,556.87 during trading.

A total of 4.13 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$107.51 billion (US$3.2 billion) , a slight decrease from the previous day's trading session that saw 4.3 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$107.7 billion.

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks and construction stocks both moving down the most at 2.7 percent, followed by electrical shares at 1.5 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.2 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.9 percent, textile issues at 0.6 percent, and bank and insurance shares at 0.2 percent.
Foodstuff stocks, however, rose 1.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 581 to 219, with 163 stocks remaining unchanged.
