DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN ACTIVATES ANTI-SARS MECHANISM
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, April 28 (CNA) (By K.Y. Ni and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The outlying island of Kinmen activated an alert mechanism against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) Wednesday after a would-be airline passenger was discovered to be running a fever.
The Kinmen health and police authorities activated anti-SARS measures Wednesday after the female passenger was found to have developed a fever of 38 degrees Celsius.

The island's SARS alert mechanism started with immediate effect and will be continued, although the passenger was later discovered to be SARS-free but suffering from a common cold, said Lin Ren-hsin, president of the Kinmen County Hospital.
Unexpectedly, the woman also became the target of a police investigation as she was suspected of being an illegal stowaway from mainland China.
According to Kinmen police authorities, the woman, probably in her late 20s, attempted to board a Trans Asia Airways plane leaving Kinmen for Kaohsiung at round 5 p.m. a day earlier.
She was stopped from boarding after the airport police discovered that she was holding a fake ID card bearing the name of Republic of China citizen Huang Li-rong.
The woman, who spoke with an obvious northern Chinese accent and refused to say anything about herself, was detained by the police and spent the night at the police station.

The following morning she caused jitters when she was found to have a fever. She was immediately rushed to the Kinmen County Hospital, where health care personnel equipped with SARS-fighting masks and gear examined her.
After several hours of examinations, doctors declared the woman to be SARS-negative.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC TO OFFER SARS ALERT ADVICE FOR PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: The Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health will continue to watch closely for any resurgence of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Taiwan and will offer SARS alert advice for the presidential inauguration slated for May 20, CDC Director-General Su Ih-jen said Wednesday.
Su said the CDC will continue to monitor the SARS situation but will not offer SARS alert advice to the government until May 10 with regard to the presidential inauguration.
The CDC will recommend which level the country should be on in terms of its anti-SARS efforts after May 10, Su added.

He called for the public to refrain from taking part in mass public gatherings such as the presidential inauguration ceremony if they have traveled to mainland China, Hong Kong or Macau over the past two weeks or they have developed fever.
The Department of Health (DOH) has a four-level SARS alert system -- Zero, A, B, and C -- with level C being the highest level of alert.

The DOH upgraded Taiwan's epidemic prevention mobilization level against SARS from level zero to level A from last Saturday after Beijing confirmed two SARS cases a day earlier on the mainland, in addition to two already reported suspected cases and one possible fatality from the disease.

Under the level A alert mechanism, all inbound and outbound passengers are required to have their temperatures taken and to fill out SARS questionnaires. All passengers arriving from the mainland, Hong Kong and Macau have to exercise self-health management, including regular hand-washing and temperature-taking, while all government agencies and institutions are advised to conduct temperature-taking.

A researcher at a private Taiwan biotechnology company has caused jitters over the past few days, particularly among the health-care community, after he visited Beijing and developed a fever upon returning to Taiwan.
After three rounds of lab examination of his throat swabs, the researcher was confirmed Tuesday as not being infected with SARS.

While in Beijing from April 19-24, the researcher visited a lab where one of the latest SARS cases had been reported. His case drew much attention from Taiwan's health authorities as it occurred at a time when the potentially fatal flu-like disease has been showing signs of resurgence on the mainland, particularly in Beijing.

It was the second case in Taiwan of an individual being monitored for possible SARS infection since the outbreaks of the atypical pneumonia on the mainland subsided last summer. In December, a researcher with the military Institute of Preventive Medicine Research inadvertently infected himself while working with the SARS viruses at his lab. He was cured later.
Taiwan was hit hard by SARS between March and June last year, resulting in 37 deaths and heavy economic losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COUNTY MAGISTRATE DISMISSES REPORTS OF NEW APPOINTMENT

TEXT.P: Taipei County Magistrate Su Tseng-chang said Tuesday that reports about his appointment as secretary-general of the Presidential Office are mere speculation.

Su made the remarks upon his return from a three-day visit to South Korea at a time when the ruling Democratic Progressive Party is making decisions on the lineup of the new Cabinet prior to the May 20 presidential inauguration.

Su, who was one of the core five-member campaign team for President Chen Shui-bian during his re-election bid, has been tipped to new heights in his political career after Chen won a narrow victory against his rival, Lien Chan of the opposition Kuomintang.

On his visit to South Korea, Su said that in addition to accepting an honorary doctorate from South Korea's Kyungnam University, he also visited the Masan Free Trade Zone, a trip which he described as worthwhile.
Su also described a recent trip to Japan at the head of a delegation comprised of chiefs of towns and villages from Taipei County as a"communication trip."
Su said that while overseas trips might be a time of relaxation for some, for him such trips are work focusing on communicating with grassroots chiefs.

He said he had extensive communication with town and village chiefs during the trip and learned about the problems they face. "This is the reason why Taipei County has always performed so well over the years," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW VICE PREMIER NAMED

TEXT.P: Council for Hakka Affairs (CHA) Chairwoman Yeh Chu-lan has agreed to serve as vice premier in the new Cabinet to be sworn in after President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inauguration for a second four-year term, Cabinet spokesman Lin Chia-lung said Wednesday.

According to Lin, Premier Yu Shyi-kun, who will continue to head the new Cabinet, first invited Yeh to succeed Lin Hsin-i as vice premier in mid-April. "After extensive talks with Yu April 18, Yeh accepted the offer," Lin said.
Lin's remarks came after Yeh met with Yu and Lin Hsin-i earlier in the day. Lin Hsin-i, an entrepreneur-turned-politician, insists on leaving public service after President Chen's re-election.
Lin quoted Yeh as having assured Yu that she will do her utmost to fulfill her duty under Yu's leadership.

Yeh had served as a legislator and minister of transportation and communications before assuming her current post. The post to be left vacant by Yeh will be filled by Legislator Lo Wen-chia of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Meanwhile, Lin said, DPP Legislator Chen Chi-mai has agreed to serve as spokesman for the new Cabinet.

It remains unclear what Lin's new job will be after Chen Chi-mai takes over his post. One previous press report said Lin is likely to serve as chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC), as incumbent RDEC Chairman Lin Chia-cheng has decided to return to his teaching post at Soochow University.

Some other new Cabinet members have been decided upon, including Education Minister-designate Tu Cheng-sheng and Council for Cultural Affairs Chairman-designate Chen Chi-nan, while incumbent Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan and Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu have agreed to stay on in their current posts.

In line with constitutional precedents, the current Cabinet will resign en masse ahead of the presidential inauguration. The exact resignation date may fall between May 5 and May 12, Yu said earlier this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INSPECTS RECONSTRUCTION IN ABORIGINAL VILLAGE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made an inspection tour of an aboriginal village in central Taiwan Wednesday to check out post-disaster reconstruction in one of the areas that had been virtually reduced to rubble in the deadly earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999.

Accompanied by Nantou County Magistrate Lin Tsung-nan and Kuo Yao-chi, CEO of the Cabinet-level 921 Earthquake Post-Disaster Recovery Commission, President Chen traveled to Hsinhsiang village in the rural township of Hsinyi in Nantou County.

President Chen was briefed by local officials about the progress of a community development project that began in Hsinhsiang village at the end of 1999. The village currently has about 160 households with 800 residents. More than 90 percent of the residents are aboriginal citizens.

Chen said that although many aboriginal villages have been recovering from the destruction caused by the 921 earthquake, the 921 Earthquake Post-Disaster Recovering Commission has still allocated another NT$240 million this year to finance reconstruction and development in aboriginal communities.

Under the government's assistance, Chen said, Nantou County's Hsinhsiang village, Hsinchu County's Chienshih rural township and Kaohsiung County's Sanmin rural township have become model aboriginal communities through integrated development programs that have been carried out over the past four years.
The integrated development programs include reconstruction and development of infrastructure, as well as cultural and humanistic development, Chen said.
After listening to the briefing, Chen was entertained by a group of elementary school students who performed traditional Bunun Tribe dancing and singing.

Following the Hsinhsiang village inspection tour, Chen and the accompanying officials proceeded to Hsinglung village in Shuili rural township in Nantou County to inspect the progress of a river streamlining project along the Chung-keng-yeh-chi River.
The 921 earthquake killed about 2,400 people and left some 100,000 others homeless.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WELCOMES RESOLUTION PASSED BY NORDIC CONFAB ON TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Tuesday expressed appreciation and welcome to the resolution passed by the Nordic Conference on Taiwan in Denmark in support of Taiwan's bid for observer status in the World Health Organization (WHO).
The ministry also said that it will continue working to drum up more support from the international community for the rights and interests that Taiwan deserves to have as a normal country.

According to the ministry, the conference was held Tuesday at the Danish Parliament in Copenhagen with the participation of more than 150 dignitaries from five Nordic countries -- namely Denmark, Finland, Norway, Sweden and Iceland.

The ministry said that at the invitation of the conference, President Chen delivered a speech via video link and responded to questions raised by conference participants regarding the island's important policies and administrative work.

The conference was presided over by Jens Hald Madsen, chairman of the Foreign Policy Committee of the Danish Parliament, and included speeches by several dignitaries, including Klaus C. Pedersen, secretary-general of the Danish Academic Association of Foreign Policy; Jesper Poulsen, representative of the Nordic Medical Association; Kerstin Engle, member of the Swedish Parliament; Linda C. Hofstad, member of the Norwegian Parliament; Ole Andreansen, member of the European Parliament; and Peng Ming-min, senior advisor to President Chen Shui-bian.

During the conference, Madsen announced the official inauguration of a "Taiwan Friendship Group" in the Danish Parliament to establish a solid foundation between the two countries' parliaments, the ministry said.

Praising Taiwan's further democratic progress through the holding of its third direct presidential election, the resolution said the conference wants to see the international community's unjust treatment toward Taiwan redressed.

Noting that Taiwan continues to be excluded from various international organizations, including the WHO, the resolution said that considering the interests of world health, the representatives from the Nordic countries would take the same position as the United States, Japan, the European Parliament and the World Health Professions Alliance of supporting Taiwan's WHO bid.

In the interests of world peace, the resolution also echoed the stance of the European Parliament by calling for mainland China to abandon the option of the use of force to resolve the Taiwan question and to reduce or dismantle its missiles aimed at Taiwan.

It also said Taiwan has the right to participate in the international community, urging the governments and legislative bodies of the Nordic countries to adopt concrete measures to extend their political, economic, scientific and cultural relations with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FO GUANG SHAN INTERNATIONAL BUILDING CARE CENTER IN MALAWI
DOC.DATELINE: Lilongwe, Malawi, April 27 (CNA) (By Yang Hui-chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Fo Guang Shan (Buddha's Light Mountain) International Organization is building a care center which includes an orphanage in the southeastern African country of Malawi.

The Amito-Fo Care Center, being established by the Nan Hua Temple in South Africa -- the headquarters of Fo Guang Shan in Africa and the largest Buddhist temple in the southern hemisphere -- is envisaged to also include a health care center exclusively for AIDS patients, said Lin Rui-hsiang, a Fo Guang Shan volunteer worker.

The first-stage development of the orphanage, located in Malawi's capital city of Lilongwe, is scheduled to be completed in November of this year at a cost of US$1.4 million. At that time, the institution will be able to take in some 120 orphans aged below 10, Lin said. All the funds used to build the orphanage are donations from Fo Guang Shan followers from Taiwan and around the world, he added.

The Nan Hua Temple -- founded by Ven. Hui Li in 1994 -- is aiming not only to provide accommodations and education to the orphans, but also to teach them about Buddhism to enable them to lead tranquil, unselfish and productive lives, Lin said.
According to Lin, the Amito-Fo Care Center has also been preparing to build a health center, exclusively for the treatment of AIDS patients and for HIV prevention.

Republic of China Ambassador to Malawi H.T. Chen said that it is a pity the ROC embassy could not render financial assistance toward Nan Hua Temple's efforts in Malawi because of budget limitations. Chen called for the private business sector and social organizations in Taiwan to give concrete support to the Buddhist organization to help facilitate its missions.
The Nation, the largest circulation daily newspaper in Malawi, ran a full-page report Tuesday on the Amito-Fo Care Center and its operations under the headline: "With Kindness from Taiwan."

The Nan Hua Temple in South Africa, which already has branch temples in Cape Town, Johannesburg, Durban and New Castle, has also been running the African Buddhist Seminary, which began recruiting students in 1994. Currently, the seminary has several hundred student monks from Brazil, Israel, Congo, Kenya, Madagascar, Malawi, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Africa, Tanzania and Zimbabwe.

According to Ven. Hui Li, the goals of the Nan Hua Temple in South Africa are teaching the Buddhist Dharma to help people leave suffering behind and gain joy; educating locals to become monks so as to plant the seeds of Buddhism; translating the Chinese-language Buddhist scriptures into the local languages; and constructing temples.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 28, or the 10th day of the third month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1442: King Edward IV, the Yorkist leader during the War of the Roses, is born. He was crowned king of England after defeating the Lancastrians at Mortimer's Cross and Towton in 1461.
1545: Yi Sun-shin, Korean admiral and national hero, is born.
1758: James Monroe, the fifth president of the United States, is born. His administration is noted for the acquisition of Florida in 1819, and for the proclaiming of the Monroe Doctrine in 1823, which declared that no foreign power would be allowed to colonize any part of the Americas.
1789: On a return trip from Tahiti in the South Pacific, mutinous crew members of the British transport ship Bounty set Captain William Bligh and 18 sailors adrift in an open boat. Bligh and his royal crew manage to reach Timor Island near Java on June 14 after sailing 3,500 miles.
1788: Maryland becomes the seventh state of the United States.
1876: Queen Victoria of Britain is declared Empress of India.
1902: The U.S. Senate passes an anti-Chinese bill.
1922: War between Wu Pei-fu of the Chihli faction and Chang Tso-lin of the Fengtien faction breaks out.
1922: Dr. Sun Yat-sen issues a manifesto urging the reunification of China by peaceful means.
1937: Saddam Hussein, president of Iraq since 1979, is born.
1945: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini is shot by his countrymen, who then string up his body head down.
1952: At his own request, Dwight D. Eisenhower is relieved of duty as Supreme Allied Commander in Europe. He is succeeded by Gen. Matthew Ridgway.
1952: The Treaty of Peace between the Republic of China and Japan is signed in Taipei by Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh and Japan's special envoy, Isao Kawata.
1962: The Taiwan Television Enterprise, Ltd. is established in Taipei.
1963: Yang Chuan-kuang, the ROC's decathlon champion who won the first Olympic silver medal for his country on Sept. 6, 1960, sets a new world record in the sport in the United States with 9,121 points.
1963: Taiwan holds elections for the third Provincial Assembly.
1969: President Charles De Gaulle of France resigns and is succeeded by Georges Pompidou.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo is elected chairman of the Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang.
1976: Delegates headed by Dr. Ku Cheng-kang, honorary president of the World Anti-Communist League, leave Taipei for Seoul and the Ninth General Assembly of the WACL.
1980: U.S. Secretary of State Cyrus Vance resigns.
1988: A Republic of China delegation attends the annual convention of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in Manila.
1992: The Afghan government cedes power to Islamic guerrillas in Kabul, ending 14 years of armed resistance and civil war.
1992: Yang Chi-chang, a police officer, is killed in an explosion while trying to defuse a bomb placed by blackmailers near the McDonald's fast food branch on Minsheng East Road in Taipei.
1996: The Ministry of Economic Affairs announces that starting July 1, 1996, imports of another 1,609 categories of industrial commodities will be allowed into Taiwan from mainland China, marking the ROC government's largest ever relaxation of restrictions on mainland imports.
1998: David Hempleman-Adams, British explorer, reaches the geographic North Pole, becoming the first person to reach the Earth's northern magnetic and geographic poles.
2000: The Legislative Yuan passes an amendment to the Passport Law which extends the term of validity of Republic of China passports from the present six years to 10 years.
2001: Republic of China government spokesman Su Cheng-ping leaves for New York for a one-week speech tour of the United States.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A workman who wants to perfect his work first sharpens his tools. When you are living in a country, you should serve those nobles and ministers in that country who are men of moral worth, and you should cultivate the friendship of the gentlemen of that country who are men of moral worth."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS COMPETITIVE IN TELE-HOME CARE MARKET: ITRI

TEXT.P: With the popularity of medical care institutions and advanced information technology, Taiwan is quite competitive in the tele-home care market, a section chief of the Industrial Technology Research Institute said Thursday.

Hsu Ming, a laboratory director of ITRI who presides over the tele-care project, noted that with the aging society and increasing segment of the population crippled by chronic disease, the ITRI saw the potential in the tele-home care market and began the research project two years ago with the sponsorship of the government, which considers it a promising industry for the future.

Hsu said the domestic annual tele-home care market is estimated to be worth NT$21.9 billion (US$633 million) , with some 5 million patients needing the service, which links patients with hospitals via telecommunication technology in order to transfer medical data for diagnosis, therapy and care, according to Hsu.

The popularity of these medical care institutions, as well as the sound national health insurance and highly developed information technology industry, will help lower the cost of tele-home care and thus lead to increased client numbers, Hsu predicted.

In addition to integrating several laboratories within the ITRI and telecommunications enterprises around the island, the institute will also cooperate with well-known medical education hospitals to develop best tele-health monitoring systems, Hsu said, adding that Taiwan might become a world model in this area.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SEIZE LARGE HAUL OF HEROIN

TEXT.P: Police discovered 7.8 kilograms of heroin in a wooden case Thursday at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport's cargo terminal.

The case had been airlifted to CKS Airport, some 40 kilometers south of Taipei, via Myanmar and Thailand, police said. Customs brokerage documents claimed that the goods inside the case were wood carvings.

As suspicious goods from Myanmar and several other Southeast Asian countries are subject to special scrutiny, the case was put through an X-ray scanner, after which police opened the case and discovered 78 heroin bricks hidden in a secret compartment.
Police said the drugs had a street value of more than NT$100 million. In addition to tracking down the consignee of the goods, police said they will also probe upstream and downstream suspects.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT WINS LAWSUIT AGAINST WEEKLY

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu won a lawsuit against the Journalist weekly Thursday after the Supreme Court threw out an appeal by the magazine for a reversal of a lower court ruling in Lu's favor.
As a result, the Journalist will have to follow a judgment of the Taiwan High Court by publishing the court ruling against it in advertisements in newspapers, as well as apologizing to Lu.

Judge Lee Chin-feng, who is the spokesman for the Supreme Court, told a news conference that the Journalist failed to check its facts when it published a story in 2000 claiming that Lu was circulating a rumor that President Chen Shui-bian was having an affair with one of his young aides.
Lee said his court was charged with reviewing the rules applied by the lower court in handing down its judgment, rather than examining the case on its merits.

Instead of questioning the facts determined by the Taiwan High Court, Lee said the Supreme Court concerned itself with whether the lower court's ruling violated the freedom of expression guaranteed by an interpretation of the Constitution made by the Council of the Grand Justices.

Since the interpretation was aimed at defining the criteria for the crimes of libel and slander, Lee said, it would not work for the current case in which the vice president asked for a "restoration of her reputation" damaged by the Journalist's story rather than criminal punishment against the weekly.

Lee said the panel of five judges hearing the case fully agreed with the Council of Grand Justices' opinion that it would unnecessarily limit the freedom of the press and jeopardize the mass media's role as a monitor of society if they were required to report only "accurate" stories, Lee went on.

However, the court found, based on the Taiwan High Court's investigation, that the appellants in the case failed to reasonably verify the truth of its story and should be held responsible for damaging Lu's reputation.

The Journalist attributed its sources to its editor-in-chief Lee Ming-chun, who goes by the pen name of Yang Chao, claiming that Yang was told by Lu on the phone about the alleged affair at the Presidential Office. However, neither the Journalist nor Lee were able to prove their claim during the trial and the telephone company's records did not show any such call as having been made by Lu.
After learning of the Supreme Court's decision, Journalist President Wang Chien-chung complained that the ruling "went against the Constitution" and dealt a heavy blow to the freedom of the press.
Wang said he will ask the Council of Grand Justices to look into the legality of the judgment while asking for a retrial of the case.

Lu, who brought the lawsuit against the weekly as well as its president, editor-in-chief, and writers of the story, called on the public to push the Journalist and the other defendants to comply with the judgment.
In a statement issue by her office, the vice president said the Journalist not only damaged her reputation but also cheated the public with groundless accusations.
Noting that the trial has lasted for four years, Lu said the Journalist has squandered too many social resources through its lies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE TYCOON DONATES FUNDS TO BUILD SCHOOLS IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) Chairman Wang Yung-ching has donated 24 million renminbi (about NT$96 million) to build 60 elementary schools in mainland China's Sichuan Province, according to reports from Beijing.
Beijing's China Broadcasting Network reported Thursday that Wang's donation is part of his efforts to support the Sichuan provincial government's plan to promote elementary education in rural areas.

The report said the 60 elementary schools will be in the same architectural style and will use the same title of "Mingde Elementary School." All the schools are scheduled for inauguration this autumn.
Construction of the first school will soon get underway in Sichuan's village of Shihku, the report said.

The report further said that Wang plans to invest up to NT$20 billion to build 10,000 elementary schools in rural mainland areas to assist in manpower cultivation. The Sichuan project marks the first time Wang has helped finance educational programs in rural mainland areas, the report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER VOWS TO SET UP FIREWALL AGAINST PERSONAL DATA LEAKS

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Su Jia Chyuan vowed Thursday to set up an inter-ministerial firewall in an attempt to prevent leaks of private individual data that can be used by fraudsters for scams via telephone or the Internet.

Su made the pledge during an inspection visit to the Kaohsiung Municipal Police Department, where more than 15 million items of personal and corporation data nabbed by Kaohsiung police in recent days from a fraud ring were on display, including those of some government officials and public opinion leaders, including Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.

Citing the results of an initial Kaohsiung police investigation, Su said that banks, cellphone companies, hospitals and clinics as well as even state-run organizations and schools are allegedly involved in the rampant scams illegally orchestrated by fraudsters, many of who are based in mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau.

Su gave high praise for the clampdown efforts thus far by the Kaohsiung police and stressed that the government will never back off from the sweep against fraud rings that have made off with billions of dollars by staging scams or threats via the Internet or telephones.

According to the interior minister, his ministry will take the initiative to build an across-the-board firewall against information leaks of private individuals or companies by collaborating with relevant government agencies, such as the Ministry of Transport and Communications and the Ministry of Finance.

Su said he strongly believes that the planned protection network will be effectively stem personal data leaks from a wide range of sources and he called for increased public awareness of fraud rings, which he said is the most important countermeasure that can be taken.
Meanwhile, various lawmakers of the opposition People First Party called for harsher punishments for this type of crime, especially in the case of repeat offenders.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHAIRMAN CALLS FOR RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should resume constructive dialogue and use new thinking to create a new environment for cross-strait interaction, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China said Thursday.

Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu made the appeal in a written statement commemorating the 11th anniversary of a historic meeting in Singapore in 1993 between he and his mainland Chinese counterpart, Wang Daohan, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

Koo and Wang signed four agreements on behalf of their respective governments during their historic April 27-29, 1993 meeting to lay a framework for institutionalized cross-strait consultations and exchanges.

Koo admitted in his commemorative statement that cross-strait relations have not proceeded as smoothly as originally expected over the past decade. The institutionalized SEF-ARATS communication and consultation channel has repeatedly been disturbed and disrupted, he lamented.

Over the past decade, Koo said, cross-strait exchanges in various non-political fields have continued to grow, but he said that many problems have also arisen from these increased commercial, cultural and civilian exchanges.

Koo said that although the two sides differ on their political stances, such differences should not hinder bilateral dialogue. In his view, he said, the existence of political disputes signifies the necessity of bilateral dialogue to forge mutual trust and seek common ground to serve as foundations for resolving practical issues and disputes.

"I hope both sides can put aside their political disputes and show goodwill and generosity, just as they did in 1992, so that cross-strait dialogue can resume for the sake of the welfare of the people on both sides of the strait, " Koo said, referring to the so-called "1992 consensus" that paved the way for the 1993 Koo-Wang meeting -- the first high-level cross-strait talks in decades.

Beijing has unilaterally closed regular SEF-ARATS dialogue since July 1999, when then-President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait ties as "a special state-to-state relationship, " which Beijing saw as a step to promote formal Taiwan independence.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies set up to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES YOUNG PEOPLE TO PARTICIPATE MORE IN PUBLIC AFFAIRS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged young people Thursday to participate more in public affairs rather than politics.

In a meeting with some 200 young people at the Presidential Office, Chen said that while Taiwan becomes more democratic and its prosperous Internet culture keeps attracting people's attention, young people's interest in politics is decreasing.

However, he said, their participation in public affairs should be increased, and he claimed that this is partly why the government has been promoting alternative service abroad for the last few years.

Chen also urged young men and women to serve as voluntary workers for non-government organizations working abroad and said he will instruct the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cabinet-level National Youth Commission to promote this cause.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOFT LANDING FOR MAINLAND CHINA ECONOMY GOOD FOR TAIWAN: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A soft landing for the mainland Chinese economy would be beneficial for the rest of the world, including Taiwan, which relies heavily on mainland China for its exports, a government official said Thursday.

Ho Mei-yueh, vice chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said that it would be good for the entire world if the mainland adequately handles its overheating economy. Taiwan's trade dependence on the mainland market has surged to more than 30 percent and it has replaced the United States as the country's leading export market.

Should the mainland authorities succeed in cooling off an investment boom that is creating price hikes and straining a fragile financial system already troubled by bad debts, it is expected to have a positive impact on the international economy in the long term, despite short-term negative effects, Ho said.

Under such circumstances, she urged the public not to overreact to temporary falls in the domestic stock market. As long as the mainland has a soft landing, the present woes will soon be over, she predicted.

The weighted index, the domestic bourse's key barometer, plunged by 172.54 points to close at 6,402.21 points earlier in the day following reports that the mainland is to make moves to curb its overheating economy and that shares on Wall Street dropped noticeably the previous night.

Touching on widespread speculation that the renminbi -- the mainland currency -- will appreciate in the near future, a financial management consultant called on mainland-based Taiwan businesses to pay heed to the mainland's economic and monetary policy adjustments and take swift precautions.

In addition to holding assets in strong currencies, Taiwan companies with operations on the mainland still need to draw up long-term market deployment strategies in response to a highly volatile business environment on the mainland, the consultant suggested.

Meanwhile, an official of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs claimed that mainland China's planned economic cooling will only have a limited impact on the Taiwan's economy on the ground that hi-tech parts and components form the bulk of Taiwan's exports bound for the mainland, while the mainland will focus on traditional businesses such as steel, cement and real estate companies to help stem its economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PLANNER URGES REVISION OF FREE TRADE HARBOR ZONE REGULATIONS

TEXT.P: A top economic planner on Thursday urged the speedy revision of the regulations governing the management of the planned free trade harbor zone, saying that it will help upgrade its competitive edge.

Ho Mei-yueh, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, made the remarks after giving a speech on Taiwan's planned free trade harbor zone over a luncheon hosted by the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei and the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei.

Ho said that not only Taiwan, but Hong Kong, Singapore and mainland China are also working toward the goal of becoming the logistic center of the Asian-Pacific region by setting up free trade harbor zones to attract manufacturers with various tax incentives.

But compared with free trade harbor zones in other countries, Taiwan's would allow goods to come in for processing and retransport, which will be attractive to foreign manufacturers because it would save a lot of transportation costs and add value to the goods.

Ho said that after Taiwan proposed its creative ideas in setting up the free trade harbor zone, mainland China has responded speedily by saying that it will follow the same model in its future free trade harbor zones, posing a potential threat to Taiwan.
"If Taiwan cannot set up a free trade harbor zone soon, it will lose its competitive edge," Ho said.

Ho noted that the current regulations governing the establishment of a free trade harbor zone demand that the zone hire out of its total workforce 5 percent aboriginal workers, which she said was a defect.

She expressed the hope that the legislature can revise related regulations before the end of this session in May, so that after the regulations provide the legal basis, the Keelung Free Trade Harbor can open in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CALLS FOR SOLUTION TO MARCH 19 SHOOTING BEFORE MAY 20

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged police and prosecution authorities Thursday to resolve the case of the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu before May 20.

It marked the first time that the DPP legislative caucus has formally set a timeframe for law enforcement authorities to solve the mysterious shooting on the eve of the March 20 presidential election.
DPP legislative whip Tsai Huang-lang said the shooting, which slightly wounded Chen and Lu, has overshadowed the joy of the Chen-Lu ticket's re-election victory.

"We earnestly hope that the shooting can be resolved before May 20 when Chen and Lu will be sworn-in for a second four-year term," Tsai said, adding that if this goal can be reached, it will be very meaningful for Chen and the DPP.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) has declined to concede defeat in the March 20 election on the ground that the election-eve shooting unfairly swayed sympathy votes in Chen's favor. Chen won the election by a slim margin of 29,518 votes out of 13 million ballots cast.

In addition to organizing massive and sometimes violent street protests in the wake of the election, the alliance's presidential candidate, KMT Chairman Lien Chan, has filed two lawsuits to demand a vote recount and even nullification of the entire election so that a new one can be held. The Taiwan High Court is scheduled to begin the recount May 10.

The alliance is also pushing for the establishment of an independent committee to investigate the shooting even though law enforcement authorities have set up a special task force to probe the case, with State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa as its convener.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR ASKS FOR HELP TO OPEN DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT TRANSPORT LINKS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou suggested Thursday that Jodi Shelton, chief executive officer of Fabless Semiconductor Association (FSA) , urge the ROC government to accelerate the opening of cross-Taiwan Strait direct transport links.

The FSA set up its Asia-Pacific headquarters at Taipei's Nankang Software Development Park in last October. FSA's members represent fabless firms, integrated device manufacturers, foundry providers, electronic design automation companies, and investment bankers.
Ma told Shelton that Taipei has been working hard on creating a favorable investment environment at its Nankang Software Development Park and Neihu Science-based Industrial Park.

However, Taiwan entrepreneurs have encountered a major investment barrier -- a vague relationship between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and the government's restriction on local enterprises' investments in mainland China.
The mayor said that he had suggested to the government many times to open direct cross-strait transport links, with Taipei Sungshan Airport as its hub to keep Taiwan enterprises competitive.
However, his suggestion was not accepted by the central government, Ma said, adding that Shelton could take the matter to the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY HALF OF BUSINESS EXECUTIVES UPBEAT ON POST-ELECTION SITUATION

TEXT.P: Nearly half of Taiwan's business executives are upbeat about Taiwan's post-election situation, while more than half of them believe that ethnicity confrontations are serious and call for adequate government handling of the issue, the results of a poll show.

According to the results of a survey carried out by an executive research Web site under the commission of opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker Wang Yu-ting, 47 percent of business executives polled have confidence in Taiwan's political situation after the March 20 presidential election, ahead of 37 percent who expressed pessimism.

At the same time, 44 percent are optimistic about Taiwan's economic outlook, citing reasons such as an influx of foreign capital and a rebounding world economy, while 28 percent said that they feel upset because of the lack of direct three links across the Taiwan Strait, an inefficient government and ethnic rifts, according to the poll.

Ethnic harmony, the opening of full trade, transport and postal links between Taiwan and mainland China and government reforms are the top three tasks that the respondents to the survey think that the government should first grapple with after the election, the poll finds.

Some 34 percent of the business executives surveyed regard Taiwan's ethnic confrontation as "serious, " slightly ahead of 31 percent who think is "very serious." Only 21 percent and 10 percent believe that the situation is "OK, " and "not seriously at all, " respectively.

By and large, 34 percent of them see Taiwan society as lacking mutual trust as a result of the rift over different political stances, while 37 percent admit that they are considering moving out of Taiwan. The United States, Europe, and Australia and New Zealand are their top three options, while Shanghai, Shenzhen and Hangzhou are listed as the leading destinations in mainland China.
Some 41 percent said that they have no plans to settle in other countries, while 21 percent said that they will take a wait-and-see attitude for the time being, the survey discovers.
The poll of 1,000 ranking business officials was conducted April 14-22, and received 579 valid questionnaires.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTERS EXCHANGE VIEWS AT APEC MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Panama, April 29 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: ROC Minister of Education Huang Jong-tsun held a dialogue with his Chilean counterpart, Sergio Bitar, Wednesday for educational cooperation on the sidelines of the education minister's meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum being held in Santiago, Chile.

This was the third time that education ministers from APEC member countries have met to discuss cooperative projects in educational development. Except Russia, Papua New Guinea, Philippines and Vietnam, all other APEC member economies sent their representatives to attend the meeting held between April 27-30.

On one of its diverse activities held Wednesday - an exhibition of educational technology products and solutions, Taiwan's delegation demonstrated the results of a cyber-academic project it concluded with the United States, which drew much attention from the visitors, including the Chilean education minister.

Later in the day, Huang and Bitar held a conversation for educational cooperation, in which both sides agreed to strengthen cooperation in language teaching, earthquake, biochemical, and basic science research.

Meanwhile, Bitar also expressed gratitude to Taiwan for its assistance in helping Chile set up an information technology school. For his part, Huang suggested that Chile send a delegation to attend an APEC youth camp to be held in Taiwan in August.

The official education ministers' meeting will be held April 29-30 with a main theme of "skills for the coming challenges." The participants will focus on four key topics: learning each other's languages; English and other languages; stimulating learning in math and sciences; developing information technology to support teaching and learning communities; and centralizing and decentralizing education systems.
After concluding the meeting on April 30, the delegates will release a joint statement to express their new visions on educational and cultural development in the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW FOREIGN AFFAIRS MINISTER OUTLINES DIPLOMATIC PROGRAM

TEXT.P: New Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Thursday that he will promote diplomatic works based on the principles of pragmatism and flexibility, hoping to reflect Taiwan's rising national identity in an international context.
Chen made the remarks when he reported for the first time to the Foreign Affairs Committee at the Legislative Yuan since he took over the post 13 days ago.

Several legislators have questioned the pro-independence stance of the new foreign minister, saying that his appointment has sent a message to the international community, while some others hope that the ministry will not be excluded from the decision-making process, and that it can play a responsible role in passing the messages of the international community for domestic reference.

Chen, in reporting his direction, said the short-term goal will be to push for entrance into the World Health Organization, and the invitation of foreign leaders and dignitaries to the May 20 inauguration ceremony of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.

On long-term diplomatic works, Chen said that he will insist on maintaining national integrity and the right to join international organizations, insist on cross-strait stability and strengthen cooperation with the United States and Japan, and insist on international cooperation and fulfilling international responsibilities, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER VOWS TO SAFEGUARD TIES WITH 26 DIPLOMATIC ALLIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will strive to safeguard the Republic of China's relations with its 26 diplomatic allies as diplomatic ties are an important symbol of a sovereign state, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Thursday.

Chen made the remarks while delivering a report on the nation's diplomatic work at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs Committee. It marked the first time that Chen has spoken at the legislature since he assumed his current post 13 days ago.

Noting that diplomatic work involves delicate and complicated operations, Chen said he doesn't have a definite timeframe for his work. Nevertheless, he said, pragmatism, flexibility and innovation will be his top working guidelines.

As the so-called "one China" policy prevalent in the international community has substantially diminished Taiwan's international presence, Chen said the foreign ministry must pool all available wisdom and resources to cement relations with the ROC's diplomatic allies while seeking to make friends with as many other countries as possible.

In addition to fulfilling its duty as a trustworthy friend in the world community, Chen said Taiwan must also use innovative thinking to get through the bottlenecks created by Beijing's diplomatic embargo to expand its diplomatic frontiers.

Touching on the ministry's work agenda, Chen said that in the short term, the most important is to promote Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) . Besides seeking the support of the ROC's diplomatic tallies, Chen said his ministry has also stepped up lobbying other major countries, including the United States, Japan and European countries, to help with Taiwan's WHO bid.

During the meeting, some lawmakers asked Chen about his view on recent statements made by David Keegan, deputy director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , that the United States is against changing the status quo in the Taiwan Strait and that Taiwan should heed mainland China's threats.

Addressing a foreign ministry-sponsored seminar earlier this week on the 25th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act and the prospects of U.S.-Taiwan relations, Keegan said that while President Chen Shui-bian's plan for writing a new constitution for Taiwan is not yet clear, the United States will speak bluntly of its opposition to unilateral changes to the status quo.
Tan Sun Chen said Keegan's speech was largely a reiteration of U.S. Assistant Secretary of State James Kelly's testimony to the House International Relations Committee last Wednesday.

In his view, Tan Sun Chen said, Keegan's remarks manifest U.S. concerns about the Taiwan Strait situation. "Keegan's statements can serve as a reminder to us and let our people gain a better understanding of the current state of Taiwan-U.S. relations, " he noted.

Stressing that U.S. concerns about Taiwan's new constitution plan largely results from its lack of understanding of the details, Tan Sun Chen said the foreign ministry has compiled all the president's relevant statements and sent them to the ROC's overseas offices.

"Our diplomatic staff have been directed to expound on our new constitution plan to authorities of their resident countries in terms of the president's remarks, " Tan Sun Chen told lawmakers, adding that the foreign ministry will join forces with the Government Information Office in preparing a new constitution position paper to facilitate international publicity on the ROC government's stance on this critical topic.

The minister also confirmed that President Chen intends to appoint Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman to serve as the ROC's new representative to the United States. Incumbent representative, Chen Chien-jen, has tendered his resignation.

Asked whether reports about the possibility that a bomb concealed in a remote-controlled toy airplane operated by a terrorist might explode over President Chen and the crowd on the day of his inauguration for a second four-year term on May 20 will affect foreign dignitaries' attendance at the inauguration ceremony, Tan Sun Chen said the foreign ministry has so far not received information that any foreign guest would cancel their trip to Taiwan to attend the ceremony because of misgivings about terror threats.

Chen said the foreign ministry will gear up preparations to ensure that foreign dignitaries receive hospitable treatment and attentive security protection during their visits to attend the presidential inauguration.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLU VACCINATION PROGRAM BEARS FRUIT: DOH

TEXT.P: The outbreaks of influenza this year have been 80 percent less serious than those of the previous two years, showing the vaccination program implemented late last year has borne fruit, a Department of Health (DOTH) official said Thursday.

Su Ih-jen, director of the DOH's Center for Disease Control, said it is estimated the vaccination program will save NT$20 billion (US$606.06 million) in health insurance costs over the course of this year, which he said is well worth the NT$126 million spent on the program.

According to an assessment report Su delivered at the Legislative Yuan's Health, Environment and Social Welfare Committee meeting, as of March 12 of this year, the DOH has targeted medical institution staff, disease prevention workers, citizens over the age of 65, and residents of old age homes with the vaccination program.

The report showed that 271,521 of medical staff and disease prevention workers, or 92.1 percent of the total of 294,864 in Taiwan, have received flu shots. Meanwhile, 1.42 million of Taiwan's senior citizens, or 69 percent of the total, and 72,996 of the 80,101 old age home residents have received shots. In addition, nearly 25,000 of those directly or indirectly employed in the poultry industry have been vaccinated.
Su gave the influenza vaccination program report at the committee meeting to highlight its effectiveness in order to secure the budget for the program for the next fiscal year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 29, or the 11th day of the third month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1429: French military leader and heroine Joan of Arc enters Orleans, France, and defeats English forces. She was later tried for heresy and witchcraft and was burned at the stake in Rouen.
1661: Cheng Cheng-kung, also known as Koxinga, a national hero and one of the Ming loyalists and resistance fighters against foreign invasion, claims Taiwan from the Dutch and chooses Anping (present-day Tainan) as his capital, in the hope of returning to mainland China one day to restore the Ming dynasty.
1667: John Arbuthnot, Scottish physician and writer, is born. He was noted for his satirical anti-Whig pamphlets published in 1712 as "Law Is a Bottomless Pit" and later retitled "The History of John Bull."
1769: Arthur Wellesley, Duke of Wellington, English soldier and later the prime minister known as the Iron Duke, is born. He defeated Napoleon at Waterloo.
1818: Alexander II, the czar of Russia who emancipated the serfs in 1861, is born. He was assassinated in 1881 after severe repression of political opposition.
1863: William Randolph Hearst, American newspaper and magazine publisher, is born. Beginning with the San Francisco Examiner in 1887, he built the world's largest publishing empire, comprised of 28 major newspapers.
1901: Hirohito, the Japanese emperor who advocated the country's unconditional surrender that ended World War II, is born. He renounced his divine status in 1946.
1903: After Russia refuses to leave Manchuria when the troops of other foreign powers withdraw from Chinese territory, and prior to the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War, Chinese students studying in Japan meet in Tokyo and set up a "Resist Russia" volunteer corps.
1937: American chemist Wallace Hume Carothers commits suicide just two months after he patented nylon.
1942: Japanese troops capture the Burmese town of Lashio, cutting off the Burma Road between China and India.
1945: U.S. forces in Germany liberate 32,000 victims of the Nazi death camp at Dachau, just northwest of Munich.
1946: Former Japanese leaders are indicted in Tokyo as war criminals.
1948: Li Tsung-jen is elected vice president of the Republic of China in the republic's fourth ballot.
1957: The first nuclear reactor goes into operation in the United States.
1969: Hsu Peh-yuen, governor of the Central Bank of China, is released from office and succeeded by Yu Kuo-hwa, the incumbent minister of finance.
1975: The last U.S. troops are evacuated from Saigon as thousands of foreigners and South Vietnamese are ferried out by helicopter from the roof of the American embassy.
1976: Edward Y. Kuan, ROC vice minister of foreign affairs, is named by the Executive Yuan as first ambassador to South Africa.
1976: The Sino-U.S. Seminar on Food Science and Nutrition opens in Taipei with 24 food scientists attending.
1980: Alfred Hitchcock, the British-born film director and the silver screen's master of suspense, dies in Los Angeles at the age of 80.
1985: The space shuttle Challenger is launched, and Dr. Wang Kan-chuen becomes the first Chinese American astronaut in space.
1992: Bolivian Vice President Luis Ossio Sanjines officiates at the inauguration of the Bolivian Commercial and Financial Representative Office in Taipei.
1993: Representatives of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, sign three agreements and a joint accord at a historic meeting in Singapore; the agreements and accord went into effect on May 29.
1996: On the third anniversary of the Koo-Wang cross-strait talks, SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu appeals to mainland China not to postpone the second round of talks so that both sides can resume their pursuit of reunification.
1998: North Korea publishes an open letter by its leader Kim Jong-Il calling for unification with South Korea.
2000: Premier-designate Tang Fei checks out of Taipei Veterans General Hospital after fully recovering from surgery removing a benign thymoma on April 16.
2001: The Ministry of National Defense says that in accordance with relevant government laws, military generals on active service will not be allowed to travel to mainland China either for meetings or visits.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A workman who wants to perfect his work first sharpens his tools. When you are living in a country, you should serve those nobles and ministers in that country who are men of moral worth, and you should cultivate the friendship of the gentlemen of that country who are men of moral worth."

DOC.HEADLINE: TIES WITH CHINA TO BE TOUGH IN NEXT COUPLE OF YEARS: DPP OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The country's ties with mainland China will be "relatively tough" in the next couple of years, and the public should not raise their expectation too high about an improvement in this field, an official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Friday.

Chen Chung-hsin, director of the Department for Chinese Affairs under the DPP, said Beijing did not anticipate that President Chen Shui-bian would win a second term, nor did they expect that the DPP would rule the island for a considerable period of time.
Therefore, Beijing is still waiting for Chen's victory to sink in before responding to the new situation in Taiwan, Chen said.

When President Chen won the presidency in 2000 with 39 percent of the votes, Chen Chung-hsin said Beijing didn't believe the new president would be able to secure a second term and were astounded that he was able to win in 2004 with a majority.

Beijing is in no hurry to respond to President Chen's victory, probably because the referendum initiated by the president failed to be validated, and his election victory was questioned by the opposition, Chen Chung-hsin said.

Given the fact that Beijing frowned on Taipei's proposal for a referendum on the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant, Chen Chung-hsin said bilateral ties would be tough before 2006, the year President Chen vowed to put a new constitution for the island to a referendum.
Therefore, he played down the possibility that ties between Taipei and Beijing could improve significantly in the next two years.

Beijing has tried to disarm Western powers by portraying itself as a peace-maintaining force in the region, but it never denounces the use of force against Taiwan; therefore, the United States has warned that neither Taiwan nor the mainland should alter the status quo unilaterally.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATURALIZED MAINLANDERS COULD FACE FURTHER LIMITS IN CIVIL SERVICE

TEXT.P: Mainlanders naturalized in Taiwan should be restricted from taking part in civil service examinations for a certain period as stipulated by related laws, according to a proposal presented Friday by a commission under the Examination Yuan.

Officials of the Civil Service Protection and Training Commission said after a meeting for the revision of related laws that according to the existing Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, mainlanders who are naturalized in Taiwan can serve as teaching personnel in universities, researchers with academic institutions and professionals of social and educational organizations according to related laws without being subject to the limitation of 10 years of naturalization.

However, the same bill stipulates that mainlanders who have not been naturalized in Taiwan for 10 years cannot run for public office, cannot serve as officials of government agencies, state-run enterprises and political parties unless otherwise exceptional stipulations by law are present.

It also stipulates that mainlanders who have not been naturalized for more than 20 years cannot serve as agents of intelligence institutions, military men and civilian employees and teachers of institutions under the Ministry of National Defense.
The commission suggested that the Mainland Affairs Council under the Executive Yuan revise related regulations stipulated in the statute to make clear the situation.
The Examination Yuan is responsible for Taiwan's civil service system.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH MINISTER AND LABOR AFFAIRS CHIEF TO BE RETAINED IN CABINET

TEXT.P: Minister of Health Chen Chien-jen and Chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chen Chu will be retained in the new Cabinet, while Huang Shih-cheng, chairman of the Central Election Commission, will leave his post after May 20 when President Chen Shui-bian is inaugurated for a second term.
Chen Chien-jen confirmed reports Friday that he had been asked to remain in the Cabinet by Premier Yu Shyi-kun.

Chen Chien-jen said he preferred to return to his medical research work, but Yu asked him Thursday to remain in the Cabinet, noting that the recurrence of severe acute respiratory syndrome looms large, and the reform of the national health insurance program has not yet begun; all these need Chen's attention.

Meanwhile, the premier said Friday at a ceremony marking the May 1 Labor Day that Chen Chu, the chairwoman of the Council of Labor Affairs, will remain at her job in the Cabinet, noting that he was sorry to have to retain Chen Chu at the post because she deserves a promotion in light of the good work she has done in the CLA over the last four years.
Chen Chu said later that she was glad to be able to continue serving the laborers of the country.
Central Election Commission Chairman Huang Shih-cheng has offered to quit but was asked by the premier to serve out his term until May 20.

Although Huang agreed to remain on his job for another month and a half, he said Friday that he still thinks the sooner he steps down the better, saying, "I can't endure the current political environment." He didn't elaborate.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12 CHECKPOINTS SET UP FOR MAY 20 PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION: MAYOR MA

TEXT.P: Taipei police will set up a total of 12 checkpoints in the restricted area surrounding the Presidential Office to maintain order during the May 20 presidential inauguration, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Friday.

The Taipei Municipal Police Department will send officers to help maintain order with the National Police Administration at the 12 entry/exit points, through which a large number of people invited to the ceremony will be allowed to pass, Ma said.
However, Ma added that organizers will be in full charge of security checks of personal items carried by the attendees, such as invitation cards, cellphones and umbrellas.

Commenting on the speculation that gangsters will use the occasion to create chaos during the ceremony, Ma said that the municipal police department has not received any tips leading them to believe that is going to happen, but pointed out that he has ordered the Taipei police to be fully prepared to tackle any eventuality.

The number of invited guests to President Chen Shui-bian's inauguration for his second term will be cut to 200,000 from the previously planned 500,000, a Taipei City Government official said on the same day.

The decision was made during a third meeting called by a preparatory committee responsible for the presidential inauguration, said Liu Bao-guey, deputy secretary-general at the Taipei City Government's secretariat, who took part in the meeting on behalf of the municipal authorities.
According to Liu, organizers will ask participants to allow their temperatures to be taken, while those found with a fever above 38 degrees Celsius will not be permitted to take part in the ceremony.
Traffic control will be imposed from 1: 00 p. m. to 4: 00 p m. on May 19 and from 8:00 a. m. to 1: 00 p. m. on May 20 in adjacent areas to the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAUNCH OF ROCSAT-2 POSTPONED TILL LATE MAY
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, April 28 (CNA) (By Laurence Chu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The launch of the Taiwan satellite ROCSAT-2 from the Vandenberg air force base in California has been postponed until late May, an official of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Los Angeles said Wednesday.
The decision was made in order to secure a successful launch out of concern over weather and personnel conditions, the official said.

ROCSAT-2 was slated to lift off April 10 (Taipei time) , local weather conditions permitting. The satellite's launch has been delayed several times since it was transported from Taiwan to the United States in early December last year.

The launch of the satellite, a cooperative venture between the Republic of China's National Space Program Office and the Natural Disaster Study Center under National Chengkung University, is aimed at capturing high-resolution real-time images for application in the prevention of natural catastrophes and environmental hazards.

ROCSAT-2 is designed for practical application purposes as part of the ROC government's 15-year space technology development plan implemented in 1991, which focuses on three satellites with different missions.
ROCSAT-1 was launched in 1999 and ROCSAT-3 is scheduled to lift off in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN RESIDENT CONFIRMED NOT TO HAVE SARS

TEXT.P: A Kinmen resident suspected of contracting severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) during a recent trip to mainland China was confirmed Friday not to have the atypical pneumonia.

Chen Chien-jen, head of the Cabinet-level Department of Health, made the announcement after a second test by the DOH's Center for Disease Control of the 79-year-old man's throat swab showed a negative result -- an indication that the man was not infected with the potentially deadly virus, which broke out for the first time in the first half of last year in many parts of the world.
A local hospital on the outlying Kinmen Island carried out the first test on Thursday, which showed that the man did not have the disease as had been suspected.

The senior, surnamed Tsai, developed a fever and a partially inflamed lung -- initial and key symptoms for the pneumonia-like SARS -- over the last weekend after returning home from Xiamen on a group tour through the "mini three links" framework.
The suspected case came after Beijing and Anhui province reported SARS cases earlier the same week. Tsai had visited Beijing, Shanghai and Suzhou during his mainland trip.
At the same time, 60 other members of the tour group were all located and none of them has SARS.

Meanwhile, the DOH has heightened the country's SARS response alert level to Level A from the previous Level Zero, while all inbound passengers via the "mini three links" are required to fill out a special quarantine questionnaire starting from Friday.

The "mini three links" refers to direct transport and trade ties maintained between Taiwan-held Kinmen and Matsu islands and the Fujian ports of Xiamen and Fuzhou in view of the lack of such direct services between Taiwan proper and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY COUP WOULD BE OUT OF THE QUESTION: DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: The armed forces are loyal to the country and have high morale, so there is no question of a coup, Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min was quoted as saying Friday.

Legislator Chin Hui-chu, who called on the minister along with several other People First Party (PFP) lawmakers said afterward that Tang said the armed forces have come a long way in remaining neutral in politics since Tang took office; therefore, it is out of the question that the armed forces could stage a coup.

The PFP, which was accused by President Chen Shui-bian of attempting a military coup d'etat along with its political partner the Kuomintang after the March 20 presidential election, has sought to clear the party of the charge with officials' statements that there was no hint of a coup.

Chin said the minister also assured the PFP lawmakers that the number of military personnel ordered to remain in their barracks on March 20 has been sealed to prevent meddling. The Control Yuan and law enforcement authorities may look into the matter to settle the controversy over whether extra troops were kept in their barracks during election day, as the opposition has claimed, to the detriment of the opposition presidential candidate.

As to planned arms purchases from the United States, the minister was quoted as saying that his ministry is negotiating with the Pentagon over the details of the deal; however, the special budget for the purchase will have to be prepared by his successor as Tang is set to retire by May 20 when President Chen is inaugurated for his second term.
Tang has been plagued by eye illness and has not been seen in public since March 20.
