DOC.HEADLINE: TIME NOT RIPE FOR DIRECT LINKS WITH MAINLAND: FORMER PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui said Friday that before local agricultural and fishery industries are competitive, it is not appropriate to talk about direct trade, postal and transportation links with mainland China.

Lee made the remarks when he was speaking at the inauguration of an alliance comprising Taiwan agricultural industry officials and scholars at National Chunghsing University in Taichung, central Taiwan.
Lee, in addressing the inauguration ceremony, spoke of the importance of Taiwan's agricultural industry to Taiwan's economic development.

He said that if one loves Taiwan, one must start with Taiwan's agriculture, saying that without the efforts of Taiwan's agricultural industry, Taiwan's economic development today would not be possible.
He also said that in cross-strait economic exchanges, one's nation is the most important, and one cannot only consider the interests of a few.
"If everyone goes to the mainland, who will care for the farmers, workers or even government employers," Lee asked.

He said that a national leader has to take care of all the people, and not just "take care of individual interests or a few groups, " referring to the repeated appeals from some tycoons for early links with the mainland.

He stressed that until local agriculture is competitive, it will not be appropriate to talk about direct links with the mainland, unless in the situation of "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.S. Weighs Falluja Pullback, Leaving Patrols to Iraq Troops.
United States military commanders here moved to loosen their siege of Falluja on Thursday, proposing to turn over the task of ending a fierce anti-American insurgency to a new force of Iraqi soldiers, led by officers once loyal to Saddam Hussein.
News of the proposal emerged as fresh American airstrikes and skirmishes were erupting late on Thursday inside Falluja. Pentagon officials said that negotiations on a number of possible solutions had been under way to end the three-week siege here, and that the plan was one under discussion.
Wall Street Journal: Google IPO Aims To Change the Rules I.
Google Inc., the Internet-search pioneer, Thursday filed for an initial public offering, proposing to sell an estimated $2.7 billion of shares through an auction method never used for such a large IPO.
The system is designed to put more shares into the hands of individual investors and eliminate the near-certain first-day gains for "hot" IPOs that became a central feature of recent investment scandals. The auction approach threatens to minimize the key role that investment bankers have played in deciding who gets highly coveted IPO shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOURSE PLUNGE TEMPORARY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy remains in good shape and the recent falls in the domestic stock market are only a temporary phenomenon driven mainly by the international market situation, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday.
Yu made the remarks during a creativity awards ceremony sponsored by the China Development Industrial Bank.

Pointing out that the economy has been gently recovering and claiming that now is a good time for young men to set up their own businesses, Yu said that the domestic economic prospects are optimistic and that the present stock market plunge is merely a "temporary" consequence of a volatile global market.

Mainland China's decision to cool off its overheating economy and the rising price of crude oil in the international market were ascribed by Yu as the major reasons behind the recent share price falls on the Taiwan Stock Exchange.

The weighed index, the key barometer of the domestic bourse, plummeted by 284.4 points earlier in the day to finish at 6,117.81. It fell by 172.54 points to close at 6,402.21 at the end of Thursday's trading session. The sharp falls have prompted grave concern from the public.
In view of the mainland's conspicuous plan to stem its overheating economy, government officials have made it clear that the move is expected to have limited impact on Taiwan's economy.

Ho Mei-yueh, vice chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, said Thursday that it would be good for the entire world, including Taiwan, if the mainland can adequately handle its booming economy.
She urged the public not to overreact to temporary falls in the domestic stock market on the grounds that the current woes will soon be over as long as the mainland economy takes a soft landing.

An official of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs claimed that the mainland's curb on its economy -- mainly targeting the traditional steel, cement and real estate businesses -- is not very likely to have a huge impact on the domestic economy because hi-tech parts and components form the bulk of Taiwan's shipments to the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO EASE RESTRICTIONS TOURISTS FROM MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) approved Friday a draft package of amendments to the regulations governing mainland Chinese people making sightseeing trips to Taiwan, with a view to opening the door wider to visitors from the mainland.

Speaking at a regular news conference, MAC Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong said the decision to ease restrictions on sightseeing trips by mainland tourists is part of the government's efforts to boost tourist arrivals. The government has designated 2004 as "visit Taiwan year."

Taiwan allows three categories of mainland citizens to make sightseeing trips to the island -- those who are undertaking advanced study abroad; those who have permanent residency in a foreign country; and those who have resided in Hong Kong or Macau for at least four years and have obtained work permits there. Their spouses and next of kin are also allowed entry.

At the moment, these mainland visitors must abide by the "group in, group out" principle, which permits them only to travel as part of a tour group, and they are banned from changing their travel itineraries.

Under the revised rules, the "group in, group out" principle will be scrapped and mainland visitors will be allowed to change their travel itineraries, so long as it is done through their local travel agents, who must report changes to the relevant government authorities.

With a view to cutting red tape and standardizing visa processing operations, Chen said, the Travel Agents Association of Taiwan will serve as the centralized service counter in the future to facilitate all application procedures.
The revised rules will take effect after the Cabinet approves the measures in the coming week, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTHERS MOST CONCERNED ABOUT ILLNESS, LACK OF FITNESS: POLL

TEXT.P: More than 50 percent of mothers who responded to a recent survey are worried about illness and lack of fitness, according to survey results released by the Department of Health (DOH) Friday.
The DOH unveiled the report at a press conference on "how to cherish mother" as part of activities in the run-up to May 9 Mother's Day.

The report shows that the respondents are most concerned about problems such as illness (55.7 percent) , deteriorating physical fitness (53.1 percent), declining memory (50.9 percent), weight-gain (44.1 percent), changed appearance (23.3 percent) and lowered libido (12.6 percent).
However, 26.7 percent of the respondents also said that they are not worried about any of these things.
Asked about their satisfaction with their weight, 50.7 percent said they are satisfied, compared with 40.5 percent who said they are not satisfied, and 8.8 percent who have no opinion.
On further analysis of the 40.5 percent of respondents who are not satisfied with their weight, only 43.3 percent are truly overweight.

On whether their family members are concerned about their health, 28.2 percent said their families are often concerned about them, while 36.6 percent said that their families only care about them occasionally.
The DOH conducted the survey between April 22 and 26 via telephone, with effective samples collected from 1,058 mothers. The margin of error was 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Liberals but No Hemp Lovers on May 1.
While countries across Europe celebrate the expansion of the European Union on Saturday, tens of thousands of Communists, liberals, environmentalists and human rights activists will take to Moscow's streets for rallies long associated with the May 1 holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD REFUSES TO COMMENT ON SPECULATION ON NEW POST

TEXT.P: The nation's top mainland China policy planner refused Friday to comment on reports of personnel changes in the new Cabinet.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen has been tipped as the nation's next representative to the United States.

But speaking through Vice MAC Chairman Chen Ming-tong, Tsai said that appointed officials have to resign en masse in line with constitutional practice before the May 20 inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian and that she has "no comment" on other questions.

Although the lineup of the new Cabinet is largely set, the post of representative to the United States is yet to be filled, with reports speculating that the Presidential Office wants Tsai to take over from Chen Chien-jen for the post.

But Tsai, who has won the confidence of President Chen over the years and who has on several occasions been sent to the United States to explain the government's policies, said that she has no intention of serving in the government after May 20.
Tsai, who had been on a private trip to Japan since last weekend, returned to work Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market moved down Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for May fell 379 points to close at 6,020, with 73,743 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June lost 329 points to end at 6,061, with 547 contracts traded, while September futures dropped 345 points to end at 6,050, with 78 contracts finalized.
December futures lost 325 points to end at 6,081, with eight contracts traded, while next March futures fell 380 points to end at 6,051, with 15 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,399 for May, 6,390 for June, 6,395 for September, 6,406 for December and 6,431 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also moved down.
May TE futures fell 18.5 points to close at 247.7, with 12,800 contracts traded, while June TE futures lost 14.05 points to end at 252.95, with 102 contracts transacted.
September TE futures fell 15 points to close at 252, with five contracts traded, while December TE futures dropped 10.05 points to close at 258, with two contracts finalized.
Next March TE futures lost 11.25 points to end at 255, with three contract transactions.
May TF futures lost 43 points to close at 953, with 15,851 contracts changing hands, while June TF futures fell 48 points to end at 952, with 167 contracts traded.
September TF futures dropped 43 points to close at 942, with 10 contracts concluded, while December TF futures lost 55 points to end at 975, with three contracts finalized.
Next March TF futures lost 34 points to end at 963, with five contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended the day lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 284.4 points to close at 6,117.81.
The bourse opened at 6,331.44 and fluctuated between 6,343.03 and 6,023.58 during trading.

A total of 6.35 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$161.46 billion (US$4.84 billion), an increase from the previous day's trading session, which saw 5.34 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$130.31 billion.

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 5.9 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 5.7 percent, construction stocks at 5.4 percent, pulp and paper issues and foodstuff stocks both at 5.3 percent, textile issues at 4.9 percent, electrical shares at 4.3 percent, and bank and insurance shares at 3.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 866 to 62, with 37 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO MAKE GOOD PREPARATIONS FOR MAY 20 INAUGURATION: MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that the city will make the best possible preparations to safeguard the security of the May 20 inauguration ceremony for President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.
Ma made the remarks amid speculation that there may be disturbances on that day because of post-election controversies and gangster involvement.

The mayor said that Taipei city police have yet to receive concrete information in this regard, but will "make the best possible preparations for the worst-case scenario" and will not ignore any reports but welcome any information that can help them deal with the situation.

Ma said he is more concerned about traffic control, which he said could spark quarrels, and he added that the city government has requested that the Presidential Office prepare for an influx of uninvited people trying to enter the square in front of the Presidential Office.
The security of the inauguration ceremony has been a major concern of law enforcement authorities after the opposition-incited post-election sometimes violent protest rallies.

The National Police Administration (NPA) held a meeting Thursday during which it was decided that 12 checkpoints will be set up around the controlled areas for the 500,000-strong rally, to ensure that only those who have invitation cards can enter the square.
Participants in the ceremony will not be allowed to carry umbrellas, cameras, whistles or items deemed to be a potential hazard, NPA officials said.

Also Thursday, a declaration announcing the inauguration of the "Revolution Party" signed by Lai Chu-hsing, a local small businessman, was faxed to the Legislative Yuan in which Lai said that if the truth of the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu does not come to light before May 20, he will make a lifelong association with the president and former President Lee Teng-hui.
Lai, the boss of a small company selling high-tech water products, was described by his staff as being a righteous man but too keen on politics.

Supporters of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party have held several sometimes violent rallies since the March 20 presidential election. Gangsters are said to have mingled with supporters to trigger riots during an April 10 rally.

The supporters are demanding a vote recount and an investigation of the election-eve shooting, which they claim swayed the election in Chen's favor in the bitterly contested election. Chen won by only 29,518 votes against his rival, KMT Lien Chan, out of more than 13 million ballots cast.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN STOWAWAY DETENTION CENTER TO OPEN IN MAY

TEXT.P: A newly developed Kinmen detention center for illegal mainland Chinese immigrants is scheduled to open next month, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Friday.

Under constant pressure from an ever-increasing number of mainlanders illegally sneaking into Taiwan and the mainland authorities' slow pace of accepting the repatriation of their runaway citizens, the government decided last year to increase Taiwan's detention and accommodation capacities for such stowaways.

The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) , which supervises police agencies at all levels, began last year to sponsor the expansion of Taiwan's three existing detention centers while seeking to build new detention centers in offshore areas, Chen said after attending an inter-division meeting.

When the Kinmen detention center becomes operational in May and expansion of the three existing detentions centers -- in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Ilan, eastern Taiwan and on the outlying island of Matsu -- is complete in June, Taiwan is expected to be able to detain and accommodate some 3,700 mainland stowaways, up from the current level of 2,300, Chen noted.
New dormitory rooms are also expected to be built at the Matsu detention center, which are scheduled to be completed in 2010, Chen added.

Meanwhile, Chen said, the MOI will continue to increase its hiring of personnel from the police sector and from among military conscripts to serve as managers and warders at the detention centers to meet the growing demand.

As the number of female stowaways has increased by leaps and bounds, Chen said, the National Police Administration will continue to increase its recruitment of female officers to work exclusively at the centers.
To beef up the detention center manpower, the MOI has also hired 179 unemployed citizens to work as aides at the centers. Their performance has generally been satisfactory, Chen said.
Chen said the number of mainland stowaways apprehended has always outpaced the number of those being repatriated back to the mainland.

Noting that the illegal immigrants are not only causing an increasing financial burden for the government but have also caused problems with social order and the distribution of resources, Chen once again called for the mainland authorities to face the issue squarely and resume cross-strait dialogue to seek an early solution to the problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD UNCOVERS HUMAN SMUGGLING RING IN TAOYUAN

TEXT.P: Coast guard officers said Friday that they have uncovered a criminal ring in Taoyuan specializing in smuggling young mainland Chinese women into Taiwan to engage in prostitution.
Three ring members, including the mastermind, identified as Yang-Chen Mei-yu, were arrested in the early morning raid at a private house in Taoyuan City, coast guard officers said.

Also seized were seven young mainland women who were smuggled into Taiwan by Yang-Chen's ring earlier this year to work as prostitutes in the Taipei-Taoyuan area. The illegal mainland immigrants told coast guard officers they had each spent NT$200,000 to sneak into Taiwan to work in the sex trade. They have been sent to an illegal mainland immigrant detention center in Hsinchu to await repatriation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, JAPAN INCREASE AIR TIES

TEXT.P: Diplomatic authorities from Taiwan and Japan signed a pact Friday to increase the number of Japanese cities included in Taiwan-Japan bilateral weekly flight services, according to a report by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

Under the new agreement -- endorsed by Hsu Shui-teh, chairman of the Association of East Asian Relations (AEAR) and Reijiro Hattori, chairman of the Japan Interchange Association (JIA) -- Sendai, a city in northeastern Japan popular with tourists, and Hiroshima in the Kansai area have been added to the existing list of Japanese cities operating weekly flights to and from Taiwan, MOFA officials said.

With the inclusion of Sendai and Hiroshima, the number of Japanese cities operating regular weekly flights to and from Taiwan has increased to seven from the previous five -- Tokyo, Kyoto, Nagoya, Fukuoka and Sapporo.
Sendai and Hiroshima had been operating only irregular charter flights to and from Taiwan prior to the renewal of the bilateral agreement.

AEAR and JIA are quasi-official agencies authorized by the Taiwanese and Japanese governments, respectively, to handle exchanges in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.
The renewed air pact is a shot in the arm for Taiwan in its efforts to double the number of foreign tourists arriving in Taiwan by 2008, MOFA officials said.

The pact, which took immediate effect, will not only help attract more Japanese tourists to Taiwan, but will also help boost economic and cultural exchanges between the two countries, the officials added.

According to officials from the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, Japan is Taiwan's largest source of tourists from overseas, with about one-third of the 2-3 million tourists visiting Taiwan each year being Japanese.
Under the renewed pact, CAA officials said, Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL) and EVA Airways will both increase regular weekly flights to and from Japan.

CAL is planning to add three weekly flights to and from Hiroshima from June, while EVA will operate two weekly flights to and from Sendai, starting at the end of August or early September, CAA officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CONFIDENT JOBLESS RATE CAN BE CUT TO 4% NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that he is confident the unemployment rate can be cut to 4 percent next year.
The president made the remarks when he received the winners of the national model worker awards, along with their families.

Chen noted that recent statistics show that the jobless rate was 4.45 percent in March, the lowest figure in nearly three years. The figure is lower than the 7.2 percent for Hong Kong, 5.7 percent for the United States and 5 percent for Japan, and compatible to the 4.5 percent for Singapore.

Chen said that during his presidential campaign, he pledged six things to the country's workers -- to provide more job opportunities to cut the unemployment rate to under 4 percent; to protect grassroots workers and ban the import of cheap mainland Chinese laborers; to provide each worker with a NT$20,000 (US$602) subsidy to upgrade their skill; to establish a system to provide lifelong protection for retired laborers; to cut the casualty rate resulting from vocational disasters; and to include three vital workers' rights into the new constitution.

"The six assurances, which were my platform during my presidential campaign, will become government policies after my election. In the near future, they will be the result of the performance of the administrative team," the president said.
He expressed confidence that the jobless rate this year will drop to 4.5 percent and that it will have a chance to be further cut to 4 percent next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY MUM ON REPORT ABOUT INTELLIGENCE WAR WITH BEIJING IN UKRAINE

TEXT.P: The Military Intelligence Bureau (MIB) of the Ministry of National Defense declined to make any comment Friday on a media report that intelligence agents from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have engaged in a fierce intelligence war in Ukraine.

The report out of Hong Kong said Taiwan has sent military intelligence agents to Ukraine to gather intelligence about the highly advanced Su-27SK jet fighter as mainland China has purchased scores of this type of warplane from Russia.

Responding to press inquiries about the MIB's view on the report, a spokesman for the bureau said it is the military's established practice to refrain from commenting on any intelligence-related report or speculation.

According to the Hong Kong media report, Taiwan's air force has sent pilots to test-fly the Su-27SK jet fighter. The Air Force General Headquarters said it has no knowledge of the reported event and would not make any comment.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC RETESTING KINMEN SENIOR FOR SARS

TEXT.P: A second throat-swab taken from a Kinmen senior citizen who had recently developed a fever upon returning from a trip to Beijing has been sent to Taipei for another round of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) testing.

Su Ih-jen, director-general of the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health (DOH) , said Friday that the 79-year-old Kinmen resident, surnamed Tsai, is now in good shape, adding that his fever is gone.

Although the first throat-swab tested negative for the SARS virus, Su said a second and third throat-swab test is necessary to confirm the Kinmen man has not been infected with SARS. The results of the second test are expected to come out Friday afternoon, he added.

Chang Shang-chun, director of the Infection Prevention Medical Network, Northern Taiwan Command Headquarters, pointed out that throat-swab tests are not 100-percent accurate and that the first test does not guarantee the Kinmen senior does not have SARS. Chang said that the man has displayed slight symptoms of pneumonia and partial filling of the lungs with fluid -- a symptom of SARS.

The Kinmen resident, who traveled to Beijing with a 59-member tour group several days ago, developed a fever -- an index symptom of SARS -- on the day of his return Wednesday. He was immediately quarantined, and Kinmen County Hospital staff rushed his throat-swab to Taipei for testing Thursday.

Officials from the Kinmen County Department of Health said that they have contacted all the other members of the tour group to ask them to conduct self-health management. None of the 58 tourists have developed fever, they added.

This marks the second case in the outlying island of Kinmen of an individual being monitored for possible SARS infection since the outbreaks of the potentially fatal flu-like disease subsided in mainland China last summer.

Kinmen activated a "Level A" SARS alert mechanism Wednesday after a woman getting ready to board a flight to Kinmen was discovered to be running a fever. The woman, who was discovered to be an illegal alien from mainland China, was therefore not allowed to board the flight. She was later found to only be suffering from a cold, Kinmen health authorities said.

The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) upgraded Taiwan's epidemic prevention mobilization level against SARS from "Level Zero" to "Level A" from April 24 after Beijing confirmed two SARS cases a day earlier in mainland China, in addition to two already reported suspected cases and one possible fatality from the disease.

Under the activated "Level A" SARS alert mechanism, all inbound and outbound passengers are required to have their temperatures taken and to fill out SARS questionnaires. All passengers arriving from mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau have to exercise self-health management, including regular hand-washing and temperature-taking, while all government agencies and institutions are advised to conduct temperature-taking.
The DOH has a four-level SARS alert system -- Zero, A, B, and C -- with "Level C" being the highest level of alert.
Taiwan was hit hard by SARS between March and June last year, resulting in 37 deaths and heavy economic losses.

The Japan Times: Arrow shaft not Cook's bone; Museum debunks century-old legend about explorer.
DNA testing has shot down theories that an arrow held by an Australian museum is made out of a bone from British explorer Cap. James Cook's leg.

DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Two die in worksite collapse.
In Singapore thousands of steel rods crashed down on some 40 workers at an Ayer Rajah construction site yesterday, killing two and injuring 29. The men were fixing steel supports for the foundation of a six-storey basement for Fusionpolis, a JTC Corporation high-tech township, when part of the framework collapsed.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Basement at Singapore construction site collapses, 2 workers killed.
Two construction workers were killed and dozens were injured on Thursday after steel girders at a construction site collapsed at the Fusionpolis being built along Ayer Rajah Avenue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 30, or the 12th day of the third month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1770: David Thompson, the Canadian explorer who followed the Columbia River to its mouth in 1881 and mapped much of western Canada, is born in England.
1777: Karl Friedrich Gauss, the German mathematician and astronomer known for his contributions to algebra, differential geometry, probability theory and number theory, is born in Germany.
1789: George Washington is inaugurated as the first president of the United States in a ceremony at Federal Hall in New York.
1803: The United States buys Louisiana Territory and New Orleans from the French.
1893: Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German politician who was Adolf Hitler's foreign minister, is born.
1900: The republic of Hawaii cedes itself to the United States.
1909: Juliana, queen of the Netherlands from 1948, is born. She abdicated this day in 1980 in favor of her daughter Beatrix.
1919: The Paris Peace Conference allows Japan to take over Germany's prewar rights in China's Shantung Province, whereupon China leaves the conference.
1945: Adolf Hitler, the German dictator known as "Der Fuhrer" who reduced his country and much of Europe to ashes, commits suicide with his mistress Eva Braun after bidding farewell to the few aides remaining with him in his Berlin bunker hideaway.
1946: The national government of the Republic of China issues an order moving the national capital back to Nanking from Chungking.
1948: A total of 21 American nations sign the "Charter of Bogota," setting up the Organization of American States (OAS).
1957: Egypt reopens the Suez Canal to traffic.
1967: Muhammad Ali, who first won the world heavyweight boxing crown as Cassius Clay in 1964, is stripped of his title for refusing to be drafted into the U.S. armed forces.
1968: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek approves a set of "Guidelines for the Lives of Citizens" drafted by the National Committee of Chinese Cultural Renaissance Movement.
1973: U.S. President Richard Nixon accepts responsibility for the bugging that took place at the Watergate apartment complex in 1972.
1974: Adm. Maurice F. Weisner, commander in chief of the U.S. Pacific Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1975: The Vietnam War ends with South Vietnam's surrender to the communists after North Vietnamese tanks capture the Presidential Office in Saigon.
1977: Public and private buses begin joint operations in Taipei City.
1989: Finance Minister Shirley Kuo leads an ROC delegation to the 22nd annual Asian Development Bank meeting in Beijing.
1990: Elected ROC officials of all levels are permitted to make private visits to mainland China during recesses. Veterans who were stranded on the mainland after the nationalist government moved to Taiwan in 1949 are allowed to apply for resettlement in Taiwan.
1991: Cyclone hits Bangladesh, killing more than 125,000 people.
1991: ROC President Lee Teng-hui declares the termination of the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion, effective May 1. He abolishes the Temporary Provisions and promulgates the Additional Articles of the Constitution, also effective May 1.
1997: Trains collide at Rongchiawan Station in Yuehyang City, in mainland China's Hunan Province, killing 58 people and injuring hundreds of others.
1998: Secessionist rebels sign a permanent ceasefire with the Papua New Guinea government to end a nine-year rebellion on the South Pacific Island of Bougainville.
2000: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou inaugurates Taiwan's first tap water museum.
2001: The Second Asian Physics Olympiad concludes in Taipei after more than 10 days of competition with Seven gold medals, five silvers and 11 bronzes, as well as 16 honorary citations awarded to the winners.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man takes no thought for the morrow, he will be sorry before the day is out."
